site_title: US tightens rules for visa-free visits after Paris attacks
summary: The US has tightened rules for visa-free visits from friendly countries following the Paris attacks, requiring travelers to declare previous visits to countries deemed "terrorist safe havens" and increasing scrutiny of their registrations. The US will also seek greater cooperation and intelligence sharing with allied countries to intercept "foreign fighters" returning from Syria and Iraq. This move aims to prevent individuals like those involved in the Paris attacks from entering the US via the ESTA visa waiver system.

site_title: Ho Bee buys London office property for £99m
summary: Property developer Ho Bee Land acquired a £99m (S$210m) London office property, Apollo House and Lunar House, comprising 441,797 square feet of office space. The property is currently let to the British Government until June 2023, offering a low average rent of £12.50 per square foot. This acquisition increases Ho Bee's UK investments to £600m, providing recurrent income until 2023 and allowing for development potential planning.

images.alt_text: Property developer Ho Bee Land said on Tuesday morning that it has bought its sixth prime office property in London for £99 million (S$210 million).

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; ETF targeting Chinese markets jump
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.4% to 8,356.63 points, with the electronics subindex gaining 0.6% and memory chipmaker Inotera increasing 4.1%. ETFs targeting Chinese markets rebounded following recent sharp losses. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.679 per US dollar.

site_title: Asia: Shares firm as focus turns to China PMI surveys
summary: Asian shares rose on Tuesday, shrugging off a disappointing Chinese PMI survey, which showed the economy contracting at a three-year low of 49.6 in November. However, a private survey showed factory activity contracting at a slower pace, fueling hopes for stabilisation. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 1.1%, while US stock futures gained 0.5%. The yuan remained stable after the International Monetary Fund admitted it into its SDR basket.

site_title: India exceeds expectations with Q2 growth of 7.4%
summary: India's economy grew 7.4% in the July-September quarter, exceeding expectations and outpacing China, with domestic demand and manufacturing activity driving the growth. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, and a stronger growth rate is a boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of state elections. Analysts predict the economy could reach 8% growth in the next fiscal year with the implementation of a national sales tax.

site_title: Indonesia's annual inflation rate cools to 4.89% in November
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate cooled to 4.89% in November, almost matching a Reuters forecast of 4.88%. This is significantly lower than the 6.25% in October, partly due to last year's oil-price hike. On a monthly basis, consumer prices rose 0.21%. Core inflation, excluding food and administered prices, also decreased to 4.77% in November.

site_title: US dollar rides high as ECB set to boost eurozone stimulus
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro on Monday as the European Central Bank is expected to boost eurozone stimulus this week. The euro fell to a seven-month low against the dollar, trading at US$1.0558 before edging up to US$1.0566. Analysts attribute the dollar's surge to expectations of lower interest rates in the eurozone. The US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is set to testify in Congress on Thursday, and the US jobs report for November will be published on Friday, which could influence the Fed's decision on interest rates in December.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rode high on Monday as the European Central Bank looked set to inject more stimulus into the eurozone this week.

site_title: Sydney home prices drop most in five years as regulation bites
summary: Sydney home prices dropped 1.4% in November, the largest decline in five years, as a regulatory crackdown forces banks to tighten lending and increase mortgage rates. The drop is attributed to tighter mortgage servicing criteria and affordability constraints in the Sydney and Melbourne markets. Economists forecast a decline in prices over the next two years, with Sydney home prices still up 12.8% in the past 12 months. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep its benchmark cash rate at a record low of 2% after the slowdown in the housing market.

site_title: Retail shares weigh on US stocks, Europe awaits ECB
summary: US stocks fell 0.5% on Monday, weighed down by declines in the retail sector, including Wal-Mart, Target, and Amazon. The decline was attributed to concerns over weak holiday sales and the growth of online commerce. In Europe, the DAX index rose 0.8% and the euro weakened against the dollar ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, which is expected to announce additional stimulus.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on a weaker yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on a weaker yen, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.26% and the Topix index up 0.33%, despite a weak Wall Street session and anticipation of key US jobs figures and a European Central Bank meeting.

site_title: Japan pension fund, world's biggest, loses US$64b after stock shift
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest pension fund, lost $64 billion in the July-September quarter due to a global equity market plunge. The 5.6% decline in total value was attributed to a sharp slowdown in China and a devaluation of the yuan, causing Japanese and overseas share prices to plummet. The fund's decision to double its equity holdings from 24% to 50% last year was seen as a risk, and its Japanese equity investments dropped 13% and international stock holdings fell 11% in value.

site_title: Europe the unready
summary: The European project, a decades-long effort to foster unity and prosperity, is facing significant challenges. The financial crisis, refugee crisis, and terrorist attacks have exposed weaknesses in the imperfect union, with each crisis undermining the ability to protect itself. Despite attempts to strengthen institutions and manage interdependence, the European elite's hopes for a United States of Europe seem distant. The lack of political will to address these issues has led to setbacks, including the rise of border controls, and the future of the European project remains uncertain.

site_title: Tokyo office building put up for sale for more than US$1.3b: sources
summary: A Tokyo office building, nicknamed the "Gunkan" or "Warship", is being put up for sale for over $1.8 billion. The Shiba Park Building, acquired in 2013, has over 83,510 square meters available for rent and is expected to attract investors seeking long-term stable returns. The sale process began on December 1, with the first round of bidding set to close on December 11. This sale follows a recent trend of global sovereign wealth funds expanding their presence in Tokyo, seeking stable returns in a city with falling vacancy rates and growing office rents.

site_title: Tokyo: Benchmark index closes above key 20,000 mark
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index, the Nikkei 225, closed above the 20,000 mark for the first time since late August, gaining 1.34% to 20,012.40. The broader Topix index finished up 1.37% at 1,601.95. The move was attributed to upbeat data on investment by Japanese companies, boosting sentiment.

site_title: Samsung replaces mobile-unit chief as Galaxy phones struggle
summary: Samsung Electronics replaced mobile-unit chief Shin Jong Kyun with Koh Dong Jin as the company faces declining sales and increasing competition from Apple and Chinese makers. The move is part of a larger power transition led by Vice Chairman Lee Jae Yong, who aims to revamp the company's mobile business and improve its design and functionality. Samsung's phone shipments are expected to decline for the second straight year, and the company's earnings are forecast to drop 8.2% this year, the lowest since 2011.

site_title: China: Shares end modestly up, weak factory activity curbs gains
summary: China's stocks rose modestly, with the CSI300 index gaining 0.7% and the Shanghai Composite Index 0.4%, despite weak factory activity data and liquidity concerns. The International Monetary Fund's decision to grant the yuan reserve currency status was seen as neutral, and real estate stocks jumped 10% on government support and low valuations. Banking shares weakened, curbing gains in the benchmark index. The gains were limited by concerns over further yuan depreciation to support China's struggling manufacturing sector.

site_title: South Korea Nov exports fare better than expected, surplus at all-time high
summary: South Korea's exports fell 4.7% to $44.43 billion in November, beating expectations, while imports dropped 17.6% to $34.07 billion. The trade surplus reached an all-time high of $10.36 billion. Economists expect exports to improve in 2016, but only to a limited extent, citing stabilization of oil and raw material prices. The government will release more trade details later, with South Korea's monthly trade data potentially influencing global demand.

site_title: Google opens online window on toll of climate change
summary: Google has launched a "Street View" feature on its online map service, allowing users to virtually explore remote locations affected by climate change. The feature highlights the impacts of warming temperatures on wildlife and ecosystems, including polar bears in the Canadian Arctic and communities in the Brazilian Amazon. Nonprofit organizations are using the feature to educate people about climate change and promote conservation efforts.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday ahead of China PMI data
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index opened at 2,862.73 points, up 6.79 points or 0.24% ahead of China manufacturing data and policy meetings. Trading volume was 64.7 million shares worth S$217.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 59, with top stocks including Hongkong Land, DBS, and Singtel. Analysts expect China's manufacturing PMI to show slight growth, while international trade data from Korea and policy meetings in Australia and India are unlikely to result in policy changes.

site_title: Yuan's inclusion in SDR basket may lead to devaluation: India's Rajan
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan stated that the inclusion of the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's SDR basket could lead to its devaluation. Rajan noted that the yuan has already risen following its initial devaluation earlier this year. The IMF's decision to include the yuan in the SDR basket is a key step for China's integration into the global financial market. Rajan emphasized that India does not intend to manipulate the exchange rate for the rupee to achieve macroeconomic objectives.

site_title: Australia's NSW government signs 2-year deal with Scoot
summary: The NSW government in Australia has signed a 2-year partnership deal with low-cost carrier Scoot to boost inbound tourism from Singapore to Sydney and NSW. The agreement includes multiple marketing campaigns. In 2015, NSW received 109,500 visitors from Singapore, with an estimated A$226 million spent in the state, representing an 11% growth in visitor expenditure. The partnership aims to increase tourism from Singapore, following a 19% increase in visitor numbers in 2015.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tight labour market, negative inflation raise median income (Amended)
summary: Singapore's median income increased by 5.4% in 2015, driven by a tight labour market and negative inflation. However, the Ministry of Manpower expects slower job growth for the rest of the decade as the economy continues to restructure. The report also noted a continued rise in income for lower-income earners, with a 26% increase in nominal terms. Meanwhile, employment growth eased in the first half of the year, with job growth faster for professionals and managers.

site_title: China home prices seen rising 2 per cent in 2016 on extra policy support
summary: China's home prices are expected to rise 2.0% in 2016, according to a Reuters poll, as the government is expected to unveil measures to support the struggling sector. This would ease concerns about a broader economic slowdown, which is forecast to be the weakest in 25 years this year. The forecast is attributed to President Xi Jinping's remarks on the risks posed by unsold housing, leading to expected policy measures to stimulate housing spending.

site_title: Online sales on track to break 'Cyber Monday' record
summary: Online sales on track to break 'Cyber Monday' record, reaching $490 million in the first 10 hours, with sales on track for $3 billion, a 14% increase from last year. 53% of online retail traffic came from mobile devices, and 32% of sales were from mobile. Cyber Monday sales, including Thanksgiving and Black Friday, total $8.03 billion, a 17% increase from last year. However, Chinese Singles Day generated more US$14 billion in sales, dwarfing Cyber Monday's record.

images.alt_text: Online sales for the key holiday retail day of "Cyber Monday" were on track for a record, helped by surging smartphone shopping, market trackers said.

site_title: Quick takes update: China yuan's inclusion in IMF's SDR boosts confidence in currency
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has included China's yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, boosting confidence in the currency for international trade and investment. The move is seen as a significant step towards the yuan's emergence as a major reserve currency, with companies and institutions worldwide expected to settle trade in yuan and invest in yuan assets. The inclusion is also expected to accelerate China's capital account opening and signal a significant market opportunity for RMB-denominated assets.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: France, Belgium push intelligence sharing after Paris attacks: source
summary: France and Belgium plan to improve intelligence sharing with other European nations to combat jihadist threats following the Paris attacks, which killed 130 people. French Prime Minister Manuel Valls and Belgian counterpart Charles Michel agreed to launch an initiative to harmonize and systemize information sharing within the Schengen zone. The goal is to better track and monitor individuals deemed radicalized or dangerous, amid heightened security concerns in Europe. A meeting between the two countries could take place in the coming weeks, with the European Commission proposing a pan-EU intelligence agency.

site_title: Standard Chartered, RBS avoid need for more capital in BOE tests
summary: Standard Chartered and Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) avoided needing to raise additional capital in the Bank of England's (BOE) stress test, despite falling short in some areas. Standard Chartered's capital ratio was below the required 4.5% due to recent capital strengthening efforts, while RBS met the minimum capital ratio but failed to meet its individual-capital guidance. The BOE allowed both banks to include management actions to pass the test, and signaled a gradual increase in the countercyclical-capital buffer to 1% as the UK economy recovers.

site_title: Poor countries increasingly targeted by tobacco marketing
summary: The tobacco industry is increasingly targeting poor countries with aggressive marketing, exploiting relaxed restrictions on promoting smoking. A study of 462 communities across 16 countries found that poor countries are exposed to more intense and aggressive marketing, with 81 times more advertisements per study community than in high-income countries. The industry's sales are falling in high-income countries, making it dependent on getting young people hooked in low-income countries. The study calls for stronger enforcement of the 2005 Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, especially in developing countries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ho Bee, Midas, SunVic
summary: Singaporean stocks to watch include Ho Bee Land's £99 million office building purchase, Midas Holdings' acquisition of a Chinese aluminium products maker, and SunVic Chemical's reprimand for breaching listing rules.

site_title: Ringgit snaps three-day drop as ECB expected to boost stimulus
summary: The ringgit currency halted a three-day drop as investors anticipated a possible boost in European Central Bank stimulus, which could attract more fund flows to emerging markets. Malaysia's benchmark share index rose alongside regional stocks ahead of the ECB meeting on Wednesday. The ringgit strengthened 0.3% to 4.2495 a dollar, marking its first gain in a month. Despite being down 18% this year, the currency climbed 0.8% last month, the only Asian gainer.

site_title: SPH in strong financial position to navigate changing media landscape
summary: SPH, a Singapore media conglomerate, is in a strong financial position to navigate the changing media landscape. The company has S$1.2 billion in financial reserves and a gearing ratio of 35%, allowing it to invest in new projects and fund acquisitions. Despite changing media consumption patterns, SPH's core newspaper business remains strong. CEO Alan Chan and Chairman Lee Boon Yang expressed confidence in the company's ability to capitalize on new growth opportunities.

site_title: Hackers hit three Greek banks with ransom demands
summary: Hackers have targeted three Greek banks, blocking internet banking activity for a few hours, but not penetrating their security or accessing confidential client data. The hackers, identified as the Armada Collective, demanded a ransom in bitcoins. The banks refused to pay and alerted authorities, who are investigating the incident. The attack is described as an "easy to handle situation" with no need for bank clients to worry. The hackers also previously staged sustained Distributed Denial of Service attacks on private email services.

site_title: Association of Banks in Singapore issues alert on malware targeting Android phone users
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has issued an alert warning mobile phone users about a malicious malware targeting Android smartphones. The malware, hidden in a WhatsApp software update not initiated by the app maker, has infected Android smartphones over the past few months. The ABS advises users to be cautious and avoid installing the update. This comes as a warning to mobile banking customers in Singapore, highlighting the potential risks of malware attacks on mobile devices.

site_title: Jack Ma's potential takeover of SCMP a double-edged sword
summary: Chinese internet tycoon Jack Ma's potential takeover of Hong Kong's South China Morning Post (SCMP) could bring prosperity, but also erode the paper's independence and press freedoms. The struggling newspaper, founded in 1903, has seen declining profits and sales due to industry-wide advertising revenue losses and the digital age. A buyout by Ma could bring in new capital, but analysts warn it may compromise the paper's editorial autonomy and contribute to the erosion of Hong Kong's press freedoms. The move could have significant implications for the city's media landscape.

site_title: China smog at crippling levels as climate talks open
summary: China is experiencing severe smog, with Beijing's PM2.5 levels reaching 625 micrograms per cubic meter, 25 times the World Health Organisation's recommended maximum. The air quality is so poor that flights were grounded, and visibility was reduced to near zero. The smog is part of a larger climate change issue, with a Chinese government report warning of rising sea levels and temperatures that could rise by up to five degrees Celsius by the end of the century. China is the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases and will be central to the climate talks in Paris, where President Xi Jinping met with US President Barack Obama.

images.alt_text: Choking smog blanketed Beijing and much of northern China Monday as climate change talks opened in Paris and a new Chinese report raised the alarm about rising sea levels.

site_title: Nazarbayev underlines importance of Astana Expo 2017
summary: Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev emphasized the importance of the Astana Expo 2017, stating that only a year and a half remains until the event. Despite economic difficulties, necessary funds have been allocated and construction works are progressing smoothly. Nazarbayev attributed the success to attracting experienced companies and studying the organization of the 2015 Milan Expo. With no unresolved issues, the event is expected to be completed by autumn next year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise as investors look past weak China PMIs; won flat
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.6% on Tuesday, driven by renewed foreign buying despite weak China PMIs. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,023.93 points. Investors looked past the China data, with offshore buyers purchasing 110.6 billion won of shares. The South Korean won remained flat at 1,158.0 to the dollar.

site_title: Asia's factories still struggling as US rate hike looms
summary: Asia's factories experienced a downturn in November, with China's factory activity at a three-year low. The US interest rate hike, expected at the Federal Reserve's Dec. 15-16 meeting, is causing concern among policymakers and investors. Sluggish demand in the West and other emerging markets is forcing manufacturers to throttle back production and cut jobs. Economists predict a further pinch on the region's economy, with high inventories taking time to clear. The expected rate hike may remove uncertainty but will also impact Asia's exports, which are already struggling.

site_title: Oil prices dip ahead of Opec gathering
summary: Oil prices dropped ahead of an Opec meeting, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate finishing at $41.71 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude at $44.61 a barrel. Analysts expect Opec to maintain its policy of keeping production elevated, pressuring high-cost producers out of the market. A potential production cut is unlikely, with a split decision between Saudi Arabia and its allies possible, leading to an ongoing surplus. Despite analysts' expectations, some see an outside chance of a surprise that could lift prices.

site_title: Blank spaces replace New York Times article on flagging Thai economy
summary: The International New York Times had its Thai edition printer remove a piece on the country's flagging economy, citing censorship, and replaced it with blank spaces. This is the second instance in 10 weeks where the paper has faced printer censorship. The article, scheduled for Tuesday, explored the economy's stagnation and succession concerns surrounding 87-year-old King Bhumibol. The printer's decision is likely due to Thailand's strict lese majeste laws, which carry up to 15 years in jail for insulting the monarchy.

site_title: IMF approves China's yuan as elite reserve currency
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved China's yuan as an elite reserve currency, welcoming it into the Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket effective October 1, 2016. This decision recognizes China's growing economic influence and marks a significant milestone in the integration of its economy into the global financial system. The yuan's inclusion is expected to promote further internationalization of the currency and support the growth and stability of China and the global economy, but also raises concerns about transparency and liberalization of the capital account.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund welcomed China's yuan into its elite reserve currency basket on Monday, recognising the ascendance of the Asian power in the global economy.

site_title: China official factory PMI at three-year low
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity contracted for a fourth consecutive month to a three-year low, with the official PMI falling to 49.6 in November from 49.8 in October. This marks the lowest level in three years, amid subdued demand at home and abroad. Despite a series of stimulus measures, the economy's momentum appears to be weakening, with some analysts expecting a bottom in the fourth quarter. China's Premier Li Keqiang remains optimistic, but the country's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers to maintain reasonable growth levels.

site_title: Singapore extends 3% wage offset for hiring older workers till 2017
summary: The Singapore government has extended the 3% wage offset for hiring older workers until 2017, when the new re-employment age of 67 comes into effect. Introduced in the 2015 Budget, the offset encourages employers to hire workers aged 65 and above, earning up to S$4,000. Tripartite partners are discussing the new re-employment age, and employers are encouraged to re-employ older Singaporeans aged 65 and above. The extension aims to show continued support for re-employing older workers.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Taking a reality check
summary: Despite negative eurozone news, investors can benefit from its recovery. Asia is driving and gaining from dollar asset diversification. A low-profile property trust is investing in a data centre. Ant, backed by Jack Ma, plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Amundi expects massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. The S&P 500 reached a record high, potentially marking the end of the trade war's worst effects. Productivity gains are crucial for wealth creation, and de-dollarisation is shifting safe havens. Markets continue to rise, driven by various factors.

site_title: AHPETC again gets worst rating in governance, S&CC arrears management
summary: The Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) has received its worst rating in service and conservancy charges (S&CC) arrears management and corporate governance, marking the fourth consecutive time for S&CC arrears management and the third for corporate governance. The town council, led by the Workers' Party, was banded "red" due to its failure to submit monthly S&CC arrears reports and a technical error in corporate governance. The Ministry of National Development (MND) stated that it has not received most of AHPETC's S&CC arrears reports since May 2013.

site_title: No case for further monetary easing by ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is unlikely to announce further monetary easing, citing a lack of systemic problems in the banking sector and a stable economic situation in the eurozone. Despite concerns about negative inflation and tepid international trade, core inflation remains above 1% year-over-year, and demand for credit is increasing. The cyclical recovery in the eurozone is driven by private consumption and a weak euro exchange rate, with tailwinds supporting steady growth. The ECB may instead focus on managing risks associated with a potential US economic slowdown and the threat of terrorist attacks.

images.alt_text: Demand for credit is increasing and the latest ECB survey of senior loan officers shows that banks have reversed their policy of tight standards for providing loans.

site_title: Big on themes
summary: A panel of experts discusses mega themes impacting markets, including dollar asset diversification, which is expected to drive growth in Asia. Retail investors are expected to drive massive growth in ETFs in Asia and Europe, according to Amundi. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, potentially indicating the end of the trade war's worst effects. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarisation is shifting safe havens. Experts also highlight the potential for Jack Ma-backed Ant to add a stablecoin to the global net.

site_title: Conventional wisdom or (un)intentional ignorance?
summary: A recent article discusses the importance of challenging conventional wisdom in investing, particularly in relation to China. The article highlights the need to consider alternative perspectives and not be bound by familiarity or acceptance. It cites various market trends, such as dollar asset diversification, the rise of stablecoins, and the growth of ETFs in Asia and Europe, as evidence that conventional wisdom may not always be accurate. The article concludes that being open to new ideas and perspectives is crucial for making informed investment decisions.

site_title: SGX launches equity indices around themes like healthcare, real estate, oil & gas
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a series of thematic stock indices, allowing investors to track healthcare, real estate, and oil & gas sectors through these indices. The thematic indices provide an alternative to traditional market indices, offering a more targeted approach to investing.

site_title: The tried and tested approach
summary: Aviva Investors' Tim Jagger shares insights on the Asian high yield space, stating that Asia will both drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. This trend is expected to continue, driven by the growth of retail investors in Asia and Europe, with Amundi predicting "massive" ETF growth. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us. Productivity gains and de-dollarisation are also key factors contributing to the rising markets.

site_title: Oil prices rise in Asia with Opec meeting in focus
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia ahead of an OPEC meeting, where the cartel is expected to maintain high output levels despite a global supply glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 29 cents to $41.94 a barrel and Brent crude rose 18 cents to $44.79 a barrel. Analysts expect OPEC to focus on market share rather than production cuts, and Iran's planned expansion of oil exports after sanctions are lifted is expected to further add to the supply glut.

site_title: US dollar rally hits roadblock in Asian trading
summary: The US dollar faced a setback in Asian trading, weakening against the yen, euro, and emerging Asian currencies, as investors became more cautious ahead of a potential US interest rate hike. The dollar had been at seven-month highs against the euro, but markets have nearly priced in a December rate increase, leading to profit taking. China's economy showed signs of weakness, and the European Central Bank's meeting is expected to influence the euro's value, which could potentially reach parity with the dollar.

site_title: Australia government consumption up 0.7% in Q3
summary: The Australian government's consumption spending rose 0.7% in Q3 to an inflation-adjusted A$73.34 billion. Investment spending fell 9.2% to A$16.18 billion, largely due to asset transfers between public and private sectors. The data is expected to influence the GDP report for the third quarter.

site_title: Yuan's IMF SDR entry no immediate major effect on sovereign credit profile: Fitch
summary: China's inclusion in the IMF's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket is unlikely to immediately impact the yuan's sovereign credit profile, according to Fitch Ratings. The inclusion is seen as a symbolic step, marking China's growing role in international financial institutions, and may not boost the currency's usage among reserve managers. Fitch notes that China's capital controls and lack of full convertibility of the yuan will hinder its development as a global reserve currency, with a gradual shift expected in the long term.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan said on Tuesday the inclusion of the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's special drawing rights basket could lead to more devaluation of the Chinese currency.

site_title: Japan Q3 capex points to upward revision to Q3 GDP, may dodge recession
summary: Japan's capital expenditure rose 11.2% in the July-September quarter, the largest increase in over eight years, suggesting that the economy narrowly avoided a technical recession. The revised GDP estimate may show slight growth, easing pessimism about the government's efforts to boost domestic demand. This acceleration in capital expenditure is a welcome sign for policymakers aiming to stimulate economic growth through increased domestic investment.

site_title: China orders factories shut as smog nightmare continues
summary: China has ordered thousands of factories to shut due to severe smog, with Beijing's PM 2.5 levels reaching 598 micrograms per cubic meter, nearly 24 times the safe level. The smog, which has also affected other cities like Jinan, has raised concerns about the country's participation in Paris climate talks. The World Health Organisation recommends a maximum of 25 micrograms per cubic meter. The shutdowns are part of China's efforts to combat air pollution, which has become a major environmental issue in the country.

site_title: GrabTaxi, Hailo get nod to operate in Singapore; UberTAXI, MoobiTaxi pending
summary: GrabTaxi and Hailo have received certificates of registration to operate third-party taxi booking mobile applications in Singapore. The certificates are valid for three years, starting from December 1, 2015. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is processing applications from UberTAXI, MoobiTaxi, Karhoo, and ConnexTaxi. Service providers operating without registration may face fines or imprisonment. Existing providers operating before September 1, 2015, must register by December 1 to continue operating.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Winners and losers
summary: A volatile market environment benefits actively risk-managed hedge funds. Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification. Jack Ma's Ant is adding Circle's stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive 'massive' ETF growth in Asia and Europe. The S&P 500 reached a record high, potentially signaling the end of the trade war's worst effects. Productivity gains are crucial for wealth creation, while de-dollarization and shifting safe havens are underway.

site_title: Managing the politics of climate change
summary: The Paris climate conference, attended by over 50,000 participants, aims to establish a legally binding agreement to control greenhouse gas emissions and limit global temperature increase to 2°C above pre-industrial levels. The conference comes as the world faces increasing climate change risks, driven by population growth, economic development, and rising emissions. Countries, including Singapore, which has been proactive in planning for climate change, will be affected by these changes, with some experiencing sea-level rise, droughts, and water scarcity. A global agreement in Paris could determine the future of countries, but the process may be contentious and uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks bounce back, shaking off weak China PMIs; won higher
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.3% to 2,017.24 points, rebounding from a sharp fall, as foreign investors turned net buyers after China's manufacturing sector contraction. China's official manufacturing activity declined for the second consecutive month, while private factory activity contracted for the ninth month in November.

site_title: Handle with care
summary: High-yield bonds are a valuable investment option, but require caution. Asia's dollar asset diversification is expected to drive growth, with retail investors playing a key role in ETF expansion. Productivity gains are crucial for wealth creation, while de-dollarization and shifting safe havens are underway. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us. Meanwhile, Jack Ma-backed Ant is set to add a stablecoin to its global network, and a low-profile property trust is investing in data centers. These trends signal a shift in the investment landscape.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.42 points to 1670.29. The market saw 125.8 million lots traded worth RM20.8 million, with 112 gainers and 89 losers.

site_title: Indonesia seeks funds in Paris to tackle peat fires
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is seeking funds in Paris to restore and protect the country's peat forests, which have been devastated by fires, making Indonesia the world's worst polluter. Indonesia aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 29% by 2030 with international assistance, but needs $1 billion in funding. The country has pledged to cut emissions by 41% with help from others. Jokowi's government has promised to issue a decree banning all land burning and use of peatlands, but weak law enforcement and corruption hinder efforts to prevent perennial fires.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump as investors swoop on sell-off bargains
summary: Australian shares surged on Tuesday, driven by investors buying into cheap stocks after months of selling. Banks led the gains, taking advantage of improved dividend yields. Miner BHP Billiton rallied 3% after Brazil announced a US$5.2 billion lawsuit over a dam collapse. The rally came despite declines in offshore equities and commodities markets.

site_title: Gold rallies 1 per cent on short covering, drop in dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Tuesday, extending gains above a near-six-year low, driven by short covering and a drop in the dollar. The metal traded at $1,071.60 per ounce, its highest level since October 2019. Speculators' record short positions in COMEX gold futures may help prices rise in the near term, but the European Central Bank meeting and US nonfarm payrolls report on Friday will be key influences.

site_title: Architect virtuoso
summary: Soo K Chan, founding principal of SCDA Architects, is a renowned architect with a mix of creativity and business acumen. No specific information is provided in the article about his work or accomplishments.

site_title: Erdogan says would resign if Putin IS oil trade claims proven
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan stated he would resign if allegations that Turkey traded oil with Islamic State (IS) jihadists were proven, as claimed by Russian President Vladimir Putin. Erdogan made the statement during the UN climate talks near Paris, where Putin is also attending. Erdogan challenged Putin, asking if he would remain in office if such allegations were true, emphasizing the "nobility" of Turkey's nation would require his resignation.

site_title: Indonesian central bank targets inflation at around 4 per cent in 2017, 2018: govt
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Agus Martowardojo set inflation targets for 2017 and 2018 at around 4% with a deviation of 1% above or below the goal, and 3.5% for 2019. The current annual inflation rate was 4.89% in November, in line with analysts' expectations. This targets for 2017 and 2018 are within the 3-5% range for this year and next year.

site_title: China Fishery securities suspended as liquidators step in
summary: China Fishery Group's securities have been suspended from trading as provisional liquidators step in to decide the company's fate. The company's US$300 million bonds due 2019 have also been halted, and its shares on the Singapore Exchange mainboard have been suspended. China Fishery faced cashflow problems, failed to repay a US$31 million loan instalment, and had its fishing permits valued at US$1.2 billion. The company's troubles stem from its upstream fishery and fishmeal production, as well as past political issues and debt incurred for a hostile takeover. Liquidators will now decide the company's future.

site_title: Property counters 'overly discounted': UOB KayHian
summary: UOB KayHian has downplayed concerns over the impact of rising interest rates on Singapore's property sector, stating that property counters have "over-discounted" due to overblown fears. Analysts expect a 10-15% correction in property prices, with prices trending in line with GDP growth (1-3%). This contradicts worst-case scenarios and maintains the firm's "overweight" call on the property sector.

site_title: China says no basis for the yuan to continue to devalue: PBOC
summary: China's central bank stated there's no basis for the yuan to continue devaluing, and it will maintain currency stability. The inclusion of the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket has acknowledged China's economic development, making yuan cross-border investment more convenient. PBOC Vice Governor Yi Gang emphasized that this is not a one-off move, with reforms continuing.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on Tuesday there was no basis for the yuan to continue to devalue and it would keep the currency basically stable.

site_title: Singapore business optimism hits historical low: credit bureau
summary: Singapore business optimism has hit a historical low, falling into negative territory at -2.93 percentage points in Q1 2016, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. This marks the first time in three years the optimism index has contracted. Firms cite global consumer demand constraints and sectoral weakness in manufacturing and wholesale as primary reasons. Only 1 out of 6 business indicators is in positive territory, with the services sector being the most optimistic.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Local firms in Singapore are increasingly more pessimistic, depressing a widely-followed optimism index into a contractionary zone for the first time in three years after it took a turn for the worse in the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenue plunges by a third in November
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 32.3% in November, reaching 16.4 billion patacas, its lowest this year. This decline extends 18 consecutive months, attributed to slowing economic growth and a crackdown on corruption. The territory's gaming revenues are more than five times that of Las Vegas, and the government earns over 80% of its revenue from the industry. Analysts project a 13% decline in gross gaming revenue for the year, and the short-term outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Transcending time
summary: Patek Philippe created limited-edition timepieces to celebrate Singapore's heritage and support a worthy cause, transcending time and cultural boundaries.

site_title: It's Federer v Djokovic in Singapore
summary: Tennis stars Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic will face off in a high-stakes match on December 18 in Singapore as part of the Coca-Cola International Premier Tennis League (IPTL) Singapore leg. The match will be the third encounter between the two players in less than a month, following Djokovic's win over Federer at the Barclays ATP World Tour Finals in London. The IPTL, now in its second year, features 35 players from around the world, with the winning team claiming a US$1 million prize.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Europe's 'ticking time bombs' are set for shorting, Block says
summary: Carson Block, founder of Muddy Waters, is targeting European companies due to their high indebtedness and lack of investor scrutiny. He believes investors in Europe follow a "code" that discourages asking tough questions, making them vulnerable to short-selling. Block's research firm has previously successfully shorted companies like Noble Group Ltd. in Asia. He warns that European companies are "ticking time bombs" and are ripe for shorting, highlighting the need for increased investor scrutiny and transparency.

site_title: Thai November consumer prices fall for 11th straight month
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer prices fell 0.97% in November, the 11th consecutive month, due to lower oil prices. The core inflation rate was 0.88%, lower than the previous month. State price controls and weak consumption since the army coup in May last year have also contributed to the decline. The central bank has left interest rates steady at 1.50%, near a record low, and is expected to maintain no policy change until its next review on Dec 16.

site_title: Euro weak ahead of hotly-anticipated ECB meeting
summary: The euro weakened to US$1.0580 ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, where traders expect stimulus measures to boost the eurozone economy. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to raise interest rates, with a strong jobs report adding to the likelihood of a rate hike. The eurozone's economic growth is seen as a key factor in the ECB's decision, and a dovish stance could lead to a sharp decline in the euro.

site_title: Munich Re eyes business boost from new EU capital rules
summary: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, expects to generate more business due to new EU capital rules known as Solvency II, which take effect on January 1. The rules require insurance companies to manage their capital requirements, prompting them to turn to strongly capitalised reinsurers like Munich Re. The reinsurer's economic solvency ratio is at 260%, giving it an advantage in managing capital requirements. This is expected to generate around 400 million euros in annual premiums for Munich Re.

site_title: IE Singapore CEO to step down, join Surbana Jurong
summary: IE Singapore CEO TEO Eng Cheong will step down on Dec 31, 2015, to join Surbana Jurong as CEO of international operations. Chua Taik Him will take over as acting CEO from Jan 1, 2016. TEO led IE Singapore's expansion into emerging markets and implemented various initiatives. He will leverage his international experience to help Surbana Jurong expand its international footprint in emerging markets like Mexico and Oman.

site_title: Yuan inclusion: outcome expected, question is why
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is set to make a decision on whether to grant China's yuan reserve currency status, adding it to the Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket. The move, expected to be announced soon, follows Monday's meeting between IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde and the executive board. This decision could impact global trade and economic policies, with implications for China's economic growth and the global balance of payments. The outcome is expected to be announced in the coming days, providing clarity on the IMF's stance on China's yuan inclusion.

site_title: America's friends should worry about presidential hopefuls' hate-mongering
summary: The US presidential elections are being influenced by foreign views, sparking concerns among America's friends worldwide. Presidential hopefuls are employing hate-mongering tactics, targeting immigrants, China, and Muslims. Candidates are exploiting anxiety over issues like immigration, trade, and terrorism, but this approach is misguided and goes against America's unique values. This xenophobic and nativist rhetoric could have serious consequences for the country's global standing and relationships.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singaporean companies, CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) and ISOTeam, received upgrades from analysts. CMT was downgraded to "hold" by OCBC Investment Research but then upgraded to "buy" due to its high forecast distribution yield and low price-to-book value ratio. ISOTeam was upgraded to "buy" by RHB Research due to its strong contract wins and steady orderbook. Jumbo Group was also upgraded to "buy" by UOB Kay Hian Research, driven by its expected profit growth from new outlets in China.

site_title: Indonesia to release AirAsia crash investigation report
summary: Indonesia is set to release the investigation report into the 2015 AirAsia crash, which killed 162 people. The Airbus A320 crashed into the Java Sea during a two-hour flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The report is expected to focus on whether any systems were faulty and how pilots responded, particularly a stall warning that sounded in the cockpit. Experts say an outage of the Flight Augmentation Computers would not directly cause the crash, but would require manual flying skills. The report is not designed to attribute blame, but to make recommendations to avoid future accidents.

site_title: Raffles Place's office rents catching up with Marina Bay's
summary: Raffles Place's office rents have narrowed the gap with Marina Bay's, with a 4% differential in Q3, the smallest since 2011. Higher occupancies and the lack of new Grade A space in Raffles Place contributed to this trend. Cushman & Wakefield reported this finding, indicating a softening trend in the market.

site_title: Zurich Insurance to exit life business in S'pore
summary: Zurich Insurance has decided to exit the life insurance market in Singapore, effective December 1, as part of its global strategy to exit underperforming portfolios. The decision will not impact existing customer policies, and all contractual obligations will be honoured. About 80 personnel will remain to service existing customers, and the company will redeploy affected employees. This exit is part of Zurich's efforts to deliver annual run-rate cost savings of $300 million by 2016 and $1 billion by 2018.

images.alt_text: Zurich, Europe's fourth biggest insurer by market cap, has been reviewing its business as it aims to deliver annual run-rate cost savings of US$300m by the end of 2016.

site_title: Singapore to get its Michelin Guide next year
summary: Singapore is set to receive its Michelin Guide in the second half of 2016, in collaboration with Robert Parker Wine Advocate, the Singapore Tourism Board, American Express, and Resorts World Sentosa. The guide will feature a selection of the best restaurants in the city-state, with chefs and restaurateurs expressing optimism about its accuracy. This marks a significant milestone for Singapore's dining scene, with the guide expected to provide an international benchmark for local eateries.

site_title: Amazon unveils video showing use of umanned drones for delivery
summary: Amazon has unveiled a video showcasing its unmanned drone technology for package delivery, with a prototype capable of flying 122 meters and delivering a package in about 30 minutes. The video, narrated by Jeremy Clarkson, depicts a drone dropping off a replacement soccer shoe to a family. Amazon did not specify a timeline for commercial drone operations, but a senior FAA official expects regulations to be finalized within the next 12 months. This comes as other retailers, such as Google and Walmart, also develop drones for package delivery.

site_title: Sunvic chided for breaking rules on interested-person deals
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Sunvic Chemical Holdings for breaching listing rules related to 1.6 billion yuan (S$354 million) of interested-person transactions over three financial years. The company failed to disclose and obtain shareholder approval for IPTs with associates of current executive director and CEO Sun Xiao, and the late former executive chairman and CEO Sun Liping. The reprimand cites a lack of immediate disclosures and shareholder approval for the transactions, which included loans, equipment purchases, and land transfers.

site_title: China, Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open after manufacturing activity disappoints
summary: China's major stock indexes, including the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, fell 0.1% on Tuesday, marking the lowest level of manufacturing activity since August 2012. The decline occurred after data showed China's manufacturing sector slowed more than expected in November. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.9% to 22,197.81 points, despite the global market uncertainty.

site_title: Editor's note
summary: Soo K Chan, founder of SCDA Architects, successfully navigated Singapore's property market downturn to drive his firm's growth. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Other news includes a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, Jack Ma-backed Ant adding a stablecoin to its global network, and Amundi predicting massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, while markets continue to rise amid de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens.

site_title: Tenaga slapped with RM2 billion in taxes from additional assessments
summary: Malaysia's state-owned utility Tenaga Nasional received RM2 billion in additional taxes from the Internal Revenue Board, with assessments of RM985,533 and RM1.082 billion for years 2013 and 2014 respectively. The company will appeal, which could reduce its cash pile to RM6.89 billion and push its effective tax rate to 26%. The surprise demand has sparked concerns among investors, who fear a substantial reduction in cash reserves. Analysts attribute the assessments to disputes over utilisation of reinvestment allowances and non-taxable income, with potential consequences for the tax man if the assessment is deemed unjust.

site_title: Countries will rush to join TPP once it's up: Japanese minister
summary: Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Akira Amari predicts an "avalanche" of countries will join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) once it's operational. Five countries, including Singapore, are "waiting in the wings" to join the trade and investment pact. The TPP is expected to create a market 11/2 times bigger than the European Union and ensure free movement of capital goods and people among members. Amari stated there will be "no renegotiation" of the TPP terms, and countries that ratify the agreement will be able to go into operation even if others decline.

site_title: RedMart offers 1-hour delivery of orders from food, retail partners
summary: RedMart, a Singapore-based online grocery service provider, has launched RedMart Relay, an on-demand marketplace that allows customers to order products from participating food and retail partners in select areas. Products are delivered within one hour by "runners" who purchase and deliver directly to customers. The service aims to leverage RedMart's extensive delivery network, offering faster and cheaper delivery than traditional couriers. Initially available in 6 neighborhoods, the service plans to expand nationwide by early 2016, with the goal of becoming an "everything store" delivering a wide range of products within the hour.

site_title: Kazakhstan plays key role in Central Asia
summary: Kazakhstan plays a key role in Central Asia, leveraging its well-thought-out foreign policy to achieve regional stability and prosperity. The country's multi-vector approach has fostered good relations and strong economic ties with various nations, including Russia, China, Europe, and the US. Kazakhstan is positioning itself as a partner and friend to major powers, promoting a vision of the future that prioritizes regional and global stability. The country's unique geography and size make it an attractive landbridge between economic giants, and it is working to maximize its potential.

site_title: Khorgos-East Gate set for transformation
summary: Kazakhstan's Khorgos-East Gate special economic zone (SEZ) is undergoing transformation, with construction of the country's first dry port and logistics area nearing completion. The SEZ, set to tap multiple streams of traffic, will handle over 200,000 containers annually by 2020. DP World has won a 10-year concession to run the SEZ and is investing $1 billion in developing its facilities. The project is expected to boost Kazakhstan's economy, making it a major commercial and transportation hub for the Eurasian continent, and attract companies such as Hewlett-Packard and Toyota.

site_title: Paris climate talks a demonstration of global resolve, says Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama has welcomed the start of climate talks in Paris, saying they mark a turning point for collective action on global warming. He emphasized that no nation is immune to the effects of climate change, and the US accepts its role in contributing to the problem. The US aims to secure commitments from wealthy nations to invest in clean energy research and assist developing countries. Obama also highlighted a partnership between the US and China, two of the world's biggest carbon emitters, to transition away from fossil fuels. A landmark agreement appears likely by mid-December.

site_title: In the pink
summary: The international art market is thriving, as evidenced by the enthusiasm at Frieze London and Frieze Masters. Meanwhile, Asia is poised to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. A low-profile property trust is investing in a data centre, while Jack Ma's Ant is set to add Circle's stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe, according to Amundi. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: Lower taxes for 93% of residential property owners in Singapore: Iras
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (Iras) announced that 93% of residential property owners will pay lower property taxes in 2016. All HDB flat owner-occupiers and 28,200 three-room HDB flat owners will not pay property tax, with savings ranging from 9% to 24%. For private properties, more than 80% will see tax savings of 3-20%. The annual values of properties are adjusted annually to reflect prevailing market rentals, ensuring the tax savings accurately reflect market changes.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
About 93 per cent of residential property owners in Singapore are poised to pay lower property taxes next year, with the annual values of real estate falling in tandem with market rentals.

site_title: Iran to ramp up crude exports to fend off rivals
summary: Iran plans to increase crude oil exports to counter rival producers, mirroring Saudi Arabia's strategy. With sanctions lifted, Iran aims to expand production by 500,000 barrels a day within a week and 1 million barrels a day within six months. This move could further reduce global oil prices, affecting OPEC's rivals, including US shale drillers and global oil majors. Iran's return to the market could also bolster Saudi Arabia's efforts to maintain its market share and protect prices, despite Iran's own concerns about low prices hindering foreign investment in its oil industry.

site_title: Handshakes rolls out tool for quick check on company owners
summary: DC Frontiers, a financial technology firm, has launched a search tool for quick and safe access to accurate information on shareholders of companies in Singapore and Asia. The tool, powered by company registry data, allows users to access "legal beneficial ownership" information with a single click, providing a more efficient and transparent way to conduct searches. The tool is part of the Handshakes data analysis app and aims to promote greater transparency in the region.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Celebrating wise leadership
summary: Kazakhstan celebrates the First President, Nursultan Nazarbayev, on December 1, marking over 20 years of leadership. Under his rule, the country has made significant progress, including closing the Semipalatinsk Nuclear Test Site and launching initiatives like the ATOM Project and the 100 Concrete Steps program. This program aims to drive improvements in all institutional pillars, boost infrastructure spending, and stimulate the economy, with a focus on joining the top 30 developed countries by 2050. The country's modernization plans have been accelerated, with investments in connectivity and social modernization.

site_title: All for one and one for all
summary: A Family Council's purpose is to create a whole greater than its parts. Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification. A low-profile property trust is expanding into data centers. Jack Ma's Ant is adding a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarization is shifting safe havens. Markets continue to rise despite trade war concerns.

site_title: Japan to dispatch whaling fleet to Antarctic Ocean
summary: Japan will dispatch a whaling fleet to the Antarctic Ocean on December 1, 2015, defying international criticism and a UN ruling that the "research" expedition is a commercial hunt. The move comes after a one-year suspension, with Japan citing the need for "essential information" on whale migration and reproductive rates. The UN's International Court of Justice previously ruled that Japan's whaling in the Southern Ocean is a commercial hunt, but Japan claims it is necessary for its traditional culture and that whale populations are sustainable.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund loses US$64b amid equity rout
summary: The Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), Japan's largest pension fund, reported its worst quarterly loss since 2008, with a 5.6% decline in value due to a global stock rout in August and September, wiping US$64 billion off its investments. The fund's equity holdings declined 7.9 trillion yen, with Japanese equities falling 13% and foreign equities losing 11%. This loss marks a significant shift in the fund's investment strategy, which has been criticized for its aggressive approach.

site_title: Nippon Life plans Japan's largest Reit
summary: Nippon Life Insurance plans to launch Japan's largest private real estate investment trust (Reit) with a target of 4% returns. The fund, set to open next year, aims to raise 300 billion yen and will focus on office properties, retail, and housing. The move is seen as a response to Japan's low government bond yields, with Nippon Life seeking to appeal to pension plans and big institutions. The Reit will be managed by Nippon Life Realty Management Inc, which will sell part of its existing real estate portfolio to fund the trust.

site_title: Overseas investors eyeing 'rising stars' in Japan equity market: Nomura
summary: Foreign investors, seeking opportunities in Japan's equity market, are focusing on lesser-known companies with high growth potential. Nomura Holdings Inc. has selected 25 "rising stars" to meet with global institutional investors in Tokyo, with companies like Ishikawa-based Kusuri No Aoki Co. and Tochigi-based Nakanishi Inc. on the list. These companies have an average market value of 100 billion yen and have climbed 10% this year, compared to the benchmark Topix index's 13% advance. The gathering aims to attract global funds seeking to boost profitability through acquisitions and return profits to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Euglena is developing an algae as a nutritional supplement and is working on cultivating it for use as a bio jet fuel.

site_title: China elevator market set to slow after peaking last year
summary: China's elevator market is expected to slow down after peaking at 600,000 units last year, with sales potentially dropping to 500,000 next year due to a surplus of apartments and slowdown in people moving to big cities. Otis Elevator Co, the world's largest elevator maker, believes the market may stabilize after that, but analysts warn of a potential long-term decline. The company is investing in Japan to develop more sophisticated elevator models, while United Technologies Corp, which owns Otis, has seen its shares fall 15% due to the slowdown in Chinese demand.

site_title: Holistic & unbiased
summary: Standard Chartered Private Bank's Peter Kok believes the one-bank approach appeals to its entrepreneurial client base. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to both drive and gain from dollar asset diversification. Amundi forecasts 'massive' ETF growth in Asia and Europe driven by retail investors. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, with some speculating the trade war's worst is behind us. Productivity gains are crucial for unlocking wealth creation, and the shift away from the US dollar is underway.

site_title: Singapore market cap shrinks 3.1% in November
summary: Singapore's market capitalisation decreased 3.1% in November due to weak earnings and wariness about a possible US interest rate hike. The total market cap fell to S$854.6 billion, down 10.7% from end-2014. Most sectors lost value, with commerce stocks posting the sharpest decline of 7.8%. Prudential retained its position as the largest stock, while Thai Beverage Public Co and Tiger Airways were notable gainers. Market experts expect interest rate changes to affect property companies and defensive dividend-yielding stocks, and some predict a mean reversion in market trends.

images.alt_text: Equities around the world, as a general asset class, "will probably trade higher over the coming months", said DBS's Mr Lim.

site_title: Taking good care of staff - even when parting company
summary: Businesses will continue to face challenges and job redundancies, prompting companies to initiate cost-management measures. However, proactive career planning and management can help mitigate the impact. By empowering employees to plan and manage their careers, companies can retain valuable talent and provide infrastructure and support for career growth. This approach also enables employees to take charge of finding alternative roles within the organization, reducing the need for outplacement support and enhancing the company's reputation as a preferred employer.

site_title: Singapore bank lending falls again in October
summary: Singapore bank lending fell 1.1% in October from September, with a 0.4% decline in year-on-year lending, following a 0.6% gain in September. Business loans dropped 1.9% in October, with a 2.6% year-on-year decline, while trade loans fell 5.3% and lending to manufacturers contracted for the third month. Consumer lending, however, remained stable, with a 0.2% increase in October. The decline in business lending is attributed to a weaker manufacturing sector.

site_title: Pending sales of previously owned homes up 0.2%
summary: Pending sales of previously owned US homes rose 0.2% in October after a revised 1.6% decline, beating economists' forecast of a 1% advance. Steady hiring gains and early signs of a pickup in worker pay are expected to support housing demand despite recent borrowing cost increases. The National Association of Realtors forecasts an annual existing-homes sales pace of 5.3 million at the end of 2015, with sales growth slowing to 3% in 2016 due to continued price increases and low inventory.

site_title: Hong Kong's pink dolphins at risk of disappearing
summary: Hong Kong's pink dolphins, also known as Chinese white dolphins, are at risk of disappearing due to a rapid decline over the past few decades. The population has dropped from 158 in 2003 to around 60 dolphins currently. Campaigners blame the construction of a third runway at Hong Kong's airport, as well as high-speed ferry traffic and environmental pollution, for the decline. Conservationists warn that if the project goes ahead, it could drive the dolphins away from Hong Kong waters, potentially leading to their extinction.

images.alt_text: The Chinese white dolphin - popularly known as the pink dolphin due to its pale pink colouring - draws scores of tourists daily to the waters north of Hong Kong's Lantau island.

site_title: Eye on future trends
summary: Niche markets and deregulation are creating new property investment opportunities, particularly in Asia. A low-profile property trust is expanding into data centers, while Jack Ma-backed Ant is adding a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe, with Amundi predicting significant growth. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, and productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation. De-dollarization and shifting safe havens are also emerging trends, with markets continuing to rise despite trade tensions.

site_title: ECB left with no choice but to boost stimulus: economists
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to boost stimulus measures, including a potential rate cut and increased bond purchases, as economists predict the euro-area economy will continue to recover. The ECB's President Mario Draghi is under pressure to meet expectations and avoid investor backlash, with a 100% probability of a deposit rate cut and 90% chance of a 15 basis point cut. The Governing Council will gather on December 2 to discuss measures, with economists predicting a prolonged quantitative easing program and potential expansion of asset purchases.

site_title: Midas to buy chairman's company in share deal valued at S$264m
summary: Midas Holdings agreed to buy China-based aluminium products maker Huicheng Capital in a deal valued at S$264 million. Midas will issue up to 733.3 million new shares to acquire the company, with chairman Chen Wei Ping receiving up to 271.3 million earn-out shares based on Huicheng's 2016 profit target. The acquisition aims to diversify Midas' business and provide a profitable source of revenue.

site_title: Buyout offer for Zagro Asia fair and reasonable
summary: Zagro Asia's major shareholder, Poh Beng Swee, is offering to buy out minority shareholders and delist the company from the SGX mainboard. The offer price of 30 cents is considered fair and reasonable, with the alternative option of waiting for payment in three months. If the proposal fails, shares could drop to 25 cents. Small shareholders can sell their shares now to avoid potential losses, or accept the offer and wait for payment. Rejecting the offer could incur significant losses.

site_title: Marine service provider denies distressed sales
summary: Pacific Richfield Marine Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based marine service provider, is selling up to half of its offshore support fleet to pare debt and reduce expenditure amid a 50% slump in oil prices. The company denies distressed sales, stating its US$100 million bank debt is primarily used to finance vessel construction. Pacific Richfield is working with four creditor banks and stakeholders to sell or charter bare vessels, with 14 older vessels earmarked for sale and the remaining 26 up for sale or charter.

site_title: Nokia's reinvention strategy faces its biggest test
summary: Nokia's $16.6 billion takeover of Alcatel-Lucent is set to be completed in early 2016, marking a significant step in the company's 150-year transformation from a rubber boot manufacturer to a leading cellphone maker. This move is seen as a key part of Nokia's years-long makeover strategy, aiming to revitalize the company after its market capitalization peaked at nearly $250 billion.

site_title: Ensuring survival of Michelin guide for next 100 years
summary: Michelin's international director, Michael Ellis, emphasizes the importance of digital presence, market expansion, and maintaining the anonymity of inspectors to ensure the guide's survival for the next 100 years. The Singapore edition will be the first digital guide, with plans to replicate this model elsewhere. Ellis highlights the guide's unique approach of hiring full-time inspectors, paying them competitive salaries, and focusing on food quality and technique. He also dispels the misconception that Michelin awards stars only to fancy restaurants, stating that the guide's criteria are based on the food alone.

site_title: Marco Polo takes rig dispute with SembMarine to mediation stage
summary: Marco Polo Marine announced that its unit MP Drilling has taken a dispute with Sembcorp Marine's PPL Shipyard to mediation stage over a US$214.3 million rig building contract. MP Drilling claims 70 cracks were found on the rig's legs during testing, while Sembcorp Marine insists the contract is still in force and seeks a second payment. If mediation fails, MP Drilling will proceed to arbitration. The dispute centers on the rig's quality and payment terms.

site_title: ECB set to cut deposit rate further this week, economist predicts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to cut its deposit rate by 10 basis points, according to Credit Agricole Private Banking's chief economist Marie Owens-Thomsen. This move aims to push excess funds out of the ECB's vaults and into the real economy. The ECB has seen an increase in deposits, with 170 billion euros held by banks, and has pumped in 60 billion euros a month through its quantitative easing program. Despite concerns about eurozone growth and China's slowdown, economists expect low inflation to continue, with Owens-Thomsen arguing that targets should focus on establishing low inflation rather than specific targets.

site_title: Shanghai buyer completes 137 Cecil Street purchase
summary: A Shanghai buyer has completed the purchase of 137 Cecil Street in Singapore for S$210 million. The deal involves a leaseback agreement with the seller, Cheong Sim Lam, for at least two years. The sale marks the end of a long process, with the property's value remaining stable despite market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: China to end state monopoly on electricity distribution
summary: China will end its state monopoly on electricity distribution by allowing end users to negotiate prices directly with generators, enabling direct power purchase through regional trading platforms. State-owned power distributors will operate networks and carry electricity for a government-set fee. The move aims to restore electricity's commodity character and bring benefits to end users as low coal prices and power oversupply push down rates, part of President Xi Jinping's drive to overhaul state-owned businesses and allow market forces to play a bigger role.

site_title: Fitch affirms Singapore's 'AAA' sovereign ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed Singapore's 'AAA' sovereign ratings with a stable outlook, citing the country's strong external balance sheet, robust fiscal framework, and high per capita income. However, the agency trimmed its growth forecast for 2015-2016 to 2.1%, citing an ageing population that will weaken the current account surplus position. Despite this, Fitch believes Singapore's credit profile remains strong, with a constitutional mandate to run a balanced fiscal position and a large positive net international investment position.

site_title: Chinese banks challenged to fill half-trillion TLAC capital gap
summary: China's four largest banks, the Big Four, face a significant capital gap of $553 billion to meet global standards on total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC). To comply, they will need to issue hundreds of billions of dollars of capital, mostly from overseas markets at higher yields than they are accustomed to. This poses a challenge for the banks, with some investors expressing concerns over pricing, risk, and transparency. The Chinese banks have a 10-year window to meet the TLAC requirements, but may face downward pressure on yields due to increased supply in the market.

site_title: The Swan factor in SME success
summary: Soverus Group's CEO Paul Lim highlights the importance of exceptional "above the surface" for small businesses to stay ahead. The company has expanded into cybersecurity, generating S$1 million in business this year, offering services such as regulatory compliance, risk assessments, and security architecture design. Lim's focus on cybersecurity marks a shift in the company's business, building on its existing security services.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: A Silicon Valley state of mind: smart, open and disruptive
summary: In contrast to the xenophobic sentiment in Washington, Silicon Valley embodies a state of mind characterized by openness, creativity, and collaboration. The Smart Nation conference, held in Palo Alto, California, brought together 200 representatives from Silicon Valley and Singapore to discuss the potential of technology to promote economic and social progress. The tech industry, led by companies like Google and Facebook, has been lobbying for immigration reform, supporting bills that increase the cap on H-1B visas and create a new visa category for foreign entrepreneurs. Experts predict that digital currencies and FinTech will play a significant role in promoting financial inclusion in developing countries, with Singapore well-positioned to take advantage of these opportunities.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The US stock market opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology and Grab also reported concerns, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue and operating loss targets, and CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and London's Heathrow eyed higher fees for a £10b upgrade. MAS and PBOC also announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: iX Biopharma has secured a patent in Indonesia for its WaferiX drug delivery technology, its sixth country to grant a patent. The patent expires in 2030. Rickmers Maritime has lifted restrictions on its trust, removing financial constraints. mDR Ltd has terminated a planned purchase of Shenzhen Quanli Leather Co Ltd. Infinio Group has seen the resignation of independent director CHOO Siew Lohk, who cited work commitments.

site_title: Ferrari gets 2.5b euros in funding
summary: Ferrari has secured 2.5 billion euros in funding through a 12-month bridge loan and a five-year term loan worth 2 billion euros, as well as a five-year revolving credit facility worth 500 million euros. The funding will be used in part to refinance debt owed to Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and to separate from its parent company. The company plans to refinance the bridge loan ahead of maturity with longer-term debt.

site_title: Japan may duck economic recession in last quarter
summary: Japan's economic recession may be delayed into the final quarter of 2015, according to recent data showing a 1.4% increase in factory output in October, its second consecutive month of growth. Retail sales also rose 1.8% year-over-year, exceeding expectations. However, analysts caution that the gains are not enough to guarantee an escape from further contraction, and a slowdown in China and other emerging economies could hurt business confidence. The Bank of Japan's governor warned that a continued slowdown could lead to a third round of quantitative easing to achieve the 2% inflation target.

site_title: Honda lifts retirement age to 65 as Japan Inc copes with aging
summary: Honda Motor Co plans to lift its retirement age to 65, making it one of Japan's biggest companies to address the nation's aging demographics. The company also proposes changes to its work arrangements, including a shift to child care and nursing allowances, a work-from-home system, and a revised salary structure. These moves are part of Honda's efforts to cope with Japan's rapidly aging population and contribute to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's initiatives to boost women in the workplace. The changes affect around 40,000 employees at Honda and its group companies.

site_title: German inflation picks up tentatively in November: data
summary: German consumer prices rose 0.4% in November, driven by higher costs for food, services, and rents, according to official data. This preliminary flash estimate could ease concerns of deflation in the eurozone, despite falling energy prices.
