The European Central Bank (ECB) regards annual inflation rates of around 2% as conducive to healthy economic growth, and ECB chief Mario Draghi has suggested additional monetary easing if inflation expectations do not pick up soon.

site_title: RedMart launches online app to deliver within one hour of purchase
summary: RedMart, a Singapore-based online grocery service provider, has launched RedMart Relay, an on-demand marketplace that allows customers to order products from participating food and retail partners and receive delivery within one hour. The service, which uses personal shoppers known as "Runners," aims to deepen the company's relationship with customers and expand its product offerings. RedMart CEO Roger Egan hopes to become an "everything store" and believes the service will attract more frequent repeat purchases and encourage retailers to partner with the company.

images.alt_text: A worker picking grocery items according to customer orders at local online grocery retailer RedMart's warehouse at Jalan Terusan on 17 July 2014.

site_title: China, US holding high-level cybercrime talks: Xinhua
summary: China's Public Security Minister Guo Shengkun is in the US for the first high-level dialogue on cyber crime between the two countries. Guo will meet Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson. This dialogue aims to address long-standing cybersecurity issues between China and the US, despite robust economic ties worth $590 billion.

site_title: DC Frontiers launches tool to access information on owners of companies
summary: DC Frontiers, a financial technology firm, has launched a tool to access information on company shareholders in Singapore and Asia. The tool, developed in collaboration with the Singapore Association of the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators, uses data from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority to provide timely and accurate information on shareholders in a single click. This enhances transparency and efficiency for users conducting searches on ownership information. The tool is the first of its kind in Singapore and Asia.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: The road ahead
summary: Despite global macro headwinds, investment ideas from a bottom-up perspective remain viable. Asia is expected to both drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. A low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, while Jack Ma-backed Ant is set to add a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are forecasted to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarization is underway with shifting safe havens. Markets continue to rise, with the S&P 500 reaching a record high.

site_title: Data breach at VTech highlights broader problems
summary: VTech Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-based toy maker, has suffered a data breach that exposed customer information, including children's data. The stolen data included information about customers who downloaded children's games and books. Industry watchers say this highlights the growing problem of basic cyber security measures at small, non-financial companies handling electronic customer data. VTech has taken steps to prevent further attacks and its stock has fallen 22% this year. The breach underscores the increasing threat of cyber crime as more devices connect to the internet and companies collect personal information.

site_title: Culinary travelling at home
summary: Affluent Singaporeans are recreating international culinary experiences at home, driven by their travel bug. This trend reflects the growing interest in recreating exotic flavors and cuisines in the comfort of their own kitchens. By exploring new ingredients, cooking techniques, and recipes, individuals can relive their travel memories without the need for international travel, providing an affordable and convenient alternative to culinary tourism.

site_title: China's Xi demands developed nations pay for climate action
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged developed nations to fulfill their commitment of providing $100 billion annually to support developing countries in tackling climate change. He emphasized that developed countries should accept "more shared responsibilities" for limiting global warming and helping poor countries adapt to a climate-afflicted world. The call comes six years after rich nations pledged to provide the funding, but poor nations are frustrated with the lack of progress. Xi stressed that addressing climate change should not deny developing countries' legitimate needs to reduce poverty and improve living standards.

site_title: US pending home sales edge higher amid tight supply
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.2% in October, reaching 107.7, up 3.9% from last year. Despite low interest rates, tight supplies keep home prices high, causing buyers to hesitate. The National Association of Realtors forecasts an annual existing-homes sales pace of 5.3 million at the end of 2015, the best year since 2006. Sales growth is expected to slow to 3.0% in 2016 due to continued price increases.

site_title: Small units lead price falls for completed condos
summary: Small units in Singapore have led to a 3.1% decline in completed condo prices year to date, according to the National University of Singapore's October flash estimates. This decline is more severe than for other apartments and condos, attributed to rental erosion for shoebox units. The overall SRPI has slipped 2.2% year to date, with smaller units experiencing a bigger decline than Central and Non-Central regions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

Small units have led prices falls for completed apartments and condos year to date as well as on a year-on-year basis, according to National University of Singapore's October flash estimates for its Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI).

site_title: Eyes wide open
summary: A pre-nuptial agreement in Singapore is deemed relatively useful but unenforceable due to the country's laws. The agreement is considered binding only for the duration of the marriage, and in the event of divorce, the court can override it. The lack of clear guidelines and inconsistent court decisions hinder the enforceability of pre-nuptial agreements in Singapore. This leaves couples with limited protection in the event of a divorce.

site_title: Arson disrupts high-speed international trains from Brussels: officials
summary: Arson disrupted high-speed international trains on the Brussels-Lille line, targeting signalling cables. The Belgian railway operator, Infrabel, reported no attempt to derail a train and no injuries. Cables were set on fire in four locations near Ath, France. Services were halted until at least early afternoon, with 15 trains cancelled. The incident occurred amid a climate of fear over terrorist attacks, with Belgium on its second-highest terror alert level. Prosecutors and police are investigating the deliberate act targeting the signal system.

site_title: It's always 1979 somewhere
summary: Stock markets continue to cycle through periods of high and low prices, offering opportunities for investors to exploit similarities between these cycles. A low-profile property trust is investing in a data center, while Jack Ma's Ant is planning to add a stablecoin to its global network. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, with retail investors anticipated to drive ETF growth in the region. Productivity gains are also seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, as markets continue to rise despite concerns about the trade war and de-dollarization.

site_title: India's economy grows by 7.4% in second quarter
summary: India's economy grew by 7.4% in the second quarter, outperforming China and beating analysts' expectations. This marks the third straight quarter of growth above 7%. The positive data is a boost for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has made boosting economic growth a priority. However, investors remain concerned about the pace of promised economic reforms needed to create jobs for India's young population. The Reserve Bank of India is likely to keep interest rates unchanged, and the government's revised GDP calculation method has raised concerns about the accuracy of economic indicators.

site_title: Arrested Brazilian billionaire resigns as head of investment bank
summary: Brazilian billionaire Andre Esteves, 47, has resigned as chairman and CEO of BTG Pactual after being arrested on charges related to Brazil's Petrobras corruption probe. He was arrested along with Delcidio Amaral, a senior senator, on charges of obstructing justice. Prosecutors allege Esteves planned to finance a former Petrobras executive's escape in exchange for silence. Both Esteves and Amaral have denied wrongdoing. The arrest is part of a massive bribes and faked contracts scheme at Petrobras, which has cost the company over $2 billion.

site_title: Asad Jumabhoy-led Scotts Group sells 10% stake in Fintrax
summary: The Scotts Group, led by Asad Jumabhoy, has sold its 10% stake in Fintrax, a global value-added tax refund processing company, to French private equity group Eurazeo for 300 million euros. Eurazeo acquired 90% of Fintrax from British group Exponent Private Equity in a deal that valued Fintrax at 550 million euros. Asad Jumabhoy will step down from his Fintrax vice-chairman position. The remaining 10% stake will be held by Fintrax management.

site_title: Felda Global plans to renegotiate US$680 million Eagle High deal
summary: Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd, the world's largest crude palm oil producer, plans to renegotiate its $680 million deal to buy a stake in Indonesia's PT Eagle High Plantations due to bearish crude palm oil prices and a weakening ringgit. The deal, which was initially set to be announced by mid-August, has been extended twice and may involve issues such as stake size, pricing, and research and development partnerships. Felda's CEO Mohd Emir Mavani Abdullah said the company may seek a lower price and consider raising debt to finance the purchase.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Wall Street opened lower on July 11, 2025, amid US President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half, with an operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was previously a DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China QFII quota rises to US$79.10b in Nov: FX regulator
summary: China's outstanding QFII programme quota rose to US$79.10 billion as of November 27, up from US$78.97 billion at the end of October. The QFII scheme allows foreigners to invest in Chinese capital markets.

site_title: Gold set for worst month in 2½ years on US rate hike view
summary: Gold prices are poised for their worst month in 2½ years due to expectations of a US interest rate hike in December, which could lead to a decline in demand for the precious metal. Spot gold has dropped 0.2% to $1,055.60 an ounce, nearing its lowest level since 2010. Investors are positioning themselves for the rate hike, which could exacerbate the sell-off in gold. Other precious metals, including silver and platinum, are also expected to decline.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker despite heavy STI volume
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 3.18 points weaker at 2,855.94, despite heavy trading volume of 1.4 billion units worth S$1.7 billion. The reversal came after an 8-point gain at 5pm, with a net absence of direction from overseas markets due to traders waiting for the IMF's decision on China's yuan reserve currency status and the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting, which is expected to yield an interest rate hike.

site_title: STI stocks active in end-of-month trading
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day 3.18 points weaker at 2,855.94, despite a pre-market rally, due to last-minute selling of several index stocks. The index had gained 8 points earlier but lost those gains at 5pm. Turnover was 1.4 billion units worth S$1.7 billion, with 166 rises versus 225 falls. This follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singapore iron ore futures drop below US$40/tonne, more steel output cuts in China weigh
summary: Singapore iron ore futures dropped below US$40/tonne on Monday due to concerns over China's demand for steelmaking ingredient. Prices have lost 34% since the start of the year, with steel mills expected to step up output cuts due to deeper losses and shrinking demand. China's economy is cooling, and construction activity is slowing, forcing steel mills to cut inventories of raw material. Iron ore prices have also dropped on the Dalian Commodity Exchange, with the most active contract trading at 293.5 yuan (S$64.77) a tonne.

site_title: China smog climbs to perilous levels on eve of climate talks
summary: China's northern cities, including Beijing, experienced severe smog on the eve of global climate change talks in Paris, with PM2.5 levels reaching 560 micrograms per cubic meter, 22 times the healthy limit. The pollution alert was triggered by President Xi Jinping's arrival, with residents advised to stay indoors. The city's environmental protection bureau warned that the pollution would last until a cold front arrives. China, the world's largest emitter of greenhouse gases, has pledged to peak carbon dioxide output by 2030, but its emissions continue to rise, linked to hundreds of thousands of premature deaths.

images.alt_text: Northern China choked under some of the worst smog this year on Monday, with levels in Beijing soaring to 22 times healthy limits, triggering the city's second-highest pollution alert on the eve of global climate change talks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore labour force participation rate increased, while median income rose 4.7% to S$3,949 a month in 2015, according to the Singapore Workforce 2015 report. In other news, Singapore bank lending fell in October, and Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure. Additionally, Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: The Singapore labour force posted broad-based gains in 2015, according to the newly released Singapore Workforce 2015 report from the Ministry of Manpower.

site_title: Russia will not attend Opec consultations, meeting this week
summary: Russia will not attend Opec consultations this week, with the Russian Energy Ministry instead expecting an experts-level meeting with Opec in mid-December. The Opec meeting, scheduled for December 4 in Vienna, will be the first time the organization has trimmed oil demand forecasts for the next four years.

site_title: Zurich Life to stop accepting new policy applications in Singapore from Dec 1
summary: Zurich Life Insurance Singapore will no longer accept new policy applications from December 1, as part of the insurer's efforts to streamline its business. The move affects the life business, while the general insurance division remains unchanged. Existing customers will not be impacted, with Zurich committing to servicing all policies with a dedicated local team and honoring contractual obligations. The decision is aimed at prioritizing investment where Zurich can compete to win and establish a distinctive position in the market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open, await busy week
summary: European stock markets fell at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.4% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also declining. The decline comes ahead of a potential European Central Bank stimulus announcement and key US jobs data. The busy trading week follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

images.alt_text: Traders are pictured at their desks in front of the DAX board at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, November 27, 2015.

site_title: Swatch, Visa launch pay-by-wrist watch venture
summary: Swatch, Visa, and Visa Europe have launched a project allowing Visa cardholders in the US, Switzerland, and Brazil to make payments using Swatch's "pay-by-the-wrist" Bellamy watch. The watch, set to launch in early 2016, uses near-field communications (NFC) and can be used worldwide where Visa payments are accepted.

site_title: Falling oil weighs on ringgit as Fed interest-rate rise looms
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell for a third day due to declining oil prices and a strengthening US dollar, ahead of a likely interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve. The ringgit has dropped 22% this year, with foreign funds pulling 18.4 billion ringgit from Malaysian stocks. The government's 1Malaysia Development Bhd sold its power assets to China General Nuclear Power Corp, bringing it closer to winding down operations. The ringgit strengthened 0.8% in November, but its losses this year have narrowed to 18%.

site_title: China plans to launch carbon-tracking satellites into space
summary: China plans to launch carbon-tracking satellites into space by next May, aiming to monitor its greenhouse gas emissions and improve data accuracy. The country's first two satellites will be developed by the Changchun Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics and Physics, with the goal of becoming the world's third country to track greenhouse gases. The satellites will monitor oceans, which account for 71% of the world's surface, and expand research into emissions. This move comes as China steps up its efforts to cut emissions, with Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Barack Obama discussing a low-carbon global economy.

site_title: German retail sales dip on the month in October
summary: German retail sales declined 0.4% in October, missing expectations, but rose 2.1% year-over-year, the strongest increase since 1994. Despite the dip, retail sales from January to October rose 2.8%, driven by record employment, rising wages, and low interest rates. Consumers' morale and willingness to buy remained strong, indicating a positive outlook for the Christmas season. The solid retail performance strengthens expectations that private consumption will remain a key growth driver for Germany's economy in the final quarter of the year.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher ahead of busy week of data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, ahead of a busy week of economic data, including the November jobs report. The Dow Jones rose 21.68 points, or 0.12%, to 17,820.17, while the S&P 500 gained 2.91 points, or 0.14%, to 2,093.02. The Nasdaq composite added 12.20 points, or 0.24%, to 5,139.73. The market is anticipating a key jobs report, which could impact investor sentiment and stock prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 10.43 points higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed 10.43 points higher at 1,672.16, despite trading 2.5 billion lots valued at RM3.79 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 679 to 270.

site_title: 8 things you need to know about the Michelin Guide
summary: The Michelin Guide, which awards stars to restaurants, will introduce a Singapore edition in the second half of 2016, available in both English and Chinese. The guide, which started as a tyre business venture, began publishing in 1900 to help road-weary travelers find places to eat. Interestingly, the guide initially had blue covers and was free, but after someone used it to prop up a garage workbench, the price was increased. The guide has also had a significant impact on restaurants, with some losing business after losing stars, while others have seen an increase in revenue.

site_title: Fitch affirms Singapore at 'AAA'; outlook stable
summary: Fitch Ratings has affirmed Singapore's long-term foreign- and local-currency Issuer default ratings at 'AAA' with a stable outlook, citing its strong external balance sheet, robust fiscal framework, and high per capita income. However, the agency has revised its growth outlook for Singapore to 2.1% in 2015-2016 due to a less favourable external environment. The sovereign's fiscal position remains a credit positive, with no fiscal financing needs and a balanced fiscal position. The stable outlook reflects Fitch's assessment that downside risks to the 'AAA' rating are not significant.

site_title: SGX reprimands Sunvic for breaking rules on 1.6b yuan of IPTs over 3 years
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded Sunvic Chemical Holdings for breaching listing rules related to 1.6 billion yuan (S$353 million) of interested-person transactions (IPTs) over three financial years. Sunvic failed to immediately announce and seek shareholder approval for IPTs with associates of executive director and CEO Sun Xiao. The company also failed to properly disclose IPTs in annual reports. The reprimand comes after auditor Grant Thornton highlighted breaches of SGX listing rules in 2014. Sunvic's directors claim the IPTs were necessary for business operations and did not prejudice minority shareholders.

site_title: VW proposes fixes for all three dirty diesel motors in Germany
summary: Volkswagen AG submitted proposals to fix its three dirty diesel motors in Germany, addressing a scandal that affected 8.5 million cars. The company has already secured approval for a software repair for its 2.0-litre motors and a new air filter part for 1.6-litre engines. Only a repair for the 1.2-litre engines remains pending. German regulators have expressed positive impressions on the proposals, with Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt stating they will work quickly to clear up the manipulation and allow Volkswagen to remedy the issue.

site_title: Japan's GPIF posts record loss in July-Sept as China worries, yen bite
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest public pension fund, reported a record 7.9 trillion yen (S$90.7 billion) loss in the July-September quarter due to market turmoil triggered by China's economic slowdown. The fund made significant losses in domestic and foreign equities, with a 5.6% decline in earnings rate. The Nikkei share average fell 14.1% and the Topix dropped 13.5% during the period, largely attributed to concerns over China's economic slowdown and the yen's rise.

site_title: South Korea legislature approves free-trade pact with China
summary: South Korea's parliament has ratified a free-trade agreement with China, authorizing the expansion of relations with the country's largest trading partner. The pact, signed in June, aims to reduce commerce barriers but leaves curbs on rice and automobiles in place. The agreement benefits South Korea, which runs a trade surplus of US$55.2 billion with China in 2014, primarily due to exports of electronics. The pact is set to take effect as early as this year, further solidifying South Korea's trade ties with China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dip, but recovery in mainland market calms jitters
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.3% to 21,996.42 on Monday, despite a positive close for mainland markets. The Hang Seng index declined 2.8% for the month, its largest drop in two months. Analysts warn that Hong Kong's economic troubles and China's financial deregulation make it less attractive to investors, potentially shifting its role as a Chinese investment proxy.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi to meet president, military chief on Wednesday
summary: Myanmar opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi will meet President Thein Sein and military chief Min Aung Hlaing on Wednesday, their first meeting since her NLD party won a landslide election. Suu Kyi needs to forge a working relationship with the military to run smoothly, despite the military-drafted constitution limiting her role. The meetings will discuss national reconciliation and the NLD's dominance in the new parliament, set to sit in February.

site_title: Australia: Shares turn lower on weak commodities, China woes
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Monday due to a broad-based sell-off sparked by lower commodities prices and concerns about China's equity markets. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 36.1 points to 5,166.5, marking a 1.4% decline for the month. New Zealand's NZX 50 index remained flat.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda dismisses calls to go slow in hitting inflation target
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has dismissed calls to slow down in hitting the 2% inflation target, stating that the central bank must take necessary steps to achieve its goal. Kuroda emphasized the need for price increases to break deflation and urged the BOJ to be proactive, warning that slow price growth would also slow wage adjustments. This comes as Japan struggles with slow wage growth and a slowdown in China, which has contributed to the country's recession. The BOJ is expected to continue its aggressive monetary policies to achieve its inflation target.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda puts US$680m Eagle High stake deal on hold: sources
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd has put on hold a planned $680 million purchase of 30% of Indonesian palm plantation PT Eagle High Plantations due to shareholder criticism and deteriorating market conditions. The deal was initially announced in June, but Felda has extended deadlines and is now restructuring the deal without providing details. Felda's shares have fallen 8% since initial reports of the deal emerged, and the company's spokeswoman declined to comment on the matter. The companies plan to announce the restructuring on Monday.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd, the world's No.3 palm plantation operator, has put on hold a planned US$680 million purchase in Indonesia after shareholders criticised the deal as too expensive and market conditions deteriorated, sources directly involved with the matter said.

site_title: South Korea IT firms see shares surge after online banking nod
summary: South Korea's top messaging app operator, Kakao Corp, and telco major KT Corp, have seen their shares surge after being named by financial regulators as one of two companies permitted to start Internet-only banking services. Kakao's share price rose 13%, while KT Corp's jumped 5.0%, with Kakao aiming to start operations as early as the latter half of next year. This move is expected to create fresh competition in the banking industry and create job opportunities, with the companies also planning to expand their services to Southeast Asian nations.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall, weighed by China market losses
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 1.6% to 8,264.55, weighed down by losses in China's markets, which slid 5% in the previous session. Taiwan's export-driven economy has been impacted by a slowdown in mainland China and global markets. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.136 per U.S. dollar.

site_title: Oil dips on firm dollar, ahead of Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday due to a firm dollar and anticipation of an Opec meeting later this week. Brent crude fell 25 cents to $44.61 a barrel, while US crude dropped 10 cents to $41.61. Despite expectations of no production cuts, analysts believe Saudi Arabia may consider price support measures. Opec's research team forecasts higher demand for oil in 2016, potentially reducing the supply glut. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and upcoming non-farm payrolls report will also impact oil prices.

site_title: China: Stocks end flat after volatile session
summary: China's stock market ended flat on Monday after a highly volatile session, with major indexes swinging wildly. The CSI300 index rose 0.3% to 3,566.41, and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.3% to 3,445.40 points. Despite a 5% slump on Friday, bargain hunters lifted the gauges into positive territory. Analysts differ on the market's future, with some expecting a short-term correction and others warning of a potential repeat of the summer market rout due to economic concerns and a depreciating yuan.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei slips amid China concerns but gains in November
summary: The Nikkei share average fell 0.7% to 19,747.47, but still gained 3.5% for the month of November. Industrial production in Japan fell short of expectations in October, and concerns about China's economic strength impacted Japan's exports and production, leading to a bumpy week. Despite this, the Nikkei managed to test support levels and edge up 3.5% for the month, while the broader Topix slipped 0.9% to 1,580.25.

site_title: Singapore to get Michelin Guide in 2016
summary: Singapore will receive its first Michelin Guide in the second half of 2016, marking the city-state as the first South-east Asian country to have the prestigious culinary guide. The bilingual guide will feature English and Chinese text, joining Japan, Hong Kong, and Macau as the only Asian countries with Michelin guides.

site_title: Australia: Shares feel the pressure of weak commodity prices
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.6% on Monday, weighed down by weak commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 32.8 points to 5,169.8, with the materials sector particularly affected. Top miners BHP and Rio Tinto fell 2.7% and 1.64%, respectively, due to rising costs and US dollar strength. The major banks edged up, while healthcare shares and technology provider 3D Medical Ltd rose.

site_title: Jason Holdings exec chairman sued by CIMB Securities in personal contractual dispute
summary: Jason Holdings executive chairman Jason Sim Chon Ang is being sued by CIMB Securities over a contractual dispute in his personal capacity. The company's board believes Sim is suitable to continue as executive chairman and CEO, but will monitor the claim's progress. Jason Holdings' share price has declined 11.4% to seven Singapore cents after a sharp rise over 2014 and 2015.

site_title: Data breach at Hong Kong toy maker VTech highlights broader problems
summary: VTech, a Hong Kong-based toy maker, suffered a data breach resulting in the theft of customer information, including names, email addresses, passwords, and home addresses of parents and children. The breach, which affected 4.8 million parents and over 200,000 children, highlights the vulnerability of small non-financial companies to cyber attacks. Industry experts say this trend will continue as more devices are connected to the internet and companies collect personal information.

images.alt_text: The theft of toy maker VTech Holdings Ltd's database highlights a growing problem with basic cyber security measures at small, non-financial companies that handle electronic customer data, industry watchers said on Monday.

site_title: Prices of completed non-landed private homes in Singapore up 0.1% m-o-m in Oct: NUS
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes saw a 0.1% month-over-month increase in October, according to the National University of Singapore's flash estimate. This follows a 0.3% rise in September. The Central Region saw a 0.3% gain, while Non-Central Region prices remained unchanged. Small apartments and condo units (up to 506 sq. ft.) fell 0.6% in October, after a 0.7% drop in September.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore labour force participation rate up, median income up 4.7% to S$3,949 a month
summary: The Singapore labour force participation rate rose to 68.3% in June, marking a fourth consecutive year of increase. Median monthly income from work for full-time employed residents grew 4.7% to S$3,949, while incomes excluding employer CPF rose 5.8%. However, older workers faced challenges, with the unemployment rate for those aged 50 and above increasing to 3.3%. The report also noted that some older and less educated workers continued to struggle.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post worst day in nearly 10 weeks; won down
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 1.8% on Monday, marking the worst day in nearly 10 weeks, as investors avoided risk after Chinese stocks extended losses. Foreign investors sold 538.7 billion won of KOSPI shares, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,991.97 points. This is the largest one-day percentage loss since September 23.

site_title: Ex-Malaysia envoy guilty of New Zealand indecent assault
summary: A former Malaysian diplomat, Mohammed Rizalman bin Ismail, pleaded guilty to indecent assault in New Zealand, admitting to bursting into a woman's bedroom naked from the waist down. He had initially fled citing diplomatic immunity but was extradited to face charges. The original charges of attempted rape and burglary were dismissed as Rizalman admitted to one count of indecent assault. A hearing into disputed aspects of the case will take place before sentencing, with a possible home detention sentence allowing him to serve it at the Malaysian embassy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OKP, Jumbo and others
summary: Newly listed Jumbo Group reported a 8% decline in full-year profit to S$10.6 million, despite a 9% increase in revenue to S$122.8 million. OKP Holdings won a S$94.6 million contract from the Land Transport Authority for a viaduct construction project. Other stocks announcing full-year results include Keong Hong Holdings, Nam Lee Pressed Metal Industries, and Chew's Group.

site_title: China Fibretech suspends share trading after unit receives damage claims
summary: China Fibretech has suspended trading of its shares after its subsidiary, Shishi Simwa Knitting & Dyeing Co, Ltd, received damage claims from three customers. The customers alleged "substantial damages and financial losses" due to non-compliant products, delivered in 2014 and early 2015. The company's CEO, Wu Xinhua, stated that management will investigate the claims before reporting to the board of directors and considering compensation. Trading will remain suspended until further notice to ensure a fair and orderly market. The validity of the claims remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda warns of risk from emerging market slowdown
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned of potential risks to Japanese business confidence due to a prolonged slowdown in emerging economies. He emphasized the BOJ's willingness to respond with stimulus measures if necessary to achieve its 2% inflation target. The BOJ has maintained its massive stimulus program since October, despite the economy's recession and falling energy costs. Kuroda's comments came as emerging economies face slowdowns, potentially affecting global economic trends.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall on China worries; ECB in focus
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.7% on Monday, pressured by a decline in Chinese markets and anticipation of possibly more volatility ahead of Chinese surveys on manufacturing and services. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,995.04 points. Tech stocks underperformed, with Samsung Electronics and LG Display falling 2.7% and 1.8% respectively. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares, and the South Korean won fell 0.3% against the dollar ahead of the European Central Bank's expected stimulus announcement on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.18 points to 1675.41, following a 7-day winning streak. Losers outnumbered gainers 84 to 77, and volume reached RM12.8 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday ahead of busy news week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Monday at 2,866.01 points, up 6.89 points or 0.24%, ahead of a busy news week including the potential inclusion of the renminbi as a global reserve currency and European Central Bank easing. The top stocks traded by value were DBS, OCBC, City Developments, Global Logistic Properties, and Singtel, with gains outmatching losers 64 to 60.

site_title: VW to recall 2.46m German cars with illegal software
summary: Volkswagen will recall 2.46 million German cars with illegal software, including 1.54 million Volkswagen-branded, 531,813 Audi, 286,970 Skoda, and 104,197 Seat models. The company has set aside 8.5 billion euros for fixes and 2 billion euros for compensation payments. Analysts estimate the costs could top 40 billion euros, citing fines, lawsuits, and vehicle refits due to the manipulation of diesel emissions tests. Volkswagen has approval from Germany's KBA for fixes for over 90% of the affected cars.

site_title: New Zealand business sentiment rises to 6-mth high in November: survey
summary: New Zealand business sentiment reached a six-month high in November, according to an ANZ Bank survey, with a net 14.6% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the year ahead. This represents a 3.1% increase from the previous poll. Meanwhile, 32% of respondents expected their own businesses to grow in the next 12 months, up from 23.7% last month. Inflation expectations eased to 1.64%.

site_title: Japan PM's support rebounds after difficult debate over security laws
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's public support has rebounded to 49% after the passage of controversial security laws, according to media surveys. The laws allow the military to fight overseas for the first time since World War Two. Despite this, 57% of respondents felt there was no need to rush to revise the pacifist constitution, a long-held goal of Abe's. Support for Abe's cabinet rose eight points, and his Liberal Democratic Party's support increased to 36.7%. The upper house election next year may influence Abe's pledge to refocus on Japan's economy.

site_title: Mini-vans the next big thing as China eases one-child policy
summary: China's relaxation of the one-child policy is expected to boost the popularity of mini-vans, or multi-purpose vehicles (MPVs), as families with extended members seek practical and affordable transportation options. Industry experts predict that MPV sales will grow faster than the entire auto market, potentially making China the largest MPV market after the US. MPV sales in China increased 7.8% in the first 10 months of the year, outperforming the overall car market's 1.5% growth. Automakers like Volkswagen and GAC Motor are investing in MPV models to capitalize on the trend.

site_title: Lower taxes for 93% of residential property owners in Singapore: Iras
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (Iras) announced that 93% of residential property owners will pay lower property taxes in 2016. Public housing flat owners will not pay any property tax, with savings ranging from 9% to 24%. Private residential property owners will see tax savings of 3% to 20%, with over 80% eligible for the reduction. The tax savings are due to annual value reviews, which adjust property tax rates based on prevailing market rentals. The changes will take effect from January 1, 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Amazon releases video showcasing unmanned delivery drones
summary: Amazon has released a video showcasing its unmanned delivery drones, which can fly up to 400 feet and stay airborne for 15 minutes. The prototype technology was announced two years ago, and the company plans to have the drones in service at an unspecified time. The video, narrated by Jeremy Clarkson, shows a drone delivering a package to a family in about 30 minutes. The Federal Aviation Administration expects to finalize regulations for commercial drone operations within the next 12 months, potentially paving the way for Amazon's drone delivery system.

site_title: Greek central bank chief says need political consensus to end debt crisis
summary: Greek central bank governor Yannis Stournaras urged party leaders to maintain political consensus to help Greece exit its financial crisis. This comes after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras failed to secure opposition backing for pension reforms. Stournaras emphasized the need for consensus to secure stability, debt relief, and growth. Greece agreed on new reforms with international lenders to qualify for additional aid, with pension reforms remaining a key issue. The Greek people are weary after six years of austerity, and legislating painful pension reforms will be a test of Tsipras's coalition government.

site_title: About 100 passengers rescued after Batam-Singapore ferry hits floating object
summary: A ferry carrying 97 passengers from Batam to Singapore hit a floating object and began to sink, prompting a rescue operation. All passengers were safely rescued by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore. The incident occurred after the ferry left the Nongsapura ferry terminal in Batam. No injuries were reported, and the cause of the collision is currently under investigation.

site_title: China, Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly lower after biggest drop since summer rout
summary: China stocks opened slightly lower on Monday, falling 0.1% to 3,554.89 on the CSI300 index, after a 5% drop on Friday triggered by concerns over a widening probe into brokerages. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.1% to 3,433.86 points. The market's biggest drop since summer was linked to Haitong Securities being probed by China's securities regulator.

site_title: Assad says enemies boosting his opponents
summary: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad claimed his enemies are increasing support for rebels fighting his regime, citing Russia and Iran's backing as key factors in the surge. The statement came after Russia's air strikes on a rebel-held town in Syria, which killed 18 civilians and wounded 40. Britain is pressing to join a US-led air coalition against the Islamic State in Syria, with Defence Secretary Michael Fallon lobbying the opposition Labour party for support. Meanwhile, thousands protested in London and Madrid against military action in Syria.

site_title: TUI Group picks Singapore as seasonal base for cruise operations
summary: TUI Group has chosen Singapore as its seasonal cruise base for the northern winter, with the Mein Schiff 1 departing on three seven-day routes to Malaysia, Vietnam, and Thailand. The move aims to grow the company's presence in South-east Asia, with 2,000 passengers expected to depart weekly from Marina Bay Cruise Terminal. TUI expects to increase bookings to Asia, with a 45% rise in Germany for Singapore and a 15% rise for the entire region. The partnership with the Singapore Tourism Board and Changi Airport Group is expected to attract over 90,000 cruise passengers and generate S$50 million in tourism receipts.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan's factory output rose 1.4% in October
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.4% in October, marking the second straight monthly increase, according to the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry. This growth was attributed to increased production of general machinery, transport equipment, and electronic parts. However, the ministry expects production to fall 0.9% in December, citing "one step forward and one step back" in overall production. This comes after Japan's GDP shrank 0.2% in the July-September period, amid weak household spending and falling prices.

images.alt_text: Japan's factory output rose 1.4 per cent in October year on year, marking the second straight monthly rise, the government said on Monday.

site_title: Gearing up for climate change
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, as part of its efforts to combat climate change. The city-state is also exploring the introduction of carbon offsetting legislation for airlines and has seen significant growth in its sustainability-aligned investments, valued at $46 billion in FY2025. Additionally, Temasek's subsidiary SIA has reported a high burden of sustainability-related costs, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is evolving its climate investing approach and deepening cooperation with the People's Bank of China in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore bank lending falls again in October
summary: Singapore bank lending fell 1.1% in October to S$602 billion, a deeper contraction than September's 0.8% decline. This marks the second consecutive month of decline in bank lending, primarily due to weaker business loans. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported a 1.1% decrease in domestic banking unit loans, down from S$608 billion in September.

site_title: CPF rates maintained for Q1 2016
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) rates for Q1 2016 will remain unchanged, with the Ordinary Account (OA) maintaining a legislated minimum of 2.5% per year. The concessionary interest rate for HDB mortgage loans will stay at 2.6% per year. Special and Medisave Account monies will earn a floor interest rate of 4% per year, and new Retirement Account monies will earn a fixed rate of 4% for the full year of 2016. These rates apply from January 1 to March 31, 2016.

images.alt_text: Central Provident Fund (CPF) rates will be maintained at current levels from Jan 1 to March 31 next year, said a joint press release from CPF Board and the Housing and Development Board.

site_title: US holiday sales on track amid online boost: NRF survey
summary: US holiday shopping sales are on track for a 3.7% rise this year, driven by strong online sales and a modest increase in in-store shopping, according to the National Retail Federation. The industry group's survey found that shoppers spent an average of $300 over the four-day weekend, with 151 million people expected to shop in stores and online. Online sales jumped, balancing out slowing in-store demand, and retailers are optimistic about the holiday season despite concerns about price competition.

images.alt_text: US holiday shopping is on track for a modest 3.7 per cent rise this year after strong turnout during the Thanksgiving and Black Friday weekend and thanks to strong online sales, the National Retail Federation said on Sunday after releasing an annual consumer poll.

site_title: Defiant Trump refuses to take back 9/11 cheering claim
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump refused to retract claims that Arab and Muslim Americans cheered after the 9/11 attacks, despite lack of proof. Trump stated he saw footage on TV, citing hundreds of phone calls from supporters, but was contradicted by police, fact-checkers, and media at the time. Trump cited a 2001 article from The Washington Post, but it showed no evidence of widespread cheering. Trump said he wouldn't take back his statement, sparking widespread condemnation.

site_title: Chinese banks challenged to fill half-trillion TLAC capital gap
summary: China's four largest banks face significant funding costs due to global rules requiring them to issue hundreds of billions of dollars of capital to meet total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) standards. The shortfall is estimated at US$553 billion, far more than the US$115 billion needed for US banks and the US$201 billion for European banks. The banks will need to issue capital at yields higher than they're accustomed to, making it challenging to find buyers, particularly from overseas markets. This poses a significant challenge for China's banks to comply with worldwide standards.

site_title: Oil prices rise slightly as investors away Opec meeting
summary: Crude oil prices rose slightly in early Asian trade on Monday, driven by a slight increase in US crude oil to $41.88 a barrel. However, gains were limited due to investors' concerns about an Opec meeting on December 4, where ministers will set policy amidst a market still in a glut. Oil prices are expected to decline by 10% this month, with Brent crude forecast to drop 9.4% in November. Opec officials question the group's optimistic forecast, with some doubting a quick easing of the supply glut in 2016.

site_title: Turkey and EU strike 3b euro migrant aid deal
summary: Turkey and the European Union agreed on a $4.5 billion aid deal to stem the flow of Syrian refugees and other migrants to Europe. The deal includes three billion euros in aid to refugees in Turkey and steps to prevent refugees from reaching Europe. In return, Turkey will accelerate its bid for EU membership, with the EU agreeing to open a new chapter in the accession process and hold regular summits. The deal aims to address the EU's worst refugee crisis since World War II, with over 850,000 people entering the bloc this year.

site_title: Manila mall operators looking to add record space
summary: Manila mall operators, such as SM Prime Holdings and Ayala Land, are racing to add new retail space to meet the growing demand from South-east Asia's most-confident consumers. A record 724,620 square metres of new retail space will be added in 2016, with private consumption accounting for 60% of the Philippine economy. Rising remittances and a business-process outsourcing boom are fuelling household spending, with consumer sentiment remaining positive and buying intentions steady next year.

site_title: Euro holds drop as ECB week begins with all eyes on China stocks
summary: The euro is expected to drop further this week amid expectations of the European Central Bank's monetary policy easing. Chinese stocks are also under scrutiny following regulatory probes into local brokerages, with the Shanghai-traded shares slumping the most in three months. The focus is shifting to policy divergence and how other central banks may respond to US policy tightening, with odds of a US interest-rate increase in December above 70%. The euro is trading around its weakest level in over seven months against the dollar.

site_title: OKP Holdings wins S$94.6m LTA project
summary: OKP Holdings won a S$94.6 million contract from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to construct a viaduct from the Tampines Expressway to the Pan Island Expressway (Westbound) and Upper Changi Road East. The contract began on Nov 23, 2015, and is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2020. This brings OKP's total 2015 contract value to S$291.3 million, with the company's stock price increasing by 10% following the announcement.

site_title: South Korea's October factory output surprisingly falls
summary: South Korea's industrial output unexpectedly fell 1.4% in October from September, the largest drop since May, contrary to a 0.2% rise forecast. The September reading was revised up to a 2.2% increase. On an annual basis, industrial output rose 1.5% in October, after a revised 2.8% rise in September. The service sector also saw a slower monthly growth of 0.2%, down from 1.1% in September. The data raises concerns about a sustained recovery in the country's economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip as Topix heads for second monthly increase
summary: Japanese stocks slipped, with the Topix index falling 0.3% to 1,590.08, on track for a second monthly gain. Steel manufacturers led declines, while electrical appliance makers rose. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average also fell 0.3%. Despite a strong dollar and expectations of a US interest rate hike, investors are optimistic about Japanese corporate earnings and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic growth measures, which include a new budget to boost the economy.

site_title: Opec rivals become unwitting allies in push for oil-market share
summary: Saudi Arabia and Iran, Opec adversaries, are becoming unwitting allies in their efforts to increase oil-market share. Following the US shale oil surge, Saudi Arabia pushed for Opec to keep pumping, while Iran initially resisted but is now set to amplify the strategy with increased crude exports after sanctions end. This move is seen as "Iran's return is effectively the Saudi policy on steroids," according to Societe Generale's Mike Wittner. The unlikely partnership aims to counter US shale oil dominance and boost prices.

images.alt_text: Almost by accident, Opec adversaries Saudi Arabia and Iran are about to work as a team.

site_title: Local SMEs positioned to weather headwinds
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are well-positioned to weather global economic headwinds by building new capabilities and leveraging technology. Experts say talent acquisition and strengthening senior management teams are key to driving growth. The government should streamline existing schemes to support SMEs, with a focus on lifelong learning and skills mastery. Despite slowing growth in China, the impact is expected to be felt globally but not through a massive renminbi devaluation.

site_title: Jokowi's US$4b model power plant faces day in court over land
summary: Indonesia's top court is set to rule on whether the government can forcibly purchase land from farmers refusing to make way for a US$4 billion coal-fired power plant in Java. The project, stalled since 2012, was formally launched by President Joko Widodo in August, but full-scale construction has yet to begin. The government has used a never-before-used law to allow for compulsory land purchases, but villagers backed by Greenpeace are challenging this in court. A decision in favor of the government could boost Widodo's image, but some farmers say they will refuse to leave their land, raising human rights concerns.

site_title: Record watch sale to heighten demand for luxury timepieces
summary: A record-breaking Swiss francs 7.3 million (S$10 million) price was achieved for the Patek Philippe Reference 5016A-010 wristwatch at the Only Watch auction in Geneva. The sale, held on November 7, was 10 times the low estimate, with two anonymous telephone bidders competing for nine minutes before the hammer fell. The charity event, organized by Phillips, raised funds for a good cause. This sale heightens demand for luxury timepieces and showcases the exclusivity and value of high-end watches.

site_title: Singapore to shift to even greener footing
summary: Singapore has committed to reducing its carbon emissions intensity by 36% by 2030, from 2005 levels, in a bid to meet the goals of the UN climate change talks in Paris. The city-state aims to achieve this by increasing energy efficiency, adopting cleaner technologies, and promoting sustainable growth. With current renewable energy sources accounting for only 8% of its energy mix, Singapore is focusing on solar power and energy efficiency measures to reduce emissions. The government has also identified the clean technology sector as a growth area, with significant potential for job creation and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Starting on Monday, world leaders from 190 countries will gather in Paris over the next two weeks to finalise a new global climate accord aimed at reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Beijing issues orange alert for heavy smog
summary: Beijing issues its highest smog alert this year, urging residents to stay indoors due to hazardous air pollution levels exceeding 15 times recommended levels of PM2.5. The alert comes as global leaders gather in Paris for a climate change summit. Industrial plants must reduce production, and large trucks are banned from the roads. China's coal-burning for heating contributes to the pollution, and hundreds of thousands of people joined worldwide protests against the issue.

site_title: Massive rallies for the climate, but violence in Paris
summary: Thousands of people gathered in Paris on the eve of a UN climate summit, defying the threat of terrorism with emotional protests and human chains. However, clashes broke out between anti-capitalist militants and riot police, detaining over 200 people. Despite the violence, hundreds of thousands participated in global climate rallies worldwide, with 500,000 people co-organizing the protests. The UN summit aims to limit global warming and avert catastrophic climate change, with 150 world leaders attending the talks.

site_title: GSH gearing up for leadership transition
summary: Singapore-listed GSH Corp, a real estate firm, is poised for a leadership transition as its founder and chairman Sam Goi prepares to step aside. Goi has been training his children to take over the business, with his eldest daughter and two sons already involved in various pockets of the family business. The succession plan has no definitive timeline, but Goi is confident that his children are ready to lead. The company has seen significant transformation under Goi's leadership, including a 60% improvement in topline revenue and a net profit of S$6.5 million in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Africa to focus on its China debts at summit
summary: African countries are expected to discuss renegotiating existing debts to China, which has provided over $32 billion in loans to the continent in the past two years. China will also offer new loans and investment opportunities, including in manufacturing and infrastructure projects. The summit aims to address concerns about China's labor practices and the lack of skills and technology transfer to African economies. Experts expect China to push for new loan and trade proposals despite its own slowing economy, with key themes including Africa's growing debt to China and China's domestic stimulus to reignite commodity demand.

site_title: Iran eyes US$25b in investments from 50 oil & gas deals
summary: Iran is seeking $25 billion in investments from 50 oil and gas deals with international companies, with the goal of lifting US sanctions in early 2016. The new Iran Petroleum Contract (IPC) will replace "buy-back" agreements and launch joint ventures for crude oil and gas production, with international companies paid a share of the total output. The contracts will initially be four years in length, with Iran paying back initial sums invested by foreign companies once production starts, but cooperation and development can go on for up to 25 years.

site_title: Fossil fuels still key in green-energy future: Statoil
summary: Norwegian oil giant Statoil estimates the world will need another 5-6 Saudi Arabias in production by 2040 to meet global energy demands, despite efforts to cap global warming at 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels. The company believes fossil fuels will still play a key role in the future, with natural gas being the cleanest option. Statoil is pushing for a level playing field for carbon tax, advocating for uniform charges across countries and regions to ensure regulatory arbitrage is eliminated.

site_title: Nippon Life plans Japan's largest REIT as investors crave yield
summary: Nippon Life Insurance Co plans to launch Japan's largest private real estate investment trust (REIT) with a target of 300 billion yen, seeking 4% returns. The fund, managed by Nippon Life Realty Management Inc, will initially target 100 billion yen and aim to collect 300 billion yen in the mid-to-long term. It will be open to large Japanese investors such as pension funds and banks. This move comes as investors seek higher yields due to low government bond yields.

site_title: Cameron, Tusk see progress despite 'difficult' EU talks
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron and European Union president Donald Tusk made progress in talks on London's EU reform goals despite difficulties. They discussed the UK renegotiation in a bilateral meeting and agreed to continue making progress in four key areas. The talks come as doubts grow about securing a deal by the December EU summit, with Cameron pledging to win reforms by the end of 2017. Cameron's proposals include improved competitiveness, fairness, and sovereignty issues, with a focus on banning EU migrants from claiming certain state benefits for four years after arriving.

images.alt_text: European Council president Donald Tusk (right) shakes hands with British Prime Minister David Cameron during a bilateral meeting at the EU headquarters in Brussels on Nov 29, 2015.

site_title: IMF expected to include yuan in SDR basket
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is expected to approve the inclusion of China's yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, rewarding Beijing's pursuit of global status. The decision, set to take effect on September 30, 2016, marks a major diplomatic success for China, with the yuan's weight in the basket likely to be between 10-16%. The inclusion is seen as a significant step in the yuan's globalisation, but may face opposition from US lawmakers amid concerns over trade and currency manipulation.

site_title: Black Friday shopping frenzy moves from stores to online
summary: US shoppers shifted their Black Friday frenzy to online shopping this year, with eBay and Wal-Mart reporting significant sales. Adobe tracked over 180 million visits to US retail websites, with $1.73 billion in online sales, a 22% increase from 2014. Mobile devices accounted for 60% of traffic, with shoppers spending $822 million online between midnight and 11am on Friday. Brick-and-mortar stores saw less action, with traffic across apparel and department stores considered "uninspiring." Online sales are expected to reach $2.6 billion, a 14% increase from last year.

site_title: Show me the oden
summary: Ginza Yoshihiro, a sushi joint in Marina Mandarin Singapore, offers a unique blend of sushi and oden. Although oden is its selling point, the restaurant primarily serves sushi, tempura, sukiyaki, and tendon. The omakase options, priced at S$148 and S$168, feature various combinations of appetizers, sashimi, sushi, and oden. The "signature oden" is a single, fat momotaro tomato in a clear broth, which is not what the reviewer expected. The restaurant's identity is lacking, and the menu could be improved to stand out from other sushi bars. Rating: 6.

site_title: Nearly 75% of Poiz Residences units in Potong Pasir snapped up
summary: Nearly 75% of Poiz Residences units in Potong Pasir sold, with 260 out of 350 units snapped up by buyers, representing 35.57% of the total 731 units. Prices averaged S$1,380 per square foot. The project, developed by MCC Land, sold out units evenly distributed among one- to four-bedroom units, with Singaporeans accounting for 98% of buyers. The Poiz Centre, part of the mixed-use development, will span 50,000 sq ft with 84 shops, including 10% allocated to food and beverages.

site_title: Garden variety Chinese, with flashes of potential
summary: Avenue Joffre, a Shanghai-themed Chinese restaurant at Resorts World Sentosa, offers a mixed experience. The menu features Cantonese and other Chinese dishes, but the emphasis is on Cantonese fare with little distinction between styles. Service is efficient but lacking in knowledge, with staff seemingly indifferent to the origins of dishes. However, flashes of potential are evident in some dishes, such as the juicy pork belly and white pepper crab. To elevate the experience, the restaurant needs to sharpen its act and provide more distinct and well-prepared dishes. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: Buying and buybacks continue to rise, selling down
summary: SIA Engineering and United Overseas Bank (UOB) saw significant buyback activity in the fourth week of November, with SIA Engineering repurchasing shares for the first time since listing in May 2000. UOB chairman Wee Cho Yaw also resumed buying shares at a higher price. Other companies with notable buyback activity include ISEC Healthcare, Mewah International, and Zagro Asia. In contrast, directors at Pacific Radiance and Viva Industrial Trust sold shares, while Cityneon Holdings and ISEC Healthcare saw buying activity from their CEOs. The buyback activity was driven by the decline in share prices.

site_title: Activity trackers new area of growth
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) market, particularly in healthcare and sports activity trackers, is expected to reach $7.1 trillion by 2020. Wearable device shipments are projected to surpass 140 million in 2016, generating nearly $30 billion in revenue. Companies like Jawbone and Fitbit have dominated the market, but recent high-profile launches of smartwatches from Apple and Samsung may impact the space. Experts believe that activity trackers like Jawbone's UP3 will continue to thrive, as they offer 24/7 wearability and comprehensive health and wellness tracking.

site_title: Women and poor not as financially literate
summary: A recent global survey by Standard & Poor's found that women and the poor are less financially literate than men and wealthier individuals, respectively. In Singapore, 67% of men and 52% of women are financially literate, with a 15 percentage point gap. Financial literacy is higher among the wealthy, well-educated, and those who use financial services. The survey, which polled over 150,000 people in 140 economies, found that just 1 in 3 adults worldwide are financially literate, with the highest rates found in Norway, Denmark, and Sweden.

site_title: Fossil fuel divestment drive gathers momentum
summary: A global campaign to divest from fossil fuels is gaining momentum, with major players such as banks and investment funds joining the movement. The campaign began in the US in 2008 and has since spread to Norway, which recently divested its sovereign wealth fund from coal, and many advanced nations that have restricted subsidies for coal-fired power plants.

site_title: Rosberg ends F1 season on hat-trick high
summary: Nico Rosberg secured his third consecutive win and 16th of the season, finishing 8.2 seconds behind teammate Lewis Hamilton in the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. Hamilton clinched his championship with 10 victories, one fewer than in 2014, and finished second for the 12th one-two finish of the year for Mercedes. Rosberg's hat-trick win was his sixth of the season and 14th of his career, securing a dominant end to the season for the team.

site_title: Absence of optimism in next year's outlook
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to see a lackluster performance in 2016 due to a combination of factors, including the European Central Bank's potential rate cuts and the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hikes. China's yuan may also be devalued if it's admitted as a reserve currency. The US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting on Dec 15-16 is expected to bring significant changes to the market, with interest rates potentially rising by 0.25-0.5% in 2016. Despite some positive signals, market optimists should temper their expectations for a drastic turnaround in fortunes.

site_title: Asian central banks seek tools to defend growth
summary: Asian central banks emphasized the need for expanded policy instruments and careful coordination to defend growth and financial stability amid increased global economic uncertainty. Risks to stability may be transmitted through trade, foreign exchange, interest rates, and capital flows. The governors also highlighted the importance of strengthening domestic economies and reforming the international monetary system to address challenges. Despite a slowdown in growth in some developing nations, Asia is expected to expand 5.4% in 2015 and 2016, outpacing the global economy's growth of 3.1% and 3.6% for the same periods.

site_title: UK to stay high-borrowing welfare state with cutback in austerity policies
summary: The UK government has announced plans to maintain a high-borrowing welfare state, scaling back austerity policies in its latest spending review. Chancellor George Osborne is raising stamp duty on new rental properties and relying on growth forecasts of 2.4% per annum to finance spending and slash the government deficit. Despite claims to cut the welfare state, total government spending has increased to £773 billion in 2015, and public spending is projected to rise to £821 billion in five years. Economists have criticized Osborne's reliance on optimistic forecasts and predicted economic growth of 1.8% per annum.

site_title: Paris attacks reveal troubling dark side to using anonymous prepaid cards
summary: Paris terror attacks have revealed a dark side of using anonymous prepaid cards, which were initially seen as a positive development for those excluded from the banking system. Attackers used prepaid cards to rent hotel rooms, avoiding detection by intelligence agencies, and to launder funds. Prepaid cards have become a popular payment method, with 11.4 billion transactions worldwide in 2012, but their anonymity has raised concerns that they may be used by criminals to hide their activities. French authorities plan to reduce the amounts that can be charged without identification and identify the need for identification from the first euro.

site_title: Three China brokerages under probe
summary: China's securities regulator is investigating three brokerages, Citic Securities Co, Haitong Securities Co, and Guosen Securities Co, over alleged breaches of margin-trading rules. The probe involves contracts signed with clients on margin finances and short-selling, and the firms have cooperated with the regulator. The investigation comes amid a government crackdown on malpractice in the securities industry, following a $5 trillion US stock-market rout this summer. The three brokerages' shares declined significantly, with Citic dropping 10% in Shanghai and Guosen closing 10% lower in Shenzhen.

site_title: When shareholders have a say on pay
summary: Shareholders in developed economies are increasingly calling for greater oversight of executive pay, leading to the adoption of "Say on Pay" mechanisms. This involves voting exercises at annual general meetings to express views on companies' executive remuneration practices. The goal is to ensure fair pay commensurate with company performance. In countries like the UK and US, Say on Pay votes can be binding, while in Singapore, no such mechanism exists. The movement aims to address concerns about inequality in pay and excessive remuneration for senior executives.

site_title: Andy Murray ends 79 years' British wait for Davis Cup
summary: Britain won the Davis Cup for the first time in 79 years, defeating Belgium 3-1 in the final. Andy Murray, the world number two, defeated David Goffin 6-3, 7-5, 6-3, securing the winning point and cementing his place in tennis history. This victory marked the first time Britain has won the tournament since 1936, with Murray winning all 11 singles rubbers in the campaign.

site_title: China's shadow banking risk shifts to booming bond market
summary: China's shadow banking risk has shifted to the booming corporate bond market, with new bond issuance reaching 914 billion yuan in the third quarter, accounting for 29% of all new credit. Regulators allowed unlisted companies to issue bonds on public exchanges, and wealth managers are now turning these bonds into leveraged high-yielding products, sold to investors desperate for returns. Analysts warn that this trend may create speculative activity and forces that regulators can't handle, echoing the stock market boom that preceded a summer crash.

site_title: Rosberg ends F1 season on a hat-trick high
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Formula One season finale in Abu Dhabi, securing his third consecutive victory and 16th win of the season for Mercedes. Lewis Hamilton finished second, ending his championship-winning season with 10 victories, despite attempting a different strategy. Rosberg's win marked a dominant performance by Mercedes, with the team achieving a record 12th one-two finish.

site_title: Oil prices gain ahead of Opec meeting
summary: World oil prices rose ahead of the Opec meeting, with Brent crude edging higher to $44.93 a barrel. Analysts expect the cartel to stick to its current production target of 30 million barrels per day, despite concerns about geopolitical tensions disrupting Middle East supplies. The meeting, scheduled for December 4, is expected to maintain the status quo, with oil market oversupply expected to continue due to US shale production and high Opec output.

images.alt_text: Most analysts expect Opec to stick to its target output of 30m barrels of oil per day when members meet in Vienna on Dec 4.

site_title: India's SpiceJet says it has received interest from Gulf airlines
summary: SpiceJet, an Indian budget airline, has received interest from Gulf airlines looking to acquire a stake. Chairman Ajay Singh stated that the airline is not ready to dilute its equity, as shares remain undervalued. SpiceJet plans to order new planes, including over 150 single-aisle jets, and is in talks with suppliers like Boeing and Airbus. The airline aims to use the new aircraft to open new routes and increase flight frequencies, generating enough cash internally to sustain the orders.

site_title: Rate cut, more stimulus in store at ECB meet: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to cut interest rates and increase asset purchases at its upcoming meeting, aiming to boost weak inflation in the eurozone. Global growth is forecast to be the weakest since 2009, and the eurozone's rebound is the lowest since 1998. Analysts predict a decisive move to stimulate the economy, with some warning that any less than expected measures would be a disappointment. The ECB has already launched a 1.1-trillion-euro quantitative easing program to lift consumer prices.

site_title: Singapore starts new public engagement initiative, looking at SG100
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong launched a new public engagement initiative, SGfuture, to gather ideas for the country's future until 2030. The initiative aims to strengthen national unity and build on the Our Singapore Conversation, which began in 2012. Minister Grace Fu will lead the series, which will include focused discussions, dialogue sessions, and workshops to turn ideas into reality. The goal is to maintain unity as Singapore charts its way forward, despite emerging "new fault lines."

site_title: Growth amid uncertainty seen in 2016
summary: Singapore's top management believes the region's cornerstones for growth are in place despite 2015's volatility. Industry leaders are focusing on strengthening capabilities to take advantage of new growth opportunities. Economies are strengthening cooperation to stabilize growth, with key capabilities including data centers and other areas. Industry leaders are optimistic about the future, citing Asean's efforts to promote economic growth and stability.

site_title: Rate cut, more stimulus in store at ECB meet: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to cut interest rates and increase its trillion-euro asset purchases to combat weak inflation in the eurozone. Analysts expect a decisive move, citing Draghi's dovish signals, and warn that any less-than-expected action would be a disappointment. The ECB has already launched a 1.1-trillion-euro quantitative easing program, but inflation remains below target, prompting calls for further stimulus to boost consumer prices.

site_title: Africa to focus on China debt at Jo'burg summit as commodities slump
summary: African countries may renegotiate existing debts with China due to the slump in commodity prices, but are unlikely to reject new loan offers. China is expected to push for new investments in factories, roads, and railways, despite its own slowing economy. Experts say African economies should focus on institutionalizing intellectual property and developing skills, rather than relying on loans. China's investments in Africa have fallen 40% in the first half of 2015, but the country is expected to continue providing support and loans to the continent.

site_title: Facebook makes paid time off for baby leave a global benefit
summary: Facebook is extending its paid parental leave policy globally, providing four months of paid time off to all new parents, regardless of location or gender. The policy, which was previously only available to US-based employees, will be implemented starting January 1. The move follows Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's announcement of taking two months of paternity leave after the birth of his daughter. The new policy aims to support families and help the company recruit and retain top talent in the tech industry.

site_title: Swing it right, with Faldo
summary: Sir Nick Faldo imparted his golfing knowledge to a group of kids and parents, showing his dedication to teaching despite exhaustion. No key events or conclusions were found in the provided article.

site_title: US store sales down slightly for Thanksgiving and Black Friday
summary: US brick-and-mortar store sales on Thanksgiving Day and Black Friday fell 1.5% from last year, with average spending per shopper dropping 1.4%. However, online sales surged 18% to $4.47 billion, driven by double-digit growth. Despite the decline in physical sales, the performance is seen as strong due to pent-up demand and lower gas prices. Retailers are shifting their focus to earlier promotions, and electronics and toys were among the best-selling categories.

site_title: Beijing issues orange alert for heavy smog
summary: Beijing issued its highest smog alert this year due to air pollution levels reaching 15 times the recommended limit. Residents were advised to stay indoors as PM2.5 levels exceeded 390 micrograms per cubic meter, prompting industrial plant closures and truck bans. The pollution was linked to coal-burning for winter heating, contributing to China's high greenhouse gas emissions. Hundreds of thousands joined worldwide protests against climate change, but no similar demonstrations were reported in China, where the ruling party suppresses organized opposition.

site_title: Lufthansa wage accord for 30,000 ground staff
summary: Lufthansa has reached a wage accord with services sector union Verdi covering 30,000 ground staff, providing a one-off payment of 2,250 euros and a 2.2% wage rise. The accord runs to the end of 2017 and comes after several strikes, including the longest strike in the company's history. Lufthansa is still facing disputes with pilot and cabin staff unions over pay and retirement benefits. The agreement follows a jobs summit scheduled for December 2 to address ongoing issues.

site_title: Emerging Asian currencies weaken on stronger US$
summary: Emerging Asian currencies weakened on Friday due to a stronger US dollar, with the Chinese yuan posting its longest weekly losing streak in five months. The yuan fell ahead of the International Monetary Fund's meeting on Monday, which is expected to decide whether to include the yuan in its reserve basket. Other currencies, such as the Indian rupee and Indonesian rupiah, also lost ground, while the Malaysian ringgit rose 1.2% on China's support and a rebound in crude prices. The European Central Bank is expected to add extra stimulus next week, which could help emerging Asian currencies resist the strong dollar.

site_title: Three dead in shooting at US family planning centre
summary: A gunman opened fire at a family planning center in Colorado Springs, Colorado, killing three people and wounding several others in a five-hour standoff. The shooting occurred on a day after Thanksgiving, just hours after millions of Americans celebrated the holiday. A police officer was among the dead, while nine others, including five police officers, were wounded. The gunman, who was armed with a rifle, surrendered to police without further bloodshed. The Planned Parenthood center, which provides women's health services, including abortion, has become a target for criticism from social conservatives.
