The investigation was sparked by concerns over market stability, with trading in Haitong's shares halted. The China Securities Regulatory Commission declined to comment. This probe adds to growing scrutiny of China's largest brokers, highlighting the need for increased regulatory oversight to maintain market stability.

site_title: Asia: China market plunge sparks sell-off across Asia
summary: China's stock market plummeted, with Shanghai sinking over 6% and Shenzhen's composite index falling 6.1%, amid a probe into brokerages and declining industrial profits. The sell-off, sparked by a June 12 peak and mid-August trough, has brought back memories of the summer's panic-driven sell-off, wiping trillions of dollars off valuations. The probe into top brokers, including Citic Securities and Guosen Securities, has triggered a broader sell-off, with Asian markets also affected, including Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul.

site_title: Off Grid Electric of US gets US$25m for African Projects
summary: Off Grid Electric, a US-based company, has secured $25 million to boost electricity access in East Africa. The funds will be used to enter Rwanda's market and increase energy access in Tanzania by 1 million homes by 2017. This investment is part of a 55 million euros ($82.3 million) fund by Paris-based Energy Access Ventures, which also includes investors DBL Investors, Zouk Capital, Vulcan Capital, and SolarCity. The Tanzanian government aims to increase power generation by 88% to 2,780 megawatts by 2017, while Rwanda seeks to raise installed power capacity by almost five times to 563 megawatts by 2017.

images.alt_text: Off Grid Electric, a San Francisco-based company with African operations, has received a total of US$25 million to boost electricity access in the continent's east, according to one of the project's investors.

site_title: Oil prices drop on China data, firmer dollar
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday, with Brent crude falling 4 cents to $45.42 per barrel and US WTI futures falling 50 cents to $42.54 per barrel. The losses were due to disappointing Chinese economic data and a firmer US dollar, which made oil contracts more expensive for holders of other currencies. The market is now shifting focus to the OPEC meeting on December 4. Despite geopolitical risks in the Middle East, analysts believe the well-supplied crude market and lack of material threats to oil facilities will prevent oil prices from rising.

site_title: Axcelasia trades 2% higher on Catalist debut
summary: Axcelasia, a Malaysian tax advisory firm, made its Catalist board debut, trading 2% higher at S$0.255. The company raised approximately S$11.9 million by issuing 47.5 million shares at S$0.25 each. Axcelasia aims to leverage its success in Malaysia to expand its presence in the Asean region, with executive chairman Veerinderjeet Singh stating the IPO marks a significant milestone for the company's growth.

site_title: US Thanksgiving shopping crowds 'good not great'; online sales strong
summary: US retailers offered early Black Friday discounts on Thanksgiving eve, with crowds in brick-and-mortar stores showing a "good but not great" turnout. Online sales, however, surged with shoppers spending over $1 billion in just 5 hours. Analysts expect 20% of holiday shopping to occur over the Thanksgiving weekend, with retailers monitoring sales to adjust promotions and pricing. Despite lower-than-expected online discounts, shoppers are cautious with spending due to stagnant wages and sluggish job growth.

site_title: China navy holds first joint anti-piracy drill with Nato
summary: China's navy has conducted its first joint anti-piracy drill with Nato ships in the Gulf of Aden, aiming to improve maritime security and stability. The drill, held on Wednesday, demonstrates China's growing commitment to global security as it seeks to expand its role. China has been actively participating in anti-piracy patrols and has built logistics facilities in Djibouti to support its peacekeeping and anti-piracy missions. The move is seen as part of China's efforts to overcome its discomfort about overseas military bases and solidify its position as a major global power.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.16 points to 1676.93. Losers outnumbered gainers 112 to 81, with a total trading volume of 73.8 million lots worth RM18 million.

site_title: Japan Oct jobless rate falls to 3.1 per cent
summary: Japan's jobless rate in October fell to 3.1%, lower than the median forecast of 3.4%. The jobs-applicants ratio remained unchanged at 1.24. This marks a decrease in unemployment, indicating a strengthening labor market in Japan.

site_title: Sentences on City Harvest's six accused 'manifestly inadequate': prosecution
summary: The prosecution in the City Harvest case has filed notices of appeal against the sentences imposed on the six accused, citing them as "manifestly inadequate". Judicial Commissioner See Kee Oon had previously sentenced the individuals to custodial terms ranging from 8 years to 21 months. The convictions were for criminal breach of trust and falsification of accounts. The prosecution's appeal is based on the written grounds for the sentences, which were released on November 23.

images.alt_text: The Attorney General's Chambers on Friday said that the prosecution is of the view that the sentences imposed are "manifestly inadequate, in all the circumstances of the case".

site_title: Euro weak ahead of European Central Bank meeting
summary: The euro hovered at seven-month lows against the dollar and other currencies due to speculation of the European Central Bank's potential stimulus measures next week. Analysts expect the ECB's actions to pressure Asian policymakers to loosen monetary policy, potentially pushing down their currencies. The euro weakened to US$1.0612 and 130.10 yen, while the dollar rose to 122.61 yen, amid expectations of a US interest rate hike in December.

images.alt_text: The euro on Friday hovered around seven-month lows on the dollar and was also weak against Asian currencies on speculation that the European Central Bank will unleash fresh stimulus measures next week.

site_title: China Fishery missed loan payment earlier this month, S&P says
summary: China Fishery Group Ltd., a Singapore-listed fishing group, missed a US$31 million loan payment and has had its cash position dwindle to US$41.3 million. One of the lenders, HSBC Holdings Plc, has applied for provisional liquidators, indicating a lack of willingness to negotiate further extensions or waivers. The company has faced declining profits and is under investigation for an offence under the Securities and Futures Act in Singapore. Analysts believe the impact of El Nino and the investigation may affect China Fishery's rights to catch in Peru, rather than its asset coverage.

site_title: Britons chase Black Friday bargains
summary: Britain's shopping streets and websites will be filled with discounted goods on Black Friday, with retailers hoping to kick-start Christmas trading after a weak November. The event is expected to top last year's record level, generating 1.6 billion pounds in UK sales, up 20% from 2014. However, in-store shopper numbers are forecast to be down by up to 4% year-on-year, with some retailers offering deals over a longer period.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks add to gains at the open
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.25% at the open, driven by a weak yen boosting exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 reached fresh three-month highs, approaching the 20,000 mark, as investors took advantage of the favorable currency exchange.

site_title: Gold poised for 6th straight weekly drop, Fed rate hike view drags
summary: Gold prices are poised for a sixth straight weekly decline, weakened by a strong US dollar and expectations of a US interest rate hike next month. The dollar is near an eight-month high, boosted by euro weakness and prospects of higher US rates. Investors expect higher rates to decrease demand for non-yielding bullion, further depressing gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold dipped towards its lowest level in nearly six years on Friday and was on track for a sixth straight weekly decline, weakened by a robust dollar and expectations of a US interest rate hike next month.

site_title: Oil spurs ringgit's best emerging-market gain aided by 1MDB sale
summary: The Malaysian ringgit saw its largest emerging-market gain in two weeks, rising 1.2% to 4.2332 a dollar, amid a two-week rally in Brent crude prices. The appreciation is attributed to 1MDB's sale of its power assets to China General Nuclear Corp for $2.3 billion and improving domestic sentiment. The sale has helped reduce 1MDB's debt, which accumulated to about RM42 billion in less than five years, and has also contributed to a decline in the cost to insure sovereign debt from default.

images.alt_text: A two-week rally in Brent crude spurred the Malaysian ringgit's biggest gain in emerging markets, adding to improving sentiment for the net oil exporter as a debt-ridden state investment company sells its assets.

site_title: Singapore's financial system remains sound but sectors should buffer against rising risks: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial system remains stable despite some sectoral weaknesses, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Financial Stability Review. The central bank identified rising risks, including US interest rate normalization, currency risks in China, and financial volatility, as potential concerns. The banking sector's asset quality has deteriorated, with a 1.5% non-performing loans ratio, but overall remains healthy. The corporate sector's profitability has declined, while households have become more prudent in their debt exposure. MAS urges sectors to buffer against future risks and maintain financial health.

images.alt_text: Singapore's financial resilience seemed to show signs of weakening on some fronts, but the central bank concluded after stress tests that the country's financial system remains healthy in the event of future shocks.

site_title: China's October industrial profits fall 4.6% year-on-year
summary: China's industrial profits fell 4.6% in October from a year earlier, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline. The decline was attributed to falling sales, rising costs, and hits to the oil, steel, and coal industries. The mining industry saw the largest drop, with profits falling 56.3% in the first 10 months of the year. China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the economy is on track to reach its 7% growth target for the year, and the government announced new measures to help exporters and importers amid a "complicated and grim" foreign trade environment.

site_title: Rich Asians mostly stick with US dollar rally UBS sees almost done
summary: UBS, the world's largest private bank, expects the US dollar's gains to be limited as the Federal Reserve will likely tighten policy gradually after the first interest-rate increase since 2006 next month. The dollar is expected to peak at around US$1.05 against the euro, with further European Central Bank stimulus also supporting its value. Wealthy clients, including those in Asia, remain bullish on the dollar, with some predicting it will reach parity with the euro.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.38% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 11.03 points to 2,873.66. This follows a 0.24% drop on Thursday. Asian markets were influenced by European shares hitting three-month highs, while Tokyo stocks rose 0.25% due to a weak yen. Key movers included QT Vascular (up 4.3%) and Tiger Airways (up 1.2%), amidst concerns over Tiger Airways' takeover by Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Weak Japan data offer latest bad news for Abenomics
summary: Japan's economy released weak data, with household spending and inflation falling in October, fueling concerns about Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics. The country's GDP shrank 0.2% in the July-September period, and the labor market remains tight despite a 2-decade low unemployment rate. The Bank of Japan is set to consider a special stimulus package, and its policy meeting next month will determine whether it adds to its $653 billion annual stimulus program. The weak data raises doubts about Abe's bid to spur the economy and exit years of deflation.

site_title: France to mourn Paris attack dead
summary: France will hold a solemn ceremony on Friday to mourn the 130 people killed in the November 13 Paris attacks, with President Francois Hollande leading the tribute. The ceremony will take place at the Invalides and will be broadcast live on television. Hollande has called on French citizens to display the Tricolour flag, but some victims' families have expressed anger and disappointment, accusing the government of failing to improve security. France has stepped up air strikes against IS targets in Syria and Iraq, and Hollande has secured offers of support from France's allies, including Britain and Germany.

site_title: New York reassures tourists after terror threat
summary: New York City is reassuring tourists that the city is safe after a terror threat, despite a worldwide travel alert issued by the US State Department. The city's tourism industry saw some cancellations following the Paris attacks, but officials say business is as usual. The city's holiday season, which typically attracts over 5 million visitors, is expected to proceed as planned, with events such as the Thanksgiving Parade and Rockefeller Centre Christmas tree lighting. Reassured by increased security measures, some tourists from France who were initially hesitant to travel are reconsidering their plans.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise to three-month high in thin trade
summary: European shares rose to a three-month high, driven by expectations of aggressive European Central Bank action next week and solid quarterly reports from chipmaker Infineon and metal price rebounds. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed up 0.9% at 1,516.25 points, despite thin trade volumes. The euro edged towards seven-month lows against the dollar as investors bet on further ECB easing. Other sectors, including mining, healthcare, and auto stocks, also gained ground.

site_title: Risk management, SME financing top Islamic banks agendas: survey
summary: Islamic banks worldwide view risk management, SME financing, and expanding client base as top issues in coming years, according to a survey of 83 Islamic finance institutions. Commercial financing remains the top revenue driver, but SMEs are seen as key for growth, particularly in Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. Strengthening risk management and shifting to equity-based financing are major challenges. The industry remains fragmented, with few signs of change, and banks in Africa are the most optimistic about future growth despite regulatory concerns.

images.alt_text: Islamic banks around the globe view risk management, equity financing and deepening their client base as the most pressing issues facing the sector in coming years, a survey released on Friday showed.

site_title: Germany plans tax incentives to build new homes for refugees
summary: Germany plans to offer tax incentives to builders of new homes for refugees, aiming to address housing shortages. The incentives, set to last three years, will allow owners of new apartments to write off 10% of their costs on taxes. The move aims to accommodate the influx of about 1 million asylum seekers, with an estimated 350,000 apartments needed annually. The government expects to need 800,000 flats, and the construction industry is expected to benefit from increased state spending on refugees.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as copper and banks recover
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by a base metals rally and improved investor perception of banks. Copper prices led the gains, with mining stocks including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also rising. Bank stocks, which have been impacted by regulatory changes, also saw buying, with National Australia Bank and Westpac Banking Corp up 0.6% and 0.4% respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 12.4 points to 5,223.1, marking its seventh consecutive gain.

site_title: Merck said to weigh allergy therapy unit sale to trim debt
summary: Merck KGaA is considering selling its allergy business, Allergopharma, to reduce debt following the US$17 billion takeover of Sigma-Aldrich Corp. The business, which focuses on diagnosing and treating allergies, could fetch approximately 600 million euros (S$896 million). The sale process is at an early stage, and Merck could still decide against it. The move aims to reduce the company's dependence on pharmaceuticals after more than a decade of failing to develop new drugs.

site_title: White House on lockdown after fence-jumper caught: reports
summary: The White House was placed on lockdown on Thanksgiving Day after a person jumped the fence, was immediately caught, and a security sweep was conducted. The incident comes amid heightened security concerns following the Paris attacks in November, which killed 130 people. The Secret Service, which was recently implementing security measures, was investigating the incident, and the presidential mansion remained locked down as a precaution.

site_title: China Everbright Water wins deal to upgrade, expand Beijing waste water project
summary: China Everbright Water has won a deal to upgrade and expand the Beijing Daxing Tiantanghe Waste Water Treatment Project. The total investment for phase one and two is approximately 228 million yuan, with a daily treatment capacity of 80,000 cubic meters expected to be completed in the second half of 2016. The project's water tariff is expected to increase by 85.7% upon completion. This marks the company's first project to meet the discharge standard of category IV surface water, aiming to further develop its business in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei economic region.

site_title: LG Display to invest US$8.7b in new OLED plant
summary: LG Display plans to invest US$8.7 billion in a new OLED plant in Paju, South Korea, with production expected to begin in the first half of 2018. The plant, called P10, will produce panels for TVs and flexible OLED panels for devices such as smartwatches and auto displays. The investment is in anticipation of Apple's adoption of OLED technology for its iPhone in 2018, although LG Display's spokeswoman declined to comment on the report. The new plant is part of LG Electronics' efforts to popularize OLED technology in TVs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, China Fishery, SembMarine, Marco Polo, IHH Healthcare, QT Vascular
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies are under scrutiny, with IHH Healthcare posting a 19% year-on-year fall in net profit, and China Fishery Group facing a club loan facility wind-up after missing a US$31 million instalment. CDL is buying a landmark brewery site in southwest London for £158 million. SembCorp Marine and Marco Polo Marine are in a dispute over a US$214.3 million rig construction contract. Meanwhile, a US court has granted QT Vascular a stay on enforcing a trial court's judgement, pending an appeal.

site_title: Obama's Thanksgiving message likens refugees to pilgrims
summary: US President Barack Obama released a Thanksgiving message, likening refugees to pilgrims seeking a safer future. He emphasized the importance of generosity and openness to those in need, referencing the generosity of Americans who've offered to host refugees. Obama assured that refugees would undergo the highest security checks before entering the US, addressing concerns sparked by the Paris attacks. His message comes amid opposition to his plan to resettle 10,000 Syrian refugees in the US in the coming year.

site_title: Japan inflation continues slide, spending slumps
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.1% in October for the third consecutive month, while household spending declined 2.4% from the previous year, indicating a fragile economy. The decline in energy costs, which the Bank of Japan will look through, was the primary factor. This data casts doubt on the BOJ's inflation target of 2% by early 2017. Analysts expect the BOJ to ease monetary policy in January due to continued declines in oil costs, but officials are cautious about expanding the stimulus program.

site_title: SembMarine, Marco Polo headed for long tussle
summary: SembMarine and Marco Polo Marine are embroiled in a dispute over a $214.3 million jack-up rig construction contract. Marco Polo Marine's MP Drilling unilaterally terminated the contract, citing defects and a demand for a refund of $21.4 million. SembMarine's PPL Shipyard disputes the allegations, saying the contract is still subsisting and they will seek a second payment if MP Drilling fails to deliver on time. The dispute may lead to the first cancellation of a jack-up rig building order in Singapore.

site_title: Cameron makes case for Britain to join Syria air strikes
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron made a case to MPs for Britain to join air strikes on Islamic State (IS) targets in Syria, amid signs of opposition weakening after the Paris attacks. Cameron argued that Britain should not wait for an attack to occur before acting, citing it as "morally" unacceptable to outsource security to allies. A vote is expected early next week, with polls suggesting approval of the move. Cameron has stepped up pressure on MPs since IS claimed responsibility for the Paris attacks, which killed 130 people, and has ruled out deploying British ground troops.

site_title: Say 'no' to dual class shares
summary: Singapore is reviewing whether to allow dual class shares, a type of ordinary share with different voting rights, for listed companies. Dual class shares have been banned in Hong Kong and the UK, but are used by some US technology companies. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are considering whether to allow dual class shares, with some commentators arguing they protect entrepreneurial management from shareholder demands. However, others argue that dual class shares can reduce firm value and undermine corporate governance. Proposed safeguards include restrictions on dual class shares, increased independent directors, and automatic conversion of superior voting shares to ordinary voting shares.

site_title: Bidadari flats big draw in latest HDB BTO sale
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) saw a warm response to its November launch of new flats, with five-room flats in the Bidadari estate being the most popular, drawing over 20 times applications. Despite higher prices, the central location and presence of two MRT stations contributed to the strong demand. To meet this demand, HDB plans to launch more flats in Bidadari next year, with 1,600 units available in the February 2016 BTO exercise.

site_title: MH17 victims to get Dutch memorial at Schiphol
summary: A forest in Vijfhuizen, near Amsterdam's Schiphol airport, will be planted to commemorate the victims of downed flight MH17, with 298 trees representing each of the 298 victims. The memorial, designed by the National Forest Fund, will include an amphitheatre and be lit up at night, with sunflowers surrounding it annually on July 17. The project was chosen by the next-of-kin, who preferred the park to other possible sites. The unveiling is planned for July 17, 2017.

images.alt_text: A general view of the location near Schiphol where the national monument will be placed in memory of the victims of disaster flight MH17 in Vijfhuizen, The Netherlands, Nov 26, 2015.

site_title: Germany offers France recon jets, frigate for IS fight
summary: Germany has offered France support in the fight against the Islamic State, including Tornado reconnaissance jets, a naval frigate, aerial refuelling, and satellite images. The offer, which must be formally approved by the German government, comes after Chancellor Angela Merkel pledged to help France battle the group in Syria. The move is seen as a significant contribution to the EU's efforts to combat terrorism, with French President Francois Hollande thanking Germany for its support.

images.alt_text: Germany on Thursday offered France Tornado reconnaissance jets, a naval frigate, aerial refuelling and satellite images to back the fight against the Islamic State jihadist group.

site_title: UK consumer confidence slips to 6-month low, service sector growth slows
summary: British consumer confidence has dropped to its lowest level in six months, with a monthly consumer sentiment indicator dipping to +1 in November from +2 in October. The service sector growth has also slowed, suggesting further moderation of economic growth. Optimism about the economy over the next 12 months has reached its lowest level since July 2013, despite consumers still being willing to spend on major purchases.

site_title: Google gets 348,085 'forget' requests in Europe
summary: Google received 348,085 'forget' requests in Europe, with France leading the way, accounting for 73,399 applications. The search engine complied with less than half of the demands, granting 42% of the requests. Countries with high request rates included Germany, the UK, Spain, and Italy. Google removed information from 1.23 million internet pages, with common causes for "delisting" including health and criminal information, and endorsed requests from crime victims or their families to remove news reports of assaults.

site_title: Adele announces 2016 live concert tour, first in four years
summary: Singer Adele announced a 15-week concert tour of Britain, Ireland, and continental Europe in February 2016, her first tour in four years. The tour will begin on February 29 at the SSE Arena in Belfast and end at the Sportpaleis in Antwerp, Belgium. Adele, who broke sales records with her album "25", addressed rumors of her fear of performing, stating she had been "bluffing" and was relieved to finally announce the tour.

images.alt_text: Adele, whose latest album "25" has smashed sales records in its first week of release, announced on Thursday she would begin a 15-week concert tour of Britain, Ireland and continental Europe in February.

site_title: Hollande, Putin agree to work more closely to combat Islamic State in Syria
summary: French President Francois Hollande and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to exchange intelligence on Islamic State and other rebel groups in Syria to improve their aerial bombing campaigns. However, they disagreed on the fate of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. Hollande aimed to target only Islamic State and similar groups, while Putin insisted Assad should remain in power. The two nations also agreed to step up air strikes against oil supplies and cooperate with the US against Islamic State, but relations remain tense due to the downing of a Russian plane by Turkey.

site_title: US knew flight path of plane downed by Turkey: Putin
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin stated that the US was aware of the flight path of the downed Turkish plane on the Syrian border. Putin claimed the US had prior information about the location and time of Russian planes' flights, which were hit by a Turkish jet. He dismissed Turkey's claim that it wouldn't have shot down the jet if it knew it was Russian, citing visible identification signs on the planes. Putin also accused Turkey of buying oil from the Islamic State, calling it a major concern.

site_title: Australia flags cutting tax breaks for wealthy retirees
summary: Australia's Treasurer Scott Morrison is considering reducing tax breaks for wealthy retirees as part of a government overhaul of the nation's tax system. The superannuation scheme, which offers generous tax breaks, has been identified as a key area for reform. Morrison stated that the system should not be seen as a means for wealthy Australians to accumulate large balances. The move is part of a broader plan to stimulate growth and productivity, with a potential tax package to be introduced before the election in the second half of next year.

images.alt_text: Australia's Treasurer Scott Morrison indicated he's looking at reducing tax breaks for wealthy retirees as part of a government plan to overhaul the nation's tax system.

site_title: EU air-traveller terror proposal likely to be widened
summary: The European Union is likely to broaden its plan for airlines to share passenger information with national governments due to heightened terrorism concerns following the Paris attacks. The draft law, which aims to include intra-EU flights, has gained support from the European Commission and is expected to pass the EU Parliament. The move aims to strengthen the EU's counter-terrorism efforts and follows the January Paris attacks that killed 17 people. A final compromise may include a clause to review the legislation after several years.

site_title: Integrating with SIA group will help Tiger's long-term growth
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched an offer to acquire the remaining shares of budget carrier Tiger Airways, seeking to integrate the airline into its group to achieve long-term growth. The offer price is 41 Singapore cents per share, a 32% premium over the last traded price. SIA aims to delist Tiger and align its operations with other carriers, including Scoot and SilkAir, to enhance synergies and deliver growth. However, minority shareholders have expressed concerns over the offer price, citing a 39% discount compared to their initial investment.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Four senior KPMG executives arrested in UK tax probe
summary: Four senior KPMG executives were arrested in Northern Ireland as part of a tax evasion investigation. The tax agency officers visited KPMG's Belfast office and arrested four partners, who are currently on administrative leave. Finance Minister George Osborne has pledged to crack down on tax evasion, investing an additional £800 million in the fight against evasion. The investigation is ongoing, with no further information available at this time.

site_title: Banks lower as market drift continues
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,884.69, down 6.89 points, due to low trading volume of 977 million units worth S$1 billion. The US market was closed for Thanksgiving, while Hong Kong and China experienced weakness. All three Singapore banks closed weaker, with OCBC having the highest loss of S$0.08. This marks another quiet session in the market, following previous ones this year.

site_title: Black Friday bargains are fewer than you think
summary: Black Friday bargains are not as lucrative as traditionally thought, according to a study by The Wirecutter. Only 0.6% of online deals, or 200 out of 34,000, are good ones on Black Friday, with the rest being similar to year-round prices. A smarter way to shop is to research online and use trackers to follow product pricing year-round, with tools like Camel Camel Camel providing price history and alerts for price drops. This approach can help consumers understand pricing trends and find better deals on specific items, even on Black Friday.

site_title: China Fishery Group sinks amid liquidity problems
summary: China Fishery Group, a Singapore-based industrial fishing group, has failed to repay a US$31 million instalment on its US$650 million club loan facility, according to Standard & Poor's. This missed payment triggered a series of events, leading to the company's liquidity problems. The company's financial struggles have resulted in its sinking, with the loan facility likely to be restructured or defaulted upon. The incident highlights the risks associated with high-yield debt and the importance of managing cash flows for companies in the industry.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing hits another speed bump
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced another decline in October, with factory output contracting 5.4% year-on-year, driven largely by a 14% drop in electronics production. This marks the ninth consecutive month of declining industrial output, with economists warning of a "big bucket of cold water" over the country's economy. The sector's weakest link, manufacturing has been stuck in a structural decline, and the decline is expected to continue, with economists predicting a -4% growth in industrial production for 2015.

site_title: Australian regulators to simplify rules for securitisation
summary: Australian regulators, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA), have proposed simplifying rules for securitization, a move expected to lower funding costs for banks. The plan removes a "skin-in-the-game" credit risk retention requirement and allows for more flexibility in certain forms of securitization. Industry experts praise the move, saying it simplifies the approach to securitization and aligns with international standards. The changes are aimed at offsetting rising capital costs and are considered a major step forward for Australia's securitization market.

site_title: City buzz
summary: National Gallery Singapore opens with a two-week carnival featuring performances, film screenings, and art talks. Admission to the museum's galleries and exhibitions is free until Dec 6, but tickets must be booked online. The Fullerton Hotel hosts a Christmas light-up ceremony with a charity buffet dinner. Elton John returns to Singapore for a couple of intimate shows at The Star Theatre. Chef Marco Guccio from Zafferano offers a pasta dinner journey through Italy, while Master Chef Hiroshi Ishii from Keiyaki features a seasonal menu from Ishikawa Prefecture. A Christmas Faire at A Very Singapore Special features adoptable dogs, including a four-year-old mixed-breed and a six-year-old Oreo.

site_title: Homecoming show for Singapore: Inside Out
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board's (STB) showcase "Singapore: Inside Out" made its debut in Singapore on November 27, 2015, after touring Beijing, London, and New York. The 10-day exhibition features 20 local artworks, performances, and a food component called "Singapore Takeout" with over 10 local chefs serving up Singaporean dishes with a twist. The event aims to showcase Singapore's creative sector and attract more than 10,000 visitors, supported by the National Arts Council and the DesignSingapore Council.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Health insurance must remain affordable and sustainable
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life, a universal health plan, has launched, covering 3.9 million people and addressing concerns about affordability and sustainability. The plan's launch raises questions about the future of private Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) under the CPF umbrella, as premiums have risen significantly since 2013. Industry data shows claims for public and private hospitals have increased by 12% and 17% respectively over the past few years, driven by an ageing population, declining health, and poor lifestyle habits. To maintain affordability, measures such as public education, transparency from insurers, and more visible premium hikes are needed.

site_title: US laws can't keep pace with the latest fad - hoverboards
summary: US hoverboards, also known as self-balancing motorized boards, are banned in many places due to safety concerns. Despite this, they remain popular, with parents and lawmakers struggling to regulate them. California has passed a new law allowing electric-powered boards to be ridden in bike lanes and pathways, with riders required to be at least 15 years old and wear protective gear. Other cities and states have similar restrictions, with some property owners banning them for liability reasons.

site_title: Asia-Pac FTA is next up after RCEP: Swee Keat
summary: Singapore aims to establish a 16-party free-trade agreement (FTA) as the next step to create a pact encompassing the entire Asia-Pacific region. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of think tanks in enhancing the country's knowledge economy and turning it into a "trusted home base" for companies. The development comes as Singapore continues to push for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a free-trade agreement with 16 participating countries, including Australia, China, and Japan.

site_title: Ageing rock gods make it look easy
summary: Def Leppard, a legendary rock band, performed a career-spanning set at the Suntec City convention hall, entertaining a 7,000-strong crowd with hits from their 1987 album Hysteria and other classic hits. The band, consisting of Joe Elliott, Rick Savage, Rick Allen, Phil Collen, and Vivian Campbell, looked visibly older but maintained their signature chemistry and tight performance. Despite having released a new album, only two songs were played from it, with the majority coming from their iconic 80s era.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Brussels lockdown leaves trail of cancelled trips
summary: The Brussels lockdown following the Paris terror attacks has led to a significant decline in travel bookings to the Belgian capital, with net bookings plummeting 159% since the lockdown began. Business travel is being hit harder, with bookings down 195% compared to leisure travel, which saw a 106% decline. Most cancellations originated from Austria, Italy, and the UK, with bookings out of these countries down 236%, 206%, and 191% respectively. However, some business travelers are postponing their trips, with bookings for Dec 7 and 14 running ahead of last year's periods.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Why Islamic State may be targeting France
summary: Islamic State may be targeting France due to its weak link in the EU and its economic struggles. France's failure to integrate its Muslim population and its economic woes make it an attractive target for destabilization. The Paris attacks have raised concerns about the Schengen agreement, which may be suspended or its implementation halted, allowing for reinstated border controls. France's economic significance as the second-largest economy in the euro area makes it a prized target for those seeking to destabilize the EU.

site_title: CPFIS-included funds down 6.36% in Q3
summary: CPFIS-included unit trusts and investment-linked products fell 6.36% and 7.1% respectively in Q3, while bond and money market funds posted positive returns. The MSCI AC Asia ex-Japan Index declined 12.29% over the same period. For the 12-month period, CPFIS-included funds and unit trusts recorded negative returns of 0.52% and 0.51% respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to slowing China's economy and global market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Calling all anime-niacs
summary: The Anime Festival Asia Singapore 2015 (AFASG15) is set to attract 100,000 attendees this year, surpassing expectations. The festival, now in its eighth year, features a concert component, cosplay, and exhibits showcasing anime-related products and services. Notable performers include May'n, Back-On, and Bless4, while voice actresses Ayana Taketatsu, Maaya Uchida, and Suzuko Mimori will also be present. The event also boasts a large number of cosplayers, both professional and amateur, with 14 professionals and approximately 4,000 amateurs expected to attend. The festival runs from November 27-29 at the Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre, with tickets starting at S$13 per day.

site_title: Syndicating for good
summary: A group of corporate foundations and non-profit organizations in Malaysia formed the Malaysia Collective Impact Initiative (MCII) in October 2015, pooling their resources to tackle education sector problems. The organization, facilitated by Credit Suisse, aims to create lasting social impact and address systemic social challenges through collaborative partnerships between business, government, NGOs, academia, and the private sector. By leveraging shared goals and agendas, MCII seeks to drive scalable and sustainable social change in Malaysia.

site_title: Jack Ma paper chase is test of newsprint's appeal
summary: Alibaba is in talks to buy the South China Morning Post, a 112-year-old English-language newspaper, as part of its media ambitions. The deal is seen as a test of newsprint's appeal, with the company facing financial pressure. The Post's circulation and advertising revenue have declined, but its reporting freedoms and global interest in China-related information may help. Alibaba's bid could fetch a premium, with estimates suggesting a value of $373 million to $500 million, potentially driven by the company's deep pockets.

site_title: Ascendas clinches CPF Building for S$550m
summary: Ascendas clinched the tender for the CPF Building in Singapore with a top bid of S$550 million, planning to redevelop it into a Grade A CBD office project with supporting retail elements. The winning bid translates to a unit land price of S$1,032 per square foot per plot ratio, 24% higher than the existing GFA. The project's new owner will take vacant possession of the building around Q1 2017, and the redevelopment plans could include mixed-use projects with offices, retail, and other amenities.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Governance gap between S-chips and other stocks widening: study (Amended)
summary: A study by the Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations at NUS Business School found that the governance gap between S-chips (China-focused stocks listed in Singapore) and other stocks is widening, with S-chips scoring 42.2 out of 143 points on the Governance & Transparency Index, compared to 48.8 for non-S-chips. The gap has been widening since 2012, when revised corporate governance standards were introduced. The main differences between S-chips and non-S-chips are disclosure and independent board members, with S-chips lagging in disclosure and non-S-chips having more independent chairmen.

site_title: A Madeira aged 110, still lovely
summary: A 110-year-old Madeira wine, D'Oliveiras Madeira 1905, was described as stunning and still at its peak, with a delicate balance of flavors and a refreshing acidity. Madeira is a Portuguese dessert wine made from native grapes and exposed to heat during fermentation and maturing. The wine's unique aging process, which involves heating the wine to arrest fermentation, results in a 17-18% alcohol content. A Tokay Pinot Gris Reserve Personelle 1992 from Alsace was also praised for its rich, ripe fruit flavors and dry finish, making it suitable for pairing with spicy seafood.

site_title: US carrier JetBlue to hire and train pilots with no experience
summary: US carrier JetBlue plans to recruit and train pilots with no flight experience under a proposal awaiting federal regulator approval. Dubbed Gateway 7, the program aims to accommodate candidates with little-to-no aviation experience, with a trial introduction in 2016 for its 100-seat Embraer E190 jets. The airline will provide training and exposure to scenarios in simulators, followed by 1,500 hours of flying time at a partner company. The program is similar to those used by European and Asian carriers and will consider applicants with no prior training.

site_title: ADB says East Asian bond markets in good shape, but warns of risks ahead
summary: East Asian bond markets are in relatively good health, with declining bond yields and rising prices, according to the Asian Development Bank. However, the bank warns of potential risks ahead, including tightening liquidity, large price swings, and destabilizing outflows of funds. The US Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hike in December may prompt foreign investors to cut their holdings of East Asian local currency bonds, but local-currency bond ownership remains narrow, leaving the market vulnerable to increased risk perception and yield increases.

site_title: CDL buys landmark brewery site in UK for S$335m
summary: CDL buys a landmark brewery site in Southwest London for £158 million (S$334.96 million), located beside River Thames and 200 meters away from Waterloo's mainline station. The 89,000 sqm site has "tremendous potential for redevelopment" with a planned mixed-use scheme, including residential, school, hotel, and employment/leisure uses. The acquisition is part of CDL's overseas diversification drive and marks the company's eighth freehold property investment in the UK.

site_title: Abe raises stakes in game to secure stronger capital investment
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed with business leaders to increase capital spending if the government cuts corporate taxes and makes other business-friendly reforms. The Japan Business Federation pledged to boost capital spending 14% over the next three years if reforms are adopted, including a cut in the corporate tax rate to 30%. Abe also announced a more significant cut in corporate taxes than planned, aiming to reduce the standard corporate tax rate to 30% in the next fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe appeared to give ground, saying corporate taxes would be cut more than originally planned next fiscal year. But the pledge could have political repercussions, with a consumption tax hike planned.

site_title: S'pore acts get Sing Jazz boost
summary: The Singapore International Jazz Festival (Sing Jazz) will return to Marina Bay Sands from March 4-6, 2016, featuring a diverse lineup of international and local artists. The festival will include Grammy-winning singer Joss Stone, saxophonist Candy Dulfer, and acid jazz giants Incognito, alongside local acts such as BADBADNOTGOOD and Charlie Lim. The event aims to support the development of Singapore's music scene and provide a platform for local musicians to collaborate with international jazz artists.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: More senior citizens becoming tech-savvy: survey
summary: Singapore is seeing a rise in senior citizens becoming tech-savvy, with 63% of those aged 50-59 and 27% of those 60 and above using the internet to access government services, information, and social networks, according to the Infocomm Development Authority's 2014 survey. This represents a 14% and 11% increase from 2012, respectively. As Singapore aims to become a "smart nation," this trend is expected to play a significant role in its digital transformation efforts.

site_title: Tesco will pay US$12m to settle suit over accounting scandal
summary: Tesco has agreed to pay US$12 million to settle a US shareholder lawsuit over accounting irregularities that inflated its share price. The scandal, revealed in 2014, involved overstating profit by £250 million ($531 million) due to incorrect payments from suppliers. The settlement covers investors who acquired Tesco's American depositary shares and "F-shares" between 2012 and 2014, and denies wrongdoing by Tesco. The company will pay the settlement in an all-cash deal that requires court approval.

images.alt_text: Tesco plc has agreed to pay US$12 million to settle a US shareholder lawsuit claiming that accounting irregularities inflated the share price of Britain's largest retailer.

site_title: Go digital to win emerging middle class in Asean
summary: Asean's emerging middle class is expected to reach 100 million new consumers by 2020, injecting $770 billion into the market annually. The region's largest economy, Singapore, is projected to reach $3 trillion by 2020, with consumer spending expected to grow 6% annually. Companies must adapt to rapidly changing consumers and leverage digital strategies to reach the increasingly connected Asean consumers, particularly in Singapore, where 15% of consumers are loyal to specific brands. Winning loyalty requires deep customer insight, engaging new consumers, and building brand loyalty through digital applications and strategic partnerships.

site_title: Class action suit accuses Wall St's big banks of interest rate swaps collusion
summary: A class action lawsuit has been filed in the US District Court in Manhattan against 10 major Wall Street banks and two trading platforms, alleging they conspired to limit competition in the $320 trillion interest rate swaps market. The banks accused are Goldman Sachs, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Credit Suisse Group, Barclays Plc, BNP Paribas SA, UBS, Deutsche Bank AG, and the Royal Bank of Scotland. The lawsuit claims the banks prevented trading of interest rate swaps on electronic exchanges, hindering competition and potentially costing consumers billions of dollars.

site_title: Battle over Canadian Oil Sands hinges on one thing: crude prices
summary: A bid by Suncor to acquire Canadian Oil Sands is contingent on a lower oil price, as the company's offer of a quarter share in the company for each barrel of oil may not be enough. With oil prices near US$40, Suncor's offer appears more attractive, according to strategist Sachin Shah. Canadian Oil Sands has rejected Suncor's US$4.5 billion offer and is instead meeting with other potential bidders, while the Alberta Securities Commission is set to hear a plea by Suncor to strike down a "poison pill" adopted by Canadian Oil Sands.

site_title: A well-told tale and riveting performances
summary: Australian director Justin Kurzel's adaptation of Macbeth, starring Michael Fassbender and Marion Cotillard, brings a haunting visual intensity to the classic Shakespearean tale. The film, written by Jacob Koskoff, Michael Lesslie, and Todd Louiso, explores the destructive consequences of ambition and greed. With a searing performance from Fassbender and Cotillard's restrained portrayal, the movie offers a compelling viewing experience, reimagining key scenes with fresh life. The film's cinematography and background music add to its foreboding atmosphere, making it a required watch for literature enthusiasts and film lovers.

site_title: Rocky reboot delivers a knockout punch
summary: Ryan Coogler's Rocky reboot, Creed, delivers a knockout punch with a gritty and heartfelt tribute to the iconic sports franchise. The film follows Adonis Johnson, the illegitimate son of Apollo Creed, as he trains to become a boxer under the guidance of Rocky Balboa, played by Sylvester Stallone. Despite some familiar cliches, the film shines with impressive fight scenes and a strong performance from Michael B. Jordan. Coogler's passion for the series, evident in his own filmography, adds a personal touch to the film, making it a surprise hit.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KLW Holdings has withdrawn an earlier lawsuit against Michael Chan Ewe Teik for the repayment of S$7 million, following legal advice that it is unlikely to succeed in obtaining summary judgement. IHH Healthcare Berhad reported a 19% year-on-year fall in net profit for the third quarter due to unrealised foreign exchange losses. A US court has granted a stay on the enforcement of a $20.4 million judgment against QT Vascular and its CEO, pending an appeal.

site_title: China's chip quest to intensify sector's record M&A run
summary: China is intensifying its chipmaking sector's record-breaking mergers and acquisitions (M&As) run, with over $80 billion in deals announced in 2015. Chinese companies like Tsinghua Unigroup are acquiring peers to expand capacity and capabilities ahead of a surge in demand for semiconductors driven by the Internet of Things. This buying spree may push merger targets beyond rivals' reach, with some analysts warning that Chinese companies are driving up M&A valuations and becoming major rivals.

site_title: CDL acquires landmark brewery site in UK for S$336m
summary: CDL has acquired a landmark brewery site in Southwest London for £158 million (S$336 million). The 89,000 square metre site, near River Thames and Waterloo station, offers "tremendous potential for redevelopment". CDL plans to begin planning and consultation early next year, with planning approval expected in Q1 2018. The acquisition is CDL's eighth in the UK and marks the company's overseas diversification drive.

site_title: Get the low-down on tech startups in Singapore at TechSG
summary: Singapore has launched TechSG, a free platform providing real-time, integrated data and insights on the local tech entrepreneurial ecosystem, created by NUS Enterprise and IBM. The platform aims to connect key players, including investors, mentors, and corporations, to share information and support startup growth. With features such as user-driven insights, analytical tools, and interactive mind maps, TechSG will help entrepreneurs build connections to help them grow. IBM will also provide free trials of its Bluemix cloud platform and up to $120,000 of cloud credits to local startups.

site_title: Pimco sues Citi over mortgage debt losses
summary: Pimco has sued Citigroup over alleged failure to properly monitor toxic mortgage securities, resulting in $2.3 billion losses. The lawsuit claims Citigroup breached its duties as trustee by ignoring "pervasive and systemic deficiencies" in loan underwriting and servicing, prioritizing business relationships over loan performance. The lawsuit seeks class-action status and damages, citing loans from issuers such as American Home Mortgage and Washington Mutual.

site_title: Golden Shoe Car Park ripe for redevelopment
summary: CCT, a Singapore property trust, may redevelop Golden Shoe Car Park, a 10-storey building in the Raffles Place financial district. The trust can start redevelopment plans without waiting for leases to expire due to a standard clause allowing it to take back space from tenants by giving them six months' notice. However, the government owns the popular hawker centre on Levels 2-3, requiring NEA's recommendations on the redevelopment plans. A redevelopment could be viable, but CCT's decision would be tied to its plans for the remaining stake in CapitaGreen, a completed office asset. The trust could exercise its call option and raise its stake in CapitaGreen before redeveloping GSCP, providing a balanced approach to income stability and property development.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Tomorrow's service desk must excite users
summary: Companies must elevate IT from a business support function to one that drives the business, converging CIO and digital business roles to fend off digital native companies. To excel, organisations must deliver experiences that excite customers, internal users, and partners by leveraging big data and behavioural analytics. The service desk must evolve to be proactive, prevent issue inquiries, and represent the user community in strategic business decisions. A digital service desk can drive operational maturity, technological innovation, and cross-pollinate ideas across business and IT functions, delivering seamless and insightful user experiences.

site_title: Iran sweetens terms for oil investors
summary: Iran is hosting a two-day conference in Tehran to attract foreign investors for over 50 oil and natural gas projects, aiming to boost oil-production capacity by one million barrels a day. The government seeks at least $100 billion in investment, with a new investor contract offering better incentives than previous buy-back agreements. The framework allows for project-by-project negotiations, rather than a uniform contract draft. This move comes as Iran prepares to end sanctions that have stifled energy development and production. The goal is to revive Iran's energy industry and increase oil production.

site_title: Is Singapore Inc selling off its iconic brands too easily?
summary: Singapore is selling off some of its iconic brands, including Neptune Orient Lines, Raffles Hotel, and CPG, sparking concerns that the country is losing its identity. The sale of these assets, which were previously considered "crown jewels," has raised questions about the national interest and security implications. While the sales are driven by economic factors, authorities must ensure that Singapore's security, particularly sea lanes, is maintained. The sale of NOL, in particular, has raised concerns about potential compromises to national or security interests.

site_title: South Korea orders recall of 125,522 Volkswagen vehicles
summary: South Korea ordered the recall of 125,522 Volkswagen vehicles due to intentional manipulation of a diesel emissions device. The country's testing showed Volkswagen installed software to understate emissions in vehicles with older engines. The recall affects Euro 5 engine vehicles with 2,000cc and 1,600cc diesel engines sold in South Korea between 2008 and 2015. The environment ministry fined Volkswagen Korea 14.1 billion won (S$17 million) and ordered a recall plan by January 6, 2016. This is South Korea's first move based on its own testing to address the diesel emissions scandal.

site_title: Trendlines slips below the line on debut
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israeli biomed incubator, made its debut on the Catalist board, marking the 100th firm to list on the junior board since its launch in 2017. The listing also represents the first time an Israeli firm has listed on SGX in a decade. However, Trendlines' stock performance was weak, failing to live up to expectations.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Barclays fined for inadequate scrutiny in £1.9b deal
summary: Barclays has been fined £72.1 million by UK regulators for failing to adequately scrutinize "politically exposed" ultra high net worth clients in a £1.9 billion transaction. The lender executed the deal in 2011 and 2012 without proper due diligence, prioritizing revenue over risk. The Financial Conduct Authority found Barclays ignored its own procedures and red flags to win new business, generating £52.3 million in revenue. The fine is the largest imposed by the FCA for failings tied to financial crime.

site_title: China to probe largest brokerage for alleged violation of rules
summary: China's securities regulator will investigate Citic Securities Co, the country's largest brokerage, for allegedly violating rules on supervision and administration of securities firms. The probe follows a report by the Securities Association of China that Citic overstated financial derivatives by over one trillion yuan in monthly reports from April to September. Citic has said the error was caused by a system upgrade and will fully cooperate with the investigation. The move is part of a broader crackdown by Chinese authorities on the financial industry, which is seeking to assign blame for the nation's summer stock-market rout.

site_title: Malaysian bonds rise as default risk drops on 1MDB asset sales
summary: Malaysian bonds saw a significant drop in yields to 3.68%, the lowest level since August, following the sale of 1MDB assets. The company agreed to dispose of its power assets to China General Nuclear Corp for RM9.83 billion and plans to clear its debt by the end of the year. This move has improved investor confidence, reducing the cost to insure Malaysia's sovereign debt and contributing to a rally in local-currency bonds. The sale is expected to alleviate concerns about 1MDB's debt burden and its impact on the government.

site_title: China steps up energy overhaul with PetroChina pipeline sale
summary: China is selling a 50% stake in the 1,830 km Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline to China Reform Holdings for US$2.4 billion, part of President Xi Jinping's energy overhaul. The move aims to inject private ownership and market forces into the state-dominated energy sector. This is the first step in China's pipeline restructuring, which includes spinning off assets into independent businesses to address underperformance and the impact of low energy prices.

site_title: Good ol' family fare with cutting-edge, dazzling animation
summary: Pixar's 16th feature, The Good Dinosaur, is a family-friendly adventure story about a young dinosaur who embarks on a journey to return home after being separated from his family. The film boasts cutting-edge animation and a "what-if" premise that explores an alternate history where dinosaurs coexist with humans. However, the storyline lacks inspiration and sophistication, and the characters are one-dimensional. Despite this, the film's landscapes are breathtaking, and its message is surprisingly bland, hewing to Disney classics. The film received a B- rating for its family-friendly tone and tame violence.

site_title: Europe's central banks in quandary as Fed tightening nears
summary: Europe's central banks face a quandary over reviving inflation and sustaining economic growth as the US Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis. The European Central Bank is expected to ease monetary policy further, while the Bank of England is still considering its first rate rise. Japan and China are experiencing economic challenges, and central bankers are struggling to find effective ways to combat low inflation and high unemployment. The European Central Bank is exploring various options to revive inflation, including cutting interest rates and increasing bond purchases.

site_title: Suzuki plans factory in India after failed bid to tie up with Volkswagen
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp plans to establish a wholly-owned factory in India, supplying cars and components to its 56%-owned unit Maruti Suzuki India. The move aims to free up Maruti to expand its sales network and build a new premium brand, while Suzuki gains a bigger presence in its largest market. The plan has sparked concerns among Maruti minority shareholders, who fear it will sideline the Indian unit. The proposed investment of 50 billion yen (S$574 million) will give Suzuki full control of exports and production, with the goal of increasing earnings for both companies.

site_title: Euro struggles as ECB stimulus speculation ramps up
summary: The euro struggled in Asia, down against the dollar, as speculation grew that the European Central Bank will announce a boost to its monetary stimulus measures next week. Expectations of further ECB action pushed down the currency, potentially leading to a test of parity with the dollar for the first time since 2002. The dollar edged down against the yen, while emerging markets currencies declined against the US unit.

site_title: 17 regional artists, 25 works, 1 travelling show
summary: A group show, "In Time of Others - Contemporary Art from Four Museums across the Asia-Pacific," features 17 regional artists and 25 works, showcasing their individual practices and corresponding themes. The show was selected by four museums - Singapore Art Museum, Museum of Contemporary Art Tokyo, National Museum of Art Osaka, and Queensland Art Gallery: Gallery of Modern Art - in collaboration with the Japan Foundation Asia Center. The exhibition aims to provide a comprehensive view of contemporary art in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Working together to improve education in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's collective impact initiative, MCII, brings together foundations and corporations to improve education in the country. The initiative, launched by Agensi Inovasi Malaysia (AIM), aims to address the country's disappointing education statistics and promote systemic change. Participating foundations, including Hong Leong Foundation and Credit Suisse, contribute financially and provide expertise to support the project. The initiative's goal is to break the cycle of poverty by improving the education system and create a scalable model for other areas in Malaysia. By working together, the partners hope to maximize impact and create a lasting change in the education sector.

site_title: Consultants expect warm interest in Siglap residential site
summary: A 1.93 ha residential site in Siglap Road, near East Coast Park and existing condominiums, is expected to draw warm interest from developers under the Government Land Sales programme. The site, in a prime area near schools and MRT stations, is launched for public tender. Consultants anticipate strong bidding, with prices potentially exceeding the S$3,000 psf benchmark. The site's proximity to popular amenities and its relatively large size are expected to attract developers seeking to capitalize on Singapore's prime property market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close flat as MidEast tensions ease
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Thursday as Asian markets stabilized following easing tensions in the Middle East. The Hang Seng index remained unchanged at 22,488.94. Investors remained cautious ahead of a potential US interest rate hike next month, but the Federal Reserve's policy change has been priced in.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: How the EU can woo Britain
summary: European leaders can counter the perception that Britain has little influence in the EU by agreeing to key demands from UK Prime Minister David Cameron and launching a charm offensive to persuade the British people of their value. Leaders can praise Britain's contributions to the single market, competition policy, and foreign policy, and acknowledge their influence on EU decisions. By staying in the EU, Britain will have a significant role in shaping the continent's future, particularly in areas like security and foreign policy.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts and Global Invacom Group have been upgraded to "buy" by OCBC Investment Research and RHB Research, respectively. CDLHT's RevPAR for Singapore hotels increased by 1.4% in the first 26 days of October, despite a 6.4% y-o-y dip in 9 months 2015 RevPAR. Global Invacom Group's utilisation rate has recovered to 70-80% and its new product pipeline is expected to drive a strong rebound into profitability next year. The retail Reits sector is expected to grow at a manageable 1.7-2.3% per annum from 2015-18.

site_title: Lloyds to cut 945 jobs as part of three-year restructuring strategy
summary: Lloyds Banking Group announced plans to cut 945 jobs as part of a three-year restructuring strategy aimed at reducing the bank's workforce by 9,000. The affected staff are from retail, commercial banking, and consumer finance teams, with the goal of using natural turnover and redeployment to retain expertise. Unions Accord and Unite were consulted prior to the announcement, with voluntary redundancy being the preferred option.

images.alt_text: Taxpayer-backed Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday it was cutting around 945 jobs in a restructuring plan first outlined a year ago with the aim of reducing the bank's workforce by 9,000.

site_title: More retail stock added to Iskandar Malaysia
summary: Iskandar Malaysia's retail stock is expected to increase over the next two to three years due to the addition of megamalls as part of the masterplan for major township developments in the southern economic zone. The retail stock has doubled from 6 million sq ft in 2006 to 12.34 million sq ft in 2014, with occupancy rates reaching 77%. Key performers include JB City Square and Johor Premium Outlet, which have high occupancy rates and prime rental values. However, some malls, such as Medini Mall, are affected by the economic slowdown and weaker consumer demand.

site_title: UK to increase stamp duty on buy-to-let, second homes
summary: The UK will increase stamp duty on buy-to-let and second homes by three percentage points, starting from April, to reduce competition for first-time property buyers. The additional revenue will be spent on new and existing home construction. The move aims to address the issue of cash buyers, particularly in London, where prices have risen 40% since 2013. This change is expected to affect small banks that provide loans to landlords, with shares declining in London trading. The goal is to make it less affordable for investors to purchase homes for rental purposes.

site_title: Mattel-Hasbro short spread widens in Barbie vs Darth Vader
summary: Mattel Inc. faces high short interest, with 21% of shares outstanding bet against the company, ahead of the holiday season. In contrast, Hasbro Inc. has a significantly lower short interest of 4.3%. Despite Mattel's recent investment and break from a downward trend, investors remain pessimistic due to sluggish sales and currency headwinds. Analysts, however, note that Mattel could be gaining momentum ahead of the sales season, potentially offsetting bearish bets.

site_title: Brazil graft probe widens as Senate leader, billionaire bank CEO are arrested
summary: Brazilian Senate leader Delcídio do Amaral and BTG Pactual CEO André Esteves were arrested on suspicion of obstructing the country's corruption investigation, which started with state-run oil company Petrobras. The arrest of Esteves sent BTG Pactual's shares plummeting, wiping out a fifth of its market value, and raised concerns about the bank's future. The Supreme Court's decision to order their arrest is seen as a significant escalation in the bribery scandal, which threatens Brazil's banking and politics. The country's currency also fell as the scandal continues to unfold.

site_title: Malaysia's Genting reports 2.4% rise in Q3 profit
summary: Genting Bhd, Malaysia's gaming-to-plantations conglomerate, reported a 2.4% rise in Q3 profits to 361.1 million ringgit (S$120 million), driven by higher net foreign exchange gains and reversal of impairment losses. Revenue increased 3.4% to 4.65 billion ringgit. The company's profits and revenue are attributed to the reversal of previously recognized impairment losses.

site_title: AirAsia reports Q3 net loss, hit by Indonesia and weak currencies
summary: AirAsia reported a Q3 net loss of 406 million ringgit due to foreign exchange losses and a writedown at its Indonesian associate, with prior-year unabsorbed losses of 469 million ringgit. The airline attributed the losses to high debt and dues owed by affiliates, despite founder Tony Fernandes' optimism about the remainder of the year. The losses were offset by one-off gains, and the company's major shareholders are evaluating "all strategic options."

site_title: French 2016 deficit reduction goals unchanged: Sapin
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin stated that France will maintain its 2016 deficit reduction targets despite increased security spending following the Paris attacks. Sapin said he wouldn't impose budget constraints on security, but France would not abandon deficit reduction goals. The government allocated 600 million euros for additional security spending next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 1.33 points to 1,683.09. The index saw 2.33 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 439 to 425.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker in low volume, dragged down by banks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 6.89 points to 2,884.69 in low volume, with banks contributing to the loss. The STI's 30 components saw 222 falls and 163 rises, with OCBC being the only bank to close weaker. Analysts at Nomura expect 2016 to see a shift in focus from asset quality to growth for Singapore banks, driven by modest loan growth and higher interest rates. Despite this, Nomura believes the banks have attractive valuations and estimate earnings growth of 12% in 2016.

site_title: Russia orders retaliatory economic measures against Turkey over jet
summary: Russia is preparing retaliatory economic measures against Turkey after Ankara downed a Russian warplane on the Syrian border. Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev announced plans to halt joint economic projects, restrict financial and trade transactions, and target the tourism, transport, and humanitarian sectors. Measures are expected to be implemented within two days. This response comes after Moscow warned its nationals against visiting Turkey and stepped up controls on Turkish agricultural imports.

site_title: China to probe largest brokerage for alleged violation of rules
summary: China's securities regulator will probe Citic Securities Co, the country's largest brokerage, for alleged rule violations related to supervision and administration. President Cheng Boming and six other executives are under investigation as part of a financial-industry crackdown following the summer stock-market rout. The probe aims to assign blame and punish Citic Securities for its role in the selloff. The company will cooperate fully with the investigation and maintain normal operations.

site_title: 'Tis the season to be jolly
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

This Christmas season, Singapore offers a variety of festive shows and concerts. W!ld Rice's pantomime "The Emperor's New Clothes" is a must-watch, featuring socio-political jokes and witty references that cater more to adults. Dream Academy's "Crazy Christmas: A Groundnutcracker" brings together comedians and entertainers for a year-end celebration. Jeremy Monteiro's "Frankly, It's Christmas" is a jazzy tribute to Frank Sinatra, featuring popular standards and Christmas carols. Other notable shows include "Ave Maria and Carols for Advent & Christmas" by the Choir of Gonville & Caius College, Cambridge, and "Swan Lake" by Singapore Dance Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Philippine growth misses forecast as risks loom
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.0% in the third quarter, below the 6.3% median expectation, as a slowdown in manufacturing weighed on growth. A leadership change next year and the El Nino dry spell pose risks to the economy. Analysts predict strong private consumption and government spending will drive future growth, but weak exports may temper it. The government hopes the new leader will speed up and sustain reforms to boost the economy, which has the potential to grow up to 8.0% next year.

images.alt_text: The Philippine economy grew slower than expected in the third quarter, as risks from a leadership change next year and the El Nino dry spell loomed, the government said Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened steadily on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index flat at 6,337.88 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 edged up 0.1% to 11,180.13 points, while the Paris CAC 40 lost 0.2% to 4,884.35 points. Trading was quiet due to the US Thanksgiving holiday.

site_title: Embarking on a new musical adventure
summary: Ride, an influential 1990s English indie band, is set to play its first show in Singapore at the Neon Lights festival on November 28-29. The band, which split up in 1996, reunited last year and is now on a world tour. Founding member Mark Gardener says they play every show like it's their final one, due to their past experience of crashing spectacularly. Ride's music, known for its "shoegaze" style, has endured despite the decades, as it never followed musical trends.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Private sector loans growing fast in eurozone: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a 1.0% increase in private sector loans in the euro area in October, surpassing the 0.6% growth in September. This growth was driven by a 0.8% increase in credit to households and companies. The ECB's data also showed a 5.3% acceleration in overall money supply, M3, in October. The central bank has implemented a massive bond-buying program to boost liquidity and is considering a potential increase in quantitative easing. These positive economic indicators suggest a stronger eurozone economy, which could help alleviate current weak economic conditions.

site_title: Iata cuts long-term passenger growth forecast on weaker economy
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has cut its long-term growth forecast for air passengers, citing weaker economic forecasts, particularly for China. IATA now expects 7 billion passengers by 2034, up from 3.5 billion in 2015, with a 3.8% average annual growth rate. This is down from its previous forecast of 7.4 billion passengers in 2034, with an average annual growth rate of 4.1%. The decline in forecast is attributed to negative economic developments, including weaker forecasts for China.

site_title: Airbnb to boost listings in Japan, its fastest-growing market
summary: Airbnb plans to increase listings in Japan, its fastest-growing market, amid a surge in guest numbers (529% increase this year) and a shortage of supply. Listings have risen 373% to 21,000, creating a challenge for the company due to regulatory issues and high demand. Japan's record 16.3 million inbound tourists have also led to a shortage of hotel rooms in cities like Tokyo and Osaka.

site_title: China and Europe test bilateral currency swap operations: PBOC
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has successfully tested bilateral currency swap operations with the European Central Bank. The 350 billion yuan (S$77.14 billion) deal, signed in 2013, was conducted in April and November this year. The successful tests aim to facilitate better trade and investment between China and Europe, a step towards strengthening their economic ties.

images.alt_text: China's central bank has tested bilateral currency swap operations with the European Central Bank, according to a notice posted on the People's Bank of China (PBOC) website on Thursday.

site_title: Glaxo sees return to growth in China next year after state probe
summary: GlaxoSmithKline expects its China business to return to growth next year after a two-year sales slump due to a government investigation. The company was fined 3 billion yuan (S$675 million) for bribing non-government personnel. Glaxo has reduced its local sales representatives to 3,000 from 5,000 and has pledged to overhaul its practices. The company's China head, Herve Gisserot, stated that Glaxo is committed to regaining growth in the country.

site_title: Russia says strengthens control over food imports from Turkey
summary: Russia has strengthened control over food and agriculture imports from Turkey, following a research showing that 15% of imports did not meet Russian regulations. The agriculture ministry has instructed the food safety watchdog Rosselkhoznadzor to increase oversight. Turkey is a main supplier of vegetables, fruits, and meat products to Russia.

images.alt_text: Russia has strengthened control over food and agriculture imports from Turkey, the agriculture ministry said in a statement on Thursday.

site_title: Abe says corporate tax to be cut more than planned next financial year
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced plans to cut corporate taxes more than initially planned, aiming for rates below 30%. This move is seen as a key component of generating a virtuous economic cycle, with increased capital spending and wage hikes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output declined 5.4% in October, with a 14% drop in electronics production. The Straits Times Index closed weaker, losing 6.89 points, amid low trading volume. The HDB's new flat application rates stabilized at 2.5 times for two-room flats with flexible leaseholds. China Fishery bonds dropped 34% after HSBC asked a court to wind them up. TechSG, a new digital platform, was unveiled to boost Singapore's tech entrepreneurship ecosystem.

site_title: International Rectifier lifts Infineon's Q4 profit
