summary: Infineon, a German auto and industrial chip maker, reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter operating results and forecast a 11-15% revenue rise for 2015/16. The company's power-management chips are expected to grow faster, while automotive chips will grow more slowly. Infineon's fourth-quarter operating profit rose 52% to 286 million euros, beating analyst estimates. The company's shares are expected to open 3.1% higher, and the German blue chip index is forecast to rise 0.1%.

site_title: Barclays fined for failings on US$2.9b 'elephant deal'
summary: Barclays has been fined 72.1 million pounds (S$153 million) by UK regulators for failing to thoroughly investigate a group of "politically exposed" ultra-high-net-worth clients tied to a 1.9 billion-pound transaction in 2011 and 2012. The bank ignored its own process to safeguard against financial crime and overlooked red flags to win new business and generate revenue. The fine is the largest ever imposed by the UK's Financial Conduct Authority for failings tied to financial crime. Barclays' chairman, John McFarlane, has faced criticism for his approach to addressing past misconduct.

images.alt_text: Barclays was fined 72.1 million pounds (S$153 million) by UK regulators for failing to fully probe a group of "politically exposed" ultra-high-net-worth clients tied to a transaction of 1.9 billion pounds.

site_title: New digital platform to boost Singapore's tech entrepreneurship ecosystem
summary: Singapore has launched a new digital platform, TechSG, to boost its tech entrepreneurship ecosystem. Developed by NUS Enterprise and Wonderlabs, the platform provides real-time data and insights on the ecosystem, powered by IBM cloud technology. It aims to integrate data from various sources, enabling new insights and analysis. The platform will be open and collaborative, soliciting inputs from the startup community and offering regular updates on startups and entrepreneurial ecosystem developments. IBM will also provide cloud credits and resources to local startups, joining Singapore as part of IBM's digital initiative.

images.alt_text: Low Yen Ling, parliamentary secretary for the Ministries of Trade & Industry, and Education.

site_title: Quick takes: Economists point to challenging outlook for industrial output
summary: Singapore's industrial production has declined for nine months, with a 5.4% year-on-year drop in October. Economists attribute the decline to a challenging global environment, with China's slowdown and the US Fed's rate hike. While the monthly increase in production is a positive note, economists warn about the sustainability of this trend due to external demand fluctuations. The current contraction is longer than the 2008-2009 crisis period, but the magnitude of decline is smaller.

images.alt_text: Singapore's industrial production has declined for nine months in a row, with output falling 5.4 per cent year-on-year in October.

site_title: More senior citizens accessing internet: IDA survey
summary: More senior citizens in Singapore are accessing the internet, with a 63% computer usage rate among those aged 50-59 and a 27% rate among those 60 and above in 2014, according to the IDA survey. This represents a 14% and 11% increase from 2012, respectively. Smartphone usage among seniors also increased, with 75% of those aged 50-59 and 31% of those 60 and above using their smartphones to access the internet in the past three months. This trend is part of Singapore's goal to become the world's first Smart Nation.

site_title: Thai Q4 GDP growth seen at least 2.9% y/y: ministry
summary: Thailand's fourth-quarter GDP growth is expected to be at least 2.9% year-over-year, driven by higher public investment. This is in line with the third quarter's growth rate, which was 2.9%. The country's economy has yet to recover from 18 months of political unrest, with exports and domestic demand still weak. The forecast is a positive sign for the country's economic growth, which was just 0.9% last year.

site_title: Update: Putin, Hollande to meet as Russia penalizes Turkey over jet
summary: Russia imposed trade retaliation against Turkey, subjecting agricultural products to additional border checks and controls after downing one of its warplanes over Syria. Russia has also banned poultry imports from a Turkish supplier, citing repeated violations of Russian standards. President Vladimir Putin will meet with French leader Francois Hollande to discuss combating Islamic State militants, amid tensions between the two countries. The incident has raised concerns about the conflict spiraling into a broader war, with the US and other nations calling for calm.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks higher, led by electronics, machinery sectors; won down
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.1% to 2,030.68, driven by gains in electronics and machinery sectors, with institutional buying supporting the main board. Foreign investors purchased 68.8 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, marking the fifth consecutive session of net buying. The won fell 0.3% to 1,147.3 to the dollar, contrasting with Wednesday's close.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain, miners struggle
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, ending a two-session losing streak, with financial and healthcare stocks driving gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 17.01 points to 5,210.7. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also edged up 0.3% to a record high.

site_title: CEO wants more than US$60 million for biggest diamond in a century
summary: The CEO of Lucara Diamond Corp, William Lamb, is seeking more than US$60 million for the 1,111 carat diamond discovered by his company, which is considered the second-biggest diamond of the century. Lamb has not disclosed the exact amount, stating it's higher than the current estimates of US$60 million.

images.alt_text: Lucara's 1,111 carat gem-quality, type IIa diamond.

site_title: OCBC Bank appoints new corporate finance head
summary: OCBC Bank appointed David Cheng as Head of Corporate Finance, bringing over 20 years of industry experience. Cheng, 44, will oversee equity capital markets, mergers & acquisitions, and equity syndication teams, focusing on growing the bank's corporate finance business and supporting clients with financing solutions. He joins from Deutsche Bank, where he led the team in Southeast Asia, and previously worked at Citi, Credit Suisse First Boston, and J.P. Morgan. His appointment is expected to strengthen OCBC's ability to advise clients on corporate financing needs.

site_title: Thanksgiving marketing hits the Web, awkwardly
summary: Thanksgiving has become a major commercial holiday, with companies launching advertising campaigns to capitalize on digital ad space and attention spans. Last year, 32% of holiday shoppers went shopping on "Gray Thursday," and advertisers are recognizing how Thanksgiving can serve as a launchpad into the Christmas advertising season. Companies are using social media and mobile marketing to reach younger audiences, with some campaigns, such as Verizon's "#Thanksgetting," sparking backlash for being seen as overly commercial. Despite this, many companies are finding success in promoting their products and services on Thanksgiving, with some retailers opting to promote online shopping to avoid annoying customers.

site_title: Toshiba's third-party accounts probe comes under fire from lawyer group
summary: Toshiba's third-party probe into its accounting practices has received criticism from a lawyer group, who gave it a failing grade due to its lack of independence and failure to examine key divisions. The probe found that Toshiba had padded profits for seven years, but the group argues it did not thoroughly investigate. Toshiba has declined to comment on the report, which comes as the company seeks to recover from a US$1.3 billion accounting scandal and a 40% decline in market value.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as technology companies lead decline
summary: China's stocks fell for the first time in three days, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 0.3% to 3,637.04. Technology companies led the decline, while commodity producers rose. Jiangxi Copper posted its biggest gain in two weeks, driven by industrial metals. Regulatory probes into short-selling on local exchanges were also a factor.

site_title: Quick take: UOB cuts 2015 industrial output forecast for Singapore to -4.0% from -2.0%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output declined 5.4% year-on-year in October, mainly due to a 14% drop in electronics production. Excluding the biomedical cluster, output would have fallen 6.4%. The Economic Development Board (EDB) lowered its 2015 industrial output forecast for Singapore to -4.0% from -2.0%.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Credit Suisse wins approval for broking in China economic zone
summary: Credit Suisse's joint venture in China has received approval to offer securities brokerage services in the Qianhai economic zone. The venture, controlled by local partner Founder Securities Co, will start offering brokerage services early next year. This is the first global brokerage to win a license after China re-opened the securities industry to foreign participation in 2008. The move comes after a former chairman went missing in January but was later released from police custody. The approval boosts Credit Suisse's business in China, which is now allowed to offer brokerage services for the first time.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank's Q3 profit up 18 pct, net interest income at record
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest lender by assets, reported an 18% rise in Q3 net profit to 1.90 billion ringgit, driven by the sale of its Papua New Guinea operations. Net interest income reached a record 2.9 billion ringgit, while revenue climbed 27.4% to 11.38 billion ringgit. Despite a challenging economic environment, Maybank aims to raise operational and capital efficiencies and leverage growth opportunities.

site_title: Financial flows now most pressing challenge for Indonesia: c.bank governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo stated that financial flows are now the most pressing challenge for the country, surpassing the current-account deficit. The balance of payments recorded a $4.6 billion deficit in the third quarter due to outflows from stocks and bonds, despite a narrowed current account deficit. The rupiah has fallen 10% against the dollar this year, making it difficult for the central bank to cut rates to support growth, as capital outflows are expected ahead of potential US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby hit by low commodity prices, Q1 profit down 34%
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby, the world's largest palm oil planter, reported a 34% decline in Q1 net profit to 328.4 million Malaysian ringgit due to weaker demand in consumer businesses and low commodity prices. The company also warned its 2016 performance will be lower than the previous year. Revenue increased slightly to 10.17 billion ringgit. Sime Darby's shares rose 1.4% after the announcement, despite a 11% year-to-date decline. The company plans to establish a 3 billion ringgit sukuk programme.

site_title: Singapore Power says 4 ex-staff to be charged for alleged corruption
summary: Singapore Power announced that four former employees will be charged in court for alleged corruption, following an internal inquiry and referral to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau. The employees resigned or were dismissed between April and September 2015. The company stated that it takes a serious view of corrupt acts and does not tolerate employee conduct that brings the company into disrepute. The charges are a result of a complaint received by the company.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Even Hong Kong property bears are bullish on real estate stocks
summary: Hong Kong property analyst Jonas Kan predicts a 10% decline in home prices by mid-2016, but expects real estate stocks to rise at least 20% over the next year. Kan's forecast at Daiwa Securities Group Inc's Hong Kong unit suggests that publicly-traded shares have already factored in the potential price drop, making them a bullish investment opportunity.

site_title: Credit Suisse wins China brokerage approval in sign of reform
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG has won approval to provide securities brokerage services in China, marking a significant step in the country's gradual warming to foreign players in the securities industry. The joint venture, Credit Suisse Founder Securities Ltd, will operate in China's Shenzhen Qianhai development zone, offering brokerage services to clients. This approval follows China's 2007 rewrite of rules for foreign participation in its securities industry, and comes at a time when trading in China's volatile stock markets is providing strong returns to local brokers.

site_title: Alibaba in talks with Hong Kong's SCMP Group for media assets: source
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has initiated talks with Hong Kong's SCMP Group to discuss buying its media assets, including the South China Morning Post newspaper. The approach comes after the publisher received a preliminary offer from an unidentified party. The South China Morning Post is a significant English-language publication in Hong Kong, and changes to its editorial direction are seen as a barometer for press freedom under Chinese rule.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba Group Holding has approached the publisher of Hong Kong's South China Morning Post newspaper to discuss buying its media assets, a source familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

site_title: Templeton puts faith in Malaysia with new global Islamic funds
summary: Franklin Templeton Investments plans to launch global Islamic stock and bond funds in Kuala Lumpur next year, aiming to attract some of the $376 billion in Malaysian bank deposits. The move follows a 17% decline in the ringgit and a political scandal that hurt investor confidence. The funds will complement existing Shariah-compliant options from CIMB-Principal Asset Management Bhd and RHB Islamic International Asset Management Bhd. The company's Luxembourg funds have already seen cumulative net returns of 7.53% and 11.1% over the past three years.

images.alt_text: The world's second-largest asset manager by market value plans to lure some of the US$376 billion parked in Malaysian bank deposits by setting up global Islamic stock and bond funds in Kuala Lumpur next year.

site_title: Southernwood Property clinches CPF Building sale tender with S$550m bid
summary: The CPF Board has awarded the S$550 million sale tender for the CPF Building at 79 Robinson Road to Southernwood Property, a unit of Ascendas Land. Southernwood Property met all tender criteria, including financial standing and purchase conditions. The sale follows the CPF Board's relocation of corporate operations to Novena Square Towers A and B, a "strategic move" to free up prime office space. The CPF Service Centre will continue to operate at 79 Robinson Road until further notice.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Good response for HDB's bumper crop of new flats; application rates stabilising: Wong
summary: Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said the HDB's November launch of new flats received a good response, with application rates stabilizing. The two-room flat with flexible leaseholds saw a 2.5 times application rate, while three-room flats received a 3.2 times rate. Notably, first-timer applicants in non-mature estates had a 1.6 times application rate, offering a chance for them to select an affordable flat. The November sale exercise saw a record 12,411 BTO and sale of balance flats on offer, with several policy changes benefiting Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Response for the Housing and Development Board's (HDB) November launch of new flats was good, Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said in a blog entry on Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.42% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.42% higher on Thursday, following gains on Wall Street after a one-day decline from a three-month peak. The Nikkei 225 index rose 82.39 points to 19,929.97, while the Topix index gained 0.36% to 1,600.34.

site_title: South Korea economy sustaining recovery at mid-Nov: central bank
summary: South Korea's economy maintained a modest recovery into mid-November, driven by growth in private consumption, construction spending, and service-sector output. Manufacturing output posted little growth, while capital investment remained unchanged. The Bank of Korea attributed the recovery to solid growth in these key categories.

site_title: Germany pledges to stand with France in fight against IS
summary: Germany pledged to stand with France in its fight against Islamic State (IS) jihadists, with French President Francois Hollande seeking support from his EU partner amid a diplomatic spat between Russia and Turkey. Hollande hoped Germany would do more in the fight against IS in Syria and Iraq. This comes as France prepares for a diplomatic tour, including a visit to Moscow, following the Paris attacks claimed by IS.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande (right) and German Chancellor Angela Merkel (left) make a statement at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France on Nov 25 2015.

site_title: South Korea central bank member sees no need for tightening soon after US hike
summary: South Korea's central bank does not anticipate raising interest rates soon, even if the US Federal Reserve hikes interest rates next month. Bank of Korea board member Chung Soon-won stated that the US rate hike will not prompt an immediate consideration of a rate hike in South Korea. Chung emphasized that the Bank of Korea's monetary policy committee will only consider a rate hike if the country's economic recovery strengthens. The committee has kept interest rates at a record low of 1.50% since June.

site_title: South Korea holds state funeral for ex-president
summary: South Korea held a state funeral for former president Kim Young-Sam, who died on Sunday at 87. The funeral was attended by President Park Geun-Hye, but the turnout was negligible, reflecting public ambivalence over Kim's legacy. Kim's term was marked by major events, including the 1994 nuclear crisis with North Korea and the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. He launched an anti-corruption campaign, arresting two former presidents on treason charges, but his son's bribery scandal later tarnished the effort. Kim's funeral was held at Seoul National University Hospital, followed by a ceremony at the National Assembly and burial at the national cemetery.

site_title: China's carbon footprint grows with the good life
summary: China's growing middle class has led to a significant increase in its carbon footprint, with the country now the world's second-largest economy and the worst polluter on the planet. Despite having a burgeoning middle class of 300 million, average incomes remain far below those of the US, and most people do not consider climate change a "very serious" problem. China's reliance on coal-fired power plants and smoke-belching factories contributes to its high emissions output, with the country's carbon footprint growing alongside its economic prosperity.

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by banks, healthcare; miners unloved
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by gains in banks and healthcare stocks, while miners fell. The S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 40.119 points to 5,233.8. Westpac, Commonwealth Bank, and National Australia Bank rose 1.7%, 1.1%, and 0.8% respectively. The gains were attributed to "buyers looking to pick up banks and high-yielding defensive names."

site_title: Singapore factory output declines 5.4% in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output declined 5.4% in October, driven by a 14% drop in electronics production. The overall decline matched market expectations, while excluding the biomedical cluster, output fell 6.4%. The electronics sector remained in contraction mode, with semiconductor output dropping 16.6%. In contrast, the chemicals cluster saw a 5.5% increase. After adjusting for seasonal factors, industrial production rose 2.5% in October.

site_title: Residential site at Siglap Road launched under government land sales programme
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a residential site at Siglap Road under the 2nd Half 2015 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. The 19,309.6-square metre site can potentially yield about 750 residential units, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 67,584 square metres and a maximum building height of 90 metres. The tender will close on January 14, 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Japan business lobby forecasts big capex growth if govt adopts sweeping reform
summary: Japan's largest business lobby, Keidanren, forecasts a 14% growth in capital spending to 81.7 trillion yen over the next three years if the government adopts sweeping reforms, including a cut in the corporate tax rate. The proposed tax rate would be below 30% and lower than the current 32.11%. The move aims to stimulate economic growth, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" strategy continues to struggle.

site_title: South Korea orders recall of 125,522 Volkswagen vehicles
summary: South Korea has ordered the recall of 125,522 Volkswagen vehicles due to allegations that the company manipulated diesel emissions devices. The country's testing revealed intentional manipulation by Volkswagen, and a fine of 14.1 billion won (S$17.3 million) was imposed. The recall affects Euro 5 engine vehicles with 2,000cc and 1,600cc diesel "EA189" engines, mainly sold in South Korea between 2008 and 2015. A separate investigation into newer "EA288" engine models is ongoing.

site_title: Japan pay disappointment: Grinch steals winter bonuses
summary: Japan's economy is facing another blow as analysts predict a 1-2% drop in winter bonuses for salaried workers, following a decline in summer bonuses. This is a disappointment for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government, which aims to boost consumer spending and economic growth through pay gains. The decline is attributed to the weakened economy, and it comes after summer bonuses shrank.

site_title: Japan business lobby says capex could surge if government moves on reforms
summary: Japan's business lobby, Keidanren, forecasts a 14% surge in capital spending over the next three years if the government adopts reforms, including a reduced corporate tax rate. The projected capital spending of 81.7 trillion yen would be the highest since the global financial crisis. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is pushing for companies to increase investment and raise pay to spur economic growth, with a goal of nominal 3% growth. The government plans to lower the corporate tax rate to below 30% and increase it to 25% as early as possible to accelerate investment.

site_title: China Fishery bonds drop 34% after HSBC asks court to wind it up
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc asked the Hong Kong High Court to wind up China Fishery Group Ltd and appoint a liquidator, causing its bonds to drop 34% in value. The company had received notices from Singapore authorities about an investigation and Moody's Investors Service downgraded it to Caa2 due to insufficient cash to cover expenses. This move comes after the company's 2019 bonds were bid at 33 cents on the dollar. The liquidation application was made after HSBC's decision to wind up the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Chinese stocks rise as PetroChina gains with banks
summary: Chinese stocks rose in Hong Kong for the first time in four days, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index gaining 1% to 10,227.13, driven by PetroChina's 1.4% advance and Industrial & Commercial Bank of China's 1.4% rise. The gains came amid speculation of government reforms to state-owned enterprises, and lower trading volumes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.71 points to 1678.15. Despite this, the market still saw 114 gainers for every 111 losers, with a total volume of 58.9 million lots worth RM14.1 million.

site_title: Asia: Shares rally with industrial metals while Aussie declines
summary: Asian stocks rallied ahead of the US Thanksgiving holiday, with industrial metals gaining as crude oil held above $43 a barrel. The Asia-Pacific equity benchmark rose 0.7% as shares in PetroChina Co surged for a sixth day, while Australia's dollar retreated amid a record pullback in business investment. The rally follows a two-year low in September and expectations of a US interest rate hike. Industrial metals, including nickel and copper, rebounded, while the euro remained unchanged despite speculation of a European Central Bank stimulus cut.

site_title: BNP Paribas turns to Singapore dollars for Tier 2 capital
summary: BNP Paribas is marketing Basel III-compliant Tier 2 Singapore dollar bonds at a price guidance of 4.5% to raise capital. The offering follows a similar non-call 5.5 bonds sale by BPCE in June, with a marginal premium at guidance. The notes, which will be used as a reference, are now indicated at around 4.4%. BNP, OCBC, and UOB are joint lead managers and bookrunners for the issue, expected to price today, with a rating of Baa2/BBB.

site_title: South Korea's November consumer sentiment at 14-month high
summary: South Korea's consumer confidence index reached a 14-month high in November, rising to 106 from 105 in October, according to the Bank of Korea. The index, which measures consumer optimism, has increased for five consecutive months, indicating consumers feel more optimistic about their economic and living conditions. This boost in consumer spending is seen as a positive sign for the economy's sustained recovery, offsetting the impact of weak exports.

site_title: Brazil central bank keeps key interest rate at 14.25%
summary: Brazil's Central Bank kept its key interest rate at 14.25% to combat inflation, which reached 9.93% in October, the highest in over a decade. The decision aims to address the country's deepening recession and economic struggles. The International Monetary Fund predicts a 3% shrinkage in Brazil's economy this year, while government forecasts indicate a 3.1% contraction and 1.9% decline next year. The country's currency has lost 30% of its value against the dollar, and unemployment remains at 7.6%, the highest rate since 2009.

site_title: Brazil corruption probe widens; Senate leader, BTG Pactual CEO arrested
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court ordered the arrest of Senate leader Delcídio do Amaral and BTG Pactual CEO André Esteves on suspicion of obstructing a corruption investigation into state-run oil company Petrobras. The arrest sent shares of BTG Pactual plummeting 21% and raised concerns about the bank's stability. The investigation has already implicated over 50 politicians, including President Dilma Rousseff, and threatens the country's banking and politics. The arrest of Esteves, a billionaire and influential dealmaker, has raised red flags at the central bank and raised questions about the bank's ability to navigate Brazil's recession.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KLW, PSL, KS Energy, Cordlife
summary: KLW Holdings withdrew an earlier action against Michael Chan Ewe Teik for S$7 million repayment. It filed a new Writ of Summons and Statement of Claim against Chan and Straitsworld Advisory. PSL Holdings completed the acquisition of a 49% stake in PT Momentum Indonesia Investama and approved a 10-into-one share consolidation. KS Energy's KS Marinehub acquired a 20% stake in Ocean Offshore Engineering for S$2.34 million. Cordlife Group is in discussions on various acquisition opportunities.

images.alt_text: The Cordlife Group, which preserves and stores stem cells from umbilical cords collected at birth for use in the future.

site_title: China oil giants seek asset sales to meet annual growth targets
summary: China's largest energy companies, including China Petrochemical Corp and PetroChina Co, are seeking to sell assets to meet annual growth targets amid falling oil prices. The companies face "unprecedented pressure" and are urged to cut costs. The move is part of a broader effort to meet government-set growth targets, with China Petrochemical's listed unit posting a 92% profit decline in the third quarter. Selling non-essential assets could help the companies focus on core businesses and survive the crude price slump.

site_title: Number of UK oil jobs falls at fastest rate in at least 11 years
summary: The UK oil and gas sector has seen a 6% decline in employment over the past year, with 62% of contractors reporting staff cuts, according to a survey by the Aberdeen and Grampian Chamber of Commerce. The sector has lost over 5,000 jobs since late 2014 due to a slump in oil prices. Contractors' business confidence has hit a historic low, with only 24% reporting new staff hires, and the outlook for next year remains negative. The decline is attributed to higher costs in the mature North Sea basin and project cancellations.

images.alt_text: The number of contractors employed in Britain's oil and gas sector has fallen over the past year at the steepest rate since at least 2004, an annual industry survey carried out by a Scottish business association showed on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Thursday, in line with Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.3% higher on Thursday, reaching 2,900.23 points. This follows Wall Street's mostly higher close on Wednesday. In Asia, Tokyo stocks rose 0.42% and Noble's share price remained flat. The STI had slipped 32 points on Wednesday. Overall, 91.3 million shares worth S$229.7 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 81 to 33 at 9am.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia
summary: Oil prices held above $43 a barrel in Asia, driven by a slower increase in US commercial crude supplies and lingering fears of escalation in the Middle East conflict. US commercial crude supplies rose 1.0 million barrels for the week ending November 20, but at a slower pace than previous increases. The market also reacted positively to better-than-expected durable goods orders in the US, and tensions in the region, including Turkey's downing of a Russian warplane, continue to support prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices held above US$43 a barrel in Asia Thursday after US commercial crude supplies rose at a slower pace while jitters over the shooting down by Turkey of a Russian warplane lingered.

site_title: US new-home sales rebound in October
summary: US new-home sales rebounded in October with a 10.7% increase to an annual rate of 495,000, surpassing the previous month's revised sales of 447,000. This marks a 4.9% year-over-year gain. The rebound follows a September slump, and prices fell year-over-year.

site_title: Euro falls ahead of ECB; dollar gains on data
summary: The euro fell ahead of an expected European Central Bank (ECB) monetary stimulus, while the US dollar gained due to strong economic data. Expectations of the ECB increasing debt purchases or taking unconventional measures led to the euro's decline. In the US, consumer spending rose 0.1% in October, but jobless claims edged lower, and durable goods orders and new-home sales gained. Analysts believe the Federal Reserve may consider raising rates in December due to the mixed but mostly positive US economic data.

site_title: Tesco in US$12m settlement over accounting scandal
summary: Tesco Plc has agreed to pay US$12 million to settle a US shareholder lawsuit claiming accounting irregularities inflated the share price of the British retailer. The settlement, which requires court approval, covers investors who acquired Tesco's American depositary shares and "F-shares" between 2012 and 2014. Tesco denied wrongdoing in agreeing to settle. The lawsuit alleged the company misled investors by overstating profit and inventory. The average recovery per share will be 37 cents, with Kahn Swick & Foti seeking up to 30% of the gross settlement fund in legal fees.

site_title: Big banks accused of interest rate-swap fixing in class action suit
summary: A class action lawsuit has been filed against 10 major Wall Street banks and two trading platforms, accusing them of conspiring to limit competition in the $320 trillion interest rate swap market. The lawsuit alleges that the banks colluded to prevent new competition from non-banks and extracted billions of dollars in monopoly rents from the market. The plaintiffs claim that the banks' collusion resulted in overpaying for interest rate swaps, with the Chicago teachers' pension and retirement fund allegedly paying billions of dollars more than necessary.

site_title: Obama says no specific terror threat against US
summary: US President Barack Obama reassured Americans traveling home for Thanksgiving that there is no credible and immediate terror threat against the US. Despite a worldwide travel alert issued by the State Department, Obama stated that "right now, we know of no specific and credible intelligence indicating a plot on the homeland." He emphasized that security services are working around the clock to keep the US safe, and urged the public to remain vigilant. The comments come amid heightened fears in the US following recent attacks by the Islamic State group in Paris and other locations.

site_title: Groundbreaking projects
summary: China's top-tier cities have seen infrastructure projects involving Singaporean government agencies and private sector players. Details of specific projects are not provided. China has urged South-east Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, while also unveiling new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as US rig count falls
summary: Oil prices rose 17 cents to $43.04 a barrel, with European benchmark Brent oil adding 5 cents to $46.17 a barrel. US oil supplies rose 1 million barrels, but a decline in US oil rigs to 555 suggested a supply glut. Analysts say the market remains skeptical, awaiting evidence of reduced output from lower rigs. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' meeting next week may provide insight into potential output cuts.

site_title: KLW withdraws earlier action for S$7m repayment, only to file another on Wed
summary: KLW Holdings has withdrawn an earlier action against Michael Chan Ewe Teik for S$7 million repayment, following legal advice. The company had advised to withdraw the action and file a fresh claim after November 21, 2015. KLW filed a new Writ of Summons and Statement of Claim against Chan and his company Straitsworld Advisory, claiming S$7 million repayment, damages, interests, and costs. The decision comes after KLW's board was advised that it's unlikely to succeed in obtaining summary judgement against Chan due to the repayment's timing.

site_title: China's chip crusade to intensify sector's record M&A run
summary: China's semiconductor industry is intensifying its mergers and acquisitions (M&A) run, with over $80 billion worth of deals announced in 2015. The country's state-owned companies, such as Tsinghua Unigroup, are acquiring foreign chipmakers to expand capacity and capabilities ahead of the Internet of Things (IoT) demand explosion. This buying spree is expected to push up M&A valuations and make it difficult for rival companies to compete, with some analysts warning that Chinese companies may be overpaying for targets.

images.alt_text: Tsinghua Unigroup logo is seen at its office in Beijing, China on Nov 15, 2015.

site_title: Fantasy sports site closes digital loophole ahead of US hearing
summary: DraftKings, one of the largest fantasy sports companies, has closed a digital loophole allowing users to make bets from states where daily fantasy sports is illegal. The company had been accessible via proxy servers, but has now partnered with GeoComply to provide geolocation services, blocking proxies. This move comes ahead of a court hearing in New York, where the state's attorney general is seeking a preliminary injunction to bar residents from accessing the sites, citing daily fantasy sports as a form of illegal internet gambling.

site_title: A learning journey
summary: Li Rongrong, former head of China's State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (SASAC), was inspired by Singapore's model of good governance during a 1999 visit. He studied Temasek Holdings' operations and implemented similar reforms, reducing the number of state-owned enterprises from 196 to 123 and increasing their value from 7 trillion yuan to 24 trillion yuan. Li's efforts led to increased interaction and partnership between SASAC and Singapore companies, earning him the Business China Excellence Award in 2015.

site_title: HP Inc plunges after printer business underwhelms
summary: HP Inc shares plummeted 16.3% after the company's printer and PC businesses underperformed, with revenue declining 14% each in the fourth quarter. The printer business, a "much greater challenge" for CEO Dion Weisler, saw revenue fall 10% due to price cuts and a stronger dollar. The PC business has been struggling due to falling sales worldwide, despite the launch of Windows 10. The company forecasted current-quarter profit below market expectations, contrasting with Hewlett Packard Enterprise's maintained profit forecast for fiscal 2016.

site_title: Macau's house of cards topples as investors lose big on junkets
summary: A Macau junket operator, Dore Entertainment Co Ltd, has been embroiled in a scandal after an employee stole millions of dollars from investors, sparking protests and hastening the demise of a business model that relied on VIP gamblers. The scandal has accelerated Macau's shift towards the mass-market segment of less wealthy tourists, with analysts predicting a stabilisation in mass-market gaming revenues. The junket industry's reputation has been severely damaged, with many operators going out of business or struggling to recover.

site_title: China's top cities to see home prices rise amid demand, says GIC
summary: China's top cities, including Beijing and Shanghai, are expected to see further home price increases due to strong demand from residents. The country's urbanization and economic growth prospects support the long-term outlook for the real estate market. Retail properties are consolidating as consumers turn to online shopping, while the government's stimulus measures have boosted property prices. GIC, a Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, is investing in China and other markets, with a focus on "increasingly dominant centers" and attractive tourism industries.

site_title: US reviews Thailand's trade benefits after labour complaint
summary: The US will review Thailand's eligibility for trade benefits after the AFL-CIO accused the country of breaching labor standards, including acceptable working conditions and forced labor. The US Trade Representative announced a hearing in January to address the issue. This review follows a similar assessment of Fiji, Georgia, Iraq, Niger, Uzbekistan, and Ecuador. Thailand exported $27.1 billion in goods to the US in 2014, mainly machinery and electrical machinery. The US previously closed a review of the Philippines after the country made progress in protecting workers' rights.

site_title: UK swings austerity axe but spares key welfare scheme, police
summary: The UK government announced a fresh round of austerity measures, including a £12 billion reduction in welfare payments and a 37% cut in government department budgets. However, it spared the police from savings, defying concerns about their ability to prevent a major attack. The decision was made after the House of Lords voted against a plan to cut tax credits, a benefit payment for low-income working families. Finance Minister George Osborne said the move was affordable due to projected tax revenue increases.

images.alt_text: Britain announced a fresh round of deep cuts to public spending Wednesday but dropped a plan to cut welfare payments for the poorest and spared the police from savings after the Paris attacks.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher in pre-holiday session
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Wednesday ahead of the Thanksgiving Day holiday and the holiday shopping season. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 1.20 points, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.27. Data showed consumer spending rose 0.1%, jobless claims edged lower, and durable goods orders rose. Analysts expect a 2% rise in US growth in the fourth quarter, potentially allowing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Markets will be closed Thursday and Friday.

site_title: Security firms warn of complex malware stealing card data
summary: Cybersecurity firm iSight Partners has warned of a complex malware, dubbed ModPOS, that can steal credit card and debit card numbers from retailers, evading current antivirus scans. The malware, discovered after two years of tracking, combines multiple modules and plug-ins to collect detailed information, including payment data and personal credentials. Experts warn that even EMV-protected systems can be compromised if infected point-of-sale systems are used, and consumers may not be aware of the technology used by retailers to protect their data.

site_title: Europe: Equities rebound, take step back from geopolitics
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Wednesday, driven by a positive economic outlook and tourism-linked firms, despite geopolitical tensions. The FTSE 100 index rose 1.0%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained. The eurozone's economic growth is expected to continue, according to Standard and Poor's, which noted stronger domestic demand outweighing soft exports. British homebuilders surged ahead of a government plan to build 400,000 affordable homes, and US stocks rose on mixed jobless and spending data.

site_title: Indonesian Vice-President challenges central bank to reduce interest rates
summary: Indonesian Vice-President Jusuf Kalla challenged the country's central bank to lower interest rates, citing the high rates as a hindrance to investment. The current rate of 7.5% is higher than neighboring countries, and Kalla argued that the central bank's reliance on the US Federal Reserve as an excuse to keep rates steady is unacceptable. The central bank, led by Governor Agus Martowardojo, has maintained its stance, citing stability and commodity prices.

site_title: Hilton hotels probing breach after cyber attack
summary: Hilton hotels reported a cyber attack that infected some of its point-of-sale systems with malware designed to steal credit card information. The breach occurred between November 18 and December 5, 2015, and April 21 and July 27, 2015, at a "limited number" of hotels in North America. Hilton is investigating the breach with third-party experts and advised customers to monitor their credit card accounts for irregular activity. The incident follows a similar breach at Starwood Hotels, which also reported a payment system hack potentially leaking customer credit card data.

site_title: Strengthening ties through music
summary: Singer-songwriter Tanya Chua, a Singaporean musician, is strengthening ties between Singapore and China through her music. She won the Business China Young Achiever award for her high profile in the Chinese pop scene. Chua plans to open a chain of bakeries, inspired by her passion for French pastry, in China, particularly in Beijing. Her latest Mandarin album, Aphasia, features an electronica vibe and explores themes of self-discovery and cultural identity. Chua aims to promote Chinese culture through her music, not as a diplomat, but as a human being.

images.alt_text: Tanya Chua is the 2015 winner of the Business China Young Achiever award for contributing to Sino-Singapore relations with her high profile in the Chinese pop music scene.

site_title: Chile faces copper smelting dilemma
summary: Chile, the world's top copper-producing nation, is facing a crucial decision regarding its antiquated smelters. The country's state-owned copper company, Codelco, is considering either investing billions to overhaul its smelters or closing them down and shipping more unrefined material to Asia or Europe. This decision will have significant implications for the global copper trade and is expected to be presented to President Michelle Bachelet next quarter. Experts recommend either shutting down and reopening smelters or investing in new, more efficient technology to add value to Chile's copper production.

site_title: US Republicans move to dump Trump
summary: US Republicans are increasingly criticizing Donald Trump's candidacy, with some labeling him a "fascist" due to his inflammatory remarks. Trump's comments on registering Muslims and his assertion that thousands cheered on 9/11 have sparked outrage among party members and experts. The New York Times and Seattle Times have denounced his rhetoric, calling it "racist lies" and "creeping fascism." Despite criticism, Trump's campaign remains resilient, and Republican groups are preparing attack ads against him, including a new anti-Trump ad blitz.

site_title: US regulator files lawsuit against ex-Goldman staff for insider trading
summary: US securities regulators filed a lawsuit against former Goldman Sachs employee Yue Han, alleging he engaged in insider trading based on information about deals involving the bank's clients. Han, who worked in compliance, traded on confidential information obtained through the bank's IT systems, earning over $468,000. The trades occurred from July to October, including a $397,000 profit from a deal involving Lam Research Corp. Han's assets have been frozen, and he is believed to be living in China, where he is a citizen.

site_title: PlayStation 4 console sales top 30 million
summary: Sony announced that PlayStation 4 (PS4) consoles have sold over 30 million units worldwide as of November 22, marking the fastest and strongest adoption since the first generation of video game consoles. This surpasses Microsoft's Xbox One sales, which are estimated at around half of PS4's. The strong sales contributed to Sony's six-month net profit of almost US$1.0 billion, with the company crediting its PlayStation unit and a weak yen for the improvement in its finances.

images.alt_text: A customer holds a bag containing the Sony Computer Entertainment Inc. PlayStation 4 (PS4) video game console after purchasing at the Sony showroom in Tokyo, Japan, on Saturday, Feb 22, 2014.

site_title: 2015 exports and trade forecasts cut, again
summary: Singapore's trade promotion agency International Enterprise Singapore has cut forecasts for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) and total merchandise trade for 2015, citing a disappointing third-quarter performance. NODX is now expected to grow 0.5-1.0% for 2015, down from earlier forecasts of 1-2 and 1-3%. Total merchandise trade is likely to fall 10-10.5%, with growth expected to return only in early 2016.

site_title: Summit in Paris presents best chance yet of climate change deal
summary: The UN Climate Change Summit in Paris, set to begin on November 30, holds the best chance yet to secure a global deal on climate change. Over 130 world leaders, including US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping, will gather to address the issue. The summit comes after 166 countries have submitted national climate plans, but a 3°C rise in temperature is still considered too high by the UN. The US, China, and India have shown greater resolve, but developing countries demand more funding to help them reduce emissions and adapt to climate change, leaving a significant funding gap.

site_title: Google gets 348,085 'forget' requests in Europe
summary: Google has received 348,085 "forget" requests in Europe, with users in France and Germany leading the way, following a European Court of Justice ruling in 2014 recognizing the "right to be forgotten" on the net. Since then, Google set up an online form for users to request removal of inaccurate or irrelevant search results about them.

site_title: Celebrating 25 years of Singapore-China diplomatic ties
summary: Singapore is celebrating 25 years of diplomatic ties with China, marking a significant milestone in the growing partnership between the two nations. The upgraded partnership aims to enhance mutual benefits, strengthen regional and global coordination, and promote peace and stability in the region. Key agreements include the China-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (CSFTA) upgrade, government-to-government projects, and collaborations in education, urban management, and customs. The partnership also includes initiatives to promote bilingualism and biculturalism in Singapore, such as Business China's programs.

site_title: The Fed is overhauling standards for large-bank examiners
summary: The Federal Reserve is overhauling standards for large-bank examiners following criticism that the agency has been influenced by Wall Street firms it supervises. The overhaul includes creating a formal process for examiners to express dissenting views and establishing a centralized committee to oversee minimum operating and documentation standards. The changes aim to strengthen oversight of the largest and most complex financial institutions, following a year-long review that found inconsistency across the Fed's 12 regional banks.

site_title: Dollar to surge afresh in '16; EM currencies to crumble: JP Morgan
summary: JP Morgan predicts the US dollar will surge against emerging-market currencies, with the yen likely to appreciate against most leading currencies, in 2016. The bank forecasts the renminbi to depreciate by 5% in real terms against the dollar. The report highlights acute risks faced by the US Federal Reserve as it approaches potential interest rate hikes, citing poor prospects for emerging-market economies, including China's economic slowdown.

site_title: United Continental, Delta bet on long oil slump
summary: Two major US airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Continental, are reducing their fuel hedging due to the prolonged low oil prices, which have cost them hundreds of millions of dollars in the past three quarters. The airlines are becoming more cautious, similar to American Airlines, and are now focusing on long-term strategies rather than short-term hedging. Delta has reduced its fuel hedging to 5% for next year, while United is 17% hedged, down from previous levels. This shift is expected to save the airlines from further losses.

site_title: Global group wins A$10.3b bid for Australia power assets
summary: A global group, consisting of Canadian and Middle Eastern investors, has won a bid of approximately A$10.3 billion to acquire TransGrid, the electricity network in Australia's most populous state of New South Wales. The successful bidders, including Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, beat rival offers from companies including State Grid Corp of China. The deal is part of NSW Premier Mike Baird's plan to raise A$20 billion for new infrastructure projects, and marks a significant increase in foreign acquisitions of Australian companies this year.

site_title: For S'pore economy, a heavy note of caution
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow as little as 1% in 2016, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry's forecast, marking one of the most pessimistic projections in over a decade. The government's cautious view reflects sector-specific factors, including weak manufacturing and sustained low oil prices, as well as labor constraints in labor-intensive sectors. Global growth is expected to improve in 2016, but downside risks include a potential "significant drop in demand" in China and the normalization of US monetary conditions.

site_title: RFI exercise on KL-S'pore high-speed rail project receives 98 submissions
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project has received 98 submissions from firms worldwide, with the majority from European companies. The Malaysia and Singapore governments expect to finalize the project's commercial model and procurement approach by next year. The project, initially set to be completed by 2020, now faces a revised timeline with trains expected to start running in 2023 at the earliest.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

The iconic Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur. A total of 98 submissions have been received for the Kuala Lumpur - Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project, with the majority of firms hailing from Europe.

site_title: Chinese lenders scramble to strengthen their trading desks
summary: Chinese lenders are scrambling to hire currency traders to capitalize on the yuan's inclusion in the IMF's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, which could attract $1.1 trillion in Chinese assets over the next five years. Despite a recent devaluation, the yuan's volatility has made traders with experience and international exposure highly sought after. Banks are offering higher salaries and bonuses to attract top talent, with some even willing to hire foreigners who have passed a test conducted by the China Foreign Exchange Trade System.

site_title: Building bridges through business
summary: Keppel Corporation has strengthened ties between Singapore and China through various businesses, including the China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) and the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City. The company has operations across 25 cities in China, with a strong track record and good relations with Chinese partners. Despite challenges, Keppel remains confident about China's potential and plans to seize opportunities in the market, leveraging its competencies to offer solutions for the country's rapid urbanisation.

images.alt_text: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation is one of the leading Singaporean logistics service providers in China, with operations in five cities, including Foshan in Guangdong (above).

site_title: Rolls-Royce boss says no to break-up
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings CEO Warren East has concluded that the company is better off retaining its current focus, resisting investor calls for a break-up, and refocusing on its nuclear and marine-engines businesses. East cited the growing nuclear sector and potential for profit in Asia as reasons to resist re-entry into the narrow-body market. The company aims to save £200 million a year from 2017 by slimming down management and improving market response. East also rejected activist fund ValueAct Capital Management's call to break up the company, stating that non-core under-performing businesses should be re-focused rather than sold.

site_title: PSL completes acquisition of stake in Momentum Indonesia
summary: PSL Holdings has completed the acquisition of a 49% stake in Indonesia-based marine logistics player PT Momentum Indonesia Investama. The acquisition, approved unanimously by shareholders, includes a 10-into-one share consolidation. PSL Holdings will lend US$11.5 million and US$8.5 million to Momentum, which will use the funds to pay down existing bank borrowings. Sudirman Kurniawan, one of the two stake vendors, will join PSL as an executive officer.

site_title: Upgraded A320 gets nod from US, European regulators
summary: Airbus has secured certification from the European Aviation Safety Agency (Easa) and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for the A320neo, a fuel-efficient upgrade of its popular A320 medium-haul jet. The approval paves the way for the first delivery of the revamped jet to Qatar Airways next month, with over 4,300 units expected to be sold. The upgrade, which includes new engines from Pratt & Whitney, aims to achieve 15% fuel savings and has boosted Airbus' share price. This move follows Boeing's similar upgrade of its 737 model, solidifying the dominance of these two plane giants in the global market.

site_title: Global insurers increase risk appetite in low yield environment
summary: Global insurers are increasing their investment risk appetite in a low-yield environment, with 57% planning to boost exposure in the next 1-2 years, up from 33% last year. BlackRock attributes this shift to insurers seeking alternative credit asset classes to boost income. The move is seen as a response to decreasing yields due to loose central bank policy and a stuttering economy. Insurers must adapt to support the fund management industry, which is expected to "raise its game" to support insurers in this new environment.

site_title: No respite for South Korea's corporate bond issuers
summary: South Korea's corporate bond market is experiencing a surge in bond yields, making it difficult for companies to access cheaper financing. Despite two Bank of Korea interest rate cuts earlier this year, investors are demanding higher premiums due to the country's industrial sector's decline and the expected US Federal Reserve rate hike. The yield spread for BBB-minus rated corporate bonds has reached its highest since 2012, while new issuers are struggling to find buyers, with the volume of new issuance halving to 2.50 trillion won in September.

site_title: Maersk Line sees intra-Asia trade growing 3-5% in 2016
summary: Maersk Line expects intra-Asia trade to grow 3-5% in 2016, higher than its global forecast of 2-4%. Despite a slowdown in China's economic expansion, the Danish shipping giant remains positive on the region's trade volume due to its large population and expanding income per capita. Maersk Line plans to reduce its shore-based staff worldwide by 4,000 by 2017 through cost restructuring, with some positions moved from Denmark to Asia. The company expects South-east Asia trade to expand 2-4% in 2015 and 3-5% in 2016.

site_title: Telegram, the messaging app ISIS used, shrouded in secrecy
summary: Telegram, an encrypted messaging app, has faced concerns over its adoption by the Islamic State. Despite founder Pavel Durov's claims of the app's security, cryptologists and security experts have questioned its trustworthiness. Telegram was initially conceived as a non-profit, but was later managed by for-profit shell companies, including in the US. The app's true ownership and base of operations are unclear, and Durov has faced criticism for not doing enough to address extremist groups using the platform. The app's founder, Pavel Durov, has been described as unpredictable and has a history of secrecy and conflict with the Kremlin.

images.alt_text: "Pavel is really unpredictable. His biggest drive has always been notoriety." - Axel Neff, the estranged co-founder and former chief information officer of Telegram

site_title: VW under probe for tax evasion from emissions cheating
summary: German prosecutors have opened an investigation into Volkswagen for allegedly making false claims about carbon dioxide emissions from its vehicles, potentially leading to tax evasion. The probe, focusing on five suspects, stems from the carmaker's admission that it understated emissions for about 800,000 vehicles sold in Europe. Volkswagen has estimated a 2.2 billion euro (S$3.3 billion) cost to reimburse European governments. The investigation comes as allegations of emissions cheating spread to other carmakers, with a Renault passenger van showing suspicious pollution readings.

site_title: Top China official among Business China Award winners
summary: Li Rongrong, a top Chinese official, was honored at this year's Business China Awards for promoting Singapore-China relations. He received the award along with Keppel Corporation and singer Tanya Chua. The sixth annual awards ceremony was attended by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean. This recognition aims to strengthen bilateral ties between Singapore and China.

site_title: STI slides on jitters over Middle-East conflict
summary: The Singapore stock market declined 32 points, or 1.09%, to close at 2,891.58, amid geopolitical concerns following Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet near the Syrian border. Investors focused on the Middle East conflict rather than local data, which showed the Singapore economy grew better than expected in the third quarter. Key losses included SingTel, DBS, and OCBC, while Neptune Orient Lines and Memtech International gained. The market remains fixated on a potential December Fed rate liftoff, with analysts predicting a "gradual" tightening process.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Over 1,000 firms to take part in 2016 Singapore Airshow
summary: The 2016 Singapore Airshow, the fifth edition, will take place from February 16-21 with over 1,000 participating companies from 50 countries. Over 90% of exhibition space has been booked, mainly by returning exhibitors and industry powerhouses. The event will feature a training and simulation zone, an aerospace emerging technologies zone, and strategic conferences. French firms will be the featured country, with special programmes and facilitated meetings with VIP delegations. The airshow aims to capitalize on Asia's growing fleet and support investment in the region's aerospace industry.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: A sterling track record in China
summary: Singapore companies have established themselves as key players in China's infrastructure development, leveraging their experience to contribute to the country's rapid urbanization. Since the 1990s, companies such as Keppel Corporation and Ascendas Singbridge have been involved in high-profile government-to-government projects, including the Suzhou Industrial Park and Tianjin Eco-City, which have become models for sustainable urbanization. Their efforts have attracted significant investments and helped to address China's infrastructure challenges, with Singapore companies now operating in 25 Chinese cities.

site_title: Motivating households to reduce electricity consumption
summary: Singapore aims to reduce its emissions by 2.5% each year from 2020 to 2030, prompting households to cut down on unnecessary electricity usage. Despite the goal, Singapore households have deeply entrenched energy habits due to the small size of their electricity bills relative to other expenses. The government has implemented measures such as bar graphs on utility bills and a pilot mobile app to encourage energy conservation. The introduction of smart meters and energy-efficient appliances is also expected to promote energy-saving habits among households.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KS Energy's unit, KS Marinehub, acquired a 20% stake in Ocean Offshore Engineering for S$2.34 million. This acquisition makes KS Marinehub an indirect wholly owned unit of KS Distribution. Meanwhile, Cordlife Group is in discussions with parties on potential acquisitions, divestments, and joint ventures, but no agreements have been signed.

site_title: US$ eases as geopolitical woes boost euro, yen
summary: The US dollar experienced broad losses on Wednesday as investors cut long positions ahead of the US Thanksgiving holidays and amid heightened geopolitical tensions. The euro and yen strengthened, with the yen hitting a 1 ½ week high against the dollar. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 99.429, despite expectations of temporary weakness. Analysts attributed the dollar's decline to risk aversion, rather than Fed expectations, with the euro and yen benefiting from the trend.

site_title: Getting to the heart of the energy debate
summary: Global leaders will gather in Paris to discuss balancing rising energy demand with environmental impact at the UN Climate Change Conference. The world's energy consumption is expected to double by 2050, with Asia-Pacific driving most of the growth. Renewable energy currently accounts for just 3% of global energy consumption, mostly due to its high cost. Governments, industry, and society must work together to develop long-term, sustainable energy solutions, including cleaner energy sources and carbon pricing. Key questions include how to incentivize investment in renewable energy, minimize environmental impact of fossil fuels, and balance energy demands with environmental consequences.

site_title: Financing China's Asian ambitions
summary: OCBC aims to position itself as a trusted partner for Chinese enterprises venturing into South-east Asia, leveraging its long track record on the mainland and expertise in regional markets. The bank's "offshore and onshore" strategy has helped fuel growth, with China now accounting for 20% of its pre-tax profit. OCBC's head of corporate banking, George Lee, notes that Singapore's strong relationship with China and initiatives like the "One Belt, One Road" initiative have boosted business ties between the two countries, and the bank intends to play a significant role in the initiative.

site_title: US jobless claims tumble
summary: US jobless claims fell to 260,000 in the week ending November 21, a four-decade low, with a 12,000 drop from the previous week. The four-week moving average remained at 271,000, unchanged from the prior week. This decline in claims follows the strongest job growth in the year, with 271,000 jobs added in October and the unemployment rate dropping to 5.0%, its lowest level since early 2008.

site_title: UK banks step up pace of mortgage approvals: BBA
summary: UK banks increased mortgage approvals in October, reaching the highest annual growth rate since April 2014. 45,437 mortgages were approved, a 21% increase from the previous year. Personal lending also expanded, with a £228 million increase in October, the largest since 2006. The British Bankers' Association attributes the growth to consumer confidence and rising incomes. The Bank of England may implement new capital requirements to curb rapid consumer credit growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China's wastewater treatment stocks are being upgraded due to the country's efforts to improve its water treatment industry. RHB Research recommends China Everbright Water and SIIC Environment Holdings, citing their strong balance sheets and first-mover advantages. Meanwhile, Memtech International is expected to deliver strong earnings growth due to its diversification into the automotive and consumer electronics sectors. Singapore's Pay-TV players, M1 and StarHub, are also valued, but at risk due to the threat of a potential fourth mobile player.

site_title: German economic growth depends on a weak euro
summary: German economic growth is heavily dependent on a weak euro, which has boosted exports to countries like China, accounting for 20% of Germany's surplus. A stronger euro would harm Germany's export-led economy, while a further shift towards monetary easing by the European Central Bank would send the euro lower, providing a boost to exports. However, the Chinese economic slowdown has weakened the German economy, and the outcome depends on central banks' efforts to influence exchange rates, with potential further euro decline providing German stimulus.

site_title: HK hedge fund seeks US$4b payout from Kyocera
summary: A Hong Kong hedge fund, Oasis Management, is pressuring Japanese electronics maker Kyocera to pay back over $4 billion to investors by selling its stake in phone carrier KDDI Corp. The stake, worth $11.7 billion, is considered too risky and equivalent to years of profits. Oasis Management's chief investment officer, Seth Fischer, wants Kyocera to sell its stake and use the proceeds to boost its safety buffer and invest in its growth businesses. Kyocera's chairman emeritus, Kazuo Inamori, has refused to consider the request, citing the investment as a reserve against hard times.

site_title: Manufacturing loses traction as services lead Q3 growth
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 1.9% in the third quarter, driven by growth in the services and construction sectors. Manufacturing, however, contracted 6.2% year-on-year, marking the first decline this year. The services sector, including wholesale and retail trade, posted growth ranging from 0.3% to 6.8%, while employment in manufacturing declined by 4,300. Economists attribute manufacturing's contraction to a decline in transport engineering, electronics, and precision engineering output.

site_title: Qatar to vote on family-only days at major shopping malls
summary: Qatar's Central Municipal Council (CMC) will vote on December 1 to introduce "family-only days" at major shopping malls, restricting entrance to families only on one day each weekend, potentially excluding foreign laborers. The proposal, championed by a CMC member, aims to address perceived intimidation of locals, particularly women, by the presence of male laborers in malls. However, human rights groups warn that the policy could further restrict access for foreign workers and damage Qatar's reputation, particularly after the 2022 World Cup.

site_title: Civil servants to get 0.65-month year-end bonus
summary: Singapore civil servants will receive a year-end bonus of 0.65 month, with lower-wage officers receiving at least S$1,100. This compares to the previous year's bonus of 0.8 month. The decision was made after consultation with public-sector unions, amid a slowing economy with a 1.9% year-on-year GDP growth in the third quarter. The total bonus package for public servants amounts to 1.15 months, with lower-wage officers receiving more than if pegged to their monthly wages.

images.alt_text: Civil servants will be paid a year-end bonus of 0.65 month, and lower-wage officers, at least S$1,100.

site_title: Banks picked to lead Swedish bank Resurs' flotation
summary: Private equity firm Nordic Capital has selected Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Carnegie to lead the stock market listing of Swedish banking and insurance group Resurs Holding, planned for the first half of 2016. Based on valuations of listed peers, Resurs may be worth around 13 billion Swedish kronor (S$2.1 billion). The company has been exploring strategic options, including a listing, due to the growth of the financial services sector in Sweden.

site_title: Shift to 'more accurate' productivity measure, but challenges remain
summary: Singapore's government plans to shift to a more accurate metric of value-add (VA) per actual hour worked to measure labour productivity. This change could potentially show the economy better satisfies productivity growth expectations. Currently, VA per worker showed zero growth in the three months ended September compared to the same period a year ago. The shift aims to provide a more accurate representation of productivity growth.

images.alt_text: Singapore's government will place a greater emphasis on the "more accurate" metric of value-add (VA) per actual hour worked to measure labour productivity.

site_title: Powered by technology, smart toys are us
summary: Smart toys are becoming increasingly popular, with many featuring advanced technology and personalized play. The "toys-to-life" category, led by Activision's Skylanders, has grown to a $4 billion market, with new characters and franchises emerging, including Disney, Lego, and Nintendo. Smart toys extend beyond figurines, with Disney and Hasbro's Playmation toys allowing kids to play video games in real life. However, concerns over privacy have risen, particularly with toys that record children's speech, such as Mattel's Hello Barbie. Manufacturers are working to address these concerns, providing parents with access to data and clear guidelines on data usage.

site_title: Opec may stay the course despite fears of US$20 oil
summary: OPEC is set to maintain its current oil production levels despite concerns that US$20 oil could be reached due to global oversupply. Saudi Arabia, the policy's chief architect, is under strain from the resulting budget deficit, but is choosing to keep production levels high in hopes of a longer-term payoff. Russia may attend informal consultations with OPEC but is unlikely to join coordinated output cuts, making a policy U-turn unlikely. Analysts predict that prices could continue to drop, potentially reaching mid-20s, unless non-OPEC producers join the effort to cut output.

site_title: Consumer spending points to moderate Q4 growth
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in October, slower than forecast, but still points to moderate economic growth in the fourth quarter. Households boosted savings to nearly three-year highs, driven by rising incomes and wages. The Commerce Department reported a 2.1% economic growth rate in the third quarter, with an anticipated drag from inventory reduction. Economists predict a 2% growth rate for the fourth quarter, with business investment plans showing a surge in October.

site_title: UBS gives Edmund Koh enlarged Asia-Pac role
summary: UBS has appointed Edmund Koh, 55, as head of UBS Wealth Management in the Asia-Pacific, overseeing Singapore, Hong Kong, and 11 other locations. Koh, who joined UBS in 2012, takes over from Kathryn Shih, who is now president of UBS Asia-Pacific. The appointment is seen as a strategic move to develop the bank's strong position in the region.

site_title: GIC 'underinvested' in real estate, eyes deals in key gateway cities
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is underinvested in real estate, currently holding 7% of its assets in the sector. The fund aims to increase this proportion to 9-13% through large transactions in key gateway cities, such as New York and London, and emerging markets, which will be crucial for its long-term strategy despite short-term geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: "We must be very disciplined in looking at every asset and determining in the long term which assets have income growth left in them. Because when cap rates move up, you need income growth to shelter the impact of cap rate movements." - Goh Kok Huat, chief operating officer and president of real estate at GIC

site_title: ECB warns of Asia risks rising as Fed liftoff tests stability
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has raised its risk-assessment level for global financial-market instability to "medium" due to rising risks in emerging markets, particularly if the US Federal Reserve increases interest rates faster than expected. The ECB warns of a rapid repricing of global risk premium, which could lead to a reversal of global term premia and potentially impact the euro area. The bank is considering expanding monetary stimulus to counter stagnation in consumer prices, with options including stepping up bond-buying and cutting the deposit rate further below zero.

site_title: Cordlife in talks for potential acquisitions, divestments and JVs
summary: CORDLIFE Group is in talks with various parties for potential acquisitions, divestments, and joint ventures. The company's shares rose 8% to S$1.32 following the announcement. Cordlife stated that no definitive agreements have been signed and there is no certainty that any deals will materialize. The firm will keep shareholders informed of any material developments.

site_title: Coca-Cola's chief scientific and regulatory officer stepping down
summary: Coca-Cola's chief scientific and regulatory officer, Rhona Applebaum, is stepping down after revelations that the company funded research that downplayed the role of Coke products in obesity. Applebaum helped establish the Global Energy Balance Network, a non-profit group that encouraged public focus on exercise over food and beverages. The company spent $1.5 million on the group, including a $1 million grant to a university medical school, prompting criticism that Coca-Cola was influencing scientific research. The university returned the funds, and the company has acknowledged a lack of transparency in its involvement with the group.

site_title: Japan's negative yields drawing record global investment
summary: Global investors are flocking to Japan's government bonds with negative yields, drawing a record $27.5 billion in October, despite US Treasuries offering higher yields. The Bank of Japan's stimulus has depressed yields, making JGBs attractive to foreign investors. The spread between JGBs and equivalent Treasuries has widened, with two- and five-year debt yields more than those of major sovereigns. The trend is expected to continue as monetary policy diverges, with Barclays predicting further widening in dollar-yen basis swaps.

site_title: Existing Reit markets still have room to grow
summary: Existing Reit markets in Asia-Pacific, including Australia, Japan, Singapore, and Hong Kong, have room for growth despite being developed. Analysts point to tax and legislation as major hurdles to forming Reit regimes in nascent markets such as the Philippines, Thailand, and Indonesia. Key markets like India and Vietnam are being explored, but face challenges like high VAT and lack of implementing regulations. The lack of a proper Reit code in China is also hindering its growth, with the government postponing the release due to stockmarket fluctuations.

images.alt_text: "I think that the core markets we have are not yet fully developed. Having more regimes out there is a very positive thing, but I see the major markets, especially Japan, far from developed. Japan to me could potentially be a game-changer if it were to adopt policies that allow major developers to defer paying exit taxes of some sort." - Christian Bernasconi, managing director of B&I Capital. (Above) Aerial view of Tokyo

site_title: Playground weaklings give Li Ka-shing bloody nose
summary: Hong Kong's public investors rejected tycoon Li Ka-shing's $12.4 billion bid to merge his energy and infrastructure units with Power Assets, a 61% stake in the company. The bid was initially met with a low ratio of 1.04 CKI shares for each Power Assets share, sparking concerns about the terms. Despite the low ratio, shareholders voted against the deal, with only half in favor, sending a message that Hong Kong's institutions will no longer be pushed around. The decision could prove painful for Power Assets shareholders in the short term, but it shows investors are willing to flex their limited muscles.

site_title: Thailand's car exports set to hit record, shift economy into higher gear
summary: Thailand's car exports are projected to hit a record this year, boosting the economy after 18 months of military rule. Exports rose 3.9% in the first 10 months, driven by increased demand for pick-up trucks and affordable car models. Industry executives expect exports to reach 1.2 million cars this year and 1.22 million next year, with major manufacturers like Toyota and Honda aiming to increase their exports. However, weak global demand has led to a decline in other export sectors, and total shipments are forecast to fall 5% this year.

site_title: HP Q1 profit forecast falls short amid PC slump
summary: HP Inc forecasted first-quarter profit between 33-38 cents per share, missing analyst estimates, amid a decline in personal-computer and printer sales. The standalone business faces challenges as corporations shift to cloud-based services and mobile devices. CEO Meg Whitman is looking for ways to return to growth. HP Enterprise Co also reported lower-than-expected profit, with its annual forecast unchanged, and shares rose 2.5% in extended trading.

site_title: Optimism in West as markets prepare for Fed hike
summary: The global economy shows signs of optimism, with the US and Europe poised for growth despite emerging markets facing challenges.
