Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's recent visit to the region aimed to counter Chinese President Xi Jinping's "Silk Road" diplomacy and secure access to natural resources. China has launched the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which Japan has declined to join, further escalating the competition. Russia, a key player in the region, sees Central Asia as its "backyard" and is deepening its ties with China. The geopolitical transformation in North-east Asia is driving Japan's desire to strengthen its presence in the region and counter China's growing influence.

site_title: Ambank shares fall on news of its RM54m penalty
summary: Ambank Holdings Bhd shares dropped 0.7% to RM4.56 on Tuesday after agreeing to pay a nearly RM54 million penalty for unspecified law breaches, linked to the 1MDB scandal. The fine pertains to non-compliance with regulations, according to the Financial Services Act and Islamic Financial Services Act. Ambank said the penalty will not impact its FY16 earnings and has committed to a four-year programme to achieve market best practices. The banking group has also agreed to provide RM25 million annually for investment in systems and training.

site_title: US$ drops on Russia-Turkey tensions
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.3% against the yen and 0.1% against the Swiss franc due to rising tensions between Russia and Turkey. Turkish fighter jets shot down a Russian warplane near the Syrian border, triggering a "flight to safety" and supporting safe haven currencies. The dollar index fell 0.2% to 99.569, while investors see a near-75% chance the Fed will hike rates next month, boosting expectations that interest rates will remain low.

site_title: Hong Kong's natural heritage
summary: Hong Kong's rural areas harbor a surprising abundance of wild animals, including monkeys, Burmese pythons, and 14 types of venomous snakes. After being abandoned by farmers in the 1970s, feral cattle and water buffalo have thrived, with some herds now numbering in the hundreds. Conservation efforts, led by the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department and volunteer groups, aim to preserve these animals and their habitats. The cattle's presence has sparked a shift in attitudes towards wildlife in Hong Kong, with some residents embracing the animals as part of their community.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's Power Assets buyout offer rejected
summary: Li Ka-shing's US$12.4 billion buyout offer for Power Assets Holdings Ltd was rejected by shareholders, falling short of the 75% minority shareholder vote needed. The proposal, made through Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd, aimed to consolidate Li's utilities and infrastructure businesses before handing over control to his son Victor. The rejection marks a rare setback for Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing, as he seeks to consolidate his empire.

site_title: RBA chief sees low global rates for most of the decade ahead
summary: RBA governor Glenn Stevens predicts low global interest rates for "a good part" of the decade ahead, citing low inflation and slow wage growth. He notes that recent data suggests improving industry prospects and increasing employment, despite weaker-than-expected inflation. Stevens also mentions that global interest rates will likely remain low due to structural changes in the global economy, with the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan unlikely to raise rates anytime soon.

site_title: The end of fiscal obstruction
summary: Fiscal policy in the US, eurozone, and Japan is expected to become more growth-friendly in the coming years, reversing years of austerity. A recent US budget deal and potential overseas profit repatriation tax bill and infrastructure spending in the US, as well as fiscal fatigue and immigration in the eurozone, could lead to mildly expansionary fiscal policies. In Japan, a fiscal stimulus package is reportedly in the works. This shift is seen as a welcome change, particularly in an ailing global economy, where every penny counts, and may bear watching for potential synchronization across G-3 economies.

site_title: Banks, Genting fuel STI rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 20 points to 2,923.49, driven by short-covering in banks and Genting Singapore ahead of an expected Wall Street rebound. The healthcare sector saw gains, with Raffles Medical rising S$0.01 to S$4.20. OCBC Investment Research upgraded OCBC to a "buy" citing undervaluation, while Maybank Kim Eng maintained a "hold" on SIA Engineering Company. Nordic Group's shares dropped 11.8% due to unusual trading activity, and Catalist-listed KLW ended S$0.001 weaker amid accounting concerns.

site_title: ECB launches 20-euro note with enhanced security
summary: The European Central Bank launched a new 20-euro banknote with enhanced security features to foil counterfeiters. The note features a "portrait window" that becomes transparent when seen against the light, revealing a portrait of Europa from Greek mythology. This move aims to maintain the importance of cash as a payment method, according to ECB Executive Board member Yves Mersch.

site_title: SGX reviewing corporate governance compliance
summary: SGX is reviewing its corporate governance compliance among listed companies, with potential action against those that fail to meet the code. The review aims to boost the bourse's regulatory credibility. Chief Regulatory Officer Tan Boon Gin warned that unexplained deviations could lead to action. The review will publish results and highlight areas for improvement, including boilerplate explanations. Companies that fail to comply may face one-on-one improvement efforts and potential regulatory action.

site_title: Germany power market resorts to algorithm trading
summary: Germany's shift to renewable energy has led to a highly volatile power market, making it difficult for humans to manage risk limits. To cope with this volatility, many trading firms, including Grundgruen Energie GmbH, are using algorithmic computer programs to buy and sell electricity contracts. These programs can quickly react to changes in weather and power supply, but also require rapid decision-making, giving humans limited control. The use of algorithms in power trading is increasing, with around 9 other firms using similar methods, and is seen as a competitive advantage by companies like Grundgruen.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's commitment to green energy has led to a three-fold increase in solar and wind power in the past decade as well as an exit from more predictable nuclear.

site_title: Asean's quest for relevance, purpose
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has made significant progress in regional integration, with leaders agreeing to establish the Asean Community by 2025 and adopt a roadmap for the grouping. This move aims to strengthen Asean as a leading regional organization and promote integration efforts in the economic, political-security, and socio-cultural spheres. Closer integration will enable Asean to effectively engage with a more competitive global landscape and an ascendant China. However, the grouping's ability to achieve its goals will depend on its ability to entrench norms, calibrate itself to external norms, and address domestic challenges.

site_title: 2 sites launched under industrial government land sales programme
summary: JTC has launched two industrial government land sales (IGLS) sites in Singapore. A 0.41-hectare site in Tampines will be sold on a 20-year tenure with a maximum gross plot ratio of 1.4, while a 1.61-hectare site in Woodlands will be sold on a 30-year leasehold with a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.5. Analysts expect three to five bids for the Tampines site and a top land bid of S$65 to S$70 per square foot per plot ratio. The sites are part of the government's drive to offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: ADB should step up its role as a catalyst for regional integration
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) should step up its role as a catalyst for regional integration, according to a report by the ADB's Independent Evaluation Unit. The report highlights the need for increased cooperation between the ADB and China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), as well as with the Silk Road Fund. Regional economic cooperation is being hindered by competition between Japan and China, and rival territorial claims, potentially drawing other nations into the conflict. The ADB should revive its proactive role in promoting regional integration, as it has the potential to evolve into a major economic player in the region.

site_title: S'pore oil borrowers asking bondholders to cut them some slack
summary: S'pore oil borrowers, including Dyna-Mac Holdings and Pacific Radiance, are seeking to alter debt limits or profit targets due to contract delays and depressed oil markets. The companies are among 28 oil services firms in Singapore with over S$1.8 billion of notes maturing next year. Analysts warn that if oil markets remain depressed beyond 2016, firms may need to restructure their bonds, with some facing "cash flow issues" and high debt-to-equity ratios.

site_title: India among most open in world for investment: Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi emphasized India's openness to foreign investment, stating the country is now among the most open in the world. Over the past 18 months, his government has restored credibility and liberalized the FDI regime. Modi also highlighted opportunities in sectors such as manufacturing, renewable energy, and infrastructure development. He noted that India's youth population will drive economic transformation and urged businesses to invest in the country. Singapore is India's 10th largest trade partner and second-largest source of FDI, with bilateral trade expanding significantly since the CECA agreement in 2005.

images.alt_text: "We are working on all fronts to make India a global manufacturing hub. We are creating the global skill pool to establish a modern economy with a worldclass manufacturing sector," said Mr Modi.

site_title: Most life insurers are in position to pay out non-guaranteed bonuses
summary: Most Singaporean life insurers have sufficient reserve buffers to pay out non-guaranteed bonuses, according to regulatory filings. Prudential has the highest reserve ratio of 44.6%, while AXA Life has the lowest at 7.1-11.8%. Insurers with higher guarantees in Par products tend to have lower reserve ratios. Reserve buffers depend on the maturity of the Par fund portfolio, with more mature portfolios resulting in lower future non-guaranteed benefits. Five out of 10 insurers have maintained buffers at more than a third of their total Par assets.

images.alt_text: Most of the 10 major life insurers here now have less of an excuse not to pay out non-guaranteed benefits or bonuses on their products linked to participating funds - because they are all in a position to do so, the latest filings show.

site_title: South Korea online messaging services scoring wins in bond market
summary: South Korea's online messaging services, Naver and Kakao, are scoring victories in the bond market as investors shun the nation's struggling manufacturers. Naver issued 150 billion won of three-year notes at 2.126% interest, while Kakao plans to sell its first bond since a merger last year. The trend is attributed to the Internet industry's growth and the companies' solid financial structures. The move is seen as a positive sign for the "creative economy" push by President Park Geun-hye, aiming to bolster growth amidst forecasted weak exports.

site_title: About a third of Audi's buyers in China are women
summary: Audi has seen a significant shift in its Chinese buyer demographics, with women making up about a third of its buyers, particularly in the eastern regions. This trend is attributed to the increasing presence of young, successful women in China. To counter slowing luxury sales, Audi is focusing on appealing to a broader demographic, including women, who now account for 50% of entry-level premium brand buyers. This shift aims to capture a larger market share and offset declining sales.

site_title: ONGC closing up on Vashishta FID
summary: ONGC is nearing a final investment decision on the Vashishta and S-1 fields after receiving a winning bid from US-based McDermott. The bid of US$366 million, submitted within the revised project budget, outbid Subsea 7 and Technip. This marks a significant milestone for the development of the fields, which had been delayed. The successful bid is seen as a boost to ONGC's plans to expand its oil and gas production capabilities off eastern India.

site_title: Philippines has perfect investment climate
summary: The Philippines has been identified as a prime destination for investment, particularly by Singapore companies, due to its favorable business climate and growing economy. The country's young population, widespread English proficiency, and skilled labor force make it an attractive location for industries such as logistics and infrastructure development. The Philippines has been ranked 47th in the World Economic Forum's global competitiveness index, up from 85th in 2010, and its gross domestic product is expected to grow between 6 and 6.5% this year.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: STI's 4.2% dividend yield highest in Asia
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) offers the highest dividend yield in Asia at 4.2%, surpassing the region's average of 2.4%. The top 5 STI stocks with the highest dividend yields are Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, Keppel Corporation, Ascendas REIT, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and Sembcorp Marine. Analysts attribute the STI's attractiveness to its dividend support, which provides downside protection, particularly in a low-growth environment. This makes Singapore an appealing market for investors seeking stable returns.

site_title: Simsek to take charge of economy in new Turkish cabinet
summary: Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu named Mehmet Simsek, former finance minister, as deputy prime minister and economy minister in a new cabinet. The cabinet, which includes allies of President Tayyip Erdogan, aims to implement structural reforms and rewrite the country's constitution. Simsek and former finance minister Ali Babacan are seen as counterweights to Erdogan, who has been critical of high interest rates. The new cabinet takes office after the AK Party regained single-party rule in snap polls earlier this month.

site_title: Team Boustead emerges victorious in BT Corp Golf League
summary: Team Boustead emerged victorious in the 2015 Business Times Corporate Golf League, presented by Audi Singapore, held at Sentosa Golf Club's Serapong Course. Despite a rain delay, the event saw great golf scores, networking, and entertainment. The final round was followed by post-event activities, including cocktails, dinner, and prize-giving. This marks another win for Team Boustead in the league.

site_title: Turkey's Erdogan to chair security summit after Russian jet downed: sources
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan will chair a security summit on Tuesday to discuss developments after downing a Russian warplane that Ankara claimed had violated its airspace. The meeting will be attended by various Turkish officials, including Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu and the head of the armed forces. The summit aims to address the escalating tensions between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan will chair a security summit later on Tuesday, presidential sources said, to discuss developments after Turkey downed a Russian warplane that Ankara said had violated its airspace.

site_title: Singapore-based leasing firm BOC Aviation orders 22 B737s
summary: Singapore-based leasing firm BOC Aviation ordered 22 Boeing 737 planes worth US$2.27 billion, consisting of 11 next-generation 737-800 and 11 737 MAX 8 aircraft. The order, valued at catalogue prices, demonstrates the company's confidence in the 737 aircraft's high performance, reliability, and asset value. BOC Aviation is a key customer for Boeing, and this new order, combined with a previous 2014 order for 80 737s, showcases the company's leading position in the leasing market.

site_title: US third-quarter GDP growth revised up to 2.1%
summary: The US economy grew at a 2.1% annual pace in the third quarter, revised from 1.5%, indicating resilience that may boost the Federal Reserve's confidence to raise interest rates next month. The growth was driven by upward revisions to business spending on equipment and investment in home building, while consumer spending remained brisk despite a slight decrease. The revised estimate suggests the economy is on track for at least 2% growth in the second half of the year, setting the stage for potential interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The US economy grew at a healthier clip in the third quarter than initially thought, suggesting resilience that could help give the Federal Reserve confidence to raise interest rates next month.

site_title: US home prices rise faster in September, beat forecast
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.5% in September, surpassing the 5.1% estimate and marking a faster pace than in August. The S&P/Case Shiller composite index, covering 20 metropolitan areas, showed renewed strength in the economy. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise its fed funds target range to 25-50 basis points, potentially leading to higher mortgage rates, but not enough to slow home price gains.

site_title: Suntec office deals see revival after drought in 2014
summary: Suntec City's office transactions have seen a revival this year, with six deals totaling S$169.12 million, after a drought in 2014. The average per square foot price has risen from S$1,745 psf in 2009 to S$2,641 psf in 2013 and S$2,774 psf this year. The revival is attributed to a narrowing buyer-seller price gap, with buyers seeking office space for their own use or as a long-term investment, and sellers open to divesting their office space due to non-core business needs.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Malaysia remains fragile despite China power deal
summary: Malaysia's troubled sovereign fund 1MDB has secured a RM9.83 billion deal with China General Nuclear Power to buy its energy assets, providing a significant lifeline to the struggling fund. This deal, including debt, could be worth up to RM18 billion, helping to reduce 1MDB's RM38 billion net borrowings. However, Malaysia's economic fragility persists due to a 23% decline in the ringgit against the dollar, a widening corruption scandal, and dependence on declining crude oil prices, putting pressure on Prime Minister Najib Razak's leadership.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is getting another sovereign lifeline. State-owned China General Nuclear Power will buy the energy assets of troubled sovereign fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) for RM9.83 billion (S$3.3 billion).

site_title: German prosecutors launch tax evasion probe at VW: media
summary: German prosecutors have launched an investigation into suspected tax evasion at Volkswagen, focusing on five employees linked to rigging CO2 emissions data, which resulted in millions of euros in evaded tax payments. This probe comes amid Volkswagen's admission of false emissions data on 800,000 cars, potentially costing 2 billion euros in compensation and other costs.

site_title: Opec seen defending strategy of letting oil price sink
summary: Opec is expected to maintain its strategy of letting oil prices sink, despite a 44% decline in crude prices, which has cut member revenues by almost half a trillion dollars. Analysts predict it will take more than $40 crude to change the group's mind. Saudi Arabia, the largest Opec member, is determined to see through its plan to eliminate a supply glut, despite dissent from Venezuela, Algeria, and Iran. Opec may agree to raise its output target to 31 million barrels a day, but this is seen as a formality.

site_title: Greater London set to outperform prime in 2016
summary: Knight Frank predicts Greater London will outperform prime central London in 2016, with home prices expected to rise 5% next year, compared to 2% in central London. This growth is driven by the expansion of the London Tube network, including the Crossrail project, and increased demand from short-term corporate tenants. Volumes of home sales have plummeted 20% this year, but are expected to rise 5% in 2016. Liam Bailey, Knight Frank's global head of research, attributes the growth to a safe haven effect, with Europeans seeking affordable London real estate during the eurozone crisis.

images.alt_text: Knight Frank's Liam Bailey says "the growth in demand for workers' accommodation is exponential".

site_title: Noble tumbles as S&P puts rating on review
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a commodity trader, has seen its shares tumble 3.7% after Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service review its ratings amid concerns over liquidity. S&P has placed Noble's BBB- rating on review with negative implications, and Moody's may cut its rating to junk if the company's liquidity position doesn't improve. Noble aims to raise at least $500 million through asset sales or strategic investors to bolster its balance sheet and enhance liquidity. The company's bonds have also fallen in value, with prices down 4.7 cents to 76.1 cents on the dollar.

site_title: India mulls tax breaks to spur investment in housing
summary: India's government is considering tax breaks to encourage investment in the housing sector, amid efforts to revive economic activity. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has asked the National Housing Bank to design a programme to attract investments. This move comes after a government panel recommended a 24% salary increase for federal employees, which would cost the government $15 billion. Home sales in India's top markets fell 4% in the past quarter, while unsold inventory rose 18%. The Reserve Bank of India has also eased mortgage rules, lowering the cost of funds.

site_title: Global markets take a dive as Turkey downs Russian plane
summary: Turkey shot down a Russian plane near the Syrian border, triggering a global market downturn. Stocks fell in Moscow, London, and Europe, with Turkey's lira weakening 0.4%. The incident threatens to escalate tensions between Turkey and Russia, which have been working together against Islamic State. The US stock market also opened sharply lower, with the Dow down 85.62 points. Investors are seeking safe havens, driving up gold and government bonds, but the situation remains uncertain.

site_title: Japan to raise minimum wage by 3% to boost consumption
summary: Japan is set to raise its minimum wage by 3% annually starting next fiscal year as part of a package to boost consumption and stimulate economic growth. The government aims to increase the minimum wage to 1,000 yen per hour and ease regulations to encourage corporate investment and female workforce participation. The move is seen as crucial to addressing Japan's 15-year period of deflation and supporting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic agenda.

site_title: Seadrill turns to loss on US$1.8b writedown in oil rout
summary: Seadrill, a US$1.8 billion-worth offshore driller, reported its first quarterly loss since 2011 due to a collapse in oil prices reducing demand for its rigs. The company booked a non-cash impairment charge of US$1.8 billion, resulting in a net loss of US$1.83 billion. Despite this, Seadrill's underlying business is deemed "very sound and healthy," and the company is taking steps to postpone delivery of new units and renegotiate contracts to weather the downturn.

site_title: China proposes joint financing firm with Central, East Europe
summary: China proposes setting up a multilateral financing institution to support project lending in Central and Eastern Europe, a key part of its "Belt and Road" strategy. The proposal, made by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, aims to strengthen China's influence in the region and reduce financing costs for big projects. The institution would be a 16+1 company, with China as the lead, and would finance trade and investment in the region. This move comes as China seeks to diversify its economy and increase its presence in the region, which is also a gateway to the European Union.

site_title: Overseas Indians wield growing political might
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 2019 re-election campaign relied heavily on a network of overseas Indians, with the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) utilizing the Overseas Friends of BJP (OFBJP) arm to bolster its machine. The party's efforts to co-opt the diaspora, including staging enthusiastic rallies and building a database of overseas Indians, were orchestrated by the OFBJP and Hindu nationalist groups like the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS). The strategy aims to replicate the party's 2014 landslide win and has raised concerns among opposition parties.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's CKI loses bid to buy out Hong Kong utility Power Assets
summary: Li Ka-shing's CKI loses bid to buy out Hong Kong utility Power Assets, a deal worth US$12.4 billion, after nearly 49% of Power Asset shareholders rejected the proposal. CKI, which already owns 39% of Power Assets, had increased its bid in early October but ultimately failed to secure the necessary votes. The rejection marks a defeat for Li as he seeks to diversify his investments away from slowing growth in China and Hong Kong.

site_title: Japan Post to set up private equity investment arm
summary: Japan Post Bank Co, the newly privatized bank managing 205 trillion yen in Japanese government bonds, plans to establish a private equity investment arm. The new department, led by Tokihiko Shimizu, will be set up on Dec 1. Shimizu previously led the Government Pension Investment Fund's drive to diversify its allocation into alternative assets, including private equity and property. This move aims to explore investment opportunities in private equity and potentially generate new revenue streams for the bank.

site_title: Russian fighter jet downed in Syria by Turkish military
summary: A Russian Su-24 fighter jet was downed in Syria by Turkish military forces, with the Turkish military claiming the plane violated airspace and was shot down 10 times in five minutes. However, Russia's defense ministry disputed this, stating the jet had not entered Turkish airspace and its pilots had ejected safely. The incident occurred as two Turkish F-16 jets were on patrol duty along the border.

site_title: Update: Hot stock: Noble Group tumbles as S&P's move seen step toward junk
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, fell 3.7% in Singapore after Standard & Poor's (S&P) began reviewing its investment-grade status, citing concerns about its liquidity. S&P's review comes amid slumping raw-material prices and Noble's accounting criticism. The company aims to raise $500 million through asset sales or partnerships to bolster its balance sheet and maintain its investment-grade rating. Moody's has also reviewed Noble's rating, with a possible downgrade to junk if its liquidity doesn't improve in the next one to two quarters.

site_title: China proposes firm to fund projects in Europe
summary: China proposes a financial firm to fund projects in central and eastern Europe, offering cheap Chinese funds to support cooperation. Premier Li Keqiang said the firm would be led by Industrial and Commercial Bank of China and China Export Import Bank. The move aims to boost lending in the region and strengthen exchanges with other multilateral organizations, such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. China's goal is to extend its global reach and flex its economic muscles, following the success of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: Rowsley invests in redevelopment of UK boutique hotel through JV
summary: Rowsley has invested £3.2 million (S$6.8 million) in a joint venture to redevelop the Northern Stock Exchange building in Manchester, UK into a boutique hotel. The joint venture, Finestday Limited, is also owned by Gary Neville, Ryan Giggs, Sherborne Corporate Services Limited, and Kenilworth Consultants Inc. The project will include restaurants, a rooftop bar, and other amenities, marking the redevelopment of the building.

site_title: Anti-graft investigators probe two brokerages in Shanghai
summary: Anti-corruption investigators in Shanghai have opened probes into two state-owned brokerages, Guotai Junan Securities and Haitong Securities, amid a campaign against graft in the financial sector. This is the third probe in Shanghai this year and involves sweeping investigations of 12 other companies and six universities. The move follows a market slump and allegations of insider trading and 'malicious' short-selling. Meanwhile, four executives at the state-owned People's Insurance Company of China were punished for various misdemeanors, including using trade union money for personal expenses.

site_title: Time zone differences no barrier to London-Shanghai link: LSE CEO
summary: London Stock Exchange CEO Nikhil Rathi says a time difference between London and Shanghai should not be a barrier to linking the city's stock markets. Despite critics citing a 7-hour time difference, Rathi notes that London is a complementary time zone to Asian markets, a strength of the London market. The proposed link is part of a feasibility study launched by the British and Chinese governments, with details yet to be disclosed. Rathi emphasizes that while challenges exist, the potential benefits of the link outweigh them.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower on heightened security risks
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.27% due to heightened security risks following Turkey's downing of a Russian warplane. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.5 points to 17,744.18, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.36% and 0.63% respectively. Despite stronger US economic growth data, investors fled risky assets, leading to the decline in stock prices.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as investors fled risky assets after Turkey shot down a Russian warplane, even as data pointed to stronger US economic growth.

site_title: New Myanmar government to tighten safety after jade mine disaster
summary: Myanmar's newly elected government plans to tighten safety controls at jade mines following a landslide that killed around 200 people. The National League for Democracy (NLD) aims to review existing regulations and require companies to have safe dump sites when applying for licenses. However, the jade business is dominated by powerful vested interests, which could lead to conflict if the government moves too forcefully to rein in their business. The government's move may impact companies linked to the previous military government and ethnic armies.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Tuesday, extending losses from the previous day. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.4% to 6,280.07 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 slid 0.3% and Paris' CAC 40 fell 0.5%. Investors sought shelter from tumbling commodity prices and a strong dollar, which also affected US markets.

site_title: India among the most open economies for foreign investment: Modi
summary: India Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated the country is now among the most open economies for foreign direct investment, following liberalization efforts since his government took office. The government has increased FDI limits in key sectors and finetuned procedures to address operational issues. Singapore, a key investor in India, has seen its trade and investments with the country grow significantly over the past decade. India and Singapore have committed to five initiatives to strengthen economic ties, including scaling up trade and investment, and developing smart cities.

site_title: Rolls-Royce launches major restructuring programme
summary: Rolls-Royce launches major restructuring programme amid four profit warnings in a year, with new CEO Warren East aiming to turn around the company. The programme will simplify the organisation, streamline senior management, and reduce fixed costs to add pace and accountability to decision making. Activist shareholder ValueAct, which now holds a 10% stake, has pushed for the restructuring. The move follows pressure from the activist investor and will be presented to investors later on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: After four profit warnings in just over a year, the aero-engine maker was already under pressure to outline how it would return to growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 6.13 points to 1,677.03, driven by 2.67 billion lots valued at RM2.39 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 573 to 373.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore oil borrowers are seeking more slack to avoid bond defaults due to contract delays affecting earnings. Meanwhile, Singapore and India have signed a strategic partnership agreement. In other news, Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target for the global equity index. The Thai government is confident that a court will clear its prime minister's daughter in an ethics case, and ASEAN has downplayed the importance of Myanmar's upcoming election.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall as weaker metal prices hit resource shares
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng index closing at 22,587.63 points. Weaker metal prices led the decline, particularly in resources shares, which fell nearly 1%. This was the second consecutive day of losses for the Hang Seng, following a 0.6% drop on Monday. The decline was attributed to lower metal prices, which have touched multi-year lows.

site_title: China: Stocks recoup losses as small-caps offset drop in resource shares
summary: China's stocks recouped losses on Tuesday as small-cap stocks offset weakness in resource companies. The CSI300 index ended marginally higher, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.2%. Commodity-related stocks fell due to low metal prices, and bearish sentiment spread to other sectors, leaving the market vulnerable to a correction. Chinese banks are also facing concerns about loan recognition, with some failing to acknowledge bad debts to avoid capital shortfalls.

site_title: Thai central bank says may cut growth estimates as risks rise
summary: Thailand's central bank may lower its economic growth projections due to rising risks from China and Asia. Deputy Governor Paiboon Kittisrikangwan cited a regional economic slowdown and drought impact on farm products as reasons for the potential revisions. The bank previously forecast 2.7% growth this year and 3.7% for 2016, but no official new projections are expected until December 25. This move comes after the economy grew just 0.9% last year due to weak exports and prolonged political unrest.

site_title: EVA Airways and Boeing sign Taiwan's biggest ever plane deal
summary: EVA Airways signed a $6 billion deal with Boeing for 26 new jetliners, including 18 787-10 Dreamliners and 2 777-300ER aircraft. The order, valued at $2.3 billion per plane, is Taiwan's largest single commercial plane purchase in history. The expanded fleet will help EVA compete with regional rivals and add routes in new markets, including North America. The deal, announced Tuesday, marks a significant investment in the airline's future growth and innovation.

site_title: Findings from special audit of Cedar Strategic's accounts published
summary: A special audit of Cedar Strategic's accounts has revealed weaknesses in corporate governance, internal controls, and possible non-compliance with Catalist Board rules. The audit highlighted issues with divestments, acquisitions, and severance payments. Cedar Strategic Holdings has acknowledged the findings and appointed professionals to address the issues, including implementing an enterprise risk management system. The company is also considering taking legal actions or reporting incidents to relevant authorities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Frontline says to start paying quarterly dividends
summary: Frontline, a crude oil tanker firm, reported a smaller-than-expected third-quarter operating profit of $19.3 million, up from a loss of $37.5 million the previous year. The company plans to start making quarterly dividend payments, with amounts equal to or close to its earnings per share, adjusted for non-recurring items. This follows a planned merger with Frontline in 2012.

site_title: SIAS registers concerns of Tiger Airways' minority shareholders with Singapore Airlines (Amended)
summary: The Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) has expressed concerns to Singapore Airlines over its offer price for Tiger Airways' minority shares. The offer price of 41 Singapore cents per share is 32% higher than the last traded price, but SIAS claims it's 39% lower than what long-term minority shareholders paid. SIAS urges the board of Tiger Airways to review the offer and ensure fairness for minority shareholders, advising them to wait for an independent financial advisor's report to determine the offer's fairness.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore and India strengthen cooperation on cyber security
summary: Singapore and India have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to strengthen cyber security cooperation, focusing on five key areas: professional dialogue, operational readiness, technology research, best practices, and human resource development. This is the third bilateral MOU signed by Singapore's Cyber Security Agency, following agreements with France and the UK in 2015. The MOU aims to enhance cyber security capabilities and prevent new threats, with a two-year initial period.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, led by banks and Genting
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rebounded 20 points to 2,923.49, driven by short-covering in banks and Genting Singapore ahead of a potential Wall Street rebound. Turnover remained low, with 65% of dollar value provided by the 30 STI members. Raffles Medical and Genting Singapore also saw significant gains, with Raffles Medical rising 0.01 cents to S$4.20 and Genting Singapore surging 6% to S$0.795. Analysts upgraded Raffles Medical to a "buy" due to its undervalued valuation.

site_title: Priced for crisis, Malaysian banks still too expensive for top fund
summary: Malaysian banking stocks, down 40% since 2015, remain pricey, with valuations at a 10-year low. Despite this, some funds are considering them again. Former DBS veteran Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, and Chinese banks are struggling with consumer lending.

site_title: Double or nothing is way into lucrative Indonesian banking
summary: Foreign banks can now gain management control in Indonesia by merging two local lenders, exceeding the 40% foreign ownership threshold imposed by regulators. China Construction Bank and Korea's Shinhan Bank have received approval for such deals, paving the way for consolidation in the country's banking sector. Indonesia aims to weed out weaker banks, with the top 10 banks accounting for over 60% of total assets. The move is seen as a long-term strategy, but analysts warn of operational challenges and Basel rules requiring more liquidity buffers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend winning streak to 4th session; won up
summary: South Korean stocks extended their winning streak to a fourth session, closing 0.6% higher at 2,016.29 points, despite foreign selling and weak commodity prices. Household credit growth of 3.0% in the third quarter could fuel economic growth but also raise concerns about high debt burdens. The South Korean won rose 0.4% against the dollar.

site_title: China on track to hit 7% GDP growth target this year: Premier Li
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that China is on track to reach its 7% GDP growth target for the year, amid adjustments to maintain long-term growth. During a summit with Central and Eastern European leaders, Li mentioned the possibility of establishing a multilateral financial institution and a yuan-denominated joint fund.

site_title: Is Jon Snow alive? 'Game of Thrones' teaser revives debate
summary: A "Game of Thrones" teaser suggests Jon Snow may be alive in season six, sparking debate among fans. The poster shows Snow with blood on his face, sparking speculation of his return. The teaser was released after reports of Kit Harington's appearance on the set of season six, fueling fan speculation. The show's director, David Nutter, previously confirmed Snow's death, but the teaser has reignited hopes among fans, including President Barack Obama.

site_title: Apple plans to launch Apple Pay in China
summary: Apple plans to launch Apple Pay in China by early February, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal. The iPhone maker has struck deals with China's big four state-run banks, but regulatory hurdles may still be a challenge. Apple has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei posts 5 straight days of gains; market awaits fresh trading cues
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.2% to 19,924.89, marking a fifth consecutive day of gains. Investors await fresh trading cues amid subdued US markets ahead of Thanksgiving. The Nikkei share average ended the day higher, despite choppy trade.

site_title: Swee Hong proposes issue of new shares to Singapore Infrastructure (Asia Pacific)
summary: SWEE Hong has entered into a conditional subscription agreement with Singapore Infrastructure (Asia Pacific) to issue 535 million new shares at a price of S$0.015 each, representing an 88.4% discount from its previous trading price. The proposed issue will result in Singapore Infrastructure holding approximately 29% of the enlarged share capital, with net proceeds of about S$7.7 million to be used for working capital requirements.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China regulator cancels net purchase requirement for brokers: sources
summary: China's securities regulator has canceled a requirement that brokerages must have a net positive purchase position on daily proprietary trading, a move aimed at stabilizing the country's stock markets. The policy was introduced in July at the height of the equity crash, with 21 brokerages pledging to invest 120 billion yuan in shares. The regulator has also requested further risk management measures, citing a slowing stabilization of the equity market. The decision is seen as a response to the market's recent recovery.

site_title: German growth buoyed by domestic demand, spending on refugees
summary: Germany's economy grew at a modest 0.3% pace in the third quarter, driven by record-high employment, rising wages, and higher state spending on refugees. Private consumption rose 0.6% and domestic demand added 0.7 percentage points to GDP. Weaker exports and imports, largely due to demand from China and emerging markets, subtracted 0.4 percentage points from GDP. Despite concerns about a slowdown, morale among analysts and investors improved in November, and a survey among purchasing managers pointed to accelerating growth in the private sector.

images.alt_text: A rise in German private consumption and higher state spending on refugees more than compensated for weakness in foreign trade, helping Europe's biggest economy to grow at a modest, albeit slower pace in the third quarter, data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.04% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.04% to 2,904.54 on Tuesday, with 77.4 million shares changing hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other markets, MSCI's Asia-Pacific index was almost flat, while Japan's Nikkei dipped 0.1%. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Spring Air plans to be first budget carrier to fly to Pyongyang
summary: Spring Airlines plans to become the first low-cost carrier to fly to Pyongyang, North Korea, with flights from Shanghai four times a week. The airline aims to start flights in February, with the goal of becoming the first Chinese carrier to operate this route. Currently, Air China offers flights from Beijing. This move could help Spring Airlines become the largest budget airline in Asia by market value.

site_title: No global support for US-led troops in Syria: Australia PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull stated there is no global support for a US-led ground force to combat the Islamic State group in Syria. Despite mounting calls for boots on the ground, Turnbull said leaders at the G20, Apec, and East Asia Summit expressed no support for a large Western army to conquer and hold IS-controlled areas. Australia currently has air strikes in Syria and no plans for significant changes in military commitment in Iraq and Syria.

site_title: Miner stocks fall in Asia as commodity prices sink
summary: Australian mining companies led losses in Asian mining and energy firms, with BHP Billiton reaching a 10-year low, as metals prices slipped on slack demand and a strong dollar. Copper prices sank to a six-year low, nickel hit its lowest in over a decade, and zinc and silver declined. Oil prices rose but remained subdued due to a supply glut and overproduction, with traders warning of further pressure on resource stocks.

site_title: Sharp surges third day after reports banks may forgive loans
summary: Sharp's stock surged 14% on its third consecutive day in Tokyo after reports that its main lenders, Mizuho Financial Group and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, may forgive loans to secure an investment from a government-backed investment fund. The shares have gained 25% over the past three days, the largest since May 2013. Sharp has endured over 1.2 trillion yen in losses in the past four years, and its dependence on main lenders remains a concern despite the potential investment.

site_title: UOB first to launch contactless payment with banking mobile app
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) launched its mobile application, allowing Android smartphone users to make contactless payments up to their credit or debit card limit, surpassing the current S$100 limit in Singapore. The app, UOB Mighty, also features a dining directory and genuine reviews. With the new service, customers will need to enter a PIN for transactions, ensuring security through tokenisation. The app has seen 55,000 unique downloads since its soft launch.

site_title: Australia: Shares turn lower, dragged by falling commodity prices
summary: Australian shares fell 0.62% on Tuesday, ending a five-session winning streak, due to lower commodity prices. Copper fell 3% to its cheapest in over six years, dragging down the metals sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,245.7, with Fortescue Mining, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto among the biggest losers. The decline was also influenced by a weakening US dollar and concerns over China's economy.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group tumbles as S&P's move seen as step toward junk
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, fell 3.7% after Standard & Poor's (S&P) placed its BBB- rating on review with negative implications, citing concerns about liquidity. S&P joins Moody's Investors Service in reviewing the company's ratings amid slumping raw-material prices and accounting criticism. Noble Group aims to raise $500 million through asset sales or partnerships to bolster its balance sheet and maintain its investment-grade status. A downgrade to junk could affect its credit line and access to capital.

site_title: Australia: Shares break 5-day winning streak to end down 1%
summary: Australian shares fell 0.95% on Tuesday, snapping a 5-day winning streak, as commodities prices dropped and investors took profits. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,226.4, down 50.02 points. This followed a 0.4% gain on Monday.

site_title: Fed rate odds rise to 74% in bond market as Pimco sees liftoff
summary: The odds of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December have risen to 74% in the bond market, with Pacific Investment Management predicting a move is likely. This increase comes after a two-year auction drew the highest yield in five years, reflecting traders' expectations of rising interest rates. The US 10-year note yield remained unchanged at 2.25%. The Fed's decision to raise rates would be the first since 2006, and is expected to average an effective fed funds rate of 0.375% after liftoff.

site_title: Brussels extends terror alert as US issues travel warning
summary: Belgium has extended its terror alert to the highest level for another week amid fears of an imminent attack, while the US has issued a worldwide travel warning for its citizens. The move comes as the international community steps up its fight against the Islamic State group, with France launching strikes against the group from a newly deployed aircraft carrier. Four people have been charged in connection with the Paris attacks that killed 130 people, and an international manhunt continues for key suspect Salah Abdeslam.

site_title: SGX reviewing corporate governance compliance: official
summary: SGX is reviewing corporate governance compliance among listed companies to boost its regulatory credentials. The review aims to identify areas for improvement, including the use of boilerplate explanations. Unexplained deviations from the code may lead to action against companies. SGX's Chief Regulatory Officer Tan Boon Gin emphasized the need for greater shareholder activism from institutional investors to improve compliance. The review's results will be published, and companies that fail to meet requirements may face consequences.

site_title: Pfizer's tax-avoiding megamerger with Allergan sparks outcry
summary: Pfizer's $160 billion megamerger with Allergan has sparked criticism from US lawmakers, who object to the deal's use of an "inversion" tax loophole that allows companies to avoid billions of dollars in corporate taxes by renouncing US citizenship. The deal, which would create the world's largest drugmaker, would turn Pfizer into an Irish company. Lawmakers have previously criticized such deals but have yet to take legislative action.

site_title: Singapore oil borrowers seek more slack to avoid bond defaults
summary: Singapore oil borrowers, including Dyna-Mac Holdings Ltd and Pacific Radiance Ltd, are seeking to alter debt limits or profit targets due to contract delays and depressed oil prices. The companies, which have over $1.8 billion of notes maturing next year, are facing "cash flow issues" and are likely to restructure their bonds if oil markets remain depressed beyond 2016. Analysts predict that some oil and gas players will have to restructure their bonds, and investors have seen significant losses in the past six months.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks slip in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, tracking losses in New York, and Shanghai extended losses due to concerns about liquidity ahead of initial public offerings. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.32%, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index eased 0.21%. These losses follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and come as US-EU trade talks and S&P 500 records continue to influence global markets.

site_title: Singapore, India sign strategic partnership agreement
summary: India and Singapore have signed a strategic partnership agreement, elevating bilateral relations to a higher level. The agreement, signed by Prime Ministers Narendra Modi and Lee Hsien Loong, aims to sustain momentum and enhance defence cooperation, business, and commercial linkages between the two countries. A revised Defence Cooperation Agreement was also signed, reaffirming the importance of defence relations between India and Singapore. The partnership is based on mutual trust, respect, and a shared history, with the two countries celebrating the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat after weak Wall St session
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday after a weak Wall Street session, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.02% and the Topix index down 0.11%. The markets reopened following a long national holiday weekend.

site_title: US issues global travel alert due to 'increased terrorist threats'
summary: The US State Department issued a global travel alert due to "increased terrorist threats" following the Paris attacks. The alert warns American citizens to exercise vigilance in public places and crowded areas, particularly during the holiday season. It cites threats from groups such as ISIL, Al-Qaeda, and Boko Haram, and advises citizens to avoid large crowds and be cautious in multiple regions.

site_title: Japan's Amari: Minimum wage hike important to economic growth
summary: Japanese Economics Minister Akira Amari emphasized the importance of raising the minimum wage to contribute to the country's economic growth. The government plans to increase the minimum wage and encourage companies to boost salaries as part of an economic growth package. However, Amari noted that the increase may burden some small companies. The move aims to stimulate the economy and improve living standards for workers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks set to hit four-day winning streak; won up
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, poised for a four-day winning streak, driven by a technical bounce ahead of US GDP data. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 2,011.65, while the won strengthened 0.3% against the dollar. Construction and insurance stocks led gains, while foreign investors sold Kospi shares worth 36.4 billion won. Analysts expect a US interest rate hike next month, which could strengthen the dollar.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia ahead of Opec meeting, US report
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia ahead of the Opec meeting on December 10, with West Texas Intermediate up 16 cents at US$41.91 and Brent crude up 17 cents at US$45.00. However, analysts say the Saudi oil minister's comments on production cuts were not convincing, and the market is waiting for firm announcements from Opec. Slower growth in emerging markets is also contributing to lower oil prices. Analysts expect US commercial crude stockpiles to show another build, which could further weigh on prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed in Asia Tuesday ahead of a key meeting of the Opec oil cartel and a report on US commercial crude inventories to gauge demand in the world's biggest oil consuming nation.

site_title: US dollar heads higher in holiday-shortened week
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro and Japanese yen on Monday, ahead of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike next month. Around 90% of economists expect the Fed to announce a rate hike on December 16, which has already been priced into the market. The dollar's rise is seen as a sign of improving economic reports that could support the rate hike.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 7.70 points to 1,678.60. Trading volume was 111.13 million lots, valued at RM33.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 144 to 76, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: JTC launches 2 sites under industrial government land sales programme
summary: JTC has launched two industrial government land sales (IGLS) sites in Singapore. The confirmed list site at Tampines Industrial Drive occupies 0.41 hectares and is zoned for Business 2 development, while the reserve list site at Woodlands Height occupies 1.61 hectares and is zoned for Business 1 development. The sites have 20-year and 30-year tenures, respectively, with maximum gross plot ratios of 1.4 and 2.5. The tenders for the sites will close on January 19.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Indonesia must join TPP trade deal or risk being 'left behind': trade minister
summary: Indonesia's Trade Minister Tom Lembong warned that joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal is crucial to avoid being left behind by neighboring countries, particularly Vietnam. Lembong stated that Vietnam has already joined the TPP and formed a trade deal with Europe, leading to the closure of Indonesian factories. The deal offers 10-14% trade tariff discounts to its members. Indonesia must consider joining the TPP to maintain its economic competitiveness.

site_title: HSBC sees third globalisation wave quadrupling trade by 2050
summary: HSBC predicts a third wave of globalisation, set to quadruple international trade to $68.5 trillion by 2050. This growth is driven by the emergence of 3 billion new middle-class consumers in emerging markets, technological advancements, and reduced trade barriers. The report identifies 1865-1913 and 1950-2007 as the first and second waves of globalisation, respectively. Commerce is expected to grow 5% annually over the next decade, reversing the slowdown since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: KLW shares fall 14% in early trading
summary: KLW Holdings' shares plummeted 14.29% in early trading on November 24, 2015, after announcing it was under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department for possible Securities and Futures Act offenses. The stock was the fifth top loser among top 20 traded stocks.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Noble Group may be cut to junk by S&P on liquidity concerns
summary: Noble Group Ltd may see its credit rating cut to junk by Standard & Poor's due to concerns over its liquidity. The ratings company has placed its BBB-rating on Noble on review with "negative implications" after the company's adjusted inventory and committed credit facilities declined. This follows Moody's Investors Service's warning that Noble's rating may be cut to junk if its liquidity position doesn't improve in the next one to two quarters. Noble shares have fallen 64% this year amid criticism and investor concerns over slumping raw-material prices.

site_title: Flight bookings to Paris down over a quarter after attacks
summary: Flight bookings to Paris have dropped by over a quarter in the week following terrorist attacks that killed 130 people, with a 27% decline in bookings compared to the same period in 2014. Leisure travelers, rather than business visitors, are primarily affected. ForwardKeys reported 13% decline in Christmas bookings and 21% higher cancellations in the week after the attacks, which have stabilized at last year's levels. France, normally the most-visited country, saw a significant drop in bookings, with Air France and low-cost carrier easyJet also experiencing reduced traffic.

site_title: HSBC said to plan cutting 2,000 jobs in commercial bank division
summary: HSBC is eliminating 2,000 jobs in its commercial bank division as part of a two-year cost-cutting plan, aiming to reduce its workforce by 50,000 and lower annual costs by up to $5 billion. The cuts follow a three-year plan announced in June, which also includes shedding businesses. The reductions began last week and are expected to be completed by 2027.

site_title: Oil prices little changed after Saudi remarks
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Monday as traders reacted to Saudi Arabia's remarks on a potential production cutback to stabilize global supplies. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 15 cents to $41.75 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose 17 cents to $44.83 a barrel. Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi's comments ahead of the Opec meeting on December 4 sparked skepticism, but some analysts see the move as a positive sign. The Opec meeting may lead to a production cut, but its outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: Volkswagen says it has fixes for 90% of emissions scandal cars in Europe
summary: Volkswagen has found technical solutions for over 90% of its diesel vehicles affected in the emissions scandal in Europe, with fixes ranging from simple software updates to more complex solutions. The company faces the task of recalling 8.5 million vehicles throughout Europe and has promised to submit its recall plans to German authorities by the end of November. Volkswagen's CEO, Matthias Mueller, stated that the company's main concern is restoring credibility and confidence in its brands, following a 5.3% decline in car sales in October.

site_title: Yellen cautions against overly aggressive Fed tightening
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen warned against overly aggressive interest rate hikes, cautioning they could harm the economy. In a letter, she argued that the Fed's seven-year era of zero rates had protected American savers from economic downturns. Yellen expects gradual policy tightening after the Fed's first rate hike in almost 10 years, scheduled for December 15-16. She noted that overly aggressive rate hikes could undercut the economy and reverse the Fed's current policy, drawing parallels with Japan's stagnant rates.

site_title: Allianz to pull funds out of coal businesses
summary: German insurer Allianz plans to withdraw investments from companies with significant coal ties and boost funding in wind energy over the next six months. The company will no longer invest in mining companies generating more than 30% of their sales from coal. Allianz aims to double its wind energy investments to 4 billion euros, following the shift. The move is in line with the company's new CEO Oliver Baete's pledge to boost growth and profit.

site_title: Europe: London stocks slip on sliding commodities
summary: European stocks declined on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.5% due to sliding commodities and a strengthening US dollar. The decline was partly offset by a four-and-a-half year high in eurozone business activity, which boosted confidence in the region. The euro fell to a seven-month low, while the dollar rose. The European Central Bank is expected to deliver more stimulus in December, despite the improved economic data.

site_title: Keppel prices S$200m notes issue
summary: Keppel Corporation priced an S$200 million note issue due 2023 with a fixed interest rate of 3.725% per annum. The notes are expected to be issued on or about November 30, 2015, and will be listed on the SGX. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing loans and general corporate and working capital requirements.

site_title: France strikes IS in Syria from newly deployed carrier: ministry
summary: France launched airstrikes on Islamic State targets in Syria on Monday from its newly deployed aircraft carrier in the eastern Mediterranean. Two Mirage 2000 jets targeted a site in Raqa, the jihadist group's de facto Syrian capital. This was the first attack on Syria since the carrier's deployment in the region. The strikes come after similar operations in Iraq.

site_title: Stock to watch: KLW Holdings
summary: KLW Holdings has requested to lift its trading halt after being under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) for possible offences under the Securities and Futures Act. The CAD has interviewed key company officials, including the current head of operations and former managing director. The company claims its business and operations are unaffected by the investigation and will continue as normal. No further details have been disclosed by the CAD.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Eurozone approves bailout payment to Greece
summary: Eurozone finance ministers approved a 2 billion euro payment to Greece, confirming the country's commitment to reforms. This payment, part of the 86-billion-euro bailout, follows a six-month battle and paves the way for unlocking 10 billion euros for recapitalizing Greece's top banks. Greece's leftist government has implemented extensive reforms, and the eurozone ministers welcomed the adoption of new measures, which are a condition for unlocking the remaining funds. The payment brings Greece closer to completing its first review of the bailout, which is set to last three years.

site_title: Economist Andy Xie predicts iron to fall below US$40
summary: Economist Andy Xie predicts iron ore will fall below US$40 a tonne by year-end and trade in the US$30s in 2016 due to China's sputtering demand. Mills in China will cut output, and high-cost miners will shut down. Xie, an independent economist, has predicted a collapse since 2012. His prediction is based on China's slowing demand for iron ore.

site_title: Paris attacks: 'Explosives belt' found in Paris suburb
summary: A suspected suicide belt with a similar configuration to those used in the Paris attacks was found in a Paris suburb, Montrouge, 10 days after the November 13 attacks that killed 130 people. The belt, which lacks a detonator, is being analyzed to confirm whether it is explosive. The discovery places Belgian-born suspect Salah Abdeslam, a key suspect in the attacks, in the same area on the night of the attacks. Abdeslam is believed to still be on the run, and his lawyer suggests he may have been ready to detonate, but his brother claims he decided not to go through with the attack at the last minute.

images.alt_text: A suspected suicide belt with a similar "configuration" to those used in the Paris attacks was found Monday just south of the French capital, sources close to the investigation said.

site_title: CAD starts probe into KLW consultant and senior executive
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has launched an investigation into KLW Holdings, questioning two senior executives, including former managing director Lee Boon Teck and head of operations and human resources Gaw Kuan Ching Jaslin, over alleged offences related to disclosure rules and internal controls. The probe follows a PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) report highlighting concerns over term sheets and payments to Lee. KLW has cooperated with the investigation and denied any impact on its business operations.

site_title: Spain retailers cheer signs of Christmas recovery
summary: Spanish retailers are optimistic about this year's Christmas season, anticipating their best Christmas in years. Tax cuts, low inflation, and falling energy prices have boosted family budgets, while businesses expect a spending spree to help extend an economic recovery and boost a struggling jobs market. Retailers are taking on extra staff, with El Corte Ingles hiring 7,000 workers and Amazon adding 600 jobs. Despite economic challenges, retailers remain hopeful for a positive outcome in the upcoming national election and a turning point for Spain's economy.

site_title: German luxury store brings back Israeli wine after uproar
summary: German luxury department store KaDeWe has decided to resume selling Israeli wines that it had pulled from its shelves due to new European Union labelling guidelines for products from Jewish settlements. The decision follows criticism from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the German company of a "boycott". KaDeWe's move aims to comply with EU regulations and avoid further controversy.

site_title: Risks for S-Reits to rise in 2016, more acquisitions likely: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts a rise in risks for Singapore's real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) in 2016, mainly due to weak economic fundamentals and new supply in the hospitality and industrial sectors. However, the healthcare sector is expected to perform strongly, with Fitch estimating a 3.5% net property income yield in 2016. To mitigate weak earnings, S-Reits may turn to acquisitions, with Fitch noting that Singapore Reits have completed over S$4.5 billion acquisitions in 2015.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US: Stocks dip; Pfizer, Allergan unveil merger
summary: US stocks fell modestly, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 31.13 points, as Pfizer and Allergan unveiled a record-setting $160 billion merger. Allergan declined 3.4%, while Pfizer fell 2.6%. The deal, if finalized, will be the largest pharmaceutical merger ever. Markets closed early for the Thanksgiving holiday, with below-average trading volume expected for the remainder of the week.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical heavyweights Pfizer and Allergan unveiled a record-setting US$160 billion mega-merger Monday as US stocks finished modestly lower.

site_title: China's anti-graft watchdog demotes four bank regulators
summary: China's anti-graft agency demoted four bank regulators for violating Communist Party rules, including concealing a regulator's US citizenship and attending conferences without approval. This is the latest punishment in President Xi Jinping's three-year anti-corruption campaign targeting the financial sector. The demotions follow previous actions against bank officials, with the aim of maintaining the integrity of the country's banking system.

site_title: Some of the biggest fund managers expect yuan devaluation
summary: Top hedge fund managers, including David Tepper and John Burbank, warn of a potential yuan devaluation in China, predicting a 30% decline. They cite China's struggling economy, rising non-performing loans, and falling exports as major concerns. Goldman Sachs echoes these concerns, stating a significant yuan depreciation is the biggest risk to emerging markets in 2016. The yuan's real effective exchange rate has risen nearly 20% over two years, and China's economic growth goal of 6.5% may not be met unless the yuan falls at least 8% by the end of 2016.

images.alt_text: The money managers are losing faith in China's ability to revive its economy after the surprise 1.9 per cent currency devaluation in August and global market rout that followed.

site_title: Tod's splashes out 415m euros on Roger Vivier shoes
summary: Tod's, an Italian luxury goods group, has agreed to buy the prestigious Roger Vivier shoe brand from its largest shareholder for 415 million euros. The deal gives Tod's control of a more profitable and exclusive brand, but analysts say the price tag exceeds the brand's net present value, potentially cutting the company's stock price. The deal is expected to generate over 150 million euros in sales this year, but shares initially fell 3% before recovering. The purchase will also reduce annual royalty payments of 9.2 million euros.

site_title: New York launches app to fight terror
summary: New York has launched an app called "See Something, Send Something" to encourage citizens to report suspect activities to authorities. Users can send text or photographs to the New York State Intelligence Centre, and the Metropolitan Transit Authority is hiring 46 police officers to boost counterterrorism capacity on public transportation. Governor Andrew Cuomo emphasized the efforts as part of the state's fight against terrorism following the Paris attacks.

site_title: Beijing Hualian Reit could break mainboard drought
summary: Beijing Hualian Reit, a Singapore real-estate investment trust, is set to list on the mainboard with an initial public offering worth S$597 million. The Reit, backed by strong cornerstone investors, has agreed to a 30.1% stake and will increase its distribution yield to between 5.7 and 6.3% despite pale yields compared to blue-chip peers. The IPO comes amid a tepid market and concerns over interest rate hikes and renminbi volatility.

site_title: State-built homes spurring Auckland's property boom
summary: Auckland's property market is experiencing a boom, with house prices rising 24% in the past year and now the second-highest relative to incomes among developed economies. State-built homes, once considered symbols of economic disadvantage, are fetching high prices due to their generous land sizes and proximity to the city. Over 650 state homes worth at least NZ$1 million are in the Auckland government's portfolio, with some selling for millions of dollars. This boom has raised concerns about a potential "damaging correction" in the market, which could put the New Zealand economy at risk.

site_title: NOL, Linc should disclose potential prices
summary: Singapore Exchange-listed companies Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) and Linc Energy have made potentially game-changing announcements without disclosing prices, raising concerns about their disclosure practices. Both companies have signed exclusive deals with foreign counterparties, requiring them to perform due diligence, but have not disclosed preliminary term sheets with indicative prices. This lack of transparency has led to a speculative market, where NOL's shares have been rising without disclosing a potential takeover price. The Singapore Exchange should ask both companies if prices were negotiated and why they were not disclosed, and consider imposing trading suspensions if confidentiality clauses are involved.

site_title: Existing home sales decline in October
summary: Existing US home sales declined 3.4% in October to a 5.36 million annual rate, the lowest since 2007. A limited supply of available properties, particularly affordable homes, contributed to the slowdown. Despite this, median home prices rose 5.8% from October 2014 to $219,600, driven by a dearth of supply on the market. The number of homes for sale dropped to 2.14 million, the fewest since March, and it would take 4.8 months to sell those houses at the current sales pace.

site_title: Eurozone business growth at 4-year high: poll
summary: Eurozone business activity surged to a four-year high in November, driven by a weak currency and price cutting. The Markit Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) jumped to 54.4, beating forecasts, and indicating growth of 0.4-0.5% for the region. However, the growth was largely driven by firms cutting prices, suggesting the ultra-loose monetary policy is not yet achieving its inflation target. The European Central Bank may be disappointed with the growth rate, despite injecting billions of euros into the economy through its bond-buying program.

site_title: US existing home sales fall in October
summary: US existing home sales fell 3.4% in October to a 5.36 million annual rate, down from a 5.55 million rate in September. Fewer single-family home sales drove the decline, while prices continued to rise. The median existing-home price was $219,600, a 5.8% gain from a year ago. Total housing inventory fell 2.3% to 2.14 million existing homes available for sale, with a 4.8-month supply. Despite the decline, the housing market trends higher at a modest pace.

images.alt_text: New-home construction in the US unexpectedly fell in December, indicating the industry lost some momentum entering 2016.

site_title: 'Umbrella Soldiers' win seats in Hong Kong local elections
summary: In Hong Kong's local elections, pro-democracy candidates inspired by the 2014 Umbrella movement won seats, despite some veterans from both sides suffering defeat. The election reflects continued support for political change in the Chinese-ruled city. At least 40 candidates who took part in the democracy protests or were inspired by them won office, casting them in a legitimate political light. The results may provide insight into future elections, including the Legislative Council and leadership poll in 2017.

site_title: Pfizer to buy Allergan in US$160b deal to create No 1 drugmaker
summary: Pfizer has agreed to acquire Allergan plc in a US$160 billion deal, creating the world's largest drugmaker. The acquisition will be led by Pfizer CEO Ian Read and Allergan CEO Brent Saunders. The deal surpasses Pfizer's 2000 purchase of Warner-Lambert Co and is the largest pharmaceutical acquisition in history. The combined company will be headquartered in New York, and Pfizer stockholders will receive one share of the new company for each of their Pfizer shares.

site_title: Jet Airways switches to A330 to up capacity on S'pore-Delhi route
summary: Jet Airways is upgrading its daily flights between Singapore and Delhi to a wide-body Airbus A330 aircraft, increasing seat capacity by 50% starting Wednesday. The move aims to enhance comfort and offer convenient connections for travelers from the Asean region and Australia. The A330 features a two-cabin configuration with 18 Premiere seats and 236 Economy seats, equipped with an on-demand entertainment platform. The upgrade follows a steady growth in traffic, particularly among business travelers, and is part of Jet Airways' expanding fleet, which includes 115 aircraft.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Emerging markets turning a corner?
summary: Investors are putting more money back into emerging markets, reversing a trend of asset outflows. Despite challenges such as US monetary policy tightening and slowing growth in China, experts believe the asset class remains a growth driver for the world. Many emerging markets have structural weaknesses, but government efforts to address these are underway. Countries like India, Vietnam, and Indonesia are showing resilience, with improving macroeconomic fundamentals and growth potential. Investors are being cautious, focusing on well-managed growth leaders at undervalued prices, and see opportunities for the next market turn.

site_title: Catalist-bound Trendlines could soon monetise 3 firms it helped incubate
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israeli agritech and medtech incubator, will debut on Singapore's Catalist exchange on Thursday with a S$25 million initial public offering (IPO). The firm, which has incubated 60 companies, including 16 that failed, is expected to monetize its investments with potential exits for three of its companies. Trendlines' co-founder Steve Rhodes said investors in Singapore have asked the same hard questions but have found the answers sufficient for comfort. The firm's IPO is backed by a cornerstone investor, B.Braun Melsungen, and marks a strategic shift towards Asia, with plans to set up an overseas incubator in Singapore by mid-next year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Moving towards low carbon, climate resilient economies
summary: The financial sector is increasingly focusing on supporting low-carbon, climate-resilient economies, with commercial banks, insurance companies, and investors recognizing the opportunities and risks presented by climate change. The UN's Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21) in Paris aims to limit global temperatures to 2 degrees Celsius by the end of the century. Financial leaders are calling for regulators to create incentives for sustainable financing and investment, and proposals have been made to bring in tougher corporate disclosure standards to enable investors to better judge climate change risks.

site_title: Linc Energy continues to climb
summary: Linc Energy's shares surged 52% in Singapore, closing at 24 cents, after the firm confirmed it's in compliance with listing rules and denied any unannounced information causing the spike. The stock's trading was unusually high, with 18 million shares changing hands. The surge followed news of a potential sale of the company's South Australian shale oil assets, but Linc Energy clarified that no binding agreement has been reached and formal negotiations are pending due diligence.
