images.alt_text: SGX Centre 1 (left) at Shenton Way Road in the Raffles Place District.

site_title: Overcapacity in SEA remains a problem for LCCs in short term
summary: Low-cost carriers (LCCs) in South-east Asia face overcapacity challenges due to inadequate infrastructure, limited airport slots, currency depreciation, and a softer economic environment. Despite this, the long-term outlook remains positive, with some markets still showing growth potential. Airlines have already curbed capacity growth, but some carriers, like Vietjet Air, remain optimistic about future expansion. Experts predict that Asean Open Skies, a proposed regional aviation agreement, will open up the market in 5-10 years, potentially increasing competition and capacity.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US$ up as Fed policymaker bets on December rate increase
summary: The US dollar rose to a seven-month high against the euro as a Federal Reserve policymaker, John Williams, stated that there's a "strong case" for a rate increase in December if economic reports continue to be encouraging. This move followed European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's comments suggesting policymakers may ease policy next week to raise inflation. Hedge funds increased bets on dollar strength, causing commodity currencies like the Australian dollar and South African rand to decline.

site_title: The Achilles' heel of American foreign policy
summary: The article discusses the "Achilles' heel" of American foreign policy, citing the Paris massacre as a reminder of its limitations. Since World War II, US foreign policy has relied on the idea of shared prosperity as a force for social stability and democracy. However, this approach has two major defects: unrealistic expectations that can lead to popular discontent and protectionism when growth stalls, and the failure to address the values and goals of non-Western societies, such as nationalism and radical Islam. The article concludes that the US is facing a new and disorienting threat, as non-Western societies are now challenging the legitimacy of the secular state and the values of shared prosperity.

site_title: CCB Asia to issue, list 1b yuan of Silk Road bonds on Bursa
summary: China Construction Bank (Asia) Corporation plans to issue and list 1 billion yuan (S$222 million) Land & Maritime Silk Road bonds on Bursa Malaysia, supporting the Chinese government's initiative and boosting the offshore RMB market. The notes, due 2017, are priced at 4.00% and rated A2 by Moodys Investors Services. This is the world's first 21st-century Maritime Silk Road bond, and the first China yuan-denominated bond issued by a Chinese state-owned bank to be listed on Bursa under the exempt regime.

images.alt_text: China Construction Bank (Asia) Corporation plans to issue and list one billion yuan (S$222 million) Land & Maritime Silk Road bonds on Bursa Malaysia on Thursday in support of the Chinese government initiative as well as to boost the development of the offshore RMB market.

site_title: Negative inflation seen persisting with wider output gap
summary: Singapore's output gap, the difference between actual and potential GDP, is perceived to be wider than initially expected, according to ANZ economist Glenn Maguire. This has led him to believe that negative inflation will persist for longer. The near recessionary conditions of the Singapore economy point to a significant output gap, and downward pressure on prices may be more enduring than previously thought.

site_title: Last decent shot at making 680% on China IPOs
summary: China is set to scrap its upfront payment rule for initial public offerings (IPOs), slashing the odds of a winning bid to about 0.01% after the final 28 IPOs under the current system are completed. The move aims to increase investor participation and provide a more level playing field for individual investors, who currently face significant barriers due to the pre-funding requirement. The new rules are expected to attract millions of new bidders, with the average Chinese IPO tracking a 681% surge in the 18 months leading up to June.

site_title: Beijing should rethink its approach to South China Sea issues
summary: US President Barack Obama pressed for bold steps to lower tensions in the South China Sea during the Apec and Asean talks, urging a halt to further reclamation work and emphasizing the importance of freedom of navigation. Obama also announced military aid to countries locked in disputes with China, while Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi made similar remarks. The US, Japan, and the Philippines are considering joint actions to patrol the disputed region, amid $6 trillion in global trade passing through the waters.

images.alt_text: Beijing's efforts last week to keep the region's attention away from its disputes in the South China Sea during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) meeting and the Asean-related talks in Kuala Lumpur were always going to fail.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Midas Holdings subsidiary Jilin Midas Aluminium Industries Co has won four contracts worth 72.5 million yuan (S$16.1 million) to supply aluminium alloy extrusion for metro trains in China and airport rail trains in Malaysia. New Silkroutes Group has become a shareholder in a joint venture with Malta, transforming the island into a Mediterranean oil and gas trading hub. Global Logistics Properties has signed leases totaling 69,000 sq m with JD.com, Best Logistics, and STO Express in China. These deals are expected to positively impact Midas Holdings' performance for 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Healthcare stocks show vitality in uncertain market
summary: Healthcare stocks on the Singapore bourse have shown vitality, with the SGX Healthcare Index generating a 4.9% dividend-exclusive year-to-date total return and a three-year total return of 46.2%. The MSCI Asia Healthcare Index also saw a 4.9% dividend-exclusive total return. The top performers in the index include Riverstone Holdings, UG Healthcare Corporation, and Q&M Dental Group, which averaged a year-to-date total return of 90.8%. The SGX All Healthcare Index closed at 1,495.90 on November 20, taking its total return to 49.6% since December 2010.

site_title: Ireland - the Celtic Tiger roars again
summary: Ireland's economy is experiencing a resurgence, earning the nickname "Celtic Tiger" again. Key financial news includes China's GDP growth expected to slow, which may pressure policymakers, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index. In international news, a Malaysian agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion belonging to Daim Zainuddin, and the UK economy contracted for the second month, posing a challenge to Prime Minister Starmer. Meanwhile, a Thai court is expected to clear the PM's daughter from an ethics case, and ASEAN has downplayed the importance of Myanmar's election.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UOB launches US$8b global covered bond programme
summary: UOB launched a US$8 billion global covered bond programme, its first such initiative, as it expands access to global funding markets. The covered bonds will be backed by mortgage loans in Singapore, rated AAA by Standard and Poor's and Aaa by Moody's. The programme aims to diversify funding sources, broaden investor base, and offer investors a growth opportunity. Singapore's strong housing market and robust financial sector are expected to appeal to European investors, with demand expected to come from asset managers, bank treasuries, and central banks.

site_title: Galvanised for growth
summary: Asia Galvanizing, a Singapore-based steel galvanizing firm, has experienced rapid growth since its establishment in 2012. The company, founded by brothers Albert and James Ang, has expanded its customer base to over 300, including companies from the oil & gas sector and government bodies. With a revenue of S$16 million in FY2014, the firm has become one of the youngest and most modern galvanizing plants in Singapore. Despite the initial challenges, the company has adopted environmentally responsible practices, such as using a concrete roof that reduces maintenance costs. The brothers aim to expand overseas and educate consumers about the benefits of galvanizing steel.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
Mr James Ang (above, left) and Mr Albert Ang are proud of their company, which is one of the most modern and state-of-the-art galvanising plants in Singapore.
Mr James Ang and Mr Albert Ang are proud of their company, which is one of the most modern and state-of-the-art galvanising plants in Singapore (above).

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Three Singapore stocks are recommended as potential winners in the next 12 months: Centurion, Valuetronics, and Singapore O&G. Centurion's robust occupancy rates and share buybacks are key drivers, while Valuetronics' net cash position and potential takeover candidate status are highlighted. Singapore O&G's recent acquisition of Dr. Joyce Lim's practice is expected to drive growth and enhance EPS by 27-29%. In contrast, the Land Transport Sector is downgraded to neutral due to SMRT's train disruptions and regulatory uncertainties.

site_title: ST Index down in quiet trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 14.42 points to 2,903.49, with weak turnover of S$685 million. Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares rose due to hopes of a takeover, while Linc Energy shares jumped 52% on a possible sale of assets. Overseas markets were quiet, with Europe opening in the red. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research and JP Morgan, advise caution due to a poor industry outlook and declining domestic property prices.

site_title: Asean and Singapore crucial to India, says Modi at Singapore Lecture
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated that the Asean region, including Singapore, will be crucial to his country's foreign policy under its "Act East" policy. Modi emphasized the importance of engaging with Asean and Singapore as India builds its "India of its dreams." He highlighted the common policies and shared ties that bind India to the region, positioning Asean and Singapore at the center of this policy.

site_title: NOL soars on exclusive acquisition talks
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares rose to a 52-week high after exclusive talks with CMA CGM on a potential acquisition were announced. The stock price closed at S$1.17, a 5-cent increase from the previous close. The acquisition talks were met with positive market reaction, propelling NOL's shares to a record high.

site_title: Princeton forced to take a long, hard look at Woodrow Wilson
summary: Princeton University is re-examining its legacy of former President Woodrow Wilson, who initiated the university's expansion and introduced small-group classes. However, his racist views, including segregationist comments, have sparked a student-led protest. The Black Justice League, a year-old group, demands that the university publicly acknowledge Wilson's racist legacy and rename the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. After a walkout and occupation of the president's office, the university has agreed to discuss the demands and consider removing a mural of Wilson and renaming the school.

site_title: Rex in deal to merge assets in Trinidad
summary: REX International Holdings has entered into an agreement to merge its oil-related assets in Trinidad with Norwegian company West Indian Energy Holding (WIEH) and GELCO Energy Inc. under a new entity Steeldrum Oil Company. The merger will see Steeldrum hold full ownership of the subsidiaries, with RCH and WIEH contributing US$1 million each in cash. The deal is expected to have no material financial impact on REX's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: Labour, financial structures 2 key issues in Asean integration
summary: ASEAN nations have formalized plans to create an Asean Community, including the Asean Economic Community, which aims to create a single market for free flow of goods, services, capital, and labor by December 31. However, labor and financial structures are key issues hindering economic integration, with experts suggesting that lowering labor barriers and facilitating investments can lead to significant benefits, including 14 million additional jobs by 2025. Asean's aggregate GDP is projected to increase by 5% by 2030, with Singapore expected to gain the most, at 9.5%.

site_title: PM Lee unveils S$532m National Gallery
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled the S$532 million National Gallery Singapore, the country's largest and most important art museum, on Monday evening. The 64,000 sq m museum, located in the former City Hall and Supreme Court buildings, features over 800 significant works by Singapore and South-east Asian artists, including Lim Hak Tai, Cheong Soo Pieng, and Latiff Mohidin. The museum officially opens to the public on Tuesday, with two weeks of celebrations and free events, including a carnival and performances on the Padang.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

PM Lee admiring calligraphy by Pan Shou at the National Gallery. With him are museum director Eugene Tan and Ms Fu. The museum, which has been 10 years in the making, occupies the former City Hall and Supreme Court buildings. Its handsomely refurbished interiors display more than 800 significant works in the DBS Singapore Gallery and UOB Southeast Asia Gallery.

site_title: British bus operator clinches second govt bus contract
summary: The Go-Ahead Group, a British bus operator, has secured its second government bus contract in Singapore, winning a bid to operate 25 bus services in Pasir Ris and Punggol from the third quarter of next year. Local incumbents SBS Transit and SMRT missed out on the contract.

images.alt_text: This is Go-Ahead's first bus contract outside Britain, where it has a fleet of around 4,600 buses. It is the largest bus operator in London with a market share of 24 per cent and a fleet of 2,300 buses.

site_title: Keppel Corp prices S$200m notes due 2023
summary: Keppel Corp priced S$200m notes due 2023 at a fixed rate of 3.725% per annum, with semi-annual payments and an 8-year tenor. Net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing loans and general corporate requirements. The notes are expected to be issued on or about Nov 30 and listed on the SGX.

site_title: Philippine phone giant investing record amount to boost data use
summary: PLDT, the Philippines' largest telecommunications company, plans to invest a record 43 billion pesos to expand and improve its network, amid increased competition from Globe Telecom Inc. The company aims to fend off Telstra Corp.'s potential entry into the market and boost data use. PLDT's mobile-phone users have declined, and the company is reviewing its mobile brands and digital operations. Chairman Manuel Pangilinan acknowledged the company's slow response to digital trends, citing complacency as a major factor, and vowed to refinance debt and trim expenses to remain competitive.

site_title: Part of Eden Hall land on Nassim up for sale
summary: The British government's Foreign & Commonwealth Office has launched a public tender for two adjoining freehold plots of Good-Class Bungalow (GCB) land on Nassim Road, Singapore. The plots, measuring 18,620 sq ft and 15,634 sq ft, are being offered for sale at guide prices of S$2,200 psf and S$2,000 psf, respectively. This is the first time GCB land has been sold on Nassim Road in eight years, with only three sales recorded since 2007. The plots are expected to generate significant interest from buyers, including ultra-high-net-worth families and developers.

site_title: Modern men overeat like cavemen to show off to women
summary: Researchers from Cornell University found that men tend to eat nearly double the amount when in the presence of women, consuming 93% more pizza and 86% more salad at an all-you-can-eat Italian buffet. This excessive eating is believed to be a hardwired male urge to demonstrate prowess, a trait that may have been advantageous in the past but lacks relevance in modern society. The study suggests that men overeat to signal their biological fitness and distinguish themselves as relatively superior to others.

site_title: The camera that could bring virtual reality to the masses
summary: A new stereoscopic, 3D 180-degree virtual-reality camera, LucidCam, aims to bring high-quality virtual-reality content to the masses. The portable camera can be held steady to capture 180-degree footage and is designed for point-and-shoot use. LucidCam's creators plan to launch the product in mid-2016 and raise $100,000 on crowdfunding site IndieGoGo. The goal is to make virtual-reality content accessible to the average consumer, with a projected price of under $499. The camera's potential applications include user-generated content, such as virtual-reality yoga classes or weddings, and could also lead to a shift from professional to amateur-created content.

images.alt_text: A number of media companies are busy experimenting with virtual-reality journalism.

site_title: Michelin-starred Hakkasan to hit US malls with tea house
summary: Hakkasan Group, a Michelin-starred hospitality company, is expanding its international presence with two new establishments in US malls: Yauatcha tea houses in Houston and Honolulu. The group, which has seen revenue increase 600% since 2012, aims to capitalize on the casual and scalable nature of Yauatcha, which is less expensive than its fine dining counterpart, Hakkasan. The move marks the group's entry into the US market and follows previous successes in Las Vegas and failures in New York, with lessons learned from past mistakes informing its strategic partnerships and cautious approach to expansion.

site_title: US car buffs get govt nod to 'jailbreak' software
summary: The US government has approved changes to a federal copyright law, allowing car owners to "jailbreak" their vehicle software without incurring legal wrath from carmakers. This decision, scheduled to take effect next year, aims to give consumers access to vehicle software for repairs, adjustments, and performance enhancements. Digital-rights activists have applauded the change, while environmental regulators and carmakers have warned of potential pollution and safety risks. The move is seen as a response to the widespread practice of modifying car software to evade emissions standards, which was exemplified by the Volkswagen emissions scandal.

site_title: Air strikes alone won't defeat ISIS
summary: France and the US have intensified air strikes against ISIS, but a coordinated ground strategy with Iranian and Kurdish forces is necessary to defeat the terrorist group. The US should leverage its relationship with Turkey to reduce opposition to Kurdish forces, while Iran has a strategic interest in countering ISIS due to its Shia ideology. Russia's involvement in the fight against ISIS is also significant, and coordination among Western powers, Russia, and Iran is becoming more likely. A joint strategy could help mitigate Saudi Arabia's concerns and bring about a more effective end to the ISIS threat.

site_title: H&M, global union team up to teach labour relations at suppliers
summary: H&M has partnered with IndustriALL Global Union to train its direct suppliers and workers in labour relations, aiming to improve wages and working conditions in countries such as Bangladesh, Cambodia, and Myanmar. The training will focus on negotiating wages, collective agreements, and conflict resolution. H&M's sustainability chief Anna Gedda stated that the goal is to achieve functioning labour market relations in these countries, similar to Sweden. Around 600 suppliers will receive training in 2016, with suppliers expected to participate.

images.alt_text: Fashion retailer Hennes & Mauritz (H&M) said on Tuesday it had agreed with IndustriALL Global Union to jointly train its direct suppliers and their workers in how to improve relations and dialogue between social partners.

site_title: US: Stocks open little changed
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Monday, following last week's strong gains. Gains in consumer staples offset losses in energy stocks, with the Dow Jones rising 2.14 points, the S&P 500 gaining 0.2 points, and the Nasdaq Composite adding 1.11 points.

site_title: BHP faces ratings downgrade amid prolonged commodities slump
summary: BHP Billiton faces a potential credit ratings downgrade due to the prolonged commodities slump, with investors questioning whether the mining company should continue to target increases to dividend payouts. The company's iron ore price has dropped to a four-month low, and its debt insurance costs have reached a four-year high. Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings have downgraded BHP to A+, with a negative view, while Moody's has maintained a stable outlook. The company's shares closed 2.1% lower, and analysts predict a possible downgrade to A from A+ or A.

site_title: Iskandar builder Astaka ends debut on Catalist at 24 S'pore cents
summary: Astaka Holdings, a Malaysia-based builder, debuted on Singapore's Catalist at 24 Singapore cents, surpassing its opening price of 24.5 cents. The counter, focused on Iskandar region developments, saw 1.5 million shares traded worth S$371,000. Astaka's listing brings the total market capitalisation of Catalist-listed companies to S$10 billion, with the exchange's total real estate companies reaching 50, valued at S$95 billion.

site_title: Norway's offshore fleet in for more pain, says top lobbyist
summary: Norway's offshore fleet has seen a significant increase in idle vessels, from zero to 100 in just one year, according to the Norwegian Shipowners' Association. The industry's top lobbyist, Sturla Henriksen, predicts that 2016 and 2017 will be particularly challenging years, with "the worst is still to come." The rising number of idle vessels poses significant financial pain for the industry.

site_title: Asia has long way to go in integration: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) released a report stating that Asia remains a fragmented continent in terms of economic integration, with South-east Asia being the only region making "substantial progress". The report calls for greater efforts to integrate the region, citing the need for cooperation with other development organizations, such as the AIIB and Silk Road Fund. The report also highlights the region's lagging progress in regional cooperation, citing examples of declining regional trade and infrastructure development. It emphasizes the potential benefits of integration, including improved social stability, peace, and governance, but notes that failure to integrate is a wasted opportunity.

site_title: Elon Musk ties to SolarEdge cast long shadow on already troubled stock
summary: SolarEdge Technologies Inc, a leading provider of photovoltaic systems, is facing a decline in stock price following a scaling back of installations by its largest client, SolarCity Corp, backed by billionaire Elon Musk. Despite beating profit and sales estimates, the company's shares have dropped to $18, down from a peak of $42. Analysts predict the stock will rally 77% in the next year, but turmoil in the solar industry and competition from other companies are concerns. SolarEdge is diversifying its customer base and focusing on European and Japanese markets to mitigate risks.

site_title: This time, it's not deflation: economists
summary: Singapore has logged its 12th straight month of negative inflation, with October's headline inflation easing to -0.8% from September's -0.6%. However, economists stress that the reasons for negative inflation are different this time, with falling car prices and housing rentals, as well as lower global oil prices, contributing to the decline. Despite core inflation remaining positive at 0.3%, economists predict headline inflation will turn positive around the second quarter of next year, and core inflation to rise gradually over the course of next year.

site_title: Singapore business delegation in Indonesia
summary: A 19-member Singapore business delegation, led by Keppel Corporation's Tay Lim Heng, is visiting Indonesia's cities of Semarang and Yogyakarta for a five-day business mission. The delegation aims to network with potential business partners and explore opportunities in sectors such as education, manufacturing, and tourism. Indonesia is seen as a promising market for Singapore companies due to its large consumer base and rising middle-class. The visit is part of efforts to strengthen bilateral trade between the two countries, which has increased over the past decade to $72.4 billion in 2014.

site_title: Evergrande buys insurer as China developer diversifies
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group, China's third-largest developer, has acquired a 50% stake in Great Eastern Life Assurance's Chinese joint venture for 3.9 billion yuan (S$866.2 million). The purchase, valued at more than twice the initial asking price, aims to diversify into insurance. Evergrande's shares jumped 5.4% to HK$6.81, following the announcement, which is seen as a positive for the company's rating. The move increases Evergrande's risk profile, but its shares have more than doubled this year, outperforming the Hang Seng Mainland 100 Index.

site_title: China to buy M'sian bonds, offers investment quota
summary: China will buy more Malaysian government bonds and grant a 50 billion yuan (S$11.1 billion) investment quota to invest in Chinese stocks and bonds, aiming to strengthen ties with Southeast Asia. Premier Li Keqiang made the announcement during his visit to Kuala Lumpur for the Asean summit. China also offers $10 billion in infrastructure loans to Southeast Asian countries and aid to underdeveloped states. This move is seen as an effort to expand China's influence in the developing world and stabilize Malaysia's financial markets.

site_title: Milan stock exchange set to be Ferrari's next stop
summary: Ferrari plans to list 9% of its shares on the Milan stock exchange, following a similar listing on Wall Street in October. The listing will allow for dual listing in New York and Milan, with the Wall Street sale valuing Ferrari at $10.6 billion. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, which owns 90% of Ferrari, aims to strengthen its finances by spinning off the sports car maker. The company plans to invest $48 billion to expand global sales to 7 million vehicles per year.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies reported mixed earnings, with Creative Technology warning of lower-than-target revenue and operating losses similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Singapore, stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. MAS and the PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2.

site_title: Saudis reiterate readiness to work with producers to stabilise oil
summary: Saudi Arabia reaffirmed its commitment to stabilize the oil market by cooperating with Opec members and non-Opec producers. The country aims to preserve market stability and prices, amid rising output from North America and Russia. Brent crude prices rose 48 cents to $45.14 a barrel after Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi stated that cooperation with non-Opec countries could lead to a stable market. Saudi Arabia has been pumping above its target for 17 months to take market share from higher-cost producers.

site_title: US existing home sales fall more than expected in October
summary: US existing home sales fell 3.4% to 5.36 million units in October, exceeding expectations, but underlying trends suggest a firmer footing for housing. Sales rose 3.9% from last year, and are on track to record their best annual sales in eight years, driven by a strengthening labor market and household formation. However, a persistent shortage of houses for sale remains a constraint, driving up prices and sidelining first-time buyers, particularly in the West and South regions.

site_title: Malta's energy ministry is new shareholder for New Silkroutes' JV
summary: Malta's Ministry of Energy and Health has become a shareholder in New Silkroutes' joint venture IEG Malta Limited, a Mediterranean oil and gas trading hub. The move is part of Malta's ambition to become the preferred oil trading hub between Europe and Asia. The joint venture, formed in May, aims to transform Malta into a key player in the Euro-Asian energy market, with CEO Goh Jin Hian stating that the collaboration is timely given the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 9.01 points to 1,670.90, after trading 2.95 billion lots valued at RM1.93 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 474 to 449.

site_title: Update: Malaysia's 1MDB agrees sale of power assets to China firm for US$2.3B
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has agreed to sell its energy assets to China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN) for 9.83 billion ringgit (S$3.23 billion). The sale, part of 1MDB's efforts to cut its US$11 billion debt, will see CGN assume all debt of Edra Global Energy Bhd, 1MDB's power unit. The deal is a key step in the embattled state fund's restructuring efforts, which have been marred by allegations of graft involving Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore inflation eased to -0.8% in October, mainly due to lower costs of oil-related and retail items. Fitch Ratings warned of rising risks for Singapore Reits in 2016 due to weak economic fundamentals and new supply. A part of land at the British High Commissioner's official residence is up for sale. Meanwhile, Beijing Hualian Group plans to list a S$597 million Reit in Singapore. The yuan fell to a three-month low amid concerns of a decline to help China's economy.

site_title: BoE official: Paris attacks unlikely to have much impact on UK or global economy
summary: A Bank of England policymaker, Don Kohn, stated that the Paris attacks are unlikely to have a significant impact on the UK or global economy, citing past incidents as having minimal economic effects. Economies have proven resilient to such threats, with the UK and global economy expected to remain resilient. Kohn also expressed concerns over rising house prices and the need to monitor the buy-to-let market.

site_title: CAD starts investigation into KLW Holdings
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in Singapore has launched an investigation into KLW Holdings, a Catalist-listed doormaker, over alleged lapses in internal controls and potential breaches of disclosure rules. The company's head of operations and human resources, Gaw Kuan Ching Jaslin, and former managing director Lee Boon Teck were interviewed by CAD on November 19 and 20, respectively. CAD has requested access to the company's accounting records, banking records, and corporate documents, following a special auditor's findings. The investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: The white-collar crime busters have come knocking on the doors of KLW Holdings.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB's deal with China power firm on agenda for PM meet: document
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak signed a document with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang during a joint media conference, but the details of the agreement were not disclosed. The document listed a share sale and purchase deal between 1MDB and China Nuclear Power Corp, a move aimed at reducing the state fund's debt burden. The deal was not signed, and business agreements were also set to be unveiled, but their details were not released. Sources previously reported that 1MDB was nearing the sale of its power assets to an overseas consortium, including a Chinese company.

site_title: Pfizer buys Allergan in massive US$160b deal to create world's largest drugmaker
summary: Pfizer Inc has agreed to buy Allergan Plc in a US$160 billion deal, creating the world's largest drugmaker. The deal, valued at 11.3 Pfizer shares for each Allergan share, will see Pfizer stockholders receive one share of the combined company for each of their Pfizer shares. The acquisition will combine Pfizer's portfolio of prescription medications with Allergan's popular Botox brand, expanding the company's offerings in the healthcare sector. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of 2015.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma said to be in discussions to buy SCMP stake
summary: Alibaba's founder Jack Ma is in talks to buy a stake in the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post (SCMP), a struggling traditional newspaper. The discussions are at an advanced stage, with a signing ceremony expected soon. This move would follow other Internet tycoons, such as Amazon's Jeff Bezos and Facebook's Chris Hughes, who have purchased storied brands. The SCMP has faced declining earnings and circulation due to the shift to online media, and control has remained unchanged since 1993. Financial details of the deal are not available.

site_title: The Emerald Isle's startling economic rebound post-crisis
summary: Ireland is experiencing a remarkable economic rebound, with a projected 6% growth rate this year, making it the top performer in the EU. The country's jobless rate has fallen to 9.5%, and the government is eager to woo its skilled emigrants back home. The economy's recovery is driven by exports, a weak euro, and low commodity prices, with the government unveiling an expansionary budget to stimulate jobs and raise wages. However, critics argue that the government's pro-cyclical fiscal policy could limit its options in a downturn, and the country still faces high debt and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Ireland's jobless rate has fallen from a peak of 15 per cent in 2012 to 9.5 per cent this year, and is expected to slide to 8 per cent next year, versus 11 per cent in the euro area.

site_title: UOB launches US$8b global covered bond programme
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a US$8 billion global covered bond programme, backed by a portfolio of mortgage loans linked to properties in Singapore. The programme aims to diversify funding sources and broaden investor base. Covered bonds, comparable to mortgage-backed securities, will be rated AAA by Standard and Poor's and Aaa by Moody's. The programme is the second covered bond launch by a Singapore bank this year, following DBS's debut in the same period, and will help maintain UOB's solid funding base.

site_title: Rolls-Royce lifts stakes in engine maintenance centres
summary: Rolls-Royce is increasing its stakes in two aero-engine maintenance centers in Singapore and Hong Kong, investing $206.5 million to reach 50% ownership. The move aims to improve competitiveness and is part of CEO Warren East's plan to cut costs and overhaul the company. East has stated the need for cost-cutting and transformation to adapt to changing markets. The company's three maintenance centers will now compete for new work, as part of the plan to boost competitiveness.

site_title: Indonesia to make green financing compulsory for banks by 2018
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority plans to introduce rules by 2018 to restrict banks' lending to environmentally-damaging projects, aiming to curb forest fires and haze. The rules will target agriculture, energy, fishery, and microfinance companies, building on guidelines for sustainable financing in the palm oil industry. The move is part of efforts to reduce Indonesia's environmental impact, which worsened this year due to widespread forest fires. The regulator aims to encourage banks to invest in sustainable projects to offset non-environmentally friendly activities.

site_title: China seeks to remove provincial barriers to trade
summary: China's State Council announced plans to accelerate reforms to remove internal barriers to trade, aiming to boost domestic consumption in its slowing economy. The move includes increasing access to foreign and domestic investors, eliminating administrative monopolies, and strengthening anti-monopoly laws. The government also aims to reform the residence registration system to unleash spending potential of rural population, improve internet infrastructure, and expand market access for foreign firms. The reforms are part of China's five-year strategic objectives, designed to promote consumption and lift domestic demand.

site_title: Credit Suisse reviews management compensation after overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse is reviewing its management compensation structure after scrapping profitability targets under new CEO Tidjane Thiam's strategy. The bank has scrapped return-on-equity and cost-to-income ratios as targets and is seeking 6 billion francs in equity to fund its new strategy. Executive board members will receive 2 million francs, up from 1.5 million francs for 2014, with CEO's yearly salary raised to 3 million francs. The review comes after the bank named six new executive board members and scrapped four, as part of its overhaul announced last month.

site_title: British operator Go-Ahead Group wins second Government bus contract
summary: The Go-Ahead Group, a British public transport operator, has won its second government bus contract in Singapore, securing a 25-bus service package in Pasir Ris and Punggol. The contract, worth an undisclosed amount, will be operated in two phases from 2016, replacing SBS Transit's services. Go-Ahead will also manage bus interchanges and a new depot. This marks the second contract awarded to a foreign operator, following a previous win by SBS Transit in 2013.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker in low volume
summary: Singapore stocks declined on Monday with low trading volume, falling 14.42 points to 2,903.49 on the Straits Times Index. The main driver was a weak performance from overseas markets, including Hong Kong and China, and a lack of guidance from US markets. Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares rose due to potential takeover talks, while Linc Energy shares also gained due to a possible asset sale. The STI ended with 163 rises versus 238 falls, but overall market sentiment was subdued.

site_title: Midas wins four contracts worth S$16 million
summary: Midas Holdings, a subsidiary of Midas Holdings, has won four contracts worth S$16.1 million to supply aluminum alloy extrusion for metro trains in China and Malaysia. The contracts, awarded by Changchun Railway Vehicles Co, are valued at 72.5 million yuan and are expected to contribute positively to Midas' performance for 2015 and 2016. The contracts include deliveries in 2015 and 2016, with Midas CEO Patrick Chew stating that they augment the company's track record and position Midas well for China's growing metro investments.

site_title: Selloff from oil to metals to crops halts global rally in stocks
summary: Global stock markets halted a five-day rally due to a slump in commodities, including a 5% drop in nickel, a 6-year low in soybeans, and a drop below $42 a barrel in crude oil. The Bloomberg Commodity Index fell to its lowest level since 1999, with 22 raw materials prices tumbling 23% this year. The slump is attributed to slowing demand in China and a stronger dollar, which makes commodities more expensive for buyers in other currencies. The MSCI All-Country World Index fell 0.3%, while the Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped 0.5%.

site_title: National Gallery Singapore unveiled
summary: The National Gallery Singapore, a $532 million museum, was unveiled by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on November 23, 2015, after a decade of planning. Located in restored buildings of the former Supreme Court and City Hall, it is the world's first museum dedicated to Singapore and South-east Asian art. The gallery will open to the public on Tuesday, offering a comprehensive showcase of the region's art and culture.

site_title: Eurozone business growth at 4-year high as firms cut prices
summary: Business activity in the eurozone reached a 4-year high in November, driven by a weak currency and price cutting, with new orders and employment increasing. The Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index jumped to 54.4, beating expectations, but was largely driven by firms cutting prices, which may not be enough to boost inflation. Despite the European Central Bank's stimulus, growth remains below target, and policymakers may need further action to address the slowdown.

site_title: Aberdeen adding to Malaysian holdings, says selloff was overdone
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management is increasing its holdings in Malaysia's bonds and currency, citing a selloff that was overdone. The decision comes as the ringgit, Malaysia's currency, has lost 19% this year due to a slump in crude prices and a political scandal involving Prime Minister Najib Razak. Despite this, foreign funds have become net buyers of Malaysian bonds, and the economy has expanded 4.7% last quarter. Aberdeen's senior investment manager, Kenneth Akintewe, believes the ringgit will be neutral or even overweight by the end of the year.

site_title: Asean, Singapore at centre of India's Act East policy: Modi
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated that the Asean region, particularly Singapore, is at the center of his country's Act East policy. Modi delivered a lecture in Singapore, praising the city-state's achievements and citing its example as a model for India's growth. He emphasized that Singapore's success is not limited by its size or resources, and that it teaches India and other nations about innovation and inspiration. Modi's visit to Singapore coincided with the State Funeral Service of Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew.

images.alt_text: Laying a broad roadmap of India's foreign policy and engagement, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, said on Monday that as his country engages with the Asia under its Act East policy, the Asean region in general and Singapore in particular is "at the centre" of this policy.

site_title: Beijing Hualian Group looks to list Reit in Singapore with strong cornerstone investors
summary: Beijing Hualian Group plans to list a Singapore real estate investment trust (Reit) worth S$597 million, with a 30.1% stake held by a strategic investor. The Reit will acquire five malls from the sponsor, and the public offer is expected to open on Dec 2. Cornerstone investors, including China Hi-Tech Holding Company and China Life Insurance, have agreed to subscribe for 34.4% of the units. The Reit's distribution yield is expected to increase to 5.7-6.3%, with trading set to begin on Dec 11.

site_title: Asia: Shares, dollar rise on expectations of US rate increase
summary: Asia shares rose on Monday as investors gained confidence in a potential US interest rate hike next month, boosting the dollar and driving up shares on Wall Street. The greenback rose against emerging-market currencies, while oil and raw materials fell. European stocks also rose, led by mining and healthcare shares, despite the euro's seven-month low. The US dollar is expected to remain strong, with market expectations of a rate hike in December driving bullish positioning.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at highest in nearly 2 weeks; won down
summary: South Korean shares rose to their highest level in nearly two weeks, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing up 0.7% at 2,003.70 points. Investors are watching for possible monetary policy easing by the European Central Bank next week. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares worth 102.2 billion won ($125 million), while the South Korean won decreased 0.4% to 1,158.5 to the dollar.

site_title: Singapore economy stands to gain from Asean Economic Community
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to benefit from the Asean Economic Community (AEC), which aims to promote free trade and capital movement in the region. Experts predict a 9.5% increase in GDP by 2030 if the AEC is well-implemented. The AEC will come into effect on December 31, 2025.

site_title: France targets prepaid debit cards in fight against terror finance
summary: France is targeting prepaid debit cards in its fight against terrorist financing, with Finance Minister Michel Sapin announcing stricter regulations to make it harder to remain anonymous. The current system allows prepaid credit cards to be recharged without identity checks, but Sapin plans to change this to prevent anonymous transactions. This move comes after prepaid cards were used in the November 13 Paris attacks, with authorities aiming to disrupt terrorist financing networks.

site_title: Philippines' Jollibee says looking to buy 1 or 2 more foreign firms
summary: Philippine fast-food chain Jollibee Foods Corp plans to acquire one or two foreign-owned food suppliers, similar in size to its recent $99 million purchase of 40% of US-based chain Smashburger. The goal is to reach the top five in market value among global food suppliers. Jollibee Chairman Tony Tan Caktiong stated that the acquisitions will be crucial for the company's financial growth.

site_title: China stock offers to resume next week: companies
summary: China's stock market is set to resume initial public offerings (IPOs) next week, with 28 companies previously frozen due to market volatility. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has lifted the freeze after exchanges became more stable. The first company to list is Kailong Chemical, an industrial explosives maker, followed by 9 others over three days. The resumption aims to introduce a market-based system, replacing the current system where the government regulator determines pricing and size of share issues. Analysts have mixed views, with some concerned about short-term market volatility.

images.alt_text: China's stocks fell for the first time in three days as losses for technology companies overshadowed a rally for commodity producers.

site_title: Jalan Besar Plaza site up for en bloc sale (Amended)
summary: Jalan Besar Plaza, a 4,927.8 sqm freehold site in Singapore, is up for collective sale with an estimated sale price of S$390 million. The site has a plot ratio of 3.0 and currently houses a 16-storey building. The tender closes on January 21, 2016. The estimated price per square foot per plot ratio is S$2,499, including a development charge of S$7.63 million.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Brussels under lockdown as Paris terror suspect eludes police
summary: Belgium's capital, Brussels, is under a third-day lockdown due to the ongoing manhunt for Salah Abdeslam, a key suspect in the Paris terror attacks that killed 130 people. The city's metro, shops, and schools are closed, and the government warns of a serious threat to the public. European governments prepare to carry out airstrikes against Islamic State in Syria, and leaders, including French President Francois Hollande and UK Prime Minister David Cameron, plan to meet to discuss the crisis.

site_title: PUB explores solar deployment at reservoirs and facilities
summary: PUB is conducting a nine-month feasibility study to explore the potential for solar deployment at its reservoirs and facilities in Singapore. The study, valued at $338,000, aims to assess the extent to which solar panels can be installed and the achievable solar yield. Ten reservoirs will be studied, and the research will also examine the potential for solar deployment at land-based facilities. The study's findings will inform a proposed business model and implementation plan, with the goal of balancing solar energy generation with other water activities at the reservoirs.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Oslo-listed BW Offshore suspends dividend due oil sector crisis
summary: BW Offshore, a Norwegian oil company, has suspended its dividend payments until the outlook for the oil sector improves. The company reported a third-quarter earnings of $174 million, beating analyst expectations, but noted the impact of the oil crisis. The firm cited an insurance recovery of $75 million not included in analyst projections. The move is a response to the current market conditions, highlighting the challenges faced by the oil industry.

site_title: Siemens chief warns on investment after Paris attacks
summary: Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser warns that the recent Paris attacks may lead companies to put investment plans on hold due to sapped investor confidence. He cites the biggest economic damage as a loss of confidence, a crucial element in this phase. Kaeser also expresses concern over the geopolitical fallout, stating it as his top business concern. The attacks' impact on investor confidence is expected to be significant.

site_title: India to cut stake in state-run companies when markets improve: Jaitley
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced plans to sell shares in state-run companies when market conditions improve, aiming to meet its asset sales target to reduce the deficit. The country has raised only $2 billion, or 20% of its target, so far this year. Additionally, Jaitley expressed optimism that recent government and central bank steps will improve the asset quality of state-run banks within a "reasonable" timeframe, addressing the banks' highest bad loan ratio in a decade.

images.alt_text: India will sell shares in some state-run companies when market conditions improve, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said on Monday, as the government struggles to meet its asset sales target that is crucial to help plug its deficit.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.7% to 6,293.27 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also declined, with the latter losing 0.2% to 4,901.68 points.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down, Guotai Junan shares slump on missing CEO
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.4% to 22,665.90, tracking weak mainland markets and uncertainty over the Chinese economy. Guotai Junan shares plummeted 12.3% after the brokerage failed to reach its CEO since November 18. In contrast, Evergrande Real Estate shares surged 5% after announcing a US$617 million deal. Investors remain cautious ahead of potential US interest rate hikes and are seeking fresh cues on the Chinese economy.

site_title: Shares in Chinese brokerage slump as chief goes missing
summary: Shares in Guotai Junan International, a Chinese brokerage firm, plummeted 15% after its Hong Kong chief, Yim Fung, went missing. The company cited "severe disciplinary violations" in the anti-graft campaign, which comes as Beijing targets the financial sector. Guotai Junan's shares dropped to HK$2.91, down 10.46%, amid concerns about Yim's disappearance and potential ties to the financial sector. The incident raises questions about the effectiveness of China's anti-corruption campaign.

site_title: French services growth slows after Paris attacks
summary: French services growth has slowed after the Paris attacks, with the flash composite Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) for November coming in at 51.3, down from 52.6 in October. Despite this, manufacturing activity has increased, with the manufacturing index rising to 50.8, its highest since April 2014. The attacks are believed to have had a short-lived impact on the economy, with companies citing reduced footfall and consumer sentiment as the main reasons for the slowdown.

site_title: Retailers give shoppers new reasons to use mobile phones in stores
summary: Retailers are launching mobile apps to enhance in-store shopping experiences, aiming to regain market share from online rivals. Macy's, JCPenney, and Staples are testing apps that allow customers to find products, order out-of-stock items, and compare prices with online retailers. The apps will also enable customers to summon clerks and access digital coupons. Despite the efforts, challenges remain, including getting customers to adopt the new technology and ensuring in-store systems function smoothly.

site_title: Australia: Shares post 5th straight rise on banks, Woolworths
summary: Australian shares rose for a fifth straight session on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing up 0.4% or 20.3 points at 5,276.4. Woolworths surged 3.9%, its largest gain in a month, driven by takeover rumors. The benchmark has risen 5.2% since November 16. Meanwhile, New Zealand's NZX 50 index rose 1.2% to finish at 6,077.6.

site_title: Part of land at official residence of British High Comm in Singapore on sale
summary: The British government has put two adjoining freehold land plots on Nassim Road, near the official residence of the British High Commissioner in Singapore, up for sale. The plots, totaling 34,254 sq ft, have guide prices of S$2,200 psf and S$2,000 psf, respectively. The sites are zoned for residential use and are expected to be sold as part of Eden Hall, the British High Commissioner's official residence.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore inflation eases to -0.8% in October
summary: Singapore's inflation eased to -0.8% in October, driven by lower costs of oil-related and retail items. Core inflation moderated to 0.3%, lower than the previous month's 0.6%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributed the decline to reduced electricity tariffs and cheaper personal care products. Accommodation costs fell 3%, while private road transport costs dropped 2.3%. The government reaffirmed its inflation projections, expecting core inflation at 0.5% and headline inflation at -0.5% for the full year.

site_title: Wal-Mart pulls Cyber Monday forward to Sunday, record industry sales expected
summary: Wal-Mart is shifting Cyber Monday to Sunday, Nov 29, for the first time, offering 2,000 online-only deals starting at 8 pm Eastern US time. The move aims to capture online demand as retailers compete with Amazon.com. Industry-wide Cyber Monday sales in the US are expected to reach $3 billion, up 12% from last year, while Black Friday sales are expected to rise 15% to $2.7 billion. This change is part of retailers' efforts to stretch single-day shopping events to capture more demand.

images.alt_text: Wal-Mart Stores Inc has decided that Cyber Monday, the biggest online shopping day of the year, should not start on a Monday anymore.

site_title: Rajah & Tann launches new practice group to serve startups, SMEs
summary: Rajah & Tann Singapore has launched a new practice group, Business Fundamentals, to serve startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The group, led by partner Jonathan Yuen, will provide legal advice in deal-making, dispute resolution, and customized documentation for startups and SMEs. This move aims to address the pain points faced by SMEs in managing their business operations and establishing a sound legal framework.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Euro drops to seven-month low as Draghi feeds bears; New Zealand dollar falls
summary: The euro dropped to a seven-month low against major peers after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi hinted at potential policy easing next week. Hedge funds increased bets on dollar strength, while the New Zealand dollar also declined. The New Zealand central bank is expected to cut interest rates, fueling speculation.

site_title: Inadequate dirty money regulation 'leaves UK open to terror funds'
summary: Britain's anti-money laundering system is deemed "woefully inadequate" by Transparency International UK, leaving the country vulnerable to terrorist funds and corrupt money. Billions of pounds of dirty money flow through the UK each year due to a fragmented and unaccountable system. The group recommends creating a single, independent national supervisory body to replace the current 22 private sector supervisors. Senior professionals should also be personally liable for money laundering, but the government has scrapped plans to make senior bankers guilty until proven innocent. The UK's economy also shrinks for the second month in a row.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reclaim 2,000 level following Wall Street rally; won down
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.7% to 2,004.09 points, reclaiming the 2,000-point level, following a Wall Street rally and expectations of European Central Bank stimulus. The won fell 0.4% to 1,158.3 per dollar. Samsung C&T and Hanmi Pharm Co Ltd rose 6% and 7.5% respectively after winning new orders and announcing a phase 2 clinical trial. The rally comes ahead of the ECB's December policy meeting and US Fed meeting.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.03% to 2,918.88. Trading was light, with 39.6 million shares changing hands. Asian shares were sluggish due to a Japanese holiday, but the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq ended higher.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Iron ore bear Andy Xie predicts prices below US$40 by year-end
summary: Iron ore prices are predicted to drop below US$40 by year-end, according to independent economist Andy Xie. This prediction is based on China's demand sputtering and high-cost iron ore miners going under. Mills in China will cut output and the steel industry is reaching a critical point, with major bankruptcies expected. The four biggest producers, including BHP Billiton and Vale SA, still have costs below current prices, but are betting on higher production to cut costs and raise market share.

site_title: Update: Hot stock: NOL shares jump on exclusive sale talks
summary: NOL shares jumped 4.0 Singapore cents, trading at S$1.16, after its controlling shareholder entered into exclusive sale talks with CMA CGM, the world's third-largest container shipping firm. The deal, valid until Dec 7, would be one of the top M&A deals involving a Singapore entity and among the biggest tie-ups between container shipping lines in recent years. AP Moeller-Maersk, the world's biggest container group, is out of the race.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China: Stocks end lower, telecom sector drags
summary: China's stocks ended lower on Monday, with the telecom sector leading declines, as investors remained cautious ahead of fresh listings. The CSI300 index fell 0.6% to 3,753.34 and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.5% to 3,610.31 points. Ten Chinese companies filed prospectus filings for 3 billion yuan in share sales, resuming initial public offerings suspended during the summer market rout.

images.alt_text: China stocks ended lower on Monday, with the telecoms sector leading declines and as investors remained cautious ahead of a fresh batch of listings.

site_title: Euro hits 7-month low, pressured by ECB stimulus expectations
summary: The euro plummeted to a 7-month low against the dollar, reaching US$1.0610, due to expectations of increased European Central Bank stimulus next month. This marks the lowest level since April. The decline is attributed to investors' concerns about the economic outlook and the potential impact of the ECB's monetary policy.

site_title: China to buy Malaysian bonds, offers investment quota in SE-Asia push
summary: China plans to buy more Malaysian government bonds and grant the country a 50 billion yuan (S$11.1 billion) investment quota in Southeast Asian markets, aiming to strengthen ties with the region. Premier Li Keqiang made the announcement during his visit to Kuala Lumpur for the ASEAN summit, as part of China's efforts to increase its economic presence in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: China will buy more Malaysian government bonds and give the country a 50 billion yuan (S$11.1 billion) quota to invest in Chinese stocks and bonds as it looks to strengthen ties with Southeast Asia.

site_title: Risks to rise for Singapore Reits in 2016; more M&As likely: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings warns that risks will rise for Singapore Reits in 2016 due to weak economic fundamentals and new supply. Sector leverage is expected to increase, with hospitality and industrial S-Reits facing declining earnings, while healthcare S-Reits are expected to maintain strong performance. The ratings agency predicts that S-Reits with stronger balance sheets will become more acquisitive in 2016 to boost earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Pfizer set to buy Allergan for more than US$150b: sources
summary: Pfizer Inc has secured formal board approval to acquire Botox maker Allergan Plc for more than $150 billion, creating the world's largest drug maker. The deal will create a pharmaceutical colossus with annual sales of over $60 billion and will involve Pfizer paying 11.3 of its shares for each Allergan share, with a small cash component. The acquisition will also lead to Pfizer's CEO Ian Read becoming the CEO of the combined company, while Allergan's CEO Brent Saunders will join as a senior executive focused on operations and integration, with a seat on the board.

site_title: Japan govt plans to raise minimum wage to boost economy: draft
summary: Japan's government plans to raise the minimum wage and wages for other workers to boost the economy, aiming to reach a 600 trillion yen GDP in five years. The government will also offer financial support to pensioners and reward companies investing in energy-efficient plants and equipment. Additionally, a lower corporate tax rate below 30% is expected to be introduced to improve competitiveness. The draft economic stimulus measures will be presented by Economics Minister Akira Amari, with finalization expected by the end of the month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.49% in early trade on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 110.68 points to 22,644.04. This came after pro-democracy protests in the city, which held its first elections since last year. Mainland Chinese stocks rose slightly, with the Shanghai Composite Index edging up 0.15% to 3,635.97. Shares in Guotai Junan plummeted 11% due to concerns over its chairman's unavailability.

site_title: Ringgit leads decline in Asia as recent gains deemed excessive
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led losses in Asia after speculation that last week's rally was overdone. The currency rose 2.1% in five days before declining 0.4% to 4.3025 a dollar. The decline is attributed to profit-taking and the slight drop in oil prices. The ringgit has dropped 19% this year, the most in Asia, due to depressed oil prices and a looming US rate increase. Foreign investors sold RM320.1 million worth of Malaysian shares last week, taking net sales to RM18.5 billion this year.

site_title: Feline surreal: Belgians tweet cat photos for #BrusselsLockdown
summary: Belgian Twitter users responded to police requests for social media silence during anti-terrorism raids in Brussels by posting thousands of cat photos under the hashtag #BrusselsLockdown. The surreal response, which included pictures of cats looking suspicious and riding hover scooters, was met with international support. Authorities thanked the internet for taking into account the needs of the ongoing operation, resulting in 16 arrests. The unusual reaction was seen as a humorous and creative way to cope with the tension and anxiety caused by the lockdown.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.09 points to 1,661.59. Trading volume was high, with 95.7 million lots valued at RM20.4 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 129 to 59.

site_title: Hot stock: Astaka Holdings lists on Catalist at 24.5 Singapore cents
summary: Astaka Holdings, a Malaysia-based property developer, listed on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at 24.5 Singapore cents following the acquisition of Astaka Padu Limited by E2-Capital Holdings Limited. The enlarged entity has an estimated market capitalisation of S$449 million after a placement exercise raising S$58 million. Astaka Holdings focuses on high-end projects in Iskandar Malaysia, including the 1 Bukit Senyum integrated development project.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Carmakers at China show predict new era of slower sales growth
summary: Chinese carmakers predict slower sales growth, with Volkswagen China's Soh Weiming forecasting a 3-5% expansion in passenger vehicle sales next year. Executives at major automakers, including FAW Toyota and Daimler AG, also note a "new normal" of slower growth due to the economy's slowdown. Total vehicle sales may increase 3% this year, down from a 36% average growth in the past decade. The industry is shifting focus to expanding in smaller cities and introducing more SUV and minivan models to tap demand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KrisEnergy, Rex International, SIA, NOL
summary: KrisEnergy received government approval for the Rossukon oil discovery in the Gulf of Thailand. Rex International's subsidiary, Rex Caribbean Holdings, entered into an investment agreement with West Indian Energy Holding and GELCO Energy to merge their assets in Trinidad into Steeldrum Oil Company Inc. SIA confirmed a bomb threat on flight SQ001, while Neptune Orient Lines is in exclusive talks with CMA CGM over a potential takeover.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Financial markets in Japan were closed on Monday for a national holiday. Meanwhile, in other markets, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while Asia's stocks continued to rise despite US President Trump's new threats. In Europe, mining and healthcare stocks boosted shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising despite uncertainty.

site_title: Paris attacks: Arrests in Brussels raids but Paris suspect still on run
summary: Belgian police arrested 16 people in anti-terrorism raids, but Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the Paris attacks, remains on the run. The raids, which took place in Brussels and Charleroi, did not yield any arms or weapons, and the city remains under a high security alert level. Schools and the metro will be closed, and the government is urging non-essential staff to work from home. The European Union and NATO have increased security measures, and US President Barack Obama has called for resolve in the fight against the Islamic State.

site_title: SBF leads business mission to Indonesia
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) is leading a five-day business mission to Indonesia's Semarang and Yogyakarta, focusing on sectors such as education, manufacturing, and tourism. The mission aims to network with potential business partners and government agencies, building on Singapore and Indonesia's $72.4 billion trade figure in 2014, with Singapore being Indonesia's top foreign investor. The 19-strong delegation is supported by IE Singapore, the Indonesian Investment Coordinating Board, and the Indonesian Embassy in Singapore, led by Tay Lim Heng, director of group risk management at Keppel Corporation.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Oil prices slide as Venezuela sees mid-US$20 crude if Opec doesn't act
summary: Venezuela predicts oil prices may drop to mid-US$20 a barrel unless Opec takes action to stabilize the market. Saudi Arabia and Qatar are considering Venezuela's proposal for an equilibrium price of US$88 a barrel. Opec's collective quota is 30 million barrels a day, but Iran plans to boost output by 1 million barrels a day within five to six months. Oil prices have slumped 45% in the past year amid speculation of a global glut. The 12-member Opec group meets on Dec 4 to discuss production ceilings.

images.alt_text: Venezuela's Oil Minister Eulogio del Pino attends an extraordinary ministerial meeting of the Gas Exporting Countries Forum (GECF) in Tehran on Nov 21, 2015.

site_title: Devaluation bets push yuan to three-month low as fixing weakened
summary: The yuan fell to a three-month low of 6.3955 per dollar amid concerns China will devalue the currency to boost its economy. The central bank weakened the currency's reference rate, cutting the onshore yuan's daily fixing by 0.14% to 6.3867. Hedge fund managers predict a 30% devaluation, while billionaire David Tepper says the yuan is massively overvalued and needs to drop. The move follows a dollar advance and Federal Reserve officials' comments on a potential December interest-rate increase.

site_title: Train fault on North-South Line at around 6.30am on Monday
summary: A train fault on the North-South Line in Singapore caused a 20-minute delay on Monday morning, affecting travel from Yishun to Marina South Pier. Free bus services were provided from Newton to Marina Bay to compensate for the disruption, which has since been resolved.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise for 5th day on banks, Woolworth takeover talk
summary: Australian shares rose for a fifth consecutive session on Monday, driven by high-yielding bank stocks and persistent takeover rumors surrounding Woolworths, sending the S&P/ASX 200 index up 21.9 points or 0.4% to 5,278.0 points. Bank stocks, including Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Westpac Banking Corp, led the gains, while Woolworths shares rose 3.8% amid takeover reports. Mining stocks fell, and energy stocks were mixed despite a weaker oil price.

site_title: Former South Korean president Kim Young-sam dies at 87
summary: Former South Korean President Kim Young-sam, 87, died on November 22, 2015, due to septicemia and heart failure. He served as president from 1993 to 1998, introducing landmark reforms aimed at transparency in financial transactions and purging politicized generals. Kim was a key figure in South Korea's transition from dictatorship to democracy, but his term was marked by missed opportunities and criticism, including a failed bailout of the country's economy and corruption charges against his son.

site_title: Don't change your holiday plans: US Homeland Security
summary: US Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson urges Americans not to change their holiday plans despite the recent Paris terror attack, stating there's no specific credible intelligence about a threat to the homeland. Johnson encourages public events, travel, and family gatherings, citing the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade in New York City as a safe and secure event. However, officials express concerns about potential copycat homegrown violent extremism and the use of "dark" communications by extremists.

site_title: Nuclear and renewable: South Africa's ambitious new energy mix
summary: South Africa aims to diversify its energy mix, shifting away from coal-fired electricity. Solar and wind energy plants are expanding, while the government plans to expand nuclear power. However, coal is expected to remain a significant source of energy. The country's efforts are part of an effort to address frequent power cuts that have hindered its economy.

images.alt_text: Cranes sit beside the Medupi power station in Lephalale.

site_title: Asia: Shares steady, euro under pressure as ECB seen easing next week
summary: Asian shares remained steady on Monday, influenced by the prospect of the European Central Bank's potential policy easing next week. The euro was under pressure due to the expected stimulus measures, benefiting the US dollar. Meanwhile, the head of the ECB, Mario Draghi, hinted at fresh stimulus at the Dec 3 policy meeting. South Korea's main index gained 0.2%, while the MSCI Asia-Pacific index outside Japan was flat.

site_title: Nearly 80 bodies pulled from landslide at Myanmar jade mine
summary: Nearly 80 bodies have been recovered from a landslide at a jade mine in Myanmar's northern Kachin State, with an estimated 100 people still missing. The landslide occurred in the early hours in Hpakant, a region known for producing high-quality jade. Many workers, mostly migrants, toil in hazardous conditions for low pay. Rescue efforts continue to search for the missing, with officials stating that nearly 80 bodies have been pulled from the collapsed dump.

site_title: Which country creates 4,000 new businesses a day? China
summary: China is re-inventing itself as the next Startup Nation, spawning 4,000 new businesses a day. Since 2010, the country has doubled its startups to 1,609,700 in 2014, with the UK lagging behind. Under President Xi Jinping, China aims to shift its economy from investment-driven exports to consumer spending and services, with subsidies and venture capital financing promoting Internet, technology, and innovation. Despite concerns over high valuations, China's entrepreneurial spirit is on the rise, with Alibaba Group's chairman Jack Ma setting the pace for aspiring Chinese billionaires.

site_title: Sinarmas Land ramps up overseas expansion
summary: Sinarmas Land, majority owned by Indonesia's Widjaja family, is expanding its overseas presence by targeting London and continental Europe for commercial assets. The company aims to boost its international portfolio and recurring income, with a target of 20% of total revenue from abroad within three to five years. Sinarmas Land has already acquired several Grade-A office buildings in London, with a focus on under-rented or under-managed properties. The company also continues to accumulate land in Indonesia, with plans to launch new residential projects, despite a slowdown in demand.

site_title: Pro-market Macri wins Argentina presidency: exit polls
summary: Mauricio Macri, a pro-market leader, won Argentina's presidential runoff vote, according to exit polls. Macri, 56, defeated his left-wing rival Daniel Scioli, marking the end of 12 years of leftist government. Macri's victory promises to free up trade, liberalize the economy, and negotiate with foreign debtors, breaking the grip of Peronism in Argentine politics. Official results are due, but cheering crowds of Macri's supporters celebrated at his rally, with many expressing optimism about the future.

site_title: Hot stock: NOL shares rise on sale talks with France's CMA CGM
summary: Neptune Orient Lines Ltd (NOL) shares rose 4.5% after its controlling shareholder, Temasek Holdings, entered into exclusive sale talks with CMA CGM, the world's third-largest container shipping firm. Temasek, which owns nearly 67% of NOL, agreed to the deal until Dec 7. The move follows a surge in NOL shares over 39% this year on acquisition talks.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of Neptune Orient Lines Ltd. (NOL) stand in Singapore, on Friday, Mar 19, 2010.

site_title: US pushes China on market access, little progress seen
summary: US Trade Secretary Michael Froman urged China to liberalize its market access regulations, but progress appears unlikely due to tensions over cyber hacking and a bilateral investment treaty. China has repeatedly pledged to ease restrictions but regulators issued a broad negative list of prohibited industries. US experts say Chinese hackers continue to target US firms despite a September agreement to prevent corporate secret theft. The talks ended with few breakthroughs, but various memorandums of understanding were signed, including a US$1 billion investment in a US pulp mill.

site_title: Why American landlords love refugee tenants
summary: US landlords are finding that renting to refugees can be a stable business, with 80% of tenants in one Cleveland property being refugees. The resettlement process, which can take 18-24 months, often relies on landlords renting to tenants sight-unseen, with minimal credit checks. Refugees receive a one-time stipend to cover initial expenses, and resettlement agencies provide job placement support and private funds to help tenants. Advocates argue that refugees are reliable tenants who stay in apartments for long periods, making them a valuable asset to landlords.

site_title: Greek PM seeks 'national dialogue' on retirement reforms
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras called for a national dialogue on retirement reforms, aiming to create a just and viable system. This comes after his government narrowly passed a bailout reform vote, weakening its majority. Tsipras plans to develop his own reform plan and engage with all political powers and social stakeholders. The government's move is seen as a step towards addressing the country's economic challenges and implementing further reforms, including those in the education system and constitution.

site_title: High costs shackle green carbon capture technology
summary: A crucial green technology, carbon capture and storage (CCS), is hindered by high costs, making it difficult to implement on a large scale. CCS can remove CO2 from power plants and steel mills, preventing global warming. However, only a handful of projects are in service, and experts estimate over 1,000 are needed to meet climate goals. The technology's hefty price tag, estimated to require a 70% larger infrastructure than the global crude oil industry, has kept investors away, delaying the development of a massive new industry to capture and store 20% of the world's CO2 emissions.

site_title: Major indices looking to December Fed meeting for directions
summary: Major US stock indices are awaiting the December Federal Reserve meeting for policy directions, with a potential rate hike expected to shape the remainder of 2015. Despite a rally last week, the market remains flat for the year, and a new policy is likely to be announced before Christmas unless a global market shock occurs. The US dollar's strength is expected to continue, impacting earnings and sector performance, particularly in commodities and multinational manufacturers.

site_title: Belgian police mount raids in Brussels and other towns
summary: Belgian police launched raids across Brussels and other towns on Sunday, following a lockdown announcement by Prime Minister Charles Michel, who feared a new Paris-style mass attack. The raids targeted possible targets such as malls, shopping streets, and public transport, with several arrests reported. The threat level in Brussels remained at four, indicating an imminent attack, while the rest of the country was placed at level three. The government has boosted police and army presence, with measures including the closure of the metro, universities, and schools, and a call for citizens to avoid crowds.

images.alt_text: Police arrive for an operation in Brussels, Belgium on Nov 22, 2015.

site_title: Paris attacks: Police release photo of 3rd stadium suicide bomber
summary: French police released a photo of the third suicide bomber who detonated outside France's national stadium during the November 13 Paris attacks, killing one person. The bomber, identified as Mohammad al-Mahmod, had a Syrian passport and was among seven attackers in a wave of coordinated strikes that left 130 dead and 350 wounded. The other two bombers were identified as Bilal Hadfi, 20, and an unidentified attacker who was also a refugee on the Greek island of Leros. Investigators continue to hunt for Salah Abdeslam, suspected of fleeing the scene and heading to Belgium.

images.alt_text: This undated and unlocated image shows French national Bilal Hadfi, 20, one of the suicide bombers who blew himself outside the Stade de France stadium during the Paris attacks on Nov 13.
