The firm plans to help the company's founder, Aloysius Lim, exit the business by giving it a fresh breath of life. Shaw Kwei believes that the growing number of first-generation Asian manufacturing entrepreneurs are seeking an exit, driven by demographic changes such as aging founders with fewer children and a desire for alternative careers. The firm aims to capture this opportunity and generate returns, although it has yet to exit any of its majority investments.

site_title: Shining a light on the impact of giving
summary: Entrepreneur Alexandre Mars has founded the Epic Foundation, a non-profit organization aiming to create tools for monitoring the impact of donations to charities supporting children and young people up to age 24. Mars' inspiration for the foundation came from his wife's work with Mother Teresa's organization. The Epic app, launched at the Credit Suisse Philanthropists Forum, allows donors to track the impact of their donations, providing transparency and immediacy to philanthropy. Mars' goal is to connect people with big hearts, skills, and money to social organizations tackling youth issues, changing the mindset about doing good.

images.alt_text: Mr Mars, 39, picked up his mother's devotion to humanity as a child, and was later inspired by his wife's work with the Missionaries of Charity, an organisation set up by the late Mother Teresa.

site_title: Poiz Residences in Potong Pasir may be launched at S$1,380 psf
summary: MCC Land is set to launch The Poiz Residences in Singapore with approximately 40-50% of its 731 units available for sale at a starting price of S$1,380 per square foot (psf). The mixed-use project includes retail component The Poiz Centre, connected to the adjacent Potong Pasir MRT station. MCC Land's managing director, Tan Zhiyong, hopes to sell more than 40% of the units during the launch weekend, citing attractive pricing and government-moderated land sales.

site_title: Nursing home provider rides the silver tsunami
summary: Orange Valley, a Singapore-based nursing home provider, is riding the "silver tsunami" of an aging population to become the largest nursing home operator in the country. With six locations and over 1,000 beds, the company aims to focus on growth and improving quality of care. Following the introduction of enhanced nursing home standards, Orange Valley has reviewed and improved its systems, passing all licensing audits with zero findings. The company is also exploring new models of care, such as the "Eden" concept, and is looking at opportunities in the overseas market, particularly in China.

site_title: Helping lives in the Coral Triangle
summary: The Tahija Foundation, founded by Indonesian businessman George Tahija, is a philanthropic organization that works alongside his family's businesses. The foundation has launched initiatives to eradicate dengue in Yogjakarta and the Coral Triangle Center (CTC), which trains marine resource managers and educates coastal communities. The CTC has conducted over 130 training sessions, educating 2,500 professionals, and aims to measure success through output, outcome, and impact. The foundation views philanthropy as equally important to its business operations, aiming to contribute to the well-being of the communities where its family business operates.

site_title: Tapping overseas markets for growth
summary: Singaporean SMEs are tapping into overseas markets to boost growth amid rising costs and manpower constraints. Three companies, IPS Group, Moveon Technologies, and Hotel Royal Limited, shared their experiences expanding abroad. Challenges include adapting to local culture and regulations, managing foreign exchange risk, and retaining key employees. Banker support is crucial in navigating these complexities. SMEs are advised to conduct thorough market research, set clear goals and vision, and invest in employee training and retention. Leveraging productivity and innovation, such as automation and employee knowledge enhancement, is also key to staying competitive in a dynamic business environment.

site_title: Celebrating the future-ready at this year's E50 Awards
summary: The Enterprise 50 (E50) awards in Singapore recognized 50 local businesses for their future-readiness, with a focus on the sharing economy, disintermediation through technology, and open innovation. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran emphasized the importance of building broader partnerships to leverage strengths and drive growth. The top-ranked company, Rotating Offshore Solutions, demonstrated success through diversification and innovation, while others expanded into foreign markets and adopted digital disruption strategies to gain a competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Smart technology makes its mark in preschools
summary: House of Kids, a Singapore-based preschool, has implemented a preschool management system called LittleLives to streamline its administrative tasks and improve communication with parents. The system allows teachers to manage daily tasks efficiently, receive real-time updates on attendance and child activities, and provide parents with daily check-in and check-out photos and learning progress. The system has enabled the preschool to save time and improve productivity, while also reducing paper wastage and costs. The school has reported positive results, citing the benefits of using technology in preschool management and expressing hopes for future government grants to support small and medium-sized enterprises.

images.alt_text: House of Kids principal Josephine Cheong leverages technology to help run the preschool.

In addition to administrative reports, the system allows House of Kids to provide parents with a range of updates, including the daily check-in and check-out photos of their children and a portfolio management folder where parents can find out what their child has learnt via videos and photos.

site_title: M&L Hospitality acquires new hotel site in Sydney
summary: M&L Hospitality, a Singapore-based real estate investment group, has acquired a hotel development site in Sydney, set to open in Q4 2017. The 65 Sussex Street project will be its 16th hotel worldwide, increasing its Sydney portfolio to over 1,000 hotel rooms and 16 hotels globally.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tiger 'brewed by the sun', as APB takes solar plunge in Singapore
summary: ASIA Pacific Breweries (APB) Singapore has installed solar panels on its factory rooftop, making all Tiger beer consumed in the Republic "brewed by the sun". The 25-year project, Heineken's first solar installation in the Asia-Pacific and largest worldwide, reduces APB's carbon footprint by a fifth and generates 2.3 million kWh of clean energy annually. The project follows Apple's announcement to power all Singapore operations with solar energy from January.

site_title: French MPs vote to extend state of emergency by 3 months
summary: French MPs voted to extend a state of emergency in the country for three months following the devastating jihadist attacks in Paris, which left 129 people dead. The state of emergency was announced by President Francois Hollande shortly after the attacks.

site_title: Macau casinos still a good bet despite slump
summary: Macau casinos are expected to continue as a good investment despite a 17-month slump, with new projects earmarked for US$28 billion in spending over three years. Operators aim to broaden appeal to families and tourists, and placate the Chinese government on corruption. New projects are predicted to return an average of 21% three years after opening, compared to 50% during the peak in 2013-2014. While risks remain high, analysts see the gaming sector as a good long-term investment with high cash returns and high dividends.

site_title: Fed says US economy strong enough for rate increase
summary: The Federal Reserve policy makers have signaled that it "may well become appropriate" to raise the benchmark lending rate in December, with a gradual pace of increases, according to the minutes of the October meeting. The US economy has been strong, with encouraging data, including a 271,000 jobs added in October and unemployment at 5%. Most Fed officials expect to raise interest rates this year for the first time since 2006, with some estimating that conditions necessary for tightening policy have already been met.

site_title: Weakening inflation expectation may give BOJ scope for further easing
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) Policy Board maintained monetary policy unchanged despite Japan's economy slipping into recession for the second time in a year. However, the board hinted at the possibility of further easing, citing weakening inflation expectations. The BOJ stuck to its assessment that the economy is recovering "moderately," while core consumer price inflation remains at zero. The decision was seen as positive for Tokyo stock prices, which rose to a three-month closing high. The BOJ's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, defended the central bank's target of achieving 2% inflation, citing underlying consumer price inflation of 1.2% and a possible delay in oil price increases.

site_title: Tan Swie Hian scores a first
summary: Singapore artist Tan Swie Hian's work "Pandas" is set to be auctioned by Christie's in Hong Kong, marking the first time one of his pieces is being sold by the international auction house. The 1993 ink-and-acrylic work on rice paper is estimated to fetch between US$64,100 and US$89,700. This sale is significant as it breaks into the Chinese market dominated by big-name Chinese artists, and is part of Christie's Autumn auction in Hong Kong to mark Singapore's golden jubilee.

site_title: PM Lee urges Asia-Pac nations to form region-wide free trade zone
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Asia-Pacific nations to form a region-wide free trade zone, citing the recent completion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and the upcoming launch of the Asean Economic Community. He praised the Pacific Alliance's efforts to deepen market integration and encouraged Apec economies to work towards a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) with the ongoing study on the initiative. Lee emphasized the importance of cooperation in services liberalization to deepen economic integration.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Coming out of Jumbo's shell
summary: Jumbo Seafood, a Singaporean seafood-focused restaurant group, has set its sights on regional and global expansion. Following its initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board, which was eight times subscribed, the company plans to further expand in China, targeting the mass market with lower labor costs and rental costs. Managing human capital remains a priority, with initiatives such as scholarships, staff referrals, and comfortable accommodation for foreign workers. Jumbo Seafood aims to inspire others in the F&B industry to follow a similar path to growth, with CEO Ang Kiam Meng expressing hope that the company's IPO will contribute to Singapore's food culture.

site_title: Worthy of a three-fingered salute
summary: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 concludes the series with Katniss Everdeen leading a rebellion against the Capitol. The film ties up loose ends, including the fate of Katniss's love interests, Gale and Peeta, and the assassination of President Snow. The movie follows Katniss as she navigates the aftermath of the war, with some scenes feeling rushed. Despite this, the film provides a satisfying conclusion to the series, cementing Katniss's status as a symbol of resistance and inspiration.

site_title: Singapore corporates' USD bonds warmly received by international investors
summary: Singaporean corporations' US dollar-denominated bonds have been warmly received by international investors, with two benchmark issues from SP Powerassets and Stats ChipPac selling well and Citic Envirotech Ltd's USD perpetual deal closing early at US$950 million. Strong demand from investors such as insurance and pension funds, banks, and funds has driven the success of these deals, with US and Asia investors accounting for 43% of the total. The strong reception is attributed to the diversification from China-based issuers and the larger size of the USD market.

site_title: S$112m boost for digital drive by Singapore petrochem sector
summary: A Japanese firm, Yokogawa Engineering Asia, has opened its first co-innovation centre in Singapore, investing S$112 million to develop technologies that apply Big Data to industrial automation systems. The centre aims to improve planning, predictability, and operational effectiveness in the oil and gas, chemical, and petrochemical industries. Yokogawa's clients in the region face challenges in enhancing plant availability, reliability, and safety. The centre will work with clients and IT companies to develop technologies that can process large amounts of data and improve manufacturing processes.

images.alt_text: Plans to digitise operations on Jurong Island so as to prepare the local petrochemical industry for the future of manufacturing received another boost on Thursday when Japanese firm Yokogawa Engineering Asia opened in Singapore its first co-innovation centre worldwide.

site_title: Chinese are buying gold due to lack of investment options
summary: Chinese investors, seeking safe-haven assets due to economic uncertainty, are buying gold in large quantities. Despite a global decline in gold prices, China's demand has surged, with imports from Hong Kong reaching a 19-month high in September. The country's central bank has also been accumulating gold reserves, and investors are turning to gold as a hedge against a weakening yuan and volatile stock market. China's gold consumption may exceed 1,000 tonnes this year, surpassing India's estimated purchases.

site_title: Fiabci-Singapore gives out 28 awards
summary: The Singapore chapter of Fiabci awarded 28 projects in 10 categories at the 2015 Singapore Property Awards. Far East Organization clinched the most awards with four, while Soilbuild Group Holdings secured three. The winners will be eligible for the Fiabci Prix d'Excellence international competition in May 2016, and the awards aim to promote architectural innovation and excellence in Singapore's property sector.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US fantasy sports crackdown may hurt TV advertising growth
summary: A US crackdown on daily fantasy sports sites may hinder TV advertising growth. The industry, dominated by FanDuel and DraftKings, accounted for 60% of the increase in ad sales last quarter, totaling $134 million. However, regulators are suing the companies, arguing they're a form of illegal gambling, and a Manhattan judge will decide their fate on November 25. This could lead to a decrease in ad spending and impact ratings, particularly for NFL network partners.

images.alt_text: The future growth of television advertising could be hobbled by a crackdown on one of its big contributors: daily fantasy sports sites.

site_title: Asian stocks up on Fed position to hike rates gradually
summary: Asian stocks rose 1.6% to 133.57, driven by the Federal Reserve's indication of a gradual rate hike, which investors view as a positive sign for the world's biggest economy. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index has rallied 10% from its two-year low in September. Japan's Topix index advanced 0.9%, while South Korea's Kospi and New Zealand's NZX 50 Indexes rose 1.3% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: More economies keen to join TPP but that will take years: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore stated that several economies, including South Korea, Indonesia, and the Philippines, are interested in joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade pact, but it will likely take years before new invitations are sent out. Lee believes it will be "several years down the road at the very earliest" for new members to join. The priority now is to sign the document, with a signing ceremony possible in New Zealand next February, followed by the difficult ratification process.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after Fed minutes, jobs data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday after minutes from the Federal Reserve's October meeting indicated a December interest rate hike, and jobless claims data showed a decline. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.03%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.08%. These gains came despite ongoing trade uncertainty and split views on the Fed's intentions.

site_title: Mastermind of Paris attacks died in police raid: prosecutor
summary: The body of Abdelhamid Abaaoud, the suspected mastermind of the Paris attacks, has been identified among those killed in a police raid in a northern Paris suburb on Wednesday. Abaaoud, a Belgian jihadist and top Islamic State commander, was thought to be behind France's deadliest terror attacks last Friday. His body was identified using fingerprints.

images.alt_text: The body of the suspected mastermind of the Paris attacks, Abdelhamid Abaaoud, has been identified among those killed in a police raid, the prosecutor's office said Thursday.

site_title: Risk of inflation target miss increased: ECB minutes
summary: The European Central Bank's minutes revealed that the risk of missing its inflation target has increased due to disappointing government reform efforts and a lack of momentum in the Juncker Plan. Current measures may not be sufficient, and the bank may need to take more forceful action or acknowledge its inability to meet the objective. The Governing Council is divided on the issue, with some members calling for a broader set of tools to achieve the inflation target.

site_title: EU countries to agree on tighter passport checks: draft document
summary: EU interior ministers are set to agree on tighter passport checks at the external borders of the Schengen area in response to the Paris attacks, a draft document reveals. The new proposal would upgrade existing controls to include checks against criminal and security databases. This move aims to boost security and strengthen the external borders of the 26-nation Schengen area, excluding Britain, Ireland, Croatia, Cyprus, Romania, and Bulgaria. The agreement is expected to be implemented immediately.

site_title: Jurong Country Club to submit compensation claim on Nov 25
summary: Jurong Country Club, slated as the future terminus for the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail, will submit a compensation claim on November 25. The 67ha site will be valued by the club and submitted to the Collector of Land Revenue.

site_title: S&P 500 cash hoards are playing havoc with measures of valuation
summary: The US stock market's high valuation is partly due to companies' large cash hoards, which distort valuation measures. Credit Suisse analysts estimate that if excess cash were eliminated, the S&P 500 Index would be valued at its historical average, rather than its current high multiple of 18.6 times earnings. This excess cash, totaling $1.5 trillion, reduces companies' return on invested capital and makes them seem more expensive than they are, according to analysts.

site_title: US jobless claims, continuing claims decline
summary: US jobless claims fell to a seasonally adjusted 271,000 for the week ended Nov 14, marking 37 consecutive weeks below the 300,000 threshold, a level associated with a healthy job market. This decline suggests a robust labor market.

site_title: Businesses here see prospects at lowest since financial crisis
summary: Businesses in Singapore report the worst performance since the 2008 global financial crisis, with sales, profits, and new orders plummeting in the third quarter. Companies project a 0.5% to 1.4% GDP expansion or contraction for the last quarter of the year, indicating widespread pessimism. The Business Times-UniSIM Business Climate Survey found a net balance of -65% for business prospects, the lowest since 2008, with 61% decline in sales, 55% in profits, and 57% in new orders. Worsening global conditions, particularly China's economic slowdown, have contributed to the decline.

site_title: United to let travellers use miles for in-flight W ifi
summary: United Airlines plans to allow travellers to redeem frequent-flier miles for in-flight Wi-Fi on flights, starting with a web portal testing phase. The feature aims to roll out to most US domestic flights by early 2016 and international flights by mid-summer. Regional jets will be installed later. This move makes United the first US carrier to offer this service, providing customers with an alternative way to access the internet during flights.

site_title: M&L Hospitality acquires hotel development site in Sydney
summary: M&L Hospitality, a Singapore-based real estate investment group, has acquired a hotel development site in Sydney. The 65 Sussex Street site, close to Four Points by Sheraton Sydney and Barangaroo, will increase the company's portfolio to over 1,000 hotel rooms and 16 hotels globally. Development is planned to begin by the first quarter of next year, with completion expected by the fourth quarter of 2017.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: British retail sales fall after surge
summary: British retail sales declined by 0.6% in October, ahead of the Christmas shopping season, according to official data. This marks a reversal from the 1.7% surge in September, which was driven by the Rugby World Cup. The October drop was slightly lower than analysts' forecast of a 0.5% decline. The decline in retail sales is a fresh blow to the UK economy, which has already shrunk for the second month.

site_title: How to stand out in the marketplace
summary: Singapore companies must differentiate themselves through innovation, branding, and intellectual property management to stand out in the marketplace and gain a competitive edge. The government has introduced initiatives such as Collaborative Industry Projects, Capability Development Grant, and Innovation & Capability Voucher to support small and medium-sized enterprises. Companies like Adonis International and Greenology have successfully implemented these strategies, increasing their profitability and productivity. Protecting intellectual property is also crucial to maintaining competitive advantage, with companies like Action implementing IP portfolio management systems to track and manage their assets.

site_title: UK manufacturers expect lower output for 1st time in 3 years: CBI
summary: UK manufacturers expect a decline in output for the first time in three years, according to a CBI survey. The expectation for manufacturing output over the next three months worsened to -6 from +5 in October, with the chemicals, mechanical engineering, and metal manufacture sectors driving the decline. This marks the first prediction of a fall since November 2012.

site_title: Unique model in the private education sector
summary: Singapore's oldest not-for-profit professional institute, the Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS), is celebrating its 60th year. Founded in 1956, MDIS has expanded aggressively overseas, opening campuses in Tashkent, Malaysia, and Chennai, India. The institute has a unique business model, reinvesting profits into infrastructure and curriculum development. Its courses are offered in collaboration with universities from Australia, France, and the US. MDIS has turned its fortunes around under the leadership of R Theyvendran, who has implemented a culture of innovation and improvement. The institute plans to launch its 60th anniversary book and aims to expand its international awards and recognition.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 3.56 points to 1,660.06. The index saw a trading volume of 3.43 billion lots valued at RM2.12 billion, with 502 gainers outnumbering 425 losers.

site_title: Asian businesses on the prowl for acquisitions
summary: Asian businesses are increasingly active in acquiring assets in the US, driven by a growing appetite for M&A transactions. A JP Morgan survey found that 88% of Asian corporations identified as net buyers, with regional banks and Chinese businesses leading the charge. This has lifted M&A volume from Asia-Pacific to 30% of global volume, exceeding the past decade's proportion of 10%. Asian companies are seeking to expand products and services, bolster technology, and manage operations, with a focus on strategic thinking and long-term investment horizons.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Demand for temporary staff in Singapore has surged to its highest in three years due to companies meeting year-end deadlines. International investors are also seeking Singapore corporates' US dollar-denominated bonds, with two benchmark issues selling well. A report found 35% of cyber attacks in South-east Asia originated from the entertainment/media/hospitality industry. The Singapore Exchange is launching SGX-listed FX block futures. The Straits Times Index rebounded 1.17% on a Wall Street rally, but low trading volume persists.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality launches second Tianjin property
summary: Frasers Hospitality has launched its second serviced residence in Tianjin, China, with the 192-unit Fraser Place Tianjin. The property is located in the city's prime entertainment district, adjacent to the Olympic Stadium Centre. This marks Frasers Hospitality's 15th property in China and its 30th in the country by 2019. The company aims to double its presence in China by 2019, with a global portfolio of 132 properties and over 21,000 keys worldwide. CEO Choe Peng Sum expressed confidence in China's continued growth as an economic powerhouse.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says buy dollar, US 'breakevens' as top trades
summary: Goldman Sachs recommends buying the US dollar against the euro and yen, citing a divergence between the Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan. The bank expects the US 10-year break-even rate to jump to 2 percentage points, creating an opportunity to capitalize on expectations. Goldman also advises buying Mexico's peso and Russia's rouble against South Africa's rand and Chile's peso. The US dollar has risen against all major peers this year, and the bank sees the dollar as having more room to appreciate against the euro and yen.

site_title: Is fintech just full of froth?
summary: Fintech, short for financial technology, is a vast space that encompasses various financial transactions, including banking, payments, and investments. The interest in fintech stems from perceived inefficiencies in the financial services system, such as high fees and poor user experience. Many fintech startups claim to be revolutionizing the financial system with blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. However, upon closer inspection, some startups appear to be lacking a clear understanding of their business proposition and revenue streams. To avoid investing in "froth," stakeholders should ask fundamental questions about the product or service's value proposition and potential market demand.

site_title: Sharp may shut remaining overseas TV plants: exec
summary: Sharp Corp may shut its remaining overseas TV plants in China and Malaysia, but still expects its TV operations to turn profitable next year, according to a company executive. The company is considering restructuring measures, including the sale of its Mexican plant to China's Hisense Group. Sharp's digital information appliance division, which includes TVs, is likely to swing to a profit in the fiscal year starting April due to strong demand for 4K ultra-high definition TV sets in Japan. The division previously forecast an operating loss of 13 billion yen for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Euromoney appoints executive chairman Rashbass as CEO
summary: Euromoney Institutional Investor Plc has appointed executive chairman Andrew Rashbass as CEO, effective immediately. Rashbass joined Euromoney from Thomson Reuters Corp in October and initiated a strategic review of the company's business and corporate structure. As part of the review, the board agreed to make the chairman role non-executive and create the position of chief executive.

site_title: Saudi says oil price slump should not stop investment
summary: Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi urged sustained investment in new oil output capacity, despite the 50% slump in global prices since mid-last year. He predicted a 1 million barrel-per-day increase in global demand, requiring 5 million barrels-per-day in new production to meet demand. Al-Naimi emphasized the need for large investments to meet these needs, as excess supplies are expected to last well into 2016.

site_title: Singapore Exchange's senior tech executive departing: sources
summary: Singapore Exchange's executive vice president Bob Caisley is leaving the company after nearly eight years, citing personal and professional reasons. He will be replaced by Tinku Gupta. Caisley's departure comes after the bourse suffered trading disruptions and was rebuked by the regulator. The company had previously invested S$20 million to improve its technology. Caisley's relocation to Europe marks a significant change for the company, following a period of challenges in trading volume and regulatory issues.

site_title: Credit Suisse's Thiam asks investors to support capital increase
summary: Credit Suisse's CEO Tidjane Thiam asked investors to support a US$6 billion capital increase to meet tougher regulatory requirements. The bank plans to raise 1.32 billion Swiss francs through a direct placement and up to 4.7 billion francs through a public offering. This move aims to help Credit Suisse meet future regulatory capital adequacy requirements and implement its strategic plans.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse group chief executive officer Tidjane Thiam asked investors for permission to tap them for about US$6 billion in equity.

site_title: Hot stock: Raffles Education tumbles 8.6 per cent as CEO offloads to meet SIC terms
summary: Raffles Education Corporation shares plummeted 8.6% after CEO Chew Hua Seng sold 1 million shares to meet Securities Industry Council (SIC) terms. The sale reduced Chew's stake to 36.57% in the company. Trading had been suspended since October.

images.alt_text: Chew Hua Seng, Founder, Chairman & CEO, Raffles Education Corp.

site_title: Indonesia to put off executions due to economic slowdown
summary: Indonesia has postponed planned executions due to its economic slowdown, according to Coordinating Security Minister Luhut Pandjaitan. The country has executed 14 drug offenders this year, straining relations with several countries. Indonesia's economy expanded 4.73% in the third quarter, slightly faster than the previous quarter. The decision to postpone executions was made without explanation, and no new date has been set for the next round of executions.

site_title: Hot stock: Spackman's counter marches up
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's shares surged 9.4% to S$0.151, with over 112 million shares traded, making it the most active counter on Thursday. The company's shares have been on an upward trend for the past month. This comes as the broader market rallies ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, investors remain positive, with stocks extending their rally.

site_title: Ringgit rises most in a month as oil advance brightens outlook
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 1% to 4.3440 a dollar, its largest gain in a month, due to rebounding oil prices and a gradual pace of US interest-rate increases. Oil stockpiles in Saudi Arabia fell, boosting the outlook for Malaysia, which is Asia's only net exporter of oil. The Federal Reserve indicated it will raise rates next month, but at a guarded pace, supporting the ringgit's strength. This is Malaysia's best performance in over a week.

site_title: Oil prices up on France IS strikes, stockpiles data
summary: Oil prices rose in Asian trade on Thursday as Europe struck back against the Islamic State (IS) group after the Paris attacks, lifting confidence and fueling crude prices. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 25 cents to $41.00, while Brent crude for January increased 39 cents to $44.53. The market is closely monitoring geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and expectations of a US interest rate hike in December. A modest rise in US commercial crude stockpiles also supported prices.

site_title: Indonesia plans to issue global bonds in Dec to help fund 2016 budget: official
summary: Indonesia plans to issue global bonds in December to help fund its 2016 budget, according to a Finance Ministry official. The bonds are expected to be sold early in the month to avoid missing the window. The official declined to specify the issuance size, but stated it wouldn't be too large. This move comes after Indonesia raised $4 billion in US dollar bonds in January this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump on US rate talk
summary: Tokyo stocks rose over 1% on Thursday, driven by solid US market gains and minutes from the Federal Reserve showing increased confidence in the US economy. The yen strengthened against the dollar after the Bank of Japan decided not to increase monetary stimulus despite the country's recession. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,859.81, while the Topix index gained 0.87%.

site_title: VW to add 10 new locally produced SUV models in China by 2020
summary: Volkswagen AG plans to introduce 10 new locally produced SUV models in China by 2020 to address the gap in its product offerings in the country's fast-growing market. The move comes as the company seeks to capitalize on China's critical importance for its business, following the fallout from its emissions-cheating scandal. VW also aims to introduce 15 locally produced new-energy vehicles in the next three to five years in China and add 30,000 Chinese employees by 2019.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG said it will add 10 new locally produced SUV models to China by 2020, increasing its offerings in the fastest growing vehicle segment of its largest market.

site_title: LG Electronics to develop own mobile payment system
summary: LG Electronics signed an agreement to develop its own mobile payment service called LG Pay, in partnership with Shinhan Card and KB Kookmin Card. The service will be available on all LG smartphones, unlike Samsung Pay which is limited to certain models. No specific technology or timeline was disclosed. This move enters the crowded mobile payment market, following similar initiatives by Apple and Samsung Electronics.

site_title: Taiwan's Ma seeks corporate tax breaks in push to boost wages
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou is seeking corporate tax breaks to boost wages and address income stagnation, as the country faces economic challenges due to China's slowdown. Ma aims to encourage companies to increase wages, and has ruled out changing the exchange rate to support exports. He has also highlighted a trade deal with China to open up services, despite domestic opposition, and emphasized the importance of engaging with China for economic benefits.

site_title: Cosco Dalian to cancel construction of one bulk carrier, build two oil tankers
summary: Cosco Dalian Shipyard has agreed to cancel the construction of one 82,000-dwt bulk carrier originally scheduled for delivery in the third quarter of 2016. This decision comes after a request from the shipowner. The shipyard was contracted to build two units of the same vessel for a European company, but will now focus on building two oil tankers instead.

site_title: Singapore corporates' USD bonds warmly received by international investors
summary: Singapore corporates' US dollar-denominated bonds have received strong demand from international investors. The Citic Envirotech Ltd USD perpetual deal closed early at US$950 million, exceeding its issue size five times. This is attributed to "preventing an allocation nightmare." DBS Bank's head of fixed income, Clifford Lee, commented on the early closing to manage demand. The strong demand highlights the interest of international investors in Singapore corporates' bond deals.

site_title: Match Group prices 33.3m shares at US$12 per share: source
summary: Match Group Inc, the owner of Tinder and other online dating services, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$12 per share, raising around US$400 million. The IPO was within the indicated US$12 to US$14 per share range.

site_title: Europe relies on 'queen' Merkel more than ever
summary: European Union leaders rely on German Chancellor Angela Merkel more than ever, 10 years after she took office, due to her trailblazing decisions on the Ukraine conflict and refugee crisis. Despite domestic weakening, Merkel's economic dominance and lack of rivals have earned her the nickname "Queen of Europe." Her leadership has helped keep Greece in the eurozone and navigated the EU through crises, solidifying her position as a key figure in European politics.

site_title: China: Stocks rise on small caps; property shares retreat
summary: China's stocks rose 1.6% to 3,774.97 on the CSI300 index, driven by a rebound in small-cap stocks and gains in the tech sector. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.4% to 3,617.06 points. Fund manager Wayne Shen attributed the rally to ample liquidity in the market, with investors returning to equities after fleeing to bonds during the summer stock market rout. However, property stocks retreated on profit-taking, while the tech sector led the gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on strength in US, China markets
summary: Hong Kong shares rose over 1% on Thursday, driven by a strong rally on Wall Street and a rebound in mainland Chinese markets. The Hang Seng index increased 1.4% to 22,500.22, while the China Enterprises Index also gained 1.4% to 10,193.11 points. The US Federal Reserve's minutes strengthened expectations for a rate hike in December, which is expected to have a positive impact on markets. Hong Kong stocks were seen as undervalued compared to their mainland peers, making them attractive targets for Chinese companies seeking growth.

site_title: Freddy Soon, former Hyflux exec and Spring Singapore deputy CEO, dies at 73
summary: Freddy Soon, a former Hyflux executive and Spring Singapore deputy CEO, has died at the age of 73. He was advisor to Hyflux's group CEO until his retirement two years ago. His death was sudden, and he was just days shy of his 74th birthday.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as on Fed economy confidence
summary: Asian markets rallied after minutes from the Federal Reserve showed growing confidence in the US economy, increasing the chances of a December interest rate hike. The minutes stated that "most participants" expected conditions to be right for a hike by the Fed's next meeting, citing improved job growth and price rises. This led to a surge in US stocks and a rise in emerging market currencies, with the dollar reaching a near three-year high. The rally also boosted higher-yielding currencies, including the South Korean won, Australian dollar, and Indonesian rupiah.

images.alt_text: A man walks past a panel displaying figures of China stock indexes and Hang Seng Index at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China in this Sept 2, 2015 file photo.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.6% to 6,313.77 points. The rebound follows gains across Asian and US indices, which were driven by minutes from the Federal Reserve's last policy meeting suggesting a likely US interest rate increase in December. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 advancing 0.9% and the Paris CAC 40 winning 0.8%.

site_title: Opec policy is right, oil price to start improving next year: UAE
summary: The United Arab Emirates' energy ministry stated that Opec's decision not to cut supplies last year was the right one, and oil prices are expected to start improving next year. Undersecretary Matar al-Nyadi believes that a correction in the market is possible in 2016, indicating a potential price increase. This statement suggests that Opec's strategy has yielded positive results, and oil prices are expected to rise in the coming year.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on positive note; Wall Street
summary: Australian shares rose 2.13% on Thursday, driven by a positive view on the Federal Reserve's October monetary meeting minutes. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 109.5 points to 5,242.6, with BHP Billiton shares rising 3.08% after maintaining a healthy balance sheet. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also rose 0.26%. The positive market sentiment was fueled by the Fed's suggested interest rate hike in December and confidence in the US economy's ability to absorb a rate rise.

site_title: SEA businesses, governments remain likely targets of cyber attacks: report
summary: Businesses and governments in South-east Asia remain vulnerable to cyber attacks, with 35% of attacks originating from the entertainment/media/hospitality industry and 25% from governments. Advanced persistent threat (APT) groups target media companies to shape public opinion and gain diplomatic and economic advantages. The region's rapid economic development and military spending contribute to the threat. Businesses face a 45% higher risk of targeted cyber attacks than the global average, with Thailand and the Philippines being the hardest hit.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Wall Street rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rebounded 33.75 points or 1.17% to 2,919.83 on Thursday, following an unexpected Wednesday rally on Wall Street. The rally was driven by the release of US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting minutes, which confirmed the start of interest rate hikes in December. The index was led by Singtel, banks, and CapitaLand, which rose 0.08 cents on volume of 12 million. Despite the rebound, brokers noted low trading volume, with only 1 billion units worth S$775.8 million traded.

site_title: SGX to launch SGX-listed FX block futures on EBS Market
summary: SGX has partnered EBS BrokerTec to launch SGX-listed FX block futures on EBS Market, a primary venue for e-traded currencies. The listed futures will be available in early Q2 2016, pending regulatory approval, and will include instruments in Indian rupee, South Korean won, offshore renminbi, Singapore dollar, and onshore renminbi. The collaboration aims to enhance liquidity and provide automated straight-through-processing for trades, with SGX's CEO Loh Boon Chye calling it a sign of commitment to innovate and grow the Asian currency futures market.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Demand for temp staff in Singapore soars to highest in three years: Robert Half
summary: Demand for temporary staff in Singapore has surged to its highest in three years, with 73% of firms increasing interim professionals and temporary staff, surpassing Hong Kong, Japan, and the UK. Accounting, finance, and banking professionals are in high demand, commanding top dollar due to a talent shortage between November and March. Mid-sized firms (250-499 employees) account for 80% of increased temporary staff and interim professionals, driven by the need to finalize accounts before year-end and kick-start new strategies.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Alibaba picks Gobi to manage US$130m Hong Kong startup fund
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has established a HK$1 billion (S$182 million) startup fund in Hong Kong, managed by Gobi Partners. The fund aims to support online and brick-and-mortar companies, offering internships to 200 students annually. Co-founder Jack Ma has emphasized the importance of entrepreneurship among youths and supporting small businesses in Hong Kong, which lags behind other markets in startup funding. The fund will judge investments based on merit, with local business leaders joining the board to support the initiative.

site_title: Hong Kong: Chinese stocks rise to one-week high as banks gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose to a one-week high, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index advancing 1.2% to 10,179.59, driven by gains in financial companies such as Industrial & Commercial Bank of China and China Construction Bank. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.3% as technology companies resumed their year-long rally. The Federal Reserve's minutes suggested a gradual pace of US rate increases, boosting global equities and bolstering China's export outlook.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysian shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.22 points to 1,658.72, driven by a significant increase in trading volume. A total of 217.4 million lots were traded, with 199 gainers and 60 losers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on eased US policy uncertainty
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.3% on Thursday, their largest daily gain in two months, following minutes from the US Federal Open Market Committee's October meeting that hinted at a potential interest rate increase. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,988.91 points. The won currency also rose 0.9% to 1,161.7 won per dollar. Despite offshore investors' net sales, the gains were driven by easing US policy uncertainty and expectations of future interest rate hikes.

site_title: Metals rout means struggling miners are even more unprofitable
summary: Global metal prices have hit new six-year lows, causing significant losses at mines. As of this month, an additional 500,000 metric tons of copper and 800,000 tons of zinc are unprofitable, with over two-thirds of mined nickel and 60% of aluminum production also losing money. The losses are attributed to a slowdown in top commodities user China and a 25% drop in the London Metal Exchange's index of six main contracts this year. Producers are expected to implement wholesale production cuts to trim the glut of metals, but some companies are willing to maintain output despite low prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 1.07%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.07% on November 19, 2015, as investors reacted to the Bank of Japan's unchanged monetary easing program. The Nikkei 225 and Topix indices increased by 210.63 and 13.85 points, respectively. The yen strengthened against the dollar, while global markets continued to trend upward, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Raffles Education CEO to sell 1 million shares when trading resumes
summary: Raffles Education CEO Chew Hua Seng plans to sell 1 million shares when trading resumes at 1:30pm. After the sale, he and his wife Doris Chung will collectively hold 356.08 million shares, representing a 36.57% stake. The shares were suspended pending a consultation with the Securities Industry Council regarding Chew's shareholding.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Pfizer 'near agreement' to buy Allergan for close to US$150b in biggest healthcare deal ever
summary: Pfizer is in advanced talks to buy Allergan for approximately $150 billion, making it the largest healthcare deal ever. The proposed deal, valued at $370-$380 per share, would strengthen Pfizer's brand-name drug business and potentially pave the way for an eventual split into two companies. The US Treasury Department's review of tax inversion deals could delay the final agreement, but a deal could be announced as soon as Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open up 1.03% following Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.03% in opening deals on Thursday, following Wall Street gains, amid rising expectations of a US interest rate hike next month. The Nikkei 225 index reached 19,851.24, while the Topix index rose 0.96%. The gains were driven by solid performances on US stock markets, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Police fire water cannon on protesters near Apec in Manila
summary: Police in Manila fired water cannons on protesters near the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, scuffling with demonstrators who criticized the Philippine government's ties to the US. The protesters, estimated to be around 1,000, waved placards and chanted slogans, prompting police to use reasonable force to disperse the crowd. Several police were injured, but the water cannon was not intended to cause injury. APEC leaders plan to condemn terrorism and urge cooperation against militancy, amid heightened security measures following deadly attacks in Paris and a recent hostage beheading in the southern Philippines.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally after Fed minutes
summary: Hong Kong shares rose over 1% in opening trade on Thursday following the release of Federal Reserve minutes showing increased confidence in the US economy. The Hang Seng Index increased 1.06%, while Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices also edged up. The positive sentiment was attributed to the Fed's more optimistic outlook, boosting investor confidence and lifting Asian markets.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.93% higher on Thursday after Wall Street rises
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.93% on Thursday, following a gain on Wall Street, as investors awaited a potential Federal Reserve rate hike in December. The Straits Times Index reached 2,912.99 points, with 36.6 million shares traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 30. The move follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: First Reit to acquire stake in Indonesian hospital and mall for S$70m
summary: First Reit, a Singaporean real estate investment trust (Reit), has agreed to acquire a stake in Siloam Hospitals Kupang and Lippo Plaza Kupang in Indonesia for S$70 million. The acquisition will expand First Reit's portfolio to 17 properties across Indonesia, Singapore, and South Korea, boosting its total asset size by 6.84%. The deal is expected to enhance the trust's income stream with a triple net rental yield of 9.91%.

images.alt_text: Mr Ronnie Tan, chief executive officer (CEO) of Bowspirit Capital Corporation Limited, which manages First REIT.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-week high on Wall Street strength
summary: Australian shares rose 1.5% to a two-week high on Thursday, driven by Wall Street's gains after the Federal Reserve indicated that US interest rates may increase in December without causing a market reaction. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,209.9, its highest level in two weeks, and is on track for its best weekly performance since October 9.

site_title: Update: Diller's Match Group raises US$400m in online-dating IPO
summary: Match Group, the parent company of online-dating sites Tinder, Match, and OkCupid, raised US$400 million in its initial public offering (IPO), pricing the shares at US$12 each. This gives the company a market value of approximately US$2.9 billion. The shares will start trading on the Nasdaq Stock Market under the symbol MTCH, providing public investors with a direct stake in the company. This is one of the largest tech IPOs this year, following a relatively slow period for US-listed technology offerings.

site_title: BOJ keeps policy steady even as Japan slides into recession
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, expecting the economy to recover from recession. The BOJ cited a moderate recovery, with exports and production affected by emerging economies. It reiterated its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen through purchases of government bonds and risky assets. The central bank kept its economic assessment unchanged, citing a tight job market and rising wages that underpin consumption.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Marco Polo, SIIC Environment, Keppel T&T
summary: SembCorp Marine's shares declined 2.22% after a potential cancellation of a contract with Marco Polo Marine over a S$214.3 million jack-up contract. SIIC Environment Holdings' shares also fell 7% after a broad market drop. Keppel T&T appointed Tan Eng Hwa as CFO and Desmond Gay Kah Meng as CEO of Keppel Logistics to boost its management team.

site_title: 'No credible threat' right now from Islamic State against US: Obama adviser
summary: US President Barack Obama's counterterrorism adviser, Lisa Monaco, stated that there is "no credible threat" against the US from Islamic State militants. Monaco emphasized the US government's rigorous review of Syrian refugee applicants, having interviewed and accepted fewer than 2,000 of 7,000 refugees since 2011.

site_title: Strong demand for Citic Envirotech USD perpetual bond issue; orderbook closed
summary: CITIC Envirotech Ltd's USD perpetual bond issue received strong demand, with orders exceeding $250 million, and its orderbook closed at 12:45pm. The initial price guidance is in the 5.75% area, and the issue is reportedly 4-5 times oversubscribed. This follows similar successful issues for benchmark USD bonds by SP Powerassets and STATS ChipPAC. CEL has a proven track record in providing wastewater treatment solutions in Asia and has strong shareholders, including Citic and KKR.

site_title: Volkswagen says 120,000 US diesel owners will get gift cards, repairs
summary: Volkswagen is offering US$500 gift cards and US$500 towards vehicle repairs to approximately 120,000 US diesel car owners who have violated US emission standards. The move aims to cover costs associated with the emissions scandal, with the company setting aside 6.5 billion euros. US regulators have estimated potential fines of up to $18 billion. The offer does not prevent owners from filing lawsuits, which the company faces.

site_title: Paris attacks: Fate of 'mastermind' unknown after massive raid
summary: A massive police raid in a Paris suburb left at least two dead, including a female suicide bomber, and thwarted a "team of terrorists that could have struck." The raid targeted Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a 28-year-old suspected mastermind of the Paris attacks, but his fate remains unknown. Eight people were arrested, but Abaaoud and Salah Abdeslam, suspected of taking part in the attacks, were not among them. The police operation came after intelligence led investigators to believe Abaaoud was in the apartment in Saint-Denis.

site_title: Singapore needs to review tax policy: PwC
summary: Singapore's tax policy needs to be reviewed to solidify its position as an attractive location for businesses, according to a PwC report. The report suggests using tax incentives to attract industries that create value for the economy and society, and increasing government revenue to fund social programs. It also recommends expanding the treaty network, publishing sanitized private rulings, and establishing an Asian/Asean tax arbitration hub. The review is timely, following global developments aimed at combating Base Erosion and Profit Shifting practices.

site_title: US: Stocks jump on Fed; terror fears weigh in eurozone
summary: US stocks rose 1.6% on Wednesday following minutes from the Federal Reserve's October meeting, which indicated a likely interest rate hike in December. The eurozone was affected by terror fears, with Paris stocks down 0.6% and Frankfurt stocks experiencing a volatile session. The dollar retreated against the euro, while Apple surged 3.0% after being added to Goldman Sachs' "conviction buy" list.

site_title: Paris attacks: US warned of 'mastermind' in May
summary: US intelligence warned in May that the Islamic State had developed the capability to carry out a Paris-style attack, specifically citing Abdelhamid Abaaoud as the suspected mastermind of the coordinated suicide bombings and shootings in Paris that killed at least 129 people. The assessment noted that the group had developed the capability to launch more complex operations in the West, but warned that the threat was more acute in Europe than the US. The plot disrupted by Belgian authorities in January may indicate that the group has developed this capability.

images.alt_text: An undated picture taken on Nov 16, 2015 from the February 2015 issue 7 of the Islamic State (IS) group online English-language magazine Dabiq, purportedly shows 27-year-old Belgian IS group leading militant Abdelhamid Abaaoud, also known as Abu Umar al-Baljiki.

site_title: Japan posts more than US$900m trade surplus in October: govt
summary: Japan posted a trade surplus of over $900 million in October, the first since March, due to falling oil prices. The surplus came despite a decline in exports for the first time since August last year. Exports fell 2.1% and imports decreased 13.4% from a year earlier. The trade surplus was attributed to the weak yen, which boosted shipments to the US, but hurt sales to China. The move is seen as a positive sign for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" program, which aims to revitalize Japan's economy through monetary easing.

site_title: As emerging markets grow, Android extends smartphone lead
summary: Android smartphone sales surged in the third quarter, accounting for 84.7% of global sales, up from 83.3% the previous year. Emerging markets drove growth, with sales increasing 18.4% compared to 8.2% in mature markets. Apple's market share rose to 13.1%, while Windows Phone and Blackberry saw significant declines. Samsung maintained its top spot, followed by Apple, Huawei, and a virtual tie between Lenovo and Xiaomi.

site_title: CosmoSteel Q4 profit plunges amid challenging market
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings reported a 49.3% drop in net profit to S$1 million in Q4 2015, with revenue declining 41.6% to S$24.2 million. The company attributed the decline to a weak oil market and fewer projects available. Despite a full-year net loss of S$0.9 million, CosmoSteel declared a dividend per share of 0.5 cent, citing "sound business fundamentals". CEO Ong Chin Sum expects revenue and profit margins to remain under pressure in FY2016.

site_title: Apple, Spotify face rival in race for exclusive music
summary: WeTransfer, a Dutch file-sharing service, is launching a new music player to compete with Apple and Spotify for exclusive songs and music videos. The company, which serves 85 million users monthly, aims to differentiate itself by using music to attract potential hits and promote artists. WeTransfer has already partnered with Prince, Big Grams, and Disclosure, and plans to recruit more talent through its service. The company's goal is to become a major player in the music industry, despite not generating revenue from music sales. WeTransfer generates half of its sales from advertising and subscription services.

site_title: French police raid suspected hideout of terror ringleader
summary: French police raided a suspected hideout of terror ringleader Abdelhamid Abaaoud in the Paris suburb of Saint-Denis, killing two extremists and arresting seven others. The operation came after phone taps, surveillance, and witness accounts led investigators to believe Abaaoud was holed up in the area. President Francois Hollande vowed to annihilate the ISIS threat, while a French aircraft carrier set sail for the eastern Mediterranean to intensify bombing of ISIS positions in Syria.

site_title: Oil prices edge higher after US, Fed reports
summary: Global oil prices rose modestly on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing eight cents to $40.75 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude rising 57 cents to $44.14 a barrel. The gains were driven by a small increase in US inventories and a Federal Reserve report that supported expectations of a December interest rate hike. The reports were seen as positive for the US economy, contributing to the oil price increase.

site_title: Square prices shares at US$9 in long-awaited IPO: sources
summary: Square Inc. priced its shares at US$9 in its initial public offering (IPO), raising US$243.5 million and valuing the company at US$2.9 billion, a 52% drop from its previous valuation. The lower price reflects widespread uncertainty about the payments industry's profitability and Square's own slowing revenue growth. Despite a 49% increase in revenue for the nine months ending September, the company posted a loss of US$131.5 million, and its cash from operations remains negative.

site_title: Linc Energy responds to SGX query on trading activity
summary: Linc Energy responded to the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) query on trading activity, stating it is in compliance with listing rules. The energy company had seen its shares rise for three consecutive days, from S$0.125 to S$0.155. Linc Energy entered a confidentiality agreement with an Australian company on November 11 for its SAPEX assets, with a 30-day exclusivity period for due diligence. The company clarified that no formal negotiations for the sale of SAPEX have been held, pending due diligence completion.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) logo outside SGX Centre.

site_title: US dollar dips vs euro as Fed minutes point to December rate hike
summary: The US dollar dropped against the euro on November 18, 2015, following the release of the Federal Reserve's October policy meeting minutes. The minutes indicated that most committee members expected the US economy to be strong enough in December to justify a rate hike for the first time in nine years. Some officials believed the economy was already strong enough at that time to warrant a hike. This reinforced expectations of a December interest rate hike.

site_title: McDonald's operator sued after diners exposed to hepatitis A
summary: A customer sued the operator of a McDonald's restaurant in Waterloo, New York, after being exposed to food and drinks prepared by a worker with hepatitis A. The lawsuit seeks class-action status for potentially affected customers, estimated to be over 1,000. The infected worker was confirmed to have hepatitis A on November 13, and public health officials urged those who consumed food and drinks on November 2-8 to consider treatments if not vaccinated.

site_title: Telegram messaging app acts to block Islamic State sites
summary: Telegram, a messaging app used by Islamic State, has taken action to block the group's channels. The move comes after security researchers reported that the app's public broadcast feature was being used by the group to share news and videos. Telegram has 60 million active users and is considered an ultra-secure platform. The blockage is seen as a response to the group's use of the app for recruitment and propaganda purposes.

site_title: UberPOP driven out of Netherlands
summary: UberPOP, a ride-sharing service in the Netherlands, has stopped operations due to a ban by Dutch judges in December 2014. The service, which allowed private car drivers to offer taxi services via smartphone, was declared illegal. Uber will continue to operate its more expensive services, such as UberX and UberBLACK, but will not pursue further expansion in the Netherlands. The decision follows similar bans in France and the introduction of new legislation in the Netherlands concerning the taxi market.

images.alt_text: The controversial ride-sharing service UberPOP is to stop operations in the Netherlands almost a year after it was declared illegal in the country.

site_title: Canadian banks face C$152b bill for 2008 crisis they avoided
summary: Canada's six largest banks face a C$152 billion bill to convert capital into securities to meet global regulations designed to prevent taxpayer-funded bailouts. The banks, which never received bailouts during the 2008 financial crisis, must meet the 18% liability-to-risk-weighted asset ratio by 2022. Market signals indicate banks will have to pay to meet this requirement, potentially raising the cost of doing business and making credit more expensive. This could have a ripple effect across the Canadian economy, making banking services more costly.

site_title: Bombardier in talks with Canadian govt on further cash infusion: CEO
summary: Bombardier Inc is in talks with the Canadian government about a further cash infusion into its struggling CSeries jet programme. The company, which expects to turn a profit by 2020, is seeking a participation in financing investment from the new federal government. This comes after the Quebec government invested $1 billion in the CSeries programme in exchange for a near 50-per cent stake. Bombardier has received 243 firm orders for the CSeries, but is short of its target of 300 firm orders by the time the jet enters service in 2016.

images.alt_text: Mr Bellemare has been focusing on reducing debt on Bombardier's balance sheet through asset sales.

site_title: COE premiums higher across the board
summary: COE premiums rose strongly in Singapore's latest bidding exercise, with all categories experiencing increases. Category A premiums jumped to S$59,200, Cat B to S$61,103, and Cat E to S$62,019. Dealers had expected the surge due to the success of TheCars@Expo event, which attracted car buyers with promotions. The increases are expected to continue towards year-end, with sales managers predicting a steady rise in COE premiums.

site_title: Building smarter
summary: Cities are employing new technologies to address rapid urbanization challenges such as overcrowding, congestion, and pollution. By 2050, 70% of the world's population will live in cities, with Asia being the fastest urbanizing region. Smart city solutions like cloud computing and Internet of Things (IOT) are being used to optimize traffic flow and reduce energy use. Countries like Singapore, China, and India are leading the way in developing smart cities, with Singapore aiming to become the world's first Smart Nation and China's Tianjin Eco-City showcasing sustainable urban solutions. Experts believe that smart solutions will become the norm in many urban centers, contributing to sustainable growth and transformation.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine scores newbuild FSO vessel win
summary: Sembcorp Marine has secured a newbuild floating storage offloading vessel (FSO) construction contract from Modec on a full turnkey project basis. The FSO will be delivered in the first quarter and deployed at Maersk Oil's Culzean field in the UK North Sea. This marks SembMarine's first newbuild FSO award on a full turnkey project basis, and it will be the company's first FSO vessel built from scratch.

images.alt_text: Signage of Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Fed officials again flag December; see smooth rates liftoff
summary: Federal Reserve officials signaled a potential interest rate hike in December, with two officials expressing confidence in a smooth rate increase despite market concerns. The odds of a rate hike in December increased to 72% based on interest rate futures prices. Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester stated that the US economy is strong enough to absorb modest policy tightening, citing a strong labor market and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: Richard K. Davis (left), CEO of US Bancorp, listens to a panel where New York Fed President William Dudley (second from left), Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester (right), and Dennis Lockhart of the Atlanta Fed speak about the health of the U.S. economy in New York on Nov 18, 2015.

site_title: Why Singapore is winning over companies looking at Asia
summary: Singapore is emerging as the preferred location for regional headquarters of top 100 companies with operations in Asia, with 75% of these companies having their regional HQ in Singapore. The city-state's ease of doing business, access to a highly skilled talent pool, and excellent infrastructure contribute to its attractiveness. Singapore's education system is among the best in the world, and its fluency in English and Mandarin adds to its appeal. The country's stable political environment, efficient public service sector, and effective legal system also make it an attractive choice for companies.

site_title: Danone raises sales target for first time in four years
summary: Danone, the world's largest yogurt maker, has raised its sales target for the first time in four years, aiming for 5% growth on a like-for-like basis through 2020. The company's fresh-dairy business, which accounts for over half of its revenue, expects to boost profitability and increase its profit margin by over two percentage points by 2020. The company's other units, including water and infant-formula, are expected to post 7-10% and 6-8% like-for-like sales growth, respectively.

site_title: More economists believe BOJ is done boosting stimulus
summary: Economists increasingly believe the Bank of Japan (BOJ) has completed its stimulus efforts, with 46% of respondents in a poll predicting no further boost in asset purchases, up from 33% last month. Despite Japan's economy contracting for the second quarter, economists largely don't expect the BOJ to expand stimulus, with most predicting no change at the upcoming policy meeting on December 17-18. The BOJ's target of achieving 2% inflation by October 2016 is also seen as unlikely, leading to a decrease in expectations for future easing.

site_title: Air Liquide to buy Airgas for US$10.3b in US expansion
summary: Air Liquide has agreed to acquire US-based Airgas Inc for $10.3 billion, marking the European company's largest US expansion. The deal, which represents a 50% premium to Airgas' 20-day average price, would give Air Liquide a leading share of the US industrial gases market. The acquisition is expected to help Air Liquide leapfrog competitors Linde AG and Air Products & Chemicals Inc to the top spot in North America, with forecasted further growth in construction and manufacturing.

site_title: Jewish school teacher stabbed in Marseille: police
summary: A 57-year-old Jewish school teacher in Marseille was stabbed by three people shouting anti-Semitic slurs and expressing support for the Islamic State group. The attackers, who were traveling by scooter, demanded the teacher look at pictures of a Toulouse jihadist and showed him a t-shirt with the logo of Daesh before attacking him. The teacher escaped serious injury and was taken to hospital. This incident comes as France is on high alert following the Paris attacks, with a regional president expressing concern about the threat of further attacks and a debate on extending the state of emergency scheduled for Thursday.

site_title: Don't fear a rising dollar
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in December, but experts argue that the impact will be minimal, as businesses and consumers are unlikely to change their behavior due to a quarter-point change in short-term interest rates. The Fed's objective is to lift inflation to 2%, and Janet Yellen has committed to keeping rates low despite rising inflation. Contrary to fears of a stronger dollar, the market consensus is likely incorrect, as monetary policy divergence, trade deficits, and other factors will influence currency values. The widely assumed correlation between monetary policy and currency values does not hold up to empirical examination.

site_title: Non-lawyer employees can now have a stake in their law firms
summary: Non-lawyer employees in Singapore can now become partners, directors, or shareholders in law firms, allowing them to share in profits. This change, made to the Legal Profession Act, marks the first time such employees can have a stake in law firms. The amendments take effect immediately.

site_title: Aramco Trading Co expanding operations into Singapore: sources
summary: Aramco Trading Co, a subsidiary of Saudi Aramco, has established a Singapore office to market oil products, marking the company's expansion into the city-state. Nader Al-Arfaj, hired from the parent company, heads operations in the region. The office will provide marketing support for Saudi Aramco and liaise with the trading headquarters in Dhahran, without immediate plans for trading from Singapore. The move follows Saudi Arabia's shift from a net diesel importer to an exporter, with the office targeting new business from Asia.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as Air Liquide loses steam
summary: European shares fell on Wednesday, retreating from gains in the previous session, with French industrial gas company Air Liquide dropping 7.4% after announcing a $13.4 billion deal to buy US peer Airgas. The FTSEurofirst 300 index fell 0.2% and the Euro STOXX 50 index closed down 0.6%. Despite a rally in Russia-exposed stocks following air strikes in Syria, investors remain cautious amid concerns over terrorism and the ongoing conflict. The European travel and leisure sector declined 0.4%, while retailer Metro rose 2.4% and pharmaceutical company Stada increased 2.8%.

site_title: Bids for CPF Building top S$500m: sources
summary: Bids for the CPF Building in Singapore have exceeded S$500 million, surpassing market expectations of S$450 million. Two of the highest bids are believed to be from Ascendas-Singbridge and Richard Li's Pacific Century Premium Developments (PCPD), with a small price gap between the top two bids. The CPF Board is evaluating the bids, with conditions offered by the bidders potentially determining the award. The building, about 40 years old, has substantial untapped gross floor area and a 51-year land tenure, making it an attractive investment opportunity for PCPD.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Crackdown on foreign ownership: Australia orders sale of 7 homes
summary: Australia's government ordered the sale of 7 homes bought in breach of foreign ownership laws, taking the total to 19. The properties, mostly owned by Chinese nationals, were bought in breach of rules restricting foreign buyers to new homes only. Treasurer Scott Morrison said the forced sales demonstrate the government's commitment to enforcing laws to improve affordability. The move comes as economists forecast a slowdown in Australian house prices due to rising interest rates. Since March, the government has investigated 1,044 property sales and has another 532 under investigation.

site_title: Renewable energy will spur rather than slow growth: Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the importance of transitioning to renewable energy at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) CEO Summit. Obama urged governments and companies to reduce emissions contributing to climate change, stating it would spur business opportunities and boost the global economy. Xi pledged continued green policies, announced plans to slash market curbs for foreign investors, and stressed the need for regional economic integration through the Free Trade Agreement of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP).

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Yahoo a new target in NY daily fantasy sports probe: source
summary: New York State's attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, has expanded a probe into daily fantasy sports to include online media giant Yahoo. The probe, which seeks to shut down DraftKings and FanDuel, claims daily fantasy sports are "nothing more than a rebranding of sports betting" and "plainly illegal." Yahoo was issued a subpoena, and the company has not commented on the matter. A hearing on the injunction is set for November 25, with the outcome potentially crippling the daily fantasy sports industry, which has become a multibillion-dollar market.

images.alt_text: DraftKings, one of the leaders among online companies offering paid-for daily fantasy sports contests, has pledged to continue running its business as usual in the state.

site_title: TPP faces tough passage through US Congress
summary: US President Barack Obama faces an uncertain fate for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, with Republican leaders planning to shelve it until after the 2016 presidential election. Despite Obama's confidence in its passage, opposition from many Democrats and some Republicans, including Donald Trump, complicates the process. The Senate Finance Committee chairman, Orrin Hatch, suggests the deal may not be voted on before Obama leaves office, casting doubt on the administration's hopes for a vote in the first half of 2016.

site_title: Proposed law on Fed will damage economy, warns Yellen
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen warns that a proposed law to oversee the Fed would politicize monetary policy and harm the economy. The Fed Oversight Reform and Modernization Act, which aims to make Fed policymaking more predictable and transparent, would tie the hands of Fed policymakers to a formulaic rule, potentially worsening economic crises. The White House warns that President Barack Obama could veto the bill if it passes Congress, citing threats to the nation's financial system and economy. The bill faces a full House vote this week.

site_title: All Blacks legend Jonah Lomu dies at 40
summary: Jonah Lomu, the legendary New Zealand rugby player, has died at 40. Lomu's career was cut short by kidney disease, but his performances at the 1995 and 1999 World Cups raised rugby's profile globally, making him a record try-scorer with 43 tries in 73 matches. His impact on the sport extends beyond his playing career, as his performances helped persuade Rupert Murdoch to buy the television rights to southern hemisphere rugby, leading to the sport's switch to professionalism.

site_title: Global engineering consultancy Aurecon buys Singapore firm
summary: Global engineering consultancy Aurecon has acquired Singapore firm AUP Consultants, marking its first acquisition in the country. The deal aims to enhance Aurecon's capacity to service large and complex projects in Singapore and Asia. Aurecon CEO Giam Swiegers plans to double the team's size in Asia over the next two to three years, focusing on local talent and leadership. The acquisition is part of Aurecon's strategy to achieve higher sustainable profits and expand its presence in key markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Vietnam.

site_title: October home starts fall more than forecast
summary: US home starts declined 11% in October to a 1.06 million annualized rate, the slowest pace since March, according to the Commerce Department. Single-family home construction fell 2.4% and multifamily home construction plummeted 25.1%. Despite the drop, homebuilders remain optimistic, with the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo builder sentiment index easing to 62. Stronger hiring and cheap borrowing costs are expected to support the market, with a surge in payroll growth and low mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: The drop in home starts last month was primarily due to a 25.1 per cent slump in work on multifamily homes, the biggest drop since August 2014.

site_title: China ties deserve close attention, says Suu Kyi
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi has pledged to pay close attention to ties with China, a key foreign investor, as her party takes office. She emphasized the need for public support and transparency to improve relations, amid historical mistrust and concerns over China's influence in Myanmar's peace process and domestic border conflicts. Suu Kyi also noted that Myanmar's foreign policy is about balance, and China and Myanmar can have a good friendship if both parties are willing, as she maintains friendly ties with countries near and far.

site_title: US retailers post upbeat sales numbers
