summary: A New York attorney general probe into daily fantasy sports has expanded to include Yahoo Inc, the online media company, which operates a daily fantasy sports site. A subpoena was issued to Yahoo by New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman. The investigation aims to determine whether Yahoo and other companies have engaged in unfair or deceptive practices. This expansion follows similar probes into other major daily fantasy sports operators, such as FanDuel and DraftKings. The outcome of the investigation is expected to have significant implications for the multibillion-dollar industry.

images.alt_text: A probe by the New York attorney-general into the fast-growing, multibillion-dollar daily fantasy sports industry has expanded to include Yahoo Inc.

site_title: The final TPP roadblock lies in US presidential politics
summary: The US has released the full text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement, aiming for Congressional approval within 90 days. Despite President Obama's efforts, the accord faces opposition from Democrats and has sparked concerns about its impact on American workers and the economy. The White House is counting on Republican lawmakers to support the agreement, but populist sentiments among leading presidential candidates, including Donald Trump, have raised doubts about its passage.

site_title: SembMarine says termination by Marco Polo Marine breaches contract
summary: SembMarine claims Marco Polo Marine's termination of a $214.3 million newbuild contract is a "repudiatory breach" of the agreement, as the latter announced the contract's termination without prior notice. SembMarine will terminate the contract and pursue claims against Marco Polo Marine and its guarantor Marco Polo Drilling.

site_title: SGX's bond-market foray now includes a dark pool
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch a dark pool for bonds, allowing traders to flag interest in a security without revealing the size or price of their desired transaction. The platform, part of SGX's Bond Pro, aims to minimize price impact and will initially deal in bonds denominated in dollars, euros, and yen. The move follows the expansion of dark pools globally, driven by electronic trading and regulatory efforts to cut transaction costs. SGX's platform is set to enter the institutional fixed-income trading business in the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: Tableau to release first smartphone app
summary: Tableau, a data-analytics firm, is launching its first smartphone app, version 9.2 of its software, for the Apple iPhone and Android platforms. The app will allow users to analyze and visualize data on-the-go, filling a gap in the market for mobile data analysis. The company's expansion into the Asia-Pacific region, with new offices in Shanghai, Vancouver, and Singapore, is driven by the proliferation of data and mobile devices, with 92% of the population in the region having access to mobile connections.

site_title: 15 global banks' legal costs still mounting: Moody's
summary: Global banks, including Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan, and Goldman Sachs, face high risk litigation tied to alleged misconduct such as currency market rigging and mortgage-backed securities sales. Moody's Investors Service estimates $219 billion in costs for 15 global banks between 2008 and 2014. These costs may lead to "substantial costs" and criminal proceedings. Regulators continue to investigate wrongdoing, with Deutsche Bank facing $3 billion in fines and a Russian unit under investigation.

site_title: Optimism for steel recovery overrrated: Macquarie
summary: Macquarie analysts, led by Colin Hamilton, warn that optimism for a steel recovery in China is overrated due to a material slowdown in demand. Global steel consumption has contracted annually throughout 2015, and the successful rebalancing of China's economy is expected to further reduce steel demand. The industry's overcapacity, averaging below 80% utilization for seven years, poses concerns, particularly for China's domestic steel producers with weak balance sheets. To achieve 90% capacity utilization, nearly 275 million tonnes of steel would need to be mothballed, highlighting the scale of the problem facing the global steel market.

site_title: Stats ChipPac US$425 million senior notes priced at 8.5%
summary: STATS ChipPAC Ltd priced US$425 million in senior secured notes at 8.5% interest, due 2020. The notes will be issued on Nov 24 and used to repay US$890 million bridge loan facility. The company will guarantee the notes by its subsidiaries, except for those in China and Thailand. The notes will mature on Nov 24, 2020, with interest payable semi-annually starting from 2016. They are redeemable at the company's option, with certain conditions. The notes were offered to qualified institutional buyers in the US.

site_title: Greece inks deal with creditors to unlock 12b euros
summary: Greece has reached a deal with its international creditors to unblock 12 billion euros in loans, following marathon talks. The agreement includes 48 additional measures, including reforms on home loan foreclosures, which were previously a point of contention. The funds, including 10 billion euros for bank recapitalization, are expected to be unlocked by Friday. Greek bond yields fell to their lowest in over a year, and banking stocks rose 10% after the agreement, easing fears of another government debt restructuring. Eurozone officials are expected to approve the agreement later on Tuesday.

site_title: US$ stuck after hitting 7-month high
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-month high against the euro on Tuesday, hitting US$1.0647, but struggled to make further progress. The euro was up 0.15% at US$1.0671 and flat against a basket of currencies. Major currency trading banks forecast a rise towards parity with the euro in the months ahead, but options markets indicate substantial barriers to further gains. Concerns about US consumer price data and potential Federal Reserve interest rate hikes may weigh on the dollar's upward momentum.

site_title: US, China vie for influence at Asia-Pacific summit
summary: US and Chinese leaders attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in Manila, amid a tense contest for influence in the South China Sea. The 21-nation group aims to promote trade, but the summit's focus has shifted to the disputed territory, home to key shipping lanes. US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping will attend the two-day gathering, which seeks to forge trade unity. The summit's outcome is uncertain, with both countries vying for regional influence.

site_title: Artificial intelligence draws new connections for personalisation
summary: Sentient, a San Francisco-based company, has developed a visual search service for Shoes.com using advanced artificial intelligence. The service allows customers to browse pictures of shoes and receive personalized results in real-time, without knowing the brand. This technology, known as "dynamic ontology," enables the AI to understand complex interrelated data and make decisions based on the situation. Early customer tests have shown increased sales, and the technology has the potential to revolutionize personalization in retail and other industries.

site_title: Bumper crop of HDB flats up for sale
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched its largest sales exercise, offering 12,411 flats across 25 estates under the November build-to-order and sale of balance flats exercise. The Bidadari flats, in particular, are expected to be popular due to their proximity to MRT stations and higher price points. New policies announced in August, including a two-room flexi scheme, increased income ceilings, and enhanced Special CPF Housing Grant, are expected to boost demand for new public flats. The application period has been extended to 10 days, with a deadline of November 26.

site_title: Marco Polo to cancel rig contract with SembMarine unit
summary: Marco Polo Marine is terminating a US$214.3 million contract for a jack-up rig under construction at Sembcorp Marine's PPL Shipyard. Cracks were detected in the rig's legs during two tests, prompting Marco Polo to seek a refund of its 10% deposit, approximately US$21.4 million. The contract was signed in February 2014, before a collapse in oil prices, and was intended to be Marco Polo's first drilling unit. The decision comes as the offshore support vessel-focused company faces persistent weakness in oil prices and a rig supply glut.

site_title: Global stocks stay resilient after Paris attacks
summary: Global stocks remained resilient after the Paris attacks, with major European bourses surging and US stocks holding gains. London's FTSE 100 rose 2.0%, the French CAC 40 index gained 2.8%, and Germany's DAX 30 index advanced 2.4%. US stocks finished near-flat, with the S&P 500 slipping 0.1% and the Dow and Nasdaq rising by a small fraction. Asian markets also advanced, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney posting gains, while Shanghai edged down. The dollar strengthened after the US consumer price index rose 0.2% in October.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during the morning of Nov 16, 2015 in New York City.

site_title: UPS rolls out telematics system for delivery fleet in Singapore
summary: UPS has rolled out a telematics system in Singapore, tracking over 200 vehicle-related elements, including speed, idling time, and brake usage, to analyze and improve delivery efficiency. The system, developed in-house, has been installed across UPS's entire fleet of vans and trucks in Singapore, marking the company's first market in Asia Pacific to implement the technology. This initiative aims to enhance delivery services and reduce costs.

site_title: Sino-US rivalry assumes centre stage at Apec summit
summary: Key leaders from Asia-Pacific and the Americas gathered at the Apec summit in the Philippines, focusing on economic issues amid a backdrop of rising tensions between the US and China. China is pushing for a Free Trade Area of Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) as an alternative to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which the US is championing. The FTAAP aims to create an integrated Asia-Pacific free trade area with China potentially at the center, but faces challenges, including the uncertainty over TPP ratification in the US Congress. The summit's outcome will determine which regional economic integration model prevails, with implications for US-China relations and global economic order.

site_title: Strategic plan to boost tourism
summary: Oman is implementing a strategic plan to boost its tourism industry, aiming to become a key contributor to its gross domestic product. The country has commissioned a long-term vision for tourism, covering the next 25 years, with four major pillars: tourism competitiveness, marketing and product development, governance, and education and socio-economic development. The plan includes initiatives to promote local and foreign investors, showcase historical attractions, and encourage sustainable tourism. Oman is also targeting new segments such as sports tourism and the MICE industry, with investments in sports facilities and sailing programs.

site_title: Swelling global grain glut spurs biggest bearish bet since June
summary: Global grain inventories are expected to reach all-time highs before next year's North American harvests, prompting hedge funds to expand their bearish bets on lower crop prices. The combined net short position across corn, wheat, and soya beans has risen to 131,650 futures and options, the largest since June. Global supplies are forecast to outstrip demand, with record production in some regions and favourable weather contributing to the surplus.

site_title: A great investment destination
summary: Foreigners are investing heavily in Oman due to its business-friendly environment, modern infrastructure, and strategic location. The country's free trade agreement with GCC countries, low taxes, and one-stop-shop for business registration attract international firms. Non-oil exports grew over 8% last year, driven by infrastructure investments. The government is promoting downstream manufacturing and diversifying the economy, making Oman an attractive destination for foreign direct investment. Key investors include Singapore companies and Brazilian multinational Vale, which has generated over 1,200 direct jobs. Oman aims to attract high-impact inward investment and is working with partners to enhance its competitiveness and capitalize on emerging economic trends.

site_title: NOL surges in heavy trading, prompting SGX query
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares surged 7% to an intraday high of S$1.145 due to unusual price and volume movements, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). NOL confirmed talks on a potential acquisition, citing discussions with CMA CGM and AP Moeller-Maersk, but warned no assurance of a definitive agreement or transaction. The stock closed 5.16% higher, with over 51 million shares changing hands, amid concerns over the impact of a sale on NOL's margin.

site_title: Significant milestone in ties between Singapore, Oman
summary: Singapore and Oman celebrated Oman's 45th national day, marking a significant milestone in their ties. The celebration included events such as a reception in Muscat, a photography exhibition, and the signing of a free trade agreement between the GCC countries and Singapore. The agreement is expected to boost investment opportunities between the two countries, particularly in the economic, trade, and tourism sectors. Oman's Consulate-General in Singapore also hosted a reception to commemorate the 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries, highlighting the deep historical and cultural ties between them.

site_title: Vigilance by shore staff is key to reducing engine-damage claims
summary: Engine damage caused by human error, particularly incorrect maintenance and repair, remains a significant issue for marine insurers, with nearly 35% of machinery claims costs attributed to this factor. Lubrication failure is the most costly cause of damage to main engines, often resulting from insufficient experience and training of crew, contaminated lubrication oil, and improper management systems. The Swedish Club's report highlights the importance of shore-based vigilance in preventing engine damage, particularly in vessels with low-speed engines, which run up fewer claims than those with medium- and high-speed engines.

site_title: New Lexus RX expected to stay in global No 1 spot
summary: The new Lexus RX is expected to maintain its global No. 1 spot in the luxury crossover segment, thanks to its loyal fan base and consistent sales. The fourth-generation RX boasts a new spindle grille, a stiffer body, and a more upscale interior. Chief engineer Takayuki Katsuda attributes the model's success to "customer loyalty" and its ability to maintain annual sales volumes of around 13,000 units per month. With a strong dealer network and repeat buyers accounting for 50% of sales, Lexus is confident of retaining its market share in the lucrative mid-sized SUV segment.

images.alt_text: The new Lexus RX (above) has a stiffer body with a more upscale interior, and a more focused drive with a re-designed suspension and engine mounts.
Mr Katsuda is the chief engineer for the third and fourth-generation RX.

site_title: Still more sells than buys in Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more shares than they bought in Singapore stocks in the three months to Nov 16, with net sells of S$1.8 billion and net buys of S$567.4 million. Singtel was the top stock among sells, with a volume of S$532.2 million, while Olam International was the top buy, with a volume of S$141.3 million. This trend suggests that investors are cautious on the market, with many alternative investors and institutional money managers not disclosing their trades.

site_title: Educating the CEO (Amended)
summary: A growing number of corporate leaders are pursuing MBAs to upgrade their skills, with 40% of S&P 500 CEOs holding an MBA in the US and over 70% in Singapore and Hong Kong. The benefits of an MBA include networking, learning from fellow CEOs, and gaining access to cutting-edge business research. Top business schools now offer fast-track versions for working executives, with estimated costs ranging from $101,650 to $110,000. Studies show that MBA graduates can achieve their career goals, with nearly three-quarters of those aged 31 or above achieving promotions and 95% overall reporting success.

site_title: Apec hails progress in setting up region's trade zone
summary: APEC officials welcomed progress in establishing a region-wide free-trade zone, aiming to create the world's largest free-trade pact. The 21-member economies have begun a joint study to assess the viability of a new free-trade framework, with an initial report due in January. The goal is to eventually create the Free-Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific, an alternative to the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The ministers also discussed pressing issues, including terrorism, and condemned the Paris attacks, reaffirming their collective resolve to counter terrorism.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Taking giant strides
summary: Oman celebrates its 45th National Day with pride and determination, marking a historic turning point in the country's modern renaissance under the wise leadership of Sultan Qaboos Bin Said. The country has scored milestones in reviving its prominent status in the world arena, despite a 36% drop in international oil prices since 2014. Oman has continued to promote peace, hosting negotiations between Iran and the Group of 5+1 and exerting efforts to stop ongoing fights in Yemen. The country also celebrates the 30th anniversary of diplomatic relations with Singapore, with enhanced ties through cultural, historical, and economic projects.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of Oman's capital city Muscat.
Sultan Qaboos Bin Said has presided over Oman's rapid progress, ensuring that the country keeps scoring milestones towards reviving its prominent status in the world arena.
Oman Consul-General to Singapore Zakariya Hamed Hilal Al Saadi.

site_title: Chip credit cards give retailers another grievance against banks
summary: Retailers are experiencing another headache with the implementation of new chip credit cards, which are often slower and may exacerbate long lines during the holiday season. The upgrade, which began October 1, was meant to enhance security but has also increased costs for retailers. The dispute between banks and retailers over interchange fees, which merchants pay to process transactions, has grown, with some arguing that the new system only cuts down on bank-provided fraud protection. The impact on merchants' bottom line is significant, with $61 billion in interchange fees paid last year, dwarfing $30 billion in fraud losses.

site_title: Sembmarine achieves record cruise ship upgrades
summary: Sembcorp Marine completed a record number of cruise ship upgrades in 2015, with the recent refits of Pacific Eden and Pacific Aria at its Admiralty Yard. The upgrades, which involved concurrent drydocking, marked the first time for P&O Cruises (Australia). The successful completion reinforces Sembcorp Marine's reputation as a leader in the cruise refit market, boosting Singapore's status as a major global cruise hub. The company's shares closed trading at S$2.25, up three cents.

site_title: Singapore economy ranked as Asia's most talent-competitive
summary: Singapore has been ranked as Asia's most talent-competitive economy, placing 10th globally in the IMD's World Talent Ranking of 61 economies. The country excels in "readiness", ranking second, but struggles in "investment and development" and "appeal", ranking 18th and 29th respectively. IMD attributes Singapore's low scores in public expenditure on education and cost of living to its large pool of talent that may shrink in the future.

site_title: SGX fires warning on suspect China-linked impairments, write-offs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a warning to listed companies, particularly those with operations in China, over potential impairments and write-offs due to "perplexing circumstances." The regulator is concerned about large swings in financial positions and performance, as well as customer claims and write-offs without due process. The warning is seen as unusual, but SGX chief regulatory officer Tan Boon Gin notes that the actions mentioned are a trend observed based on publicly disclosed information, and companies are urged to be vigilant.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: The business case for sustainable design
summary: A roundtable discussion on sustainable design was held, focusing on climate change and environmental degradation. The event highlighted the need for companies to adopt environmentally friendly practices and reduce their supply chain's impact. The discussion emphasized the importance of sustainable design in reducing the environmental footprint of businesses, particularly in the face of climate change and haze issues in South-east Asia.

site_title: An undiscovered gem on the Arabian Sea
summary: Oman is a hidden gem in the Middle East, boasting a diverse landscape and unique cultural heritage. Despite regional tourism challenges, Oman's stability and security make it an attractive destination. The country's 500+ castles and forts, four World Heritage sites, and 18km coastline of sandy beaches are just a few of its many attractions. The government aims to boost tourism through sustainable development, preserving cultural integrity, and protecting the environment, with a focus on economic diversification and promoting Omani nationals in the sector.

site_title: Staying relevant in a changing world
summary: Singapore's top universities, NTU and SMU, are evolving their postgraduate programs to keep pace with the changing job market. With the rise of technology and globalisation, executives and professionals are seeking to upgrade their skills through postgraduate degrees. Universities are offering programs in emerging areas such as data analytics, environmental sustainability, and innovation. Employers are looking for graduates with interdisciplinary skills, entrepreneurial spirit, and the ability to solve complex problems. To address these demands, universities are introducing new programs, such as the Master of Tri-Sector Collaboration and the Master of Human Capital Leadership, and strengthening their research in areas like big data analytics and sustainability.

site_title: Standard Chartered's unravelling India bet means more pain ahead
summary: Standard Chartered's Indian operations are causing significant financial strain, with the bank recording $315m of loan impairments in Q3, a quarter of the global total. The bank's expansion in India, which began in the late 2000s, has failed to fully factor in the risk of lending to companies like Essar, resulting in delinquent debts and loan writedowns. The bank's CEO, Bill Winters, is raising money and cutting jobs to address the issue, which has led to a significant reduction in exposure to India.

images.alt_text: Mr Winters must untangle the Indian bad-loan mess even as he retains his predecessor's focus on emerging markets. It may take time: 65% of exposure is to below-investment-grade borrowers.

site_title: Malaysia sukuk yield at 18-month high
summary: Malaysia's Islamic bond market yields have reached an 18-month high due to investors' skepticism over the country's economy. The 10-year sukuk yield is higher than two-year securities, indicating a lack of confidence in long-term borrowing. The high yields come as the country faces a slump in oil export revenue and looming US interest rate increases. Investors believe that longer-term borrowing won't become cheaper anytime soon, exacerbating Malaysia's economic woes.

site_title: Duqm SEZ offers exciting investment opportunities
summary: Duqm Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in Oman offers exciting investment opportunities due to its prime location, political stability, and natural resources. Strategically situated along the Arabian Sea, Duqm SEZ provides access to high-density population markets in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, as well as a gateway to the Middle East, North, and East Africa. The zone is expected to attract US$12.6 billion in industrial investments, with opportunities in petrochemicals, iron & steel, aluminium, and mineral resources. Duqm also features a multi-purpose port, airport, and tourism projects, making it an ideal location for business, tourism, and logistics.

images.alt_text: Duqm SEZ offers an exceptional value proposition for investors, such as 100 per cent foreign ownership, no customs duty, zero per cent income and corporate tax, 30 years renewable tax exemption from the date of initiating the business, renewable lease agreements up to 50 years, and no currency restriction.

site_title: CapitaLand navigates China slowdown
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based real estate company, is expanding its presence in China despite the country's slowdown, focusing on Tier 1 and 1.5 cities. The company expects China's consumption-driven economy to drive demand for real estate, particularly in major cities like Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou. CapitaLand is ramping up onshore funding options, including Panda bonds and China-listed Reits, to finance its projects. The company's CEO, Lucas Loh, remains bullish on China's growth prospects, citing its increasing urbanization, market liberalization, and the internationalization of the yuan.

site_title: MOF accepts 31 suggestions on draft income tax Bill 2016
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) in Singapore has accepted 31 out of 70 suggestions on the draft Income Tax (Amendment) Bill 2016, following a public consultation exercise. The draft Bill aims to implement tax changes announced in Budget 2015 and other system changes. The accepted suggestions include enhancements to the mergers and acquisition scheme, double tax deduction for internationalisation, and the international growth scheme. The bill is set to be introduced in Parliament in early 2016.

site_title: October CPI up 0.2%, boosting rate hike expectations
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in October, reversing a two-month decline, and are expected to support interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve next month. Industrial production fell for the second straight month, raising concerns about fourth-quarter growth. The core CPI, which excludes food and energy costs, also rose 0.2%. The modest inflation increase may give the Fed confidence that inflation will gradually move towards its 2% target.

site_title: Korean billionaire's fortune soars as his pharma stocks surge
summary: Korean billionaire Lim Sung-ki's fortune has surged to approximately $2.7 billion after his pharma stocks, Hanmi Science and Hanmi Pharmaceutical, have surged 971% and 805% respectively over the last 12 months. The surge is attributed to a string of licensing deals with global drugmakers, including Eli Lilly and Sanofi, for potential treatments for conditions such as diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis. Analysts believe the deals will generate significant payouts for the company, with milestone payments potentially reaching up to $3.5 billion.

site_title: Noble Group 'confident' of meeting Moody's targets in review
summary: Noble Group Ltd said it remains confident of meeting Moody's Investors Service targets despite the agency placing its ratings under review for a downgrade. The review focuses on Noble's ability to improve liquidity, cash flow generation, raise capital, and reduce leverage. Moody's cited weaker-than-expected liquidity and high leverage as triggers for the review. Noble's shares initially gained but dropped to close at 42 cents, down 1.5 cents, on Tuesday.

site_title: Upmarket nosh keeps Abenomics' pulse beating
summary: Japan's economy has slipped into recession for the second time in a year, but consumers' spending on upmarket products, such as premium noodles and chocolates, suggests some resilience. Sales of value-added products rose, and part-time wages hit record highs, supporting private consumption. Economists predict the economy will rebound this quarter and stay on a moderate growth trend through the next fiscal year, with wage growth and strong part-time wages seen as positive indicators for Abenomics, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reflationary policies.

images.alt_text: After Nissin Foods Holdings added more meat and toppings to its signature Cup Noodle products and raised prices by 5-8 per cent, sales rose by a 10th in April-September from a year earlier.

site_title: Emerging markets unlikely to trigger global recession
summary: Emerging markets are unlikely to trigger a global recession, according to recent analysis. China's fiscal deficit has stabilized, and global policymakers are poised to ease monetary policies, which will help stabilize growth. The risk of a systemic crisis similar to the 1997-98 scenario is deemed unlikely due to better control over domestic liquidity conditions, flexible exchange rates, and adequate foreign exchange reserves in many emerging markets. While domestic demand in developed markets remains strong, the global economy is expected to remain intact, with a steady but sub-par recovery.

site_title: Charity from Asia rich shifting towards impact investing: poll
summary: Asia's wealthy individuals are shifting towards impact investing, with 44% of ultra-high net worth individuals expecting to allocate 44% of their capital to impact investing over the next three years, according to a Credit Suisse report. This shift is expected to replace philanthropy as the dominant form of charitable giving, with the "feel-good" factor ranking top among factors. However, there are concerns that millennials may find impact investing too complex to handle, with 60% believing some forms of impact investing will remain too complex for the next generation.

site_title: dnata launches new premium lounge at T1
summary: dnata has launched a new premium lounge at Changi Airport's Terminal 1, catering to over 250,000 passengers annually. The 860 sq m lounge offers amenities such as a dining area, showers, and fully-equipped work zones, with a pan-Asian theme and modern Peranakan-styled decor. The lounge is open 24/7, with complimentary high-speed WiFi and a VIP room available for pre-bookings. This new lounge replaces dnata's existing Skyview lounge at T1, and the company also provides passenger and ramp handling, flight catering, cargo handling, and security services.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Sofa seats (above) are equipped with power outlets and charging points
The wallpaper at the dining area (above) is inspired by Peranakan culture.

site_title: Paris attacks renew US call to access encrypted communications
summary: US officials, including Senator Dianne Feinstein and Attorney-General Loretta Lynch, are renewing calls for limits on technology that prevents governments from spying on encrypted communications, citing the Paris attacks as a prime example. The calls come amid concerns that terrorists are using encryption to plan and execute attacks, with the CIA director stating that the technology makes it exceptionally difficult for intelligence services to have insight into terrorist planning. The debate highlights the balance between security and privacy, with companies such as Apple and Google resisting calls for new restrictions on encryption.

site_title: Stocks
summary: QAF Limited's Q315 revenue fell 5% y-o-y to S$243.2 million due to FX translation effects, with bakery and primary production segments showing growth. OCBC Investment Research expects "satisfactory" profitability for the year. Meanwhile, Overseas Education Ltd's Q315 revenue dropped 5.2% y-o-y due to soft student enrolment numbers, leading CIMB Research to trim its assumptions for enrolment numbers and annual school fee hike.

site_title: Asia-Pac institutional investors seen doubling property portfolio
summary: Asia-Pacific institutional investors are expected to double their property portfolio to US$500 billion by 2020, with a total investment of US$240 billion. The investors are driven by a search for higher returns, stable long-term returns, and a desire to mitigate financial burdens. Major investors, including Chinese, Japanese, and South Korean institutions, are expected to lead the investment surge, with direct investments in commercial assets reaching US$19 billion last year. The investments are expected to be split between direct acquisitions and indirect channels, with 60% going into real estate and 40% into commingled funds and other channels.

site_title: Indonesian stocks may be hazardous to your wealth
summary: Indonesian stocks appear attractive due to their low valuation, but investors remain cautious due to the country's vulnerability to global economic fluctuations. Projections for corporate earnings in Indonesia seem overly optimistic, and the country's economic climate is hindered by slowing inflation, declining exports, and a widening current account deficit. With the US Federal Reserve expected to raise interest rates, Indonesia's currency is likely to fall, further crimping corporate earnings and making the country a chronic underperformer in the stock market.

site_title: STI narrowly avoids 8th consecutive loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) narrowly avoided an eighth consecutive loss, ending with a 1.05-point gain to 2,916.78. The index's drift was subdued, with most of the action among its 30 components. Concerns include weak commodity prices, the impending US interest rate hike, and the threat of terror attacks. The market's resilience was attributed to the rebound in western markets on Monday, which some analysts saw as a sign that markets are adapting to terror-related events or responding to the need for monetary stimulus.

site_title: S'pore NODX beats forecasts but still down 0.5% in Oct
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 0.5% in October, beating forecasts but still down from the previous year. Economists predict a trade recession in Singapore until Q1 2016 due to weak global trade and strict foreign labor policies. Despite a 44.6% year-on-year increase in pharmaceutical exports, non-electronics NODX rose just 0.7%, while electronics NODX declined 3.2%. Shipments to China, Taiwan, and South Korea also fell, with only non-oil re-export (NORX) showing a 6.6% increase.

site_title: S'pore Reits increase perpetual bonds before new rules take effect
summary: Singaporean Reits are issuing record amounts of perpetual bonds to circumvent new debt limits, amid a property slump. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has capped Reits' borrowings at 45% of assets from next year, prompting landlords to use debt that can be treated as equity. Reits issued S$700 million of perpetual notes in 2015 and are likely to sell more, with Fitch Ratings predicting a further S$1 billion issuance. The move aims to reduce leverage and comply with stricter rules, as falling property values and rents tip the economy into further trouble.

site_title: Growing interest in postgrad studies
summary: More Asian students are pursuing postgraduate studies due to robust economic growth in the region, fueling demand for higher qualifications. Governments, such as Singapore, are also investing in workforce development, while universities compete for international students. According to a British Council report, postgraduate students now make up around a third of all higher education awards in eight leading countries. India and Indonesia are expected to have the largest growths in tertiary enrolments to 2024, with the US being the top destination for Indian students.

site_title: Wal-Mart earnings beat expectations; shares up
summary: Wal-Mart reported stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, with net profit of $3.304 billion and $1.03 per share, beating analysts' expectations of $1.03 per share. Same-store US sales have now booked its fifth straight gain, causing shares to rise over 2% in premarket trading.

site_title: Britain says Volkswagen must meet the costs of retesting vehicles
summary: Britain's transport minister Patrick McLoughlin stated that Volkswagen must meet the costs of retesting vehicles in the country due to the diesel and carbon dioxide emissions scandals. The German carmaker has affected around 1.2 million vehicles in Britain, and the Vehicle Certification Agency (VCA) will incur costs for retesting vehicle types. Volkswagen will have to cover these costs to demonstrate conformity.

site_title: Learning business through Asian lens
summary: Two French business schools aim to provide executives worldwide with insights into doing business in Asia through a unique lens. Annie Joseph, a senior executive at Baxter Healthcare in Singapore, received the Women Leadership Excellence Award 2015 for her leadership skills in Asia. Despite having 20 years of experience, she believes many organizations still hold misconceptions about succeeding in Asia. The initiative seeks to address these misconceptions and provide a more accurate understanding of the region's business landscape.

site_title: Home Depot quarterly sales rise 6.4%
summary: Home Depot Inc reported a 6.4% rise in quarterly net sales to US$21.82 billion, driven by strong demand from professional contractors and builders. Net income rose to US$1.73 billion, or US$1.35 per share, from US$1.54 billion, or US$1.15 per share, a year earlier. This marks the company's second consecutive quarter of sales growth.

site_title: Triyards beefs up product range with US$12.8m deal
summary: Triyards Holdings has secured a US$12.8 million contract to deliver four RAstar 3400 Azimuth Stern Drive Tugs to Greenbay Marine Pte Ltd. The tugs are expected to be delivered by early 2017 and will be used for escort operations in adverse sea and weather conditions. The contract adds to Triyards' growing earnings visibility for the financial year ending August 31, 2017, and expands the company's product and client bases. Triyards' orderbook now stands at US$564 million.

site_title: Landmark lower house elections
summary: Oman held landmark lower house elections, with a good voter turnout of 64% of voters under 45. The Shura Council gained more legislative powers, enabling it to study public budgets and query ministers. The election marked a turning point in the legislative body's history, following recent amendments to the Basic Law. 590 candidates vied for 85 seats, with electronic voting introduced for the first time. The Shura Council now participates in state budget studies and queries ministers, as part of a bicameral assembly with the State Council.

site_title: Universal Studios rides and more for 700 at Children for Children event
summary: More than 700 children from Singaporean schools participated in the annual "Children for Children" event at Universal Studios Singapore on November 17. The event, which raises funds for charity, featured performances by over 250 students from CHIJ (Kellock) and included a concert and SG50-themed productions. The event raised S$150,000, with major donors including CA Technologies and CWT Limited. The event aims to promote community service and appreciation for the less fortunate, with the remaining funds supporting the Sing50 Fund, which preserves and celebrates Singapore's musical heritage.

site_title: Russia offers US$50 million reward for help detaining Egypt plane bombers
summary: Russia is offering a $50 million reward for information leading to the detention of those responsible for placing a bomb on a Russian passenger jet that killed 224 people in Egypt last month. The Kremlin has vowed to hunt down those responsible and intensify air strikes on Islamist militants in Syria. This comes after the first public acknowledgment of a bomb causing the plane's breakup.

site_title: British inflation remains in negative territory
summary: British inflation remains in negative territory, holding at minus 0.1% in October, unchanged from September. This is the lowest level since March 1960, mirroring the April rate. Muted inflation suggests no interest rate hike is likely soon, according to economists. The data also comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, posing a challenge to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Helping to boost Oman's exports
summary: Oman's investment and export promotion agency, Ithraa, is helping boost the Sultanate's non-oil exports and attract foreign investment. Since 1997, Ithraa has assisted Omani businesses in identifying opportunities domestically and internationally, resulting in $10.71 billion in non-oil exports in 2014. The agency provides support services and information to help businesses set up and export from Oman, with a focus on targeting middle-class consumers in Asia, Africa, Europe, and North America. Ithraa's efforts have led to an increase in Omani firms exporting to international markets, creating jobs and driving economic growth.

site_title: Berlin Philharmonic's Beethoven marathon a missed opportunity
summary: Conductor Simon Rattle's upcoming Beethoven marathon at Carnegie Hall, featuring the Berlin Philharmonic's nine symphonies, has sparked criticism that it may be a missed opportunity. The marathon, which runs for five consecutive evenings, may not allow for a nuanced understanding of each symphony. Rattle's past programming, which often pairs Beethoven with contemporary works, has demonstrated his commitment to innovation and engagement with living composers. However, the Beethoven cycle may give the impression that classical music is stuck in tradition, overshadowing the orchestra's more daring recent initiatives.

site_title: G-20 leaders vow to crack down on terrorist financing
summary: Global leaders at the G-20 meeting have pledged to crack down on terrorist financing, with tighter border controls and increased intelligence sharing. Analysts warn that reducing ISIS's funding would hinder its ability to recruit soldiers and followers. The terrorist organization is estimated to have a wealth of $2 billion, largely generated from oil sales, taxation, and illicit activities such as antiquities theft and kidnapping. The West has been criticized for failing to impede ISIS's financial gains, and combined bombing remains the main strategy against the group in Syria.

site_title: Indonesia fends off pressure to cut benchmark interest rate
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has held its benchmark interest rate steady despite political pressure to cut it due to weak economic growth. Governor Agus Martowardojo cited global uncertainty and the potential US rate rise as reasons for caution. However, the bank lowered a reserve requirement, making 18 trillion rupiah (S$1.9 billion) available to banks to loan, which could indirectly lower interest rates. The move is seen as a first step towards easing monetary policy, increasing the chances of a rate cut in the next few months.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Q&M Dental plans to spin off its China manufacturing business through a listing on China's New Third Board, with Singapore Exchange having given its approval. Interra Resources sold a granite quarry in Indonesia to PT Sanmas Mekar Abadi for 39 billion rupiah. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada, while Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected revenue and operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Set another place at the table: Fido's coming to dinner
summary: Freshpet Inc, a gourmet food manufacturer, is revolutionizing the US$23.7 billion pet food industry with its high-quality, refrigerated pet food made with fresh ingredients. The company is among innovators winning over dog and cat owners with healthy chow comparable to human food. Companies like Colgate-Palmolive, Nestle, and Mars Petcare are responding with their own healthy and fresh pet food options, including customized blends and farm-to-table products, as sales of premium dog food surge 45% to US$10.5 billion since 2009.

images.alt_text: Freshpet is breaking into new territory with its refrigerated dog meals sold in their own branded refrigerated display cases inside nearly 15,000 US stores.

site_title: Paris attacks: US House leader calls for pause in Syrian refugee program
summary: US House Speaker Paul Ryan has called for a pause in the Syrian refugee program, citing security concerns following the Paris attacks. He joined 49 state governors in urging President Barack Obama to review the vetting process to prevent jihadists from entering the country. The pause would allow for a full assessment of the vetting process and ensure the safety of American citizens.

site_title: Why Fannie and Freddie survived
summary: The US government's conservatorship of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two giant housing entities, has led to their survival despite initial plans to dismantle them. Since 2008, the government has provided $187 billion in aid, making them profitable with $241 billion in profits for the US Treasury. However, the entities' continued dominance in the $9 trillion mortgage market poses concerns about taxpayer exposure to potential losses. The government's reluctance to ease them out is due to fear of stifling the housing recovery and protecting the 30-year-fixed-rate mortgage, which Americans prefer.

images.alt_text: Fannie Mae said on Monday 36,583 single-family homes whose mortgages it guarantees were in the initial impact area of Harvey, the most powerful storm to hit Texas in more than 50 years.

site_title: US industrial output falls for second straight month
summary: US industrial production fell 0.2% in October, its second consecutive decline, according to the Federal Reserve. The decline was driven by a 1.5% drop in the mining index and a 2.5% decline in utilities. Manufacturing output rose 0.4% due to increases in durable goods, but overall output declined, reducing the percentage of industrial capacity in use to 77.5%. The drop raises concerns about the robustness of fourth-quarter economic growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 5.53 points to 1,661.53, as 2.18 billion lots valued at RM2.04 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 533 to 379, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after Wal-Mart results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday after Wal-Mart and Home Depot reported better-than-expected earnings, alleviating concerns about a retail slowdown. The Dow Jones rose 12.5 points, the S&P 500 gained 1.34 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 6.70 points. These gains follow a sharp selloff in the retail sector last week. The positive earnings reports and stable market sentiment have investors optimistic despite ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Starwood deal means more points for customers: Marriott CEO
summary: Marriott International CEO Arne Sorenson stated that the US$12.2 billion acquisition of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. will provide "more and more points" to customers, benefiting from the combined company's 5,500 hotels with 1.1 million rooms worldwide. The acquisition is seen as a positive for consumers, despite increased competition from online travel services. The merged company will operate under 30 brands, including Marriott's and Starwood's popular rewards programs.

site_title: Hyflux taking 50% stake in Indonesia's PT Oasis
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-listed company, is investing S$50 million in PT Oasis, a bottled drinking water manufacturer in Indonesia, for a 50% stake. PT Oasis has revenues of S$73 million and a 36% year-over-year growth rate. The acquisition aims to provide Hyflux with a distribution platform in Indonesia and contribute to future earnings. The investment will be made in tranches, with conditions including regulatory approval and PT Oasis' net profit after tax not being negative for FY15 and FY16.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong pays tribute to Kwek Leng Joo
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid tribute to property tycoon Kwek Leng Joo, who passed away suddenly. Lee expressed his condolences to Kwek's wife, Alice, describing him as a champion of the environment and leader of corporate social responsibility. The PM also mentioned being shocked and saddened upon hearing the news while in Turkey.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has conveyed his condolences to property tycoon Kwek Leng Joo's wife, Alice Kwek, on the death of her husband.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on Wall St as jitters from Paris attacks ease
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.2% on Tuesday, driven by a Wall Street rally that eased concerns following the Paris attacks. Most Asian markets followed suit, with energy and IT stocks leading gains. Hong Kong-listed Citic Securities rose 2.1% after announcing plans to select a new chairman. The Hang Seng index reached 22,264.25 points, while the China Enterprises Index gained 1.0%.

site_title: Triyards extends product range to escort tugs through US$12.8m deal
summary: Triyards Holdings has secured a US$12.8 million contract with Greenbay Marine Pte Ltd to deliver four RAstar 3400 Azimuth Stern Drive Tugs, which will be used for escort operations in adverse sea and weather conditions. The newbuild contract is expected to be completed by early 2017 and adds to the company's growing earnings visibility. This deal expands Triyards' product and client bases, and its orderbook now stands at US$564 million. The company's diversification strategy aims to build a diversified orderbook.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange is monitoring companies' financial disclosures, warning of audit infractions if necessary. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan promised upgraded North-South and East-West rail lines by 2018. The Housing & Development Board launched 12,411 flats for sale. Neptune Orient Lines Limited confirmed talks on a potential acquisition. Singapore's non-oil domestic exports slipped 0.5% in October, while the economic cost of terrorism reached US$52.9 billion in 2014. The Straits Times Index closed mixed, narrowly avoiding an eighth straight loss.

site_title: After market crash, China mulls single 'super-regulator': sources
summary: China is considering merging its banking, insurance, and securities regulators into a single 'super-commission' in response to the 2015 stock market crash, which saw markets drop 40% due to poor inter-agency coordination. The move aims to reform China's markets and improve coordination among regulators. The proposal is part of a broader goal to address the issues that led to the crash, which embarrassed the government and delayed planned market improvements.

site_title: US consumer prices rise, may further support rate hike views
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in October, reversing a two-month decline, as gasoline and other goods costs increased. The modest inflation growth may support expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next month, which could bring inflation closer to its 2.0% target. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, also rose 0.2%, driven by rent and medical costs. The increase is a tentative sign that inflation is stabilizing, giving the Fed confidence that inflation will gradually move toward its target.

site_title: Tributes continue pouring in for CDL's Kwek Leng Joo
summary: CDL deputy chairman Kwek Leng Joo, 62, died in his sleep from a heart attack in Turkey on Monday. Tributes poured in from Singapore's leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Tony Tan Keng Yam, who praised his environmental advocacy, corporate social responsibility, and philanthropic works. Kwek was a champion for the environment and CSR, and had made significant contributions to Singapore's development, including supporting the Botanic Gardens' Unesco World Heritage Site bid. He was awarded the Public Service Medal and Public Service Star for his services to the nation.

site_title: Foreign companies scrap Paris events after terror attacks
summary: Foreign companies, including ABN Amro, Sharp, and Airbnb, have cancelled or postponed events in Paris due to security concerns following the city's terror attacks, which killed at least 129 people. Many companies are hesitant to travel to Paris, citing disruptions from security checks, and some have advised employees to avoid travel altogether. The cancellations reflect France's struggle to reassure businesspeople and tourists about its ability to maintain security.

site_title: Wall Street urged to improve its cybersecurity defences
summary: The US Treasury Department is urging Wall Street banks to strengthen their cybersecurity defenses against cyber-attacks, as President Barack Obama's administration views the finance industry as a "treasure trove" for high-tech criminals. Deputy Treasury Secretary Sarah Bloom Raskin recommended multi-step identity checks and limiting high-level access to only those necessary for business operations. The call comes after a multi-year criminal enterprise targeting financial and publishing companies was revealed, and payment-system firms are considered attractive targets due to their role in transferring monetary value.

site_title: Greece says secures deal to unlock 12 bn euros bailout funds
summary: Greece has reached a deal with its international creditors to unblock 12 billion euros in bailout loans, worth 18.2 billion SGD. The agreement includes 48 measures, including reforms on home foreclosures, which will protect around 60% of indebted households from having their primary residence seized. The funds, including 10 billion euros to recapitalise Greek banks, will be unlocked on Friday, avoiding Greece's potential exit from the eurozone. The deal is seen as a "painful compromise" that enabled Greece to avoid bankruptcy and stay in the euro.

site_title: PBOC will inject funds if IPOs push money rates higher: ANZ
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will inject funds into the financial system if initial public offerings (IPOs) lead to higher money rates, according to ANZ. China's IPOs are expected to unlock up to $290 billion, and if this leads to higher rates, the PBOC will stabilize the market through open-market operations. The central bank has been providing liquidity through open-market operations for the past three weeks, and recently injected 10 billion yuan via seven-day reverse repos. The yield on 10-year government bonds remained little changed at 3.16%.

site_title: China to expand quota, number of shares investors can trade on HK-Shanghai Connect
summary: China plans to expand the trading quota and number of shares investors can trade on the Hong Kong-Shanghai Stock Connect, according to Fang Xinghai, a China Securities Regulatory Commission official. The regulator will also continue to push forward with the Hong Kong-Shenzhen Stock Connect scheme. This move aims to increase market participation and liquidity, potentially benefiting investors and the Chinese stock market.

site_title: Australia says will restart trade talks with Indonesia early next year
summary: Australia plans to restart trade talks with Indonesia early next year, aiming to reach an agreement within 12 months. The talks were put on hold in 2013 due to rising diplomatic tensions, but Australian Trade Minister Andrew Robb says both countries are ready to re-engage. The talks will be led by Robb's delegation of over 300 businesspeople, following a meeting between Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Indonesian President Joko Widodo to mend diplomatic and economic ties.

site_title: SGX aims to launch bond trading platform in Q1
summary: SGX plans to launch a corporate bond trading platform in Q1 2016 to boost revenue and diversify its product suite. The move comes as global investment banks scale back in the fixed income segment due to regulatory changes. CEO Loh Boon Chye views the platform as a way to position SGX as a multi-asset platform, expanding its offerings beyond equities.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) is looking to launch a corporate bond trading platform in the first quarter of 2016 as it seeks to expand its product suite in an effort to boost revenue, its CEO said.

site_title: Terrorism cost world a record US$52.9b in 2014: report
summary: The Global Terrorism Index (GTI) reports that terrorism cost the world a record $52.9 billion in 2014, a 61% increase from the previous year, with 32,658 lives lost. ISIS and Boko Haram are responsible for 51% of global fatalities, with Boko Haram becoming the world's deadliest terrorist group. Terrorism is concentrated in five countries: Afghanistan, Iraq, Nigeria, Pakistan, and Syria, accounting for 78% of deaths. The majority of deaths occur in non-Western countries, and lone wolf attackers are the main perpetrators of terrorism in the West.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

The cost of terrorism to world economies reached a record US$52.9 billion in 2014, up 61 per cent from the previous year's total of US$32.9 billion, and a 10-fold increase since the Sept 11 attack on the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in 2001.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia taps banks for US dollar funding programme
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Bhd has hired Barclays PLC, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, and RHB Capital Bhd to arrange financing through a US dollar medium-term note programme. This comes as the airline's major shareholders evaluate "all strategic options" after its CEO sought investors for a potential private buyout. The move follows a research report criticizing the airline's accounting practices, which led to a seven-year low in its shares. AirAsia's founders are considering a management-led buyout, with the airline's shares currently under evaluation.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed as STI narrowly avoids 8th straight loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) narrowly avoided an eighth consecutive loss, closing at 2,916.78 with a nett gain of 1.05 points. The initial rebound was attributed to leftover short covering from the previous day's US market jump, but the index eventually drifted into the red in the late afternoon. Concerns over weak commodity prices, an impending US interest rate hike, and global growth slowdown continue to weigh on markets, with no change in turnover totals or composition.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close more than 1% higher
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.22% to 19,630.63, driven by a weaker yen, and the Topix index gained 0.93% to 1,586.11. The gains followed solid performances on Wall Street and recover losses from the previous day due to the Paris attacks.

site_title: ECB asking top banks to hold 10.1% CET 1 capital on average
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has announced that top banks in the euro zone will be required to hold 10.1% Common Equity Tier 1 capital on average, with globally significant institutions facing a 50 basis point increase. The ECB's Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process aims to strengthen banks' capital buffers, with individual banks' requirements varying between 8% and 14%. Most banks already meet the new requirements, but some are working on plans to raise capital. The move aims to enhance the resilience of the euro zone banking system.

site_title: Korean billionaire's gains add up as pharma stock jumps 900%
summary: South Korean billionaire Lim Sung-ki's fortune has increased to approximately $2.7 billion after his companies, Hanmi Science Co and Hanmi Pharmaceutical Co, surged 971% and 805% respectively over the past 12 months. The gains were largely due to licensing deals with global drugmakers, including Janssen Pharmaceuticals and Eli Lilly Co, for potential treatments of diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis.

site_title: Australia shares rally; NZ inches up
summary: Australian shares rose 2.3% on Tuesday, driven by broad-based gains across sectors as concerns about a fallout from the Paris attacks receded. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,118.20, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index edged up 0.099%. These gains followed a 0.9% decline on Monday.

site_title: China to expand Singapore RQFII quota to 100b yuan
summary: China plans to expand Singapore's Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) quota to 100 billion yuan, according to a central bank statement. This expansion was first announced by Chinese President Xi Jinping during his visit to Singapore in early November. The move aims to increase investment in the Chinese yuan in Singapore.

site_title: Barclays picks new chief operating officer for investment bank
summary: Barclays has appointed Mike Bagguley as its new chief operating officer for the investment bank, tasked with accelerating the restructuring of the business. Bagguley, who previously oversaw the reduction and reshaping of the macro business, will report to investment bank chief executive Tom King. The move aims to cut costs and improve profitability as the bank slims down its investment bank. Bagguley will also align infrastructure functions and join the executive committee. The bank has been following a strategy to shift focus from trading activities to areas less affected by regulation.

site_title: Rail commuters will have 'almost new' North-South, East-West lines in 2018: Khaw
summary: Singapore's North-South and East-West rail lines will be upgraded by 2018, with "almost new" systems, according to Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. The upgrade includes replacing old electric motors, upgrading the power supply system, and increasing maintenance resources. The government aims to improve safety and reliability, with the goal of increasing capacity by up to 20%. The upgrade will be carried out through seven key elements, including ramping up maintenance, having a strong engineering core, and integrating the industry structure.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end up as Paris attacks effect fades
summary: South Korean shares and the won currency rose on Tuesday, following a relief rally in US stocks after the Paris attacks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 1.1% at 1,963.58 points, while the won closed at 1,170.4 per dollar, up 0.3% from Monday. Investors drew comfort from the US market's recovery, easing concerns about global economic fallout from the attacks.

site_title: China plans tighter e-commerce checks to tackle shoddy goods
summary: China plans to increase online e-commerce inspections to tackle low-quality goods, including counterfeit products and shoddy merchandise. The State Administration for Industry and Commerce will step up random quality checks and cooperate with e-commerce platforms to address the issue. Those found selling non-compliant goods will be required to stop sales, and platforms will be held responsible for removing the products. Failure to cooperate will result in the matter being referred to local regulators. The move aims to protect Chinese consumers and improve the country's reputation in the global market.

site_title: Singapore landlords discover perpetual debt is the new equity
summary: Singapore landlords are loading up on bonds labeled as equity to circumvent new debt curbs, amid a property slump. Real-estate investment trusts (REITs) issued a record $700 million of perpetual notes in 2015, and more are likely to follow, as the Monetary Authority of Singapore caps borrowings at 45% of assets. The move aims to reduce leverage, but investors are seeking yield in a low-growth environment, with the FTSE Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust Index down 11.4% this year.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rally at open
summary: European stocks rose sharply in opening trade Tuesday, driven by investor resilience following deadly Paris terror attacks. The CAC 40 index gained 0.96%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and London's FTSE 100 rose 0.91% and 1.15%, respectively. Most Asian markets also advanced, as fears about the European economy's impact from the attacks began to fade. Despite US trade tensions and a strong dollar, the rally continued, with mining and healthcare stocks propelling gains.

site_title: Indonesia considers new tax incentives for employees: minister
summary: Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for Economics Darmin Nasution announced plans to consider offering tax incentives for employees to increase purchasing power and help employers. The government has introduced various tax incentives this year, including increasing the income tax threshold and offering free corporate tax for some investors. The Finance Ministry plans to cut income tax rates and introduce a tax amnesty pending parliamentary approval. Despite previous tax incentives, state revenue is expected to be US$11 billion below target this year.

site_title: China: Stocks flat as small-caps slump on profit-taking
summary: China's stocks ended Tuesday flat, with the CSI300 index falling 0.2% to 3,758.39, as small caps slumped due to profit-taking. Despite fears after Paris terror attacks, the yuan's potential inclusion in the IMF's global currency basket offered some support. Banking, energy, and property shares were firmer, but gains were offset by a 2.2% drop in Shenzhen's ChiNext start-up board. Traders are concerned about the resumption of Chinese initial public offerings, which could put pressure on the market.

site_title: BI holds rate at 7.5%, lowers reserves requirement
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its benchmark interest rate at 7.5% as expected, despite Vice-President Jusuf Kalla's call to lower it to boost weak growth. The bank also lowered the statutory reserves ratio to 7.5% from 8%, effective Dec 1. The decision was in line with market expectations, which anticipated no policy changes before a possible US rate hike in December.

site_title: Paris attacks: Suspected mastermind cast as macabre jihadi
summary: French investigators believe Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a 28-year-old Belgian, masterminded the deadliest terrorist assault in peacetime France, killing at least 129 people. Abaaoud joined the Islamic State a few years ago and is linked to a failed train attack and a plot to attack a church in Paris. He was tracked by Belgian security in 2014 after appearing in a video dragging corpses to a mass grave in Syria. Abaaoud's trail went cold after he was thwarted in attempts to kill Belgian police, and he is believed to have returned to Syria.

site_title: Dollar falls against emerging currencies as oil gains
summary: The euro fell to a seven-month low against the US dollar, trading at $1.0656, after a European Central Bank official hinted at further monetary easing. The euro's decline was fueled by expectations of a US interest rate hike before 2016 and the bank's vast bond-buying program. Meanwhile, emerging currencies like the South Korean won, Indonesian rupiah, and Malaysian ringgit rose against the dollar, driven by revived risk-buying interest and a rally in regional stock and oil markets.

site_title: Asia-Pacific leaders in Philippines under security shadow
summary: US President Barack Obama and other Asia-Pacific leaders arrived in the Philippines for a two-day APEC summit, amidst global security concerns following the Paris attacks. The summit will focus on trade unity, but terrorism and territorial disputes, including China's assertive claims in the South China Sea, are likely to dominate discussions. Obama vowed to pursue the Islamic State group ruthlessly, while Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to assert control over the disputed waters. The Philippines has sought to firm up alliances to counter China's influence, with US military presence in the region.

site_title: It's pineapple shirts for world leaders at Apec summit in Manila
summary: The Philippines is hosting the Apec summit in Manila, where world leaders will wear traditional "barong" shirts, semi-sheer and partially made from pineapple fibre, at the summit opening. Filipino designer Paul Cabral created the 21 custom shirts, embroidered with individual symbols of each country, in an effort to avoid past ridicule. The shirts are a mix of traditional cloth and modern materials, including silk, and include secret satin linings to prevent itching. The move aims to showcase Filipino talent and culture, with the designer confident that his design will not be the butt of jokes.

site_title: Russia's security chief says plane over Sinai downed in 'terror act'
summary: Russia's security chief, Alexander Bortnikov, told President Vladimir Putin that a plane carrying 224 people over Sinai was downed due to a "terror attack". Experts believe the plane disintegrated in midair due to a bomb with the equivalent of a kilo of TNT. The incident occurred on November 17, 2015, resulting in significant loss of life. Bortnikov's statement confirmed the cause of the downing, labeling it a "terror act".

images.alt_text: Russia's security chief told President Vladimir Putin that a plane carrying 224 people over Sinai was downed due to a "terror attack," the Kremlin said on Tuesday.

site_title: NOL confirms talks on potential acquisition still on
summary: NOL confirms ongoing discussions about a potential acquisition, despite previous announcements. The shipping company stated it is not aware of any undisclosed information that may explain recent trading activity in its shares. NOL emphasized compliance with listing rules and advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its securities. As of 1:52 pm, the counter rose five cents to S$1.115, with 38.4 million shares changing hands, amid ongoing discussions.

site_title: HDB launches 12,411 flats for sale in 25 towns
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched 12,411 flats for sale in 25 towns, the largest sales exercise in its history. The flats include 7,061 BTO and 5,350 balance flats, offering 25,837 flats for sale this year. The launch meets HDB's commitment to 15,000 BTO flats and provides more choices for buyers under new policies, including higher income ceilings and enhanced CPF housing grants.

site_title: VW's European car sales, market share slip after emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen's European car sales and market share declined in October, following the emissions scandal, with a 2.7% year-over-year increase in new passenger car registrations to 1.14 million vehicles. This marked the 26th consecutive month of growth, but at a slower pace. The overall European market continued to grow, with the Association of European Carmakers (ACEA) attributing the slowdown to Volkswagen's issues. The German carmaker's market share slipped, contributing to the decline.

site_title: 'Shadow banking' hit US$80t in 2014: regulator
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) reported that non-bank "shadow banking" reached a value of US$80 trillion in 2014, accounting for 80% of global GDP and 90% of global financial system assets. The FSB tracks shadow banking activities to identify systemic risks and has devised a monitoring framework to mitigate risks. The sector's value increased by US$2 trillion across 2014, from US$35 trillion in 2013, and represents 30% of overall non-bank financial sector assets and 60% of the GDP of participating jurisdictions.

site_title: Paris attacks put focus on Southeast Asia's terrorism fight
summary: Global leaders are pressing Southeast Asian nations to cooperate more to combat terrorism, following the deadly Islamic State attacks in Paris that killed at least 129 people. The attacks, planned in Syria and carried out in France, highlight the need for cross-border approaches to countering militarism. Southeast Asian governments are urged to share information on financing and adopt a common framework for fighting terrorism in the region. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is expected to condemn the attacks and raise the issue of terrorism at its summit, with US President Barack Obama joining the gathering.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rebound after Paris-fuelled sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded strongly on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.38% to 22,315.18, following a sell-off on Monday triggered by the Paris terror attacks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter jumping 1.04%. The gains were attributed to a decrease in global market volatility and investor confidence.

site_title: New technology development centre to prototype inventions from Singapore
summary: The Invention Development Fund (IDF) has unveiled a multi-million-dollar investment in a technology development centre in Singapore, aiming to prototype inventions and translate them into valuable products and businesses. The centre will utilize external technology and expertise to accelerate innovation and minimize risk. The move is part of IDF's commitment to developing, protecting, and distributing inventions from around the world, with a focus on driving innovation in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region. The centre is expected to create new jobs and sources of growth, solidifying Singapore's position as a global hub for innovation.

site_title: CIMB sees bad loan provisions peaking in Indonesia, Thailand
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, sees peak bad loan provisions in Indonesia and Thailand, but expects improvement in 2016. CIMB's Indonesian unit has already seen the peak in provisions, while its Thai unit is improving. The bank's CEO, Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz, is optimistic about next year's prospects due to these developments.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up, Apple supplier Hon Hai leads tech rally
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.8% on Tuesday, led by technology shares and Hon Hai Precision Industry, Apple's key supplier, which reported solid third-quarter profit. Gains in US stocks overnight also boosted domestic sentiment. The main TAIEX index closed at 8,443.10.

site_title: AIA, Konica Minolta call out to startups to develop integrated healthcare delivery
summary: AIA Group Limited and Konica Minolta Inc. launched a 12-week digital health accelerator programme in Singapore to support startups in developing an integrated healthcare delivery system. The programme, called the "AIA - Konica Minolta Digital Health Accelerator", aims to provide resources, expertise, and mentor networks to innovative startups in digital healthcare. Up to 10 companies will be selected and guided through their business growth and development plans, with a deadline for applications set for January 31, 2016. The programme is part of AIA's efforts to address the estimated US$305 billion protection gap in Singapore's healthcare system.

site_title: Asia: Stocks surge after Wall St takes Paris attacks in stride
summary: Asian stocks rose 1.6% to 1.7% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 6-week low after Wall Street took the Paris attacks in stride. The US stock market surged 1.4% and 1.5% on Monday, with investors expecting limited long-term impact on the global economy. The dollar rose to a 1-week high, while the euro dipped to a 7-month trough. The rally was driven by market consensus that the attacks have a limited impact on the stock market, and investor focus shifted to a potential rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December.

site_title: S&P upgrades Qantas rating from 'junk' status
summary: Qantas has upgraded its credit rating from 'junk' to 'BBB-' by Standard & Poor's, marking a significant turnaround for the Australian carrier. The airline completed a profit turnaround this year, driven by lower fuel prices and a more conservative financial framework. Qantas' revised framework is considered more prudent and creditor-friendly than previously announced policies. The upgrade comes after the airline posted a A$557 million annual net profit in 2015, reversing a net loss of A$2.84 billion in the previous year. The rating change reflects Qantas' efforts to improve its financial position.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysian shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 11.44 points to 1,667.44. Gainers outnumbered losers 222 to 44, with 150 million lots valued at RM51 million traded.

site_title: Quick take: Singapore seen entrenched in a trade recession till Q1 2016: ANZ
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports dipped 0.5% in October from a year ago, with a drop in electronic exports outweighing a rise in non-electronic exports. This marks the first decline in exports since April. The trade recession is expected to last until Q1 2016, according to ANZ.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Big hedge funds trimmed Apple stakes during Q3 share slump
summary: US hedge funds trimmed their Apple stakes during Q3, with shares declining 12% to close at $110.30 on Sept 30. Top funds, including Adage Capital Partners, Bridgewater Associates, and Coatue Management LLC, reduced their holdings by 4-20%. The sales may have protected against losses, but also could have occurred before July 20 when the stock reached its highest close of the quarter.

site_title: Noble Group 'confident' of meeting Moody's targets amid review
summary: Noble Group Ltd said it remains confident of meeting Moody's Investors Service targets despite the agency placing its ratings under review for a downgrade. The commodity trader reported a 84% drop in quarterly profit and under pressure on liquidity, but the company's quarterly results showed a return to positive cash flow. The rating review will focus on Noble's ability to improve liquidity, raise capital, and reduce leverage over the next two to three months.

site_title: MOF accepts 31 of 70 suggestions on draft income tax Bill
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has accepted 31 out of 70 suggestions on the draft Income Tax (Amendment) Bill 2016, following a public consultation exercise. The draft Bill aims to implement tax changes announced in Budget 2015 and other system reviews. The MOF will revise the draft Bill based on the accepted suggestions.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore shares opened higher, rising 0.67% to 2,935.41, following a rally on Wall Street overnight. The Straits Times Index gained 19.68 points, with 73.2 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 119 to 24, with Stratech Group, Nam Cheong, and Golden Agri-Resources among the most active counters.

site_title: Inaugural Singapore-Shanghai financial forum launched
summary: The inaugural Singapore-Shanghai Financial Forum was launched on November 17, 2015, with over 100 senior industry professionals from both cities in attendance. The one-day forum aimed to strengthen financial ties between Singapore and Shanghai, focusing on topics such as the "One Belt, One Road" initiative, offshore renminbi markets, and financial technology innovation. Co-organised by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Shanghai Municipal Financial Services Office, the forum marked a new start for deeper and more comprehensive cooperation between the two financial centers.

site_title: Australia police in extremist 'shoot on sight' training
