The euro slipped to US$1.0720 and 131.31 yen, while the dollar rose to 122.50 yen. Japan's economy slipped back into recession in the third quarter, adding to the risk-off mood. The eurozone's struggles, coupled with expectations of increased European Central Bank stimulus, further pressured the euro. Dealers moved into assets seen as less risky, such as the yen, in times of uncertainty.

site_title: CDL deputy chairman Kwek Leng Joo has died
summary: CDL deputy chairman Kwek Leng Joo, 62, has died. He was also chairman of CDL's Corporate Social Responsibility & Corporate Governance and a non-executive director of Hong Leong Finance. No further details are available.

images.alt_text: City Developments Ltd (CDL) deputy chairman Kwek Leng Joo, 62, has died.

site_title: Seah Kian Peng to take over duties of NTUC FairPrice's group CEO from Jan 1 (Amended)
summary: NTUC FairPrice has announced that Seah Kian Peng will take over as group CEO from January 1, 2016, succeeding Tan Kian Chew, who will step down after 23 years of service. Tan Chew focused on NTUC FairPrice's social mission, absorbing the impact of the goods & services tax and introducing discounts for seniors and pioneers. Under his leadership, the cooperative grew to become Singapore's leading retailer, with annual sales growth from $752 million to $3.2 billion. Seah Peng, who has worked in both public and private sectors, will continue to enhance NTUC FairPrice's social mission.

site_title: HSL Constructor to design and build Singapore's third desalination plant in Tuas
summary: Singapore's third desalination plant in Tuas, expected to start operations in 2017, has been awarded to HSL Constructor Pte Ltd at a tender price of S$217 million. The plant will add 30 million gallons of water per day to Singapore's supply, increasing the current 25% desalinated water capacity. The plant will be owned and operated by PUB, the national water agency. This new addition aims to meet 25% of future water demand in 2060, as part of PUB's long-term water supply strategy.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall in line with overseas markets; tech, transport sink
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on Monday, following overseas markets, due to terror attacks in Paris and Japan's recession. Tech and transport shares declined, with TSMC and China Airlines experiencing significant drops. The electronics and financial subindices also fell, while the transport subindex dropped 3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.795 per US dollar.

site_title: Ramsey the Bear who called S&P 500 correction sends new warning
summary: Doug Ramsey, chief investment officer of Leuthold Weeden Capital Management, warns of a potential 20-25% correction in the S&P 500 in 2016 due to deteriorating revenue and profits. He notes that valuations are higher than pre-selloff levels, with the S&P 500 trading at 1.8 times sales. Industrial stocks are also overvalued, priced at 20 times earnings, the highest in over a decade. This contradicts Ramsey's previous call of the broad 2011 rally, highlighting concerns about the economy and companies' ability to boost earnings.

site_title: China's economy to grow at around 7% this year: Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country's economy is expected to grow at around 7% this year, maintaining a medium to high growth rate. This announcement was made during the G-20 Summit in Turkey. The growth rate is a significant indicator for China's economic stability and could alleviate pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Oil prices up on geopolitical tensions sparked by Paris attacks
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday following the Paris attacks, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 27 cents to $41.01 and Brent crude up 50 cents to $44.97. The surge was attributed to geopolitical tensions, but analysts expect prices to remain restricted by a global crude supply glut. French military efforts in Syria sparked fears of escalating tensions in the Middle East, but a strong dollar and oversupply also tempered enthusiasm, with prices unlikely to rise significantly in the long term.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine completes upgrading of two cruise vessels
summary: Sembcorp Marine completed the upgrade of two cruise vessels, Pacific Eden and Pacific Aria, at its Admiralty yard, marking a record for the company with 12 cruise ships repaired, upgraded, and refurbished in a single year. The upgrades were done concurrently and included work for several major cruise lines, including P&O Cruises (Australia), Carnival Cruise Line, and Royal Caribbean Cruises. The successful project showcases SembMarine's capabilities in cruise ship repair and refurbishment.

site_title: Noble promotes global head of oil liquids to newly created president of Noble Americas
summary: NOBLE Group has promoted Jeff Frase to president of Noble Americas, effective immediately. Frase, who was previously global head of oil liquids, will oversee client coverage, stakeholder relationships, and business activity in the Americas for the commodities group. This new role reflects the increasing importance of the Americas to Noble Group's global footprint and profitability.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Regional tensions, Paris attacks hang over APEC summit
summary: Regional tensions and security concerns following the Paris attacks will overshadow the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Manila, where leaders from the US, China, and Japan are expected to attend. The Philippines has deployed 30,000 police and soldiers to secure the summit, despite no credible threats. Tensions over the South China Sea will also be a topic, with the Philippines vowing to keep it off the agenda but allowing it to be discussed at a concluding retreat. The summit aims to boost trade and growth, but market uncertainty and protectionist pressures may hinder efforts.

site_title: Asia: Markets down after Paris attacks, Japan in recession
summary: Asian markets declined following the Paris attacks, with the euro losing ground, amid concerns about security in Europe and its impact on the struggling eurozone economy. The attacks also added to existing uncertainty in markets, which had ended last week on a low due to worries about the global economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 13.86 points to 1,645.05. Volume was 92.4 million lots worth RM30.8 million. The market saw more losers than gainers, with a ratio of 57 to 249.

site_title: The nine lives of Russia's Hermitage cats
summary: The Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia, has a long-standing tradition of having a large feline population, with over 70 cats serving as pest control for the museum's sprawling cellars. The cats have been a part of the museum since the 18th century and have survived wars, invasions, and even the Nazi siege of Leningrad during World War II. Today, the cats are beloved by tourists and have become a popular attraction, with the museum even considering copyrighting their name and hosting an annual holiday in their honor.

site_title: Most Singaporeans believe in job loyalty, onus on employers to groom staff: survey
summary: A survey conducted by recruitment firm Hays found that 59% of Singaporeans believe in job loyalty, wanting to stay with an employer for more than five years. The survey suggests that employers should focus on staff development and loyalty, as these are mutually inclusive. Another 30% of respondents plan to stay with an employer for up to five years.

site_title: Asian airlines fall on fear Paris attacks will curb tourism
summary: Asian airlines' shares plummeted as concerns over the Paris attacks raised fears of a decline in tourism, negatively impacting the tourism-related sectors. Eva Airways, China Southern Airlines, and China Eastern Airlines dropped 7.8%, 4.8%, and 4.7%, respectively. Analyst Zhang Qi attributed the decline to the "uncertain situation in France" and "broadly risk-off" market sentiment. The drop in airline shares reflects the potential impact of the attacks on tourism, which could have long-term consequences for the industry.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday after Paris attacks
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, November 16, 2015, following the Paris attacks by Islamist militants, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 29.64 points or 1.01% to 2,896.04. The decline was driven by jittery investor sentiments across Asian markets.

site_title: Thai Q3 GDP grows 1.0% q/q, better than forecast
summary: Thailand's economy expanded 1.0% in the third quarter, beating expectations, driven by stronger public spending and the service sector. This marks a reversal of the economy's recent contraction, with annual growth at 2.9%. The better-than-expected growth may alleviate concerns about the country's economy, which has struggled since the army seized power in 2014.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy expanded 1.0 per cent in the third quarter from the previous three months, more than expected on stronger public spending and the service sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower after Paris horror
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.96% as investors reacted to the weekend terror attacks in Paris. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,958.28, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index dropped 1.63%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 2.02%. The decline was attributed to global market uncertainty and nervousness following the attacks.

site_title: Demand for risk and compliance specialists to remain high in 2016: Randstad
summary: Risk and compliance specialists are expected to see a higher salary increase in 2016, with a 3-5% rise, compared to general banking colleagues, according to Randstad. Demand for these experts is expected to remain high due to the growing complexity of Singapore's regulatory environment. This is driven by the creation of a Smart Financial Centre and increased regulation, leading to a doubling of compliance teams and recruitment of specialists focused on regulation, policy development, and risk assessment. Banking operations will see a greater demand for fresh graduates, while sales relationship managers will be in high demand.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Risk and compliance specialists are expected to enjoy a greater increase in average salary compared to their general banking colleagues, according to recruitment firm Randstad.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 1.70%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 1.70% on Monday, following Japan's second consecutive quarter of contracted gross domestic production, and the strengthening yen after terrorist attacks in France. The Nikkei 225 index fell 332.95 points to 19,263.96, while the Topix index dropped 1.67% to 1,559.34.

site_title: Broker's take: Paris attacks to reinforce predisposition towards lower global stock prices, says DBS
summary: DBS Bank's chief investment officer Lim Say Boon believes the Paris attacks won't have a lasting impact on global stock prices, as markets were already correcting before the event. Global equities were expected to weaken in December due to a slowing global economy and potential US Federal Reserve rate hike. The attacks were seen as a "tragic but unsurprising" event, reinforcing the bank's previous warnings about a US rate hike and a Chinese equities rally running out of steam.

site_title: Paris attacks expose US 'failures': lawmakers
summary: US lawmakers criticize President Barack Obama's strategy against the Islamic State, calling it a failure that could lead to more attacks. The attacks in Paris, which killed 129, exposed weaknesses in the US approach, with some lawmakers arguing that the US has allowed the group to establish a "sanctuary" in Syria and Iraq. The US has been conducting air strikes and targeting the group's leaders, but lawmakers say more needs to be done to address the conflict. Obama and his advisors vow to intensify military coordination and intelligence sharing with France, but details on how to change the US strategy remain unclear.

site_title: Rex Oman's US$8.21m share subscription in Masirah Oil completed
summary: Rex Oman's US$8.21m share subscription in Masirah Oil Ltd was completed on Nov 12, 2015, with a 57.6% stake in the company. Masirah Oil, a 64% subsidiary of Lime Petroleum Plc, issued 9,000 new shares to raise US$12.8m. The remaining shares were subscribed by Petroci, an existing shareholder. The capital injection will fund drilling activities and general working capital.

site_title: UN chief Ban Ki Moon to visit North Korea: Yonhap
summary: UN chief Ban Ki Moon is set to visit North Korea, the first head of the world body to visit the isolated state in over 20 years. He will meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, and the visit is seen as a significant development. Ban had previously been scheduled to visit in May but was cancelled due to comments he made about North Korea's tensions. This will be Ban's second visit to North Korea, following a 2006 trip as South Korea's foreign minister.

site_title: CPF Board's corporate operations to relocate to Novena Square
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board's corporate operations will relocate to Novena Square Towers A and B from November 23, 2015, freeing up prime office space in the Central Business District. The relocation does not affect the CPF Service Centre at 79 Robinson Road, which will continue to operate on the second floor of the CPF Building. This move aims to optimize office space and enable higher-value uses in the area.

site_title: Japan economy shrinks 0.8% in Q3, back in recession
summary: Japan's economy contracted at a 0.8% annualized rate in the July-September quarter, slipping back into recession due to weak domestic demand. This follows a revised 0.7% decline in the April-June quarter. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, the economy shrank 0.2%. The contraction is the first in three quarters, reversing a previous upward trend.

site_title: China watchdog starts probe into mutual funds: media
summary: China's markets regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), has started a probe into mutual funds for alleged illegal activity. The investigation, which began after a sharp decline in bourses in mid-June, may involve a wide-ranging audit and could include some brokerages. The CSRC plans to announce details of the investigation this month, with the expected conclusion before the end of the year. This move is part of the regulator's efforts to crack down on illegal stock trading, short-selling, and insider dealing.

site_title: Crucial for S'pore to have presence at int'l summits: SBF chief
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief executive officer Ho Meng Kit emphasized the importance of having a presence at top-tier international meetings, such as the G20 Summit. He stated that Singapore must advocate for its interests, even if it cannot change the outcome of international policies. Ho cited the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) new tax proposals and the sluggish global economy as key issues that require Singapore's participation. He urged Singapore to continue having a seat at the table to protect its companies and ensure growth.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit one-month lows in jittery start after Paris attacks
summary: Australian shares fell 1.0% on Monday, their lowest in over a month, following the Paris attacks that left over 130 dead. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped to 5,001.00, extending a 1.4% slide from last week. Big four banks suffered losses, while software company Xero fell 2.8%. However, Fonterra's fund rose 1.9% after increasing its earnings forecast. Analysts expect the market reaction to be short-lived, citing similar reactions to past global attacks.

site_title: Wary of capital outflows, Japan urges China to go slow on yuan reform
summary: Japan has expressed concerns to China about the pace of capital outflows, urging Beijing to slow down on yuan reform to avoid repeating Japan's past mistakes. Capital outflows have reached hundreds of billions of dollars, prompting China to intervene with foreign exchange reserves. Japan's officials caution that rapid reform could destabilize China's financial system and impact its $3.5 trillion in currency reserves. China has taken steps towards internationalizing its currency, including IMF endorsement of its inclusion in the Special Drawing Rights basket, but Japan suggests reforms should come first.

site_title: Paris attacks: France hits back, striking IS in Syria after Paris carnage
summary: French warplanes struck the Islamic State group's stronghold in Syria, destroying key targets including a command post and recruitment center, in response to the Paris attacks that killed 129 people. President Francois Hollande vowed "no mercy" against the group, and a suspect, Salah Abdeslam, linked to the attacks, is wanted by police. Three groups of attackers were involved, with three French nationals identified, and investigators believe two cars used in the violence were hired in Belgium. World leaders united to condemn terrorism and observe a minute's silence in respect of the victims.

site_title: Paris attacks seen causing short-term global markets drop
summary: Global markets are expected to experience a short-term sell-off on Monday following the coordinated attacks in Paris that killed 129 people. However, few strategists anticipate a prolonged economic impact or change in prevailing market directions. The European Central Bank's decision to ease monetary policy further next month may support European asset markets. Some analysts expect a boost in the defense sector due to potential military action in Syria. The typical "risk off" trade is expected to push investors into global sovereign debt and the US dollar, with a possible volatile move into Treasuries.

site_title: Paris attacks: Belgium launches international manhunt for suspect
summary: Belgium issues an international arrest warrant for Salah Abdeslam, 26, suspected of participating in the Paris attacks with his brothers. The attacks claimed at least 129 lives, with two brothers in custody and one on the run. Investigators believe the brothers were involved in the attacks, which also involved two rented cars in Belgium. French police found abandoned assault rifles and cars near the Bataclan concert hall and on the outskirts of Paris.

site_title: France names first attacker as carnage re-ignites refugee row
summary: France has identified one of the Paris attackers as a 23-year-old man named Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian national. Three coordinated attacks by jihadist cells killed 129 people and injured 352, prompting a renewed debate over Europe's refugee crisis. Conservatives are demanding an end to "uncontrolled immigration" as the investigation into the attacks continues.

site_title: Paris attacks: Hospitals see 'scenes of war' in aftermath
summary: Hospitals in Paris treated victims of the November 2015 attacks, describing the injuries as "scenes of war". At least 129 people were killed and over 350 injured. Many survivors have serious injuries, requiring immediate medical attention, with about a third being rushed to operating theatres or intensive care. The head of emergency services at the Georges Pompidou hospital, Philippe Juvin, compared the situation to a combat zone, citing his experience in Afghanistan.

site_title: Labuan ramps up efforts to complement S'pore
summary: Labuan International Business and Financial Centre (IBFC) in Malaysia is positioning itself to complement Singapore in oil trading and wealth management. The Global Incentives for Trading (Gift) programme, launched four years ago, offers tax incentives to oil traders and has attracted US$40 billion in trading volume. Labuan also offers a wealth management vehicle in the form of its Foundation Act, allowing relationship managers and private wealth advisers to serve clients. The centre aims to capture 10% of Singapore's oil trading market, which is valued at US$1 trillion, and enhance its business volume.

site_title: Director trades rebound, buyers outweigh sellers in holiday-shortened week
summary: Singapore's director activity rebounded in the holiday-shortened week of Nov 9 to 13, with 12 companies recording 21 transactions worth S$8.5 million. Buyers outweighed sellers with nine purchases worth S$7.9 million and three disposals worth S$0.61 million. The buyback activity also rose, with 11 firms posting 35 repurchases worth S$7.53 million. Despite this, the majority of significant director trades were disposals, with sales in Jacks International and HL Global Enterprises.

site_title: As China firms walk out on Wall St, spurned investors demand payback
summary: Chinese companies listed on Wall Street are facing backlash from minority shareholders as they plan buyouts and delistings. Dozens of mainland Chinese firms, worth $40 billion, are seeking to return home in search of higher valuations. Hedge funds and lawyers are coalescing to pressure companies to accept fairer bids, with some firms urging a 2.5 times valuation on assets. Minority shareholders are demanding better premiums, reflecting historical valuations rather than current market conditions.

site_title: Rastafarians of Ethiopia lost in their own land
summary: In Ethiopia, Rastafarians who settled in the town of Shashamane in the 1930s continue to struggle for basic rights despite being in their promised land. The community, around 500 members, has failed to gain control over their property, education, or work, and remains stateless. They face restrictions on building permits and owning property, and are excluded from working, paying taxes, and sending their children to university. Despite celebrating the 85th anniversary of their messiah's coronation, the Rastafarians' political wing continues to lobby for their basic human rights, which they believe have been denied them for decades.

site_title: Europe's youth yearn to move as prosperity proving to be elusive
summary: Europe's youth are seeking a better life abroad due to unfulfilled economic prospects, with 23% of 18-24 year olds considering relocation. Countries like Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia have the highest percentages, mirroring high youth unemployment rates. This trend highlights the EU's struggle with integrating refugees and addressing youth economic concerns, with some nations citing insufficient resources to cope with their own citizens' needs.

site_title: US government's retirement savings plan seen as a good starter
summary: The US government has launched MyRA, a free, guaranteed-return retirement account nationwide, allowing tens of millions of workers without employer-sponsored plans to start saving. The plan, open to those earning under $131,000, offers a low-risk investment option with no fees to open and automatic payments from a checking or savings account. While MyRA won't match the returns of a stock fund, it provides a risk-free option for workers to build up their nest egg, with contributions up to $5,500 per year.

site_title: SingPost announces new organisation structure
summary: SingPost has updated its organisation structure to four pillars, effective December 1. Marcelo Wesseler will lead e-commerce business in the US, while Woo Keng Leong will focus on the mail business. Goh Hui Ling is appointed deputy CEO of International Mail, overseeing business relations with Alibaba. Dr. Sascha Hower will oversee logistics acquisitions, and Mervyn Lim has been appointed deputy group CEO of Corporate Services. The changes aim to integrate global acquisitions and investments in postal operations, transforming SingPost into a digital company.

site_title: Automakers battle for high-tech dominance on the road to self-driving car
summary: Automakers are racing to develop high-tech features for self-driving cars, with companies like Ford, BMW, and Tesla unveiling advanced semi-autonomous features. These features, such as adaptive cruise control and lane-keeping aid, aim to make driving easier and more convenient, while also paving the way for fully autonomous vehicles. However, experts warn that mastering these features can be time-consuming and may require significant changes to driving habits. The development of self-driving cars is expected to take several decades, with companies like Google and Toyota targeting a 2020 launch.

site_title: Apple to power Singapore operations with renewable energy
summary: Apple has signed a deal with solar energy developer Sunseap Group to power its Singapore operations with 100% renewable energy, starting in January. This marks a significant step in Apple's goal to power 100% of its facilities worldwide with clean energy. With over 800 buildings in Singapore, the deal will make Apple the first company in the country to run exclusively on renewable energy.

site_title: Obama urges Russia to join renewed effort to eliminate Islamic State
summary: US President Barack Obama urged Russia's Vladimir Putin to focus on combating the Islamic State in Syria, following the Paris attacks that killed over 120 people. The two leaders agreed on the need for a Syrian-led transition, including UN-mediated talks, and a political process leading to elections within two years. Obama wants to step up efforts to eliminate Islamic State and prevent further attacks, while Russia's involvement in the conflict has complicated US-led efforts. The Paris attacks have renewed a sense of urgency to find a solution to the Syrian war.

site_title: Investing just got a lot harder
summary: Investing has become increasingly challenging due to the transition from "bad economic news is good for stocks" to "good economic news is good for stocks." The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike and unclear guidance on future rate increases will continue to make markets volatile. The shift in monetary policy, combined with weak commodity prices, a US dollar that may be overbought, and a Chinese renminbi that has likely been intentionally oversold, creates a confusing investment landscape.

site_title: ECB stimulus decision depends on long-term trends: Mersch
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will consider long-term trends when deciding on its stimulus package in early December, rather than focusing on short-term indicators. Executive Board member Yves Mersch stated that inflation is expected to rise in 2016 due to energy price base effects, but analysts should not prioritize short-term data. The ECB may expand its asset buying program and lower the deposit rate, which could weaken the euro and boost inflation and growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Offshore and marine, Swiber, ComfortDelGro, CAO
summary: Malaysia's offshore support vessel builder Nam Cheong posted third-quarter earnings of RM6,000, a stark contrast from RM126.3 million a year earlier. Swiber Holdings reported a net profit of US$3.2 million, a turnaround from reported losses, due to new projects and cost control measures. ComfortDelGro Corp's third-quarter net profit rose 5.4% to S$85.2 million, lifted by growth in transport-provision businesses. Meanwhile, China Aviation Oil's net profit more than doubled to US$17.7 million despite revenue falling by half due to a fall in jet fuel prices.

images.alt_text: A passenger exits a ComfortDelgro Corp. taxi in Singapore.

site_title: Saks puts hopes on US$250m, three-year restoration of Fifth Avenue flagship store
summary: Saks Fifth Avenue is investing $250 million in a three-year restoration of its iconic flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York. The 91-year-old department store chain aims to recreate a lavish shopping experience, featuring a 23-foot-high spiral staircase and a glass elevator. The renovation will also include the relocation of the beauty department to the second floor, a boutique for fine jewelry, and a new Paris restaurant, L'Avenue. The overhaul is part of a broader effort to revitalize the brand, which has faced challenges from online retailers and changing consumer habits.

site_title: Deutsche Bank Japan bond veteran turned author warns of bubble
summary: Deutsche Bank veteran trader Yoshihiro Matsumura warns that the Bank of Japan's bond-buying stimulus is creating risks similar to the 2008 debt crisis, artificially lifting asset prices and misleading the public. Matsumura, who retired in 2011, believes the BOJ's policies are creating moral hazard and luring investors to join the market, which will ultimately lead to losses for the Japanese public. The BOJ's balance sheet has grown to over two-thirds of Japan's economic output, and critics worry about the central bank's options running out unless it succeeds soon.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan's bond-buying stimulus is exposing investors to risks similar to the 2008 debt crisis, according to a Deutsche Bank AG veteran trader turned best-selling author.

site_title: Commodities tumble as gloom spreads
summary: Commodity prices plummeted last week due to a strong dollar and concerns over weak Chinese demand, with copper, gold, and oil hitting six-year lows. The US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike in December fueled dollar appreciation, making commodities priced in US dollars more expensive for holders of rival currencies. Global gold demand rose in the third quarter, while oil prices sank to two-month lows amid a record-high commercial crude stockpile. Analysts warn that commodity markets will remain volatile until the US rate outlook is resolved.

site_title: Manila raises security level to 'red' ahead of Apec leaders' arrival
summary: The Philippines has raised its security level to "red" ahead of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit, following the deadly terror attacks in Paris. US President Barack Obama and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong are among the 17 leaders attending the summit. The government has taken measures to ensure the summit's success, including deploying 18,000 police officers and declaring public holidays. The summit will focus on pushing for an early ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a landmark free trade deal covering 40% of the global economy.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Swiber Holdings posts Q3 net profit of US$3.2m
summary: Swiber Holdings reported a net profit of US$3.2 million for the third quarter, reversing a year-ago loss of US$27.5 million. Revenue doubled to US$215.7 million, driven by new projects and cost control measures. The company's cash and cash equivalents rose to US$114.7 million, while total borrowings decreased to US$1.03 billion. Despite a cautious outlook for the oil and gas industry, Swiber sees opportunities in shallow water developments and has a record US$1.5 billion order book.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Indirect discounts losing favour in dull residential market
summary: Indirect discounts such as cash rebates and furniture vouchers are becoming less popular in Singapore's residential market, with only 3% of non-landed private homes sold since May 25 having such offers. The average discount was 1.7% of the transacted price. This trend reflects the price-sensitive nature of the market, where buyers are increasingly looking for value rather than incentives.

site_title: G20: US says to support yuan in IMF basket, if it meets criteria
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew announced his support for adding the yuan to the IMF's SDR basket, contingent on meeting the IMF's criteria. This move would mark a significant diplomatic victory for China's efforts to internationalize the currency. The IMF's executive board is likely to approve the inclusion, with opposition unlikely to have been voiced before now. The yuan's inclusion would add a new currency to the US$280 billion SDR basket, which is used to facilitate international transactions.

site_title: 'Comply or explain' - or 'comply or else'?
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is cracking down on companies' compliance with its Code of Corporate Governance, moving from a "comply or explain" to a "comply or face the music" approach. The regulator plans to use new enforcement powers, including fines and market access denial, to ensure companies meet the code's requirements. A review of 550 mainboard-listed companies' annual reports will identify non-compliers, with SGX working with them to improve compliance. This shift aims to return to the original philosophy of the code, emphasizing compliance with "good practices" and justifiable explanations for non-compliance.

site_title: Euro airports boost security after Paris terror attacks
summary: European airports have increased security measures following the Paris terror attacks that killed at least 120 people, with airlines offering free journey delays. Aeroports de Paris warned of customs and immigration delays at Charles de Gaulle airport. The French government has imposed a state of emergency and mobilized its military. London's Gatwick Airport was evacuated after a suspicious item was found, and the UK is assessing events in Paris to boost security. Extra police officers and checks will be implemented at ports and events across the country.

site_title: China stabilising but economy on two tracks
summary: China's economy appears to be stabilizing despite weak absolute demand, with underlying sectoral divergence continuing. Retail spending remains solid, driven by car and appliance sales in a recovering housing market. The government has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, and Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: Japan carmakers aim to put self-driving cars on roads by 2020
summary: Japanese car manufacturers, including Toyota, Nissan, and Honda, aim to introduce self-driving cars on highways and city roads by 2020. The technology has the potential to save lives and alter car journeys, according to Nissan CEO. However, the industry faces a challenge in convincing the public of the safety of autonomous vehicles, while also addressing security concerns related to human users. The companies have made significant advances in the technology, as showcased at the recent Tokyo Motor Show.

images.alt_text: Toyota giving a demonstration of its autonomous driving technology in Tokyo. Obtaining the trust of drivers is crucial, as without it, "we cannot move forward", said a Toyota executive.

site_title: VW tags 430,000 new cars with 'implausible' carbon dioxide ratings
summary: Volkswagen AG has identified 430,000 new cars with "implausible" carbon dioxide ratings, affecting over half of the 800,000 vehicles impacted by the emissions cheating crisis. The affected vehicles are primarily from the 2016 model year. Volkswagen is investigating previous model years and seeking to address the issue with regulators. The company has not yet determined the correct CO2 ratings for the affected vehicles. This discovery comes as Volkswagen continues talks with regulators to resolve the emissions scandal.

site_title: CyberArk distances itself from FireEye as stock takes a beating
summary: CyberArk CEO Udi Mokady reassures investors that a decline in high-profile data breaches won't hurt security software companies like CyberArk, which has seen its stock drop 23% after FireEye reported disappointing earnings. CyberArk's revenue rose 43% in the third quarter and adjusted net income jumped 57%, beating estimates. Mokady emphasizes that CyberArk's focus on privileged account management is a growing market, and the company is seeing increased demand and awareness of its services. Despite this, investors remain cautious, citing the vulnerability of data security companies to market corrections.

site_title: Door to more China business
summary: Singapore's bilateral agreements with China, signed during President Xi Jinping's visit, offer opportunities for businesses and industries to tap into the renminbi market outside China, solidifying the city-state's position as an offshore currency centre. The initiatives will facilitate the use of the renminbi, promoting trade and investment between the two nations. This move is seen as a strategic step to boost economic ties and further strengthen Singapore's financial sector.

images.alt_text: Judy Hsu

site_title: London office properties worth £6.1b up for sale
summary: Asian investors are selling London office properties worth £6.1 billion due to a surge in the value of the pound, seeking to profit from the increased value. The sale comes as demand eases, with sovereign wealth funds facing lower inflows and some facing outflows. Despite this, some investors remain bullish on City property, citing long-term potential. The sale follows a 510% increase in properties on the market since May, with prices jumping 59% since September 2012.

site_title: StanChart carnival treat for 800 elderly
summary: Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore organized its third Silver Lining Carnival, a day-long event for 800 elderly members of 26 Voluntary Welfare Organizations (VWOs), with 1,300 volunteers. The bank has seen a significant increase in employee volunteerism, with a 40% take-up rate in the past two years. The event included a S$250,000 donation to support the GroovyFIT wellness program and the launch of the SG Volunteers App, which provides practical knowledge and resources for volunteers to engage with seniors.

site_title: Inclusion of RMB in IMF currency basket a mixed blessing for China
summary: China's renminbi (RMB) is set to be included in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, alongside the US dollar, euro, yen, and pound, after IMF staff deemed it "freely usable". The move is expected to be approved by the IMF Board on November 30. However, some experts warn that the timing may create problems for China's rapidly slowing economy, which may struggle to maintain the RMB's value. The inclusion of the RMB in the SDR basket could lead to increased capital outflows and downward pressure on the currency.

site_title: ECB asks Portugal's Novo Banco to plug 1.4b euro capital hole
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has ordered Portugal's Novo Banco to fill a 1.4 billion euro capital hole, potentially delaying its planned sale and hindering Lisbon's efforts to resolve the country's biggest banking collapse. The request comes after a stress test found Novo Banco to be short of capital, and the bank has two weeks to present a plan to raise capital. The sale process can resume, but political uncertainty, as a centre-left government takes power, may weigh on the process.

site_title: First Sponsor acquires Dutch office assets
summary: First Sponsor Group Limited has acquired a portfolio of 16 office assets in the Netherlands, including the crown jewel Mondriaan Tower in Amsterdam, for 205.6 million euros (S$315.2 million). The deal grants the group access to a strong tenancy profile and a 50% interest in VOF De Omval retail spaces near the Mondriaan Tower. The acquisition is expected to generate a 6.1% net property income yield and will further boost the group's recurrent income base in the Netherlands.

images.alt_text: The office building in Amsterdam (above) acquired by investors led by First Sponsor. First Sponsor Group Limited has enlarged its footprint in the Dutch commercial real estate market by brokering another deal, this time with three co-investors to acquire a portfolio of office assets in the Netherlands.

site_title: Head Down Under to avoid 2016 global bond rout: analysts
summary: Australia's bond market is emerging as a potential safe-haven amid a looming global selloff in bonds. Analysts predict a 15 basis point decline in 10-year yields by March to 2.80%, offering investors a 2.3% return. This contrasts with rising yields forecast in other Group of Seven nations, including the US. The Reserve Bank of Australia's inflation rate below target and moderate economic growth suggest the option to cut interest rates if needed.

site_title: Recent Chinese bond defaults suggest more to come
summary: China's bond defaults are expected to increase as part of market reform, but domestic ratings agencies and investors still believe Beijing will intervene to prevent bank damage. Recent defaults, including those by state-owned firms, suggest a shift in the government's approach. Despite this, bond yields remain low, and investors view defaults as less risky, driven by assumptions about government intervention. Domestic debt rating agencies face criticism for overly optimistic ratings, and policymakers must balance the risks of allowing market discipline with the potential consequences for China's banks.

site_title: Effects of shocks likely to persist this week
summary: The US stock market is expected to remain volatile this week, following a disappointing jobs report and worrying statements from retailers Macy's and Nordstrom. The economy is facing a short circuit in its traditional expansion cycle, with corporations slow to rebuild their labor forces and consumers showing restraint in spending. Early indications suggest that this year's peak shopping season will be a disappointment, with sales in October showing little change from the previous month. Analysts warn that the economic costs of the Paris attacks and the impact of lower oil prices on the global economy could be significant.

site_title: Japan's economy rides on tailwind of Fed rate hike prospect
summary: Japan's economy is benefiting from a weak yen due to the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike, which could bolster export price competitiveness. The Bank of Japan, however, maintained its monetary policy despite a more hawkish Federal Reserve stance. A strong US job growth report and the Fed's explicit mention of a possible rate hike in December strengthen the case for a rate hike. As a result, the yen is expected to remain weak against the dollar, with the Bank of Japan closely monitoring Fed decisions to adjust its strategy accordingly.

site_title: Rolls-Royce crisis is a big test for microchip kingpin Warren East
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings plc is facing a major crisis under new CEO Warren East, who must slash costs and rebuild the company's management and operations. The aircraft-engine maker issued a profit warning, wiping £2.5 billion off its value, and is expected to double output of complex machines. East, who previously led microchip designer ARM Holdings plc, faces the challenge of adapting to a heavy-engineering company, where nimbleness is crucial. The company's 2016 earnings are forecast to be hit by a slide in demand and deep-seated organisational issues, with East introducing a restructuring plan and management cuts.

site_title: Global stock markets brace for short-term hit after Paris attacks
summary: Global stock markets are expected to experience a short-term decline following the Paris attacks, with French stocks likely to suffer the largest impact due to the country's large tourism sector. However, analysts believe the economic impact will be limited and markets will quickly recover, with a knee-jerk reaction expected in investment decisions. European and Asian markets were already expected to fall due to weak US retail sales figures, and some experts predict a brief safety bid in Treasuries, but overall, a prolonged economic impact is unlikely.

site_title: Social media sites activated crisis tools during Paris attacks
summary: Social media sites activated crisis tools during the Paris attacks, providing a source of information beyond news outlets. Facebook activated its Safety Check tool, allowing users to mark themselves or others as safe, and Twitter used its Moments tool to highlight top news tweets and prayers from celebrities. The hashtags #PorteOuverte, #prayforparis, and #StrandedInUS gained traction, with over 6.7 million posts and 1 million tweets, respectively. These platforms provided a means for people to offer support and get updates on the situation, as well as a way for those in Paris to offer shelter to those in need.

site_title: Obama vows to step up efforts to eliminate ISIS
summary: US President Barack Obama vowed to intensify efforts to eliminate ISIS, describing the Paris attacks as an attack on the civilized world. He pledged to work with France to hunt down those responsible. Meanwhile, European leaders urged Russia to focus on ISIS, while other news includes Malaysia seizing assets from Daim Zainuddin, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: Mr Obama (centre) speaking to Mr Putin (right) as they participate in a family photo during the G-20 summit in Antalya, Turkey, on Sunday. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is at left.

site_title: Paris attacks: World shows solidarity, tightens security after Paris attacks
summary: World leaders showed solidarity with France after deadly attacks in Paris that left at least 129 dead. The Islamic State claimed responsibility, prompting European neighbours to increase security measures, including Britain, Belgium, and Germany. France temporarily imposed border controls. Leaders, including US President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin, condemned the attacks, which Hollande described as an act of war against France.

site_title: Governments must prepare workers for future via skills training: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for governments to prepare workers for the future through skills training, citing the impact of technology on jobs and industries. This is a long-term issue, but immediate action is required to avoid structural mismatches in the workforce.

site_title: Terrorism threat in S-EA growing more acute: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warns that the terrorism threat in South-east Asia is becoming more acute, with hundreds from the region and a few from Singapore attempting to join ISIS in Syria. Indonesia's Poso region is also seen as a potential base for militant training. The threat also includes released terrorists who pledge allegiance to ISIS, with hundreds nearing the end of their jail terms. Lee emphasizes that overcoming the ideology is a difficult problem, requiring vigilance and security measures.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Dithering local officials in China stall stimulus push
summary: China's economic growth is slowing due to local officials' reluctance to approve projects and business deals, partly to avoid scrutiny from the anti-corruption campaign. Despite the National Development and Reform Commission's approval of $424 billion in investment projects, $45 billion are behind schedule. Procrastinating officials fear drawing attention to their past corruption, and Beijing's efforts to lure private investment into infrastructure projects are hindered by low returns and lack of legal protection. The slowing growth poses a challenge to the government's goal of doubling GDP and per capita income by 2020.

site_title: Mobile charges way too expensive in US
summary: US mobile phone users pay significantly more than their European counterparts, with a 50GB data plan costing $390 per month compared to €20 (approximately $30.60) in France. The disparity is attributed to limited competition, with only one or two national operators in the US, whereas four national operators exist in countries like France and Sweden. Industry experts suggest that increased competition in Europe has led to lower prices, while the US market's lack of competition drives up costs.

site_title: Black Friday grows less appealing for all involved
summary: Retailers are shifting their focus from Black Friday to spreading discounts throughout November, reducing the need for costly promotions and security measures. This trend is driven by consumers' growing preference for online shopping and decreased interest in participating in the traditional Black Friday ritual. According to a Deloitte survey, 52% of consumers are relying less on Black Friday to make holiday purchases, with online sales forecast to rise 6-8% in November and December. Despite this, Black Friday remains an important sales day for retailers, with many planning to continue offering discounts on the day.

images.alt_text: Surveys are finding consumers are less interested in participating in Black Friday. This could be good news for merchants, which can boost profits by cutting back on the day's rock-bottom discounts.

site_title: Paris attacks: China's Xi says willing to join France in combating terrorism
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed willingness to join France and the international community in combating terrorism after the Paris attacks that killed about 120 people. In a telephone call to French President Francois Hollande, Xi condemned the attacks and offered condolences to the victims. This move comes as China seeks to strengthen its security cooperation with France and other countries.

images.alt_text: China is ready to join France and the international community in stepping up security cooperation and combating terrorism, President Xi Jinping told French President Francois Hollande on Saturday, after attacks in Paris that killed about 120 people.

site_title: Dubai rents, yields holding up but price slump continues
summary: Dubai's real estate market is expected to continue its decline in 2016, with home prices potentially falling 20% and yields increasing, according to Standard & Poor's. The slump is attributed to the ruble crisis, the euro's drop against the dollar, and decreased demand from European buyers. Despite this, rents are holding steady, and developers are reporting higher profits, with rental yields reaching 7.8% for apartments. Approximately 6,000 homes are set to be completed in the final quarter of 2015, and another 23,000 and 22,000 are scheduled for 2016 and 2017, respectively.

images.alt_text: Dubai's property market is one of the most volatile in the world, swinging between troughs and peaks.

site_title: Paris attacks: Bloodshed lifts terrorism fight to top of G-20 agenda
summary: The Paris attacks, which killed at least 120 people, have elevated the fight against terrorism to the top of the G-20 agenda at the upcoming summit in Turkey. World leaders are expected to discuss ways to combat militant groups like Islamic State, with a focus on cooperation and communication. The attacks have also raised concerns about refugees pouring into Europe, potentially leading to stricter border controls and a harder-line response from European countries.

site_title: Chinese economy won't collapse - but SOE reform doubtful
summary: China's economy appears stable despite challenges, with officials and corporations expressing concerns but little evidence of a crisis. State-owned enterprise (SOE) reform is doubtful due to vested interests among senior management. The country has taken steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, but long-term concerns remain. China has urged South-east Asian countries to support openness, amid looming US tariffs.

site_title: David Hale - a sensei who will be much missed
summary: David Hale, a respected economist and sensei, died suddenly in October at home in Chicago after a brief illness. Hale, known for his enthusiasm and ability to communicate complex economics concepts, helped change the perception of economics as a "dismal science." His warmth and friendliness as an individual made him relatable, and his prolific writing, lecturing, and advising endeared him to many. Hale will be "remembered as someone who could walk with kings but never lost the common touch."

site_title: What to expect at SME Outlook 2016
summary: Singapore's SME Outlook 2016, scheduled for Nov 27, will discuss the muted 2016 outlook despite challenging economic conditions. Experts, including David Koh from PricewaterhouseCoopers and Jimmy Koh from United Overseas Bank, will share insights on strengthening preparedness, adapting to market shifts, and leveraging regional growth opportunities through the Asean Economic Community and other initiatives. The event aims to provide SMEs with strategies to shift from value-adding to value-creating and mitigate the impact of economic changes.

site_title: Human roadblock for Japanese firms developing autonomous cars
summary: Japanese car manufacturers Toyota, Nissan, and Honda aim to launch autonomous cars on highways and city roads by 2020, with a goal of preventing road deaths. Despite technological advancements, the companies face challenges in convincing the public of the safety of self-driving cars and dealing with human error. Nissan plans to introduce autonomous cars with a driver-like interface, while Toyota and Honda emphasize caution due to the limitations of current technology. Regulatory approval and public trust are crucial for the successful deployment of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Singapore raises alert level after Paris attacks
summary: Singapore has raised its security alert level following the Paris attacks that killed at least 120 people. Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam said the country has stepped up security measures, border checks, and vigilance. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed shock and outrage, condemning the attacks as an attack on shared humanity. The government encouraged everyone to remain vigilant and report suspicious activities to the authorities.

site_title: Paris attacks: France says three teams led terror spree as Paris reels
summary: At least 129 people were killed in a coordinated terror attack in Paris, France, as three teams of assailants linked to the Islamic State group carried out the assault. The attack, which began with three suicide bombings at the Stade de France, involved multiple locations in central Paris, including the Le Bataclan concert hall. A French citizen and a Syrian passport holder were among the perpetrators, and at least three people have been arrested in Belgium in connection with the attack. The French government has vowed to increase security measures and combat terrorism, amid a growing refugee crisis and jihadist retribution.

site_title: China welcomes IMF backing to make yuan world reserve currency
summary: China welcomed IMF backing to include the yuan in its reserve currencies, a milestone in its efforts to become a global economic power. The yuan meets the requirements to be a "freely usable" currency, a key hurdle to joining the SDR basket, according to IMF chief Christine Lagarde. The inclusion is expected to strengthen the world's financial system, boost demand for yuan-denominated assets, and give the currency a sheen of respectability. The decision is expected to be finalized by the IMF's executive board on November 30, with actual inclusion potentially taking place by September 30, 2016.

site_title: The return of chef Royer
summary: Renowned chef Julien Royer has returned to the culinary scene with his new restaurant, Odette, located at the National Gallery in Singapore. The restaurant, previously at the iconic Jaan, offers a luxurious dining experience with elegant staff and a focus on sharing wine knowledge. Royer's menu features his signature dishes, including the 55-minute egg, mushroom tea, and hay-smoked pigeon. Odette is now open for lunch and dinner, offering a new and exciting dining experience in the heart of the National Gallery.

site_title: 1MDB to have at least RM10b in assets after revamp
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) is expected to have between RM10 billion to RM12 billion in assets after its proposed reorganisation, according to President Arul Kanda. This includes a 40% stake in Bandar Malaysia and land worth RM5 billion to RM6 billion in the Tun Razak Exchange development. The reorganisation aims to revamp the debt-ridden state investment company, which nearly defaulted earlier this year.

site_title: Singapore and Turkey sign comprehensive free trade agreement
summary: Singapore and Turkey signed a comprehensive free trade agreement (TRSFTA) on November 14, 2015, in Antalya, Turkey. The agreement will eliminate tariffs for 80% of Singapore's exports to Turkey, rising to 95% over 10 years. The deal aims to boost trade and investment between the two countries, with Singapore's exporters benefiting from reduced tariffs and more Turkish companies leveraging Singapore as a gateway to Europe and beyond. The agreement was signed by Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat and Turkey's Minister of Economy Nihat Zeybekci.

site_title: Philippines vows 'higher' Apec summit security after Paris attacks
summary: The Philippines has increased security measures for the upcoming APEC summit in Manila, citing the recent Paris attacks that left over 120 dead. US President Barack Obama will attend the November 18-19 summit, along with leaders from China, Japan, Australia, and 15 others. The Philippines has deployed 18,000 police, cancelled flights, and declared public holidays to ensure a safe summit. Major streets are being closed to traffic, and building owners are being asked to close windows to prevent sniper attacks, following a long history of Islamic militancy in the country.

site_title: Paris attacks: Paris attacks: Singapore condemns strikes, PM Lee says it is 'attack on our shared humanity'
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong condemned the Paris attacks, calling it an "attack on our shared humanity". He expressed outrage and sympathy for the victims and their families, and offered support to the people and government of Paris and France. This is not the first time Singapore has condemned such attacks, with PM Lee stating that innocent civilians being massacred is an attack on humanity.

site_title: Paris attacks: American Airlines delays Paris flights; United operates as planned
summary: American Airlines has delayed flights to Paris due to the recent attacks, while United Continental Holdings operates as planned. Despite French airports remaining open, American Airlines is holding departures until further information is available. United will still depart for Paris on Friday evening from its hubs in Chicago, Newark, and Washington, DC, according to its spokesman.

site_title: Paris attacks: Obama says US stands with France
summary: US President Barack Obama condemned the Paris attacks as an "attack on all of humanity" and vowed to work with France to bring those responsible to justice. The attacks, which killed at least 39 people, did not pose a specific threat to the US. Obama pledged to provide any assistance needed to France and reiterated the importance of universal values such as liberty, equality, and fraternity. He also expressed his resolve to tackle terror and work with nations worldwide to bring terrorists to justice.

site_title: Paris attacks: French security services' nightmare comes true
summary: A series of coordinated attacks in Paris on Friday night killed over 120 people and wounded over 200, in a nightmare scenario that French security services had long feared. Eight assailants, including gunmen and suicide bombers, targeted popular recreational spots, including the Bataclan concert hall and eateries near the Stade de France sports stadium. Experts had predicted such an attack was inevitable, citing the increasing number of radicalized Muslims returning from warzones and the difficulty in keeping tabs on them. The attack marked a turning point in France's anti-terror efforts, with security officials acknowledging they are overwhelmed.

site_title: Paris attacks: French witness relates 'bloodbath' at packed concert venue
summary: A French radio reporter recounts a harrowing 10-minute attack at the Bataclan concert venue in Paris, where black-clad gunmen firing AK-47s killed at least 100 people and injured many more. The attacker, likely 20-25 years old, was calm and determined, reloading his gun multiple times and shouting "Allahu akbar" as he fired. The reporter, Julien Pierce, narrowly escaped with his life and found an exit, carrying a teenage girl to a hospital. Police later stormed the venue, killing three suspected assailants, and found several others hiding in fear.

site_title: 'Uber get out,' say protesting Uruguay taxi drivers
summary: Uruguay taxi drivers block a central street in Montevideo to protest Uber's planned rollout, claiming the service will take away jobs and not pay taxes or permit fees. The taxi drivers' union president, Oscar Dourado, met with Labour Minister Victor Rossi, and the training session was cancelled. The protest is part of a growing controversy over Uber's expansion in Uruguay, with the southeastern department of Canelones planning to fine drivers and confiscate license plates.

site_title: Paris attacks: World reacts in shock, solidarity
summary: World leaders responded with shock and solidarity to the Paris attacks, condemning the "barbaric and cowardly terrorist attacks" that killed scores of people. US President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed support for French President Francois Hollande, while NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg pledged unity in the fight against terrorism. European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and British Prime Minister David Cameron, also offered condolences and assistance.

site_title: Paris attacks: At least 120 dead, Hollande declares emergency
summary: At least 120 people were killed in coordinated terrorist attacks across Paris, France, on November 13, 2015. Gunmen and bombers targeted restaurants, a concert hall, and a sports stadium, with the deadliest attack occurring at the Bataclan music hall. President Francois Hollande declared a nationwide state of emergency and announced the closure of France's borders. The attacks, which included multiple explosions and shootings, were claimed by supporters of the Islamic State militant group, although no direct claim was made. The incident raised concerns about terrorism and France's security ahead of a global climate conference.

images.alt_text: Wounded people are evacuated outside the scene of a hostage situation at the Bataclan theatre in Paris, France, Nov 14, 2015.

site_title: Paris attacks: US Homeland Security says no credible threats of an attack on US
summary: US Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson stated there are no credible threats of an attack on the US, following the Paris attacks that killed over 100 people. The FBI and DHS are closely monitoring the situation and consulting with state and local law enforcement. Johnson acknowledged the agencies' cautious approach out of concern for the safety of the US public.

images.alt_text: One World Trade Center's spire is shown lit in French flags colors of white, blue and red in solidarity with France after tonight's terror attacks in Paris on Nov 13, 2015 in New York City.

site_title: IMF experts recommend inclusion of Chinese yuan in elite currency basket
summary: IMF experts have recommended that the Chinese yuan be included in the Fund's SDR basket of currencies, a move that would mark a significant step in China's push for greater global economic influence. The yuan was deemed to meet the requirements for being a "freely usable" currency, a key hurdle to its inclusion alongside the US dollar, euro, and yen. The recommendation is set to be decided by the IMF executive board on November 30, with actual inclusion potentially taking place as late as September 30, 2016.

site_title: More orchestras join Google classical project
summary: Four leading orchestras - the London Philharmonic Orchestra, Orchestre de Paris, Sydney Symphony Orchestra, and Boston Pops Orchestra - have joined Google's Classical Live project, offering new recordings for streaming or downloading on Google Play Music. The project aims to bring more concert hall audiences into the growing sector of streaming. This expansion is part of the Internet giant's efforts to share music-making worldwide, according to Timothy Walker, chief executive and artistic director of the London Philharmonic Orchestra.

site_title: EgyptAir barred from flying to Russia
summary: Russia has banned EgyptAir from flying to the country, with flights between Moscow and Egypt already suspended following the Sinai plane crash. The ban, effective Saturday, was allegedly due to a demand from the Russian Federal Air Transport Agency for an EgyptAir operational manual translation into Russian. EgyptAir has expressed opposition to the decision, claiming it is "unjustifiable" and damaging to passengers. The Egyptian aviation authority is in contact with its Russian counterpart to review the decision, which may last for months.

site_title: Paris attacks: New York on heighted state of alert, police deployed
summary: New York City has deployed counter-terrorism police units to crowded areas and French interests following the Paris attacks that killed at least 39 people. The NYPD stated there's no known nexus to New York City, but is working closely with the FBI and French police to assist in the investigation. The city has a population of 8.4 million and is on a heightened state of alert.

site_title: Myanmar president 'will hand power' to Suu Kyi after poll win
summary: Myanmar President Thein Sein announced a smooth transition of power to Aung San Suu Kyi's party after a landslide victory in historic polls. Thein Sein credited the reforms implemented by his government for the election's success, stating that the process will be handed over to a new government. Suu Kyi's party won 80% of the elected seats, while Thein Sein's party secured 10%. Thein Sein and the army chief agreed to talks with Suu Kyi in the coming days to negotiate a long transition, with Thein Sein retaining his position until March.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's President Thein Sein on Sunday said historic polls won in a thumping landslide by Aung San Suu Kyi's party were the consequence of his government's reforms and vowed a smooth transition of power.

site_title: Oil sinks to two-month lows as global stockpiles mount
summary: Oil prices plummeted to two-month lows, dipping to $40.74 a barrel, amid concerns over a record high commercial crude stockpile of 3 billion barrels. The International Energy Agency's report renewed worries over the global supply overhang, which has driven a 60% collapse in oil prices since last year. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $1.01 to its lowest level in two months. The bearish outlook, coupled with Trump's tariff threats, has fueled market volatility.

site_title: Global shares tumble after poor European, US data
summary: Global shares plummeted on Friday due to poor European growth data and concerns about US consumer spending ahead of the Christmas season. European shares fell nearly as much as the US, with the eurozone's growth slowing to 0.3% in the third quarter. US retail sales were disappointing, sparking worries about consumer spending and economic growth. Crude prices also dropped, hitting shares of mining and oil companies. The European Central Bank is expected to deliver more stimulus at its December policy meeting to combat sluggish growth.

site_title: Thousands cheer India's Modi at London mega-rally
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi received a massive welcome at London's Wembley Stadium, where thousands of people gathered to celebrate British-Indian ties and India's growing international clout. The event, attended by 60,000 people, featured Indian pop music and videos highlighting the country's economic prowess. Modi's supporters praised his shift from a political pariah to a leader who promises economic reform and development. The event marked a significant shift in relations between India and Britain, with British Prime Minister David Cameron also in attendance, expressing his admiration for the Indian community in Britain.

site_title: Paris attacks: France, allies signal major response
summary: At least 127 people were killed in coordinated attacks in Paris, France, with 300 injured. The Islamic State claimed responsibility, describing the attacks as an "act of war" against France and the West. The attacks, which included bombings and shootings, targeted concert halls, restaurants, and a soccer stadium, and were carried out by eight attackers who were killed, including one with a Syrian passport. France has declared a state of emergency and imposed border controls, with the US, UK, and other countries offering support and condolences. The attacks have raised concerns about the growing threat of terrorism.

site_title: US fines Alstom record US$772m over international bribery
summary: The US Justice Department fined French energy giant Alstom a record $772 million for bribing government officials in several countries, including Indonesia, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia. Alstom pleaded guilty to two criminal counts related to bribery and corruption and agreed to pay the fine in 2014. The company paid over $75 million to secure over $4 billion in projects worldwide, with a profit of approximately $300 million. Five company executives were also charged, with four pleading guilty.

site_title: France declares emergency as dozens die in wave of Paris attacks
summary: France declared a state of emergency after a series of deadly attacks in Paris, leaving dozens dead and dozens more hostage. President Francois Hollande closed borders and imposed a state of alert, with multiple shootings and bomb attacks reported across the city. The attacks occurred near a soccer game and a concert, with the Bataclan theater among the targeted locations. The US and UK pledged support to France, with President Barack Obama describing the attacks as "an outrageous attempt to terrorise innocent civilians."

site_title: Fed officials lay out case for December lift-off
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are likely to raise interest rates in December, with a gradual approach expected after the initial hike. Policymakers see inflation rebounding, but also acknowledge the risk of slowing growth and low inflation. Fed officials, including President William Dudley and Vice Chair Stanley Fischer, have expressed a "nearly balanced" view of the risks, with some arguing that rates should be raised sooner to manage inflation and others cautioning against too rapid a move.

site_title: First Sponsor acquires Dutch office portfolio for 205.6m euros with 3 co-investors
summary: FIRST Sponsor Group Limited has acquired a Dutch office portfolio valued at 205.6 million euros (S$313.8 million) from Delta Lloyd Vastgoed Kantoren BV, a Dutch financial services provider. The portfolio includes 16 offices across the Netherlands, with a total lettable area of 164,000 sqm and 90 tenants. First Sponsor CEO Neo Teck Pheng expects a 6.1% net property income yield after transaction costs, citing the addition of quality core properties with strong tenancy profiles.

site_title: Paris attacks: Shock, horror for 80,000 fans at France-Germany friendly
summary: A deadly attack occurred during a friendly football match between France and Germany at the Stade de France in Paris, killing multiple people and injuring many more. The attack started as explosions and was initially mistaken for fireworks. The incident shocked and horrified the crowd of 80,000 fans, leaving many in a state of panic. The full extent of the damage and casualties is not yet known.

site_title: Sept retail figures reflect weak economic indices
summary: Singapore's September retail sales rose 4.6% due to a surge in car sales, offsetting weaker economic indicators. The increase is attributed to the SG50 celebrations in August, which have worn off. The figures contradict expectations of a decline in retail sales.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at the Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Paris shootings, explosion leave at least 18 dead
summary: At least 18 people were killed in a series of gun attacks and explosions in Paris on Friday, including 15 at the Bataclan concert hall and three outside the Stade de France stadium. A hostage scenario was ongoing at the Bataclan, while another attack was reported at a nearby restaurant. The attacks, which were described as "multiple" by police, came as France has been on high alert since jihadist attacks in January. A crisis cell was set up by President Francois Hollande and Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve.

site_title: Slower eurozone growth gives ECB ammunition to act in December
summary: The eurozone experienced slower-than-expected growth in the third quarter, with a 0.3% increase, as weaker foreign trade impacted Germany and France. The European Central Bank is expected to expand its monetary stimulus in December, as inflation remains low. Spain's economy is a rare bright spot, but its recovery is failing to address income inequality. The ECB's next meeting is on December 3, and policymakers are ready to extend monetary easing.

site_title: Paris attacks: Facebook sets up safety check for Paris friends
summary: Facebook launched a safety check feature to let users know if their friends in Paris were safe after a series of bombings and shootings in the French capital killed at least 120 people. The "Paris Terror Attacks" safety check allowed users to mark friends as safe or check which were unaccounted for. The feature was activated after the death toll rose, with police reporting around 100 killed at the Bataclan music venue, where an attacker yelled "Allahu Akbar." The move aimed to provide comfort and reassurance to users and their loved ones.

site_title: An argument for active investing
summary: The article argues that while passive investing has gained momentum in the past decade, there are reasons to reconsider shifting to passive management. With the S&P trebling in price, the risk premium has decreased, and the expected return from passive equity has fallen to 4-6%. Meanwhile, active managers can still deliver a significant portion of their expected returns, especially with the return of dispersion in the market and the opportunities offered by smart beta strategies. The authors believe that active management is becoming more attractive, particularly as the global financial crisis recedes and the opportunity set for active managers increases.

site_title: Banks likely to adopt new tech rather than be overrun
summary: Banks are unlikely to be overtaken by new technology firms, according to Mark Smith, CEO of Symbiont.io, a blockchain technology startup. Despite new competitors emerging from Silicon Valley, banks will remain as financial intermediaries due to regulations and duties imposed by governments. Big banks, such as JPMorgan Chase, will adopt new technologies to cut costs, while Symbiont.io expects to sell tools to banks for securities trading. This shift is expected to enable banks to remain competitive and perform certain functions required by regulation.

site_title: New-Age farming
summary: Panasonic is expanding its mini agricultural revolution in Japan to South-east Asia, with its Tuas facility in Singapore now including an agricultural area. The facility uses Japanese prototypes to grow 38 kinds of ready-to-eat vegetables, mainly for salads, under LED lighting with controlled temperature, humidity, and carbon dioxide levels. The target output is 81 tonnes per year, aiming to contribute 5% to Singapore's local production by FY2016. This innovative approach is part of a larger trend in Japan, where electronic giants are switching to hi-tech, clean-room farming to address the problem of ageing farmers and the dominance of Korea in the electronics sector.

site_title: OCBC joins DBS on FD-linked mortgages
summary: OCBC has joined DBS in offering a home loan pegged to a fixed deposit (FD) rate, with OCBC using its 36-month FD rate and DBS using its 18-month rate. The FD-linked mortgages offer price transparency and stability, with rates unchanged since November 2011. DBS has seen a significant increase in mortgage bookings, with 8 out of 10 new loans priced off an FD rate, now holding a 26% market share. Each bank charges a spread, with DBS at 1.65% per annum for the first three years and 2.3% thereafter, and OCBC at 1.68% per annum for the same period.

site_title: Home proud
summary: Singapore-based furniture retailer King Living has expanded its offerings with Lego furniture, allowing homeowners to shop for unique and playful pieces. The company also provides online styling tips to help customers choose the perfect items. Additionally, King Living has opened a new store in Singapore, offering a variety of home decor items. This expansion aims to cater to the growing demand for creative and innovative furniture solutions.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Malaysia Airlines mulls premium service
summary: Malaysia Airlines is considering introducing a premium economy option to attract long-haul business travelers. CEO Christoph Mueller said the airline will decide on the option in a couple of months, targeting economy class passengers to avoid cannibalizing business class demand. The move aims to increase revenue per passenger and help the airline exit years of losses. The airline has been seeking recovery after suffering huge damage to its brand following the disappearance of MH370 and the downing of MH17. The fate of the airline's A380s remains uncertain, with Mueller saying he would "never say never" to retiring them.

site_title: General Motors to sell China-made cars in US in 2016
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to sell Chinese-made cars in the US starting early 2016, marking a first for a major carmaker. The company will import 30,000 to 40,000 Buick Envisions, a midsize SUV, into the US market. The move aims to fill a gap in the brand's product line and isn't a cost-saving measure. The introduction of the Envision will add a third SUV to Buick's lineup in the US, joining the Encore and Enclave.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q3 profit up 5.4%
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp's Q3 net profit increased by 5.4% to S$85.2 million, driven by revenue growth in its transport-provision businesses. The company posted earnings of 3.97 Singapore cents per share for the three months ended September, with nine-month profit rising 6.3% to S$233.7 million. This represents a 5.4% increase in revenue, primarily due to sales growth in its bus, taxi, rail, car-rental and leasing, and bus-station businesses.

site_title: Christie's ends run of auctions with solid bids
summary: Christie's concluded its two-week auction run with solid bids, despite a perceived decline in interest in impressionist and modern art. The Imps & Mods sale saw 77% of lots sold, with 45% selling above estimate. Notable sales included a 1960s Warhol print and a 1980s Rothko painting. The results indicate a shift towards contemporary art, as the market continues to prioritize this sector.

site_title: Case rivets rarefied art world
summary: Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev's 38 art pieces, including Picasso's Tete de Femme.Profil and Espagnole a l'eventail, are at the center of a dispute with Swiss freeport king Yves Bouvier. The artworks, valued at US$118 million, were allegedly stolen without Bouvier's knowledge, with Picasso's stepdaughter claiming ownership. The paintings have been handed over to French authorities for investigation, and Bouvier faces charges in Monaco. A Rothko painting is also in dispute, with allegations of unpaid debt.

site_title: YouTube joins music streaming fray
