summary: YouTube launches YouTube Music, a music streaming service offering songs with and without videos, and users can switch to audio-only mode instantly. The service will create non-stop stations tailored to users and be available on Google's Android system and Apple devices, initially in the US. YouTube Music will be free but ad-free for subscribers to YouTube Red, which costs $9.99/month. The service aims to reach a new audience and draw users to streaming instead of competing with other companies, while also addressing concerns about music industry payments.

site_title: Retail sales, producer prices fare poorly in October
summary: US retail sales rose 0.1% in October, lower than expected, due to a decline in automobile purchases. Producer prices dropped 0.4% for the second consecutive month, indicating subdued inflation pressures. The weak spending tone is unlikely to shift expectations of a strong Federal Reserve rate hike next month, despite a robust employment report in October.

site_title: Gains from yuan inclusion in SDR not so clear-cut
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has designated the yuan as its fifth reserve currency, but its inclusion is uncertain due to China's slow progress in opening its markets. Banks predict that the yuan's entry could attract between $4 trillion and $7 trillion in funds over five years, but some warn that the endorsement may be symbolic until China lifts capital controls and improves its opaque markets. The yuan's potential to boost Chinese debt and interest rates is seen as a medium to long-term process, with investors favoring currencies like the Swiss franc and Aussie dollar until China's financial markets become more developed.

site_title: In his customer's shoes
summary: Chef Claude Bosi, owner of two-Michelin-starred Hibiscus Restaurant in London, regularly dines at his own restaurant to experience the same experience his customers have. He acts as a customer every six weeks to evaluate his dishes and identify unnecessary elements, ensuring that the food meets his high standards. This practice has helped him simplify his modern French dishes over the years. Bosi's approach allows him to stay connected to his customers and refine his culinary skills, making him a true master of his craft.

images.alt_text: "During winter I love a bit of smokiness to my food, during summer it would be lighter and more fresh. I wouldn't say my menu is made up of my favourite dishes, but it would be dishes I would get excited about if I were to eat it." - Chef Bosi
Meadowsweet Panna Cotta

site_title: No single solution
summary: Researchers suggest combining statins with newer alternatives to combat blocked arteries. Lowering low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) has been associated with reduced heart attacks, strokes, and death. However, statin side effects, including diabetes, brain impact, and kidney damage, are significant concerns. A 2010 study found that statin use can lead to 4 new cases of diabetes per 1,000 patients over 4 years, but also prevents 22 cardiovascular events. Combining statins with newer alternatives may offer a more effective solution without increasing side effects.

site_title: Thanksgiving turkeys cost more after bird flu wipeout
summary: US turkey prices have reached a record high due to a devastating avian influenza outbreak that destroyed nearly 8 million turkeys earlier this year. The shortage has led to smaller-sized birds, with most stores only offering turkeys weighing 20-22 pounds. Wholesale prices for fresh turkeys have surged 18% and frozen turkeys 5.6%, with average prices reaching record highs. American consumers will eat about 49 million turkeys for Thanksgiving, with demand for larger birds expected to be difficult to meet.

site_title: Singapore Flyer boosts Straco Q3
summary: Straco Corporation, a tourist attraction operator, reported a 21% increase in net profit to S$23.6 million for its third quarter ended September 30, 2015. Revenue rose 28% to S$49.3 million, driven by contributions from the Singapore Flyer, which Straco acquired last year. Total visitor numbers increased by 5% to 2 million, with higher visitor numbers at the Shanghai Ocean Aquarium. Net asset value per share was S$0.257, and the company is net cash with S$64 million.

site_title: CityDev unit to renovate Grand Copthorne Waterfront for S$17m
summary: CityDevelopments' (CDL) Millennium & Copthorne Hotels unit plans to renovate the 574-room Grand Copthorne Waterfront hotel in Singapore for S$17 million, with the first phase completed by April 2016. The makeover will include the lobby and food and beverage outlets, while the second phase will focus on the hotel's second storey, set to be completed between May and July 2016. The renovation aims to enhance the hotel's amenities and appeal to guests.

site_title: Hong Kong posts 0.9% Q3 growth
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 0.9% in Q3, outperforming expectations despite China's slowdown and weaker retail sales. The city's economy expanded 2.3% year-over-year, driven by robust domestic demand. However, the outlook for merchandise exports and inbound tourists remains bleak, putting pressure on retailers and potentially leading to job losses. Experts warn of uncertain factors, including a potential US interest rate hike, which could further impact the strong Hong Kong dollar and affect tourism.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singaporean telco Singtel reported flat core net profit in Q2 FY2016, despite higher associates earnings, due to weaker Optus earnings. Earnings were in line with expectations. Genting Singapore's core net profit fell short of expectations due to doubtful debts and reduced VIP volume. Noble Group's core profit fell 40% y-o-y, with analysts suggesting a partial sale of associates and strategic investor involvement could re-rate the company. Analysts maintained "hold" calls for Singtel and Genting, while downgrading Noble to "hold" and revising its target price. Potential catalysts include regional currency rebound and Optus earnings improvements.

site_title: Ferrari world
summary: Finali Mondiali, Ferrari's annual extravaganza, took place at the Mugello circuit in Italy, attracting a record 40,000 attendees. The event featured track days, racing, and displays of Ferrari models, including historic F1 cars and the latest F12tdf model. Ferrari drivers Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen made appearances, taking F1 customer cars out on the track for a demonstration. The event showcased Ferrari's brand equity and passion from its fans, solidifying its unique status in the automotive world.

site_title: Apec still has role in helping region grow
summary: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) bloc remains relevant, supporting sustainable economic growth and prosperity in the region. Apec's 21 member-economies, home to 2.8 billion people and 57% of world GDP, will convene in Manila for the annual Apec Summit, focusing on "Building inclusive economies, building a better world". The bloc aims to help micro, small and medium-sized enterprises access supply chains, financing, and information, while maintaining a non-binding, consensus-based approach. Apec's relevance is expected to endure, despite growing concerns about economic inequities.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
A Filipino policeman on patrol in a street leading to the venue of the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Manila, Philippines on Nov 10, 2015.

site_title: A glowing party on the run
summary: The Illumi Run, a 5km glow-in-the-dark party run, will be held on November 28 in Singapore. The event, now in its third year, attracts a large number of participants, mostly teenagers, who enjoy the music and dance elements along with the run. With its popularity, the event has expanded to other cities in Asia, including Brisbane, Beijing, and Guangzhou, with plans to introduce it in Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, and Thailand. The event's director, Jeffrey Foo, aims to sustain the event for at least four to five years before needing to come up with a new concept to retain the Illumi brand.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Mushrooming growth for a special product
summary: Singaporean supermarket chains now carry Maitake, Bunashimeji, and Bunapi mushrooms under the Hokto label, supplied by Hokuto Corporation's Malaysian subsidiary. The company, which started growing mushrooms in Japan in 1990, uses clean-room technology and organic inputs to cultivate the specialty mushrooms. Maitake mushrooms, known for their medicinal qualities, are in high demand and the company plans to expand its market to Vietnam, Thailand, and Indonesia. This high-tech farming approach ensures a stable supply and is seen as a promising future in agriculture.

images.alt_text: SHELF LIFE: The Maitake mushrooms are flown in from Japan, while the two other varieties are grown in Selangor, Malaysia, since Hokuto Corporation set up a plant under its Malaysian subsidiary, Hokto, in 2012.

SHELF LIFE: The Maitake mushrooms are flown in from Japan, while the two other varieties are grown in Selangor, Malaysia, since Hokuto Corporation set up a plant under its Malaysian subsidiary, Hokto, in 2012.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi's party seals historic election win in Myanmar
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, secured 364 seats in Myanmar's Parliament, securing a historic election win and ousting the military-linked government. This victory paves the way for Myanmar to move closer to full democracy, with the NLD promising to further open the economy and bring about change. The win is seen as a significant shift in the country's politics, with China and India watching closely, as both nations vie for influence in the region.

site_title: Freeport king fails in appeal against Monaco criminal charges
summary: Monaco's appeals court has rejected Swiss businessman Yves Bouvier's appeal against charges of fraud and complicity in money laundering, related to alleged art market fraud of nearly $1.5 billion. Bouvier, a Singapore permanent resident, had filed the appeal citing "procedural irregularities" and questioned the "systematic bias" of investigators. The case, involving Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev, is set to proceed to a trial before the Monaco Court.

images.alt_text: ART OF THE MATTER: Swiss businessman Bouvier is a Singapore permanent resident who is behind Le Freeport in Singapore.

site_title: Oil inventory glut at its highest in at least a decade: Opec
summary: Opec's oil inventory glut has reached its highest level in at least a decade, exceeding the 2009 surplus, due to increased global production and a slowdown in non-Opec supply. The group's production slipped last month, with Iraq's decline attributed to storms and sabotage. Oil prices have lost 40% in the past year, and the current excess is bigger than the 2009 surplus, with inventories 210 million barrels higher than the five-year average. Opec's policy review on December 4 may consider changing strategy to support prices.

site_title: Global uncertainty, strong dollar hit Cisco sales
summary: Cisco Systems Inc reported weaker-than-expected global sales due to economic uncertainty and a strong US dollar, forcing the company to lower its forecast. International sales of internet traffic equipment declined, with companies in Latin America, Canada, and parts of Asia hesitant to spend on new infrastructure. Despite a 20% increase in revenue from data center operators, Cisco's shares fell 5.6% in extended trading. The company now expects profit of 53-55 cents per share and revenue of up to $12.2 billion in the fiscal second quarter.

site_title: Sporting GOH joins SGX charity run
summary: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Bull Charge 2015 charity run raised S$2.9 million for four charities, including the Asian Women's Welfare Association and Autism Association (Singapore). Over 6,000 runners participated, with guest-of-honour Social and Family Development Minister Tan Chuan-Jin joining the 5km Mass Run. The event featured a 3km Chief Challenge, supported by 144 corporate sponsors.

site_title: Wheelock's net profit for Q3 up 2.4% at S$11.26m
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a 2.4% increase in Q3 net profit to S$11.26 million, driven by revenue growth from condo sales and other income. Revenue rose to S$83.90 million, with a 71.8% decline in net profit for the first nine months due to negative goodwill. The company's cash and cash equivalents stood at S$591.47 million as of end-September 2015.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Apec at a glance
summary: Key events and facts include Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup setting a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thaksin Shinawatra is confident in Thailand's court clearing his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case. ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority, and Malaysia's stance on this issue. The UK economy shrinks for the second consecutive month, posing a challenge to UK Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Fossil buys wearable device firm for US$260m
summary: Fossil has agreed to acquire wearable device firm Misfit for US$260 million, bolstering its technology and expanding into smartwatches. Misfit's battery-life tech and wearable devices, such as fitness trackers and smart buttons, will be integrated across Fossil's 16 brands. The acquisition aims to marry fashion with technology, with Fossil CEO Kosta Kartsotis stating the company is poised to capitalize on the trend. The deal is expected to be completed before the end of the year.

site_title: China banks take market share from stalwarts in Asian LBO loan business
summary: Chinese banks are expanding their market share in the Asian private equity (PE) buyout loans business, taking a 32% share of the $9 billion market, up from 6% last year. To offset slower economic growth and rising bad debts, Chinese banks are offering generous terms, including longer loan periods and higher leverage multiples, to attract clients. This is driven by China's increasing demand for LBO loans following a wave of privatisations of US-listed mainland companies, and a desire to diversify revenue sources.

site_title: Tat Hong's Q2 results show signs of stabilisation
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net profit of S$4.4 million in its Q2 results, down 62% from the same period last year, due to cost-cutting measures and economic conditions in its key markets. Revenue fell 10% to S$137.4 million, mainly due to declines in crawler and mobile crane rental segments. However, distribution revenue increased due to higher demand for cranes in certain countries. The company plans to spin off its tower crane segment in Taiwan next year and has a net asset value of S$1.02 per share.

site_title: The Philippines set to welcome Apec leaders
summary: The Philippines is set to host the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) Summit in Manila, a high-profile event in nearly 20 years. As the chair of Apec, the Philippines has held numerous meetings and is expected to roll out the red carpet for Asia-Pacific leaders. The two-day Economic Leaders' Meeting is scheduled to start on Wednesday, with event organizers raising eyebrows over the substantial budget. Despite this, Manila is optimistic about potential economic spinoffs from the event.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China probes market watchdog's vice-chair over selloff
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection launched an investigation into Yao Gang, a vice-chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, over alleged serious disciplinary violations. Yao, 53, is being probed for his role in the issuance department, where rent-seeking is prevalent. This investigation follows a crackdown on the financial industry, which has been expanding its anti-corruption campaign under President Xi Jinping. The probe may signal a fundamental change to China's financing mechanisms and orderly development of capital markets.

site_title: Up close and personal
summary: A growing trend in restaurant dining is the use of chef's tables, offering diners front-row access to the cooking action. Located in the kitchen, these tables are typically reserved for special guests and served by the head chef. This trend allows diners to experience the culinary process up close, enhancing their connection with the restaurant and chef.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Headwinds buffet Singapore retail sector
summary: Singapore's retail sector has faced a challenging fiscal quarter, with listed retailers posting gloomy results due to tough operating conditions, softer consumer demand, and a strong Singapore dollar. Key retailers such as The Hour Glass, OSIM International, and F J Benjamin reported lower earnings, with some incurring higher costs and expenses. Tourism spend also declined, with visitor arrivals dipping 0.3% year-on-year to 11.35 million. Despite this, domestic demand remains strong, driven by domestic confidence and a tight labor market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Govts should lay off property markets: don
summary: Professor Joseph Gyourko, a real estate expert at the University of Pennsylvania, suggests that governments should regulate banks instead of directly intervening in real estate markets. He argues that governments cannot accurately determine optimal price levels and that regulating banks can help prevent systemic risk. Gyourko supports increasing capital requirements for banks, which he believes can help prevent bank runs and mitigate the risk of a massive collapse. He also notes that transparency in data and information can help private developers make informed decisions about the market.

site_title: Making angels out of investors
summary: Wealthy individuals, business owners, and executives attend invitation-only "boot camps" organized by Angel Labs, a global angel investor academy, to learn about assessing startups. These events, held weekly worldwide, aim to increase the influence of angel investing, a field where affluent individuals invest in early-stage tech companies. Co-founder Tugce Ergul stated that attendees, mostly accomplished businesspeople, have never invested in early-stage companies but can offer valuable insights to entrepreneurs. The events widen the participation of angel investors in the tech industry, addressing a perceived lack of engagement among affluent investors.

site_title: Boustead Q2 profit drops 41% on oil and gas weakness
summary: Boustead's Q2 net profit fell 41% to S$10.3 million, or 2 Singapore cents per share, due to weakness in the oil and gas segment. Revenue decreased 11% to S$115.1 million, with energy-related engineering sales shrinking 33% and real estate solutions sales improving 6%. The company remains cautious on its business prospects, with lower gross margins expected and a focus on remaining profitable in fiscal 2016, albeit at a lower level than in 2015. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent is declared.

site_title: Main component in solar power dirt cheap
summary: Polysilicon prices, a key component in solar cells, have hit a record low of US$14.76 per kilogram, down 31% in the past year, due to a global supply glut. This decrease is expected to linger as suppliers struggle to maintain profitability. The drop is attributed to an oversupply of the material, with major suppliers including Wacker Chemie AG, Hemlock Semiconductor Corp, and Hanwha Chemical Corp.

images.alt_text: BOOMING DEMAND: Ninety per cent of the world's polysilicon supplies ended up in solar panels in 2014, up from 27 per cent in 2001.

site_title: Face to face with a ruthless 'Emperor'
summary: A writer shares their experience of undergoing 40 sessions of radiotherapy for prostate cancer, highlighting three key lessons: the importance of knowledge, lifestyle choices, and diet in preventing or delaying cancer. They emphasize the need for informed decision-making, including financial planning and regular health check-ups. The writer also expresses gratitude for the dedicated medical staff at the National Cancer Centre and encourages readers to prioritize their relationships and invest in their well-being to avoid meeting the "ruthless Emperor" of cancer.

site_title: US rate hike, slowing growth hobbling STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% on Friday, closing at 2,925.68, due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike in December and a slowing global economy. Weak liquidity and underwhelming third-quarter earnings reports from key stocks, including Noble Group and Genting Singapore, also contributed to the decline. Analysts predict a rate hike in December, with some warning of a slow pace of increases due to dovish Federal Reserve members.

site_title: Engineering better solutions
summary: Renowned architect Christoph Ingenhoven believes that "architects are over-rated" due to the increasing focus on facade treatments over intensive problem-solving approaches. He advocates for a more integrated design process that incorporates various disciplines, particularly engineering. Ingenhoven, a proponent of Modernist design, argues that engineering should drive the design process, not aesthetics. His firm, Ingenhoven Architects, is known for sustainable and environmentally friendly designs, such as the RWE tower and 1 Bligh tower in Sydney, which have won numerous awards. Ingenhoven's approach emphasizes the importance of engineering in creating better solutions, rather than just visually appealing designs.

images.alt_text: STUNNING STRUCTURES: Ingenhoven Architects' 1 Bligh tower in Sydney (above) has won several awards. The firm is also behind the upcoming 3.67 million sq ft Marina One at Marina Bay in Singapore.
STUNNING STRUCTURES: Ingenhoven Architects' 1 Bligh tower in Sydney has won several awards. The firm is also behind the upcoming 3.67 million sq ft Marina One at Marina Bay in Singapore (above) .

"Even if you have the technology ... it doesn't mean you have to do crazy forms just because you can. I think there's nothing special about that - it's just 'PoMo' (Post Modernism)."- Mr Ingenhoven (above)

site_title: SCC president, deputy survive ouster bid
summary: Singapore Cricket Club (SCC) president Baldev Singh and his deputy Brian Teo survived a no-confidence vote at a special general meeting, with seven general committee members failing to oust them from their posts. The resolutions to remove the seven members, who had signed a petition to oust Singh and Teo, also failed due to a lack of minimum 10-day notice period. The meeting, which lasted nearly five hours, attracted over 600 attendees. Singh and Teo secured the majority of the votes cast, securing their positions in the club's general committee.

images.alt_text: Singapore Cricket Club.

site_title: Malaysian economy's Q3 growth slowest in over two years
summary: Malaysia's economy experienced its slowest growth in over two years, with a 4.7% expansion in the third quarter. This is the lowest rate since 2013 and follows previous quarters of 5.6% and 4.9%. The country's current account surplus narrowed to RM5.1 billion, its lowest level since 2013. The Malaysian ringgit has lost 20% of its value this year due to weak global prices for oil and commodity exports, subdued demand from China, and a scandal involving the 1MDB state fund. The central bank remains cautious but notes the economy's resilience.

site_title: NYSE asks SEC to let it flag 'aberrant' trading in ETFs
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to allow it to flag "aberrant" pricing of exchange-traded funds (ETFs). The NYSE requested permission to discourage traders from relying on prices that are inconsistent with the prevailing market. This move aims to maintain market integrity and prevent trading based on inaccurate prices. The SEC will review the NYSE's request, which is based on a previous October 28 request.

site_title: Asean can take a leaf from Africa's M-Pesa
summary: African mobile money platforms, such as M-Pesa, have successfully increased financial inclusivity by providing low-cost, convenient, and safe services to millions of people without traditional bank accounts. The East African Community (EAC) members have seen significant growth in mobile money accounts, with some countries like Rwanda having 43% of bank account holders using mobile money. The Kenyan government's liberalization of the policy environment and partnerships with mobile operators have enabled the widespread adoption of M-Pesa. Similar mobile money platforms are being explored in ASEAN countries with low financial reach, such as Cambodia, Indonesia, and Vietnam, which have high mobile phone penetration and low bank account penetration.

site_title: Partial disposal gain lifts Parkson's Q1
summary: Parkson Retail Asia reported a net profit of S$49.46 million for the first quarter of FY16, up from S$6.87 million, driven by a gain of S$46 million from the partial disposal of a stake in Parkson Hanoi Co. Revenue fell 15.7% to S$92.69 million, while earnings per share rose to 7.3 Singapore cents. The company expects subdued consumer sentiment in Malaysia but expects strong performance in Indonesia, driven by increasing domestic demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Barclays puts freeze on staff hiring until Jan in cost-cutting move
summary: Barclays has implemented a hiring freeze for new staff until January as part of its cost-cutting efforts. The freeze, which has been in place since late September, includes exceptions for UK branch staff and critical positions. The bank aims to shed 19,000 staff, or 14% of its global workforce, as part of its three-year cost-cutting plan. New CEO Jes Staley is expected to continue this focus on cost savings.

site_title: Global warming may force changes to French wine
summary: Bordeaux winegrowers are adapting to climate change by exploring heat-tolerant grape varietals to preserve the region's characteristic flavor. The threat of global warming may force changes to the region's wine production, potentially altering the signature aromas that define Bordeaux wines. To mitigate this, winemakers are experimenting with techniques such as growing more bunches per vine, partially shading grapes, and planting rootstocks more tolerant of warmer temperatures. The region's prestige wines may need to be revised to include new varietals, such as Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot, to ensure optimal maturation and quality.

images.alt_text: WANTED: A MERLOT SUBSTITUTE: The search is on for grape varietals other than Merlot (left), which can stand warmer climes and yet create wines with the traditional Bordeaux flavour.

site_title: Small bites, big tastes
summary: Four new F&B outlets, including Meta Restaurant, are introducing Asian flavors to the small-plates sharing concept, elevating the concept. Meta Restaurant is located at 9 Keong Saik Road and is open Monday to Saturday from 5:30pm to midnight. The new concept aims to provide innovative and exciting dining experiences.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower on weak retail data; Cisco drags
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, driven by weak October retail sales data and disappointing forecasts from department store chains and Cisco. The Dow Jones fell 120 points, or 0.68%, to 17,324, while the S&P 500 lost 13 points, or 0.63%, to 2,033. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 42 points, or 0.84%, to 4,964.

site_title: Higher cost of sales stagnates Vallianz Q3 profit
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported flat net attributable profit of US$4.9 million in the third quarter, driven by a 52.4% increase in revenue to US$59.8 million. However, cost of sales rose 72.6% to US$43 million, offsetting the revenue growth. The company attributed the slowdown in the global offshore marine industry to increased competition and plans to diversify into other markets, with a US$940 million outstanding order book.

images.alt_text: Mr Ling Yong Wah, CEO of Vallianz Holdings.

site_title: VW brand sales fall 5.3% in first full month of emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen brand sales declined 5.3% in October, marking the eighth consecutive monthly drop, following the diesel emissions scandal. Deliveries dropped to 490,000 cars from 517,400 a year ago. Sales chief Juergen Stackmann stated that the company faces "challenging times" due to the scandal and market tensions.

site_title: Modi's UK visit yields £9 billion of deals
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's UK visit resulted in £9 billion of deals, including a £1.3 billion investment by Vodafone Group plc and a £3.2 billion package for clean energy. The agreements also cover nuclear power plants, renewable energy, and defence cooperation. Modi and UK Prime Minister David Cameron welcomed the partnerships, citing the potential for further cooperation between the two nations. The deals were made during Modi's visit, which was overshadowed by protests over intolerance in India.

site_title: Maersk gets debt market warning to shun container line takeovers
summary: Debt markets are warning Maersk against pursuing an acquisition in the struggling container line industry, citing rising borrowing costs and potential dilution of margins. Moody's Investors Service has a Baa1 rating for Maersk and a B1 junk rating for CMA CGM, and notes that consolidation in the industry would be positive for cost structures but may take more than one merger to improve market conditions. Maersk has cut its 2015 forecast for underlying profit and plans to slash 4,000 jobs, and may instead focus on investing in its other units, such as Maersk Oil.

site_title: China's 'Bling Dynasty' swept by change of pace, place and face
summary: China's luxury market is experiencing a downturn due to economic slowdown and anti-corruption efforts, but buyers remain, just requiring new approaches. The Shanghai composite index is down 35% since its peak, yet still up 40% over the last 12 months. Luxury brands should adapt to the changing market by understanding young, savvy consumers who are increasingly traveling abroad. As Hong Kong's role diminishes, luxury stores may close, and brands will need to recruit new buyers rather than relying on existing ones. Despite challenges, Chinese luxury demand is likely to double to 150 million over the next 10 years.

site_title: Britain's Serious Fraud Office charges 10 individuals over Euribor
summary: Britain's Serious Fraud Office has charged 10 Barclays and Deutsche Bank employees with conspiracy to defraud in connection with the alleged manipulation of the Euribor interest rate benchmark. The defendants, including Colin Bermingham and Christian Bittar, will appear in court on January 11, 2016. The investigation continues, with additional charges expected. This marks the first criminal proceedings related to Euribor manipulation.

site_title: PM Lee in Turkey for two-day G20 Summit
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is attending the two-day G20 Summit in Antalya, Turkey, as the country's fifth non-member invitee. The summit aims to discuss global economic challenges and promote job creation. Lee is accompanied by Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat and a delegation of 20 Singaporeans. The event also includes the signing of a Turkey-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and the Business 20 (B20) meetings, which bring together private-sector leaders from across the world.

site_title: Oil set for second weekly drop as inventories climb to record
summary: Oil prices are expected to decline for a second week, trading near two-month lows, due to record-high inventories and strong global supply. US crude supplies rose to 487 million barrels, the highest in over 80 years, while international energy advisory group the International Energy Agency reported a record 3 billion barrels of stockpiles. Crude has dropped 45% in the past year, and oil inventories in developed nations increased by 13.8 million barrels in September.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Companies reported earnings, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue shortfalls and operating losses. Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: CDL unit to renovate Grand Copthorne Waterfront hotel for S$17m
summary: CDL's Millennium & Copthorne Hotels unit plans to renovate the 574-room Grand Copthorne Waterfront hotel in Singapore for S$17 million, in two phases from 2016. The lobby and food and beverage areas will be completed by April 2016, while the second storey renovation will take place from May to July 2016. This is part of a global renovation plan by the London-listed company, which also includes projects in the US and UK.

site_title: Wheelock Properties' Q3 net profit rises 2.4% to S$11.26m
summary: Wheelock Properties' Q3 net profit rose 2.4% to S$11.26 million, driven by increased revenue from condo sales and "other income" from the disposal of investment securities. Cash reserves increased to S$591.47 million, while earnings per share rose to 0.94 cents. The counter ended 5 cents lower at S$1.465.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Boustead Q2 profit drops 41% on oil and gas weakness
summary: Boustead's Q2 profit dropped 41% to S$10.3 million due to weaker demand from the oil and gas segment, resulting in a 11% decline in revenue to S$115.1 million. The company's order book backlog remains strong at S$353 million. Despite this, Boustead expects to remain profitable in FY2016, but at a significantly lower level than FY2015. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent is declared.

site_title: Straits Trading narrows losses in Q3
summary: Straits Trading Company narrowed its third-quarter loss to S$7.05 million, a 62% reduction from the previous year, despite a 6.2% slide in revenue to S$199.1 million. The loss was mainly due to mark-to-market losses from marketable securities and lower tin prices. Resources revenue fell 5.4% to S$195.79 million, with razor-thin margins of S$3.49 million. The conglomerate's real estate unit reported a S$6.74 million net loss, down 37.1% year-on-year.

site_title: Japan's top banks to accelerate cutting client equity holdings
summary: Japan's top banks, including Mizuho Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, plan to accelerate the cutback of client equity holdings to reduce market risks and improve corporate governance. Mizuho aims to dispose of at least 70% of its equity holdings by 2019, while Sumitomo Mitsui targets a 50% reduction in five years. The move follows regulatory pressure and criticism of the practice, which has hindered good governance in companies.

site_title: Cheap oil set to lose effect on growth in demand: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) expects global oil demand to grow by 1.2 million barrels per day in 2016, a slowdown from a five-year high of 1.8 mbd this year. Cheap oil is losing its effect on growth in demand, with colder-than-year-earlier winter weather and post-recessionary economic growth contributing to increased consumption. Oil stocks remain at a record 3 billion barrels, providing a "massive cushion" against supply disruptions. The IEA warns that oil prices may continue to pressure the market, especially if forecasts for a mild winter in Europe and the US are true.

site_title: Standard Chartered CEO Winters buys US$1.5 million of bank shares
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters has bought 1 million pounds (S$2.2 million) of shares in the bank, increasing his ownership to 229,035. The move comes a week after the bank sought US$5.1 billion from investors and unveiled its revised strategy. Winters stated that the investment aligns him with shareholders and reflects his confidence in the bank's long-term growth. The bank's shares were little changed at 581.8 pence following the announcement.

site_title: Olam's Q3 profit falls 30%
summary: Olam International's third-quarter net profit fell 30% to S$31 million, despite a 4% increase in revenue to S$4.5 billion. Operational profit after tax and minority interest rose 6.2% to S$34.2 million. The absence of a one-time gain from debt redemption and a gain from the sale of a dairy processing plant in Cote d'Ivoire last year contributed to the decline. Olam's gearing level decreased to 1.43 times, and the company is pleased with its performance amidst economic turbulence, with a focus on disciplined investments and growth potential.

site_title: US retail sales barely rise as auto purchases fall
summary: US retail sales rose 0.1% in October, narrowly missing expectations, as auto purchases fell 0.5% after a 1.4% increase in September. This suggests a slowdown in consumer spending, potentially tempering expectations of strong fourth-quarter economic growth. Core retail sales, excluding autos, gasoline, and other items, rose 0.2%. The decline in auto sales may be attributed to savings from cheaper gasoline being used to pay rents, which have increased substantially over the past year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 4.29 points to 1,658.91. The trading volume was 2.2 billion lots, valued at RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 558 to 339.

site_title: Foreign-local worker swap unproductive
summary: The Singapore economy faces uncertainty, with questions about a potential tipping point and tight labor market. A roundtable discussion revealed that replacing foreign workers with locals is unproductive, with low input substitution. Economists warned of three key challenges: a highly leveraged economy, low fertility, and deflation, which could undermine growth. Higher productivity growth is seen as the only way out, but caution is advised to avoid driving away companies. The economy must also be competitive to command a market share.

images.alt_text: Photo of construction workers building a scaffold against the backdrop of the Central Business District on Jul 14, 2015.

site_title: Japan's ANA to convert passenger jets to expand air freight business
summary: Japan's All Nippon Airways (ANA) plans to convert more passenger jets into freighters to expand its air freight business amid a market downturn. The airline's CEO, Osamu Shinobe, aims to increase the number of converted jets to at least 13, using existing 767 passenger fleet. ANA prefers to use existing aircraft for cargo to keep costs low, and has signed cooperation agreements with United Airlines and Lufthansa on cargo shipments between Japan and the US and Europe. This strategy will help ANA capitalize on its cargo hub in Okinawa and provide next-day delivery to key markets in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker on US rate, global growth worries
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 33.33 points or 1.1% to 2,925.68 on Friday, marking a 2.8% loss for the week due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike and slowing global growth. Weaker liquidity and underwhelming third-quarter earnings also contributed to the decline. Key stocks such as Noble Group and Genting Singapore dropped significantly due to disappointing earnings reports.

site_title: Euro-area growth misses estimates as ECB mulls more stimulus
summary: The euro-area economic growth unexpectedly slowed to 0.3% in the third quarter, missing estimates, as the European Central Bank considers additional stimulus. The slowdown in emerging markets, particularly China, poses risks to the region's recovery. ECB President Mario Draghi has signaled the need for fresh stimulus, citing downside risks for growth and inflation. The data adds to the case for the ECB to step up monetary stimulus in December, with a 96% chance of a 10 basis point deposit rate cut.

site_title: Maersk gets debt market warning to shun container line takeovers
summary: Debt markets are warning A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S against pursuing an acquisition in the struggling container line industry due to the toxic cocktail of vessel overcapacity and sluggish global growth. Moody's Investors Service suggests that Maersk Line could dilute margins initially and that real consolidation would likely take more than one merger to improve market conditions. Despite this, Maersk has indicated a willingness to consider acquisitions and may be better off investing in its other units, such as Maersk Oil, which is preparing to buy oil assets in Kenya and Ethiopia.

site_title: China securities regulator says new IPOs should stay cheap
summary: China's stock market regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), advises new initial public offerings (IPOs) to be priced cheaply to stabilize the market. The regulator did not issue new rules or guidelines on pricing, following a halt on IPOs in June to stabilize indexes after the market crashed. China reopened the IPO market on November 6. The decision aims to support the market's recovery.

site_title: German economic growth eases in third quarter
summary: German economic growth slowed to 0.3% in the third quarter, down from 0.4% in the previous quarter. The decline was attributed to factory orders and industrial production, which fell for the third month in a row. Retail sales also stagnated, with shoppers becoming more cautious about the economic impact of the migrant influx. This slowdown comes amidst global economic headwinds, including China's slowing growth and the Volkswagen pollution scandal.

site_title: Tiong Seng turns to profit in Q3 as costs, expenses decline
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings reported a profit of S$2.7 million in Q3, reversing a year-ago loss of S$7.9 million. The construction and property development group's earnings per share rose to 0.58 Singapore cents, driven by a 71% decline in cost of sales and an 86% drop in other expenses. Total revenue rose 2% to S$165.3 million, with construction turnover growing 18% to S$155.2 million. Tiong Seng's construction order book stands at S$1.4 billion through 2020.

site_title: JPMorgan backs away from US stock bull market's top performer
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co's head of US equity strategy, Dubravko Lakos-Bujas, warns that the top-performing consumer-discretionary stocks face "significant risk" as investors seek inflation acceleration. The sector, which includes media, retailers, and automakers, has quadrupled in value since 2009, but Lakos-Bujas cites concerns over wage inflation and fading benefits from lower energy prices. Analysts are more optimistic, predicting 12.5% profit growth and 5.9% sales growth, but Lakos-Bujas recommends cutting holdings to bring them in line with market benchmarks due to "rich valuation" and sector-specific risks.

site_title: Tat Hong Q2 net profit down 62% to S$4.4m; no interim dividend
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net profit of S$4.4 million for its second quarter, down 62% from the previous year, due to revenue falls in various rental divisions. Revenue declined 10% to S$137.4 million, primarily caused by weak Australian and Singaporean construction sectors. Distribution revenue grew, however, due to higher demand for cranes in certain markets. No interim dividend was declared, and the company's shares closed down a cent to S$0.55.

site_title: Figtree Q3 profit jumps to S$3m on revenue from two projects
summary: Figtree Holdings' Q3 net profit surged to S$3 million, with earnings per share reaching 1.06 Singapore cents. Revenue from two projects, Crystal Freight Services Distripark and Development 8, increased turnover by 162% to S$48.2 million. The company remains cautiously optimistic about future prospects, with a current order book of S$66.6 million in the design-and-build segment.

site_title: Exxon Mobil to drill offshore post-Ebola Liberia
summary: Exxon Mobil plans to start drilling offshore in Liberia in late 2016 or early 2017, after the country declared itself Ebola-free in September. The move is seen as a sign of economic recovery and a demonstration of Liberia's readiness to invest in its oil industry. Exxon Mobil had previously awarded a bloc in 2003 but put the project on hold due to the Ebola epidemic. The US has lifted economic sanctions on Liberia, allowing the country to regain its economic footing after the devastating outbreak.

site_title: Hong Kong Q3 GDP grows slightly, beats estimates
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 0.9% in the third quarter, beating expectations, with a year-over-year expansion of 2.3%. The growth rate is slower than the second quarter's 2.8% but still slightly better than forecast. The economy's growth forecast for 2015 was revised to 2.4% from 2-3%. The results are attributed to a slowdown in China and weaker retail sales, with external headwinds including uncertainty over US monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's economy grew slightly in the third quarter from the second, beating expectations, despite a slowdown in China and weaker retail sales.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q3 profit grows 5.4% on modest revenue gain
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 5.4% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$85.2 million, driven by modest revenue growth in transport-provision businesses. Revenue rose 1% to S$1 billion, with sales growth in bus, rail, taxi, car rental, and leasing, but declines in car engineering and testing services. The company expects sales to improve in bus, rail, and taxi businesses, while maintaining revenue from certain other sectors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 2% lower on broad sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.2% on Friday, with the Hang Seng index closing at 22,396.14, following a strong day on Thursday. This marks the worst day in two weeks and the worst weekly performance since early October. The decline is attributed to investors taking profits across various sectors. The index fell 2.1% for the week, with a total trading volume of 2.1 billion shares.

site_title: Australia: Shares close down as falling commodities weigh on index
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.5% on Friday, closing at 5,051.3, amid falling commodity prices and expectations of a US interest rate hike. Oil, gold, and copper hit multi-year lows, contributing to the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 3.1% for the week and 7% for the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down 0.51%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.51% on Friday, following a broad sell-off on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,596.91, down 100.86 points. This comes after recent rallies, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Shanghai, Shenzhen exchanges raise margin financing requirement ratio
summary: Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges will raise the base margin financing ratio to 100% from 50% effective Nov 23, requiring investors to keep 100% of margin loan collateral. This move aims to reduce trading risk, but may also impact market liquidity. The change takes effect on November 23 and applies to both exchanges.

site_title: China Aviation Oil's Q3 profit doubles, despite revenue falling by half
summary: China Aviation Oil's Q3 profit more than doubled to $17.7 million, despite revenue falling 49.8% to $2.4 billion due to a drop in jet fuel prices. The company reported a positive gross profit of $12.9 million and reduced administrative expenses. CAO's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, attributed the result to the company's growing strengths in the jet fuel market and plans to expand its global jet fuel trading network.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 4.6% in September year-over-year, driven by motor vehicle sales, while excluding motor vehicles, sales declined 1.4%. Meanwhile, City Developments called for review of curbs due to earnings drop. In other news, Malaysia's agency is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Indonesia's Q3 current account deficit shrinks, balance of payments shows US$4.6b deficit
summary: Indonesia's Q3 current account deficit narrowed to $4.0 billion, or 1.86% of GDP, compared to $4.2 billion in the previous quarter. The balance of payments showed a $4.6 billion deficit. This improvement is attributed to a decrease in imports and a slight increase in exports.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's current account deficit shrank in the third quarter to US$4.0 billion, and the balance of payments shows a deficit of US$4.6 billion, Bank Indonesia said on Friday.

site_title: Update: Aung San Suu Kyi's NLD seals historic election win in Myanmar
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) secured 332 seats in Myanmar's parliament, a historic victory that will loosen the military's grip on the country. Suu Kyi, 70, led her party to a landslide win, allowing her to choose the next president without needing support from other parties. The NLD's victory marks a significant shift in power, following decades of military rule and Suu Kyi's years of house arrest. The election result is seen as a major step forward for democracy in Myanmar.

site_title: France returns to growth with 0.3% expansion in third quarter
summary: France's economy returned to growth in the third quarter, expanding by 0.3% in July to September, according to the national statistics agency. The growth follows a period of weak economic recovery and is expected to contribute to a 1.1% overall growth for 2015. Finance Minister Michel Sapin stated that the country has entered a "new phase" of growth, which is likely to result in faster growth next year. The government forecasts a 1.5% expansion for 2016, still below the level needed to reduce high unemployment.

site_title: Goldman says only China can rescue metals as mine cuts won't
summary: Goldman Sachs says only a significant rise in Chinese metals demand can balance copper and aluminum markets, citing recent output cuts by miners as insufficient. Copper futures are headed for a fifth straight weekly loss, and metals demand in China slipped again in October. Analysts believe supply growth outweighs demand decline, making a major pickup in Chinese demand necessary to balance markets. Copper prices have dropped 0.8% to $4,787.50 a metric ton, while aluminum has lost 19% to $1,498.50 a ton this year.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.32% to 6,158.93 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index losing 0.17%. The declines follow heavy losses the previous day due to lingering concerns over China and poor company earnings. Commodity prices also fell due to weaker Chinese demand and increased expectations of a US rate hike in December.

site_title: Japan spots Chinese spy ship in new area near disputed isles
summary: Japan has spotted a Chinese spy ship near disputed islands in the East China Sea, marking a new area of operation for the vessel. The Dongdiao-class intelligence vessel was seen near the Senkaku Islands, which Japan administers but China claims. This move follows China's increasing assertiveness in the region and Japan's efforts to strengthen border security. The incident is the latest in a long-standing dispute between the two countries, with tensions remaining high despite recent efforts to improve ties.

site_title: GPCs for Singapore's 13th Parliament formed
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore has formed 12 government parliamentary committees (GPCs) for the 13th Parliament, ahead of the January opening session. This is the first time two separate GPCs have been created for the Ministry of National Development and the Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources. The committees will scrutinize legislation and programs, and serve as an additional channel for feedback on government policies. Each GPC has at least one newly elected member of parliament, with three appointed as deputy chairpersons.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Singapore Flyer boosts Straco Q3 net profit to S$23.6m
summary: Straco Corporation reported a 21% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$23.6 million, driven by revenue growth of 28% to S$49.3 million, largely due to the contribution from the Singapore Flyer, which Straco acquired last year. The company's shares traded at S$0.85.

images.alt_text: Revenue was up 28 per cent to S$49.3 million, from S$38.6 million a year ago, boosted by contributions from the Singapore Flyer, which Straco bought last November.

site_title: China: Stocks close down as manufacturing, energy shares weigh
summary: China's stocks closed down 1.3-1.4% on Friday, weighed down by manufacturing and energy shares. The CSI300 energy subindex fell 2.4% due to sliding oil prices. Total turnover in Shanghai and Shenzhen was 70.6 billion lots. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, while the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines may launch premium economy service: CEO
summary: Malaysia Airlines may introduce a premium economy service to attract long-haul business travelers, with a decision expected in a couple of months. The airline's CEO, Christoph Mueller, stated that the new service will target economy class passengers and not cannibalize business class demand. The move is part of the airline's broader strategy to increase revenue and exit years of losses.

site_title: City Developments calls for curbs review as earnings drop
summary: City Developments Ltd, Singapore's second-largest developer, urged the government to review property curbs due to a 16% drop in earnings and eighth consecutive quarter of declining home prices. The company cited tepid demand for high-end units and adverse impact from government cooling measures, rising interest rates, and global economic concerns. City Developments' shares slid 0.7% to S$7.66, extending this year's 26% drop. The company calls for a review of property curbs, citing a 90% home-ownership rate and risk of a downward spiral in property prices.

site_title: Seoul: Shares slip to over 1-mth low, won eases on Fed, China risks
summary: South Korean shares and the won dropped on Friday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing 1.0% lower at 1,973.29 points, its biggest drop since late August. Offshore investors sold 211.8 billion won worth of stocks, while the won eased 0.5% against the dollar and 1.9% for the week. Weakening commodities, China growth concerns, and a looming US Federal Reserve policy decision contributed to the market downturn.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won hit over 1-month low pressured by commodities
summary: South Korean shares and the won dropped on Friday, hitting a one-month low, due to declining commodities and comments from US Federal Reserve officials suggesting a likely interest rate hike in December. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 1.0% and the won dropped 0.3% against the dollar, its weakest level since October 7. Declining stocks included Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp, and offshore investors were poised to be net sellers for a fourth consecutive session.

site_title: Chinese lenders eat into foreign banks' Asian buyout loan business
summary: Chinese banks are expanding their presence in the US$9 billion private equity buyout loans market in Asia, grabbing market share from European and US rivals. The lenders, including Bank of China Ltd, are using generous terms to diversify their revenue sources and capitalize on a wave of privatisations of US-listed mainland companies. Chinese banks have traditionally focused on financing state-backed acquisitions, but are now single-handedly underwriting entire loans for private enterprises, offering twice the fees typically earned from state-owned enterprises.

images.alt_text: Faced with slower economic growth and rising bad debts at home, Chinese banks are muscling in on the US$9 billion private equity buyout loans business in Asia, using generous terms to grab market share from European and US rivals.

site_title: World leaders laud Myanmar election as Suu Kyi secures majority
summary: Myanmar's National League for Democracy (NLD) party, led by democracy champion Aung San Suu Kyi, has won a majority in parliament, securing enough seats to elect its chosen candidate to the presidency. The historic election, Myanmar's first free vote in 25 years, was praised by UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and US President Barack Obama, who congratulated Suu Kyi on her landmark victory. Suu Kyi's party is expected to push out the old guard of former generals that has run the country since 2011, and the new government will face challenges, including the Rohingya minority crisis.

site_title: Singapore's retail sales up 4.6% in Sept year on year, F&B sales fall
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 4.6% in September year-over-year, driven by motor vehicle sales, which rose 48.3%. Department stores, supermarkets, and medical goods also saw higher takings. However, food and beverage sales dropped 2.7% year-over-year, with petrol stations experiencing the largest decline of 22.5%. The total retail sales value reached S$3.4 billion, higher than the S$3.2 billion in the previous year.

site_title: OCBC's new deposit-based home loan rivals DBS's, says consultancy firm
summary: OCBC has launched a deposit-based home loan pegged at 36 FDMR (fixed deposit mortgage rate), rivaling DBS's version. The loan offers a more generous cash reward, lower qualification bar, and higher payouts, making it a competitive option for homeowners. This move is seen as a strategic attempt by OCBC to win back market share and deepen its product offering. The consultancy firm believes the two loans are of the same nature and present similar benefits and risks to borrowers.

site_title: More initiatives to be introduced to benefit policyholders, says LIA
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore announced plans to introduce new initiatives to benefit policyholders, including yield to maturity (YTM) in benefit illustrations. This comes after data from the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre Ltd (Fidrec) showed a year-on-year increase in complaints filed against life insurers, with 53.7% related to financial institutions' practices and policies. LIA stated that over 70% of complaints have been resolved through mediation, and member companies are working to strengthen their sales and service standards.

images.alt_text: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore on Friday said more initiatives will be introduced "in due course" including the yield to maturity (YTM) to be presented in the benefit illustration to give policyholders "a sense of the expected yield on their participating policies".

site_title: Asia: Markets follow US, Europe down as energy firms tumble
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, mirroring losses in Europe and the US, due to a slump in energy firms and falling commodity prices. The US Department of Energy reported a surge in commercial inventories, indicating weak demand for oil, while a supply glut and weak global economy contributed to the decline. Energy firms, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, lost over 2% and 4.6% respectively. The dollar edged up against major rivals after Federal Reserve officials hinted at a potential interest rate hike, but traders remained cautious due to fragile global markets.

site_title: Stratech posts net loss of S$3.73m for H1, dragged by much lower revenue
summary: The Stratech Group reported a net loss of S$3.73 million in the first half of fiscal year 2016, down from a net profit of S$125,000 in the same period last year. Revenue declined by 77.2% to S$2.09 million due to lower project activities. The company attributed the decline to project milestones, but noted it has secured new contracts worth millions of dollars for installations at Miami International Airport and Singapore Changi Airport, which are expected to contribute to future revenue.

site_title: Malaysia's Q3 GDP growth slows to 4.7 % year on year, meets forecast
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 4.7% in the third quarter, its slowest rate in over two years, meeting analyst expectations. This marks a downtrend from the first quarter's 5.6% expansion and second quarter's 4.9% growth. The rate is the slowest since the second quarter of 2013.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy grew 4.7 per cent in the third quarter from a year ago, its slowest rate in over two years, but meeting analyst expectations.

site_title: 53 more ships from 41 companies qualify for Green Ship Programme under MPA
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) recognized 53 more ships from 41 companies for the Green Ship Programme, bringing the total to 247 Green Ships under the Singapore Flag since its inception in 2011. The program encourages ships to reduce carbon dioxide and sulphur oxide emissions, offering reduced registration fees and tonnage tax rebates. Additionally, 10 maritime companies signed the Maritime Singapore Green Pledge, and 5 companies were recognized for contributing to the 85th million gross tonnage, with MPA and Du Pont Company signing a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on maritime industry services.

site_title: South Korean president open to summit with North ... maybe
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye expressed openness to a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, contingent on a breakthrough in Pyongyang's nuclear programme. However, the door remains guarded by numerous conditions, and experts doubt the summit's likelihood. Park also warned Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe against delaying a settlement for Korean women forced into Japanese military brothels during World War II, calling for a formal apology and compensation.

site_title: Update: Malaysia Q3 growth, current account surplus weakest in more than two years
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 4.7% in the third quarter, its slowest rate in over two years, but met analyst expectations. The current account surplus narrowed to RM5.1 billion, its lowest since 2013. Despite growth, economists attribute it to domestic consumption weakness. Bank Negara Malaysia governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz described the situation as warranting "high degree of alert but not alarm." The country's growth has been on a downtrend this year, with 5.6% and 4.9% growth in the first and second quarters, respectively.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi's opposition party 2 seats off majority in Myanmar parliament
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) is two seats short of a majority in Myanmar's parliament, securing 327 seats out of 496. To form a majority, the NLD needs 329 seats, which would give it enough power to elect the new president. The country held its first free election in 25 years on Sunday, with the election commission yet to announce full results for the entire country.

site_title: Modi visit to UK brings US$13b of deals, protests
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's three-day visit to the UK resulted in $13 billion in deals, including a £9 billion (S$19.4 billion) agreement between British and Indian companies. The deals cover development of Indian cities, nuclear power plants, and rupee-denominated Indian Railway bonds. However, protests over growing intolerance in India since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party came to power in 2014 drew attention to issues such as sexual violence and caste conflict. Modi insisted that intolerance was unacceptable in the "land of Buddha and Gandhi."

site_title: Garuda to decide by end-2015 on Airbus or Boeing for 30 wide-body jet order: CEO
summary: Garuda Indonesia plans to decide by the end of 2015 whether to purchase 30 wide-body jets from either Airbus or Boeing, worth up to $9 billion. The airline signed letters of intent for both the Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 at the Paris Airshow in June. CEO Arif Wibowo stated that the airline will select only one type of aircraft, with the goal of replacing its Airbus A330s on medium- and long-haul routes. The decision will likely be made by the end of the year, following further comparisons between the two options.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble Group slumps after profit tumbles with commodity prices
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, saw its shares plummet 9% to 45.5 Singapore cents after reporting a 84% decline in quarterly net income to $24.7 million. The company cited a supply-driven bear market in commodities and a slowdown in China's growth, leading to surpluses and lower prices. Despite this, Noble plans to raise at least $500 million through asset disposals or strategic investors to maintain its investment-grade status and refinance credit lines.

site_title: Facebook tests vanishing messages
summary: Facebook is testing a feature that allows users to send vanishing messages, which disappear an hour after they're sent, in a challenge to Snapchat's ephemeral messaging. The test is being conducted in France on Messenger, and if successful, the feature could be rolled out to other countries. The move is seen as a direct challenge to Snapchat's popularity, especially among teenagers, who value the ability to keep messages private and ephemeral. The feature is currently available on mobile devices powered by Apple or Android software.

site_title: Glencore shares tumble in Hong Kong after London plunge
summary: Glencore shares plummeted 6.5% in Hong Kong, following a 7.6% drop in London, due to a global commodities price rout and its significant debt burden. The company's copper production has slumped 2% over the past nine months, and it's struggling to meet debt obligations. To reduce debt, Glencore is selling a share of its future silver output and cutting production at its Alumbrera mine in Argentina. The company's stock has lost over three-quarters of its value since its 2011 listing.

site_title: China's apparent steel consumption falls 5.7% from January to October: CISA
summary: China's apparent steel consumption fell 5.7% to 590.47 million tonnes in the first 10 months of the year, according to the China Iron and Steel Association. This decline was attributed to weakening demand and a massive 400 million tonne per annum capacity surplus, which has sapped prices. Despite producers relying on export markets, crude steel output still declined 2.2% in the same period. The industry's decline is expected to continue, with prices under pressure due to the large surplus.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, down 22.2 points or 0.75% at 2,936.81, due to a sharp decline on Wall Street and tumbling commodity prices. The Strait Times Index saw 70 million shares traded at 9.01am, with losers beating gainers 119 to 24. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and despite US stocks hitting fresh records.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down 1.0%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.0% on Friday, following a broad sell-off on Wall Street, in early trade. The Nikkei 225 index lost 196.60 points to 19,501.17, while the Topix index of all first-section shares slipped 1.13% to 1,575.60. The decline came after recent rallies and was influenced by US market fluctuations.

site_title: Manulife sees insurance, asset management deals in Asia
summary: Manulife Financial Corp, Canada's largest insurer, is exploring acquisition opportunities in Asia to strengthen its presence in Japan and Hong Kong, as well as capitalize on growth in China, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The company aims to diversify its business, improve margins, and better manage market volatility. Manulife has already made several acquisitions, including a partnership with DBS Group Holdings Ltd and the purchase of Standard Chartered's Hong Kong pension business. The company has approximately $18.3 billion in cash and short-term securities, providing the necessary capital for potential deals.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks follow US and Europe lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell in the first minutes of trade on Friday, tracking a sell-off from Europe to New York. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dropped 1.72% to 22,494.09, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index slid 0.88% to 3,600.76. Energy firms were hit by further losses in commodity prices. The declines followed a sell-off in Europe and the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Changjiang Fertilizer CFO resigns
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings announced that CFO Kelvin Ho, 39, has resigned after barely two months following the departure of CEO Soh Chun Bin in September 2015. Ho's resignation is attributed to pursuing other career options. This marks the second high-profile exit at the company, following CEO Soh's departure. The reasons for both departures remain the same, with no further details provided.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Gold dips to near 6-year low, under pressure from Fed
summary: Gold fell to a near 6-year low, closing at US$1,074.26 an ounce, as the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion and boosting the dollar. The metal has shed over 5% since November, with analysts predicting further price drops. Fed officials have expressed concerns about an economic hard landing, while others expect the Fed to cut interest rates by the end of next year, which could be positive for gold.

site_title: UN chief congratulates Suu Kyi, warns of hard work ahead
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon congratulated Aung San Suu Kyi on her party's election performance in Myanmar, describing it as a "significant achievement" in the country's transition away from military rule. However, he warned that "much hard work" remains ahead to build democracy, citing the exclusion of minority voters such as the Rohingya. The UN chief offered support to Myanmar to consolidate democracy and advance human rights, praising the military for accepting the election outcome.

site_title: Brazil's scandal-hit Petrobras posts US$1b loss in Q3
summary: Brazil's state oil giant Petrobras reported a Q3 loss of US$1 billion, mainly due to the sharp devaluation of the Brazilian currency. The loss is part of a larger scandal involving bribes and high-level corruption, which has cost Petrobras over US$2 billion. This has shaken Brazil's political establishment and contributes to the country's economic struggles, including recession, high inflation, and rising unemployment.

images.alt_text: Cars line up to refuel at a Petrobras petrol station in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on Aug 19, 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.60 points to 1663.93. Losers outnumbered gainers 173 to 59, and volume reached 83.4 million lots worth RM23.5 million.

site_title: Vallianz posts 4.7% fall in Q3 net profit to US$4.6m
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 4.7% decline in Q3 net profit to US$4.6 million, despite a 52.4% increase in revenue to US$59.8 million. Revenue growth was driven by higher chartering and brokerage fees, but was partly offset by a 72.6% jump in cost of sales. CEO Ling Yong Wah attributed the company's stable earnings to its resilient business model, primarily built on long-term vessel charters. The company's chartering services order book stands at US$940 million, with plans to expand its presence in the Middle East and pursue new project tenders in Latin America, Asia, and West Africa.

site_title: FSB, G-20 put shadow banking at US$80,000b in 2014
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) reported that the value of unregulated "shadow banking" rose to $80,000 billion in 2014, a growth of $2,000 billion from the previous year. This increase in shadow banking transactions, not subject to regulatory oversight, was attributed to the FSB's annual report, published ahead of the G-20 summit in Antalya. The FSB aims to promote international financial stability by monitoring and addressing potential weak points in the global financial system.

site_title: Linc Energy posts A$58.3m loss for Q1 of FY2016
summary: Linc Energy Ltd, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, reported a net loss of A$58.3 million (S$59 million) in its first quarter of FY2016, mainly due to the sale of Carmichael Royalty and low oil and gas prices. Revenue decreased 31.1% to A$20.4 million, while cost of sales rose 21.9%. The company expects a volatile oil market in FY2016 and plans to improve its liquidity position and de-risk the business from external economic variables.

site_title: UK govt urged to set up new body to help investment banking thrive
summary: The British Bankers' Association (BBA) has urged the UK government to establish a new body to oversee banking regulation, chaired by Finance Minister George Osborne. The proposal aims to prevent excessive regulation and facilitate policy coordination, ensuring London remains a hub for international investment banks. The BBA also recommends bringing forward changes to the bank tax and setting up an independent agency to determine bank penalties and compensation. This move is aimed at boosting London's attractiveness as a destination for international investment banks, which have been moving jobs away from the city due to factors such as unilateral regulation and tax uncertainty.

site_title: China's troubled credit swells to Sweden-sized US$628b
summary: China's troubled credit swelled to almost 4 trillion yuan ($892 billion) by the end of September, surpassing the country's GDP of Sweden. Chinese banks' profit growth slumped to 2% in the first nine months, down from 13% a year earlier. The debt crisis at China Shanshui Cement Group Ltd. prompts lenders to demand immediate repayments, raising concerns about a deeper economic slowdown. "Evergreening" debt and bad-loan provisions are contributing to the issue, with the Bank for International Settlements warning of an increasing risk of a banking crisis in coming years.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials lay case for December interest rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve officials are considering a December interest rate hike, citing the risk of chronically slow growth and low inflation. Key policymakers, including William Dudley and Stanley Fischer, argue that inflation should rebound, allowing the Fed to gradually raise rates. The decision is seen as a shift in thinking, with Dudley stating that the risks of moving too quickly versus too slowly are "nearly balanced." A rate hike could be signaled as early as next month, with the Fed aiming for a gradual normalization of rates.

site_title: US inflation to rebound next year, says Fed's Fischer
summary: US inflation is expected to rebound next year as pressures related to the strong dollar and low energy prices fade, according to Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer. He forecasts the central bank's preferred measure to rebound to 1.5% and reach a 2% goal in the medium term, citing the US economy's ability to weather the effects of a stronger dollar and foreign weakness.

images.alt_text: Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer, reinforcing previously stated confidence that more inflation was around the corner, said he expects the central bank's preferred measure to rebound to 1.5 per cent next year and to hit a 2 per cent goal in the"medium term."

site_title: VW sets end-November deadline for scandal whistleblowers
summary: Volkswagen has set a deadline of November 30 for whistleblowers to come forward under its program to disclose information about the company's two emissions scandals. The move aims to speed up investigations into the rigging of diesel emissions tests and carbon dioxide emissions certifications. Whistleblowers who report by the deadline will be exempt from dismissals and damage claims. The program is part of the company's efforts to cooperate with federal prosecutors and demonstrate its commitment to transparency and accountability.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting Singapore, Noble, Olam
summary: Genting Singapore, Noble Group, and Olam International reported disappointing quarterly results. Genting Singapore's net profit fell 62% to S$37.2 million, while Noble Group's net income dropped 84% to US$24.7 million due to lower raw-materials prices. Olam International's net profit decreased 30% to S$31.0 million, with a net exceptional loss of S$3.2 million. The three companies' shares closed down 1.5-2.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Valuetronics Q2 net profit down 11.3% to HK$32.2m
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 11.3% decline in Q2 net profit to HK$32.2 million, down from HK$36.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 16.1% to HK$526.5 million, driven by a 40.6% drop in consumer electronics revenue. The company's industrial and commercial electronics segment saw a 27.7% increase in revenue, offsetting the decline in consumer electronics. Despite the decline, the company remains optimistic about growth opportunities in the automotive industry and a wider product portfolio.

site_title: Nam Cheong posts Q3 net profit plunge, defers deliveries
summary: Nam Cheong, Malaysia's largest offshore support vessel builder, reported a Q3 net profit of RM6,000, down from RM126.3 million a year ago, due to a 69% decline in revenue to RM189.3 million. The company has deferred deliveries of vessels under construction and expects slow progress in vessel sales and shipbuilding. The group's gross order book is RM1.4 billion, with deliveries due until 2016. Analysts predict further downside in Nam Cheong's share price due to lacklustre earnings and a weak outlook.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Brazil fines Volkswagen US$13m over emissions cheating
summary: Brazil fined Volkswagen $13.2 million for its role in the emissions cheating scandal, which involved software that cheated government emissions tests. The German auto giant recalled 17,057 Amarok trucks sold in Brazil as part of the scandal, which affected 11 million vehicles worldwide. The fine is in addition to a plan to correct the recalled cars to meet Brazilian emissions standards. No Volkswagen vehicles sold in Brazil since 2012 are affected.

site_title: Europe: Shares post biggest fall since September
summary: European stocks fell 1.6% on Thursday, their biggest decline in six weeks, due to weakness in US equities and commodity prices. Weaker-than-expected earnings reports from companies like Rolls-Royce and RWE dragged shares lower. Commodity stocks, including basic resources and energy firms, were also major fallers. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed at 1,470.05 points.

site_title: IMF urges Fed to delay rate hike until inflation evident
