summary: Amazon.com Inc has debuted in the 2015 Thomson Reuters Top 100 global innovators list, marking its first time in the list. The company ranked for innovations in data centers, devices, electronic methods, and systems. IBM, the world's largest technology services company, was excluded from the list due to a lack of success, globalization, and impact. The US and Japan are innovation hotspots, with Silicon Valley being home to 31% of leading US innovators and 11% of the world's top innovators.

site_title: Facebook reports surge in government requests for data
summary: Facebook reported a 18% increase in government requests for data in the first half of 2015, reaching 41,214 accounts, up from 35,051 in the second half of 2014. The number of content restrictions also more than doubled to 20,568 pieces of content. Most requests relate to criminal cases, seeking basic subscriber information, IP addresses, or account content.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc said content restrictions and government requests for data surged in the first half of 2015, which the social network has seen continually increase since it began publicly releasing such data two years ago.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.24%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.24% on Thursday, following a weak session on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 46.74 points to 19,644.65, while the broader Topix index slipped 0.25% to 1,591.27. The decline was attributed to tepid trade and investors awaiting fresh cues from Japanese GDP figures next week.

site_title: Tiger Airways appoints Maybank Kim Eng as adviser for SIA's share offer
summary: Tiger Airways has appointed Maybank Kim Eng Securities as its independent financial adviser for Singapore Airlines' (SIA) general offer of shares. The deal values Tiger Airways at approximately S$1.02 billion, with SIA planning to invest up to S$470 million. SIA made the offer at 41 Singapore cents per share, with the cash offer expected to close in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Sydney home auction clearance rate drops to almost 3-year low
summary: Sydney's auction clearance rate has dropped to 58.4%, its lowest level since March 2013, due to a regulatory crackdown on mortgages and rising interest rates. The rate, which measures buyer demand, fell from 61.4% the previous week. Home values have soared 47% in the past three years, denting affordability, and economists predict a decline in prices over the next two years. A total of 3,300 homes will go to auction nationwide, with 1,270 in Sydney and 1,504 in Melbourne.

site_title: Wal-Mart goes "deep" on holiday inventory in bid to boost sales
summary: Wal-Mart significantly boosted its holiday inventory for electronics, toys, and other popular products to attract customers during the critical shopping season. The retailer's efforts come amid pressure on margins due to rising costs and competition. By offering 96% of Black Friday deals online, Wal-Mart aims to stay competitive. The move is part of the company's commitment to having products in stock, a key advantage.

images.alt_text: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says it significantly boosted its holiday inventory for electronics, toys and other potentially popular products, betting that the promise of being in-stock will attract customers during this crucial shopping season.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says Nov annual inflation may fall below 5%
summary: Indonesia's central bank predicts annual inflation may fall below 5% in November, driven by changes in base comparison. This is lower than the earlier outlook of 3.6%. The prediction comes after rising fuel prices pushed inflation to 8.36% in December last year. The base comparison for this year's prices was also affected by price increases in November and December last year.

site_title: Singtel's CEO downplays need for 4th player as competition looms
summary: Singtel's CEO Chua Sock Koong downplays the need for a fourth mobile carrier in Singapore, despite the regulator's plans to award a license. Consumers are already spoilt for choice with existing carriers, and competition would bring down mobile internet costs and improve services. The Infocomm Development Authority aims to release additional spectrum to allow a fourth entrant, which would be cheaper than expanding in larger countries. Singtel's shares fell less than 1% this year, while StarHub and M1 declined 11% and 23% respectively.

site_title: US dollar slips as Aussie lifted by jobs data
summary: The US dollar slipped against most currencies in Asia after a strong unemployment reading boosted the Australian dollar. The Aussie surged over 1% against the dollar, while emerging currencies such as the Indonesian rupiah and South Korean won also gained. Investors await Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's speeches for hints on US interest rate plans, with some expecting a rate hike in December. This has created a choppier investment environment, with some currencies having already priced in negative news.

site_title: South Korea central bank holds rates steady in Nov, as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank kept interest rates steady at 1.50% for a fifth consecutive month, as expected, amid global uncertainty due to an anticipated US rate hike in December. All but two analysts polled by Reuters predicted the rate would remain unchanged. The Bank of Korea's decision was seen as a cautious response to the global economic landscape, with the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike casting a shadow over the region. The decision was widely anticipated and did not surprise the market.

site_title: UK, India eye trade deals during Modi visit
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is visiting the UK from Thursday to Saturday for a three-day trip focused on trade and investment. Modi will meet Queen Elizabeth II, address a rally at Wembley Stadium, and hold talks with Prime Minister David Cameron. The visit is expected to yield billions of dollars worth of deals, including the purchase of BAE Systems Hawk trainer jets. Modi's visit comes after a decade-long ban on his entry to Britain due to anti-Muslim riots in 2002.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi will meet Queen Elizabeth II and address a huge rally at London's Wembley Stadium during a three-day visit to Britain focused on trade and investment starting Thursday.

site_title: Myanmar's president pledges peaceful power shift to Suu Kyi's NLD
summary: Myanmar's President Thein Sein has pledged a peaceful power shift to Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) after the opposition party swept 85% of declared seats in the national election. Suu Kyi's party won 256 seats, just short of an outright majority, and the president vowed to respect and obey the election results, transferring power peacefully. Suu Kyi has called for national reconciliation talks with the army chief and other officials, aiming to address past concerns about the military's influence in the country's politics.

site_title: ECB sees no 'significant' impact of Fed rate hike on Europe
summary: European Central Bank vice president Vitor Constancio stated that a potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December would not have a significant direct impact on Europe. The ECB is under pressure to stimulate growth, but Constancio said no decision has been made on steps to be taken at the next monetary policy meeting in December.

site_title: ISCA creates more pathways to widen accountancy talent pipeline
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) has introduced new pathways to enter the accountancy profession, aligning with the government's SkillsFuture initiative. ISCA is now offering an affiliate membership class for non-graduates, the ISCA Accredited Accounting Technician (AAT) Diploma, and associate membership to foreign university graduates. This expansion aims to broaden and deepen the talent pipeline, strengthening the sector and providing more career options for individuals from diverse educational backgrounds.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce off lows on upbeat jobs data, NZ subdued
summary: Australian shares bounced back from lows after employment data surged 58,600, driving the unemployment rate down to 5.9%, a five-month low. The S&P/ASX 200 index was nearly flat, with major banks rising and energy firms falling amid a gloomy outlook for crude oil. The NZX 50 index also remained subdued, despite record highs for five straight sessions.

site_title: Oil prices edge away from 2-mth low, but market outlook stays weak
summary: Crude oil prices edged away from a 2-month low, reaching $43.25 a barrel for US benchmark futures and $46.18 a barrel for Brent futures. Despite this, market outlook remains weak due to high production, rising US stocks, and economic slowdowns in Asia, particularly in China and Japan. This has led to a shift in sentiment, with traders selling out of oil, while oil producers are increasing their short positions in anticipation of falling prices.

site_title: APP completes over 400 dams to check forest fires in Indonesia
summary: Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) has completed over 400 dams in Indonesia's peatlands to block plantation perimeter canals and prevent forest fires. The dams, part of a 3,000-dam program, will protect peat forests by raising water levels and promoting rewetting. The move is a step towards implementing buffer zones between forests and plantations, which will help maintain near-natural water levels, reduce peat loss and carbon emissions, and lower fire risk. The program aims to provide a long-term solution to forest fires in Riau and South Sumatra provinces.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Bleak job prospects drive South Korean youth to vocational schools
summary: In South Korea, a growing number of young people, like Jang Dong-hae, are opting for vocational training or immediate work over university education due to bleak job prospects. The country's unemployment rate among 15-29 year olds was over 11% in February, but has since decreased to 7.4% in October. Many parents are now supporting their children's vocational choices, prioritizing employment over prestigious university degrees. This shift reflects the country's emphasis on academic success, which has led to a mismatch between education and job opportunities.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rebound; techs up
summary: Taiwan's stocks rebounded, snapping a four-day losing streak, as investors sought bargains in Apple suppliers like Largan Precision Co. The main TAIEX index rose 0.2% to 8,433.48, while the electronics subindex gained 0.4% and Largan rose 1.6%. The broader market has still declined about 5% from its recent high.

site_title: India's Modi eyes trade deals, show of strength on UK visit
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi begins a visit to the UK, aiming to secure trade deals worth $17-26 billion and boost his authority after a recent electoral loss. Modi will meet with British Prime Minister David Cameron and address a mass rally at Wembley Stadium, where he is expected to receive a warm welcome. However, protests are planned by groups opposed to Modi and his Hindu nationalist agenda. The visit aims to promote London as a center for offshore rupee bonds and Indian companies are expected to announce plans to issue debt denominated in their own currency.

site_title: Zeti says ringgit significantly undervalued amid growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz says the ringgit is significantly undervalued and risks to economic expansion are unlikely, despite strong exports. The currency's value doesn't reflect the nation's current account surplus, low unemployment, and inflation within the long-term average. Zeti expects the ringgit to recover when the US Federal Reserve normalizes interest rates and domestic issues are resolved. Despite global funds withdrawing RM17.4 billion from Malaysian equities, sentiment may be changing, with some investors buying Malaysian stocks.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian ringgit remains "significantly undervalued" and risks to economic expansion are unlikely to materialize with exports still strong, central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz said.

site_title: India: Markets closed on Thursday
summary: India's financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore's markets continued their 5-day rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US markets also reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Snapchat: Here to stay or gone tomorrow?
summary: Snapchat's value has taken a hit after one of its investors, Fidelity Fund, slashed its holding by 25%. Despite the valuation drop, the company remains valued at over $15 billion after its latest funding round. Analysts question the sustainability of Snapchat's rapid growth, citing the challenges of monetizing disappearing video content. The app's popularity among teenagers and its ability to attract major brands have raised concerns about its long-term viability.

site_title: What a gem: Hong Kong tycoon buys daughter US$48m diamond
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Joseph Lau spent a record US$48.4 million buying a 12.03-carat "Blue Moon" diamond for his daughter at a Sotheby's auction in Geneva. The sale comes after Lau spent US$28.5 million on a 16.08-carat pink diamond from Christie's the previous day, both of which he renamed after his daughter. The "Blue Moon of Josephine" and "Sweet Josephine" diamonds were purchased on consecutive days, highlighting Lau's generosity and wealth.

site_title: Rental weakness persists for condos, HDB flats in October: SRX Property
summary: The Singapore residential leasing market continued its soft patch in October, with rents and transaction volumes declining. Non-landed private residential units saw a 0.4% drop in rents, while private condos declined 5.7% year-on-year. HDB flat rents dropped 0.5% month-on-month, with a 3.3% decline from last year. Rental transactions for private condos contracted 2.7% month-on-month, while HDB flats declined 3% month-on-month. The declines indicate ongoing rental weakness for both private homes and HDB flats.

site_title: Australia jobs blow past forecasts, lengthen rate cut odds
summary: Australian employment surged in October, exceeding forecasts by 3.5 times, with 58,600 net new jobs created. The jobless rate fell to 5.9%, its lowest in five months. This strong employment data lengthened odds for a rate cut and boosted the Australian dollar.

site_title: Pacific Radiance Q3 net profit tumbles 87% on depressed oil and gas sector
summary: Pacific Radiance reported a 87% net profit decline to US$1.7 million in Q3 2015 due to weaker subsea and offshore support services businesses. Revenue fell 24% to US$33.8 million, with subsea operations down 57% and offshore support services down 13%. The company expects depressed oil and gas market conditions for the next few quarters, intensifying prudent balance sheet management and cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Ezion posts Q3 net profit fall as oil majors tighten belt; to explore M&As
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a 38.4% decline in Q3 net profit to US$30.3 million, with revenue falling 9.1% to US$86.2 million. The decline was attributed to the absence of contribution from a division in Queensland, Australia. The company expects oil majors to cut spending on exploration and development due to weak oil prices, prompting a focus on extraction and production activities. Ezion plans to meet these requirements through unit switching, modifications, and upgrades, and will also explore mergers and acquisitions to enhance returns from existing assets.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks open up on stimulus bets
summary: Shanghai and Hong Kong stocks opened in positive territory on Thursday, driven by bets on China's potential stimulus measures to support the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.18%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gained 0.47% and 0.65%, respectively. Investors are hopeful that new economic measures will boost the markets, following weak data earlier in the week.

site_title: Singtel says Q2 profit stable, currency impact hurts
summary: Singtel reported a flat second-quarter net profit of S$1.03 billion, despite a decline in underlying net profit to S$974 million due to adverse currency movements. The company's revenue is largely driven by markets outside Singapore, making it susceptible to currency fluctuations.

site_title: Success is making a positive impact
summary: The Saudee Group of Companies, founded in 1985, is a leading processed packaged food manufacturer in Malaysia with 500 employees. Its flagship brand, Saudi Gold, is widely represented in retail outlets. The company's success can be attributed to its focus on providing cost-effective, time-saving, and high-quality products to meet the industry's needs.

site_title: Asia shrugs off losses, Aussie spikes on jobs data
summary: Asian shares rose, shrugging off early losses, after crude oil prices rebounded from overnight lows. The Australian dollar surged after a stronger-than-expected employment report, driving the jobless rate down to a five-month low. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.6%, while the US dollar strengthened against major peers. The Australian dollar jumped to a three-month high, while Japan's Nikkei stock index also edged higher.

site_title: UK house price growth picks up steam in Oct: RICS
summary: UK house price growth accelerated in October, reaching a 15-month high of +53, driven by a shortage of new homes on the market. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a rise in house price balance to +49, with all parts of the country experiencing price increases. New instructions coming to the market decreased for the ninth month in a row, and respondents expect house prices to rise by 4.5% per year over the next five years, making property increasingly unaffordable.

site_title: NZ consumer confidence rises to six-month high in November
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence rose to a six-month high in November, reaching 122.7, according to a survey. This is above the 100-point threshold indicating optimism. Meanwhile, inflation expectations increased to 4.1% over the next two years, a four-month high.

site_title: Japan Sept core machinery orders up 7.5 per cent on month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 7.5% in September, the first increase in four months, according to Cabinet Office data. This suggests an encouraging sign for capital expenditure. Companies forecast a 2.9% increase in core orders for October-December. Core orders fell 10% in July-September, marking the first decline in five quarters, and were down 1.7% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares dip slightly after China factory data; won edges up
summary: Seoul shares dropped 0.1% on Thursday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) at 1,994.60 points, after lukewarm China factory data. The South Korean won edged up 0.3% against the dollar. Weak Chinese data may negatively affect emerging markets, while KAKAO Corp shares rose 4.3% despite a lower-than-expected operating profit. Foreign investors sold 75.3 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, weighing on the index.

site_title: China October fiscal expenditure up 36% y-o-y
summary: China's fiscal expenditure surged 36.1% in October from the same period last year, the largest year-over-year increase since July 2012. This follows a 26.9% hike from the previous month, as Beijing aims to offset the country's slowing economy. For the first 10 months, fiscal expenditure rose 18.1% and fiscal revenue rose 7.7%. The increases demonstrate the government's efforts to stimulate growth, but may raise concerns about the country's economic outlook.

site_title: New Facebook app fires news to smartphones
summary: Facebook has released a new app called Notify, which provides iPhone users with personalized news and entertainment notifications. The app features over 70 "stations" from media outlets such as CNN, Vogue, and Comedy Central, allowing users to select which sources to receive updates from. The Notify app was launched in the US and is designed to complement Facebook's Instant Articles feature, which also provides news stories on iPhones. The app is available for download, offering users a convenient way to stay informed about their interests.

site_title: Islamic finance can promote stability: IMF chief
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde says Islamic finance has the potential to promote financial stability due to its risk-sharing and asset-backed features. The industry's growth, now worth over $2 trillion, is driven by its Sharia-compliant principles and ability to offer profit-sharing and loss-bearing accounts. To unlock its full potential, Islamic finance must expand its customer base, harmonize standards, and improve regulatory frameworks. The IMF plans to increase its involvement in the industry through bilateral surveillance and analytical help. Islamic finance has the potential to promote economic growth, create jobs, and reduce poverty.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.31% at 2,972.46, following a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Losers outnumbered gainers 90 to 55. Globally, Tokyo stocks also opened flat, and the US S&P 500 edged to a fresh record despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: G20 fails to deliver on anti-graft pledges: Transparency International
summary: The G20 group of industrial economies has failed to deliver on its pledge to close corporate loopholes allowing corrupt individuals to hide their ill-gotten gains. Transparency International reported that up to $2 trillion is laundered annually through complex webs of anonymous entities. Only Britain among G20 countries is actively working to make it harder for corrupt individuals to hide their cash, while the US and China are among the worst performers. Transparency calls for governments to set up a central public register and tighten corporate oversight on those aiding the corrupt.

site_title: Apple mulling person-to-person payment service
summary: Apple is reportedly in talks with US banks to create a person-to-person payment service, allowing iPhone users to transfer money from their bank accounts to recipients. The proposed service would likely be tied to Apple Pay, a digital wallet for making credit or debit card purchases. This move would compete with existing services from PayPal, Google, Facebook, and Square. The talks are ongoing, and it's unclear if deals have been inked with any banks. Apple did not comment on the matter.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang goes into the red for Q1
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a Hong Kong-based traditional Chinese medicine retailer, posted a net loss of S$150,000 in the first quarter due to decreased spending from parallel traders and mainland Chinese visitors, as well as weakening currencies. Revenue dipped 9% to S$75.2 million. The company expects to turn the business around through cost reduction and emphasis on wholesale and e-commerce channels, with Australia and Singapore showing escalated growth. Despite the challenges, Eu Yan Sang has started evolving its business and improving efficiency through technology.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US dollar weakens in holiday-thinned trade
summary: The US dollar weakened against the euro and other major currencies on Wednesday due to the holiday-thinned trade, with the euro rising to US$1.0741. The dollar's weakness is attributed to the upcoming Federal Reserve interest rate decision, which may lead to a divergence in monetary policies between the US and the European Central Bank. The dollar's decline also comes ahead of a potential rate hike by the Fed, despite the recent strong US jobs report.

site_title: Australian PM seeks to repair strained ties on Indonesia visit
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull visited Indonesia, seeking to repair strained ties with his conservative predecessor Tony Abbott. Relations had deteriorated over issues such as the executions of Australian drug smugglers, Canberra's hardline immigration policies, and espionage allegations. Turnbull's visit aims to reset the relationship and focus on trade and economic ties, with Indonesia being a key market for Australian exports. The visit comes after Canberra recalled its ambassador from Jakarta following the executions and amid concerns about the return of Australians who fought with the Islamic State group.

site_title: Raffles Edu Q1 profit up 22% as exchange rates make mark
summary: Raffles Education Corp reported a 22% increase in Q1 net profit to S$867,000, driven by foreign exchange gains. Revenue slipped 1% to S$29.1 million, while other operating income rose 52% due to a government incentive. Despite a challenging operating environment, the company plans to streamline operations and seek sustainable growth opportunities. The company's shares are suspended pending an application by its chairman.

site_title: Four indicted in massive hack of JPMorgan, other firms
summary: Four individuals, including two Israeli nationals and a US citizen, were indicted in a massive hacking scheme that compromised data from millions of customers of JPMorgan Chase and other firms. The scheme, allegedly orchestrated by a "diversified criminal conglomerate," resulted in the theft or compromise of personal information from over 100 million customers across a dozen firms. The hackers allegedly used the stolen data to launder proceeds and engage in other illicit activities, netting "hundreds of millions of dollars" in illegal gains.

site_title: Brewer AB InBev buys rival SABMiller for US$121b
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) has acquired rival SABMiller for $121 billion, the third-largest takeover in corporate history. The deal brings together InBev's top lagers with SABMiller's brands Foster's, Grolsch, and Peroni. The transaction will tap into booming developing markets in Africa and China, with InBev targeting annual efficiency savings of at least $1.4 billion. The deal is expected to complete in the second half of 2016, subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Committing to creating positive change
summary: Samsung Electronics prioritizes creating positive change through its Corporate Citizenship strategy, focusing on education, employment, and healthcare initiatives. The company has established the Tech Institute to provide vocational training and Samsung SONO Schools to equip hospitals with medical equipment. In over 70 countries, Samsung has equipped schools with smart devices to bridge the digital divide. The company also organizes competitions like Solve for Tomorrow to encourage students to leverage technology to address social issues. As Samsung explores new business areas, it remains committed to being a responsible global citizen and creating positive change in its communities.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher, led by Carlsberg, Henkel
summary: European shares rose 0.65% on Wednesday, led by Carlsberg's 6.2% gain after the brewer announced restructuring plans and a $1.4 billion impairment charge. Henkel also rose 6.7% after posting a bigger-than-expected increase in third-quarter profit. However, Vivendi fell 5.8% after reporting lower third-quarter operating profit, and Mediaset dropped 9% after raising cost guidance and giving a cautious outlook for the fourth quarter. Despite a mixed earnings season, analysts say European stocks are buoyed by the European Central Bank's loose monetary policy.

site_title: Airbnb promises to play fair with cities
summary: Airbnb has released a Community Compact, promising to pay hotel and tourist taxes, be transparent about home-sharing activity, and prevent short-term rentals from impacting long-term housing. The move comes after criticism of the company's impact on housing markets, particularly in San Francisco. The compact aims to strike a balance between home-sharing and long-term housing availability. By paying taxes and working with cities, Airbnb aims to demonstrate its commitment to fair play and mitigate concerns about its influence on local housing markets.

images.alt_text: Airbnb co-founder and CEO Brian Chesky speaks during the Fortune Global Forum on Nov 4, 2015 in San Francisco, California.

site_title: Amazon flies high in the Internet cloud
summary: Amazon's cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services (AWS), is dominating the market with its massive data centers and green energy sources, handling about half of the world's public cloud business. The company's profit margin soared during the first nine months of the year, with revenue increasing 70% to $5.5 billion. Analysts predict AWS will remain a leader in the cloud market, with Microsoft and Google as its closest competitors, but for now, it has a significant edge in the market.

site_title: Delivering impact - The role of sustainability reporting today
summary: Sustainability reporting has become a strategic response to support disclosure and promote corporate value chains by analyzing non-financial risk and opportunities. Since the early 2000s, the number of sustainability reporters has grown to nearly 8,500, with the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) providing a principles-based approach for reporting. However, challenges remain, including limited assurance on performance data and voluntary reporting. Effective sustainability reporting can align business operations with ESG risks and stakeholders' interests, fostering transparency and trust, and is essential for organizations to make informed, value-enhancing investments and decisions.

site_title: McDonald's execs say it's on track to end long decline in US
summary: McDonald's Corp plans to increase spending on share buybacks and dividends to boost US sales, which have been declining. CEO Steve Easterbrook and executives met with investors to assure them the company is on track to stop its US decline and build on growth in other markets. Easterbrook aims to reverse the company's long decline in the US by focusing on investment and innovation.

site_title: Serious lapses at KLW could taint Catalist's clean record
summary: KLW Holdings, a Catalist-listed door maker, has faced serious lapses in internal controls and potential breaches of disclosure rules, according to a special auditor's report. The company's former managing director, Lee Boon Teck, had undertaken term sheets without board knowledge, and the company paid him S$16.2 million in commitment fees. The board has accepted the report's recommendations, but the incidents may tarnish the Catalist board's pristine record, which was created in 2007. The sponsor regime remains sound, with the current sponsor, SAC Capital, set to resign at the end of the year.

site_title: British town tries offshore tax tricks to rattle government
summary: Small businesses in the British town of Crickhowell, Wales, are attempting to pressure the government into cracking down on tax avoidance by multinational corporations by mimicking their offshore tax tricks. The town's independent traders, including a baker, bookseller, and optician, are drawing up plans to minimize their tax bills and hope their move will be copied by other towns. They met with officials from Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) and plan to demonstrate that small businesses can become more tax efficient by mimicking strategies used by multinationals.

site_title: US: Retail woes, cheaper oil push stocks lower
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday due to concerns over retail sales and lower oil prices. Macy's reported a dismal third-quarter and slashed its year-end forecast, affecting the broader retail industry. Oil prices dropped as US stockpiles increased, leading to a decline in oil company shares. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, driven by the US economy's resilience to tariff uncertainty.

site_title: World Bank taps French economist for private-sector arm
summary: The World Bank named Philippe Le Houerou, a French economist, to lead its International Finance Corp private-sector lending arm, succeeding Jin-Yong Cai. Le Houerou, currently vice-president at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, will be executive vice-president and CEO of the IFC. He returns to the World Bank after a 2014 stint as vice-president for the South Asia Region. Le Houerou's appointment comes amid concerns about the IFC's social and environmental standards, with some groups welcoming the move while expressing skepticism about its effectiveness.

site_title: Over S$70m asking price for school premises
summary: Several investment sales properties have been put on the market in Singapore, including a school premises at Hillside Drive valued over S$70 million, a light industrial building in Ubi area with a guide price of S$32-33 million, and a redevelopment site along Upper East Coast Road with a price tag of S$34.2 million. These properties are being marketed through various real estate agents, including Knight Frank and CBRE, and are expected to attract interest from investors and educational operators. The sales are seen as a rare opportunity for buyers to capitalize on the Singapore property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Molson Coors said to be near deal to buy rest of MillerCoors
summary: Molson Coors Brewing Co is close to acquiring the remaining 42% stake in MillerCoors from SABMiller for an undisclosed price, pending the completion of a larger deal between SABMiller and Anheuser-Busch InBev. The deal, which is expected to be announced on Wednesday, is conditioned on the Anheuser-Busch InBev deal closing first. Molson Coors would gain full control over MillerCoors, allowing it to sell Miller beer internationally, and potentially pave the way for a $104 billion merger between SABMiller and Anheuser-Busch InBev.

site_title: Vicom's Q3 net profit rises 3.1% to S$7.38m, revenue falls
summary: Vicom, a vehicle-testing and inspection company, reported a 3.1% increase in Q3 net profit to S$7.38 million, despite a 6% fall in revenue to S$25.38 million. Operating costs fell 9.1% and operating profit remained nearly flat. The company warned of lower demand for vehicle testing services due to deregistration and industry slowdowns.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Protesters rally for higher US fast-food wages
summary: Thousands of US fast-food workers protested nationwide, demanding a $15-an-hour minimum wage and union rights, as part of the "Fight for $15" campaign. The event, held in 270 cities, aimed to attract support from national political candidates ahead of the 2016 elections. The protests were also held outside the Republican presidential debate in Milwaukee, where activists carried signs and marched.

site_title: Oil prices tank after US inventories report
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Wednesday after a private report revealed a significant surge in US stockpiles, exacerbating concerns about global oversupply. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $1.28 to $42.93 a barrel, the lowest since late August. Brent North Sea crude also dropped $1.63 to $45.81 a barrel. The report, from the American Petroleum Institute, showed a 6 million-barrel increase in US commercial crude inventories. Investors await Thursday's Department of Energy stockpiles report, expected to show a 1.3 million-barrel rise.

site_title: Top oustanding leaders in Asia
summary: Top Asian leaders discuss changing attitudes towards leadership. They emphasize the importance of being open-minded and accepting diverse opinions. Ms. Khoo Gaik Eng believes leadership cannot be taught, but mentorship is crucial. Mr. Georg Johann Chmiel stresses the need for a leader to create a vision and support the company in achieving it. Mr. Marco Francesco Righi emphasizes the importance of building a working environment where employees feel free to express opinions and are respected. These leaders highlight the value of trust, flexibility, and empathy in leadership.

site_title: Germany's savers falling into swindlers' laps
summary: Germany's low interest rates are fueling a rise in financial scams, with over 7,500 cases recorded last year, a 18% increase from 2013. Thousands of savers, including a 79-year-old retiree, have lost money in scams promising unrealistic returns. The low interest rates, coupled with a high household savings rate in Germany, have driven investors to seek higher returns, making them vulnerable to unlicensed financial outfits and Ponzi schemes.

site_title: STI dips on bleak China economic figures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.54% or 16.13 points to 2,981.59, following a sluggish trading day after the public holiday. Bleak China economic figures released in the early afternoon weighed down the blue-chip index. Major Asian bourses also saw lacklustre performance, with Hong Kong closing 0.2% down and Shanghai advancing 0.3%. Notable movers included QT Vascular plummeting 18% and Cityneon jumping 25.7%.

site_title: Vard Holdings' Q3 loss widens on headwinds in Brazil and Europe
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilding group, reported a widened net loss of 486 million kroner (S$80.2 million) in the third quarter, driven by headwinds in Brazil and Europe, including reduced utilisation at its yards and increased net financing costs. The company attributed the cost increase to an unrealised foreign exchange loss from a US dollar-denominated loan. Despite expanding shipbuilding orders, the group's bottom line was also impacted by new cost overruns and delays at its Brazilian yards.

site_title: Tapping into India's huge potential
summary: Singapore companies are playing a key role in India's infrastructure development, particularly in the state of Andhra Pradesh. Surbana Jurong developed a master plan for the new capital city Amaravati, while Ascendas-Singbridge has replicated its model for cities such as Chennai and Hyderabad. With India's growing population, the country aims to develop its infrastructure, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi prioritizing this as a top priority. Several Singaporean firms, including Changi Airport International and Sembcorp, are involved in various projects, including airport development, power plants, and smart city initiatives.

site_title: Experiences sharpen leadership traits
summary: Mr. Francis Lau Choo Yew, founder of LCY Development, attributes the company's success to overcoming challenges in a competitive industry. Established in 1997, LCY has completed over 80 projects and expanded rapidly. Lau believes that difficult challenges create a learning process, sharpening leadership traits. He emphasizes the importance of dedication, persistency, and clarity in leadership, and values consistency, ambition, and strong character. Lau's leadership style is hands-on and adaptive, with a focus on retaining skilled staff through incentives and promotion schemes.

site_title: Labour costs, competition hit Boustead Projects' Q2
summary: Boustead Projects, a real estate arm of Boustead Singapore, reported a net profit of S$5.5 million in its second quarter, down a third from last year. Higher labour costs and competitive bids for projects affected the results, with gross profit margin falling to 24% from 33%. The leasing segment showed better performance, while the design and build segment saw a 64% decline. The company's order book was S$233 million at end-September, and it expects to deliver a reasonable level of profit for the current financial year despite a challenging business environment.

site_title: Prime ground-floor unit at Shenton House to go under the hammer (Amended)
summary: A ground-floor unit at Shenton House, a 25-storey commercial development, will be auctioned on Nov 20 with an indicative price of S$13.3 million. The unit, currently leased to a jewellery shop, has a net yield of nearly 3% and potential for redevelopment into a food and beverage outlet or clinic. An adjacent semi-detached house at 94 Marshall Road, with a freehold land area of 4,938 sq ft, will also be auctioned. The indicative price for this property is S$5.2 million to S$5.3 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asian companies reported mixed results in the first quarter of 2015, with Tiong Woon Corp Holding and Civmec posting losses, while OUE Commercial Reit and ValueMax Group saw profits rise. OUE C-Reit's net property income increased 4.7% and distribution per unit rose 5.2%. ValueMax Group's net profit grew 31.8% due to lower costs. Ziwo Holdings warned of a third-quarter operating loss and significant revenue drop due to various factors, including a tax penalty.

site_title: Chinese millionaires snub Aussie stocks-for-visa programme
summary: Chinese millionaires who invested in Australian bonds and real estate to obtain residency visas have largely opted out of investing in small-cap stocks under the new rules, which require a minimum investment of A$1.5 million in smaller equities and venture capital. Since July, only 19 applicants have sought permits, down from over 1,600 under the previous system. Fund managers had expected a significant influx of cash, but instead, Chinese investors are prioritizing wealth preservation and quality of life over potential returns from small-cap stocks.

site_title: Park Hyatt set for launch in Thailand
summary: Thailand is set to receive its first Park Hyatt hotel in the first quarter of next year, located at Central Embassy in Bangkok. The six-star hotel, designed by Amanda Levete Architects, will feature 222 rooms, 30 premier suites, and several luxury amenities. The hotel's general manager believes it will generate half its revenue from food and beverage operations, and aims to attract international guests despite Bangkok's oversupplied hotel market. The Park Hyatt chain is expected to be a flagship property, with plans to expand its management services to resort destinations.

site_title: With Tally the robot, scanning shop aisles has new meaning
summary: A Silicon Valley startup, Simbe Robotics, has unveiled Tally, a robot designed to help retailers track shelves more efficiently than humans. Tally can scan shelves in 30-40 minutes, capturing data on 15,000-20,000 products per hour. The robot navigates stores, taking photos of shelves and comparing them to an idealized representation to identify stock issues. Tally is being sold as a service and is best suited for stores with easily viewed barcodes and prices, with a potential market for brand managers to analyze product performance.

site_title: Compassion for the community
summary: PT Hero Supermarket Tbk, a pioneering modern retailer in Indonesia, has been recognized as a Community Care Company of the Year. The company has prioritized Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) since its establishment in 1971, focusing on education, community health, economic empowerment, and environmental conservation. Its consistent CSR efforts have increased staff engagement and customer loyalty, making it a socially responsible business. Prudential Assurance Malaysia Berhad, another Asian company, has also made significant contributions to its community, providing financial protection and education to low-income households and rebuilding homes for flood victims in Malaysia.

site_title: Reducing environmental footprint
summary: PT Great Giant Pineapple, a company, measures its environmental sustainability by tracking green parameters such as wastewater treatment. It has reduced Non Renewable Energy Coal and Heavy Fuel Oil consumption by 8% and 100% respectively, aiming for further reduction by 2020. The company's objective is to produce zero waste. This move demonstrates environmental sustainability achievable for both small and large companies.

site_title: Fund managers getting jittery about China's EM index dominance
summary: Fund managers are concerned about China's dominance in the world's main emerging market (EM) stock index, with some considering standalone China-dedicated funds to mitigate risk. Others are looking to move away from investment benchmarks. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Opec intensifies competition against US shale producers
summary: OPEC is increasing competition against US shale oil producers by shipping large quantities of crude oil to US ports. Iraq, the fastest-growing producer in the OPEC group, is loading 10 tankers with 19 million barrels of crude, the largest monthly influx since June 2012. This surge in oil shipments is expected to boost tanker owners' rates to their highest level in seven years, as the US may need to increase imports by 500,000-800,000 barrels per day to meet demand.

site_title: Two Europes in one
summary: Informal talks on the UK's relationship with the European Union are underway, with a referendum set to take place before the end of 2017. EU leaders hope to negotiate changes that will convince British voters to choose Europe, but Prime Minister David Cameron must balance the negotiations carefully to avoid appearing to cave in or give too little. The talks also focus on long-term issues such as eurozone integration, including a designated eurozone budget and increased fiscal policy coordination. A proposed division of Europe into two groups, one for non-euro countries and one for eurozone members, could provide a solution to balance integration and national sovereignty.

site_title: Russians shrug off accusations of sports doping
summary: Russia's public and officials largely downplayed accusations of sports doping, with few expressing outrage over the destruction of positive drug tests and intimidation of laboratory technicians. Despite the scandal, there were no widespread questions about President Vladimir Putin's administration's competence. Many Russians blamed the West for the scandal, shifting the focus away from the Kremlin-backed programme. Officials minimized the scandal, with some even defending the actions of those involved. The public's reaction was largely muted, with a collective shrug in response to the accusations.

site_title: Myanmar's military-backed govt vows to respect election result
summary: Myanmar's military-backed government has vowed to respect the country's election result, despite the ruling party, National League for Democracy, winning nearly 90% of the seats declared so far. Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi has called for talks with the president and the powerful army chief, and the government has congratulated the NLD on its gains. The NLD needs around 120 more seats for an outright majority, but analysts say difficult months lie ahead as the army still holds significant power.

images.alt_text: Ms Suu Kyi's early move to reach out to the army and its political allies shows willingness to work with her former captors to cut through Myanmar's tangled politics.

site_title: OUE is new title sponsor for IPTL's Singapore Slammers
summary: OUE, a Singapore-based property developer, has become the new title sponsor of the Singapore Slammers team in the International Premier Tennis League (IPTL). The team will participate in the tournament's fifth and final leg, scheduled to take place in Singapore from December 18-20. This marks a significant partnership for the UD Group, the team's owners, ahead of the tournament's start on December 2 in Kobe, Japan.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: A new perspective on leadership in Asia - Time for disruption?
summary: A new perspective on leadership in Asia emphasizes the need for disruption and self-leadership in a rapidly changing workforce. Asian leaders, particularly those in multiple countries, believe that empowering consumers and adopting a mindset that breaks down silos is key to success. To achieve this, they must shift their managers' and employees' mindset to understand all parts of the business. Additionally, individuals need to take personal responsibility and be clear about group accountability, fostering self-leadership and autonomy. This approach is crucial for Asian businesses to overcome inertia and tradition.

site_title: Energy default alarms get louder as pain seen lasting into 2016
summary: Energy companies are facing increased risk of default due to depressed oil prices, with four firms warning of potential insolvency and auditors expressing doubts over their ability to continue as going concerns. Default rates among speculative-grade energy companies are forecast to double in the next year, reaching 25% cumulatively in the next 2-3 years if oil stays below US$60 a barrel. The energy sector accounts for a significant portion of high-yield bonds trading at distressed levels, with 23 energy companies defaulting on debt between January and October.

site_title: Nurturing a culture of innovation
summary: Fusionex International Plc, a multi-award winning IT software group, aims to bridge the gap between business and technology by humanizing technology and providing value-producing solutions. Under CEO Ivan Teh's leadership, the company has achieved significant growth, exceeding RM1 billion in market capitalization, and has won numerous awards for its Big Data Analytics software. Fusionex's culture of innovation encourages staff to contribute to the development of new ideas, resulting in a "Fantastic Fusionex Family" that drives the company's success. With a focus on ease of use and effectiveness, Fusionex continues to expand its offerings in the Big Data Analytics market.

site_title: About MORS Group - the organiser of ACES Awards
summary: MORS Group, the organiser of ACES Awards, aims to promote leadership and sustainability excellence in Asia through its various programs. Founded in 2012, the organisation conducts research and development to boost Asia's business prominence. With a focus on promoting unity among industry peers, MORS Group mediates on behalf of institutional and private companies in Asia, providing a platform for them to engage stakeholders and employees. The organisation's efforts aim to champion a resilient and united Asia.

site_title: SIA, Lufthansa ink extensive partnership
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Lufthansa have signed an extensive partnership, cooperating in key markets in Europe, Southeast Asia, and Australia. The partnership includes over 20 new codeshare routes in Europe and Southeast Asia, with enhanced connections and joint fare promotions. SIA passengers will also have access to flights operated by Lufthansa and its subsidiaries, while Lufthansa will codeshare with SIA and SilkAir. The agreement aims to strengthen both airlines' positions in the market and provide benefits to customers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Happy staff and happy customers
summary: SPi Global has been named the Best Company to Work for of the Year. The company, a global KPO and CRM service provider, is one of the largest in the industry. However, the article does not provide further information on the selection process or criteria used to determine the award.

site_title: Dismal results from Metro, FJ Benjamin
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 70% decline in Q2 net profit to S$18.57 million due to lower profits from associates and joint ventures. Revenue rose 22.3% to S$38.31 million, despite a 7.8% drop in gross profit. Retail operations contributed to the increase, but higher costs and a decline in profit from associates and joint ventures offset gains. FJ Benjamin, a retail group, reported a net loss of S$5.47 million for Q1, citing headwinds in the region's retail sector.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: OCBC set to make fintech foray as well
summary: OCBC Bank is set to establish a fintech unit, joining its peers in exploring the fintech space. The bank is open to working with startups and exploring areas in fintech while staying within regulatory boundaries. OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien has expressed interest in fintechs that can make payment services faster and more convenient. This move comes as banks in Singapore are watching fintech developments in the payment space and peer-to-peer lending market.

site_title: Otto Marine in the red for Q3
summary: Otto Marine reported a net loss of US$5.5 million for the third quarter, down from a net profit of US$2 million a year ago, due to a 35% drop in revenue to US$62.97 million. Finance costs increased 55.4% to US$10.5 million. The company attributed the decline to a challenging market, reduced shipbuilding and fabrication revenue, and lower charter rates in its shipping and subsea services segments. Despite a positive operating cash flow, Otto Marine plans to improve competitiveness by rationalizing costs and stepping up efforts to secure new orders.

site_title: Departure of a farsighted European statesman
summary: Helmut Schmidt, the former West German chancellor from 1974 to 1982, has died at 96. Schmidt was part of an elite group of European monetary figures who shaped European finance in the 1970s and 1980s, including Denis Healey, Geoffrey Howe, and Karl Otto Pöhl. Schmidt's passing marks the fourth death in less than a year of this quartet, who were linked by their common interest in defence and finance. Schmidt's legacy includes his vision for European monetary integration and his efforts to steer Germany through international financial crises.

site_title: Structural reforms and global cooperation
summary: Business leaders from the world's top 20 economies gathered in Ankara, Turkey, for the B-20 Conference to finalize policy recommendations for the G-20 leaders' meeting. They emphasized the need for structural reforms and global cooperation to boost economic growth, citing the weak and uncertain global economic outlook. The B-20 participants called for the ratification of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which could create 21 million jobs globally, and the reversal of protectionist measures that have introduced barriers to trade and investments. They also highlighted the need for infrastructure investments and support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: Bihar state election results cut Modi down to size
summary: The Bihar state election results have dealt a significant blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's BJP, with a coalition led by Chief Minister Nitish Kumar and his colleague Lalu Prasad Yadav winning 178 seats. The BJP-led coalition secured only 58 seats, marking a humiliating defeat. Analysts attribute the BJP's loss to its divisive campaign against minorities and misreading the voter's pulse. The election results have raised questions about the BJP's prospects in upcoming state elections, including the 2017 Uttar Pradesh state election. The victory for Kumar's coalition has also sparked speculation about a potential rival to Modi, with some pundits seeing Kumar as a potential pole around whom further coalitions can be formed.

site_title: Japanese banks seen losing profit driver as Asian economies slow
summary: Japan's three largest banks, Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui, and Mizuho, are expected to report a 24% drop in combined net income for the second quarter due to Asia's economic slowdown and global financial-market volatility. The slowdown in overseas loan growth, particularly in Asia, has weakened profit for the banks, which have been expanding abroad in search of higher returns. The yen's depreciation since 2012 has also eased loan growth, but analysts expect a drop in consumer demand for investment trusts and earnings from bond trading.

images.alt_text: Japanese banks have been expanding in Asia through acquisitions such as Mitsubishi UFJ's 2013 purchase of Bangkok-based Bank of Ayudhya pcl..

site_title: VW hires expert in self-driving car technology from Apple
summary: Volkswagen has hired Johann Jungwirth, a self-driving car technology expert from Apple, to lead a new Digitalization Strategy Department. This move signals the company's investment in leading-edge technologies despite the financial burden from its emissions cheating crisis. Volkswagen faces billions of euros in costs to make vehicles compliant with regulations and pay fines. The hiring comes as the company begins talks with labour representatives to improve efficiency and cut costs.

site_title: HKEx Q3 profit jumps on trading, property sale
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd reported a 81% increase in third-quarter profit to HK$2.33 billion, driven by higher trading turnover and a one-time gain from a property sale. Average daily stock trading turnover rose 45% to HK$102 billion, while operating expenses increased 17% to HK$881 million. The company's shares fell 0.8% to HK$210.4. Despite the earnings boost, analysts warned that operating expenses remain elevated, and the company may need to focus on cost control to sustain earnings.

site_title: Devaluations show dizzying ride for startups may be over
summary: Devaluations of hot technology startups, such as Snapchat and Dropbox, may signal the end of the market's dizzying ride. Fidelity and BlackRock, two major investors, have discounted the companies' valuations by 25% and 10% respectively. This trend may slow down the fast-growing market, as investors face challenges in valuing private companies. The markdowns come after a period of rapid growth, where mutual funds poured billions into young private companies, pushing prices to stratospheric levels. The move by Fidelity and BlackRock reflects the need for accurate valuations, as public investors cool on new technology companies.

site_title: Perspective from the organiser of ACES Awards
summary: ACES Awards organizer Ms. Shanggari Balakrishnan notes that this year's entries, with over 110 nominations, have shown significant corporate responsibility efforts across the region. The minimum turnover benchmark has been raised to $10 million, and the focus is on sustainable operations and a conscious culture. To foster closer relationships, industry peers can share best practices, and winners can benefit from the ACES platform or MORS Group's services, including M&A opportunities, venture capital, and corporate responsibility. MORS Group aims to encourage more enterprises to adopt corporate responsibility and preserve the region's ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Ms Shanggari Balakrishnan, Chief Executive Officer, MORS Group.

site_title: A night of glitz and glamour with Tarik the Tenor
summary: Opera Tenor Tarik, from Germany, delivered a powerful performance of 'Nessun Dorma' at the ACES Awards, winning applause from the audience. He won the best-looking male singer award in Asia and the best unique voice and entertainment award in 2015. Tarik currently resides in Bali, offering Asian audiences the chance to experience his live performances.

site_title: Bumper grape harvest as thirst for prosecco grows
summary: Italy has produced the largest grape crop ever for Prosecco, a sparkling wine, with a 56% surge in output to 3.5 million hectolitres. Despite the surplus, prices won't drop as vintners are stockpiling the excess, expecting a 20% increase in global sales to 1.68 billion euros. The industry forecasts continued growth for the next five years, driven by the wine's popularity among younger consumers as an alternative to French Champagne.

site_title: Knowing what the market needs is key
summary: Serial System Ltd, a Singapore-based electronic components distributor, is set to enter a new phase of growth with revenue exceeding $1 billion. Founded by Dato' Seri Dr Derek Goh Bak Heng in 1988, the company is expanding its product portfolio to include finished consumer goods and is implementing a three-pronged growth strategy to maintain market leadership. The strategy focuses on product diversification, supply chain management, and geographic expansion to bridge the gap between suppliers and manufacturers, positioning the company as an integral part of the supply chain.

site_title: Surbana Jurong enlarges footprint in Africa, sharpens design might
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based urbanisation and infrastructure consultancy, has made two significant investments to expand its presence in Africa and enhance its building-design capabilities. It has taken a 20% stake in CITICC (Africa) Holding Ltd, a US$300 million investment platform focused on affordable housing in sub-Saharan Africa, and acquired an 8.4% stake in San Francisco-based building-design software company FLUX Factory for US$9.25 million. These investments aim to scale up Surbana Jurong's presence in Africa and leverage FLUX's technology to enhance its design and development capabilities.

site_title: Setting industry trends
summary: Megamas Training Company in Brunei Darussalam and Robert Bosch in Malaysia have been recognized for their industry trends and commendable best practices. Megamas prioritizes worker safety and offers HSE consultation and training solutions, while Bosch is credited for its independence, innovation, and global presence. Both companies have successfully implemented their strategies, with Megamas serving major clients such as Brunei Shell Petroleum and Bosch maintaining a strong reputation for quality and reliability. Their unique approaches have set industry trends and established them as leaders in their respective fields.

site_title: China industrial output growth hits 6-month low
summary: China's industrial output growth hit a six-month low of 5.6% in October, the lowest reading since March, as the country's economy continues to show signs of weakness. This follows a 5.7% increase in September and below the median forecast of 5.8%. The slowdown is attributed to overcapacity in manufacturing, a slowdown in the property market, and mounting local government debt. The government has been trying to transform the economy to a slower but more sustainable model, but the transition is proving bumpy, with GDP growth expected to slow further in 2016.

site_title: Petronas Q3 net profit crashes 90% to RM1.35b
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, reported a 90% decline in net profit to RM1.35 billion for the third quarter ended September, due to a slump in global oil prices and asset impairment losses. Despite this, its downstream business grew by a third, driven by lower feedstock prices and higher refining and marketing margins. The company has not reached a point to right-size its staffing, with CEO Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin announcing redeployments to the downstream segment and reduced dividends to the government.

site_title: China Shanshui Cement defaults on bonds, files for liquidation
summary: China Shanshui Cement defaults on two billion yuan of bonds due on Nov 12, becoming at least the sixth Chinese company to default in the local note market this year. The company's debt load is four times bigger than in 2008, and a shareholder fight for control has hindered its access to financing. Analysts predict further defaults as the government shifts the economy toward consumption and services, reducing overcapacity in industries such as raw materials and real estate. Shanshui will also default on dollar bonds and file for liquidation.

site_title: UOL's Q3 profit slips 2% to S$101m
summary: UOL Group's Q3 profit slipped 2% to S$101m, with revenue falling 18% to S$354m due to recognition of revenue from The Esplanade project in China. Property development revenue plummeted 33% to S$174m, while group gross profit rose 3% to S$136.7m. Sales from property investments increased, but hotel operations were affected by refurbishment works and currency fluctuations. The company expects continued pressure in the residential, office rental, and hotel sectors.

site_title: Saizen Reit's Q1 total return hit by fair value losses
summary: Saizen Reit, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust, reported a 53.1% drop in Q1 total return due to net fair value losses on financial derivatives and investment properties. The net fair value loss on investment properties was 69 million yen, mainly due to acquisition-related expenses. Gross revenue edged up 0.3% to 976.6 million yen, but net property income declined 1.1% to 667.7 million yen. The Reit's manager plans to distribute net proceeds from a proposed divestment of all Japanese properties to unitholders.

site_title: Fortescue begins US$750m bond buyback as costs decline
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, Australia's third-largest iron-ore supplier, is offering to repurchase $750 million in debt as it seeks to reduce costs. The company will hold a modified Dutch auction cash tender offer for bonds due in 2019 and 2022. This move is aimed at cutting costs and improving its financial position.

site_title: China's Postal Savings Bank nears US$8b stake sale ahead of IPO
summary: China's Postal Savings Bank (PSBC) is set to sell a 15% stake to investors for approximately $8 billion ahead of its planned Hong Kong IPO in 2016. The pre-IPO round saw investments from UBS AG, Temasek Holdings, JPMorgan, and the International Finance Corp. The IPO is expected to raise $15-$20 billion, with the bank's initial public offering scheduled for 2016.

site_title: KL bond bankers twiddling thumbs as firms shelve plans
summary: Malaysia's bond market has seen a significant slowdown in investment plans due to the country's struggling ringgit, which has dropped 23% in the past year. Companies have reduced their investment plans, with imports of investment goods shrinking 26.4% through August, and borrowing costs rising. The Malaysian economy grew at its slowest pace in almost two years in the second quarter, and the central bank has left interest rates unchanged, juggling risks to economic growth. Despite this, some positive signs have emerged, including increased activity from the Malaysian government and state-owned enterprises.

site_title: New mall lifts Croesus Q1 results
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.08 Singapore cents for its first quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, unchanged from the previous year. Gross revenue rose 17.2% to 2 billion yen due to the acquisition of One's Mall in Japan and tenant renewal at Mallage Shobu. However, the trust did not distribute more due to an increase in the total number of issued units. The trust's outlook is cautious, with competition for acquiring real estate assets in Japan expected to remain firm.

site_title: Singles' Day reaps billions for Alibaba
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day sales surpassed 91.2 billion yuan, eclipsing last year's record, with baby-related and apparel products being top sellers. The event, held in Beijing, marked Alibaba's efforts to expand its global reach and penetrate the northern Chinese market. The sales figures come as China's retail sales accelerated in October, beating economists' projections, and demonstrate Alibaba's ambitions to maintain growth and become a "national champion" in technology. The event's success is seen as a symbol of Alibaba's leadership in the Chinese e-commerce market.

site_title: Japan metals producers hurt by China slowdown
summary: Japanese metals producers Sumitomo Metal Mining Co and Mitsubishi Materials Corp cut their profit forecasts due to China's slowdown, with Sumitomo Metal slashing its forecast by 37% and Mitsubishi Materials reducing its forecast by 2.4%. The companies cited significant falls in metals prices and concerns over China's worsening economy as reasons for the cuts. Sumitomo Metal now expects a full-year operating profit of 74 billion yen, while Mitsubishi Materials expects 83 billion yen. The cuts reflect the challenges facing metals producers as demand slows in China, the world's largest consumer of metals.

site_title: Rare pink diamond sells for US$28.5m at Geneva auction
summary: A 16.08-carat rare pink diamond sold for US$28.5 million at a Geneva auction, narrowly beating Christie's projection of between US$23-28 million. The stone, classified as "fancy vivid," is the largest of its kind to appear at auction. A 12.03-carat blue diamond, described as flawless, is set to be sold by Sotheby's on Wednesday, potentially fetching a record US$55 million.

site_title: Lufthansa to cancel 930 flights due to strike
summary: Lufthansa will cancel 930 flights due to a strike by its cabin crew, affecting about 100,000 passengers. The strike, which began on Friday, has been prolonged despite a court ruling for the crew to end the walkout at one airport. The cabin crew union has called for walkouts at Frankfurt, Dusseldorf, and Munich airports from Wednesday to Friday, prompting the airline to cancel flights. Lufthansa remains open to negotiations with the union, but only if the strike is ended first.

site_title: Helmut Schmidt a visionary leader: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore expressed condolences on the death of former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, calling him a "visionary leader" and close friend. Schmidt, 96, died at home in Hamburg, Germany, on November 10, 2015. Lee remembered Schmidt's strategic view of the world and their close friendship, which dated back to his father, former premier Lee Kuan Yew. Schmidt governed Germany from 1974 to 1982, helping transform the country into Europe's leading power.

site_title: China's top bond fund executive expects 'substantial correction' in riskier debt
summary: China's top bond fund executive, Shao Jiamin, predicts a "substantial correction" in riskier debt as money flows back into shares following the restart of initial public offerings. The fund, HFT Pure Bond Fund, returned 24% in the first nine months of the year. This is attributed to investors shifting from lower-rated notes to equities after a stock rout in June.

site_title: China October property investment slows further
summary: China's annual growth in real estate investment slowed to 2% in the first 10 months of the year, down from 2.6% in the first 9 months. This marks the slowest rate since 2009, indicating persistent weakness in the property market. Sales also cooled slightly, further pointing to ongoing challenges in the broader economy. The slowdown is attributed to property market issues, which could continue to affect the economy.

site_title: Gushing US gas wells have stockpiles swelling to record
summary: US natural gas drillers are struggling to cut back supplies due to high efficiency rates, leading to record-breaking stockpiles and all-time highs in production. Gas prices have fallen below $2 per million British thermal units for the first time in three years, with stockpiles reaching an all-time high in October. Despite low prices and declining rig activity, production is expected to continue growing, with new pipelines set to increase gas flow from Appalachia in 2016. This oversupply is expected to keep the market under pressure through a mild winter.

site_title: Big on CSR and CSV projects
summary: Bangchak Petroleum, a Bangkok-based company, prioritizes corporate social responsibility (CSR) and community service (CSV) projects. The company's CSR activities include investments in environmentally friendly initiatives, such as Green Process, Green Service Station, and Green Energy Business. Additionally, Bangchak supports community-centered programs like Project Citizen and Bangchak Futsal Youth. These efforts demonstrate the company's commitment to sustainability and community development.

site_title: Bullish jobs report good news for Yellen, Hillary
summary: The US Department of Labor released a jobs report showing the American job market has almost fully recovered from the Great Recession, with 271,000 new jobs added in October, a 5% jobless rate, and average hourly earnings rising 2.5% over the past year. This report challenges the GOP's narrative of a stagnant economic recovery, benefiting Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, who is expected to raise interest rates next month. The report also shows wages are rising, contributing to long-term economic growth, despite concerns about labor market participation and structural problems in the US economy.

site_title: Condo resale volume up in Oct but at lower prices: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume increased 9.8% in October, driven mainly by attractive pricing, according to SRX Property. Non-landed private residential resale prices fell 0.6% in October, with all regions posting a price drop. Analysts expect a gradual price decrease to continue in 2016, with overall price declines expected to be around 2.5% in 2015 and 3-5% in 2016.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buys Sydney land for A$15.6m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired land in Sydney, Australia for A$15.65 million, planning to develop two residential buildings. The company also launched its first upscale boutique hotel in Kyoto, Japan, under the Noku Roxy brand, with 81 rooms starting from 20,000 yen. The hotel's successful soft opening has generated encouraging reservation requests, signaling healthy demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ifei Chang steps down as CEO of Greenland's US unit
summary: Ifei Chang, 50, stepped down as CEO of Greenland's US unit, citing a desire to offer her expertise as a consultant. Chang led Greenland's acquisition of the $4.6 billion Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn and the $1.4 billion Metropolis complex in downtown Los Angeles. She will now focus on helping companies break into new markets, following a 22-year career that includes work on the Baltic Pearl project in Russia.

site_title: Going green done right at HP Inc
summary: HP Inc is recognized as the 'Green Company of the Year' for its commitment to sustainability. The company has integrated environmental responsibility into its business strategy, aiming to reduce its impact on the environment through various initiatives, including energy efficiency programs, recycling, and circular approaches to its value chain. By doing so, HP has not only improved its social and environmental responsibilities but also benefits its partners and customers, such as reduced energy costs and compliance with local laws. By 2020, HP aims to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions intensity by 20% compared to 2010.

site_title: New IMF chief economist faces multiple pressing issues
summary: IMF chief economist Maurice Obstfeld faces multiple pressing issues, including the Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates, Europe's migration crisis, and the Brexit problem. He also highlights the threat of climate change, which he considers a major economic threat, and calls for collective action to address global warming. Obstfeld suggests that countries need to put a tax on carbon to reduce emissions, and criticizes the US reluctance to implement such a policy. He also advises the US Federal Reserve to hold off on raising interest rates, citing higher risks of an early increase.

site_title: Thriving SMEs excelling in a challenging business climate
summary: Three Asian SMEs, Asta Chemicals, Esquel Garment & Cho Thavee, have been crowned Top SMEs for their continued growth and innovative product offerings. Asta Chemicals, a chemical manufacturing company in Malaysia, excels in producing formaldehyde and thermosetting synthetic resin, while Esquel Garment & Cho Thavee, a Vietnam-based garment manufacturer and a Thai-based truck body manufacturer, respectively. The companies prioritize customer needs, adapt to industry changes, and focus on safety, ethics, and environmental responsibility, setting them apart in a challenging business climate.

images.alt_text: Asta Chemicals' Mr Jerry Looi, seen here with colleagues and family, said: 'Any company can succeed as long as its management is focused on the tasks at hand, with a deep understanding of the market that they are operating in, and a business strategy which adapts to individual markets.'

site_title: Deutsche Telekom draws interest from Apax, CVC for Dutch unit
summary: Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile Netherlands unit is being sold in an auction process led by Credit Suisse, with private equity groups Apax and CVC putting in rival bids. The unit, valued up to 3 billion euros, is expected to attract other investment firms, including US buyout funds Bain Capital and Providence. French entrepreneur Xavier Niel's telecoms group Iliad and cable group Liberty Global are also reportedly interested in the asset, which could be used to expand their presence in the Netherlands. The bidding process is set to close by November 16.

site_title: Prominent economist defends BOJ's moves
summary: A prominent economist, Paul Sheard, has defended the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) aggressive monetary policy, stating that no central bank can achieve its inflation target in a pinpointed way. Despite the BOJ's failure to meet its two-per-cent annual inflation target in two years, Sheard praises the BOJ for its efforts to create inflation expectations. The economist also predicts the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month, but expects minimal market impact. Meanwhile, the BOJ has vowed to maintain its massive stimulus program until its inflation target is reached.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed in choppy trade
summary: US stocks experienced a minimal change in early trading on Wednesday, despite data suggesting China may need further stimulus measures due to slowing industrial production and deflationary pressure. The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq composite index all rose slightly. Retail sales in China exceeded expectations, while Alibaba reported record sales during its Singles' Day shopping event. However, US retail stocks fell after Macy's disappointing results. Investors remain cautious ahead of a possible US interest rate hike next month.

site_title: Survey among SMEs points to growth plateau, slimmer profits
summary: A survey of Singapore's SMEs found that 53% have hit a growth plateau, while 46% have high-risk credit ratings due to economic and cost pressures. This contrasts with businesses that have turned to technology and innovation to stay competitive. The survey highlights the challenges faced by SMEs in the current economic climate, but also notes their resilience in adapting to changing circumstances.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Mr Ho said the survey figures show a fall in number of SMEs that have been in business for 10 years or less, and this needs to be examined.

site_title: Civmec Q1 profit falls 21.6% on translation from weaker Aussie dollar
summary: Civmec, a heavy-engineering company, reported a 21.6% decline in net profit to S$8.7 million in its fiscal first quarter due to a weaker Australian dollar. Revenue fell 15.5% to S$143.8 million. The company secured S$141 million in new contracts and established a new business unit for Australian defence projects. Shares slipped 1.3% to close at 39.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Vicom posts 3.1% increase in Q3 profit
summary: Vicom, a Singapore-based vehicle-testing and inspection company, reported a 3.1% year-over-year increase in its Q3 net profit to S$7.38 million. Despite a 6% decline in revenue to S$25.38 million, earnings per share rose to 8.32 Singapore cents.
