The company attributed the decline to lower demand for vehicle testing services and a slowdown in certain industries.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan's passenger jet takes to the skies for first flight
summary: Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp's new passenger jet, the Mitsubishi Regional Jet (MRJ), made its debut flight from Nagoya airport in central Japan, marking the first time a Japanese passenger plane has taken to the skies in half a century. The MRJ can seat up to 92 passengers and is expected to intensify competition with Embraer and Bombardier. Mitsubishi Aircraft has won 407 orders for the plane, which is designed to be more fuel-efficient than similar aircraft. The company hopes the MRJ can break the market's virtual lock held by Embraer and Bombardier for passenger jets with fewer than 100 seats.

site_title: Takata crisis gives Sweden's Autoliv the opportunity to expand in Japan
summary: Sweden's Autoliv, the world's top car safety equipment maker, is poised to expand its global leadership in Japan, capitalizing on the crisis engulfing rival Takata Corp. Autoliv has struggled to break ties with Japanese carmakers and Takata due to the keiretsu corporate culture, but the opportunity now presents itself. With Takata's global reputation at risk, Autoliv may finally establish a strong presence in Japan, a key car hub it has been unable to dominate. This move could further solidify Autoliv's position as a leading global supplier of car safety equipment.

site_title: Airbnb making fat profits for property investors
summary: Airbnb is generating significant profits for property investors, with some individuals earning over $500,000 annually from short-term rentals. The platform has seen a surge in listings, with over 40% of inventory in major US cities controlled by hosts with multiple properties. Critics argue that the unlicensed lodgings are driving up costs for local residents and putting pressure on city governments, while proponents claim that Airbnb provides a valuable service for hosts and guests alike. The company has faced opposition from local authorities, but continues to expand its services with support from startups offering additional amenities.

images.alt_text: "Airbnb is a middle-class, people-to- people platform - for the people, by the people, of the people," according to Chris Lehane,  Airbnb's head of global policy.

site_title: World nations reach landmark deal on using satellites to track flights
summary: World nations reached a landmark deal on using satellites to track flights, aiming to prevent future disappearances like MH370. The accord, reached by over 160 countries at the UN's International Telecommunication Union, will enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. The system will utilize a previously used frequency band to send transmissions from aircraft to satellites, providing complete surveillance of global airspace. The agreement was driven by the 2014 MH370 tragedy and is seen as a key step in improving the current civilian flight-tracking system.

site_title: UniCredit to cut 18,200 jobs, boost capital
summary: UniCredit plans to cut 18,200 jobs and restructure its retail business in Austria and leasing operations in Italy to boost financial strength and avoid a capital increase. The bank expects a CET 1 ratio of 12.6% by 2018 and a net profit of 5.3 billion euros. Job cuts will occur in corporate and commercial banks across Italy, Germany, Austria, and Central and Eastern Europe. The restructuring aims to increase core capital and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Investment, forex losses slash Wilmar gain
summary: Wilmar International's third-quarter net profit declined 34.7% to US$275.8 million due to higher investment losses and foreign exchange losses. Revenue fell 7.6% to US$10.6 billion, mainly due to lower commodity prices. The company's oilseeds and grains division saw a 38.6% increase in pre-tax profit, while its tropical oils business saw a 45.9% decline. Despite this, Wilmar remains optimistic about its performance for the remainder of the year.

site_title: US$ retreats as traders question pace of Fed rate increase
summary: The US dollar weakened, falling less than 0.1% to $1.0728 per euro, as investors questioned the pace of a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase in December. The Fed's probability of raising rates was 66%, down from 50% in October, after a jobs report showed the biggest increase this year. This tempered bets on a stronger dollar, with the Norwegian and Australian currencies gaining. The US dollar's surge risks dampening inflation and damaging US companies, while markets focus on whether the Fed will suggest successive hikes after December.

site_title: Bank hedges hit record low as traders position for rate hikes
summary: US financial stocks are experiencing a record low in short interest, with a 66% chance of a rate hike in December, according to traders. This increased confidence is driven by better-than-expected employment data and accelerating wage growth, which is seen as integral to a rate move by the Federal Reserve. Higher lending rates are expected to boost earnings for financial firms, with banks poised to benefit from higher fee income.

site_title: Drink Sake, Eat Sushi
summary: Sakae Sushi, a Singapore-founded trendy kaiten sushi concept, has become synonymous with a fun-filled, value-for-money and healthy dining experience. Founded by Mr. Douglas Foo, the company serves Japanese cuisine and has been listed on the Singapore Exchange since 2003. As the flagship brand of Sakae Holdings Ltd, it caters to customers craving affordable and quality Japanese food.

site_title: US$1b of shares frozen as China investigates hedge fund boss
summary: Chinese authorities have frozen US$1 billion of shares in listed companies as they investigate hedge fund boss Xu Xiang for alleged insider trading and stock manipulation. The freeze applies to 90 million shares held by Zexi Investment in Shanghai-based developer Deluxe Family Co, worth 1.16 billion yuan. Xu, known as "hedge fund brother No 1," was detained on November 1 amid a wave of investigations into market irregularities. The total value of frozen stakes is US$1 billion, with other firms also reporting lock-ups.

site_title: China-Taiwan talks may yield domestic dividends for both sides
summary: China's President Xi Jinping and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou met in Singapore, marking the first official meeting since the Chinese Civil War in 1949. The meeting reaffirmed both sides' positions, with Xi stating there can be only "one China" and Ma interpreting it as each side defining the term. This aligns with the 1992 consensus, allowing both sides to define "one China" differently. The meeting appears to have yielded domestic dividends for both leaders, with Xi solidifying his position and Ma addressing concerns within Taiwan.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singtel retained Barclays Premier League rights for three seasons, marking the third time it secured the deal away from StarHub. CIMB Research estimates the cost could be higher than the rumored S$410 million, impacting Singtel's FY18F Ebitda by S$56 million. In contrast, Courts Asia's Q3 earnings surged 78% year-on-year, driven by strong performance in Malaysia, while BreadTalk Group's Q3 earnings fell short of expectations due to higher depreciation costs and a challenging China operations.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Surbana Jurong Private Limited acquired stakes in two African firms to enhance its presence in the continent. GrabTaxi, an Uber rival, plans to launch a carpooling service in Singapore. Condo resale prices dropped 0.6% in October, while Alibaba's Singles' Day sales are expected to surpass $13.8 billion, a 50% increase from last year. Singapore shares closed 0.54% lower on Wednesday, while China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Fifa's Sepp Blatter hospitalised after breakdown
summary: FIFA President Sepp Blatter, 79, is hospitalized after suffering a "small breakdown." He is expected to remain in the hospital until next Tuesday. Blatter is recovering well, according to his spokesman, and is confident of appealing the suspension related to allegations of an illicit payment. The Swiss attorney general launched a criminal investigation in September. Blatter has delivered documents to prove his innocence.

site_title: Update: Petronas cuts state dividend as profit plunges on oil drop
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil and gas firm Petronas is slashing its 2016 dividend to the government by nearly 40% due to a 91% plunge in quarterly profit caused by weak global crude oil prices. The company will pay 16 billion ringgit in dividend, down from 26 billion in 2015. Petronas' net profit for July-September fell to 1.4 billion ringgit, down from 15.1 billion the same period last year, due to impairment losses and net losses on foreign exchange and derivatives.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff threats from President Trump. Creative Technology warned of H2 revenue below target and an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day run ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: ValueMax Q3 profit up 32% as clampdown on costs offsets sales drop
summary: ValueMax Group posted a 31.8% rise in its third-quarter net profit to S$2.2 million, driven by a 24.3% decrease in cost of sales. Revenue fell 21.7% to S$68.5 million due to declining retail and trading of pre-owned jewellery and gold. Despite the revenue drop, ValueMax managed to increase its gross profit margin to 10% and expects a "challenging" business environment due to rising interest rates and lacklustre gold prices. The company plans to open two more pawnshops and retail outlets in Singapore.

site_title: Yanlord's Q3 profit grows six-fold to 55.7m yuan
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group's Q3 net profit soared six-fold to 55.7 million yuan, driven by the delivery of units in a Shenzhen project. Revenue tripled to 3 billion yuan, with the project contributing 65% of gross revenue. The company's nine-month net earnings fell 16% to 242.2 million yuan.

site_title: German car regulator widens emissions probe to 23 brands
summary: Germany's motor vehicle regulator, Kraftfahrt-Bundesamt, is conducting tests on over 50 models of 23 German and foreign car brands suspected of manipulating nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel engines. The investigation was triggered by Volkswagen's admission of rigging emissions tests, as well as "verified indications from third parties." Two-thirds of the measurements have already been taken, with diesel vehicles from foreign manufacturers also subject to strict checks. The probe aims to determine if further manipulation of emissions is taking place in the market.

site_title: Myanmar President to meet Suu Kyi after final vote count
summary: Myanmar President Thein Sein will meet Aung San Suu Kyi after the final results of the Nov 8 election are tallied, following her request to ensure the "people's will" is respected. The election commission has released results of less than 200 of the 498 seats, with the National League for Democracy dominating early returns. The government has stated it will accept the outcome and work with the NLD once official results are released, amid a request for national reconciliation.

images.alt_text: Myanmar President Thein Sein will only meet Aung San Suu Kyi after the final results of the Nov 8 election are tallied, following a request from the opposition leader for a sit-down to ensure the "people's will" is respected as the vote count drags on.

site_title: Alibaba says Singles' Day sales surpass last year's US$9.3b total
summary: Alibaba reported that its Singles' Day sales surpassed last year's total of US$9.3 billion, with potential sales reaching US$13.8 billion, a 50% growth from last year. JD.com, a rival e-commerce firm, also broke past last year's full-day sales. Alibaba's focus on international e-commerce and partnerships with affiliates are expected to drive growth, with President Michael Evans stating China will become the world's largest e-commerce market for imported products within five years.

site_title: Ziwo warns of loss, revenue drop in Q3
summary: Ziwo Holdings, a synthetic fibres maker, reported a third-quarter operating loss and significant revenue drop due to losses from defective goods, impairment of receivables, and a tax penalty. The company attributed these losses to the ending of a 30D terylene filament yarn contract and compensation claims. Ziwo expects to report its third-quarter results by November 14.

site_title: Metro's Q2 earnings plunge 70% to S$18.6m
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 70% plunge in Q2 net profit to S$18.6m, despite a 22.3% revenue rise to S$38.31m due to higher turnover from its retail operations. Q2 earnings per share fell to 2.2 Singapore cents, down from 7.4 cents a year ago. The half-year net profit slid 21.4% to S$56.11m, while revenue rose nearly 30% to S$81.02m.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index retreated 16.13 points to 2,981.59 on Wednesday, closing 0.54% lower due to weak economic data from China. Banks and property counters were the main losers. Losers outnumbered gainers 301 to 137. The market saw an average unit price of S$0.81 per share, with 1.22 billion shares changing hands.

site_title: F J Benjamin sinks into the red in Q1 2016
summary: F J Benjamin reported a net loss of S$5.47 million in Q1 FY2016, down from a net profit of S$1.11 million a year ago. Turnover dropped 15% to S$63.7 million due to headwinds in the retail sector. The group expects the retail sector in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia to remain challenging in the mid-term, and is proactively managing its brand portfolio and operations. A restructuring exercise is expected to be completed by the end of 2Q16.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q2 profit falls 33% to S$5.5m on lower margins
summary: Boustead Projects' Q2 profit fell 33% to S$5.5 million due to lower gross margins in its design and build arm, which develops industrial and commercial properties. Revenue increased 6% to S$53.8 million. The leasing business is performing better, driven by completed design, build, and lease projects.

site_title: Japan advisors call for minimum wage increase to boost consumption
summary: Japanese government advisors recommend increasing the minimum wage to boost consumer spending and counter criticism that economic growth benefits have not trickled down to low-income households. The recommendation comes as part of a new package of structural reforms aimed at slowing population decline and expanding the labor force. The Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, is considering a potential wage increase before the end of the month, with a large increase expected to benefit low-income earners and counter deflation.

site_title: British unemployment hits seven-year low: data
summary: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.3% in the third quarter, a seven-year low, while employment reached a record high of 31.2 million. The jobless total decreased by 103,000 to 1.75 million, a seven-year low. However, the number of people claiming jobless benefits increased in October to 795,500, the third consecutive month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down as financial and energy firms weigh
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng index falling 0.2% to 22,352.17, as losses in financial and energy stocks outweighed gains in Tencent's strong third-quarter earnings. The China Enterprises Index also dropped 0.7%. Total trading volume was 1.5 billion shares.

site_title: Update: Julius Baer's SGD perpetual bond issue final price 6% area; order book about S$1.8b
summary: Swiss bank Julius Baer has sold a Singapore dollar-denominated, Basel III-compliant perpetual Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bond with a final price guidance of 6% area, plus or minus 10 basis points. The order book is approximately S$1.8 billion, driven by strong interest from private bank investors. This marks Julius Baer's maiden sale of such a bond, which is expected to be the highest-yielding AT1s in the SGD bond universe, surpassing existing AT1s issued by local banks.

site_title: UOL's Q3 profit slips 2% to S$101m
summary: UOL Group reported a 2% decline in Q3 net profit to S$101m, driven by lower revenue of 18% to S$354m. This marks a decrease from the same period last year, when the group recognized S$103m in net profit. The revenue drop was largely attributed to the recognition of S$212.2m in the year-ago period from a project in Tianjin, China.

site_title: Raffles Education Q1 profit up 22% on foreign-exchange impact
summary: Raffles Education Corp reported a 22% increase in Q1 net profit to S$867,000, driven by foreign-exchange gains. Revenue slipped 1% to S$29.1 million, while other operating income rose 52% due to a government incentive. The company faces new challenges from a macroeconomic slowdown and currency volatility. Depreciation and amortisation expenses fell 18% due to a change in property, plant and equipment estimates.

site_title: SIA signs extensive partnership deal with Lufthansa
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed a partnership deal with Lufthansa, expanding joint-venture flights between Singapore and European cities. The agreement includes revenue-sharing arrangements for flights between Singapore and Frankfurt, Munich, and Zurich, as well as new codeshare routes to destinations in Austria, Belgium, Germany, and Switzerland. SIA and Lufthansa also plan to coordinate schedules, offer joint fare promotions, and enhance their frequent-flyer programme ties. The partnership aims to provide customers with more convenient connections between route networks, with expanded codeshare cooperation expected in the future.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Thai Airways to cut salaries of top management by 10%
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl announced a 10% salary cut for its top management in November as part of a cost-cutting scheme to reduce operating costs by 20 billion baht. Despite aiming to cut costs by 7 billion baht, the airline has fallen short of its target. The move is part of a two-year restructuring plan to address heavy losses in the third quarter.

site_title: TalkTalk says cyber attack will cost it £30-35m
summary: TalkTalk, a British broadband company, has estimated the cost of a recent cyber attack at £30-35 million (US$45.43 million-US$53.00 million). Although 157,000 customers were affected, the company saw an initial spike in defections but a subsequent decrease. CEO Dido Harding expressed optimism about the company's prospects, citing a 4.7% revenue growth and plans to raise its interim dividend. Despite the attack, shares rose 12% as analysts revised their estimates, expecting a material step-up in earnings in the second half.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's NPI gains 4.7% in Q3; DPU up 5.2%
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's net property income (NPI) rose 4.7% to S$15.6 million in Q3, beating forecasts by 8.1%. Distribution per unit increased 5.2% to 1.02 Singapore cents. For the nine months, NPI rose 16.4% and distribution per unit increased 14.4%. The trust attributed the growth to higher office occupancy and other property-related income. However, low office vacancy in Singapore is expected to continue, with new developments potentially impacting vacancy and rents in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook hits record low after warning profit to plunge
summary: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd saw its shares plummet to a record low in Hong Kong after warning of a 40-50% decline in first-half profit due to weak consumer sentiment in Hong Kong and Macau, amid a slowdown in China's economy. The company's net income for the six months ending Sept 30 is expected to decrease mainly due to weakness in the two cities, increased sales of lower-margin gold products, and unrealized hedging losses. As a result, the company's shares fell 7.1% to HK$6.17 per share.

site_title: Wilmar Q3 profit slips as weak equity market causes investment loss
summary: Wilmar International, the world's largest palm oil processor, reported a 35% drop in third-quarter net profit to US$275.9 million, mainly due to mark-to-market losses from investment securities. The company's revenue declined 7.6% to US$10.6 billion. Non-operating items recorded a loss of US$78.9 million, mainly due to weaker equity markets. Despite low palm oil prices, the oilseeds and grains segment showed a satisfactory performance, with the company expecting improved margins in its plantation business due to rising crude palm oil prices.

site_title: Oil prices drop on rising stockpiles, Japan recession fears
summary: Crude oil prices dropped on Wednesday due to rising US stockpiles and fears of a Japanese recession. US crude futures fell to a two-week low at $43.55 a barrel, while Brent crude futures dropped 25 cents to $47.19 a barrel. The decline was attributed to increased stockpiles in North America and slowing economies in Asia, particularly Japan, where confidence among manufacturers fell for a third straight month. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is expected to maintain its production policy, despite calls from some members to cut output.

site_title: Serangoon property approved for education use up for sale
summary: A 103-year leasehold property at 11 Hillside Drive in Singapore's Serangoon sub-regional district has been put up for sale. The site, currently used by an educational institution, features a gross floor area of 46,753 sq ft and is near major retail and transportation hubs. Joint marketing agents JLL and Cushman & Wakefield expect strong interest from educational operators and investors, citing a shortage of community and education facilities in Singapore due to limited government land releases. The sale is open to expressions of interest until December 16, 2015.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher as bank rally overcomes BHP selloff
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,122.6, driven by a bank rally, despite heavy selling in miner BHP Billiton following a deadly industrial accident in Brazil. The benchmark index is down over 5% this year. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also edged higher.

site_title: Tiong Woon falls to S$3.6m Q1 loss on impairment of receivables
summary: Tiong Woon Corp Holding reported a Q1 loss of S$3.6 million due to impairments for trade receivables, down from a net profit of S$3.5 million in the same period last year. The company's net profit per share fell to 0.78 Singapore cents from 0.75 cents. Operating expenses increased by 81% to S$10.9 million, with a S$4.9 million impairment loss on trade receivables. The company's Q1 loss was largely attributed to a drop in turnover.

site_title: Australia struggles to sate China's appetite for foreign baby formula
summary: Australia is struggling to meet China's demand for foreign baby formula, with savvy Chinese tourists snapping up tins to resell at high mark-ups due to safety concerns over domestic brands. The shortage has forced top two supermarket chains to ration sales and manufacturers to boost output. Chinese visitors exploit a weak Australian dollar and safety concerns to offload Australian purchases at 500% mark-ups, with sales soaring after Hong Kong and Britain adopted enforced rationing in 2013.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won nearly flat after mixed China data
summary: Seoul's shares closed flat on Wednesday following mixed data from China, which showed spots of improvement in South Korea's largest export market. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended at 1,997.27 points, unchanged from the previous close. The South Korean won rose 0.2% to 1,154.9 to the dollar, but surrendered some gains on the China data. Markets in South Korea will be closed one hour early on Thursday due to the annual college entrance exams.

site_title: China: Stocks close up on mixed data
summary: China's stocks closed up on Wednesday, despite mixed data showing the country's economy remains lacklustre. The CSI300 index was unchanged, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.3%. The market was initially dragged down by a retreat in financial sector shares but recovered in the afternoon. Total turnover was high, with 36 billion lots traded in Shanghai and 38.2 billion in Shenzhen. The mixed data has led investors to wager on further stimulus, contributing to the market's upbeat close.

images.alt_text: China stocks closed up on Wednesday as investors wagered on further stimulus after a mixed batch of data showed growth in Asia's giant economy remained lacklustre at best.

site_title: Australian PM Turnbull looks to heal wounds on Indonesia visit
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is visiting Indonesia to repair strained diplomatic and economic ties, which have been affected by past issues including spying, executions, and asylum seeker policies. Turnbull inherited strained relations from his predecessor, Tony Abbott, and will meet with Indonesian President Joko Widodo. The visit aims to reset the relationship and address growing Chinese assertiveness in the region.

site_title: AB InBev launches SAB bid, to sell MillerCoors stake
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) launched a US$100 billion-plus bid for SABMiller, the world's second-largest brewer, to gain regulatory approval. The deal includes selling SABMiller's 58% stake in US joint venture MillerCoors to Molson Coors for US$12 billion. AB InBev expects to save US$1.4 billion annually after the merger, which would combine its brands with SABMiller's Peroni, Grolsch, and Pilsner Urquell. The takeover would be the largest of a British-based company and the fourth-biggest overall.

images.alt_text: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's biggest brewer, launched its US$100 billion-plus offer for nearest rival SABMiller on Wednesday and agreed to sell the latter's stake in US venture MillerCoors to help win regulatory approval.

site_title: Petronas's Q3 net profit tumbles 91%
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil firm, reported a 91% decline in Q3 net profit to 1.4 billion ringgit (US$321.10 million) due to weak global crude oil prices. Revenue fell 25% to 60.1 billion ringgit compared to the same period last year. This is the third straight quarter of profit declines for Petronas in 2015. The company's outlook for the rest of 2015 and into 2016 remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Petroliam Nasional Bhd (Petronas) reported on Wednesday a 91 per cent plunge in third-quarter net profit due to weak global crude oil prices.

site_title: China Jan-Oct property investment growth slows to 2.0 per cent on year
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 2.0% in the first 10 months of 2015, the lowest rate since early 2009. This marks a decrease from the 2.6% growth in January-September. However, the area of property sold rose 7.2% during the same period. The data from the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) indicates a slowdown in investment, but sales by area increased.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei steady as China data arrives in-line with expectations
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.1% to 19,691.39, marking the sixth consecutive day of gains for the benchmark Nikkei index. China's retail sales rose 11.0% year-on-year, slightly above expectations, while urban investment and industrial production also met forecasts. The Topix subindex for textiles and retail sector gained 2.3% and 1.4% respectively, despite a strengthening yen. The broader Topix added 0.4% and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 rose 0.4%.

site_title: Rabobank sees recovery in China offshore food and agri deals
summary: Rabobank's CEO Wilco Hendriks expects a recovery in China's offshore food and agri deals, driven by strong interest to meet domestic demand. Confidence had stalled due to slower economic growth, but is expected to rebound quickly. Chinese clients are eager to make foreign acquisitions or partnerships, with a focus on commodities, technology, and quality brands to feed the country's 1.4 billion people.

site_title: China says up to Philippines to heal rift over South China Sea case
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said the Philippines' case against China at an arbitration tribunal over the South China Sea has strained relations between Beijing and Manila. The arbitration case, which China boycotted, ruled in favor of the Philippines, and Wang urged the Philippines to improve ties. The Philippines claims a 200-nautical mile EEZ in the South China Sea, which China's nine-dash line claim could potentially encroach upon. Wang stated that the Philippines must resolve the issue, while China prefers bilateral negotiations to resolve disputes.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange Q3 profit jumps on higher trading volumes
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd reported a 80% surge in third-quarter profit to HK$2.3 billion, driven by higher trading volumes amid China's economic jitters. This surpassed analysts' estimates and boosted the company's share price 24% this year. The increase in market activity on the cash and derivatives markets contributed to the growth. A one-off gain from disposing a leasehold property also added to the profit. The promise of a link with Shenzhen's stock exchange further boosted the company's share price.

site_title: Ousted Thai PM Yingluck defends rice scheme in open letter to junta leader
summary: Ousted Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has defended her position in a case involving rice subsidies, which could see her jailed for up to 10 years. She claims the attorney general is rushing the case and total losses are still unknown. The military government says the scheme incurred losses of $16 billion and distorted global prices. Yingluck insists she is innocent and will prove it, but a Supreme Court review of evidence is set to last until November 2016.

site_title: Julius Baer's SGD perpetual bond issue drawing strong interest; initial price guidance at 6.375%
summary: Julius Baer's SGD perpetual bond issue drew strong interest, with indication of interest exceeding S$500 million shortly after the sale began. The initial price guidance is 6.375%. This is Julius Baer's first SGD-denominated, Basel III-compliant perpetual Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bond issue in the Singapore market, with a minimum sale size of S$250 million to S$300 million.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi edges toward landslide victory
summary: Myanmar's democracy champion Aung San Suu Kyi has won over 90% of the seats declared in the lower house and 85% in regional assemblies and the upper house, solidifying her position for an absolute majority. Despite a constitutional ban on her becoming president due to her foreign-born children, Suu Kyi has indicated she will use her majority to run the country. This shift in power could reshape Myanmar's political landscape, following the country's transition from a military regime to democracy.

site_title: Nearly half of Singapore SMEs see no growth in sales this year: survey
summary: Nearly half of Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expect no growth in sales this year, according to a survey, with 47% of respondents anticipating zero or negative revenue growth. Meanwhile, 6% of SMEs expect a decline in sales. The annual SME Development Survey highlights concerns about the economic outlook for Singapore's SME sector.

site_title: Carlsberg to cut 2,000 jobs as brewer seeks to reduce costs
summary: Carlsberg A/S plans to cut approximately 2,000 jobs, reducing annual costs by up to $288 million by 2018, as the brewer seeks to reverse a profit decline caused by the weakness of Russia's beer market. The 15% staff reduction will also cut costs by 2 billion Danish kroner. The company's CEO, Cees 't Hart, acknowledged the profit decline and is taking steps to prepare for the future, citing increased competition from rivals such as Anheuser-Busch InBev NV.

site_title: Oil prices resume decline in Asia
summary: Oil prices in Asia resumed their decline, trading at US$43.74 for West Texas Intermediate and US$47.18 for Brent crude. The decline follows a four-day losing streak, with the International Energy Agency forecasting a global oil market recovery to US$80 a barrel by 2020. The supply glut and Opec's decision to maintain output are contributing factors, with a strong dollar and interest rate expectations also keeping prices in check. The market is expected to remain in surplus through most of 2016, restricting price upside.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise, led by Carlsberg
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, led by a 8.5% gain in Carlsberg after the company announced restructuring plans and a $1.4 billion impairment charge. Analysts welcomed the steps, noting the brewer's earnings contained no negative surprises. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose on positive earnings reports from other companies, with mining and healthcare sectors contributing to the gains.

site_title: US dollar rally fizzles, dealers await China release
summary: The US dollar edged down in Asia after a brief rally since the release of strong US jobs data, amid concerns over China's economic outlook. Disappointing Chinese economic data, including trade and inflation figures, has reinforced worries about the country's growth. Despite weak global economy, the Federal Reserve is expected to hike borrowing rates to prevent bubbles. The dollar's decline was also driven by tumbling stocks, which could overhaul the scenario of a rate hike and dollar buying.

images.alt_text: The dollar edged down in Asia on Wednesday after rallying since last week's US jobs data while Asian equities mostly dipped as investors nervously await there release of more Chinese economic data.

site_title: Condo resale prices drop 0.6% in October on higher volume
summary: Singapore condo resale prices dropped 0.6% in October 2015, with all regions experiencing price declines, averaging 0.5-1.1%. Resale volume rose 9.8% compared to September, with 505 units sold in October. Year-over-year, prices dropped 2.6% and resale volume remained flat.

site_title: Australia: Shares higher as banks counter BHP selloff
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday as banks countered losses in miner BHP Billiton following a deadly industrial accident at a Brazilian mine. BHP shares fell 2.6% due to the accident, which resulted in at least six deaths and dozens more missing. The bank sector gained as investors bought financial stocks amid tough new capital rules and fears of a housing slowdown. The S&P/ASX 200 index is down nearly 6% this year.

site_title: Suu Kyi seeks meeting with Myanmar's military
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, leader of Myanmar's democracy movement, has asked for a meeting with the country's military commander, Senior Gen Min Aung Hlaing, on the basis of "national reconciliation" following her party's landslide victory in nationwide elections. The party has been declared the winner of 163 seats, with Suu Kyi re-elected to her seat. Analysts say cooperation between Suu Kyi and the military is crucial for a functioning government, as the military still holds significant power. The military-drafted constitution prohibits Suu Kyi from serving as president.

images.alt_text: Fresh from her party's apparent landslide victory in nationwide elections, Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar's democracy movement, has asked the commander of the country's powerful military for a meeting on the basis of "national reconciliation."

site_title: Gold edges up as dollar dips, still near 3-mth low on US rate view
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,091.70 an ounce as the dollar dipped, despite remaining near a three-month low due to outflows from bullion funds and anticipation of a US interest rate hike. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in December, weakening demand for non-interest-paying assets like gold. Physical demand from Asia, however, could provide a floor for declining gold prices, with premiums on the Shanghai Gold Exchange at a healthy $4-$5 an ounce.

images.alt_text: Gold ticked up on Wednesday as the dollar pared some of its recent gains, but the metal remained under pressure near a three-month low as outflows from bullion funds and an anticipated US rate hike weighed on the market.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 20 points to 1,665.320. The market saw a 710-279 loss-gain ratio, with 2.34 billion lots valued at RM2.30 billion traded.

site_title: Uber rival GrabTaxi plans carpooling service in Singapore
summary: GrabTaxi, an Uber rival, plans to launch a carpooling service called GrabHitch in Singapore, aiming to compete with existing services like Ryde and Tripda. The service, set to be launched by end-2015, will allow drivers to accept compensation from passengers but not for profit. This move comes as Singapore introduces rules for carpooling, which allow drivers to accept compensation but not profit. GrabHitch aims to provide a door-to-door transport service at a lower cost than public train or bus fares, targeting those who prefer not to pay a premium.

site_title: Asia: Shares cautious ahead of China data
summary: Asian share markets were narrowly mixed on Wednesday, awaiting Chinese data, as the US dollar strengthened, weighing on global commodity prices. Japan's Nikkei slipped 0.3% and Australia's stocks gained 0.3% after two sessions of losses. The euro lost ground due to political uncertainty in Portugal, while the dollar index reached a seven-month peak. Soft Chinese inflation pointed to global deflationary pressures, with benchmark 10-year Treasury yields dipping slightly.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks down ahead of next China data release
summary: Shanghai stocks opened lower on Wednesday ahead of China's economic data release, following recent weak readings on trade and inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.15% to 3,635.00, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.09%. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.17% to 22,439.66. The market awaits the release of more economic data, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: China factory output, investment sluggish as old economy slows
summary: China's industrial production and investment slowed in October, with industrial output rising 5.6% and fixed-asset investment increasing 10.2% in the first 10 months. Retail sales rose 11% in October, defying the weakness. China's leaders aim to transition to a more consumption and services-led economy, but policy makers face pressure to step up stimulus as growth slows. With the real estate sector stalling and manufacturing deteriorating, policymakers are under pressure to revive the nation's old economic engines.

site_title: Netflix hit by outage, vexing users
summary: Netflix experienced a temporary outage on Tuesday, affecting unspecified numbers of users in the US, Mexico, and Brazil. The streaming issues were resolved about an hour after the company acknowledged the problem on Twitter. Netflix, the world's largest video streaming service, did not provide further details on the cause of the outage. The company's tech support responded to users with a humorous message, saying its "geeks" were working to resolve the issue.

site_title: Ringgit results in poorest bond sales since 2010
summary: Malaysia's bond market has seen its poorest sales since 2010, with companies shelving investment plans due to a depressed ringgit. The country's bond bankers have had little to do in five years as imports of investment goods shrank 26.4% through August, and borrowing for investment has become tough. Despite a record US$8.9 billion of offshore bond issuance this year, mainly by the government and state-owned enterprises, private issuance has been low, with just US$2.2 billion issued since 2011.

site_title: "Too big to fail" Chinese banks face US$400 billion capital call
summary: China's four major state-owned banks, Bank of China, Agricultural Bank of China, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, and China Construction Bank, may need to raise up to $400 billion in capital to meet new global capital rules, known as "too big to fail" requirements. The Financial Stability Board's rules, finalized this week, require the world's 30 systemically important banks to hold a buffer of capital that can be written down to protect taxpayers if the bank fails. China's banks currently hold minimal senior debt, making them the most likely to struggle with the requirements, with analysts estimating they will need to raise between $350 billion and $400 billion to comply.

site_title: China's Q3 preliminary current account surplus at US$63.4b: FX regulator
summary: China reported a preliminary current account surplus of $63.4 billion in Q3 2015, with a $212 billion surplus and a $121.9 billion deficit in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares down on global uncertainty; won flat
summary: South Korean shares fell for the fifth consecutive day, down 0.6% at 1,983.85 points, due to concerns over global economic conditions and caution ahead of Chinese data. The won was also down 0.2% at 1,154.7 per dollar. Investors are waiting for Chinese retail sales and industrial production data, and some are taking money out of stocks in case of a potential US interest rate hike. Foreign investors sold 94.5 billion Korean won worth of KOSPI shares, weighing on the index.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.35% lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.35% lower on Wednesday, amid profit-taking following recent market rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 69.25 points to 19,602.01. Investors shifted focus to profit-taking after recent gains.

site_title: Freehold mixed-use redevelopment site at Upper East Coast Road up for sale
summary: A freehold mixed-use redevelopment site at Upper East Coast Road has been put up for sale by tender. The site, known as Lodge 77, has a land area of 1,219.2 square meters and is zoned for "residential with commercial at 1st storey" with a gross plot ratio of 3.0. The seller expects offers above S$34.2 million, with a land rate of about S$1,100 psf per plot ratio. The site is located near the future Siglap (Thomson-East Coast Line) MRT station and several schools, offering a quick turnaround time for prospective purchasers with no Strata Titles Board approval required.

site_title: Japan's first commercial jet in 50 years makes maiden flight
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp has successfully completed the maiden flight of its first commercial jet in 50 years, the Mitsubishi Regional Jet (MRJ). The 100-seat plane made a one-hour return flight from Nagoya Airport, marking a breakthrough for Japan's aviation industry. The MRJ aims to compete with major players like Bombardier and Embraer, with over 223 firm orders secured, including a 100-aircraft purchase from US regional airline Trans State Holdings. The plane burns a fifth less fuel than similar aircraft, thanks to new-generation engines.

site_title: Asia: Shares anxious ahead of China data
summary: Asian share markets declined on Wednesday due to anxiety over Chinese data, particularly retail sales, industrial production, and urban investment. The CSI300 index fell 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.3%. Markets are vulnerable to disappointment in Chinese figures, which could impact global commodity prices.

site_title: BOJ's Harada says it should ease further if overseas risks hurt jobs
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yutaka Harada stated that the central bank should ease monetary policy further if overseas risks negatively impact job growth and inflation. Harada defended the BOJ's stimulus program, citing its impact on corporate profits and job growth. Despite "worrying signs" in private consumption and weak corporate investment, Harada expects consumer inflation to reach the BOJ's 2% target by March 2016. The BOJ remains under pressure to ease monetary policy as Japan's economy recovers moderately and faces risks from slowing overseas growth and potential US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 11.92 points to 1673.10. Losers outnumbered gainers 114 to 94, with a trading volume of 62.6 million lots worth RM28.4 million.

site_title: Pakistan to sign economic zone deal with China: official
summary: Pakistan's Baluchistan province is set to sign a 40-year lease deal with China, allotting 923 hectares of land for a massive special economic zone in Gwadar, a deep sea port. The deal is part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, a $46 billion investment plan linking western China to the Arabian Sea. The lease will allow China to build an export zone and international airport, with a road network connecting the zone to the airport and sea port. The deal comes as Pakistan seeks to boost economic growth and address poverty in the province.

site_title: China probes Shanghai vice-mayor for suspected graft
summary: Vice-Mayor Ai Baojun of Shanghai is being investigated for suspected "serious breaches of discipline" by the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, China's antigraft watchdog. Ai, who oversaw the city's free trade zone, has headed the committee since its launch in 2013. The investigation comes amid China's ongoing anti-corruption campaign launched by President Xi Jinping. Ai's background includes working for Baosteel Group and serving as a university professor. Shanghai's party boss Han Zheng has expressed support for the investigation and a zero-tolerance policy on corruption.

site_title: Surbana Jurong enhances presence in Africa, buys stakes in two firms
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based private company, has made two significant investments in Africa and the US to expand its presence and capabilities. It acquired a 20% stake in CITICC (Africa) Holding Limited, a $300 million investment platform, and invested $9.25 million in FLUX Factory Inc, a San Francisco-based software company. These moves aim to enhance Surbana Jurong's building design capabilities and presence in Africa.

site_title: Otto Marine in the red for Q3, expects no improvement in market conditions
summary: Otto Marine reported a Q3 loss of US$5.5 million, down from a profit of US$2 million a year ago, due to a 35% revenue decline across all segments. Revenue fell from shipyards, shipping and chartering, and subsea services due to challenging market conditions and lower charter rates. The company expects no improvement in market conditions over the next 12 months and is focusing on sustaining vessel utilization and rationalizing costs to remain competitive.

site_title: New IMF economist sees major challenges to global economy
summary: IMF Chief Economist Maurice Obstfeld warns of major challenges to the global economy, citing a "nightmare scenario" in Europe where various pressures, including the refugee crisis, Brexit, and climate change, could weaken economic bonds. He also expresses concerns over the US Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates and the European Central Bank's need to loosen monetary policy. Obstfeld emphasizes the importance of collective action to address climate change, suggesting that countries implement carbon taxes to stimulate emissions reduction and innovation.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buys residential land in Australia for A$15.65m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has entered into contracts to buy two residential land parcels in Killara, New South Wales, Australia for A$15.65 million. The properties, with a total land area of 3,792.2 square meters, have been approved for development into 43 apartments and 63 car spaces. The acquisition is subject to conditions, including Foreign Investment Review Board approval, and is expected to have minimal impact on the group's earnings and net tangible assets.

site_title: Uber to relaunch premium taxi service in South Korea
summary: Uber Technologies Inc plans to relaunch its premium taxi service, UberBLACK, in South Korea's capital, Seoul, after the government eased regulations to allow high-end taxi services. The new service will feature commercially licensed drivers and is expected to be available to the general public. UberBLACK was previously limited to qualifying passengers, including those with disabilities and foreigners. The company has also partnered with Kia Motors Corp to offer discounts on K9 sedans to its drivers. The relaunch follows Uber's suspension of the service earlier this year due to regulatory issues.

site_title: Protesters rally for higher US fast-food wages, union rights
summary: US fast-food workers rallied in support of a $15-an-hour minimum wage and union rights, with hundreds protesting in New York, Washington, and Chicago. Strikes took place in 270 cities and protests in hundreds more, coinciding with televised debates and coinciding with Democratic presidential candidates backing the cause. The Fight for $15 campaign aims to gain political support for a minimum wage and union rights ahead of the 2016 presidential election. Organizers also see the protests as a response to income inequality.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Croesus, Roxy-Pacific, Otto Marine, Singtel
summary: Vard Holdings deepened its losses to 486 million Norwegian kroner (S$80 million) in its third quarter due to reduced utilisation at European shipyards amid a prolonged industry down-cycle. Croesus Retail Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.08 Singapore cents unchanged from a year ago, while Roxy-Pacific Holdings entered into contracts to buy land in Australia for A$15.65 million. Otto Marine posted a loss of US$5.5 million for its third quarter. Meanwhile, Singtel outbid rival StarHub to win the Singapore broadcast rights to all English Premier League (EPL) matches for the next three seasons starting from August 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday, in line with Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Wednesday, down 1.26 points or 0.04% to 2,996.46, mirroring a flat finish on Wall Street. Asian markets also fell, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index losing 0.35% and 69.25 points. Despite this, telco Singtel's share price remained flat after it secured the broadcast rights to English Premier League matches. Overall, 81.8 million shares worth S$83.4 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 75 to 68.

site_title: EU misspent over 6b euros last year: watchdog
summary: The European Union's financial watchdog reported that the bloc mismanaged 6.3 billion euros (S$9.6 billion) in 2014, citing examples of poorly spent funds, including unused airports and aid for farmland used as a motocross track. The watchdog urged Brussels to adopt a more flexible budget to address the migration crisis, calling for a "wholly new approach" to budget management. The error rate for spending fell slightly to 4.4% in 2014, but was still above the acceptable level of 2.2%.

site_title: Vard's losses deepen in Q3 on slowing activity in Europe, delays in Brazil
summary: Vard Holdings posted a loss of 486 million Norwegian kroner (S$80 million) in its third quarter, exceeding last year's loss of 37 million kroner. Revenue fell 19% to 2.27 billion kroner due to reduced European shipyard utilization and operational issues in Brazil. New cost overruns and delays at the Brazilian shipyards contributed to the loss, with the complexity of LPG carriers under construction exceeding original assumptions. The company faces a prolonged industry down-cycle and operational challenges.

site_title: Left-wing opposition topples Portugal government
summary: A left-wing opposition alliance in Portugal toppled the country's minority conservative government in a parliamentary vote, with the Socialist Party, Communists, and their allies rejecting the government's programme. The move brings an automatic end to Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho's government, which was sworn in just two weeks ago. The newly-formed bloc plans to reverse some cutbacks and reforms demanded by creditors, including giving back government worker pay and restoring public holidays. The vote marks the first time the three parties have put aside their differences and agreed to form a government, with President Anibal Cavaco Silva now deciding who will lead the country.

site_title: Lufthansa to cancel 930 flights on Wednesday due to strike
summary: Lufthansa will cancel 930 flights on Wednesday due to a strike by cabin crews, affecting approximately 100,000 passengers. The strike, which began last Friday, is over early retirement benefits and pensions, and the union has refused to end it despite a court ruling that it must stop at one airport. Lufthansa has offered to negotiate with the union, but only if they first end the strike. The airline has filed for temporary injunctions at labor courts, and the situation remains unresolved.

site_title: Cameron lays out demands for Britain to stay in EU
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron warned that Britain could leave the EU if its demands for reforms are not met, as he laid out his shopping list for change. Cameron's demands include slashing immigration by restricting state benefits to migrants for four years, and reforming competitiveness, fairness, and sovereignty issues. European leaders said his demands would be "difficult" to meet, and eurosceptics criticized his speech as a climbdown. A referendum on Britain's EU membership is set for 2017, and Cameron remains confident he can clinch an agreement to avert "Brexit."

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment at 6mth high in Nov: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment reached a six-month high in November, with a 3.9% seasonally adjusted increase in the Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey. The index reading of 101.7 showed optimists outnumbering pessimists and confidence in the economy over the next 5 years surged 24.2%. The Reserve Bank of Australia cited improving indicators of business and consumer confidence as a reason not to cut interest rates this month, despite news of major banks raising mortgage rates. The survey also showed a promising outlook for retailers and Christmas spending plans.

site_title: Euro hits six-month low vs US dollar
summary: The euro fell to a six-month low against the US dollar, reaching a low of US$1.0675, amid expectations of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December and speculation of further easing by the European Central Bank. Market analysts attributed the decline to dovish comments from ECB member Erkki Liikanen and investor preparations for ECB President Mario Draghi's remarks on Wednesday.

site_title: Alstom wins 3b euro Indian railway contract
summary: Alstom has won a 3-billion-euro contract to supply 800 electric locomotives to India's rail operator. The deal, worth S$4.6 billion, includes an assembly plant and two maintenance facilities in eastern Bihar state. The Indian government aims to modernize its rail network with a $137 billion investment over the next five years, with this contract seen as a key endorsement of its "Make in India" policy.

site_title: Pimco fees come under scrutiny
summary: Pimco, a US bond giant, is under scrutiny over its fees for its total return fund, which charged investors $1.1 billion last year. The fund's administrative fees, $442 million, are higher than those of competitors, sparking concerns about governance and transparency. Pimco executives argue that the fees are in line with industry standards, but critics say the cost of administrative services should not exceed investment management fees. Pimco co-founder William Gross has accused the firm's executives of enriching themselves through secret fee increases.

site_title: Japan business mood dips as economy seen in recession: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence fell in November for the third consecutive month to a level unseen in 2-1/2 years, according to a Reuters poll. The service sector also showed a decline, with sectors like retail hit by weakness in private consumption. The economy may be heading into recession, with government data expected to confirm this. Manufacturers' sentiment index fell to 3, the lowest since 2013, while the service sector index fell to 22, its lowest since March. The Bank of Japan cut its economic growth projections but held off on expanding stimulus.

site_title: Oil market ekes out gains
summary: World oil prices rose slightly on Tuesday, snapping a four-session losing streak, as traders digested a mixed outlook from the International Energy Agency. Oil prices rose 27 cents to $47.46 per barrel for Brent North Sea crude and 59 cents to $44.46 per barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate. The IEA forecast that global oil prices should recover to $80 by 2020, but trading sentiment remains bearish due to weak demand and a slowdown in China's economic growth.

site_title: European integration threatened by 'Brexit', refugee crisis: IMF
summary: The IMF's new chief economist, Maurice Obstfeld, warns that the European migrant crisis and Britain's potential exit from the EU threaten European economic integration. The refugee crisis and "Brexit" could undo economic integration, while Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron has promised a referendum on EU membership by the end of 2017.

site_title: China sees RMB as international currency by 2020
summary: China aims to make the renminbi (RMB) an international currency by 2020, according to central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan. The country plans to introduce yuan convertibility under the capital account and expand the use of the RMB at international financial hubs and in developed countries. China also wants the RMB to account for over one-third of its total cross-border payment by the end of 2020. These reforms aim to boost the development of the financial service sector and steer the economy towards a sustainable and higher value-added path of development.

site_title: Fight for Australia's Asciano intensifies with Qube's US$6.3b offer
summary: Australian stevedoring and rail giant Asciano Ltd is being aggressively pursued by Qube Holdings Ltd, which made a US$6.3 billion offer, beating a rival bid from Brookfield Asset Management. Qube, led by Chris Corrigan, has teamed up with Global Infrastructure Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) may oppose Brookfield's takeover due to its ownership of rail tracks used by Asciano's freight trains. The regulator is set to rule on Brookfield's proposal on December 17, while Qube's bid is expected to be less contentious.

site_title: New mall boosts Croesus's Q1 revenue, earnings; distributions flat
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 17.2% increase in gross revenue to 2 billion yen (S$23 million) in Q1 2015, driven by the acquisition of One's Mall in Japan and tenant renewal at Mallage Shobu. This resulted in a 10.7% increase in net property income to 1.2 billion yen. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) remained flat at 2.08 Singapore cents.

site_title: China's 2-child policy seen contributing 0.5% point to growth rate
summary: China's adoption of a two-child policy is expected to boost its economic growth rate by about 0.5 percentage point, stemming from a rise in its workforce. The policy change, announced last week, will lead to around three million extra babies born each year and increase employment in the short term. The policy aims to improve the population structure and promote balanced development, with a potential rise in the labor force of over 30 million by 2050.

site_title: EU gives Volkswagen 10 days to clarify CO2 irregularities
summary: EU regulators have given Volkswagen 10 days to clarify which nearly 1 million of its cars emit more CO2 pollution than claimed. The European Energy Commissioner has requested details on the affected models and vehicles. The move is part of a long process that could result in millions of euros in fines for the company, already embroiled in a huge pollution scandal over diesel emissions.

site_title: US, Europe: China and US rates weigh on markets
summary: Weak Chinese data fueled investor concerns about a looming US rate hike, leading to a decline in global markets. China's consumer price index reading fell to a 6-month low, while imports and exports declined sharply. The euro hit a fresh 6-month low against the dollar, and the Dow dipped 0.1% in midday trading. Analysts believe a US rate hike in December will lead to increased dollar attractiveness, while a decline in equities. European markets ended flat, with the FTSE 100 and CAC 40 experiencing little change.

site_title: GM could face punitive damage claims in ignition switch litigation
summary: A US judge has ruled that General Motors (GM) could face punitive damage claims in lawsuits over the 2014 ignition switch recall, which led to millions of vehicles being recalled. The decision, made by bankruptcy judge Robert Gerber, leaves GM potentially liable for punitive damages stemming from injuries, deaths, or loss of vehicle value. However, the ruling restricts punitive damages to be based on New GM's knowledge or conduct, rather than pre-bankruptcy Old GM's actions. This decision could increase GM's financial exposure to claims.

site_title: Campbell rethinks its recipe as consumer tastes change
summary: Campbell Soup is rethinking its iconic chicken noodle soup recipe to cater to changing consumer tastes, with the new version containing 20 ingredients found in most home kitchens. The company aims to close the gap between its plants and the kitchen, reflecting shifting consumer preferences and demographics. Despite the risk of altering a beloved product, Campbell seeks to boost anaemic soup sales, which have stagnated since 2012, with global sales projected to fall further this year. The company is also shifting its advertising budget to social media and digital advertising, highlighting its efforts to connect with consumers.

site_title: Greece plans bond market return in second half of 2016
summary: Greece plans to return to bond markets in the second half of 2016, according to Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos. The country has not issued debt to private investors since July 2014, following a tense bailout negotiation with international creditors. Tsakalotos met with hedge funds to discuss a possible return, citing concerns from investors about Grexit and the effectiveness of the bailout program. Greece's creditors have promised debt relief if the country complies with bailout terms, which could include a 15-20 year grace period on debt payments.

images.alt_text: Greece plans to return to bond markets in the second half of next year, its finance minister Euclid Tsakalotos told Reuters on Tuesday.

site_title: IMF says risks higher in an early Fed rate hike
summary: The International Monetary Fund's chief economist, Maurice Obstfeld, states that an early interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve would involve higher risks than waiting, citing concerns over market interpretation and potential economic instability. Obstfeld suggests the Fed could delay the rate hike, citing ongoing economic uncertainty and the need for continued policy options.

images.alt_text: Maurice Obstfeld, Economic Counsellor and Director, Research Department of IMF delivers the International Monetary Fund's media briefing on the world economic outlook during its annual meeting in Lima, Peru on Oct 6, 2015.

site_title: Import prices dip 0.5% in Oct on lower oil costs, strong US$
summary: US import prices fell 0.5% in October due to lower oil costs and a strong dollar, marking the 14th consecutive month of decline. This drop in import prices is attributed to soft global demand and the Federal Reserve's inflation target of 2%. Despite weak inflation pressures, the US central bank is expected to raise interest rates next month due to strong job growth and a low unemployment rate. The dollar rose to a fresh seven-month high against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Google Maps guides travellers offline
summary: Google has updated its Google Maps application to provide offline navigation for Android-powered smartphones, allowing users to download areas of the world for viewing and turn-by-turn directions without internet connectivity. The feature, which was previewed at a conference earlier this year, is expected to be available for Apple devices soon. The update aims to help people in areas with limited internet coverage, with approximately 60% of the world still lacking connectivity.

site_title: US dollar rally is back and now it has the bond market behind it
summary: The US dollar has reached a six-month high against the euro, driven by a surge in two-year dollar interest-rate swaps that surpassed those in the eurozone for the first time since 2007. This marks a significant reversal of fortunes for the dollar, which had stalled in March after interest-rate swap differentials collapsed. The dollar's rally has now gained support from the bond market, indicating a shift in investor sentiment. This development could have implications for global markets and economies.

site_title: No tough rules for foreign bank card firms: PBOC
summary: China's central bank, PBOC, will not impose strict licensing requirements on foreign bank card firms entering the country's $7 trillion card payment market. Industry sources had expressed concerns about joint venture requirements, but a senior official stated that no such restrictions will be enforced. This move is seen as a boost to foreign banks looking to tap into China's growing card payment market.

site_title: Four indicted in massive hack of JP Morgan Chase, others
summary: Four individuals, including Israeli nationals Gery Shalon and Ziv Orenstein, and US citizen Joshua Samuel Aaron, have been indicted in a massive hacking scheme that compromised data from JPMorgan Chase and other firms, affecting 76 million household customers and 7 million businesses. The scheme allegedly stole over 100 million customers' personal information and generated hundreds of millions of dollars in illegal proceeds. The indictment alleges the hackers operated a "diversified criminal conglomerate" that hacked into at least a dozen firms, including banks and brokerages, to support their illicit activities.

site_title: US sues to block United, Delta slots deal at New Jersey airport
summary: The US Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit to block United Airlines' acquisition of 24 slots at Newark Liberty airport in New Jersey, where the airline already controls 73% of available slots. The DOJ alleges that this deal would reduce competition, leading to higher fares and fewer flight options for consumers. The lawsuit targets United's planned purchase of slots from Delta Air Lines, which would further concentrate market power at the airport.

site_title: If you want to learn about gold prices, speak to an Indian farmer
summary: India's gold demand has weakened due to a drought caused by El Nino weather patterns, reducing farm output and incomes. As a result, dealers are offering deep discounts on gold, with kilogramme bars being sold at a discount to the London spot market of $4 to $11. This is the largest discounts in decades, potentially worsening the environment for international gold prices, which are already headed for the longest annual decline in the 21st century.

site_title: Seizing opportunities for PE in emerging Asia
summary: Private equity (PE) firms are capitalizing on emerging Asia's growth, with over half of investors planning to allocate or expand funds in the region over the next two years. Despite challenges in less-transparent economies, local PE firms with significant local track records are better equipped to succeed. However, foreign PE firms with global resources and reputations often outperform local firms, particularly when exiting investments to global buyers. Local firms may prefer syndication arrangements to invest in large markets, while global firms may prioritize localisation in smaller markets.

site_title: Worker who'd never quit, or be fired
summary: A healthcare company, Adventist Health-Care, used an algorithm to predict and prevent employee turnover, resulting in a 30-50% reduction in turnover and significant cost savings. The algorithm, developed by Pegged, analyzed data from job applicants, including keystrokes, browser behavior, and background information, to identify those most likely to succeed in a role. Pegged claims its median impact is reducing turnover 38% over a six to 12-month period, with some clients reporting reductions of up to 60%. The algorithm's success has been tested at 310 facilities, with no failures in improving retention.

site_title: China's north-east in search of new growth model
summary: China's north-east region, particularly Heilongjiang province, is struggling to adapt to the "new norm" of value-added growth, with the local governments heavily in debt and facing declining GDP. The region's traditional industries, such as heavy and military manufacturing, have declined, and state-owned enterprises have failed to transition to capitalist structures. The Chinese government has launched infrastructure projects to support growth, but experts suggest solutions such as agriculture and trans-border trade may be more effective. The region's population has been declining, with many young and qualified workers leaving in search of better opportunities elsewhere.

site_title: GE clinches US$2.6b Indian railway contract
summary: GE wins a US$2.6 billion contract to supply 1,000 diesel locomotives to India's railways, marking the largest foreign investment in the sector since India's 100% foreign direct investment policy was implemented last year. The US company will also invest US$200 million in local manufacturing and service facilities, with plans to build a facility in Bihar and maintain two sheds nationwide over an 11-year period. The deal is part of India's US$137 billion modernization program, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government aiming to upgrade the country's creaking infrastructure.

site_title: Rising cost, regional rivals weaken Singapore's medical tourism appeal
summary: Singapore's medical tourism industry is facing challenges due to rising costs and increased competition from regional rivals. Despite new markets emerging, the decline in traditional markets such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Brunei is not being offset. Industry observers report a drop in medical tourists, with some seeing a decline for several years. The sector's appeal is being eroded, putting Singapore's position as a leading medical tourism hub in South-east Asia at risk.

images.alt_text: The Raffles Hospital logo, operated by Raffles Medical Group Ltd., is displayed on the exterior of a hospital building in Singapore, in this 2002 handout photograph released to the media on Jul 5, 2013.

site_title: Google seeks to influence AI research by giving software away
summary: Google is releasing its internal AI development software, TensorFlow, as free and open-source software. This move aims to influence AI research and make the software available to researchers, potentially attracting talent. TensorFlow is based on Google's internal system and is used in its AI-powered products, including Google Now and RankBrain. The release of TensorFlow is part of Google's efforts to be more open and guide AI development, similar to other companies like Facebook and Microsoft.

images.alt_text: By releasing TensorFlow, Google aims to make the software it built to develop and run its own AI systems a part of the standard toolset used by researchers, according to a spokesman.

site_title: Lufthansa union rejects latest pay offer as strike continues
summary: The Lufthansa cabin crew union, UFO, rejected the airline's latest pay offer of 3,000 euros per person, leading to the longest strike in the carrier's history. The strike, which began on Monday, has resulted in 929 cancellations and 1,700 flights scrapped since Friday. The union is seeking changes to retirement benefits, and the airline is pushing for restructuring plans to compete with low-cost carriers. The strike is expected to continue until November 13, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: Singtel wins EPL rights for 2016-19
summary: Singtel has secured the rights to broadcast English Premier League (EPL) matches in Singapore for the 2016-2019 seasons, outbidding rival StarHub. This is the telco's second consecutive win of EPL broadcast rights, following Optus' Australian rights win earlier in the week.

site_title: Gadget-hungry China to boost 'lifestyle' metals: PwC
summary: China's growing middle class is expected to drive long-term demand for "lifestyle" metals such as copper, zinc, and nickel, with urbanization and consumer-driven growth poised to increase the need for these metals. China's urban population is expected to increase by 170 million in the next decade, with demand for metals also driven by emerging economies and the global middle class. Copper and nickel are likely to be the first commodities to emerge from the current rout, with producers positioning to meet demand and swoop on distressed assets.

site_title: Enhancing capabilities and processes
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-based global leader in marine and offshore engineering, has established Semb-Eco R&D Pte Ltd to develop green products and systems for the marine, offshore, and onshore industries. The company aims to strengthen its industry leadership through innovative technological and engineering solutions. In partnership with Ecospec Global Technology, Sembcorp Marine has developed gas scrubbers and ballast water treatment systems to meet maritime and governmental regulatory requirements. The company has also partnered with Nanyang Technological University to focus on research on eco-friendly solutions and emission control technologies.

site_title: Raising the productivity sales pitch, on the ground
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam is emphasizing the need for innovation and efficiency in Singapore's economy, particularly in the domestic services sector. He has been visiting businesses, highlighting the benefits of implementing productivity-enhancing practices, such as automation and centralization. The government is also providing targeted support for companies, rather than broad-based solutions, to encourage innovation and competitiveness. Examples include a centralized dishwashing facility and supermarket chains adopting efficiency-boosting practices.

images.alt_text: Singapore's first on-site centralised dishwashing facility at IMM Building which he visited this week.
Mr Tharman making a sweet treat jalebi at the Asian Culinary Institute of Singapore last month.

site_title: China October data points to persisting deflationary pressure
summary: China's October inflation data showed deflationary pressure persisting, with a 1.3% year-over-year increase, lower than the 1.6% rise in September. Analysts expect further stimulus measures to stimulate the slowing economy, with some predicting rate cuts and others suggesting greater fiscal outlays. The data suggests China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to take action.

images.alt_text: Although consumer price inflation in China is highly seasonal due to the outsize index weight of food prices, economists also highlighted weakening sequential momentum as a concern.

site_title: Modi visit will boost UK-India political and economic ties
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 2-day visit to the UK from November 12-14 aims to strengthen bilateral ties, with a focus on economic cooperation and trade. The trip is the first by an Indian premier in a decade, following visits by other world leaders. Modi will meet with UK Prime Minister David Cameron, Queen Elizabeth II, and attend high-level meetings, including a visit to Parliament and a reception for the Indian diaspora at Wembley stadium. The visit is expected to unveil $15 billion in trade and investment deals, with a focus on defence manufacturing, infrastructure development, and digital initiatives.

site_title: Fears of a China meltdown overblown
summary: China's recent sell-off in its asset market has been exaggerated, and fears of a meltdown are unfounded. The correction reflects economic rebalancing and liberalization rather than weak fundamentals. China's foreign exchange reserves are sufficient to cover two years of imports, and its short-term foreign debt is manageable. The banking sector's balance sheet has improved, and the risk of a banking crisis is within limits. A property market correction has not led to a collapse in property prices, and capital flight is unlikely due to China's closed capital account and implicit guarantee policy.

site_title: Myanmar's election went 'better than expected', says EU observer
summary: Myanmar's historic election has been deemed "better than expected" by the European Union's chief election observer, Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, with only a few instances of voter irregularities. The National League for Democracy (NLD) led by Aung San Suu Kyi appears poised for a landslide victory, winning 88% of declared seats in the lower house and 29 in the upper chamber. However, concerns remain about a lack of transparency regarding advance voting and the need for reforms to improve democracy and inclusivity, particularly for stateless Muslims.

site_title: VW giving US$1,000 to car owners in emissions-cheating scandal
summary: Volkswagen is offering US$1,000 to affected car owners in the emissions scandal, along with no-interest loans to 650 dealerships stuck with unsellable cars. The company is also providing cash and dealership credits to owners of diesel-powered cars with 2.0-litre engines under investigation. VW is encouraging dealers to offer pre-scandal prices on trade-ins and promising to make up the difference in value. The company has responded with extra incentives for both dealers and consumers for gasoline-powered 2016 models, with discounts averaging US$4,192.

site_title: Oil-price crash brings towering woes in Canada
summary: Canada's office-tower owners face significant challenges due to the oil-price crash, with vacancy rates at a five-year high and rents at the lowest since 2006. Thousands of office jobs were cut, and energy company tenants are seeking rental relief and offering subleases at significantly reduced rates. Five new office towers are set to hit the market in the next three years, exacerbating the problem. Landlords are struggling, with shares of key players dropping 27% to 14% over the past year.
