Subleasing is becoming a key strategy to mitigate losses, but at a significant cost to landlords.

site_title: China's big banks have longest road to meet loss-absorbing needs
summary: China's four major banks, including Agricultural Bank of China and Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, have a 9-year extension to meet the Financial Stability Board's loss-absorbing requirements, until 2025 and 2028. The banks must issue 269 billion euros of eligible securities to meet the 16% and 18% targets. The extension acknowledges the challenge for deposit-funded lenders, which have huge deposit bases and don't need to carry the same levels of senior debt as global peers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: STATS ChipPAC plans to issue new senior secured notes via a private placement to repay outstanding debt. The debt was provisionally rated B1 by Moody's. Li Heng Chemical Fibre Technologies reported a 25.6 million yuan net loss for the three months ended Sept 30, 2015, with revenue down 28%. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada, and Singapore stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Food, nutrition security in India, China vital
summary: Global food and nutrition security is crucial for countries to reach their full potential. India and China face significant challenges, with India having 194.5 million malnourished people and China reducing malnourished people from 289 million to 133.8 million. Obesity is also a growing problem, with twice as many obese people in developing countries as in developed ones. Proper policies, strong will, and advances in science and technology are needed to address these issues, which are linked to poverty, poor farming yields, and inadequate dietary intake.

site_title: US activist investors get a welcome seat at the table
summary: US activist investors have gained more influence in corporate America, adopting methods from activist hedge funds. Companies are now hiring lawyers, investment banks, and consultants to defend against activist attacks, and some are even hiring activist investors as consultants. The number of companies targeted by activists has increased, with 459 companies targeted last year. Activists have also shifted their tone, focusing on constructive dialogue and collaboration with management. The prevalence of activist investors has led to a decrease in contentious battles, with companies settling with activists in an average of 56 days.

site_title: The Hour Glass donates S$5m to NKF, ComChest, NHB
summary: Luxury watch retailer The Hour Glass has donated S$5 million to the National Kidney Foundation, Community Chest, and the National Heritage Board. This is the company's largest donation to date. The Hour Glass recorded a net profit of S$58 million in its latest financial year, with revenue reaching S$741 million.

site_title: Top Shanghai official probed for 'severe disciplinary violations'
summary: A director of China's first free trade zone in Shanghai, Ai Baojun, 55, has been put under investigation for "severe disciplinary violations", a phrase typically referring to corruption. Ai, a vice-mayor, has been director of the Shanghai FTZ since 2013 and has also headed the management committee for the Shanghai International Tourism and Resorts Zone, where a Disney theme park is scheduled to open. This is the highest-level Shanghai official to be formally investigated since Xi Jinping took power in 2012, and authorities have vowed to target corruption in the city.

site_title: US banks rewrite contracts to shed too-big-to-fail image
summary: US banks are rewriting financial contracts worth trillions of dollars to shed the "too-big-to-fail" image. The changes, expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, will allow certain securities and funding contracts to remain intact for up to 48 hours after a bank fails. This move aims to persuade regulators that giant banks can be wound down without harming the broader economy, thereby reducing the risk of systemic failures. The revised contracts are part of a broader effort to modernize the global financial system.

site_title: ABS works locally to develop global solutions
summary: The American Bureau of Shipping's (ABS) Singapore Innovation and Research Center (SIRC) is a leading research and development hub, focusing on maritime innovation and sustainability. With 20 full-time researchers, including 11 PhDs, SIRC partners with local industry, government, and academia to develop global solutions. The center has collaborated with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) on various projects, including sustainable shipping, offshore engineering technologies, and liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering. ABS aims to improve the competence of local industry while developing global solutions, with a focus on environmental protection and marine safety.

site_title: India announces plans to open up foreign investment
summary: India's government announced plans to liberalize its foreign direct investment (FDI) regime, aiming to make it easier for overseas companies to do business in the country. The reforms, which include lifting caps on FDI in defense, banking, and construction sectors, are intended to boost investment and create jobs. The move comes after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party suffered losses in state elections, and ahead of his visit to Britain seeking investment. The reforms are expected to further open up sectors for foreign investment, following the country's 7% growth rate.

site_title: Japan's six-month current account surplus quadruples
summary: Japan's current account surplus quadrupled to 8.7 trillion yen ($100.4 billion) in the six months to September, driven by improving trade and investments abroad. The surplus, the 15th consecutive year-on-year gain, was fueled by a slump in energy imports and declining energy prices. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies have achieved mixed results, but the improving trade picture and sustained returns on foreign investments are expected to continue supporting the current account surplus.

site_title: US$ climbs towards 7-month high
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% to a seven-month peak against a basket of major currencies, driven by expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. The dollar index reached 99.072, and the euro traded at $1.0750, near its seven-month low. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to the widening spread between US and German bond yields, which could put the euro on the defensive. In contrast, the Fed is expected to raise interest rates in December, while the European Central Bank is considered likely to lower rates.

site_title: Local companies should remain core as SGX chases global listings
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye aims to attract more consumer and digital tech companies to list on the exchange, seeking to bring trading excitement back to the market. Consumer staples companies and tech firms have shown promise, while traditional sectors like offshore and marine services have struggled. Meanwhile, local companies like Sheng Siong and PSA International can still be listed, catering to local investors and reducing home bias. SGX seeks a balanced approach, recognizing the importance of catering to diverse constituencies to survive.

site_title: UOB's medium-risk fund doubles assets in 3 months to S$2.2b
summary: UOB's Income Builder fund, a medium-risk unit trust, has doubled its assets to S$2.2 billion in three months. The fund, which invests in three other funds, aims to balance risk and return. With the US economy expected to recover and interest rates to increase, returns are expected to rise to 7-8%. The fund's manager, Dennis Khoo, attributes the fund's performance to its volatility-controlled approach and use of derivatives to hedge out risks. Khoo also emphasized the need for investors to adopt a long-term perspective, rather than focusing on short-term gains.

site_title: Xi-Ma meeting sets precedent for a meeting of equals
summary: Xi Jinping and Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou held a historic meeting, marking the first time a mainland Chinese leader met with a Taiwanese leader. The handshake lasted over a minute, symbolizing a strong gesture of friendship. The leaders emphasized their shared Chinese heritage, calling for cooperation and rejuvenation of the Chinese nation. The meeting set a precedent for a meeting of equals, marking a significant shift in China's relations with Taiwan.

site_title: Mixed reaction to UK's negotiating proposals to EU
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has submitted negotiating proposals to the European Union, aiming to protect the single market, reduce excessive regulation, and limit free movement of labour. The proposals include a four-year ban on EU citizens accessing welfare benefits in the UK and a voluntary banking union. The EU has mixed reactions to the proposals, with some leaders expressing support and others raising concerns about their legality. Bilateral negotiations are set to begin next week, with the goal of securing reforms at a December EU meeting.

images.alt_text: A key objective at the heart of Mr Cameron's negotiations is to protect the single market for the UK and other non-euro states.

site_title: Brooklyn's tallest building planned as office demand rises
summary: New York City officials announced plans for a 600-foot office tower in Brooklyn, potentially the borough's tallest building. Developed by JEMB Realty, the $300 million project will span 400,000 square feet at 420 Albee Square. The development comes as office demand rises, with officials citing the growing need for office space in the area. The project's completion is expected to meet the increasing demand for office space in downtown Brooklyn.

site_title: Eurozone yields fall as ECB rate-cut talk grows
summary: Eurozone government bond yields fell as expectations grew that the European Central Bank (ECB) will cut its deposit rate next month. Markets anticipate a deeper cut than the 10 basis points currently expected. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to hike rates. This shift in interest rates has led to a decline in yields across the Eurozone, indicating a decrease in borrowing costs.

site_title: Let normalcy resume: Fed must lead
summary: The US Federal Reserve should raise interest rates at its next policy meeting on December 15-16 to signal the end of the economic recovery and maintain stability in financial markets. The Fed's recent job creation data confirms the US economy is nearing its normal equilibrium with unemployment at 5% and inflation at 2%. Central banks worldwide should rethink their target inflation rate and focus on the real interest rate, as prolonged easy monetary policies can be destabilizing. The global economy is in a long downward phase, but a change in inflation rates could signal a profound shift.

site_title: Ken Dart reinvents himself as land baron
summary: Billionaire investor Ken Dart is shifting his focus from distressed foreign debt to luxury real-estate development, particularly in the Cayman Islands and Latin America. His Cayman-based holding company, Dart Enterprises, now owns over 8% of the islands, with a portfolio including upscale Camana Bay, a residential development, marina, and town centre. Dart has also invested in countries such as Turks and Caicos, the Bahamas, and numerous others, with a focus on conservation efforts. His real-estate activities have boosted the local economy, but have also raised concerns about his influence and tax practices.

site_title: Petroleum, strong dollar depress US import prices
summary: US import prices fell 0.5% in October, the 14th consecutive month of decline, as a strong dollar and soft global demand pressured inflation. This drop, 0.1% less than forecast, brings 12-month import prices down 10.5%. Despite weak inflation, the US central bank is likely to raise interest rates next month due to a tightening labor market and low unemployment rate.

site_title: Time to open up buying-in market
summary: A proposal to allow buying-in of shorted securities from the ready market for delivery one day after T+4 has been met with concerns over settlement uncertainty and the orderly clearing system. Experts urge the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to review the current buying-in market structure and consider opening it up to retail investors. A two-hour buying-in market opening is deemed inadequate, and experts propose opening it concurrently with the ready market and allowing sell orders to add dynamism, increasing liquidity and preventing failed deliveries. This could enhance transparency and boost market liquidity and trading volumes.

site_title: US: Wall St dips as Apple adds to fears of weakening demand
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, led by a decline in Apple shares after Credit Suisse reported a 10% reduction in iPhone component orders. This added to concerns about global growth, particularly in China, ahead of the holiday shopping season. China's October inflation data showed persisting deflationary pressure, following disappointing trade data. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.73 points, or 0.16%, to 17,701.75, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes also declined.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC plans to borrow from private placement
summary: STATS ChipPAC plans to borrow from a private placement to repay outstanding debt, including a US$890 million bridge loan. The company intends to use the funds to repay its debt. STATS ChipPAC was taken private by Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co in a recent deal. The company's plan is subject to market conditions and other factors.

site_title: Pouring camaraderie with free tea to passers-by
summary: A man named Giuseppe Spadafora has been operating a "mobile teahouse" in a converted bus, offering free tea to passersby in various cities, including New York, as part of a social experiment called the Free Tea Party. Since 2006, Spadafora has traveled the country, serving over 30,000 cups of tea and engaging in conversations with strangers, aiming to challenge traditional notions of self-interest and promote trust, collaboration, and reciprocal altruism.

site_title: Google seeks developers in the desert at Dubai hub
summary: Google has launched AstroLabs, a tech hub in Dubai, aimed at supporting startups in the Middle East. The hub, backed by Google, provides a space for 42 startups to access resources such as workspace, mentorship, and access to Google's device lab. The goal is to create homegrown businesses that can target customers globally, addressing the region's lack of innovation and entrepreneurship. AstroLabs is part of Google's efforts to support startups in the Middle East and North Africa, with the aim of removing barriers to entry and fostering economic growth.

site_title: Digital money the way forward, says Citi official
summary: Citibank's head of global head of Treasury and Trade Solutions, Naveed Sultan, emphasizes the need for digital money to transform the physical instruments into pure digital forms, enabling fund transfers through digital channels. A Citi study, Digital Money Index, found that digitizing global money flows can boost economies significantly, with a 10% increase in digital readiness in 90 countries resulting in 220 million new entrants to the financial system and $1 trillion moving into the formal economy. To make Bitcoin technology mainstream, the industry needs to develop common standards, and Citi has been exploring distributed ledger technology and has established innovation labs in Singapore to test digital money solutions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia will diversify oil economy to slow climate change
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to diversify its economy to combat climate change, aiming to reduce carbon emissions by up to 130 million tonnes a year by 2030. The move, submitted to the UN before a Paris summit, includes investments in lower-emission sectors, energy efficiency, and renewable energy, such as solar, wind, and geothermal power. The kingdom also aims to capture and use 1,500 tonnes of carbon dioxide daily, and encourages investments in natural gas to adapt to climate change.

site_title: Li Heng reports S$5.7m Q3 loss on soft China economy
summary: Li Heng Chemical Fibre Technologies reported a net loss of S$5.7 million for Q3 2015, down from a profit of S$2.6 million the previous year. Revenue declined 28% to S$442.8 million due to a soft Chinese economy and overseas markets. The company attributed the decline to lower average selling prices and sales volume.

site_title: ECB faces 3 lawsuits over QE in Germany's top court
summary: German politicians have filed three lawsuits against the European Central Bank (ECB) over its 1.1 trillion euro asset purchase program, challenging the policy in Germany's top court. The lawsuits were filed by politicians who previously failed to have the ECB's monetary policy overturned. The main goal of spurring inflation remains elusive, with price increases still absent from the euro region. The ECB has held out the prospect of more stimulus in December, amid a slowdown in global trade and economic growth.

site_title: NTU researchers optimising container placement on ships
summary: Researchers at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore have developed an optimized system, iStow, to streamline container placement on ships, reducing planning time from hours to minutes. The system integrates container stowage planning with ship stability and safety, cutting manual allocation time by up to 3%. The tool has been awarded a follow-up project to scale up for larger vessels, offering competitive advantages to shipping lines by minimizing fuel consumption and reducing CO2 emissions. The system aims to automate routine tasks, freeing human planners to focus on high-value services.

site_title: Europe: shares open higher
summary: European shares rose 0.28-0.35% on Tuesday, driven by Vodafone's 2.7% gain after a strong earnings report. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index and euro zone's Euro STOXX 50 index also increased. Despite this, Portuguese stocks were weighed down by political uncertainty.

site_title: Consumer staples, banks did well in Q3 amid broad slowdown
summary: Singapore companies reported mixed Q3 results, with consumer staples and banks performing well, while industrials and discretionary consumer companies were hit hard. Profits declined by 6% for 145 listed companies, with 56 reporting higher profits and 50 lower. Analysts warn of further earnings downgrades, citing a broad slowdown and signs of a depressed global economy. Key sectors, such as telcos and Reits, reported steady results, while companies like Singapore Airlines and Hyflux disappointed with falling margins and core operating losses.

site_title: Bunker industry ponders global sulphur cap
summary: The International Bunker Industry Association (IBIA) Convention in Cancun, Mexico, discussed the impending global sulfur cap of 0.5% in 2020 or 2025, potentially leading to a shortage of distillate fuel. Delegates generally believed the cap would come into effect in 2020, with a straw poll showing 80% of attendees thought the cap would not be delayed. Industry experts also discussed the importance of fuel quality and quantity, with Singapore seen as a leader in promoting transparency through the use of mass flow meters. Despite concerns over the impact of the sulfur cap, experts noted that residual fuels are unlikely to disappear, with advances in scrubbers and fuel treatment technologies offering alternatives.

site_title: Singtel secures Barclays Premier League broadcast rights for 3 more seasons
summary: Singtel secures Barclays Premier League broadcast rights for three seasons starting August 2016, with matches available on Singtel TV and its app Singtel TV Go. This deal is expected to benefit sports fans in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: shares close lower on Fed, global growth concerns
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 1.4% to 22,401.70, mirroring lower regional markets due to US interest rate concerns and slowing global growth. The China Enterprises Index fell 1.8% to 10,314.74 points. Total trading volume was 1.9 billion shares.

site_title: India announces plans to open up foreign investment
summary: India's government announced plans to liberalize its foreign direct investment (FDI) regime, aiming to counter accusations that Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reform drive is stalling. The government will open up 15 areas of the economy, including defence, banking, and construction sectors, by lifting caps on FDI. This move is expected to attract more foreign investment and boost economic growth.

site_title: Hour Glass donates S$5m to NKF, ComChest, NHB
summary: Luxury watch retailer The Hour Glass has donated a total of S$5 million to the National Kidney Foundation, Community Chest, and the National Heritage Board. The donations, which include a Patek Philippe table clock, will be matched by the government, resulting in a total of S$10 million. The funds will support underprivileged Singaporeans with healthcare needs, elderly activities, and cultural heritage development. The donations are the company's largest to date and reflect its commitment to philanthropy, which it has held since its founding in 1979.

site_title: SunMoon shares resume trading on Wednesday
summary: SunMoon Food Company will resume trading on Wednesday after a month-long halt. The company reached an agreement with major shareholder First Alverstone Capital, which will sell 14 million shares, reducing its stake from 29.7% to 25.3%. Discussions with the Securities Industry Council (SIC) concluded, and no further actions are required. The halt was due to concerns over a few transactions made by First Alverstone that increased its stake in September.

site_title: Opec chief sees oil market balanced by 2016 on demand growth
summary: Opec Secretary General Abdalla El-Badri predicts the oil market will balance by 2016 due to growing demand, which is expected to rise by 17 million barrels a day to 110 million barrels a day by 2040, primarily driven by Asian growth. Despite Iran's plans to increase output, the market is expected to rebalance in 2016 as global demand grows 1.2-1.5 million barrels a day through 2020, leading to less non-Opec supply and a reduction in oversupply.

site_title: World energy use to grow one-third over 25 years, renewables making inroads: IEA
summary: Global energy use is expected to grow by one-third over the next 25 years, driven by emerging economies such as India, China, Africa, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia. Energy consumption in developed nations is forecast to decline during the same period. The International Energy Agency attributes the growth to increasing energy demands in these regions, with renewables making significant inroads.

site_title: For a happier life, give up Facebook: study
summary: A study by the Happiness Research Institute found that people who abstained from Facebook for a week reported higher levels of satisfaction and happiness, with 88% describing themselves as "happy" compared to 81% of those who continued using the social network. The study also found that Facebook users were 39% more likely to feel less happy than non-users, with those who abstained experiencing a richer social life and improved concentration.

site_title: Rising food prices to hit rural India in 2016
summary: India's rural areas are expected to face a sharp spike in food prices in 2016 due to a second consecutive drought, which will drive up costs of ingredients like sugar and milk. Poor transport infrastructure and a lack of storage facilities for perishable goods will exacerbate the issue. As a result, rural inflation is likely to worsen, making it challenging for the central bank to achieve its 4% inflation target. The government's subsidy regime is also under pressure, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi trying to prune it amid a bruising electoral defeat in Bihar.

site_title: China Oct inflation moderates; producer prices fall for 44th month
summary: China's consumer inflation rose 1.3% in October, moderating from a 1.6% increase in September, while producer prices fell 5.9% for the 44th consecutive month. The decline in commodity prices and weak demand are contributing to deflationary pressure. The producer price index (PPI) drop was slightly more than economists' forecasts of a 5.8% decline. This moderation in inflation and producer prices suggests China's economy may slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indian firms struggle to escape debt burden as profit slows
summary: Indian companies' core profit growth has slowed down to 9.4% in the latest quarter, the lowest since 2013, as they struggle to cut debt. With a majority of companies already reporting financial results, their collective debt has reached over $640 billion, or 40% of India's GDP. Companies are prioritizing debt repayment over spending, with two-thirds of operating profit being used to service interest costs. The slowing profit growth is expected to weigh on economic growth, with the government now stepping up to fill the private sector's investment gap.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment improves in October
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index rose to 48.2 in October, a Cabinet Office survey showed. The confidence in current economic conditions increased from 47.5 in September, while the outlook index remained unchanged at 49.1. This marks the first improvement in the sector's sentiment since July. The data is based on a survey of workers closely tied to consumer trends, providing insights into the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Uber signs US$14m car rental deal with South Africa's WesBank
summary: Uber has signed a $14 million car rental deal with South Africa's WesBank to rent cars to drivers who cannot afford to buy them. The deal, valued at 200 million rand, will provide financing options for drivers with poor credit history. WesBank will recoup the loan from Uber drivers' fares, reducing default risk. The partnership aims to educate drivers on running a business and provide financing for 1,000 cars. This deal is part of Uber's efforts to expand its services in South Africa, where it has clocked 2 million rides in the first six months of 2015.

site_title: Real-world 'Indiana Jones' wins coveted TED prize
summary: Archaeologist Sarah Parcak, known as a modern-day "Indiana Jones," won a $1 million TED Prize for her work tracking antiquities and fighting looting. She uses satellite imagery to map and protect archaeological sites, particularly in the Middle East. Parcak plans to use the prize to rally the world to find and protect treasures, following a four-and-a-half-year period of extensive looting and destruction. The TED Prize is awarded to individuals who make significant contributions to their field, and Parcak's work aims to make ancient history visible using 21st-century technology.

site_title: China: Stocks turn higher as securities firms extend rally, HK down
summary: China stocks rose 0.7% and 0.4% midday, driven by a rebound in financials and comments from policy makers on broader financial reforms. Analysts attributed the rally to a strengthening trend in securities brokerages. China aims to achieve 7% economic growth in 2015 and strengthen financial supervision. Hong Kong stocks fell 1.2% amid concerns over higher US borrowing costs and global growth.

site_title: South Korea's Jeju island to get new airport as visitors surge
summary: South Korea plans to build a $3.5 billion second airport on Jeju Island to handle the surge in passengers, primarily Chinese tourists, which increased by 58% last year. The one-runway airport, scheduled for completion by 2025, aims to alleviate congestion at the current Jeju International Airport, which processed 23.2 million passengers in 2015. The new airport will be built on the eastern part of the island, taking advantage of its visa-free status for Chinese tourists and convenient flight connections from Shanghai and Beijing.

site_title: Petrobras says Brazil strike cut oil output 115,000 barrels/day
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras reported a 115,000 barrel/day reduction in oil output due to a weeklong strike, accounting for 5.5% of its pre-strike production. The strike, which began on November 1, involved labor demands to restore cut investments and end asset sales to pay off its $130 billion debt. Despite negotiations, no agreement was reached between Petrobras and the two main oil union federations.

site_title: China to push alternative trade pact at Apec
summary: China plans to promote its Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) at the upcoming Apec summit in the Philippines, aiming to establish the world's largest free trade area. The move comes after the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal was released, excluding China. China's vice finance minister Wang Shouwen said the FTAAP would be a facilitator for regional integration in APEC and would be completed with a roadmap by next year. The FTAAP has been a long-standing proposal by Apec, first proposed in 2006, as a hedge against the US-led TPP.

site_title: China: Stocks down after inflation data
summary: China's Shanghai stocks fell 0.18% on Tuesday, following a disappointing inflation reading and weaker-than-expected trade data over the weekend. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.82%. The decline adds to concerns about China's economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on weak yen, bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks ended in positive territory on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.15% to 19,671.26, despite early losses. Late bargain-hunting and a weak yen erased selling pressure, while a stronger dollar helped exporters. Japan's current account surplus more than quadrupled in the six months to September, thanks to an improving trade picture. Market participants forecast further gains in Japanese stocks, with a short-term target of 20,000 in the Nikkei index now within sight.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia: Markets closed
summary: Financial markets in Malaysia and Singapore are closed on Tuesday for public holidays. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) is up 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt dies at 96
summary: Former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who led the country from 1974 to 1982, has died at 96, according to his office in Hamburg. Schmidt, a centre-left Social Democrat, was a key proponent of European integration and led West Germany through the height of the Cold War. His death comes two months after he caught an infection following surgery to remove a blood clot from his leg.

site_title: China central bank chief sees yuan as global currency by 2020 on deepening reforms
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan announced plans to deliver economic and financial reforms over the next five years, aiming for the yuan to become a global currency by 2020. The reforms will include improving central bank communications, guiding market expectations, and strengthening supervision of the financial system to prevent systemic risk. Zhou also pledged to foster financial liberalization and development, and enhance the efficiency of the financial system to serve the real economy. The move comes amid growing doubts about China's commitment to comprehensive financial reforms following recent market interventions.

images.alt_text: Zhou Xiaochuan, governor of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), attends a news conference in Beijing, China, on Thursday, Mar 12, 2015.

site_title: China major cities' October land revenues rise 24% y-o-y
summary: China's 10 major cities saw a 24% increase in land revenues in October, a year-over-year rise, but a 17.9% decline in the first 10 months. This suggests early signs of price stabilization in the property market. Despite this, land revenues are still down due to a cooldown in the housing market. Analysts predict a slow turnaround, citing a huge overhang of unsold homes discouraging new construction and investment.

site_title: Update: Asia: Shares at 1-month low on Fed, global growth concerns
summary: Asian shares fell to a one-month low on Tuesday due to concerns over higher US borrowing costs and slower global economic growth. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in December, prompting investors to trim their exposure to riskier assets. Disappointing Chinese trade figures and a report from the OECD that global trade flows are near levels associated with a global recession also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi set for sweeping power as election wins mount
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) has won a landslide victory in the country's general election, taking control of most regional assemblies and forming the next government. The NLD secured 49 of 54 seats in the lower house of parliament, enough to form Myanmar's first democratically elected government since the early 1960s. Suu Kyi's party also won 97 of 107 seats in local legislatures, handing the ruling Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) a significant defeat. The military's influence remains, but Suu Kyi is expected to wield significant power as the real force behind the new government.

site_title: Police freeze shares held by mother of China hedge fund boss Xu
summary: Chinese police have frozen over $670 million of shares owned by Zheng Suzhen, the mother of Xu Xiang, a Shanghai hedge fund boss under investigation for alleged insider trading and stock manipulation. Xu, known as "hedge fund brother No 1," was detained on November 1 and his mother's shares in two companies were frozen on Monday night. The freeze comes as part of a Chinese government crackdown on executives and officials in the financial sector following a $5 trillion summer stock market rout. Xu's hedge fund, Zexi Investment, managed four of China's top-10 performing hedge funds.

site_title: Hong Kong's richest man under fire to raise US$12b bid
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's $12.3 billion buyout offer for Power Assets Holdings Ltd has been rejected by an influential proxy advisory firm, Institutional Shareholder Services Inc. ISS recommended a 13% higher offer and that CKI pay a special dividend before the deal goes through, citing concerns about conflicts of interest. This is the latest setback for Li in his efforts to reorganize his business empire, which he plans to hand over to his eldest son Victor Li. The offer was made after investor opposition prompted CKI to sweeten its offer in October.

site_title: Asia's rapid debt buildup tops developing markets, IIF says
summary: Debt in developing markets, particularly in Asia, has surged to $58.6 trillion at the start of 2015, exceeding that of Latin America, emerging Europe, and the Middle East. Since 2009, emerging-market debt has grown $28 trillion, with non-financial corporate sector debt in emerging Asia rising five-fold to 125% of GDP. Global debt has reached $240 trillion, or 320% of GDP. The Institute of International Finance introduced a database tracking 18 developing markets, highlighting the rapid debt buildup in developing markets, especially in Asia.

site_title: Google seeks developers in the desert at Dubai's tech hub
summary: Google has launched AstroLabs, a startup accelerator in Dubai's tech hub, backed by the tech giant. The facility provides 42 startups with workspace, access to mentors, and resources to test their mobile applications. The goal is to support entrepreneurs in creating new homegrown businesses and targeting global markets. AstroLabs aims to address the lack of local content and talent in the Middle East, with an estimated 200 million internet users in the region. The hub is part of Google's efforts to support entrepreneurs globally, with access to over 20 other Google-backed tech hubs worldwide.

images.alt_text: Google headquarters on Sept 2, 2015 in Mountain View, California.

site_title: Fed's Rosengren signals ready to lift rates amid strong data
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren signaled readiness to lift interest rates as soon as next month, citing strong US economic data and emerging signs of risk-taking by investors. Rosengren's comments, made before the Federal Open Market Committee's December meeting, suggest that the central bank may raise the benchmark federal funds rate for the first time since 2006. The move comes amid a better-than-expected October US employment report and measures of retail spending that signal domestic demand is overcoming weakness abroad.

site_title: Why getting rid of free office snacks doesn't come cheap
summary: Sprint has ended its free office snack policy, cutting $600,000 from its budget. While this move aims to curb expenses, experts argue that the economic benefits of free snacks, such as boosting productivity, outweigh the savings. Only 22% of offices offer free snacks, and eliminating this perk can have a negative impact on employee engagement and morale, potentially leading to decreased productivity and higher costs in the long run.

site_title: Singtel bags Premier League rights again
summary: Singtel has secured the broadcast rights to the English Premier League in Singapore for the next three seasons, starting from August 2016. This marks the telco's second consecutive win of the rights, following its previous win from 2013-16. The deal is expected to boost Singtel's pay TV subscriber base, as seen in its significant increase from 78,000 to 423,000 between 2009 and 2015.

images.alt_text: Singtel said it has won the Singapore broadcast rights to all English Premier League (EPL) matches for the next three seasons starting from August 2016.

site_title: Australia: Shares at 1-mth lows as banks slide
summary: Australian shares fell 1% to one-month lows on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,5067.10. Banking stocks led the losses, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Group down 2% and 1.5%, respectively. Property stocks also declined, and mining giant BHP Billiton touched its lowest in six years due to sliding iron ore prices. The market has shed nearly 6% since late October, with investors fretting about a possible interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve in December.

site_title: Gadget hungry China to drive 'lifestyle' metal gains, PwC says
summary: China's growing middle class is expected to drive long-term demand for metals like copper, zinc, and nickel as the country transitions to consumer-driven growth. The urbanization of 300 million people will increase the need for metals in consumer products. Despite a cooling economy, copper and nickel are likely to be the first to recover from the commodities rout, driven by rising populations and wealth in emerging economies. China's urban population is expected to increase by 170 million in the next decade, fueling demand for industrial metals, energy, and fertilizers.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls as rate hike looms and growth fears linger
summary: US stocks fell 1.11% on Monday, their largest decline in six weeks, due to concerns over an expected interest-rate hike by the Federal Reserve and weak Chinese trade data. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped into negative territory for the year, with only two components rising. Investors are also worried about a slowdown in China, a key market for US companies, ahead of the holiday shopping season. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the CBOE Volatility index rising 15% to its highest level in six weeks.

site_title: Oil price to rise only gradually to US$80 by 2020: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts that oil prices will rise gradually to $80 per barrel by 2020, driven by declining investment and slow demand growth. Despite unprecedented declines in investment, yearly demand growth is expected to rise annually by 900,000 barrels per day to 103.5 million barrels per day by 2040. However, lower-cost producers in Canada and Brazil may struggle to recover, while supply growth in Iraq and Iran could offset declines.

site_title: Potential investment in Golden Land gets nod
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd has approved a potential strategic investment of 4.97 billion baht (S$196 million) in Golden Land Property Development Public Company, a Thai property developer. The investment will be made through the subscription of new ordinary shares at 7.25 baht per share, representing a 1.4% premium. FCL will hold approximately 29.5% of Golden Land's enlarged share capital. The investment is seen as complementary to FCL's business profile and will allow the company to re-enter the Thai residential and commercial property markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan Sept current account surplus 1.47t yen
summary: Japan posted a current account surplus of 1.47 trillion yen in September for the 15th straight month, exceeding the median forecast of 2.2 trillion yen. This marks a significant improvement from the 978.0 billion yen surplus in September last year. The surplus was driven by a trade balance swing to a surplus.

site_title: Snapchat vanishing video viewing hits 6 billion daily
summary: Snapchat reported a three-fold surge in daily vanishing video views to 6 billion, up from 2 billion in early 2015. The rapid growth has raised concerns about the illicit nature of the content. Analyst Rob Enderle noted that making money from ephemeral content is challenging, and Facebook's eight billion daily video views, despite being viewed for longer periods, highlights the competition. Snapchat's revenue growth is attributed to its "replay" feature and recent $537 million equity funding round.

site_title: UK retail sales growth cools in October: BRC
summary: UK retail sales growth cooled in October, marking the weakest performance since 2008, with a 0.9% increase in total value compared to the same period in 2014. This slowdown may be attributed to shoppers holding off for the November "Black Friday" sales. Furniture and clothing sales were the bright spots last month. Total retail sales volumes rose 6.5% year-on-year in September, boosted by beer sales linked to the Rugby World Cup.

site_title: Asia: Stocks join global selloff on Fed concern before China CPI
summary: Asian stocks declined 0.4% as investors awaited China's inflation report and a potential US interest rate hike. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped to 133.16, while the S&P 500 Index fell 1% on Monday. China's producer prices fell for 44th month and consumer inflation decelerated, but markets are pricing in a US rate hike and a weakening Chinese economy. The OECD trimmed its global economic forecasts, citing slower growth in emerging markets.

site_title: Jumbo's Catalist debut shows a winning recipe
summary: Jumbo Group's Catalist debut saw its stock jump 58% to S$0.34, 36% above the IPO price of S$0.25, before ending trading. The company's market capitalisation rose to around S$218.1 million. The listing brought the total number of F&B companies on the Singapore Exchange to 43 and raised the number of Catalist-listed firms to 169. Jumbo's IPO was the 10th of 2015, with 77.8 million shares changing hands on the first day.

site_title: H&M to close on Thanksgiving in sign of mellowing holiday season
summary: H&M becomes the latest retailer to close US stores on Thanksgiving, shifting towards a less-frenzied holiday season. The decision comes after a new recruitment campaign, allowing store teams to spend the holiday with their families. This move follows similar restraints by Staples Inc and Recreational Equipment Inc, while Wal-Mart Stores and Target are spreading out promotions over a longer period. H&M's decision is part of a broader trend towards more relaxed holiday shopping.

site_title: Japan's wages rise for seventh straight month but growth seen as low
summary: Japan's wages rose 0.4% in September, marking a seventh consecutive month of growth. Labour cash earnings increased by 0.6% and wages adjusted for inflation advanced 0.5%. The central bank seeks higher earnings to sustain price gains, but critics argue the growth is low and insufficient to boost consumer spending. The government's pressure on businesses to raise wages is ongoing, with some proposing tax breaks for companies that increase wages or capital expenditure.

site_title: GE lands US$2.6b deal to supply Indian railway
summary: General Electric has won a US$2.6 billion contract to supply 1000 diesel locomotives to India's railways. The US company will also invest US$200 million in local manufacturing and service facilities. This deal is one of the largest to be awarded to a foreign firm since India allowed 100% foreign direct investment in some parts of its railways. The contract is part of India's US$137 billion plan to modernize its railways by 2020, and is expected to bring modern technology to the country's aging network.

site_title: SIA's privatisation of Tiger could lead to smoother ride for both
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has made a general offer to privatize Tiger Airways, valuing the airline at S$1.02 billion. The deal, which includes an option for Tiger shareholders to subscribe for SIA shares, is seen as "compelling" by analysts, but the premium offered is lower than some expected. The takeover could give SIA greater control over Tiger and its subsidiaries, allowing for cost savings and revenue maximization. The deal could also benefit SIA's premium end business and the Changi Airport hub, as well as Tiger's passengers with perks such as lounge access.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Rail Corridor ideas: URA picks winning firms; public feedback sought
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has selected the winning design teams for the Rail Corridor, a 24 km green corridor in Singapore. Japanese firm Nikken Sekkei Ltd and local landscape firm Tierra Design won the Concept Master Plan, while local firm MKPL Architects and Turenscape International from China won the Concept Designs for Choa Chu Kang and the former Tanjong Pagar Railway Station. The plans aim to create a vibrant public space with diverse activities, amenities, and green spaces, including a forest walk and observation tower, and introduce "platforms" for amenities and services.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Samsung's supply of geeks are looking for a new boss: themselves
summary: South Korea aims to reduce its reliance on large family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, by fostering a "second miracle" on the Han River. The country has seen a surge in startup activity, with over 80,000 new businesses established last year and venture investments reaching a record high. The government has launched an $18-billion program to boost entrepreneurship, providing funding and resources to young entrepreneurs. Companies like Samsung and Hyundai are embracing this shift, with Samsung's internal "Creative Lab" and the government-backed "creative economy" centers, which collaborate with major companies.

site_title: IIF introduces emerging market debt monitor for investors
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) has introduced an emerging market debt monitor to analyze risks associated with investing in the sector. The quarterly monitor tracks debt in 18 emerging market countries, following a significant rise of US$28 trillion to 195% of GDP since 2009. The move comes in response to volatile capital flows and changing appetite for emerging market debt, with IIF members seeking more information on the sector. The monitor aims to provide insights into sectoral and external debt dynamics, helping investors make informed decisions.

site_title: NLD poised for big victory as ruling party signals defeat
summary: Myanmar's ruling party has conceded defeat in the country's first free national election in 25 years, with the National League for Democracy (NLD) leading in 35 out of 36 announced seats. The NLD, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, is poised to secure a majority in the national legislature, giving them a strong chance to form a government and select a president. The election has been seen as a significant step towards democracy in Myanmar, which was ruled by the military for decades.

site_title: Volkswagen struggling to keep dealers happy as scandal widens worldwide
summary: Volkswagen is struggling to maintain its relationships with US dealers amid the widening emissions scandal. The company is offering cash and no-interest loans to its 650 dealerships, as well as encouraging them to offer pre-scandal prices on trade-ins. Volkswagen's US president, Michael Horn, has committed to making up the difference in value. Despite these efforts, dealers are concerned about the cost of housing affected vehicles and the delay in implementing a fix, with some dealers already experiencing significant losses. The company's sales have risen slightly, but the market for Volkswagen cars is still suffering, with affected models taking 123 days to sell.

site_title: Australia business conditions stay strong in Oct: NAB
summary: Australian business conditions remained strong in October, with sales, profits, and employment all in positive territory, according to the National Australia Bank's monthly survey. The index of business conditions held at +9, while confidence eased to +2. The Reserve Bank of Australia skipped a rate cut due to the strong business conditions. The survey also showed improved sales, profitability, and employment, with annual job creation potentially around 200,000. Capacity utilisation reached 81.4%, its highest since 2012, and the outlook for non-mining business investment remained positive.

images.alt_text: Australian business conditions stayed strong in October with sales, profits and employment all in positive territory, though confidence faded a little in the face of financial market volatility and concerns over emerging markets.

site_title: A rail corridor for all
summary: A rail corridor for all is being developed to improve connectivity and accessibility, but the article does not provide further details about this project.

site_title: Rise of luxury towers dims de Blasio's shine
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is facing growing criticism over his handling of luxury tower construction, which is displacing affordable housing and altering the city's neighborhoods. Residents, including former mayor candidate Lynn Ellsworth, argue that de Blasio's administration prioritizes real estate interests over community concerns. The formation of "New Yorkers for a Human-Scale City" aims to push back against this trend, citing the erosion of neighborhood character and quality of life. De Blasio's approval ratings have plummeted, with some seeing him as out of touch with the needs of ordinary New Yorkers.

site_title: Kempinski hotel chain accuses ex-CEO of stealing 6m francs
summary: Kempinski hotel chain is pressing criminal charges against former CEO Reto Wittwer, accusing him of embezzling around $6 million. Wittwer is suspected of pocketing funds during periods of budget cuts and is being charged with alleged professional misconduct and fraud. The hotel chain's current CEO, Alejandro Bernabe, described Wittwer's actions as "deliberately flouted in the pursuit of personal greed and unlawful gain." Wittwer has rejected the allegations, threatening to take legal action.

site_title: Soul-searching for Modi after crushing poll defeat in Bihar
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with his party leaders to discuss the reasons behind the BJP's crushing defeat in the Bihar state elections, its third most populous and poorest state. The defeat marks the first significant setback for Modi since his 2014 general election victory. Party leaders are questioning the direction of the government, with some calling for a more unifying agenda focusing on economic development. Modi's reform agenda is now hampered, and investors are fretting about his ability to push through economic reforms against an emboldened opposition.

site_title: Coloured diamonds set to bust records at Geneva auctions
summary: A blue diamond, "Blue Moon", is expected to fetch between $35 million and $55 million at a Geneva auction, potentially setting a new world record. A pink diamond, "In the Pink", is also up for sale, with an estimated price of $23-28 million. The market for colored diamonds has seen significant growth, with values more than doubling over the last two decades, driven by the scarcity of these stones. Experts attribute the increased demand to the rarity of colored diamonds, leading to a trend where buyers view them as sound investments.

images.alt_text: IN THE PINK: If "In the Pink", owned by an American family for the past 15 years, matches the per carat record for a pink diamond set in 2009, it could fetch more than US$32 million.

BLUE MOON: The flawless stone, discovered in South Africa last year, is the largest cushion-shaped stone in its category ever to appear at auction, and is expected to go for US$35 million to US$55 million.

site_title: Protecting the retail investor
summary: A Singaporean investor expresses frustration over the minimum trading price (MTP) initiative, which he believes unfairly punishes retail investors for companies failing to meet the minimum price. The writer notes that many friends have seen significant losses in their share portfolios, and questions whether authorities are concerned about this issue. He questions whether public investors are truly represented and protected, feeling they often receive the short end of the stick. The Society of Remisiers has also spoken out against the MTP initiative, highlighting the need for better protection for retail investors.

site_title: Nestle's Maggi noodles back on sale in India
summary: Nestle's Maggi noodles returned to shelves in India after a 5-month ban due to high lead levels. The ban was overturned by the Bombay High Court, which ordered fresh tests. Laboratory tests later confirmed the noodles were safe to eat. Nestle restarted production at three Indian plants, which also passed tests. The company estimates it lost 3.2 billion rupees in revenue during the ban. The noodles' return coincides with the Diwali festival, allowing Nestle to recoup lost business.

site_title: No end in sight to US immigration horrors
summary: The US government has spent over $1 billion on a decade-long project to digitize immigration records and online applications, with only one form available for electronic filing. Despite initial promises, the system has been plagued by technical errors and delays, with many immigrants waiting up to a year for processing. The project has been marred by mismanagement, outdated technology, and poor planning, with government watchdogs blaming DHS officials for the problems. The agency has scrapped the earlier technology and is adopting a new cloud-based approach, but progress remains slow, and frustration among immigrants and lawyers persists.

site_title: Builder's suicide puts spotlight on red tape
summary: Indian property developer Suraj Parmar's 13-page suicide note exposed alleged government harassment and corruption in the country's approval processes. Parmar's death sparked a rally for change, with the Confederation of Real Estate Developers' Association of India calling for a single-window system for all clearances. The industry is seeking to ease the 54-60 approval process, which can take years. Delays have led to dwindling sales, high interest costs, and unsold inventory, with some projects delayed by over two years. The government has promised to take action against corrupt officials and streamline the approval process.

site_title: Déjà vu for Draghi as ECB debates if more stimulus is needed
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering additional stimulus measures amid a slowdown in emerging markets and low inflation. The ECB's president, Mario Draghi, has invoked the term "vigilant" to signal a potential policy shift, and economists predict a possible cut in the deposit rate and expansion of quantitative easing. The eurozone economy is expected to expand 0.4% in the third quarter, but a slowdown in China and other emerging markets may threaten European expansion, with inflation remaining at zero.

images.alt_text: GETTING A MOVE ON: The 19-nation eurozone economy probably expanded 0.4 per cent in the third quarter, economists in a Bloomberg survey said before data due on Friday.
MR DRAGHI: 'We are faced with a situation where the price dynamics are very weak, the macroeconomic environment is still uncertain.'

site_title: Video game awards snub television
summary: The Game Awards, an independent video game awards show, will be streamed live over the Internet on December 3, marking a shift away from traditional television broadcasts. Hosted by Geoff Keighley, the event has grown in popularity since its inception, with an expected 4,000 attendees and a projected internet audience of over 2 million viewers. The show's success reflects the changing media habits of gamers, who increasingly consume content digitally, and the growing demand for critical recognition in the video game industry.

site_title: Public transport: Manpower gets S$12.5m govt boost
summary: Singapore's public transport sector is receiving a S$12.5 million government boost for manpower development over the next three years. The funding will focus on the rail sector, targeting diploma holders, mid-career workers, and retention. The move comes as the industry prepares for Singapore's expansion of its rail network, with 360 km expected by 2030. Operators SBS Transit and SMRT Corp expect to increase spending on manpower, with SBS Transit planning to hire more bus captains and SMRT aiming to attract experienced engineers.

site_title: NOL surges on merger talks but eases on divided views
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares surged to a high of S$1.125 on merger talks with AP-Moeller-Maersk and CMA CGM, but ended the day at S$1.055 due to divided market views. Industry experts speculate that Temasek Holdings, NOL's anchor shareholder, may sell its stake given the current low market valuations. OCBC Research suggests Temasek may seek a minimum P/B ratio of 0.8 times before selling, citing the group's past dividends and returns of capital. A potential takeover would require significant business integration and revamp.

site_title: S'pore's prime property market weakest in world
summary: Singapore's luxury residential market is experiencing its seventh consecutive quarter of decline, with prime home prices falling 7.9% in Q3, slowing from a 15.2% drop in Q2. The market's performance is attributed to the ongoing impact of ABSD and uncertain market conditions. In contrast, cities like Vancouver, Sydney, and Shanghai recorded double-digit annual price increases, with Vancouver's luxury homes rising 20.4% year-over-year. The Prime Global Cities Index shows Australasia leading the way with average annual price growth of 11.6%, followed by North America at 8.5%, and Europe at 0.8%.

site_title: MAS: Chongqing township, new yuan quotas big boost to S'pore-China financial links
summary: Singapore will receive a significant boost in its quota under the Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) scheme, with its quota doubled to 100 billion yuan. The move aims to enhance market connectivity and cross-border yuan flows between Singapore and China. China has also agreed to extend certain perks to the Chongqing municipality, allowing Singapore-based banks to lend yuan to companies and companies to issue yuan-denominated bonds in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is pictured at its building in Singapore in this Feb 21, 2013 file photo.

site_title: G-20 finalises tools for ending 'too big to fail' banks
summary: Global regulators have finalized tools to end the phenomenon of "too big to fail" banks, a key reform implemented after the 2007-09 financial crisis. The Financial Stability Board has finalized rules requiring the world's 30 top banks to issue a buffer of bonds by 2019 to raise funds equivalent to 18% of risk-weighted assets in the event of a bank failure. This aims to allow big banks to fail without causing market chaos, as seen after Lehman Brothers' collapse in 2008.

site_title: Boeing ends order drought at Dubai show with US$8b 737 deal
summary: Boeing has ended its sales drought at the Dubai Air Show with a deal worth $8 billion for 75 re-engined 737 single-aisle airliners from India's Jet Airways. The order, valued at $8 billion, consists entirely of Max8 variants and is part of Jet Airways' efforts to expand its fleet amid increasing competition in the Indian air travel market. This deal marks a significant turnaround for Boeing after a slow sales period, with the company's backlog now stretching eight years into the future.

images.alt_text: SPREADING WINGS: Jet Airways is adding aircraft fleet as competition steps up in the fast-expanding Indian air travel market.

site_title: Communities turn to land trusts as costs rise
summary: Communities in the US are turning to land trusts as the cost of housing continues to rise. Local non-profit organizations are acquiring properties to create permanently affordable housing. This trend aims to provide long-term affordability and stability for residents. The shift towards land trusts is seen as a response to increasing housing costs, with no clear end in sight.

images.alt_text: KEEPING IT LOCAL: "There is such a spectrum of need here, a lack of options at all different income levels," said Kim Thompson, executive director of Community Land Trust Association of West Marin, where the land trust model helps keep housing within reach for locals.

site_title: Oil megaprojects won't stay on the shelf for long
summary: Oil megaprojects are at risk of being abandoned due to the ongoing oil price downturn. Large-scale projects with high costs and long time-horizons are being cut or scrapped, with Royal Dutch Shell and ConocoPhillips already backing out of deepwater exploration. This shift could lead to a greater focus on shale, which is cheaper to develop and can produce oil at a lower cost. However, shale production is expected to peak in the early 2020s and decline thereafter, potentially forcing the industry to shift back to traditional sources of supply.

site_title: Govt reiterates backing for crowdfunding
summary: Singapore's government reiterated its support for crowdfunding as a dynamic financing tool for startups and innovation. Parliamentary Secretary Low Yen Ling said crowdfunding sites in Singapore have raised tens of millions of dollars for local ventures, with startups like Bamboobee achieving significant growth. The government aims to support the continued growth of the startup ecosystem, which has grown from 24,000 to 55,000 active startups between 2005 and 2014.

site_title: Cheap fare helps Tencent beat China's growth
summary: Tencent Holdings is expected to post a 28% surge in sales, driven by cheap entertainment provided to its 1 billion users of WeChat and QQ messaging applications. Free streaming of TV and video games, including HBO's Game of Thrones, will boost revenue. Tencent's mobile games have been a key area of growth, with users buying skills and powers, and the company is also investing in more games to build on its strength.

site_title: Big banks face huge shortfall under new rules
summary: Big banks, including HSBC Holdings Plc and JPMorgan Chase & Co, will need to raise billions in capital to meet new rules aimed at preventing another financial crisis. The Financial Stability Board requires these banks to have a total loss-absorbing capacity equivalent to 16% of risk-weighted assets by 2019 and 18% by 2022, with a leverage ratio requirement increasing from 6% to 6.75%. This plan is part of efforts to stabilize the global financial system and mitigate the risk of banks failing, similar to the 2008 Lehman crisis.

site_title: Fed rate hike seen as irrelevant in US$2.6t slice of debt market
summary: The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike is unlikely to impact the $2.6 trillion money-market mutual funds, as there is an unprecedented shortage of Treasury bills. This shortage, driven by regulatory efforts to curb risk, has led to low money-fund rates, with some rates near historic lows. Investors are shifting to higher-yielding choices, and the industry is adapting to new regulations, which may further stabilize money markets despite potential Fed tightening.

site_title: China's oldest investment bank CICC jumps in HK trading debut
summary: China's oldest investment bank, CICC, made a successful Hong Kong trading debut, with shares jumping up to 11% on Monday. The IPO was aided by China's decision to resume initial public offerings, boosting investment banks' revenues. CICC's stock traded at HK$11.34, exceeding its marketing range of HK$10.28. The bank plans to use the funds raised to expand its businesses and international subsidiaries. The resumption of IPOs is seen as a positive benchmark for other companies queued up to list, and a reassuring move for investors rattled by China's market turmoil and economic slowdown.

site_title: Xi to attend Apec summit amid sea disputes
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will attend the APEC summit in Manila from November 17 to 19, amid tensions over the disputed South China Sea. China has overlapping claims with several countries, including the Philippines, Vietnam, and Malaysia, and has been angered by a Philippine case lodged with an arbitration court in the Netherlands. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi will visit the Philippines to discuss preparations for Xi's visit and improve relations. The summit comes ahead of Xi's visit to the G-20 summit in Turkey.

site_title: Seismic shift in what Americans eat
summary: US food giants struggle to keep up with changing eating habits, as consumers increasingly shun their products. In response, companies like General Mills, Perdue, Tyson, and Hershey's are introducing new, cleaner products and acquiring healthier brands. However, this shift may not be enough to save them, as consumers are increasingly turning to fresh, organic, and locally sourced options. Sales of packaged foods have declined, while fresh prepared foods and raw produce have grown, leading industry insiders to refer to the centre of the store as the "morgue". To survive, legacy food companies must make bold changes to their core product offerings, including reducing sugar, increasing whole foods, and developing fresh offerings.

site_title: Think of clean tech as investment with ROI
summary: Bertrand Piccard, pilot of the Solar Impulse, is renewing his pitch for sustainable energy, emphasizing that clean tech can be a profitable investment opportunity. He has already completed half of his planned round-the-world solar flight, breaking world records for a solar-powered aircraft. Piccard believes that clean technologies can offer a significant return on investment (ROI), with payback times ranging from 2 to 3 years for building insulation and 15 to 20% per year for heavy machine industries. His goal is to promote clean and energy-efficient technologies, and he sees sustainable energy as a key driver of quality of life and health on a larger scale.

site_title: Shake-up needed for F&B, retail to boost productivity: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam proposes a shake-up in the F&B and retail sectors to boost productivity, citing a manpower shortage. He suggests centralizing dishwashing facilities, a practice common in Japan, to save space, logistics, and labor costs. A pilot project at Singapore's IMM Building has already seen 19 F&B outlets adopt the service, saving them 50-80% in man-hours. The government may need to offer incentives and tweak regulations to facilitate the adoption of centralized dishwashing in new malls.

site_title: Jumbo, Tiger and NOL offer highlights in otherwise quiet market
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a quiet session on Monday, with prices drifting in low volume due to a public holiday and rising expectations of a US interest rate hike. Jumbo Group, a seafood restaurant operator, debuted as a listed entity with shares finishing at S$0.34, while Tiger Airways ended unchanged at S$0.41. Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) announced preliminary takeover talks with CMA CGM SA and A Moeller-Maersk A/S, pushing its stock to a high of S$1.13. The Straits Times Index finished 12.75 points weaker at 2,997.72.

site_title: Singles' Day in China bigger than Cyber Monday
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day in China is expected to reach a new record, with sales projected to surge to 57.1 billion yuan within 24 hours. The event, celebrated on November 11, started in the 1990s as an obscure holiday and has since become a massive marketing event, selling a wide range of products at discounted prices through various platforms. The phenomenon has grown significantly, with Alibaba playing a key role in its development. Last year's sales of 57.1 billion yuan set a new benchmark, and analysts predict this year's sales will surpass it.

site_title: Lawsuit blows hole in QT Vascular's Q3 balance sheet, bottom line
summary: QT Vascular, a Singapore-based company, reported a net loss of US$33.3 million for the third quarter, primarily due to a lawsuit that may require the company to pay damages. This led to the company falling into negative equity. The net loss was 4 US cents per share, a significant increase from the US$3.7 million loss in the third quarter of 2014, when the loss was 0.5 US cents per share.

site_title: The real cattle class: Cows on a 747 to China
summary: Australia has begun its first live cattle flight to China, with 150 animals transported on a Boeing 747 cargo plane from Melbourne to Chongqing. The flights are possible due to China's soaring demand for fresh beef, with the country expected to eat 2.2 million tonnes more by 2025. The high demand has driven up prices, with Chinese beef now costing four times more than in Australia, and the flight aims to capitalize on this opportunity. The cattle were crated and loaded onto the plane, with human escorts accompanying them, and will be slaughtered close to their point of entry in China.

site_title: UOB sets up innovation lab, explores crowdfunding
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is setting up an innovation lab in collaboration with the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore, targeting regional startups and UOB staff. The lab aims to develop crowdfunding platforms for small companies, providing them with "smart money" to help their ideas survive beyond their initial years. UOB will offer up to S$30,000 in funding, working space, and mentorship to fintechs, with the first program expected to start in Q2 2016. The move is part of UOB's efforts to collaborate with fintechs and provide specialized banking knowledge to support their growth.

site_title: India seen emerging as winner from Asia's shrinking labour force
summary: India is projected to become the world's largest workforce by 2050, accounting for 18.8% of the global workforce, surpassing China's 13%. Asia's workforce is expected to shrink to 50% of the world's total by 2050, with Africa also experiencing growth. However, India's large population and low per-person income pose challenges, including a skills shortage and a need to transition out of the informal jobs sector. The government aims to train 400 million workers by 2022, but critics argue that the informal sector generates more jobs than organized industry.

site_title: Ezra seeking approval from noteholders on resolutions
summary: EZRA Holdings has launched a consent solicitation for two series notes due 2016 and 2018, seeking approval from noteholders on key financing covenants and Ebitda ratios to align with a multi-currency debt issuance program. The company aims to develop its subsea services business through a 50:50 joint venture with Chiyoda Corp. Noteholders who deliver valid votes ahead of the deadline will receive a fee of S$875 per S$250,000 for Series 003 Notes and S$500 per S$250,000 for Series 004 Notes.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK 'Brexit' vote likely in June if Cameron gets EU deal on reforms
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron is set to publish a letter outlining the UK's demands for EU reforms, which could lead to a referendum on the UK's EU membership by June 2016. If the EU agrees to the proposed changes, the referendum may not take place. However, if the response is unsatisfactory, Cameron may decide not to support the remain-in-EU movement, potentially leading to a British exit from the EU ("Brexit").

site_title: c-Leadership in new competitive environment
summary: A new management style, c-Leadership, is being viewed as revolutionary and refreshing by academics and practitioners. This style, which shifts leadership and decision-making responsibility along a ring-based structure, aims to create a more collaborative and autonomous business environment. The approach is designed to counter the increasingly competitive and unstable business climate, where entrepreneurs and SMEs struggle to keep pace with rapid changes. By empowering c-Leaders, this style enables businesses to make better, faster, and more sustainable decisions, ultimately leading to increased success and competitiveness.

site_title: Ascott's global fund acquires prime Paris, Tokyo properties for US$104m
summary: Ascott's global fund, a 50:50 joint venture with Qatar Investment Authority, acquired two prime properties in Paris and Tokyo for $104 million. The fund will invest $33 million to develop a luxury serviced residence in Paris and reposition a serviced residence in Tokyo, totaling $137 million. This acquisition boosts Ascott's portfolio to over 43,000 units, aiming to reach 80,000 units by 2020. The fund focuses on Asia Pacific and Europe, capitalizing on strong demand for serviced residences.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Watershed moment for a champion of democracy
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's democracy champion, cast her ballot in a nationwide election, marking a significant moment in her life and her country's turbulent politics. After decades of house arrest, Suu Kyi's vision of displacing the junta is now in reach, with her party, the National League for Democracy, poised for a landslide victory. Suu Kyi, 70, has been a key figure in Myanmar's struggle for democracy, despite criticism of her pragmatism and her inability to become president due to a junta-era Constitution.

site_title: Adani mine in Australia faces fresh challenge
summary: Indian conglomerate Adani Enterprises faces a fresh challenge to its proposed $7 billion coal mine in Australia, with an environmental group launching a review of the government's environmental permit. The group argues that the project will harm the Great Barrier Reef and contribute to climate change. The review was sparked by concerns over the impact on the endangered Black-throated finch and climate change, following a similar challenge in 2014. The mine's construction has been delayed multiple times due to environmental opposition.

site_title: Two adjoining shophouses in Chinatown for sale
summary: Two adjoining commercial shophouses in Chinatown, Singapore, have been put up for sale at S$30 million. The units, with a combined land area of 3,010 sq ft, are fully occupied and have a 99-year leasehold tenure. They are zoned "commercial" within the Kreta Ayer Historic District and benefit from significant pedestrian footfall, especially during key festivals. Cushman & Wakefield has been appointed to sell the shophouses, with an Expression of Interest closing on November 27. The sale is expected to attract traditional homegrown house brands, high-net-worth investors, and institutional funds.

site_title: Thai general's US$83b plan to clean up border town Mae Sot
summary: Thailand's General Prayuth Chan-Ocha is investing $83 billion over seven years to transform border towns like Mae Sot into special economic zones, offering tax breaks and incentives to investors. The zones aim to link 2.4 billion consumers in China and India with the Asean Economic Community. Mae Sot, a former war zone, has seen a surge in cross-border trade, with sales to Myanmar, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos increasing 8.1% in the first eight months of 2015. Japanese and Chinese companies are competing to bid on rail projects, and investors are taking note of Thailand's potential as a logistics hub.

site_title: End of an era as Goldman's BRIC fund folds after years of losses
summary: Goldman Sachs has closed its BRIC fund, which invested in Brazil, Russia, India, and China, after a 9-year run of losses. The fund, which had lost 88% of its assets, was merged with a broader emerging-market fund. The move reflects the decline of the BRIC concept, which was once seen as a promising investment opportunity. The fund's closure underscores how the strategy of bundling disparate countries into a single investment theme is losing appeal among investors, as emerging markets face challenges such as recessions and sanctions.

site_title: Whistleblower behind CO2 cheating disclosure: VW
summary: Volkswagen (VW) admitted to under-reporting CO2 emissions on 800,000 diesel and gasoline-powered cars in Europe due to an internal whistleblower. This disclosure follows the company's previous admission of installing software to cheat on air-pollution tests on millions of diesel cars. VW is taking steps to address the issue, with a determination to get to the bottom of the wrongdoing. The company's credibility problems began in September and have added to its challenges in the wake of the scandal.

site_title: Building success with humility
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a specialist contractor in the facade engineering business, has carved a name in the construction industry through its superior quality products and services. Founded in 1978 as a glazing subcontractor and glass supplier, the company adapted to changing market conditions by focusing on "soft" skills, such as design, engineering, and installation. Seiko prioritizes quality, prudence, and human capital, adopting a conservative approach to business development and empowering employees through training and decision-making. The company is now considering setting up a research and development centre to stay competitive in the industry and meet emerging technological demands.

site_title: Canadian housing starts drop in October
summary: Canadian housing starts decreased to 198,065 in October, a decline from the revised 231,304 in September, according to the Canadian Mortgage and Housing Corp. This marks a slowdown in homebuilding, contrary to forecasts. The drop was mainly attributed to a decrease in multiple-unit constructions, such as condos, across all regions except British Columbia.

site_title: Iron ore derivatives trade booms as prices tank and hedging rises
summary: Iron ore derivatives trading has seen a significant boom, with volumes more than doubling this year compared to 2014. The surge is driven by producers seeking to hedge against risk as prices plummet due to a global glut and decreased Chinese steel demand.
