A potential investor would need to pay approximately US$30 billion for a 25% stake in the company, which "few suitors" would be able to afford. TSMC has relaxed rules to allow Chinese investments in some semiconductor companies, but chip design houses and foundries remain closed to Chinese investors. Chang is open to further easing on cross-strait investment policies.

site_title: Toyota starts US$1b centre to develop cars that don't crash
summary: Toyota is investing $1 billion in the Toyota Research Institute Inc to develop cars that can overcome driver errors and reduce traffic fatalities. The institute will focus on artificial intelligence and robotics technology, with a goal of introducing cars with automated highway driving by 2020. The move aims to set Toyota apart from its Japanese peers and make it easier for elderly drivers to use their vehicles. The institute's CEO, Gill Pratt, oversees 200 employees and plans to work towards making cars safer and more accessible.

site_title: M'sian bird-nest products maker inks US$200m distribution deal
summary: Swiftlet Eco Park Group, a Malaysian maker of edible bird nest products, has signed distribution agreements worth US$200 million with companies in China, India, and the UAE. The company will sell its products, including coffee and skincare items, in these markets. The agreements are part of the company's efforts to expand its market and increase profit margins. Nests made from swiftlets' saliva are prized in China for their alleged health benefits and are being mixed into various products to broaden their appeal.

site_title: Barclays mulls sale of wealth-management business in Asia: sources
summary: Barclays is considering selling its Asian wealth-management business, citing declining revenue and high costs. The bank's chairman, John McFarlane, has refocused the company on more profitable US and UK operations. Several parties have expressed interest in the business, but a sale has not been finalized. This move would put Barclays at odds with other European lenders seeking to tap into Asia's wealthy client base. Barclays' global wealth management revenue fell 17% in the third quarter, and the unit has posted declining revenue for four quarters.

site_title: There will never be a problem with freedom of navigation in South China Sea: Xi Jinping
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that there will never be a problem with freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, emphasizing the maintenance of peace and stability in the region. This pledge comes despite long-standing disputes with several countries, including four Asean member states, over territory in the South China Sea.

site_title: TV operators seek silver bullet to fight online rivals
summary: Traditional TV firms, including Time Warner, 21st Century Fox, and Walt Disney Co, are struggling to stem the loss of customers to online rivals like Netflix. Despite working with Netflix, they debate whether to treat the streaming giant as a friend or foe, with some considering holding back content to retain value. Meanwhile, streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon create original programming, adding to tensions between old and new media groups. Executives argue that consumers are gravitating to online services for convenient on-demand viewing, forcing legacy distributors to adapt and crack the mobile code.

images.alt_text: While Time Warner is still a major industry force, the loss of viewers translates to lower advertising revenues, raising the prospect of a downward spiral.

site_title: Ma Ying-jeou arrives in Singapore ahead of landmark summit with Xi Jinping
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Singapore on November 7, 2015, for a landmark summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping. The summit is significant as it marks a rare high-level meeting between the two leaders, who have a complex relationship due to Taiwan's disputed status.

site_title: China imports fall in sign of battered domestic demand
summary: China's imports fell 16% in October from a year ago to 833.14 billion yuan, indicating battered domestic demand and downward pressures on economic growth. Exports dropped 3.6% year-on-year to US$1.23 trillion, with the trade balance rising 40.2% to 393.22 billion yuan. The decline in exports exceeded economists' median forecast of a 3.2% drop, suggesting China continues to struggle with improving domestic demand.

site_title: TAG Heuer to launch US$15,000 smartwatch on Monday
summary: TAG Heuer is set to launch its US$15,000 smartwatch, the Carrera Connected, on Monday in New York. The watch, developed in partnership with Google and Intel, will have similar functions to the Apple Watch but is aimed at a high-end clientele. The company's CEO, Jean-Claude Biver, said the watch will have features such as a customizable face and multiple wristband options, and will be available in six colors. The launch marks TAG Heuer's entry into the smartwatch market, which it hopes will help it claw back market share from Apple.

site_title: Steel exports from top producer China fall as trade friction rises
summary: China's steel exports fell 20% in October to 9.02 million metric tonnes, the lowest since June, amid rising trade frictions and weak overseas demand. This marks a shift from earlier aggressive exports that increased competition and spurred complaints. Despite a 25% increase in exports compared to the same period in 2014, China's steel market is being overwhelmed, leading to lower prices and increased competition. The US has also imposed duties on Chinese steel imports, with over 20 cases lodged worldwide.

images.alt_text: China's mills, accounting for half of global production, exported huge volumes of steel this year.

site_title: Starting Jan 1, Singaporeans aged 25 and above will get S$500 credit to upgrade themselves
summary: Singaporeans aged 25 and above will receive an initial SkillsFuture Credit of S$500 starting Jan 1, 2016, to upgrade their skills in 57 government-approved courses. This move aims to support lifelong learning and enhance employability. The S$500 credit can be used to fund courses in areas such as workplace literacy, nursing, and culinary arts.

site_title: Real Capital to set up Asia office next year amid investor interest
summary: Real Capital Analytics (RCA) plans to set up an office in Asia next year, following growing investor interest in the region. The move aims to provide data analytics to Asian real estate investors and international buyers seeking to enter Asia. RCA's executive managing director, Simon Mallinson, notes that markets like China have matured, and investors have gained confidence in their own expertise. The office will be located in Singapore or Hong Kong, with plans to hire service and research staff to replicate RCA's European office model, which employs up to 20 people.

site_title: DeClout aims to buy PacNet's Singapore and Thai assets for US$4.4 m
summary: DeClout, a Singapore-listed IT firm, proposes to buy PacNet Internet Singapore's assets and business in Singapore and Thailand for US$4.4 million. The move aims to expand DeClout's regional reach in South-east Asia, boosting its infrastructure and internet network connectivity services.

images.alt_text: Information technology firm DeClout is proposing to buy internet service provider (ISP) assets and business in Singapore and Thailand from PacNet Internet Singapore for US$4.4 million in total.

site_title: Germany landlord urges rival's investors to stop takeover
summary: Germany's Deutsche Wohnen AG CEO Michael Zahn plans to publish a letter urging Vonovia SE shareholders to reject the 9.9-billion euro takeover bid, calling it "value destructive". Zahn warns of a potentially expensive process and suggests Vonovia investors buy Deutsche Wohnen's stock instead. Vonovia has promised annual synergies of 84 million euros, but Zahn questions their ability to deliver. If the bid proceeds, high tax and financing costs could reduce profits by 30 million euros per year. The letter is an attempt to fend off the 9.9-billion euro bid by Vonovia, the industry leader.

site_title: Bombardier nearly 100% done with flight testing of CSeries FTV-5
summary: Bombardier is nearly 100% complete with flight testing of its FTK-5 test aircraft for the CSeries regional jet. President Fred Cromer stated the program is doing well, with demand from Gulf region customers. The CS100 will debut at the Dubai Airshow, and Air Baltic, a Latvian carrier, will launch the CS300 in the second half of 2016 with 20 aircraft on order.

site_title: Business travel spending set to rise in 2016 - study
summary: Business travel spending in Germany, Britain, France, Spain, and Italy is expected to rise by 6.4% in 2015 and 6.3% in 2016, driven by a recovering European economy. The total market is projected to reach $210.6 billion in 2016, up from $186.3 billion in 2014. The growth is attributed to lower unemployment and fuel costs in Britain, while weaker economic growth in France and Italy will see smaller increases. The five countries account for nearly 70% of the business travel market in western Europe.

site_title: World Bank sends chilling message on global warming
summary: The World Bank released a report, "Shock Waves: Managing the Impacts of Climate Change on Poverty," warning that 100 million people will be pushed into poverty due to climate change unless drastic actions are taken. The report highlights the devastating effects of climate change, including natural disasters, heat waves, floods, and crop failures, which disproportionately affect the world's poor. To mitigate these impacts, the World Bank suggests governments implement emission reduction policies, which can benefit poor people in the long term, even if they slow down poverty reduction in the short term.

site_title: India's PM Modi concedes defeat in Bihar
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi conceded defeat in the Bihar election, a key state in the country, after the Election Commission results showed his Hindu nationalist party leading in only 52 seats compared to 158 for opposition leader Nitish Kumar's coalition. Modi congratulated Kumar on his victory on Twitter, marking a significant blow to the prime minister's campaign. The election results are a major setback for Modi's party, with Kumar's coalition emerging as the clear winner in the 243-seat state assembly.

site_title: Billionaire hedge fund managers continue to snap up pricey property despite losses
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager Larry Robbins, founder of Glenview Capital Management, purchased a Manhattan penthouse for $37.9 million despite a potentially volatile year in the markets. Robbins, a local Wall Street celebrity, used a limited liability company to conceal his identity. This purchase highlights his wealth and resilience amidst market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Mr Robbins' new apartment in The Charles condominium (above) on First Avenue was created by combining two duplex penthouses. It now totals 11,740 square feet, including private terraces that cover 1,300 square feet. Monthly fees are US$10,547.

site_title: Nissan also dumps Takata inflators, after Honda, Toyota
summary: Nissan joins Toyota and Honda in ceasing use of Takata airbag inflators containing ammonium nitrate, following a US$200 million penalty and criticism from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The defect can cause explosive airbag deployment, linked to eight deaths and scores of injuries. Nissan will replace inflators in recalled vehicles and work to ensure customer safety. The move follows similar steps by domestic peers and comes as Takata reported a 5.6 billion yen net loss due to crisis costs.

site_title: Patek Philippe wristwatch fetches record US$7.3m at Swiss charity auction
summary: A Patek Philippe stainless steel watch sold for a record-breaking US$7.3 million at a Swiss charity auction in Geneva, with proceeds going towards research into Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The watch, featuring manual winding and a perpetual calendar, was one of 44 unique timepieces created for the "Only Watch" auction by luxury brands. The charity auction raised a total of US$11.2 million, exceeding expectations, and will aid in the fight against the disease.

site_title: Banks still struggling to make money in FICC trading
summary: Major banks worldwide struggled to make money in FICC (fixed income, currency, and commodities) trading in the third quarter, with revenue and profit declining for most of the world's major trading banks. The outlook for 2016 points to further declines, particularly in Europe. Regulatory changes and cost-cutting measures have reduced liquidity and intensified pressure to cut costs, staff, and activity. Despite some US banks' gains, the trend is expected to continue, with FICC revenues projected to decline to US$77 billion in 2017.

site_title: Appealing Japanese-Italian cuisine
summary: Chef Seita Nakahara's solo venture, Terra, showcases his unique Japanese-Italian cuisine. Located at 54 Tras Street, the restaurant is open for lunch and dinner from Monday to Friday and dinner only on Saturdays. Nakahara's culinary voice stands out from traditional Japanese and Italian cuisine, offering a fusion of flavors. Despite initial reservations from chefs of other cultures, Nakahara's Terra is a new addition to the Singapore dining scene, inviting customers to experience his innovative take on Japanese-Italian cuisine.

site_title: Suu Kyi's day of destiny arrives as Myanmar goes to the polls
summary: Myanmar's historic election began Sunday, with Aung San Suu Kyi's pro-democracy party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), seeking to capitalize on the country's long struggle against army dictatorship. Suu Kyi, a Nobel laureate, voted in Yangon, despite being barred from the presidency by the army-scripted constitution. The NLD faces an uphill struggle as a quarter of seats are reserved for the military, but supporters believe a fair vote will propel them into government, marking a major stride towards democracy.

site_title: Will the RBA succumb to easing rates?
summary: The Australian dollar reached a low of 0.6900 against the US dollar in August, its lowest since the 2008-2009 economic crisis. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) retains its cash rate of 2% but offers scope for easing, amid disappointing inflation data and a contractionary impact from mortgage rate hikes. The economy is heavily tied to China, which has cut rates for the sixth time this year, but its sluggish economy and debt burden create uncertainty. A possible decision to ease rates could further weaken the AUD, with year-end travelers expecting a more favorable economic outlook.

site_title: Taylor-made
summary: BT, a business publication, has launched a Telegram channel for daily updates and special weekend content. The channel, t.me/BizTimes, aims to provide weekday updates and curated weekend content. Additionally, several businesses have announced partnerships or new ventures, including The Social Kitchen setting up shop at Bank of Singapore, and CMC Markets partnering with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women. These developments highlight the focus on lifestyle, corporate social responsibility, and community engagement in the business world.

site_title: US interest rate decision in October a close call, says Fed's SF head
summary: The US economy has reached full employment, according to Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams, who stated that the October interest rate decision was a "close call." The economy continues to grow, but inflation remains lower than desired due to global developments. Williams noted the crosscurrents in navigating the economy, with growth closing in on full employment and inflation remaining lower than expected.

site_title: Virgin Australia, Jetstar cancel Bali flights as volcano erupts
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd and Jetstar Airways Pty canceled flights to and from Bali due to volcanic eruptions in Denpasar Airport. Mount Rinjani's eruptions caused winds to push volcanic ash toward the airport, forecast to worsen. Disruptions follow previous cancellations in July and August during an eruption by Mount Raung on Java. The airlines will reassess their flights between Bali and Australia later.

site_title: White House may have to renegotiate Pacific trade pact: senator
summary: US Senator Orrin Hatch suggests that the Obama administration may need to renegotiate parts of the Pacific trade pact, citing concerns over protection periods for biological drugs, tobacco provisions, labor rules, and dairy regulations. Hatch's support is crucial for passing the deal, and his reservations may lead to a tough battle in Congress. The administration has denied the need for renegotiation, calling the deal a "strongest possible outcome" that cuts taxes and levels the playing field for American workers and businesses.

site_title: Maersk and CMA CGM in talks with Singapore's NOL over acquisition
summary: Singapore container shipping firm Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) is in talks with CMA CGM and Maersk over a potential sale, with CMA CGM making a preliminary offer worth S$2.7 billion. NOL has reported significant losses due to sluggish global trade and lower freight rates. The company has also sold its logistics business for $1.2 billion. Talks with Maersk are less advanced, but both companies are assessing options to maximize shareholder value and improve competitiveness. No assurance is given that a definitive agreement or transaction will occur.

site_title: Exchange of letters to start talks on upgrading FTA, agreement to kickstart Chongqing project signed
summary: Singapore and China have exchanged letters to launch negotiations to upgrade their bilateral free trade agreement, which was first signed in 2008. The upgraded pact aims to cover more sophisticated economic areas, such as trade in services. This move is expected to broaden the pact and provide benefits to both countries. The talks are seen as a positive step for bilateral economic cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Protests in Taiwan as Ma leaves for meet with Xi
summary: Protesters in Taiwan attempted to storm parliament overnight as President Ma Ying-jeou departed for a historic summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Singapore. The meeting marks a significant rapprochement between the two sides, but has sparked backlash in Taiwan, with protesters fearing Beijing's growing influence. Police stopped the protesters, but a dozen remained staging a sit-in outside parliament. Ma described the summit as a "new platform" for future cross-strait relations, but his opponents accuse him of selling out Taiwan.

site_title: US: Dow, Nasdaq rise on strong US jobs report
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as a strong jobs report raised expectations of a December Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 46.90 points to 17,910.33, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 19.38 points to 5,147.12. Analysts now expect the Fed to hike interest rates in December due to stronger economic activity, with large bank stocks rallying in anticipation of higher profits.

site_title: Japan's trading firms give bleak outlook for commodity prices
summary: Japan's five largest trading firms have downgraded their commodity price recovery outlook, with Mitsubishi now expecting 2018 rather than 2017. The firms, including Itochu, Mitsui, Marubeni, and Sumitomo, have been impacted by softening demand from China and tumbling prices of oil and metals. Despite this, Itochu reported a 40% rise in net profit, citing strong profits from non-resource assets, while Mitsubishi and Mitsui posted double-digit drops in six-month profits. Analysts say Itochu can better withstand a commodity downturn due to its low exposure to resource assets.

images.alt_text: Itochu's robust results came on strong profits from non-resource assets such as tyre, pulp and satellite TV which offset slack earnings from energy and metals.

site_title: China FX reserves rise in October to US$3.5 trillion
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose to US$3.5255 trillion in October, a gain of US$11.5 billion, according to the People's Bank of China. The value of China's gold reserves increased to US$63.261 billion, while its IMF reserve position decreased to US$4.638 billion. This marks the first monthly reporting of foreign exchange reserves since China adopted the IMF's Special Data Dissemination Standard in July.

images.alt_text: China's foreign exchange reserves, the world's largest, rose by US$11.5 billion in October to US$3.5255 trillion, central bank data showed on Saturday.

site_title: New joint research institute set up as part of MOUs signed at Istana
summary: Singapore's Nanyang Technological University signed a joint research agreement with China at the Istana, establishing the Sino-Singapore International Joint Research Institute. The institute aims to develop new technologies, including next-generation electric vehicles and intelligent urban transportation systems. The agreement was witnessed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Russia suspends Egypt flights, US boosts security as intelligence points to bomb
summary: Russia suspended passenger flights to Egypt after a Russian jet crashed in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, killing 224 people, with Islamic State claiming responsibility and citing revenge for Russian air strikes in Syria. The US imposed new air travel security measures, including tighter screening of items before flights to the US from airports in the region. Western intelligence suggests a bomb may have brought down the airliner, but no official investigation has confirmed the claim.

site_title: China to restart IPOs as market stabilises
summary: China's securities regulator has allowed the resumption of initial public offerings (IPOs) after a 4-month suspension, citing stabilization of the stock market. 28 companies will be the first to list, with the first batch launching after November 20. The decision comes after the CSI300 index posted its best weekly performance since June, marking a return to a bull market. Regulators aim to introduce fresh cash while minimizing psychological pressure on investors.

site_title: Gold at 3-mth low after US data, eyes biggest weekly drop since 2013
summary: Gold prices plummeted to a three-month low on Friday, falling 1.7% to $1,084.90 an ounce, amid strong US job growth and a surge in the dollar, making a rate hike by the Federal Reserve in December likely. This marks the biggest weekly drop since 2013, with spot gold down 1.3% and the US futures contract for December delivery down 1.5%. Analysts predict further declines, with some warning that gold could retrace to its year-low.

site_title: Unease and expectation as Myanmar prepares to vote
summary: Myanmar is set to hold its first free and fair election in decades, with opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy party expected to emerge as the largest party in parliament. President Thein Sein has vowed to respect the outcome, but concerns remain over disenfranchised ethnic Rohingya Muslims and potential voting irregularities. The election is seen as a key step in Myanmar's transition from military rule to democracy, but observers warn of ongoing skepticism and potential for violence. Suu Kyi's party is barred from the presidency due to her foreign-born children, but she has declared her intention to take on a role above the president.

site_title: PM Lee to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday; agreement on Chongqing project among deals to be inked
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping on November 7, marking a two-day state visit. The two leaders will witness the signing of agreements aimed at strengthening bilateral ties, including a deal on a Chongqing project. This visit comes after Xi's arrival in Singapore on November 6, a busy day for the Chinese President.

site_title: Football: Asian tycoons frustrated in hunt for glory
summary: Asian tycoons, including Chinese and Indonesian billionaires, are investing heavily in European football clubs, often taking on debt to do so. These "vanity purchases" have raised questions about the economic rationale behind such investments. Despite the financial struggles of some clubs, such as Espanyol and Inter Milan, Asian investors are attracted to the popularity and potential for growth of European football. Experts warn that the high costs of buying a European club, combined with UEFA's financial fair play rules, may limit the number of Asian investors able to take control of top-tier teams.

site_title: Toshiba swings to operating loss, sues former CEOs over accounting scandal
summary: Toshiba reported a second-quarter operating loss of 79.5 billion yen, down from a 90.2 billion yen profit last year, due to sluggish sales of home appliances and a writedown for a business. The company sued five former executives, including three former CEOs, over their roles in a $1.3 billion accounting scandal, claiming they overstated profits. The executives have denied involvement. Toshiba also reported a dismal performance mainly due to the scandal and mismanagement.

site_title: Viva la Volvo
summary: The Volvo V60 Cross Country T5 is a practical high-riding wagon with improved handling and ride comfort. The raised version of the V60 features increased ground clearance, a rugged design, and new 18-inch alloy wheels. The V60 CC has a spacious cabin, generous luggage space, and a comfortable interior. Under the bonnet, it has a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 245hp and 350Nm of torque, allowing for enthusiastic acceleration and smooth handling despite its weight.

site_title: US rejection of Keystone pipeline won't sour Canada ties
summary: US President Barack Obama announced the rejection of the Keystone XL pipeline, a major energy project linking Canadian crude oil to the US Gulf Coast. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau downplayed the decision, stating it won't sour bilateral ties, which have been nearly a century strong. The rejection marks the first major rift in Canada-US energy cooperation, but Trudeau emphasized the relationship is "much bigger than any one project."

site_title: NY investigating Exxon over climate statements
summary: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has launched an investigation into Exxon Mobil Corp over alleged climate change misrepresentations. Schneiderman subpoenaed the company, seeking extensive financial records and documents. The investigation aims to determine if Exxon misled the public and shareholders about climate risks.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher after strong US jobs data
summary: European stock markets ended higher on Friday, driven by stronger-than-expected US jobs data, which boosted the dollar and lifted export-oriented stocks. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.27%, while the Euro STOXX 50 index gained 0.6%. Richemont plummeted after warning of tough times ahead. The strong US jobs data also boosted prospects for a US interest rate hike next month, sending Wall Street shares lower.

site_title: Public's view in masterplanning of limited use, say specialists
summary: Singapore urban planning specialists emphasize that local communities should not have significant involvement in city master plans, as this could lead to poor decisions. They suggest that planners should take a stand and prioritize their expertise. The specialists' stance is based on their experience with community participation, which they believe can be time-consuming and may not always align with the best interests of the city.

site_title: When public companies mimic private firms
summary: Public companies are shunning short-term gains for long-term performance, mirroring private firms. Companies like Dell and Uber are raising funds without going public, while others, such as Berkshire Hathaway and Amazon, are prioritizing long-term growth over quarterly earnings. This approach allows executives to take risks and invest more without being tied to short-term market pressures. Companies like Seacor Holdings and Middleby, which focus on long-term growth, outperform public companies. Berkshire Hathaway's long-term approach, exemplified by Warren Buffett's investment philosophy, produces better results, with the company's insurance businesses and railroad assets generating strong returns.

site_title: Goldman's new tack to retain junior bankers
summary: Goldman Sachs is introducing a three-part initiative to retain junior bankers, aiming to make the company an attractive career destination. The measures include streamlining mundane tasks, a 12-month rotation program after two years, and accelerated promotions to associate after two years with increased compensation. The goal is to hire and retain top talent, with David Solomon, co-head of investment banking, emphasizing the need for thoughtful human capital management. The new policies follow recent salary increases and changes to working hours.

site_title: Store and more
summary: Top beauty brands are opening standalone boutiques offering more than just products, providing makeovers, facials, and mini brand museums. Examples include Dior's Beauty House at Changi Airport, offering complimentary treatments, and La Prairie's boutique with a bar providing refreshments. Other brands, like Shilla Duty Free, are part of a luxury spa concept offering treatments to jetlagged travelers. These monobrand stores aim to replace traditional beauty shopping experiences, providing an immersive and personalized experience for customers.

site_title: Probe vehicle emission rule breaches: EC
summary: The European Commission has written to EU countries urging them to widen investigations into potential breaches of vehicle emissions rules after Volkswagen admitted to understating carbon dioxide levels and fuel consumption in about 800,000 vehicles. The Commission is seeking facts and enforcement of existing legislation, as public trust is at stake. Volkswagen's design chief has also quit, amid a scandal that has plunged the company's shares by as much as a third. The EU is also working on reforms to tighten emissions rules.

site_title: HK home prices rise for 6th straight month to record high in Sept
summary: Hong Kong's home prices rose for the 6th consecutive month to a record high in September, increasing 14.9% from last year. The official index of overall private home prices reached 305.9 points, up 0.7 percentage points month-over-month. Despite a 47% drop in overall home transactions in October, analysts attribute the slowdown to concerns over an expected interest rate hike and increased housing supply.

site_title: Square IPO priced at 30 per cent discount to last private funding
summary: Square Inc., a mobile payments company, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at a 30% discount to its last private funding valuation, setting a price range of $11-$13 per share. The company expects to raise $372.6 million and be valued at $3.9 billion. The lower price range is attributed to concerns over competition, financial results, and the limited time CEO Jack Dorsey can devote to the company due to his role at Twitter. The IPO is expected to begin trading before the Thanksgiving holiday in late November.

site_title: Berlin moves to protect its Wall from souvenir-hunters
summary: Berlin plans to build a 1.3-kilometer-long barrier to protect the East Side Gallery, a 1.3-kilometer-long stretch of the Berlin Wall with over 100 murals, from vandalism. The barrier, costing 150,000 euros, will be 1.3 meters from the wall and is intended to keep tourists at a distance, citing a sharp rise in vandalism by souvenir hunters and graffiti artists. The decision comes after many of the wall's murals were defaced despite recent restoration efforts, with officials blaming foreign tourists for the destruction.

site_title: Germany's September industrial output in biggest drop in a year
summary: Germany's industrial output dropped by 1.1% in September, the largest decline in over a year, amid a slowdown in emerging markets. This marks the second consecutive monthly fall in production and defies expectations for a rise. Economists attribute the decline to weaker foreign demand and a lack of industry support for growth. Despite this, consumption is seen as a potential lifeline for the economy, which is expected to grow by 1.7% this year and 1.8% next year. The data suggests a year-end chill for the European economy.

site_title: A house of God for a debate on inequality? That's profane
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde and former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers held a debate on economic inequality at the Washington National Cathedral, sparking controversy over the use of a sacred space for secular discussions. Critics argue that the cathedral, a symbol of Christian reverence, should not be used for such debates, which could dilute its spiritual significance. The author suggests that the focus on economic inequality, while important, should not be conflated with Christian teachings, which prioritize reverence and respect for a higher power.

site_title: US dollar hits seven-month high on jobs data; oil slumps
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-month high after the release of strong jobs data, which showed a 271,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls and a 9-cent rise in average hourly earnings. The unemployment rate fell to 5.0%, its lowest since April 2008, boosting expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. This led to a 1.26% rise in the dollar index, with oil prices also dropping. The strong jobs report increases the likelihood of a Fed rate hike, potentially ending seven years of easy monetary policy.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q3 net profit rises 9.9% as revenue falls
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 net profit rose 9.9% to S$133.26 million, driven by a 9.9% increase in net profit. However, revenue fell 3.4% to S$1.5 billion due to poor performance in land systems and marine sectors.

site_title: Chinese drones in Silicon Valley show governments' startup fever
summary: China is successfully testing its startups in the US market before investing heavily, as seen with EHANG's US$42 million funding round. This approach has led to the creation of at least 20 billion-dollar firms in China, such as Xiaomi and Didi Kuaidi. Other countries, like Chile and Berlin, are also adopting similar programs, with varying results. While some, like Chile, have seen a surge in entrepreneurship, others, like Startup Chile, have struggled to create significant companies or retain foreign talent. This public-private blend is being studied by governments worldwide, with no clear formula for replicating Silicon Valley's success.

site_title: Banks here 'well-placed to help China firms'
summary: Singapore banks are well-positioned to help Chinese companies expand in ASEAN, according to Minister of Finance Heng Swee Keat. China is Singapore's largest trading partner, with bilateral trade reaching $92 billion last year. Singapore's market infrastructure supports the hedging needs of the Chinese community, and the country is the largest offshore RMB hub after Hong Kong. The Bank of China has launched two global commodity business centers in Singapore, offering commodity financial solutions and services. Strong interest has been shown in RMB funding, with over 60% of Singapore's RQFII quota approved for Chinese companies.

site_title: Branding is vital, and so is purpose
summary: The article discusses the evolving role of business and branding in addressing customers' deeper concerns. Purpose has become a key aspect of branding, with companies like Unilever, P&G, and Virgin promoting their social and environmental responsibilities. However, recent scandals, such as Volkswagen's emissions scandal and Amazon's "bruising" workplace practices, have raised questions about the effectiveness of purpose-driven branding. Consumers are increasingly outraged when companies fail to live up to their purpose and core values, leading to boycotts and calls for greater accountability. The article concludes that businesses must address social, economic, and political issues to win customer loyalty and create sustainable competitive advantage.

site_title: China marks global chip ambitions with US$13b share sale
summary: China has raised US$13 billion through a private placement to fund the construction of a chip plant and expansion, marking a significant step towards creating a national champion in global semiconductors. The move is seen as crucial to national security and aims to reduce the country's dependence on foreign technology. However, analysts note that China lacks mainstream DRAM and NAND Flash technologies, which are held by international giants such as Samsung and Micron. The plan is expected to bankroll a move into the mainstream memory market.

site_title: After Funtasy Island, it's South Oceans now
summary: A new resort, South Oceans, is set to launch on Rompin, Malaysia's East Coast, near Tioman Island. The 486-hectare development, backed by Funtasy Island's promoters, will feature a 5.5km private beachfront, landed properties, condominiums, a hotel, and a theme park. The project aims to attract investors and developers, with luxury residential components expected to drive growth. The South Oceans consortium has seen significant growth in Funtasy Island's land value, rising from S$6 psf to S$350 psf over five years.

site_title: Picasso sells for US$67.45m in windfall for tycoon
summary: American billionaire Bill Koch sold a Picasso painting, La Gommeuse, for US$67.45 million at a New York auction, scoring a windfall after discovering a second painting hidden on the reverse in 2000. Koch initially paid US$3 million for the canvas in 1984. The sale was the top lot of the season, following other notable sales including a Vincent van Gogh for US$54 million and a Roy Lichtenstein pop art masterpiece estimated at US$80 million.

site_title: StarHub: profit up, in talks with Netflix
summary: StarHub reported a 21.5% gain in third-quarter net profit to S$118.7 million, driven by improved equipment sales and a one-time deconsolidation gain. The telco is in talks with Netflix to offer its content in Singapore in 2016. Revenue rose 1.9% to S$603.1 million, with service revenue increasing 1% and mobile revenue declining 0.1%. StarHub maintains an interim dividend payout of 5 Singapore cents per share and expects service revenue to remain at 2014 levels.

site_title: US rate fears trim STI's gain for the week
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on interest rate hikes weighed on Singapore stocks, dragging the Straits Times Index (STI) lower on Thursday and Friday. The STI recorded a net gain of 12 points, with low volume and a 13.18-point drop on Friday. Banks reported third-quarter figures, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising but falling on Friday. Nomura expressed concern over potential outflows from emerging-market banks in the event of a US interest rate hike, but investors are also looking beyond immediate concerns for growth potential.

site_title: Encouraging demand for premium economy so far: SIA management
summary: Singapore Airlines' premium economy product has seen encouraging take-up, particularly on long-haul flights to Australia and London. The airline plans to introduce a third direct US destination, besides New York and Los Angeles, in 2018 with the Airbus A350 ultra-long-range variant. The carrier also reported a net profit of S$213.6 million in its second-quarter results, driven by higher dividends from long-term investments. Despite challenging long-haul markets in Europe, SIA expects losses from hedging to decline in the second half of the financial year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK regulator censures Credit Suisse and law firms over Bumi deal
summary: The UK's takeover regulator censured Credit Suisse and law firms Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer and Holman Fenwick Willan for their roles in advising on the creation of Bumi, a coal mining company formed in 2011 through a $3 billion merger. The regulator found that the advisers failed to seek the panel's view on whether the Bakrie family and Roeslani were acting in concert, leading to a series of breaches of Britain's Takeover Code. Credit Suisse accepted the findings and cooperated with the investigation, while JPMorgan Chase was deemed to have acted "disappointingly" but not seriously enough to warrant public censure.

site_title: X change
summary: The BMW X1 has undergone significant changes in its styling and platform for its second generation. The new model features a front-wheel-drive or all-wheel-drive architecture, allowing for better interior packaging and increased cabin space. Despite being 38mm shorter in length, the X1 now offers more rear knee room and a more spacious interior. The new FWD/AWD architecture has also enabled BMW to maximize cabin space while minimizing its footprint, positioning the X1 as a more versatile urban SUV.

site_title: Rate cuts and lower currency supporting growth: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has stated that interest-rate cuts this year and the currency's depreciation are supporting growth, indicating interest rates are likely to remain on hold. The RBA lowered its inflation forecast for the year through June 2016 and trimmed its growth forecast by a quarter point at the start and end of the period.

site_title: A colourful palette
summary: Chef Massimo Bottura, a 53-year-old Italian chef, incorporates art into his food to convey a message and express culture. His dishes, such as Tribute to Thelonious Monk, are inspired by artists like Damien Hirst and Ai Weiwei. Bottura's cooking philosophy is rooted in his traditional Italian background but also incorporates molecular gastronomic techniques. He believes in transforming the past to create a new tradition for the future, rather than preserving it nostalgically. His restaurant, Osteria Francescana, has won multiple awards, including number two on the San Pellegrino World's 50 Best Restaurants list.

site_title: SCC could lose its top 2 office-bearers in spat
summary: The Singapore Cricket Club (SCC) is facing internal strife, with a special general meeting (SGM) scheduled for November 12 to potentially oust its president and deputy president. The move is in response to grievances over the club's membership structure, including a plan to reduce the number of "sports members" and a proposed change in criteria for approving new sports members. If the proposed ousters fail, the club will seek a no-confidence vote against the seven general committee members who signed the requisition for the SGM.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: SIA draws Tiger under its wing, seeks to delist the unit
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) is making a conditional general offer for Tiger Airways shares at 41 Singapore cents apiece, seeking to delist and privatize the budget carrier to promote integration across its four airlines. The offer also includes an option to subscribe for SIA shares at $11.1043 per share. The move aims to bring Tiger under SIA's wing and push for closer integration, paving the way for delisting and privatization.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Infrastructure firms gloomy despite better economic data in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure firms remain gloomy despite a 4.73% annual growth rate in the third quarter, the country's fastest pace this year. Stronger state spending has lifted the economy, but firms say it's not enough to improve business. Government capital spending rose to $3.76 billion in July-September, but over 70% of the budget remains unspent. Parliament approved $22 billion in capital spending for 2016, but lawmakers vetoed injections for state-owned enterprises, likely to slow infrastructure upgrades next year. Firms rely on government contracts to counter sluggish commercial sales.

site_title: Mahathir questioned by police but refuses to answer on lawyers' advice
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was questioned by police on Friday over his criticism of current Prime Minister Najib Razak, but declined to answer due to his lawyers' advice. Mahathir was quizzed for about 45 minutes at a charity foundation where he has an office. The police asked "general" questions, and Mahathir's lawyer stated that the statement-taking "went well." The incident highlights the tension between Mahathir and Najib, who have been at odds over various issues.

site_title: Perennial posts quarterly net profit of S$4.78m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a net profit of S$4.78 million for the quarter ended Sept 30, driven by strong performance at CHIJMES and TripleOne Somerset in Singapore and Perennial Jihua Mall in China. Revenue reached S$22.9 million, with Singapore assets contributing 65.1% and Chinese assets 30.6%. The group expects enhancement works at TripleOne Somerset and AXA Tower to commence in the first quarter of next year, while construction on Perennial International Health and Medical Hub in China is expected to be completed in 2017.

site_title: Risking your neck to run with the unicorns
summary: US startups that achieve a $1 billion valuation, known as "unicorns," are drawing significant attention from venture capital firms and top talent. As of 2015, 41 companies are valued at exactly $1 billion, and 103 startups have exceeded this valuation. However, the number is not solely based on financial data, but rather a combination of factors. This valuation milestone can significantly impact a startup's growth and success, making it a coveted goal in the tech industry.

site_title: Australia plans for Asian 'dining boom' as food exports surge
summary: Australia's food exports surged by a quarter to A$26 billion, driven by a falling currency and US dry spell, exceeding expectations. This growth is expected to please policymakers as the country shifts from mining to non-mining sectors. Australia's A$1.6 trillion economy has slowed, but the food industry is a promising area for growth, with Asian consumers increasingly seeking higher-quality meat and dairy products.

site_title: The crown jewel of women's tennis
summary: Agnieszka Radwanska won the 2015 BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals in Singapore, defeating Petra Kvitova in three sets to claim the Billie Jean King trophy and a $2.05 million prize. The tournament, held at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, featured the top eight singles players and doubles teams, with Radwanska rising from losing her first two matches to reach the championship. The event saw a record $7 million prize purse and a significant increase in overseas fans, with the WTA aiming to make tennis more engaging and interactive for everyone.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Obama: Bomb may have downed jet
summary: US President Barack Obama suggested a bomb may have caused the Russian passenger jet to crash in Egypt, but Russia and Egypt have slammed such speculation. US intelligence officials and legislators echoed the president's remarks, but cautioned that the cause remains unconfirmed. Western governments have taken steps to protect themselves, with strict new security measures in place for flights to Egypt. An official investigation is ongoing, which may take several months to complete, and the Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the crash.

site_title: Jobs report bolsters December rate hike case
summary: The US jobless rate reached a 71/2-year low in October, with non-farm payrolls increasing 271,000, the largest rise since December 2014. Average hourly earnings also increased nine US cents. These solid gains support a case for a December interest rate hike, bolstering the domestic economy.

site_title: Seeking culinary stars
summary: Singapore is close to securing a deal to bring the Michelin Guide to the country, potentially elevating its fine dining scene globally. The deal, in its final stages, could result in Michelin-starred restaurants in Singapore, following years of negotiations. The guide, first published over 100 years ago, rates food quality and does not consider service or ambiance, moving away from its traditional fine dining focus. A successful deal would solidify Singapore's position as a culinary destination, capitalizing on its diverse dining scene.

site_title: Norway SWF mulls over US$86b injection into properties
summary: Norway's $860 billion wealth fund is considering an $86 billion injection into real estate, with a focus on Asia as a growth hotspot. The fund aims to increase its property holdings from 3% to 5% by investing $8.3 billion annually. Despite nominal returns of 7-9% from 2000-2013, the fund notes a declining trend in recent years, citing emerging markets, particularly Asia, as a promising investment opportunity.

site_title: F&N sees weak Asean consumer confidence
summary: Frasers & Neave (F&N) reported a 331% surge in full-year net profit to S$633 million due to a disposal gain from the sale of its Myanmar Brewery stake. The company plans to restructure its loss-making publishing unit by shifting its education business online. Revenue rose 0.5% to S$2.1 billion, driven by the dairies business in Thailand. F&N will pay a final dividend of three Singapore cents per share and expects the printing and publishing segment to report a profit in 2016.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' H1 FY16 core net profit fell short of expectations, with passenger yields declining due to aggressive competition. However, SilkAir, Scoot, and SIA Cargo delivered substantial improvements. ST Engineering reported a 10% net profit increase but revised its FY2015 revenue and profit before tax guidance downwards. Parkway Life Reit's Q3 2016 results showed a 15.6% rise in distributable income and distribution per unit, with the stock offering attractive yields over 5%.

site_title: Jeremy Monteiro takes on ChildAid's music
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, a renowned jazz maestro, has been appointed as the new music director of ChildAid, a children's charity fundraiser. Under his direction, this year's event will have a more jazzy and intimate feel. The concert, held at Marina Bay Sands on Dec 4 and 5, will feature young musicians and performers from Singapore and the region. ChildAid aims to raise funds for its two charities, which provide music lessons and financial assistance to underprivileged children. The event's theme, "Be The Light," reflects the charity's new direction as it enters its second decade.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US: Stocks open lower after strong jobs data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday following a strong job report for October, which boosted expectations for a possible interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next month. The Dow Jones fell 0.17%, the S&P 500 lost 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.08%.

site_title: China c.bank to continue interest rate, exchange rate reforms
summary: China's central bank will maintain the yuan within a reasonable range and continue interest rate and exchange rate reforms. The People's Bank of China aims to further promote foreign institutions issuing onshore yuan bonds. This move is part of efforts to increase yuan's global use and stabilize the currency.

site_title: A nice blend of old and new
summary: Darren Sabom and Sharon Siah, a couple who moved to Singapore from the US, have designed their new home together, blending their styles and ideas. The 1,468 sq ft, two-level apartment in Tanjong Pagar features a dark blue and brass color scheme inspired by Pinterest boards. The design incorporates practical details, such as universal plugs and dimmer switches, with thoughtful touches, like a cat flap and a study under the stairs. The couple's art collection, including a Mark Rothko print, is also on display. They say they enjoy spending more time at home, appreciating the thought that went into designing their space.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Asia's challenges in managing its cities
summary: Asia's cities face significant challenges in managing growth, including reactive urban planning, uncontrolled urban sprawl, and poor governance. Experts warn that this can lead to major infrastructure mishaps and environmental problems. A new multi-disciplinary study aims to challenge the old way of city planning by coalescing different disciplines. Singapore's former urban planner, Liu Thai-Ker, believes that urban planning requires scientific precision and better governance to prevent uncontrolled urban sprawl and ensure sustainable growth. He advocates for proactive urban planning, breaking down mega-cities into smaller ones, and prioritizing environmental sustainability.

site_title: Barclays said to gauge interest for Asia wealth-management sale
summary: Barclays is exploring the sale of its Asian wealth-management business, with several parties expressing interest, according to two individuals familiar with the matter. The move is part of Chairman John McFarlane's efforts to refocus the bank on more profitable US and UK businesses. CEO Jes Staley, set to take over next month, aims to restore profit growth, which has been hindered by rising costs and past misconduct. A sale would put Barclays at odds with other European lenders seeking to tap into the Asian wealth market. A final decision has not been made.

site_title: Airbus flies past 2015 order target two months early
summary: Airbus has exceeded its 2015 order target by two months, with 850 net orders booked from January to October, surpassing the initial 630 orders. Strong demand from China and Singapore contributed to the achievement, with China Aviation Supplies Holding Company ordering 30 A330-300 jets and Singapore Airlines purchasing four A350-900 aircraft. Airbus has 6,741 jets in its order book, equivalent to "ten years of production."

site_title: New world of sports
summary: Decathlon, a French sporting goods brand, is opening its flagship store in Singapore, marking the company's entry into the Southeast Asian market. The 35,000 sq ft store in Chai Chee Technopark will offer a wide range of sports gear and apparel, with a focus on reasonably priced products. Decathlon aims to make sports accessible for all, with a vision to have six large stores and 15,000 sq ft stores in Singapore within 10 years. The company's managing director, Bastien Grandgeorge, stated that prices will be at least 20% cheaper than the competition, with some products up to 40% cheaper. Decathlon has created over 2,000 new products annually and has production centers in 23 countries.

site_title: Youku Tudou agrees to be bought by Alibaba for $27.60/ADS
summary: Youku Tudou Inc, China's YouTube, agrees to be bought by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd for $27.60 per American Depositary Share, following a previous offer of $26.60 per ADS in October. The deal marks a significant expansion for Alibaba, a leading e-commerce giant in China. The acquisition is expected to further solidify Alibaba's position in the country's online video market.

site_title: InterContinental Hotels said to explore deal after interest
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group Plc, the world's largest hotel provider, is exploring strategic options including a potential sale or merger amid a boom in lodging deals. The company, with a market value of 6.4 billion pounds, is discussing with financial advisers whether to sell itself or combine with a competitor. This comes as global lodging transactions have increased 13% to over $28 billion in 2015, with major competitors like Starwood and Hyatt also undergoing bidding wars. No final decision has been made, and the company may choose to stay independent.

site_title: Mutual respect in the workplace crucial for firms' growth: Swee Say
summary: Singapore's employment growth is expected to slow down as the country transitions towards an economy that requires less manpower. Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say emphasized the importance of mutual respect between employees and employers in the workplace, citing a study that found high levels of trust and engagement among employees are synonymous with high-performing work culture. To rise above competing employers, companies should respect and value every worker, show commitment to local society, and balance competitiveness with employee care. This is highlighted by the launch of Singapore's Best Companies to Work for List, which recognized top employers such as Salesforce and Cisco.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint's net profit jumps 54%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd reported a 54% increase in net profit to S$771.27 million for the full year ended Sept 30, 2015, driven by a 28% increase in fair-value change and an exceptional gain. Revenue rose 61.7% to S$3.56 billion, fueled by new income streams from acquisitions and completed projects. The company's strategy to diversify overseas and focus on capital productivity is bearing fruit, with recurring income's share of profit before interest, taxation, fair-value change, and exceptional items increasing to 58%.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Mining in space may cost less than on Earth
summary: A recent study by Australian graduate students suggests that mining in space could be more cost-effective than traditional mining on Earth. The estimated costs for a mission to Ceres, a dwarf planet, range from $27 billion for a full-scale operation to $492 million for capturing near-Earth asteroids. In contrast, building the largest gas terminals on Earth costs around $54 billion. While investors are needed to support the venture, proponents believe that space mining will eventually become a trillion-dollar industry, providing materials for space exploration and colonization.

images.alt_text: MARS, HERE WE COME: The costs of a two-way journey are considered uneconomic and the focus instead is on providing materials for industries operating in space to power the exploration and eventual colonisation of Mars (above).

site_title: KL's prized sushi catch
summary: Kuala Lumpur's St Regis hotel will soon open its first three Michelin-starred restaurant, Taka by Sushi Saito, in April 2024. The restaurant, led by chef Satoshi Uehara, will serve sushi crafted by chef Takashi Saito, known for his three Michelin-starred sushi in Tokyo. Ingredients will be imported from Japan, with reservations expected to be challenging due to Saito's reputation. The restaurant will have a sushi counter made from rare hinoki wood and two private dining rooms, with prices expected to be high due to the authenticity and quality of the ingredients.

site_title: Infrastructure firms gloomy despite improving economic data in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure firms remain pessimistic despite the country's economy growing at 4.73% in the third quarter, its fastest pace this year. Stronger state spending has lifted growth, but firms say it is not enough to overcome bureaucratic obstacles and improve business. Government capital spending rose to $3.76 billion, but over 70% of the budget remains unspent, and lawmakers vetoed capital injections for state-owned enterprises. Firms are counting on government contracts to counter sluggish commercial sales, with some predicting a repeat of this year's delays.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KSH Holdings reported a tripling of net profit in its fiscal second quarter due to recognised profits from a completed China project, with net earnings rising to S$23.2 million. The company plans to pay a special cash dividend and issue bonus shares. Jumbo Group's S$22.1 million IPO was eight times subscribed, while Venture Corp's net profit rose 12.2% for the third quarter. Hong Leong Finance's net interest income gained 8.8% and Lum Chang Holdings posted a four-fold increase in net profit for its fiscal first quarter.

site_title: Kering seen selling stake in Puma after revival falls short
summary: Kering is open to selling its majority stake in Puma after eight years of struggling to turn around the German sporting-goods maker. The company views Puma as peripheral to its long-term strategy, focusing on boosting sales before considering a sale. Kering CEO Francois-Henri Pinault has a history of exiting underperforming investments, and analysts predict a disposal as soon as the second half of 2016, citing a 45% gain in Puma's shares since June. Puma's sales have stagnated at 3 billion euros since 2011, with profitability narrowing under Kering's ownership.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels 290 flights due to cabin staff strike
summary: Lufthansa cancels 290 flights on Friday due to a planned week of strikes by cabin staff in a dispute over cost-saving measures. The 9-hour strike affects Frankfurt and Duesseldorf airports, impacting 37,500 passengers. The airline regrets the decision, citing short notice, and will try to minimize disruption. The union, UFO, plans to stagger walkouts and target different airports over the next seven days, with no action planned on Sunday.

site_title: Perennial posts profit of S$4.78m for quarter ended Sept 30
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings posted a net profit of S$4.78 million for the quarter ended Sept 30, driven by strong performance at CHIJMES and TripleOne Somerset in Singapore, and Perennial Jihua Mall and Perennial Qingyang Mall in China. Singapore assets contributed 65.1% of the group's revenue, while Chinese assets accounted for 30.6%. The company's revenue was S$22.9 million, a year-over-year increase.

site_title: UK manufacturing growth surges to 1-1/2-year high, trade deficit narrows
summary: British manufacturing output surged 0.8% in September, the fastest monthly pace since April 2014, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks a 1-1/2-year high and beats economists' expectations of a 0.4% increase. The country's goods trade deficit also narrowed more than expected. These positive indicators suggest a strengthening economy, but a separate report earlier in the day revealed the UK economy shrank for the second month, casting a fresh blow to Prime Minister Rishi Starmer's government.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns of potential H2 revenue below target and an operating loss similar to the first half, citing market challenges. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, a Trafigura employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case in Indonesia, and Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, CGS Investment Research downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: Japan, US lead rule-making under TPP
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe hailed the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) as a "grand plan for the long-term future of our nation," saying it will bring "transparent and fair rules" of trade among participating economies. The US and Japan are the two biggest economies in the proposed bloc, aiming to break down trade and investment barriers among 12 countries, including Australia, Canada, and Vietnam. The pact now awaits legislative approvals, which could be contentious and lengthy, amidst concerns over China's economic slowdown and potential implications for Japan's agriculture and consumer protection.

images.alt_text: MR ABE: The premier and Japanese experts hail the TPP which should give greater foreign market access for 'Japan Inc'.

site_title: Jumbo Group's IPO nearly eight times subscribed
summary: Jumbo Group's S$22.1 million Catalist IPO was nearly eight times subscribed, with retail investors putting up S$155.2 million for 2 million shares. The company offered 88.23 million shares at S$0.25 apiece, but the placement tranche was not completely filled. This overwhelming demand was driven by retail investors, who sought a piece of the seafood restaurant owner's growth.

site_title: China securities regulator says to resume IPOs
summary: China's securities regulator announced it will resume initial public offerings (IPOs), ending a freeze since early July. The China Securities Regulatory Commission made the announcement at a weekly news conference in Beijing.

site_title: One Audi and 2 Skoda cars found to have emissions-cheating devices: NEA
summary: Audi and two Skoda passenger diesel vehicles imported into Singapore have been found to be fitted with devices to evade government pollution controls, according to the National Environment Agency (NEA). The vehicles, not sold by local car distributors, were directly imported and discovered through a routine inspection. This incident highlights the need for strict enforcement of pollution controls.

site_title: KSH Q2 profit more than triples on China project
summary: KSH Holdings reported a net profit of S$23.2 million for the second quarter, more than tripling from S$6.74 million in the same period last year. The increase was mainly due to higher contributions from associates' business in China, including a S$15.8 million contribution from the Liang Jing Ming Ju Phase 4 project. Revenue fell slightly by 0.9% to S$62.1 million.

site_title: Third Singapore-China joint project to be based in Chongqing: Xi Jinping
summary: Singapore and China are set to launch their third government-led project based in Chongqing, Chinese President Xi Jinping announced. This marks the third collaboration between the two countries, following previous projects in other locations. The exact details of the project were not disclosed.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on the day but higher for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed lower on Thursday and Friday due to US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's comments on interest rate hikes, weighing on stocks. Despite a weekly gain of 12 points to 3,010.47, volume was low. Banks reported third-quarter figures, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising initially but falling on Friday. Fund managers are underweight on Asean banks, according to Nomura. The market is awaiting GDP data and a mandatory offer for PSC shares.

site_title: Lum Chang Q1 profit jumps to S$8.7m as revenue recognition begins at projects
summary: Lum Chang Holdings reported a fourfold increase in net profit to S$8.7 million in its Q1, driven by recognition of revenue from two construction projects. Revenue doubled to S$90.5 million, with S$35.9 million attributed to the projects. The company expects to begin recognizing revenue for a new project in 2016. Shares slipped 2.6% to 37.5 cents per share.

site_title: Germany's Hapag-Lloyd flounders in tepid market debut
summary: Hapag-Lloyd, a German shipping group, made a lukewarm market debut with its shares trading around the issue price of 20 euros apiece. Despite weak demand, the company had postponed its IPO and revised its offering terms. The tepid reception raised concerns about the resilience of capital markets and the shipping sector.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA dips, Tigerair soars as market digests takeover-bid news
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) takeover bid for Tiger Airways has led to a 32.3% surge in Tigerair's counter, closing at 41 Singapore cents. SIA's share price dipped 0.09% to S$11.14 after the market digested the news. The offer price represents a 32% premium over Tiger Airways' last traded price. SIA intends to delist and privatise the budget carrier, citing limited growth prospects independently in the competitive LCC landscape.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) share price shed 0.98 per cent or 11 Singapore cents, falling to S$11.04 by 2.57pm on Friday, following news of its voluntary conditional general offer for all the Tiger Airways shares that it does not already own.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance posts 17.4% gain in Q3 profit, but sets cautious tone
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 17.4% gain in Q3 profit to S$16.8 million, driven by a 18.2% increase in interest on loans to S$59.5 million. The lender maintained a cautious tone, focusing on small and medium enterprises and housing board dwellers. Allowances for doubtful debts rose to S$107.9 million. Despite this, shares closed lower by 1.25% at S$2.37, following a broader market decline.

site_title: Third Singapore-China project to be based in Chongqing: Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced the third Singapore-China government-led project, titled "Modern Connectivity and Modern Services", will be based in Chongqing, a city in western China. The project aims to lower the cost of doing business in China's western region, featuring an integrated logistics center, a modern services demonstration zone, and a smart city. The project follows in the footsteps of existing Singapore-China collaborations, including the 1994 Suzhou Industrial Park and the 2008 Tianjin Eco-City. Xi also welcomed the 50th birthday of Singapore and congratulated the nation on its bilateral ties with China, which he described as reaching a "new historical point".

site_title: Robust US jobs report bolsters December rate hike case
summary: US job growth surged in October with a 271,000 increase, the largest rise since December 2014, and the unemployment rate fell to 5.0%, a 7-1/2-year low. Average hourly earnings rose 9 cents, and construction payrolls increased 31,000. The solid gains support a likely interest rate hike in December, with Fed officials citing a low bar for a rate increase. Economists believe monthly job gains above 150,000 would be sufficient for the central bank to lift benchmark overnight borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: US job growth surged in October after two straight months of tepid gains, with the unemployment rate hitting a 7-1/2-year low in a show of domestic strength that makes it almost likely the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates in December.

site_title: Maersk Q2 profit in line with forecast, keeps outlook
summary: Maersk reported a third-quarter net profit of $778 million, in line with analyst forecasts. The Danish shipping and oil group maintained its full-year profit guidance, despite cutting its outlook two weeks ago to $3.4 billion from $4.0 billion. The company's profit fell slightly below its previous forecast.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,685.70 after losing 2.84 points. Despite 2.3 billion lots valued at RM2.0 billion being traded, gainers outnumbered losers 500 to 388.

site_title: F&N full-year profit surges on Myanmar disposal gain
summary: F&N's full-year net profit surged to S$633 million, driven by a disposal gain of S$542 million from the sale of its 55% stake in Myanmar Brewery Limited. Revenue increased 0.5% to S$2.1 billion. The company recommended a final dividend of 3 cents per share, unchanged from a year ago. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous year's loss of S$147 million.

site_title: Venture Q3 profit grows 12.2% on favourable market share, exchange rates
summary: VENTURE Corp reported a 12.2% increase in Q3 net profit to S$40.5 million, driven by favourable market share and exchange rates. Revenue rose 15.7% to S$692.9 million. The company gained share among existing customers and added new customers, benefiting from exchange rates. For the nine-month period, net profit grew 8.7% to S$109.2 million.

site_title: Xi Jinping arrives in Singapore on eve of China-Taiwan summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Singapore on November 6, 2015, for a state visit ahead of an historic summit with Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou. The visit coincides with Singapore's 25th anniversary of diplomatic ties with Beijing. Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan were greeted with full military honors and a state banquet at Changi Airport. The summit is seen as a significant development in China-Taiwan relations, with Singapore playing a key role in facilitating the historic meeting.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady before US jobs data
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Friday, with all eyes on US jobs data due before the weekend break. London's FTSE 100 index opened unchanged, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 indices dipped 0.14% and 0.30% respectively. The focus is on US jobs data, which may influence the markets' direction.

site_title: Tencent said to pick five banks to underwrite US$1.5 billion loan
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. has selected five banks to underwrite a US$1.5 billion five-year syndicated loan, according to people familiar with the matter. The banks are Australia & New Zealand Banking Group, Bank of China, Citigroup, HSBC, and Mizuho. This loan will be used to fund Tencent's expansion into online services and entertainment. The company's messaging services WeChat and QQ have over 1 billion users, and it is seeking new revenue sources through streaming entertainment and online commerce.

site_title: Nikkei 225 index closes at highest level in over two months
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index reached its highest level in over two months, closing at 19,265.60, driven by a weak yen that lifted Japanese exporters. The yen's decline, amid speculation of higher interest rates in the US, made Japanese exporters more competitive and inflated repatriated profits. The dollar rose to 121.90 yen, while the euro slipped to $1.0871. This move is seen as a positive for Japan, and traders are shrugging off weak US jobs data ahead, with the probability of a US interest rate hike increasing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines announced a voluntary offer to delist and privatize budget carrier Tiger Airways. Singapore's stock exchange is investigating potential spoofing in derivatives markets. Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou agreed to split the bill after a historic dinner in Singapore, illustrating the delicate protocol balance between the two leaders. Bank of China and Singapore's International Enterprise signed a memorandum of understanding to boost commodity financing cooperation. The Straits Times Index ended lower on Thursday and Friday, with a weekly gain of 12 points, due to comments by US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen on interest rate hikes.

site_title: Bank of China, Singapore boost commodity financing cooperation
summary: Bank of China and Singapore's International Enterprise signed a memorandum of understanding to boost commodity financing cooperation, aiming to develop Singapore's trading and financial sectors. China seeks to increase its commodity sector presence, while Singapore is Asia's main oil trading hub. The partnership aims to enhance trade and investment between the two countries.

site_title: Hong Kong charges hotel owner in US$26m fraud on China's biggest lender
summary: Hong Kong's anti-corruption body has charged hotel owner Lau Hei-wing with defrauding China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) of HK$200 million (S$36.2 million) by making false statements to obtain loans for hotel renovations between February and April 2010. Lau faces three counts of fraud and was released on bail pending a court appearance. The incident allegedly involved Lau falsely claiming the funds would be used exclusively for renovation, but details of the alleged fraud and current whereabouts of the funds are unknown.

site_title: Eurozone inflationary pressures fading: ECRI indicator
summary: Eurozone inflationary pressures have faded further, according to the Eurozone Future Inflation Gauge (EFZIG), which dipped to 98.5 in September. Despite the European Central Bank's bond-buying program, eurozone prices remained flat year-on-year in October, indicating the need for further monetary policy easing. Economists predict the ECB will ease again in December, increasing or extending its stimulus program.

site_title: StarHub Q3 profit grows 21.5% on equipment sales, one-time gain
summary: StarHub reported a 21.5% increase in net profit to S$118.7 million for the third quarter, driven by higher equipment sales and a one-time gain from deconsolidating a subsidiary. The company maintained an interim dividend payout of 5 cents per share and expects a cumulative full-year dividend of 20 cents per share. This marks a 5.5% increase in nine-month net profit to S$291.5 million.

site_title: Faster immigration clearance for eligible Chinese travellers when entering Singapore
summary: Singapore has announced that eligible Chinese travellers will be able to clear immigration faster when entering the country starting November 16. The Immigration Automated Clearance System will allow travellers to pass through automated gates, streamlining the immigration process. This move aims to enhance the travel experience for Chinese visitors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down, braced for US jobs data
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.8% on Friday, mirroring Asian losses, ahead of US employment data expected to boost the case for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Hang Seng index closed at 22,867.33, down from the week's 1.05% gain. Investors braced for potential rate hike news, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Japan, US lead economic rule-making under TPP: Japan PM
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe hailed the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a massive Pacific Rim free-trade deal, as a bid by Japan and the US to set global economic rules. The agreement, which includes 12 countries comprising 40% of the global economy, aims to break down trade and investment barriers. Abe said the TPP will bring "transparent and fair rules" of trade and will give Japan greater foreign market access. The deal now awaits legislative approvals in each member country, potentially a contentious and lengthy process.

site_title: Singapore can continue to play catalytic role in promoting yuan use: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore can continue to play a significant role in promoting the use of the yuan in Southeast Asia, according to Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat. At the China and Singapore Commodity and RMB Summit, Heng emphasized that Singapore's banks are well-positioned to help Chinese entities expand in the region. Several new initiatives were also launched during the event.

site_title: Indonesia auto industry urges cheaper biodiesel price
summary: Indonesia's government needs to increase subsidies for biodiesel fuel to make it cheaper than regular diesel to boost its take-up and cut oil import bills. The country aims to increase biodiesel subsidies to achieve a 20% bio content in transport fuel by 2016 and 30% by 2020. Despite the push, motorists prefer regular diesel, and analysts question the government's ability to enforce its targets. The government expects to raise $700 million next year from a new CPO export levy, but biodiesel is sold at the same price as diesel, and production costs are higher.

images.alt_text: Fuel tank drivers wait to load their cargo at a state-owned Pertamina fuel depot in Jakarta, in this Sept 9, 2014.

site_title: Julius Baer would consider partnerships in China, Collardi says
summary: Swiss asset manager Julius Baer Group Ltd is considering strategic partnerships or direct investments in China to expand its business, according to CEO Boris Collardi.
