The firm may set up its own operation in a free-trade zone or invest in local financial-technology businesses. China's millionaire wealth is expected to grow by 12% annually to $8.25 trillion by 2020, making it a lucrative market for private banks like Julius Baer. This move comes as European private banks prioritize managing money for affluent individuals in Asia, amid a slow Chinese GDP growth and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint net profit up 54% to S$771m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited reported a 54% increase in net profit to S$771.27 million for the full year ended Sept 30, 2015. Revenue rose 61.7% to S$3.56 billion, driven by new income streams from the acquisition of Australand and hotels. The growth was also fueled by the sale of Crosspoint mall in Beijing and completions of residential developments in China and Singapore. The company attributed the increase to a 28% year-on-year increase in fair value change and an exceptional gain of S$7.8 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Property group Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) has posted a 54 per cent increase in net profit to S$771.27 million for the full year ended Sept 30, 2015.

site_title: China: Stocks surge for 3rd day on strong financials
summary: China's stocks surged for the third consecutive day, with the CSI300 index rising 2.4% to 3,793.37 and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 1.9% to 3,590.03 points. The rally has driven trading volumes to a three-month high, with the composite index up 25% from its August trough. The strong financials of blue chip companies, particularly securities brokerages, are fueling the market's momentum, marking the CSI300's best week since early June.

site_title: Japan's Abe urges China to press ahead with structural reform
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged China to continue structural reform and maintain transparency, despite economic slowdown concerns. Abe emphasized China's development is crucial for global growth and stated Japan will provide support as needed. He also reported Japan's economy is nearing the end of two decades of deflation, with yen strength corrected.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won slip ahead of US payrolls data
summary: South Korean shares and the won slipped ahead of US jobs data, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) edging 0.4% lower to 2,041.07 points. Foreigners and domestic institutions sold 50 billion won and 144 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, respectively. The won was quoted at 1,141.9 to the dollar, down from Thursday's close of 1,138.5. Market participants await US jobs data for clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting in December.

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy ZS Pharma for US$2.7 billion in cash deal
summary: AstraZeneca agreed to buy ZS Pharma for $2.7 billion in cash, acquiring a potential blockbuster medicine for a deadly blood condition. The deal gives AstraZeneca a medicine, ZS-9, for hyperkalaemia, with sales potential exceeding $1 billion. The acquisition complements AstraZeneca's focus on cardiovascular and metabolic disease, and is expected to close by the end of the year, generating sales from next year and contributing to core earnings from 2018.

site_title: China's Xi and Taiwan's Ma go Dutch in historic dinner in Singapore
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou held a historic summit in Singapore, marking the first time the two leaders have met in person. The summit aimed to reduce tensions between the two sides, who have been divided since the 1949 civil war. To maintain the delicate protocol balance, the leaders will split the bill, address each other as "mister," and avoid joint press briefings. The talks will cover cross-strait security and domestic affairs, with no "secret deals or promises" expected, and will focus on establishing a mechanism for regular talks between leaders across the strait.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees 2015 GDP growth at lower range of 4.7%-5.1%
summary: Indonesia's central bank has revised its 2015 GDP growth forecast to the lower end of its 4.7-5.1% target, citing slower-than-expected growth in the third quarter. The bank's governor, Agus Martowardojo, maintained its 2016 growth forecast at 5.2-5.6%. This follows the release of July-September growth data, which showed 4.73% expansion, below the bank's initial estimate of 4.85%. The central bank's revised forecast suggests a slower economic expansion than initially anticipated.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses as Fed spurs rate hike talk
summary: Oil prices dropped for a second consecutive day, with Brent crude falling to $47.98 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate falling to $45.20 a barrel, amid concerns over abundant supplies and a stronger dollar following Federal Reserve hints of interest rate hikes.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher, bank bargains lead turnaround
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Friday, reversing an early sell-off, as profit-takers bought cheap bank stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to close at 5,215.0, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index fell 0.1%. The week's decline was 0.5% for the Australian index and 1.3% for the New Zealand index. Bank stocks, particularly Asciano, saw a surge due to heightened takeover interest.

site_title: Dollar holds gains ahead of key US jobs reports
summary: The US dollar remains at two-month highs against the yen and has risen against emerging currencies ahead of the October employment report, which is expected to show job growth strengthened to 181,000 new payrolls. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has stated that a rate hike in December is a "live possibility" if data shows a solid expansion in the US economy. Market sentiment has driven dollar-buying momentum, with the dollar trading at 121.66 yen, up from below 120 yen in recent weeks.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; tech, banks down
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell by nearly 1% on Friday, following a cautious investor sentiment ahead of US employment data that may lead to a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The TAIEX index closed at 8,762.9, with the electronics and financials subindices losing 1% and 1.2% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.71 points to 1686.35. The index saw 65 million lots traded worth RM16.5 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 113 to 66.

site_title: Update: Singapore looking into potential spoofing in derivatives markets
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, is reviewing potential incidents of spoofing in its derivatives market following complaints of dishonest trading practices. The exchange is evaluating possible cases of market participants making orders and cancelling them before execution. SGX's chief regulatory officer, Tan Boon Gin, is examining whether the existing false-trading laws are strong enough to prosecute spoofers, and considers introducing a spoofing law. The review comes amid a recent surge in spoofing cases in the US and amid ongoing efforts to prevent a similar stock crash to the 2013 event.

site_title: Seoul district to erect "Gangnam Style" statue
summary: A statue of Psy's signature horse-riding dance move from his 2012 hit song "Gangnam Style" will be erected in Seoul's Gangnam district, where the music video was shot. The metal sculpture, consisting of two giant fists, is set to be unveiled next month outside the COEX shopping and exhibition center. The statue aims to commemorate the song's global impact and its association with the upscale district.

site_title: US creator of the iconic 1960s Batmobile dies
summary: George Barris, the 89-year-old creator of the iconic 1960s Batmobile, has died in Los Angeles. Known as the "King of the Kustomizers," Barris designed vehicles for various TV shows and movies, including "Knight Rider" and "North by Northwest." He founded Barris Kustom Industries in 1945 and built the Batmobile from a 1955 Lincoln Futura concept sedan in just two weeks. The 1960s Batmobile sold at auction for over $4 million in 2013. Barris passed away at home in his sleep on Thursday, according to his son Brett's Facebook announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 1.01 points higher, 0.03% up, at 3,024.66, driven by early morning gains in Jardine Cycle & Carriage, Haw Par Corporation, and Singapore O&G. The trading session saw 56.1 million shares worth S$82.7 million changing hands, with 66 gainers and 61 losers.

site_title: Former Malaysian Premier Mahathir to speak to police on probes
summary: Former Malaysian Premier Mahathir Mohamad is set to speak to police on Friday as authorities investigate him for potential defamation over his criticisms of Prime Minister Najib Razak. The probes relate to Section 500 of the penal code, and authorities opened several investigation papers after reports were made against Mahathir. This marks the latest development in the ongoing controversy surrounding Mahathir's comments, which have been seen as a challenge to Najib's leadership.

site_title: Designer cells reverse baby girl's cancer in world first
summary: A one-year-old British girl, Layla Richards, has become the world's first patient to be treated with "designer" immune cells genetically engineered to reverse her cancer, Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia. The treatment, using gene-editing technique UCART19, was successful after a small infusion of the cells was given to the girl. Doctors say the results are potentially very promising, but caution that the technique needs to be replicated. The treatment is a major breakthrough in treating leukaemia and other cancers, offering a new hope for children with aggressive forms of the disease.

site_title: Oil halts drop near US$45 after biggest two-day slide in three weeks
summary: Oil prices halted their slide near US$45 a barrel after a 5.6% drop over two days, the largest decline in three weeks. US stockpiles expanded for a sixth week, exceeding 100 million barrels above the five-year seasonal average. Saudi Arabia increased crude pricing for December sales to Asia, while a possible US interest-rate increase remains a possibility for 2015. Experts say the market needs a supply-side response, and prices may continue to fluctuate in a range of US$43-50 a barrel.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won nearly flat; US jobs report in focus
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.2% to 2,045.57 points, while the won remained steady, as investors awaited the US monthly non-farm payrolls report. Pharmaceutical stocks rose, with Hanmi Pharmaceutical surging 30.0% after a deal with Sanofi. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares worth 29.4 billion won, weighing on the index. The chances of a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve are now considered "live" after Fed officials noted the economy is ready for higher rates.

site_title: "Hope to see you again": China warship to US destroyer after South China Sea patrol
summary: A Chinese warship shadowed a US destroyer, USS Lassen, in the South China Sea after it breached 12-nautical-mile territorial limits around a Chinese man-made island. The Chinese ship demanded to know the US intention, and the crew replied they were conducting a freedom-of-navigation exercise under international law. The exchange repeated multiple times. The US operation aimed to challenge China's claims to the strategic waterway, and the incident highlights tensions between the two nations in the region.

site_title: China's industrial sector 'facing increasing downward pressure': Ministry
summary: China's industrial sector is facing increasing downward pressure due to weak demand, sliding investment, and falling exports. The producer price index (PPI) has been declining, adding to operational difficulties for firms. To address this, the industry ministry plans to encourage firms to merge and restructure, and promote automobile purchasing. The ministry also recommends firms look overseas for opportunities to mitigate the downward pressure. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.41% up as weaker yen lifts sentiment
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.41% higher on Friday, driven by a weaker yen, despite a negative lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 77.93 points to 19,194.34. This continues the stock's rise from the previous day, as investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's stance.

site_title: Add a fund to Amazon Cart? You have Indian regulator's support
summary: The Securities & Exchange Board of India plans to allow online marketplaces like Flipkart and Amazon to sell mutual funds, aiming to increase online investment among Indian savers. The move is expected to provide a new distribution channel for mutual funds and help young investors who prefer shopping online. The regulator's decision could challenge traditional distributors' control over the asset management industry, but Chairman UK Sinha stated that the goal is to provide an additional avenue for investors without favoring one group over another.

site_title: Violence as anti-capitalist march hits London
summary: Thousands of anti-capitalist activists gathered in central London for the "Million Mask March" on Thursday night, resulting in clashes with police and the setting of a police car ablaze. Demonstrators, wearing white Guy Fawkes masks, chanted slogans and threw fireworks and bottles at police, with 28 arrests made and three injured officers hospitalized. The march, which also saw scuffles and arrests last year, aimed to protest inequality, with organizers stating that violence was not part of their movement.

site_title: Metered paywalls set for LA Times, Tribune dailies
summary: Tribune Publishing, parent of the Los Angeles Times and Chicago Tribune, plans to implement "metered paywalls" at its newspapers, allowing limited free access to articles and replacing the traditional premium paywall. The move aims to boost digital revenues and connect with readers. The company has been struggling financially since its split from the Tribune Co conglomerate, and speculation persists about potential sales of its prized Los Angeles daily or the entire group.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on Friday, following a weak lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index fell 1.0% to 22,819.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.24% to 3,514.44. This was after hopes for economic reforms in China were met with skepticism. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over US-China trade talks and the ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Standard Chartered's shares plunge 7% after Fitch downgrade
summary: Standard Chartered's shares plummeted 7% in Hong Kong after Fitch Ratings downgraded the bank due to "unfavourable profitability and asset quality trends". The London-based lender plans to raise $5.1 billion, cut thousands of jobs, and eliminate risky assets in Asia. This year's decline in shares extends to 35%, with the benchmark Hang Seng Index also slipping 0.9%. The downgrade follows Standard Chartered's recent announcements to raise capital and reduce risk.

site_title: Sparks fly as fight begins in the US over TPP trade deal
summary: The US is set to face opposition over the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, with opponents citing concerns over labor rights, environmental protections, and patent protections for drug companies. The deal, which includes Japan, Australia, and 9 other Pacific economies, has been released to the public after being kept secret during negotiations. Protests are scheduled for November 16, and Senator Bernie Sanders has vowed to defeat the deal, citing its potential to harm US jobs and workers. The White House faces a tough fight in seeking ratification from Congress, with many Republicans warning of giving away too much to other countries.

site_title: Man charged with sending fake tweets to manipulate stocks
summary: A Scottish man, James Alan Craig, has been charged with sending fake tweets on Twitter to manipulate stocks, resulting in losses of over $1.6 million for shareholders. He used names similar to real market research firms to spread false information about companies. The charges were made by US prosecutors in San Francisco.

images.alt_text: A Scottish man was charged by US prosecutors with sending fake posts on Twitter Inc to manipulate stocks that he then traded.

site_title: A conduit for strong business links
summary: Singapore and Germany have strengthened their business ties over the past 50 years, with Germany becoming Singapore's top trading partner in the European Union. The Singapore-German Chamber of Industry and Commerce (SGC) has played a key role in promoting bilateral trade and investment. With the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement set to be implemented in 2016 and the Asean Economic Community (AEC) aiming for regional economic integration, Mr. Huppenbauer sees tremendous potential for more investment flows between the two countries.

site_title: US to call for tighter security at foreign airports: ABC News
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security is expected to call for tighter security measures at foreign airports with direct flights to the US, possibly as soon as Friday. The proposed measures include better baggage screening at major domestic US airports. This comes after President Barack Obama expressed concern over the possibility of a bomb bringing down a Russian airliner in Egypt, killing over 200 people. The US government has no immediate announcements regarding the proposed security measures.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Homeland Security is expected to call for tighter security, possibly as soon as Friday, at certain foreign airports that have direct flights to the United States, ABC News reported on Thursday, citing aviation and government officials.

site_title: Facebook introduces music sharing feature
summary: Facebook introduces "Music Stories," a new post format allowing users to share music from streaming services like Spotify or Apple Music. Users can click "share" and copy a song link, adding commentary, and friends can view the post with options to hear the song. The feature aims to make music a better part of the Facebook experience, encouraging artists and users to engage more with music. This move follows Facebook's efforts to expand content formats and comes amid the growing music streaming market, which saw a 23% revenue rise in the US in the first half of 2015.

site_title: RBA says rate cuts and currency weakness are supporting Australia's growth
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) released a quarterly monetary policy statement, reaffirming interest rates will remain unchanged at 2% for the sixth month. The central bank cited supporting growth factors, including rate cuts and currency weakness, and lowered its inflation forecast for 2016. Employment growth and job vacancies are expected to remain strong, with unemployment projected to remain within 6% to 6.25% over the next year. The RBA forecasts a 2% to 3% expansion in the economy for 2016, with a potential pickup in consumer demand and investment in non-mining industries.

site_title: Asia: Markets eye US jobs report, Nikkei riding high
summary: Asian markets, particularly Tokyo's Nikkei index, rose on Friday, driven by a week of gains and Japan Post's successful initial public offering, now valued at US$36 billion. The Nikkei is on track for its best performance since mid-August. Meanwhile, traders in Asia await the US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The report's impact on the market is closely watched, with investors seeking clarity on the Fed's next move.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, CWT, Parkway Life Reit
summary: ST Engineering reported a 9.9% increase in net profit to S$133.26 million for its third quarter, despite a 3.4% dip in revenue. CWT suffered a 16% decline in net profit due to a net impairment loss of S$6.3 million from the Tianjin explosions. The Singapore Exchange saw a 0.4% gain in the STI index on Thursday, driven by investors' positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as investors wait on key US rates clue
summary: Australian shares traded flat on Friday, awaiting key US economic data, as declining commodity prices sent resources stocks lower. The S&P/ASX 200 index rebounded from a 0.8% drop, closing 0.1% higher, but remains down 4% for the year. Investors are waiting for the US jobs report, which could influence the US Federal Reserve's decision on a December interest rate hike.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to delist and privatise Tiger Airways
summary: Singapore Airlines has launched a voluntary conditional general offer to delist and privatize Tiger Airways, a budget carrier it owns 55.8% of. The offer price is S$0.41 per share, a 32% premium over the last traded price. SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong said the offer provides shareholders an opportunity to realize their investment and become part of the larger SIA Group through a share option component. The offer will be funded through internal cash resources and is exercisable for 15 market days. The goal is to enhance operational and commercial synergies for Tiger Airways' long-term success.

site_title: United Airlines chief to return to work in Q1 2016
summary: United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz plans to return to work in the first quarter of 2016 after suffering a heart attack last month. Munoz announced his recovery in a letter to United employees, stating he is "excited to tell you that I am on the road to recovery."

site_title: Suu Kyi eyes historic win in Myanmar elections
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi's pro-democracy party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), is poised to win the historic general election, potentially propelling the party to power after a decades-long struggle against the military. Suu Kyi's party is eyeing an outright majority, but the ruling Union and Solidarity Development Party (USDP) is expected to be a significant obstacle. The election, which will determine the country's future, has been marred by concerns of poll fraud and voting irregularities, with observers warning of potential instability if the NLD does not secure a clear victory.

site_title: Iran bans US consumer goods: minister
summary: Iran has banned the entry of US consumer goods, citing a need to boost national production and comply with a call from the supreme leader to prioritize domestic goods. This measure comes ahead of the lifting of economic sanctions on the country as part of a landmark nuclear deal. The ban aims to reduce the country's reliance on foreign goods and promote domestic production.

site_title: More non-traditional Reits, but Asia lags in this trend
summary: Singapore's Reit market is evolving, with non-traditional assets such as data centers, healthcare facilities, and infrastructure like fibre optic networks and mobile towers being listed. However, analysts say it will take time for these unique assets to gain traction, as investors in Asia are unfamiliar with infrastructure as an asset class. Stringent Reit rules and higher expectations of yields in Asia also hinder the growth of non-traditional Reit listings. Experts predict that it may take some delay for infrastructure companies to list their assets in Asia, but the right ingredients, including investor demand and regulatory support, could eventually lead to a shift towards non-traditional Reit listings.

site_title: ExxonMobil probed on climate science
summary: ExxonMobil is being investigated by New York state on whether it lied to the public about climate change risks. The investigation, led by Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, follows reports that ExxonMobil's scientists recognized climate change as a problem in the 1970s but the company later campaigned against climate regulations and funded groups questioning the link between fossil fuel emissions and climate change. ExxonMobil has confirmed receiving a subpoena and denies suppressing climate change research, stating it has included climate risk information in securities filings for decades.

site_title: Europe: Shares buoyed by Adidas and SocGen, commodity stocks dip
summary: Euro zone shares rose 0.2% to 3,447.49 points, driven by solid earnings in Germany and France, with Adidas and Societe Generale leading gains. However, commodity-related stocks fell due to a stronger dollar and rising interest rate expectations. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index declined 0.4% as metal prices dropped. The European mining index fell 3.3% due to a rally in the dollar and possible US rate hike.

site_title: Prosecute bankers, not just banks, for malfeasance: Lagarde
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde calls for prosecution of individuals in the financial industry for misconduct, citing fines against firms as merely a "cost of doing business." She argues that holding individuals accountable for wrongdoing would raise ethics standards and deter reckless behavior. Lagarde cites examples of top executives being prosecuted in Iceland and the potential for disciplinary actions in New York. She emphasizes that personal accountability is not a condemnation of risk-taking, but rather a context of responsibility.

site_title: Oil exports suspended from Libya oil terminal
summary: Libya's National Oil Corp has imposed a "force majeure" on one of its main oil terminals, suspending exports from the Zueitina terminal. The measure clears the NOC of liability for failure to honor contracts, as guards at the facility halted exports to prevent shipments on behalf of the Tripoli-based company. The decision comes amid Libya's ongoing rival administrations and competing NOCs.

images.alt_text: Libya's National Oil Corp announced on Thursday it had imposed a state of "force majeure" on one of the country's main oil terminals after exports from it had been suspended.

site_title: US jury convicts 2 ex-Rabobank traders of Libor fraud
summary: A New York jury convicted Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, two former Rabobank traders, of conspiracy to commit wire and bank fraud and committing wire fraud in connection with the Libor benchmark interest rate manipulation scheme. The scheme involved submitting false data to set the Libor rate, which underpins $500 trillion of contracts globally. Their convictions are the first in the US for the globe-spanning Libor rigging scheme, following an August conviction in Britain of Tom Hayes. The two men face up to 10 years in prison and are expected to be sentenced in March 2016.

site_title: MTP initiative hurts retail investors: SRS
summary: The Society of Remisiers (SRS) in Singapore expresses concerns over the introduction of the S$0.20 minimum trading price (MTP) initiative on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Mainboard. SRS estimates that at least 200,000 retail investors are affected, with some companies experiencing a 50% wipeout of retail investors' shareholdings due to share consolidation. SRS calls for a suitable contingency plan and emphasizes the importance of admitting only quality companies to the exchange, regardless of their listing status.

site_title: Dollar up vs yen, down vs euro ahead of jobs report
summary: The US dollar rose to 121.74 yen but slipped against the euro to US$1.0881 per euro ahead of the US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. Traders are cautious due to a strong jobs report expected to show 181,000 new payrolls. If the report meets expectations, the dollar could surge to new monthly highs, while a disappointing report could lead to a loss of recent gains.

site_title: US: Stocks drift lower ahead of jobs report
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 4.15 points to 17,863.43, and the S&P 500 losing 2.38 points to 2,099.93. The Nasdaq fell 14.74 points to 5,127.74. The decline comes ahead of the highly anticipated jobs report, which is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Investors are cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the report and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Greece approves reform bill, eyes bailout tranche
summary: Greece's parliament approved a reform bill, paving the way for a euro zone finance ministers meeting on Monday to decide on a fresh bailout worth up to 86 billion euros. The bill includes reforms on pensions, energy efficiency, and the sale of Greece's largest port, and must be legislated by the end of the year to unlock 2 billion euros of aid. Greece still faces issues with its banking system and a 23% VAT tax on private education, which are at odds with its lenders, but Deputy Finance Minister Tryfon Alexiadis stated that the issue will be solved "within the day."

images.alt_text: Greece's parliament approved early on Friday a bill with reforms prescribed by the country's international lenders, ahead of a euro zone finance ministers meeting in three days which will decide if Athens qualifies for fresh bailout funds.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 9.9% rise in Q3 profit
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 profit rose 9.9% to S$133.26 million, driven by higher revenue from electronics and aerospace sectors. Revenue dipped 3.4% to S$1.5 billion, with land systems and marine sectors experiencing declines. Earnings per share increased to 4.29 Singapore cents. No interim dividend was declared for the quarter.

images.alt_text: Singapore Technologies (ST) Engineering's net profit for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, rose 9.9 per cent to S$133.26 million from S$121.3 million a year ago.

site_title: In the fast lane
summary: Luxury hotel chain Waldorf Astoria is offering unique driving holiday packages, allowing guests to drive high-performance exotic cars such as Ferrari, McLaren, and Porsche on pre-arranged routes. The program, which launched in the US, Europe, and the UAE, includes coaching from professional drivers and can be booked until December. Meanwhile, British tour operator Ultimate Drives is offering a 007-inspired package in the Swiss Alps, and Audi is providing winter training packages on icy tracks in Sweden and Finland.

site_title: US, China least concerned about climate change: poll
summary: A global poll by the Pew Research Center found that residents of China and the US, the world's biggest polluters, are among the least concerned about climate change. In China, 18% considered climate change very serious, while 15% were concerned about personal harm. In the US, 45% saw climate change as very serious, with one-third expressing personal concern. The poll suggests a disconnect between the severity of climate change and public perception, highlighting the need for increased awareness and action.

site_title: Hail the humble CEO
summary: Researchers at the National University of Singapore and Arizona State University found that about 5% of a firm's return on assets (ROA) is linked to CEOs rated as "humble" by their CFOs. Humble CEOs tend to lead teams that collaborate, share information, and have a shared vision, resulting in stronger firm performance and lower pay disparity. The study of 105 small-to-medium-sized firms in the US computer software and hardware industry suggests that humble CEOs contribute to firm performance through top management team integration and pay equality, challenging the assumption that humility is associated with weakness.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: S'pore-China ties reach new heights
summary: Singapore and China have strengthened ties over the past two decades through various economic projects, including the Suzhou Industrial Park, which celebrated its 20th anniversary in November. The park is ranked as the second-best industrial park in China and contributes 15% to Suzhou's economy. Other notable projects include the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-city, the Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City, and the Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone, which have been successful in attracting high-tech industries and creative talent. These collaborations demonstrate the growth of government-to-government cooperation and private sector involvement in the region.

site_title: GIC invests HK$659m in Bloomage in bet on Botox
summary: GIC's private-equity unit has invested HK$659 million in Hong-Kong listed Bloomage BioTechnology Corporation Ltd, betting on China's growing medical cosmetics market. The investment includes convertible bonds and new shares, with Bloomage planning to use the funds to drive domestic and global expansion. GIC, a manager of over US$100 billion of Singapore's reserves, is increasing investments in emerging economies. Bloomage's shares surged 8.2% after the deal, driven by its expansion into the medical beauty industry through its Botox products.

site_title: Qualcomm's forecasts show struggle for licence deals in China
summary: Qualcomm's quarterly sales and profit fell short of analyst estimates, with the chipmaker struggling to collect licensing fees for smartphones sold in China. The company faces tough negotiating tactics from Chinese phone makers, who withhold payments and stop reporting shipments to secure better terms. Qualcomm's licensing business, which fuels research and development, is its most profitable but has been hampered by an antitrust investigation and reduced royalty rates. The company expects to collect in full eventually and may take legal action against holdouts.

site_title: India consumers are the world's most confident
summary: India's consumers are the world's most confident, according to Nielsen, driven by surging wealth and a growing middle class. This confidence is reflected in increased travel, credit usage, and spending power, with retail sales expected to double to $1 trillion by 2020. The government's efforts to boost consumption and create jobs are seen as a key factor in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic strategy. However, challenges such as a global economic slowdown and rural spending impairments due to monsoon rains remain.

site_title: Etihad offers Indians inflight showers on 3½-hour gulf jaunt
summary: Etihad Airways is offering luxurious Residence suites on its 3.5-hour flights from Abu Dhabi to Mumbai at a significantly lower price than its usual rate, priced at US$1,300 per trip. This move aims to attract high-paying clients and fill empty cabins. The suites feature a lie-flat bed, private shower, and butler service. The airline is targeting the Indian elite and business travelers with interests in the Gulf. Despite the lower price, the Residence deal is still relatively expensive, with Bahrain-based Gulf Air offering cheaper tickets.

site_title: Rio stands against output cuts despite falling prices
summary: RIO Tinto Group, the world's second-largest iron ore producer, has announced it will continue to defend its market share despite falling prices. CEO Andrew Harding stated that reducing output would not increase prices, as other producers would simply fill the gap. This stance comes as iron ore prices are expected to decline for a third consecutive year. RIO Tinto will maintain its production levels to maintain its market position.

site_title: Fukushima casts long shadow
summary: Fukushima nuclear disaster still casts a long shadow in Japan, with many artists expressing their shock and confusion through their works. A play called "Seed" by Singapore director Chong Tze Chien explores the impact of the disaster on ordinary Japanese lives, particularly through the theme of tainted food. The play weaves multiple storylines, including a widow's journey to Fukushima's danger zone and a mother's efforts to teach her daughter to prepare meals despite the risk. Through art and fiction, "Seed" highlights the poignancy of everyday rituals and the fear of contaminated food.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Alstom in major share buyback after General Electric deal
summary: Alstom, a French industrial group, plans a 3.2-billion-euro share buyback following the sale of its energy assets to General Electric (GE). Under the offer, 91.5 million shares will be repurchased at 35 euros apiece and then cancelled. The deal aims to refocus the company after GE's acquisition of Alstom's energy assets. GE also sold a rail signalling business to Alstom for US$800 million. The share buyback is a 17.6% premium over Tuesday's market close.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined US$258m for violating US sanctions
summary: Deutsche Bank has been fined US$258 million by US regulators for violating US sanctions, with the Federal Reserve and New York State Department of Financial Services announcing the penalties. The bank had disguised over US$10.86 billion in transactions with sanctioned entities, including Iran, Syria, and Sudan, between 1999 and 2006. As a result, Deutsche Bank will pay US$200 million to the NYDFS and US$58 million to the Federal Reserve, and has agreed to install an independent monitor and fire six employees involved in the sanctions-evasion scheme.

site_title: US rate fears drag STI lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 16.83 points to 3,023.65 on Thursday, despite a slight firming in Hong Kong and China, due to concerns over an impending US rate hike in December. The US Federal Reserve expects to move forward with the first rate increase "in a timely fashion", citing a gathering US economy and inflation returning to 2% in the medium term. Major banks DBS, Singtel, and OCBC led the fall, with shares trading below their past minus-one-standard-deviation levels on price per book value.

site_title: Century Aluminum takes on China in trade dispute
summary: Century Aluminum Co, a US aluminium producer, is leading a campaign against China's aluminium exports, citing threats to the US industry amid high costs and low prices. Century has announced plans to close capacity and shutter one plant, and has accused China of misclassifying exports to avoid export taxes. The US Trade Representative and the US International Trade Commission have been asked to investigate allegations, marking a shift in the US aluminium industry's approach to the issue. The move could lead to a trade dispute between the two countries.

site_title: Bank Negara keeps rate on hold amid growth risks, weak ringgit
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia kept the overnight policy rate at 3.25% for an eighth consecutive meeting, citing concerns over economic growth and a weak ringgit. This decision comes amid global economic risks, including China's slowing GDP growth. The central bank's decision does not signal any immediate changes in monetary policy, as it balances the need to support growth with the risk of inflation.

site_title: Minimum trading price rule may need tweaking
summary: The minimum trading price (MTP) rule of S$0.20 for the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard may need to be tweaked to accommodate concerns from retail trading representatives. The Society of Remisiers (SOR) has written to the SGX, suggesting that companies whose shares have fallen sharply after consolidation may be exempt from the rule if they can demonstrate good faith in their efforts to improve fundamentals. The proposal aims to balance the need to prevent companies from failing with the need to protect the interests of retail investors.

site_title: Traditional media still the choice of readers for news: Nielsen survey
summary: In a Nielsen survey, traditional media remains the preferred choice for news consumption in Singapore, with 92.7% of adults reading print newspapers and watching TV broadcasts weekly. Digital platforms also play a role, with 64.7% accessing news and entertainment online in the past month. The majority of these users are aged 15-44, and The Straits Times remains the most read English daily, with 30% of its news reaching the average daily audience.

images.alt_text: BT's combined print and online circulation has kept steady at a daily average of about 50,000.

site_title: Find ways to insure new risks - or risk going out of business: Munich Re
summary: Munich Re, a German-based insurance group, has identified insuring against natural catastrophes and cyber risks as key areas of focus in the Asia region, where the insurance market is growing rapidly. The number of weather-related catastrophes has quadrupled since 1980, with potential growth in Asia's coverage for natural catastrophe risks being high. Cyber insurance premiums are estimated to reach $6-8 billion by 2020, but insurers face challenges in underwriting such "fairly unknown" risks. Munich Re plans to address this through partnerships with software and hardware companies and data analytics.

images.alt_text: Dr Arnoldussen says data analytics and telematics will be "game changers'' for insurers as they help limit losses.

site_title: Tableaus of riveting fight sequences
summary: A Clockwork Orange, a stylish adaptation of Anthony Burgess's 1962 novella, has been reimagined by director Alexandra Spencer-Jones as a hybridized, choreographed theatre. The production features scuzzy and savage fight scenes orchestrated like contemporary dance, with actors using their bodies to create beautiful tableaus. The minimalist stage setting and stylized formations allow the audience to visualize the settings, while the actors convincingly morph into different characters. This adaptation successfully balances dance and drama, offering slick entertainment with visual wit and invention.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Chinese steel faces stiff US tariffs based on subsidies received
summary: The US Department of Commerce has found that Chinese exporters of anti-corrosive steel received subsidies of up to 236% and will impose tariffs on these imports. The tariffs, set at 236% of the subsidy rate, will be applied to shipments from China, India, Italy, South Korea, and Taiwan. This decision may curb Chinese exports to North America and limit the market for US steel producers. The tariffs are expected to tighten the market and potentially end some imports, helping to lift domestic prices.

site_title: Prospect of 'war' among East Asian nations still hangs in delicate balance
summary: Japan and China have been at odds since 2012 over the Senkaku islets, but recent events suggest a delicate balance between increased rapprochement and hostility. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's meeting with Chinese counterpart Li Keqiang and South Korean President Park Geun-Hye in Seoul marked a step towards cooperation, but Japan's alignment with the US in condemning China's South China Sea activities and the US's deployment of a warship in the region have raised tensions. The situation remains volatile, with China warning of a "head-on blow" to foreign forces violating its sovereignty.

site_title: Path of smart investor starts at being aware of behavioural weakness
summary: A path to smart investing begins with recognizing and understanding behavioral weaknesses, such as overconfidence, availability bias, and anchoring. These biases can lead to poor decision-making and negatively impact investment returns. Studies have shown that investors who follow a rational investment strategy tend to outperform those who rely on intuition or emotions. By acknowledging and designing a system to counter these biases, intelligent investors can make more informed decisions and achieve better long-term results.

site_title: Singapore moneylenders' credit bureau to start operations in 2016
summary: Singapore's moneylenders' credit bureau, run by DP Information Group, will begin operations in 2016. The bureau will collect and share information on loans and payment behavior of licensed moneylenders' customers, promoting responsible borrowing and reducing defaults. Licensed moneylenders must provide information on their loans and customers to the bureau, which can be accessed by other licensed moneylenders when evaluating credit applications. This move aims to address the lack of credit information on targeted borrowers and improve transparency in the moneylending industry.

site_title: Cash-hungry firms drive up pace of IPO listings in Asia
summary: Asia's IPO listings are accelerating due to cash-hungry firms seeking funds amid China's slowing economy. Valuations are expected to remain low, with an estimated $17 billion in IPOs scheduled for the last two months of the year, a near-doubling of Hong Kong deals. Despite initial public offerings being cheaper, investors are cautious, and fund managers are driving hard bargains. The region's fourth-quarter IPO tally could reach $36 billion, with Hong Kong providing the mainstay.

site_title: Malaysian govt to address Najib funds scandal in December
summary: Malaysia's government plans to address the Najib funds scandal on December 3, the last day of Parliament, amid pressure over a graft scandal surrounding state fund 1MDB. The funds, totaling nearly $700 million, were found in Prime Minister Najib Razak's bank accounts, with his government attributing the money to a Middle East benefactor. Critics, including opposition Members of Parliament, have accused the government of dodging accountability and questioned the timing of the disclosure. The move is seen as a tactic to ease concerns among investors and reassure Najib's allies within his ruling party.

site_title: German firms upbeat on S'pore: poll
summary: German firms in Singapore perceive the situation as stable and positive, with most describing their company's health as satisfactory or good. The majority of companies expect their situation to remain stable in the near future. Staff numbers remain at the same levels or increased over the last year, with a shortage of qualified technical staff. The absence of corruption, availability of skilled labor, and favorable tax framework are highly influential factors for companies' engagement in Singapore, with regional and international markets being more important than the domestic market.

site_title: Spectre mines rich vein
summary: The James Bond film "Spectre" (2015) directed by Sam Mendes is a box-office hit, following the success of "Skyfall". The film's plot picks up where "Skyfall" left off, with Bond disobeying orders from the new M (Ralph Fiennes) to stand down and instead attending a funeral in Rome to uncover a shadowy criminal organization. The film features elaborate action sequences, witty repartee, and references to previous Bond films. With a reported budget of $300 million, "Spectre" has become the longest and most expensive Bond film in the series, solidifying its place as a memorable mission in the franchise.

site_title: Why foreign policy strikes must land hard
summary: US President Barack Obama's foreign policy approach in Iraq and Syria, dubbed "half-pregnant," has failed to achieve its goals, extending the conflict. Unlike successful wars led by US presidents, Obama's strategy involved limited aid to moderate Sunni groups without deploying troops, allowing the Islamic State (IS) to grow in influence. The IS exploited growing radicalization among Syria's Sunni majority, leading to further instability. Obama's decision to deploy fewer than 50 Special Operations advisers to Syria has been seen as a fatal blow, failing to ensure the confrontation's end.

site_title: Art Stage unveils the crowd-pullers
summary: Singapore's premier art fair, Art Stage, plans to expand its 2016 edition with the Southeast Asian Forum, featuring global intellectuals discussing art and urbanization. The forum will include 10 Asian artists and a magazine, Catalyst, reporting on regional art market trends. The main fair will feature 143 galleries from 33 countries, including the centennial anniversary celebration of Dadaism. The event aims to raise awareness about South-east Asian art and its role in urban development, generating buzz for the visual arts scene in Singapore and promoting regional and international art.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: NERA Telecommunications reported a 43.3% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$2 million, or 0.55 Singapore cents per share, due to a slowdown in the Middle East and Africa market. Revenue fell 20.2% to S$39.6 million. The company attributed the decline to a decrease in sales from the telecom business and network equipment.

site_title: Adding zest with Syrah
summary: A wine tasting comparison of Old and New World Syrah was conducted to find the perfect pairing for spicy Asian food. Four Syrah wines from Araujo Estate, Fontodi, Torbreck, and Marc Sorrel were selected. Syrah is characterized by its big-bodied, lush, and soft wines with flavors of blackberries and subtle savouriness. The tasting concluded that Syrah is an ideal red wine to pair with spicy Asian cuisine due to its easy-to-appreciate nature and soft tannic edges. The selected wines offered a unique spread of Syrah from around the world.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article highlights various events and exhibitions happening in Singapore. The Arachnid Orchestra by Tomas Saraceno is an interactive sound and visual installation at NTU Centre of Contemporary Art, while 4XFOUR pop-up dining experiences feature Michelin-starred chefs at The White Rabbit. The Big N Breezy Bazaar 2015 takes place at People's Park Complex, showcasing regional brands and entertainment. Lollapalooza launches a Sunday lunch menu at Keong Saik, and the Singapore-Myanmar Film Festival returns with a second edition at The Projector. These events showcase art, culture, and entertainment in Singapore.

site_title: China Merchant Holdings Q3 profit down 20%
summary: China Merchant Holdings reported a 20% drop in Q3 net profit to HK$168.4 million due to lower profit contributions from toll road joint ventures, higher finance costs, and exchange losses. Revenue rose 4% to HK$548.8 million, partially offsetting the decline. The company expects its toll road business to remain profitable, driven by newly acquired assets and stable economic growth in the regions where its toll roads are located.

site_title: CWT Q3 earnings hit by S$6.3m net impairment loss from Tianjin blast
summary: CWT, a Singapore logistics and commodity broking company, reported a 16% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$27.2 million due to a S$6.3 million impairment loss from the August Tianjin blasts, which damaged one of its warehouses and machinery. Revenue halved to S$1.93 billion, while other operating expenses widened to S$16.4 million. The company cut its cost of sales in half, but the bottom line was dragged down by losses from the blasts.

site_title: Tan Keong Choon a leading light: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid tribute to late industrialist Tan Keong Choon, calling him a "pioneer and a leading light of the Chinese community" in Singapore. Tan contributed to the country's development and promoted Chinese culture, according to Lee's letter.

site_title: Facebook's revenue, profit grow, but not as fast as its spending
summary: Facebook reported Q3 revenue growth of 41% to $4.5 billion, with net profit rising 11% to $896 million. However, expenses surged 62% to over $3 billion, outpacing revenue growth. Despite this, investors shrugged off the costs, with shares jumping 3.7% in after-hours trading. The company's mobile advertising business and increased daily users drove revenue growth, with mobile ads accounting for 78% of ad revenue. Facebook is investing heavily in new technologies and initiatives, with a focus on future-facing bets in advertising technology, and is willing to spend aggressively to achieve its goals.

site_title: A musical that will make grown men cry
summary: The musical "Ghost the Musical" has been praised for its emotional impact, with Eurythmics' Dave Stewart stating that it will make grown men cry. The show, adapted from the 1990 film, features a powerful score and has been seen by over one million theatregoers worldwide. Stewart wrote the original music and lyrics for the production, using the 1965 hit "Unchained Melody" three times throughout the show. With its clever use of illusions and five Laurence Olivier Awards, the musical is a must-see, with tickets available now at Marina Bay Sands until November 15.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Monthly activity on SGX down in October
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 7% decrease in monthly trading activity in October, with the daily average turnover of securities falling to S$1 billion. Total derivatives volume dropped 19% to 11.3 million contracts, while commodities derivatives volume fell 20% to 772,829 contracts. Iron ore derivatives volume declined 22% to 686,456 contracts, but was still double the volume a year ago. Despite the slowdown, the market operator's shares rose 1.1% to S$7.61.

images.alt_text: The daily average turnover of securities traded on the Singapore bourse fell 7% month-on-month in October, while total derivatives volume dropped 19 per cent over the same period.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q3 DPU up 15.6%; boost from divestment gains
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 15.6% year-over-year increase in third-quarter distributable income to S$20.3 million, driven by one-time divestment gains from asset recycling initiative. Without these gains, recurring operations grew 2.5%. The trust also strengthened its balance sheet by eliminating imminent refinancing risk and hedging 78% of its interest rate exposure. Despite macro headwinds, the trust delivered consistent attractive results, with CEO Yong Yean Chau stating the company will continue to build on successful strategies to enhance value and growth potential.

site_title: Dividends, absence of associate losses bolster SIA's Q2 bottom line
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$213.6 million in the second quarter, up from S$90.9 million a year ago, driven by higher dividends from long-term investments and a reclassification of Tiger Airways as a subsidiary. The airline group warned of a challenging operating environment, with declining yields and uncertain economic conditions. Revenue decreased to S$3.84 billion, and operating profit eased to S$128.6 million. SIA has declared a dividend of 10 cents and plans to maintain a tight cost structure while leveraging its portfolio of airlines.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Germany to retest all VW cars, Moody's downgrades ratings
summary: Germany is retesting all Volkswagen car models to determine genuine emissions levels amid a corporate scandal. The move comes after VW admitted to understating CO2 emissions in around 800,000 cars sold mainly in Europe, making them more expensive to drive than buyers believed. Moody's downgraded VW's credit rating to A3/P-2 with a negative outlook, citing internal control and governance issues. The scandal has led to a 2 billion euro cost increase for VW and a 9.5% decline in its shares, wiping over 3 billion euros off its market value.

site_title: UOB's Greater China loans double to S$25b over three years
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has seen its cross-border loans to Chinese companies double to S$25.1 billion over the past three years, primarily in the real estate, trading, natural resources, and consumer products sectors. This growth is attributed to the increasing trade and investment between China and South-east Asia, particularly through the One Belt One Road (OBOR) initiative. UOB has also expanded its presence in China, with 17 branches and offices, and facilitated over 600 new customers along the OBOR trade routes.

site_title: Keen contest for plum Serangoon residential site
summary: A 1.4-hectare 99-year leasehold private housing site near Serangoon MRT station in Singapore drew 11 bids for a condo project with over 500 units. The top bidder, a consortium led by City Developments Ltd, offered S$710 per sq ft per plot ratio (psf ppr), surpassing the S$648 psf ppr winning bid for a nearby site. The site's attractive location and superior configuration contributed to the higher bid, with the second-highest bid at S$692 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Putting a lid on bank customer call volume
summary: Retail banks struggle with managing customer call volumes, with 50-70% of calls being avoidable or generated by errors. Effective management can lead to sustainable reductions of 20-40% of total demand within two years. Key strategies include planning capacity with demand forecasts, establishing a demand management function, engaging frontline employees, and changing metrics to focus on customer experience. By adopting these approaches, leading banks have achieved significant reductions in call volumes, saving $20 million annually.

site_title: Modi calls on Indians to put idle gold to good use to cut imports
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has launched three programs to reduce the country's massive gold imports by encouraging people to put their idle gold to productive use. The programs include a gold-deposit plan, a sovereign-bond issue, and the introduction of locally minted coins. The goal is to trim physical demand and reduce imports, which currently range between 800 and 1,000 tonnes annually, worth over $800 billion. The initiatives aim to provide alternative investment avenues and boost supply, with the potential to transform the Indian gold industry.

site_title: Chinese PM appeals to Japan businesses to improve two-way ties
summary: Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang urged Japanese businesses to strengthen ties with China, pledging to broaden access to Chinese markets and offer a more level playing field to foreign companies. The appeal comes amid a sharp drop in Japanese investment in China due to political tensions and slow growth. Li also expressed interest in cooperation on production capacity, infrastructure, and free trade agreements, aiming to repair economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Elegance in a hot tub
summary: Japan's luxury ryokans and onsen resorts are now offering modern comfort and contemporary design with minimal Japanese aesthetics. The Zaborin Ryokan in Hokkaido, Amanemu in Ise Shima National Park, and Suiran, a Luxury Collection Hotel, in Kyoto, feature private onsen, gourmet dining, and stunning views. These resorts blend traditional and modern design, offering unique experiences and relaxation.

site_title: Elon Musk's visionary Hyperloop takes a step towards reality
summary: Elon Musk's Hyperloop project is moving towards reality with a test track nearing construction. The technology has the potential to revolutionize transportation, but it faces challenges such as energy costs and friction. A Hyperloop capsule would require a significant amount of power, potentially as little as 27 kW per passenger, making it a potentially cost-effective option. The Hyperloop's impact on the airline industry will depend on ticket prices and travel time, with the technology having the potential to disrupt the air freight and trucking industries.

site_title: Fall from grace
summary: Standard Chartered is shedding billions of dollars in risky assets, including $3.5 billion in loans to Essar, one of India's most indebted conglomerates. The move aims to offload high-profile but troublesome debts and free up bank balance sheets. Essar's gross debt is estimated at $15.2 billion, with interest cover less than one times, making it one of India's most indebted family businesses. The potential sale of the Essar loans could be a warning to suppliers of cheap credit, which are becoming rare.

images.alt_text: A shake-up at Standard Chartered could finally turn the screws on India's tycoons.

site_title: What's real estate? Depends on who you ask
summary: The definition of "real estate" varies among individuals and regulatory bodies. The US Internal Revenue Service defines it as land or permanent structures, while Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) does not prescribe a specific definition for Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) and business trusts. Industry experts, such as Peter Verwer and Teo Wee Hwee, have broad definitions that include non-traditional assets like data centers, fiber optic networks, and even solar power plants. However, others, like Matthias Meyer, draw a distinction between real estate and infrastructure, citing differences in changeability, regulation, and monopolization.

site_title: DBS and UBS win private banking awards
summary: DBS Bank and UBS have won private banking awards at the Global Private Banking Awards. UBS Wealth Management won the title of Best Private Bank in Asia in 2015. This recognition highlights the banks' efforts in providing high-quality services to their clients in the region. The awards are presented by magazines Professional Wealth Management and The Banker.

site_title: Pacific trading partners release TPP details
summary: The US-backed Pacific trade deal, a 12-nation pact, has released its text, revealing that US tech companies, banks, and farmers are among the biggest beneficiaries of falling tariffs. The deal aims to free up commerce in 40% of the world's economy, but has been criticized for its opacity. The agreement is designed to liberate commerce among Pacific Rim nations, but the release of the text has raised concerns about the lack of transparency. The pact is expected to have a significant impact on the global economy.

site_title: Ex-graphic designer of BT clinches UOB's top art prize
summary: Former graphic designer Benjamin F Cruz, 61, won the UOB Painting of the Year (Singapore) Award for his acrylic piece "Building..." with a US$25,000 prize. Cruz, who had previously won the award in 1990 and 1991, mixed realism and abstraction to depict Singapore landmarks. This year's award saw a record number of entries, with other winners including Aaron Gan, Geraldine Schubert, and Jose Maria Bustos. Regional winners included Anggar Prasetyo from Indonesia and Tiong Chai Heing from Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: SPH launches car-selling concierge service Wheel Deal
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) launches Wheel Deal, a car-selling concierge service connecting sellers with authorized car dealers. Sellers can submit their details via phone, email, or SMS, and receive a range of quotes from dealers on the same day. The service aims to reduce dealers' advertising costs and provide a convenient platform for sellers to sell their vehicles. SPH also invests S$1 million in local used car marketplace Carro.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's little jewel in India spared the axe
summary: Deutsche Bank has spared its Indian operations from being cut, despite announcing plans to exit 10 countries worldwide to revive profits. The bank's Indian unit has managed to avoid bad-loan problems, with a low bad-loan ratio of 0.33% and a 14 billion rupee profit in the year through March. This is attributed to its focus on corporate banking and shorter-term loans. The decision to continue with India operations is seen as a strategic move to maintain performance in the country.

site_title: HDB resale volume in October highest this year: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale volume surged 16% in October to 1,745 units, the highest this year, due to recent rule changes benefiting buyers. The Proximity Housing Grant and increased household income ceiling for citizen households likely boosted demand. However, the November launch of Build-to-Order (BTO) flats may draw resale demand away. Despite a 52.2% decline from the peak in May 2010, resale transaction levels are expected to improve in 2015, possibly reaching 18,000-19,000 units, according to ERA Realty.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Michael Kors' Q2 pips analysts' estimates; new stores outside US help
summary: Michael Kors Holdings Ltd reported a second-quarter profit of $1.01 per share, beating analysts' estimates of 89 cents. Revenue rose 6.9% to $1.13 billion, driven by new international locations. However, the company lowered its forecast for the current fiscal year due to increased spending on digital operations and new stores. Same-store sales fell 3.4% and the company added $500 million to its share buyback program, extending it through March 2018.

site_title: Groupon shares take fresh hit as new CEO outlines strategy
summary: Groupon shares plummeted 27% after the company's new CEO, Rich Williams, outlined a strategy focused on customer acquisition and streamlined global operations. The company reported a quarterly loss of $27.6 million and a weaker revenue outlook for the fourth quarter. Groupon aims to shift focus to retail categories with stronger margins and will invest in international markets with strong potential, while exiting or selling underperforming markets.

site_title: Takata tumbles 25% on doubts about air-bag maker's survival
summary: Takata Corp, the Japanese air-bag maker, plummeted 25% in Tokyo trading after its largest customer, Honda Motor Co, accused the supplier of manipulating test data and announced it will discontinue using Takata's air-bag inflators in new models. This move raises concerns about the company's survival, with analysts stating there is "very little chance" for Takata to survive. The company's largest product segment, air-bags, accounts for 38% of its sales, and losing this business could devastate the company.

site_title: US$ builds on rally as Fed prepares ground for Dec lift-off
summary: The US dollar reached a three-month high against a basket of major currencies, driven by comments from influential Federal Reserve officials that kept chances of an interest rate hike in December alive. US two-year Treasury yields rose to their highest in 41/2 years, boosting the dollar's appeal to investors. The dollar index gained 0.15% and the euro fell to its lowest in over three months at US$1.0834, amid expectations of a US jobs report showing 180,000 jobs added last month.

site_title: A journey through S'pore films
summary: The 26th Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) celebrates Singapore cinema's different phases with new and old works. Director Eric Khoo's film "In The Room" is a personal tribute to late writer Damien Sin, inspired by Sin's short story "One Last Cold Kiss." Both films will be shown at SGIFF, alongside other notable films.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Josie Ho and her girls (above).

Josie Ho and her girls; and taking a photo call with director Eric Khoo (above). The film In The Room is an erotic drama and personal tribute to Khoo's friend, the late Singapore writer Damien Sin, who died of a drug overdose in 2011 at the age of 46.
(Above) Jeremy Irons and Dev Patel in The Man Who Knew Infinity.
Mark Montgomery, Tan Min-Li and Joe Thomas of Xeitgeist Entertainment.
Bugis Street (left), directed by Yonfan (right), will make a comeback on the big screen at the upcoming SGIFF with a newly restored print to celebrate the film's 20th anniversary.

site_title: Winter adventures for every taste
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article highlights various winter adventure options for different tastes. In Colorado, the Park Hyatt Beaver Creek Resort and Spa offers a $12,000 heli-skiing package with a private helicopter transfer and guided skiing. In Norway, the Northern Lights are expected to be visible from March, with remote Lapland in Finland offering exclusive "Aurora glamping" experiences. Meanwhile, river cruises on the Rhine and Danube offer a chance to experience Europe's best Yuletide markets, and Le Portetta Courchevel in the French Alps provides a luxury ski-in, ski-out retreat for families.

site_title: Lee Wen's conversations with a blank canvas
summary: Lee Wen, a Singaporean artist, has showcased his 65 selected works in his second solo exhibition, "Lee Wen: Songs Unsung," a retrospective from 1990 to 2015. His art reflects personal experiences, including childhood memories of his father's passing and his own struggles with Parkinson's disease. Despite health challenges, Lee Wen continues to create art as a form of therapy, aiming to communicate alternative thoughts and desires with sincerity. The exhibition, now ending, highlights his role in Singapore's art development and his optimism for positive change.

site_title: Kraft Heinz to trim 2,600 more jobs in cost-cutting push
summary: Kraft Heinz plans to cut 2,600 more jobs and close seven factories in stages over the next 12 to 24 months as part of its cost-cutting efforts. The moves come after the company announced 2,500 job cuts in August and aim to reduce US$1.5 billion in annual expenses by 2017. The company faces declining sales and will invest hundreds of millions of dollars in improving capacity use and modernizing facilities. The job cuts and factory closures are part of a broader effort to achieve industry-leading margins, following a playbook used by 3G Capital to transform Heinz after its private takeover in 2013.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust Q3 profit rises to US$2.8m
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a 25% increase in net cash generated from operations to US$16 million in Q3, with revenue rising 20% to US$28.4 million. Net profit nearly quadrupled to US$2.8 million. The trust agreed to buy a Japanese-built tanker for US$21.8 million, expected to deliver a 14.5% cash-on-cash yield. Gearing improved to 50.6% and nine-month profit was US$14.1 million, reversing a US$3.2 million loss a year ago.

site_title: Singapore and China to sign several agreements during Xi's visit
summary: Singapore and China will sign several agreements during Chinese President Xi Jinping's state visit starting on Friday, Nov 6, including a free trade agreement upgrade and cooperation in areas such as education and urban management. The agreements also cover the third government-to-government project in western China and collaboration between the two Customs. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties and promote economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia's quarterly economic growth lower than expected at 4.73%
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 4.73% in the third quarter, lower than expected, due to weak household spending and exports. The country's commodity demand declined, and foreign investment stagnated, posing a challenge for President Joko Widodo's government. The economy is expected to remain stuck at around 4.5-5% growth over the next few years, according to economists. The rupiah, Asia's second-worst performing currency, remained stable, and the benchmark Jakarta stock index fell 0.4%. The government has announced measures to improve the investment climate and is expected to announce incentives for special economic zones.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Standard Chartered on earnings, impairments
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Standard Chartered Plc to A+ from AA-, citing unfavorable profitability and asset quality trends. The downgrade is attributed to the bank's vulnerability to volatility in the operating and regulatory environment. CEO Bill Winters' efforts to restructure the bank, cut costs, and dispose of unwanted assets will help, but the negative outlook remains.

site_title: S Korea's answer to Mother Teresa
summary: South Korean Pastor Lee Jong-rak, known as "Korea's answer to Mother Teresa," has been saving abandoned babies in Seoul through a contraption called the Drop Box, which has led to the survival of hundreds of newborns. The documentary, "The Drop Box," directed by Brian Ivie, highlights Pastor Lee's tireless efforts and optimism, but also raises controversy over the issue of unwanted pregnancies and disabilities. Despite the controversy, the film aims to raise awareness and spread the word about Pastor Lee's cause, and has received praise for its heartwarming and thought-provoking portrayal.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
South Korean pastor Lee Jong-rak has made it his mission to save abandoned babies off the streets of Korea with his Drop Box.

site_title: Societe Generale to shut 400 branches by 2020
summary: Societe Generale, France's second-largest bank, plans to close 400 branches and cut 2,000 jobs by 2020 as clients shift to online banking. The move aims to reduce the bank's branch network by 20% and focus on its three main wings: Societe Generale, Credit du Nord, and Boursorama. The restructuring is expected to be largely staff-led, with some 1.5 billion euros invested in expanding Boursorama's client base to 2 million over the next five years. French Labour Minister Myriam El Khomri expressed concerns over potential job losses.

site_title: Singapore life insurance business up 15.3% for Q3
summary: Singapore's life insurance business saw a 15.3% increase in total weighted new business premiums for Q3 2015, reaching S$813 million. This growth was driven by new product launches, sales and marketing initiatives, and increased uptake in savings-oriented products through bancassurance. The industry posted an 8.9% rise in weighted annual premium products for the first nine months, with ILPs contributing 20% of total weighted new business premiums. The industry is committed to meeting evolving consumer needs through a wide range of products.

site_title: A long history and a bright future
summary: German Ambassador Michael Witter marks the 50th anniversary of Singapore-German diplomatic relations, citing Germany's recognition of Singapore's independence in 1965 as a significant milestone. Over the past five decades, the two countries have strengthened their ties in various fields, including politics, economy, culture, and education. Key events include Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to Germany in February, Minister Vivian Balakrishnan's visit to Germany, and a concert by German cellist Jan Vogler and the Singapore Symphony Orchestra. The ambassador highlights the potential for greater collaboration in areas such as vocational education and training, security policy, and regional economic cooperation.

site_title: KGI Fraser launches CFD platform
summary: KGI Fraser Securities and Ayondo are launching a contracts for differences (CFDs) platform called KGI Contrax, based on Ayondo's TradeHub system. The platform aims to allow investors to gain exposure to underlying assets with a smaller outlay and without owning them, and also offers a social trading feature that enables investors to automatically follow the trades of "leading traders." The move is expected to appeal to investors due to its ease of use and innovative features.

site_title: Helicopter maker AgustaWestland considering logistics centre in Singapore
summary: AgustaWestland, a helicopter maker, is considering establishing a logistics centre in Singapore to serve its clients in the region. The centre would stock spare parts and dispatch them, creating 20-30 jobs. A decision is expected by the first quarter of 2016. The move is part of the company's expansion plans, driven by growth in the commercial segment, particularly in the Middle East and Asia. The logistics centre may also offer maintenance, repair, and overhaul services and training, further solidifying its presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UOB's Greater China loans double to S$25b over 3 years
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has doubled its cross-border loans to Chinese companies investing overseas, reaching S$25.1 billion over three years. This growth is attributed to the expansion of the One Belt One Road (OBOR) trade routes and increasing trade and investment between China and South-east Asia. UOB's loans are primarily used for industries such as real estate, trading, and consumer products. The bank's Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Advisory Unit has facilitated the expansion plans of over 600 businesses along the OBOR trade routes.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank's strategy of financing Chinese companies investing overseas is paying off, with cross borders loans doubling from three years ago to S$25.1 billion.

site_title: Ramco Systems, Air France-KLM set up MRO Lab in S'pore
summary: Air France-KLM Engineering & Maintenance has partnered with India-based Ramco Systems to establish a joint innovation centre in Singapore, known as the MRO Lab. The centre will focus on developing innovative solutions for the aircraft maintenance industry, leveraging expertise in areas such as wearable technology, big data, and optimisation. The lab aims to improve customer relations and streamline maintenance data, benefiting AFI KLM E&M customers worldwide. A team of 10 people will work on priority topics, with the goal of emerging and diffusing high-value-added MRO solutions in the rapidly growing market.

site_title: EC cuts growth outlook ahead of ECB decision
summary: The European Commission has cut its euro-area growth and inflation outlook for next year, citing challenging global conditions and fading economic stimulus. The Commission now forecasts 1.8% growth in 2016, down from 1.9%, and inflation to accelerate to 1.6% in 2017. The ECB is expected to reassess its monetary policy stance, potentially including more asset purchases and a deposit rate cut, to address the inflation gap.

site_title: UK grid pays idle gas units to fire up for winter
summary: The UK grid has paid a plant to run for a short time as the country faces a looming capacity crunch this winter due to the retirement of old coal units. National Grid Plc paid a plant operated by Calon Energy Ltd a rate 60 times the market rate to fire up and provide additional generating capacity. This move was prompted by a Notification of Inadequate System Margin, the first such call in over three years, highlighting the need for more flexible capacity to meet demand.

site_title: Ellipsiz profit swings to growth from one-time recovery of bad debt
summary: Ellipsiz, a semiconductor testing and manufacturing equipment maker, reported a 32% growth in its first fiscal quarter profit to S$2.3 million, driven by the recovery of S$1.4 million in bad debt. Revenue fell 18% to S$25.3 million, with declines in distribution and services solutions. The company maintained a "cautious stance" for the rest of 2015, citing global economic headwinds.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Ltd reported a 48% year-on-year increase in profit to S$192.7 million in Q3 2015, driven by development projects and improved mall performances. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's core shipbuilding margin widened to 18% in Q3, but management remained cautious on margins for new product types. SATS Ltd's net income was in line with H1 2016 estimates, with a 18% EBITDA margin expansion, driven by productivity efforts and lower raw material costs.

site_title: World cities face challenge from emerging upstarts
summary: World cities like Sydney and Seoul are emerging as challengers to established cities such as Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo. These cities are gaining traction in attracting world-class corporations, talent, and real estate investments. Shanghai and Beijing are considered nearly-emerged, with Shanghai already ranking among the world's top 10 financial hubs. The shift could lead to a change in the "Big Six" cities' dominance, potentially altering global real estate investment patterns.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US: Stocks open higher on Dec rate hike possibility
