summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 10.05 points to 17,877.63, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes gaining 1.02 and 3.97 points respectively. The gains followed strong results from Facebook and comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggesting a possible rate hike next month. The rally was seen as a sign of investors' confidence despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff issues.

site_title: Go old-school with new card game
summary: A Singaporean startup, Starknicked, has launched a card game called Smol Tok, designed to facilitate meaningful conversations and self-discovery. The deck of 60 question cards, categorized into personality, community, and intimacy, encourages players to engage in deeper discussions. Founder Nicholas Pang aims to help people connect with themselves and others, promoting old-fashioned face-to-face communication. The game has already seen positive results, with players reporting increased vulnerability and meaningful conversations. Plans for expansion, including an English-language version and regional markets, are underway.

images.alt_text: Instead of the usual card games (above), opt for Smol Tok which brings idle chatter to an end, and good-natured banter back in vogue again. The basic deck contains 60 cards with questions ranging from "What do you most like to eat in the whole wide world?" to "How do you want to be remembered?" and retails at S$32.90.

Instead of the usual card games, opt for Smol Tok (above) which brings idle chatter to an end, and good-natured banter back in vogue again. The basic deck contains 60 cards with questions ranging from "What do you most like to eat in the whole wide world?" to "How do you want to be remembered?" and retails at S$32.90.

Instead of the usual card games, opt for Smol Tok (above) which brings idle chatter to an end, and good-natured banter back in vogue again. The basic deck contains 60 cards with questions ranging from "What do you most like to eat in the whole wide world?" to "How do you want to be remembered?" and retails at S$32.90.

site_title: Prices can't drop too deeply without affecting quality: Redas president
summary: Singapore developers face challenges due to an oversupply of residential units and rising costs. Redas president Augustine Tan stated that prices cannot drop too deeply without affecting product quality and operational obligations. The industry is also under pressure to sell 3,000 unsold Government Land Sales Programme units by 2017 to qualify for the remission of the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty. Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the government's medium-term approach to managing land supply and promoting market sustainability.

site_title: Capturing talent and growth in S-E Asian banking
summary: Southeast Asia's banking sector is poised for growth with the arrival of the Asean Economic Community, driven by a young population and rising affluence. The Asean Banking Integration Framework allows for Asean-based banks to be classified as "local", providing operational flexibility. Companies are seeking talent to generate scale, with the region becoming a key frontiers for financial services companies. Regulatory barriers and nationalistic tendencies remain, but progress has been made, positioning the region for a dynamic and integrated market.

site_title: China Everbright gets nod for 17.3% tariff hike at Shandong plant
summary: China Everbright Water has received approval to increase the tariff at its Binzhou Boxing Waste Water Treatment project by 17.3%, despite the tariff being in effect since July. The plant's wastewater treatment capacity is 80,000 cubic meters, providing about 20% of Shandong province's total capacity. The company's shares closed at 71 Singapore cents, 1.4% lower.

site_title: Emirates airline's H1 profit surges 65% to US$849m
summary: Emirates airline reported a 65% surge in its first-half profit to $849 million due to lower fuel costs and higher passenger numbers. Fuel prices decreased 41% from the same period last year, while passenger numbers rose 10% to 25.7 million. The airline attributed the increase to its robust passenger demand and cost-saving measures.

site_title: US jobless claims post largest increase since February
summary: US jobless claims rose 16,000 to 276,000 for the week ended Oct 24, the largest weekly gain since late February. This increase is consistent with a fairly healthy labor market, as claims remained below the 300,000 threshold for the 35th straight week. The four-week moving average of claims rose 3,500 to 262,750. Despite this, the trend in continuing claims suggests more long-term unemployed are finding work, with the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid increasing by 17,000.

site_title: Kicking it with the kids
summary: Two luxury resorts cater to families with children's clubs and programs. The Four Seasons Resort Orlando at Walt Disney World Resort offers a Kids for All Seasons program, Explorer Island water park, and video game room. Soneva Fushi Resort and Residences in the Maldives features The Den kids' club with indoor and outdoor attractions, and a dedicated space for kids' activities. Mandapa, a Ritz-Carlton Reserve in Bali, offers the Green Camp program, which focuses on sustainability and Balinese culture. These resorts provide a range of amenities, including babysitting services, free meals for children, and activities for kids of all ages.

site_title: Sony starts making premium smartphones in Thailand, in quest for profits
summary: Sony has started producing premium smartphones in Thailand, aiming to make 600,000 to 700,000 units in the first year. The move is part of the company's strategy to turn around its loss-making mobile phone business by prioritizing profits over volume. The new plant in Pathum Thani province began small-scale production two months ago and started shipping phones globally in October, marking Sony's first overseas mobile phone plant in two decades. The investment aims to implement cutting-edge technologies and shift focus to high-end smartphones.

site_title: Eurozone set for 'moderate' recovery in 2016, 2017
summary: The eurozone economy is forecast to experience a moderate recovery over the next two years, growing 1.8% in 2016 and 1.9% in 2017. The European Commission attributes this growth to low oil prices, a weaker euro, and the European Central Bank's quantitative easing policy. However, the recovery is tempered by global headwinds, including a slowdown in China and emerging markets. The Commission also notes that the migration crisis could have a small positive economic impact if labor markets remain open to refugees.

site_title: ECB to decide in December if QE needs ramping up: Draghi
summary: The European Central Bank will assess its asset-purchase program at its December meeting to determine if it's effective in countering a global economic slowdown. ECB President Mario Draghi said the program may need to be ramped up if it's not meeting its objective of achieving price stability. This comes as the global economy shows signs of slowing down, with China's GDP growth expected to slow. The ECB's decision will be closely watched, as investors seek clarity on monetary policy.

site_title: Bank of England sees little inflation pick-up; rate-setters stick to positions
summary: The Bank of England maintained its interest rate at 0.5% and downgraded its economic growth forecast for this year and 2016, citing a weakening global growth outlook. Inflation is predicted to rise slowly, possibly above 2% in two years, but below 1% until the second half of 2016. The central bank also warned emerging markets could experience slower growth. This decision contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's recent indication of a potential interest rate rise in December.

site_title: Air travel demand rises further in Sept: Iata
summary: Demand for air travel rose 7.3% in September, exceeding August's 7.1% gain, according to IATA. This year's demand is up 6.7%, matching the IATA's forecast of a 6.7% rise for the year. Despite economic slowdowns in emerging markets like China, IATA Director-General Tony Tyler described the demand as "robust" and predicted a positive end to 2015.

site_title: London stocks open lower before Bank of England update
summary: London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.18% to open at 6,401.57 points, ahead of the Bank of England's interest rate decision and inflation forecasts. The Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.40% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 nudged up 0.02%. Analysts expect the Bank of England's decision to clarify the timing of its first interest rate hike since 2007.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on US rate worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 16.83 points to 3,023.65 on Thursday, despite a slight rise in Hong Kong and China, as traders worried about an impending US rate hike in December. The US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen confirmed the move, citing the "prudent thing to do." The index saw 1.2 billion units traded worth S$948.6 million, with most interest in penny stocks.

site_title: Dividends, absence of losses from Tiger Airways boost Q2 bottom line of SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a net profit of S$213.6 million for the second quarter, up from S$90.9 million, due to higher dividends from long-term investments and an absence of Tiger Airways losses. Revenue eased to S$3.84 billion, while earnings per share rose to 18.3 Singapore cents. The group has declared a dividend of ten Singapore cents. Despite cautious outlooks for passenger and cargo traffic, the airline attributed the improved bottom line to the absence of losses from Tiger Airways.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia c.bank holds policy rate steady, sees risks to growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank kept its overnight policy rate at 3.25% as expected, citing a weaker external environment, slowing private consumption, and higher inflation. The decision was made despite the country's currency losing over 18% of its value against the dollar due to weak global prices for energy and commodity exports. The bank last revised the benchmark rate in 2014, when it was raised to curb rising household debt. The decision aims to support the economy amidst these challenges.

site_title: Standard Chartered currency research head said to be leaving
summary: Standard Chartered's global head of foreign-exchange research, Callum Henderson, is leaving the bank, according to two people familiar with the situation. Henderson's name was removed from the bank's website and his company email account was taken offline. Despite this, Henderson "is currently still an employee of Standard Chartered Bank" and remains the global head of foreign-exchange research, according to a bank spokeswoman.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.92 points to 1,688.54. A total of 2.2 billion lots valued at RM2.2 billion were traded, with 453 gainers outnumbering losers 412.

site_title: Pacific International Lines selling 3-year bonds
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) is selling 3-year bonds worth S$100 million, with some room to grow. The issue is progressing well, according to DBS Bank's Clifford Lee, head of fixed income. The final price and size guidance for the trade has been released.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's moneylenders' credit bureau will begin operations in 2016, requiring licensed moneylenders to provide loan information. Wheel Deal, a car-selling concierge service, was launched by Singapore Press Holdings. A study found companies with humble CEOs enjoy higher return on assets. JLL predicts new Asian players could challenge established cities like Singapore. China's President Xi Jinping will meet Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou in a historic summit. The Straits Times Index slipped 16.83 points due to US rate worries, and Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%.

site_title: Nera Q3 profit drops 43% as sales fall in all key segments
summary: Nera Telecommunications reported a 43.3% drop in Q3 net profit to S$2 million, with revenue falling 20.2% to S$39.6 million. Sales declined across all segments, including telecommunications (-15.9%), network infrastructure (-30.3%), and payment solutions (-8.3%). The company secured S$164.7 million in order intake in the first nine months, down 3.3% from the previous year. Net profit for the first nine months fell 22.4% to S$9 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit by weakness in bank stocks, NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Thursday, with bank stocks leading the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,193.00, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index reached a record high of 6,073.63, ending 0.04% higher.

site_title: Renewable energy supply to double in major economies by 2030
summary: Renewable energy supply in eight major economies, including Brazil, China, EU, India, Indonesia, Japan, Mexico, and the US, is expected to more than double by 2030, reaching 20,000 terawatt hours from around 9,000 TWh in 2009. This growth is driven by new national climate and energy plans, with combined renewable energy targets from these countries equivalent to India's current energy demand. The move sends strong signals to energy markets and investment circles, positioning renewable energy for a surge in the next 15 years.

site_title: Hong Kong street food gets nod from Michelin Guide
summary: Hong Kong's street food vendors have made it to the Michelin Guide for the first time, with a new category created to reflect the city's local culinary scene. The guide features 23 new restaurants in Hong Kong and 12 in Macau, with 77 awarded star ratings. Notable additions include T'ang Court, a Cantonese restaurant with three stars, and Forum and Ming Court, both with two stars. The inclusion of street food vendors aims to showcase the city's affordable yet high-quality dining options, with many now having fixed addresses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close flat, China rally offsets Fed chief's message
summary: Hong Kong shares finished flat on Thursday, as a rally in China's stock market offset losses from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's message of a possible "liftoff" in US interest rates in December. The Hang Seng index remained unchanged at 23,051.04. China's China Enterprises Index gained 0.5% to 10,617.67 points, while US interest rate concerns hindered the market.

site_title: Trading activity on SGX slows month-on-month in Oct, but up from year ago
summary: SGX's trading activity slowed 7% month-on-month in October, with daily average stock value at S$1.0 billion and volume rising 19.9% to 1.7 billion shares. Total derivatives volume dropped 19% over the same period. On a year-on-year basis, daily average value increased 1% while volume rose 13%. The total market turnover in October was S$20.4 billion.

images.alt_text: The daily average turnover of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell 7 per cent month-on-month in October, while total derivatives volume dropped 19 per cent over the same period, the market operator announced on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysian government to address Najib funds scandal next month
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak will address questions about a funding scandal surrounding him on December 3, the last day before parliament goes on hiatus. The scandal, which involves hundreds of millions of dollars in donations ending up in Najib's private accounts, has fueled political tensions and prompted a no-confidence motion. Najib has denied taking money for personal gain, but the issue remains a major concern for the opposition and has led to a reshuffle of his cabinet. The Malaysian government will finally address the scandal, providing answers to lawmakers' questions.

site_title: Indonesia's economic growth picks up slightly in Q3
summary: Indonesia's economy showed a slight recovery in Q3, driven by infrastructure spending, but still fell short of expectations. Growth figures rose from recent lows, with analysts cautiously optimistic that the momentum can carry over into the final quarter. Despite this, the country's economic performance remains below President Joko Widodo's ambitious targets. Indonesia's economy, the largest in Southeast Asia, continues to face challenges, but analysts believe it can ride the momentum into the year's end.

site_title: URA tender gets 11 bids for 99-year private condo site in Lorong Lew Lian
summary: A 99-year leasehold private housing site in Lorong Lew Lian has attracted 11 bids from developers, with the highest bid valued at S$321 million (S$710 per square foot per plot ratio). The lowest bid was S$265.9 million (S$588 psf ppr). The Urban Redevelopment Authority conducted the tender, and the winning bid was from a three-way partnership involving City Developments, Verwood Holdings, and others.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: UK house prices rise more strongly than expected in Oct: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 1.1% in October, surpassing expectations, with a 9.7% year-over-year growth. This beats the Reuters poll's 9.5% prediction. The increase erases the 0.9% decline in September. Halifax attributes the rise to an imbalance between supply and demand, suggesting prices will continue to climb.

site_title: Optus wins A$115m deal from Australia's immigration department
summary: Optus Business has signed a three-year, A$115 million contract with Australia's Department of Immigration and Border Protection. The deal supports approximately 15,000 IP handsets, 1,000 wireless access points, and 1,000 LAN switches, along with a managed help desk. The agreement is underpinned by Optus's MPLS carriage network, satellite communications, and mobile data services to 200 sites across Australia.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Ties with China likely worse if opposition returns to power: KMT chief
summary: Taiwan's ruling party presidential candidate Eric Chu warned that ties with China will likely deteriorate if the opposition party returns to power in January elections. This comes ahead of talks between Taiwan and China leaders in Singapore, the first such meeting since 1949. Chu's Nationalists are trailing in opinion polls, while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, led by the independence-leaning frontrunner, is favored to win. China has expressed disapproval of the DPP.

site_title: German factory orders fall in September
summary: German industrial orders fell 1.7% in September, down from August's 1.8% decline and July's 2.2% drop. Weaker foreign demand, particularly from the eurozone, led to a 2.4% decline in export orders and a 0.6% drop in domestic orders. Orders from outside the eurozone edged up 0.7%. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, underscoring the impact of weaker global demand on Germany's economy.

site_title: UBS sets up US$100m outbound investment shop in Shanghai
summary: UBS has set up a US$100m outbound investment shop in Shanghai's free trade zone, utilizing China's Qualified Domestic Limited Partner (QDLP) scheme to raise private funds for international investments. The new entity will manage Chinese investments in overseas asset classes, with the goal of enhancing access to international markets for Chinese clients. This move follows other fund managers in using the QDLP program to tap high-net-worth Chinese investors for overseas investments. The success of the QDLP funds and Beijing's openness to capital account opening remain uncertain, amid record capital outflows and yuan depreciation pressure.

site_title: China: Stocks extend rally, volume at 2-1/2 mth high
summary: China's stocks rose 2.1% and 1.9% on Thursday, driven by optimism over the Hong Kong-Shenzhen stock market connect scheme, China's telecommunication reform plan, and the country's economic growth. The CSI300 index reached a two-and-a-half-month high, with trading volume hitting 55.2 billion shares in Shanghai and 42.8 billion shares in Shenzhen. Several securities firms hit a daily upward limit of 10%. The gains were attributed to positive sentiments ahead of a meeting between Chinese and Taiwanese leaders.

site_title: CWT lost S$6.3m in Tianjin blast, posts 16% decline in Q3 profit
summary: CWT, a logistics and derivatives trading company, reported a 16% decline in Q3 profit to S$27.2 million, amid lower naphtha sales and losses from the Tianjin blast, which incurred a net loss of S$6.3 million. Revenue fell 51% to S$1.9 billion, and shares dropped 1.8%. Despite a 5% increase in gross profit, the company's operating expenses widened to S$16.4 million. The Tianjin blast also led to estimated insurance claims of S$9.2 million.

site_title: Toyota says six-month net profit jumps to US$10.35b
summary: Toyota's six-month net profit surged to $10.35 billion, a 12% increase from the previous year. The company's revenue rose 9% to $14.09 trillion yen, driven by a weak yen and cost-cutting measures. Despite selling 4.97 million cars globally, Toyota boosted its full-year sales target. The company is focusing on productivity gains and reducing development costs to offset market challenges. A new plant in Mexico and production overhaul efforts are part of its strategy to remain competitive in the global market.

site_title: Roche, to counter biosimilars, sees launches, data on 8 new drugs by 2018
summary: Roche plans to launch or release pivotal data for up to eight new medicines by 2018 to counter biosimilars. The company expects seven major clinical trial results in 2015 and 2017, including new treatments for bladder and lung cancer, multiple sclerosis, and immune system boosting. This strategy aims to fend off competition from biosimilar versions of its older drugs starting in 2017 as their patents expire.

site_title: The Buddhist priest who became a billionaire snubbing investors
summary: Billionaire Buddhist priest Kazuo Inamori is challenging the conventional wisdom that prioritizing shareholders is key to business success. Inamori, who runs electronics giant Kyocera Corp and Japan Airlines, believes that focusing on employees' happiness and well-being is crucial for long-term success. He attributes his success to his "amoeba management" system, which empowers staff to make their own plans and track their own efficiency. Inamori's approach has yielded significant profits, with Kyocera's combined market value exceeding $82 billion. He argues that companies should prioritize both shareholders and employees, and that a balance between the two is essential for sustainable growth.

site_title: Rio Tinto defends boosting iron ore output despite diving price
summary: Rio Tinto's iron ore chief, Andrew Harding, defended the company's decision to expand production despite a plunging price, citing Australia's inability to control the global market. The company's output rose 12% in the July-September quarter, adding to a supply glut worsened by slowing Chinese demand. Harding said the large miners are competing for market share and will lose if they stop producing. Rio expects world demand for iron ore to increase by two% by 2030, driven by strong demand from China and emerging markets.

site_title: China fuel surplus to double by 2020 as refining sector opens: CNPC research
summary: China's fuel surplus is expected to double by 2020, reaching nearly 30 million tonnes, driven by increasing output from independent refiners, known as "teapots". These smaller refineries, allowed to import crude for the first time, will produce higher-quality oil products, becoming more competitive in the Chinese market. The growing surplus is forecast to lead to increased exports, potentially stoking competition with the US, the world's second-largest refining industry.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won end down as Dec US rate hike looms large
summary: South Korean shares and won declined on Thursday after Federal Reserve Chair Yellen's comments hinted at a potential US interest rate hike as early as December. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed 0.2% lower at 2,049.42 points. Foreigners sold 28.5 billion won worth of shares for the first time in four days, contributing to the market's downturn. The comments sparked concerns about the impact of a rate hike on the Korean economy.

site_title: Historic Xi-Ma summit advances China's long game for Taiwan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou will meet in Singapore on November 7, marking the first formal diplomatic encounter between the two sides in 7 decades. The summit aims to promote peace across the Taiwan Strait and maintain the "status quo." Xi views Taiwan as a renegade province, while Ma seeks to maintain peace. The meeting is the latest twist in a long-standing geopolitical contest dating back to the Chinese Civil War in 1949.

site_title: Indonesia's economy expanded less than estimated last quarter
summary: Indonesia's economy expanded 4.73% in the September quarter, less than the estimated 4.8% growth, according to the statistics bureau. This growth rate is a challenge for President Joko Widodo's government as it seeks to boost growth amid declining commodity demand, stagnating foreign investment, and weak domestic consumption. The government is rolling out measures to improve the business climate to revive growth.

site_title: DBS expands non-ATM cash withdrawal points to supermarkets
summary: DBS Bank has expanded its network of cash withdrawal points to supermarkets in Singapore, allowing customers to withdraw up to S$200 without a fee at locations like Cold Storage and Giant stores. The bank now has approximately 800 such locations, known as POSB Cash-Points. This move follows a rise in customer adoption of non-ATM withdrawals, and customers can also withdraw larger amounts at SingPost outlets.

site_title: VW scandal widens as India says vehicles exceeded emission rules
summary: Volkswagen faces scrutiny in India after probes on four car models revealed diesel emissions exceeded permissible limits. The company's vehicles, including Jetta, Vento, Polo, and Audi A4, were found to have variations in results between on-road tests and laboratory tests. Approximately 314,000 vehicles are potentially affected. India's Heavy Industries Ministry has given Volkswagen 30 days to respond to the findings, which could be considered criminal if cars have defeat devices. This adds to the automaker's woes following US pollution test admissions in September.

images.alt_text: India sought a response from Volkswagen AG after probes into four car models showed diesel-fuel emissions exceeding permissible limits, and variations in results between on-road tests and those done in laboratories.

site_title: Takata plunges for second day as airbag scandal spirals
summary: Takata's shares plummeted 23% to 914 yen, losing nearly a quarter of their value, amid a fatal airbag scandal. The company faces a record fine of up to $200 million and has been recalled for 50 million vehicles worldwide. Honda dumped Takata as an airbag parts supplier, while Toyota and Nissan expressed disappointment with the company's conduct. The crisis threatens Takata's mainstay business, with shares in rival Daicel rising 6.27% in response.

site_title: New Asian players could emerge as threats to established cities like Singapore: JLL
summary: New Asian cities, including Sydney, Seoul, and Shanghai, are emerging as potential threats to established world cities like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo, according to JLL. These cities are competing to attract world-class corporations, talent, and real estate investment. The "Big Six" cities are expected to break down, with emerging cities like Bangalore, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou gaining strength. JLL identifies Taipei, Kuala Lumpur, and Jakarta as emerging world cities with strong infrastructure and governance, while Singapore's business-friendly environment is expected to cement its position as an innovation hub.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

A number of cities in the Asia-Pacific, including Sydney and Seoul, could emerge to challenge the dominance of established world cities such as Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo, property consultants JLL said.

site_title: Asian collector snaps up US$43m Modigliani in New York
summary: An Asian collector purchased an Amadeo Modigliani painting for nearly US$43 million at Sotheby's auction house in New York, marking the top sale of the evening. The two-and-a-half hour auction saw strong bidding from America and Europe, but Asia's acquisition highlights the region's growing purchasing power in the art market. The sale was part of a collection amassed by self-made American billionaire Alfred Taubman, who previously served jail time for price fixing in 2002.

site_title: US dollar steady as Fed chief keeps December rate rise in play
summary: US dollar holds steady in Asia as Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen suggests a December interest rate hike is possible. Yellen's comments, made during congressional testimony, support the view that the US economy is on the upswing, sparking dollar buying. The dollar ticked lower against the yen, while Asian emerging currencies fell against the greenback. The comments also raise pressure on policymakers, with high-yield, riskier emerging currencies hit hard this year due to fears of a US rate lift-off.

site_title: SBF appoints Lee Yi Shyan adviser to Africa, China and Mid-East business groups
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has appointed Lee Yi Shyan as adviser to its Africa, China, and Middle East business groups. As part of its internationalisation efforts, Lee will advise on economic ties between Singapore and these markets, strengthening the group's in-market reach and business facilitation efforts. His extensive relationships in government and business sectors will contribute to these goals.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes near 10-week high on weak yen, corporate earnings
summary: Japanese stocks closed near a 10-week high on Thursday, with the Nikkei share average rising 1% to 19,116.41. A weaker yen boosted exporter prospects, while corporate earnings and dividend announcements drove share buying. Food seasoning manufacturer Ajinomoto Co Inc jumped 5.5% after raising full-year guidance and announcing share buybacks, while Japan Tobacco Inc gained 6.8% after raising its dividend payout. The Nikkei's close was its highest since August 28.

site_title: Singapore life insurance business jumps 15% to S$813m in Q3
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 15% increase in total weighted new business premiums to S$813 million in Q3 2015, driven by higher annual premium products and savings-oriented bancassurance sales. This represents a 7% rise in total weighted new business premiums for the first nine months of the year, compared to the same period in 2014. New product launches, sales, and marketing initiatives contributed to the growth.

site_title: Singapore moneylenders' credit bureau to start operations in 2016
summary: Singapore's moneylenders' credit bureau is set to begin operations in 2016, according to DP Information Group. The credit bureau, run by DP Info, will require licensed moneylenders to share information on loans and customer payment behavior. This will help promote responsible borrowing and reduce defaults. The information will be accessible to licensed moneylenders only, unless approved by the Ministry of Law. The initiative aims to improve transparency and encourage individuals to carefully consider their financial circumstances before taking out loans.

site_title: Adidas raises outlook after strong third quarter
summary: Adidas raised its full-year sales and profit outlook after reporting a 18% increase in sales to 4.758 billion euros in the third quarter, beating analyst forecasts. The company expects currency-neutral sales to rise at a high-single-digit rate and net income to increase at around 10%. This is higher than its previous 7-10% target. The recovery of its golf business contributed to the positive results, with sales accelerating from a 5% rise in the second quarter.

site_title: GIC puts US$85m in Bloomage in bet on botox products
summary: GIC's private-equity unit has invested HK$659 million (S$119 million) in Hong Kong-listed Bloomage BioTechnology Corporation Ltd. through convertible bonds and new shares, tapping into China's growing medical cosmetics market. Bloomage aims to pursue internal and external growth strategies to drive domestic and global expansion. The investment will be used to inject vitality into China's aesthetic medical ecosystem.

site_title: Asia: Markets defy negative Wall Street lead
summary: Asian markets defied a negative US lead, with Shanghai's benchmark index reaching a 10-week high and Japan's Nikkei 225 up 1.03%. China's Communist party issued guidelines for its 2016-2020 development plan, including liberalization of markets and foreign exchange. Japan Post stocks soared for a second day, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 fell 1.1%. The US dollar strengthened after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate hike in December.

site_title: Japan govt to allow testing of self-driving cars from FY2017: source
summary: Japan's government plans to ease regulations for self-driving cars, allowing testing on public roads from fiscal 2017, with the goal of providing the service for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The government also aims to ease restrictions on small drones to encourage innovation. No specific details have been finalized, and the proposal will be announced at a meeting between cabinet ministers and private sector companies. This move is part of Japan's efforts to promote autonomous technology ahead of the Olympics.

site_title: Suu Kyi says 'will run government' if party wins Myanmar poll
summary: Myanmar democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi vowed to run the government if her National League for Democracy (NLD) party wins the country's landmark election, despite being barred from the presidency. Suu Kyi, who has towered over Myanmar's politics for decades, said she would be "above the president" in the event of a victory. The election, set for Sunday, could see the army's decades-long grip on power substantially loosened, with the NLD expected to make major gains if the vote is free and fair.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's democracy heroine Aung San Suu Kyi on Thursday vowed to run the government if her opposition party wins this Sunday's landmark election, despite being barred from the presidency.

site_title: Toshiba to report huge half-year operating loss: report
summary: Toshiba is expected to report a huge half-year operating loss of 90 billion yen (S$1.03 billion) due to a massive accounting scandal. The operating loss marks the company's first in six years, contrasting with a year-earlier profit of 137.8 billion yen. Despite this, Toshiba is expected to report a net profit of about 40 billion yen for the half-year after selling stakes in group companies. The scandal has slowed Toshiba's restructuring efforts and impacted its "lifestyle" products segment, leading to a net loss of roughly 70 billion yen during the six months.

site_title: Why Deutsche Bank's little jewel in India was spared the ax
summary: Deutsche Bank has decided to retain its operations in India, despite announcing the closure of 10 countries to revive profits. The Indian unit has managed to avoid bad-loan problems and has the lowest bad-loan ratio among the five largest foreign banks in India. Its corporate banking focus has contributed to its healthy loan book, with profits almost doubling in the year through March. This decision is seen as a strategic move to continue operations in a market that has performed well compared to others.

site_title: PLife Reit posts 15.6% rise in distributable income for Q3
summary: PARKWAY Life Real Estate Investment Trust (PLife Reit) reported a 15.6% year-on-year rise in third-quarter distributable income to S$20.3 million, driven by higher-yielding properties and rental income. Without one-time gains, recurring distributable income grew 2.5%. The trust has hedged 78% of its interest rate exposure and strengthened its balance sheet, eliminating refinancing risk. Despite macro headwinds, the trust delivered consistent attractive results and rewards to unitholders, with a gearing level of 35.8%.

site_title: Humble CEO generates higher return on assets: study
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore and Arizona State University found that humble CEOs, as rated by their CFOs, are associated with higher return on assets (ROA) in companies. About 5% of a firm's ROA is linked to humble CEOs, who tend to have more collaborative top management teams and lower pay disparities. The study, examining 105 small-to-medium-sized firms in the US computer software and hardware industry, suggests that humble CEOs contribute to better firm performance through top management team integration and pay equality.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia: Shares skid on caution over US rate hike; NZ steady
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% to 5,193.2, tracking a US rate hike indication by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen. Banking stocks, despite record profits, were hit by investor concerns over economic challenges. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for another weekly loss. Key sectors, including banks, grains, and real estate, were in the red, while Echo Entertainment rose 7.3% after a positive Morgan Stanley outlook.

site_title: China's Li urges Japan businesses to help improve ties
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged Japanese businesses to improve ties, promising a more open and fair investment environment for foreign companies. He also encouraged cooperation on production capacity and infrastructure development in developing countries. Li's comments come as China's economy slows and faces increased competition from Southeast Asia. China's defense minister warned Japan not to complicate the situation in the South China Sea, while Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed support for cooperation in the region.

site_title: Print publications, TV still most highly consumed media in Singapore: survey
summary: A Nielsen report found that print publications and TV are the most highly consumed media in Singapore, with 92.7% of adults reading print newspapers and 84% tuning into free-to-air TV channels weekly. Digital platforms also gained traction, with 76.2% of adults using the internet daily and 79.5% monthly. Local media owners are integrating offline and online offerings to cater to the growing demands of consumers. This shift reflects the evolving media landscape, where traditional and digital platforms coexist to provide a multi-platform experience to the Singapore audience.

images.alt_text: Traditional media - print publications and television broadcasts - continues to be the most highly consumed media by adults in Singapore, according to a Nielsen report released on Thursday.

site_title: Gold near 1-month low as Yellen signals December rate hike
summary: Gold prices near a one-month low due to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on a possible December interest rate hike, boosting market expectations. Yellen stated that low unemployment, growth, and inflation suggest the US is ready for higher interest rates. This has led to a drop in gold prices, with spot gold reaching $1,110.10 an ounce, its lowest since October 2. Investors expect a 60% chance of a December rate hike, causing a surge in US Treasury yields and a stronger dollar, hurting gold prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.75 points to 1683.43. Volume was 36 million lots worth RM11.6 million, with 101 gainers and 76 losers. This marks a change in trend from the previous day's 0.4% gain in the STI.

site_title: Fed's Fischer: proposals to limit Fed independence "dangerous"
summary: Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer stated that proposals to limit the Federal Reserve's independence could be "dangerous" and undermine its ability to control inflation. Fischer argued that central bank independence has a long track record of success and that making the Fed accountable to Congress for every policy decision would be counterproductive. He emphasized the importance of the Fed's independence in responding effectively to crises, warning that it would be "subject to the very sort of political pressure" from which central banks should be independent.

images.alt_text: Congressional influence on US monetary policy could wreck the Federal Reserve's ability to control inflation and be a "dangerous" departure from the broadly accepted norm of central bank independence, Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer said on Wednesday.

site_title: Xi meeting will maintain status quo with China, Taiwan's Ma says
summary: Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou stated that his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping will maintain the current status quo, preserving their cooperative relationship. This historic face-to-face encounter, the first in seven decades, aims to foster future negotiations. Ma sought the meeting to secure economic ties and avoid a power vacuum in Taiwan upon his departure. The meeting marks a significant milestone in relations between China and the US, which have long been at the center of tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip, Shanghai up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened down 0.25% on Thursday, tracking US losses, while Shanghai edged up 0.13% and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.23%. This follows hopes for economic reforms in China.

site_title: HDB resale prices flat in October; transactions up 16%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices remained flat in October, with three-room and executive flats rising 0.7% and 0.9% month-on-month, while four and five-room flats eased 0.8% and 0.1% respectively. This follows a 0.4% drop in September. The overall resale price index for HDB flats in October was the same as in September.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won fall on Yellen comments
summary: South Korean shares and the won fell on Thursday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments reinforced views of a possible interest rate hike in December. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 0.4%, and the won slipped 0.4% against the dollar. Yellen stated the US was ready for higher interest rates if economic data justifies them, prompting investors to sell KOSPI shares and shift to domestic consumption-related sectors.

site_title: China urges US Congress to ratify IMF quota reforms: Vice Finance Minister
summary: China's Vice Finance Minister Zhu Guangyao urged the US Congress to ratify IMF quota reforms that would give emerging markets a bigger say at the International Monetary Fund. The reforms, agreed in 2010, have been delayed due to Congress' inaction. Zhu also mentioned the upcoming Federal Reserve meeting in December, which could mark the first US rate rise in nearly a decade.

site_title: Indonesia volcanic ash closes Bali airport for third day
summary: Bali's Ngurah Rai airport was closed for a third day due to volcanic ash from Mount Rinjani on Lombok island. The closure, which began on Tuesday, has halted flights to and from Bali, Lombok, and Banyuwangi, and has canceled 692 domestic and international flights. The shutdown is expected to significantly impact Indonesia's tourism efforts, with Bali accounting for 40% of foreign tourist arrivals. The airport is set to reopen by Friday morning for an assessment of conditions.

site_title: Alibaba, Baidu turn 'kingmakers' as China sees dealmaking surge
summary: China's dealmaking surge is driven by consolidation among its largest internet companies, including Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent. The trio, known as BAT, has been merging ventures in fragmented niches, with acquisitions totaling US$413.2 billion this year, a 75% increase from last year. Investors are pushing for profitability, and the deals are expected to continue, with potential candidates for consolidation including food-delivery firms. Analysts say the wave of deals is driven by the need for strategic consolidation and the abundance of capital in China's startup market.

site_title: China says Disney to get special trademark protection
summary: China will grant special trademark protection to Walt Disney Co for its upcoming theme park in mainland China, starting in 2016. This move aims to crack down on Disney counterfeits and promote a fair market, protecting China's international image. China has struggled with a reputation for fakes, affecting brands like Apple and LVMH, and this initiative will run until October 2016. The campaign will also target other counterfeiters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, PLife Reit, Thakral, Rowsley
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) completed its $4.55 billion US acquisition, expanding its US footprint by 50% to 173 million square feet. Parkway Life Reit reported a 15.6% increase in distribution per unit to 3.36 Singapore cents. Thakral Corporation swung back into profit with a net profit of $5.8 million, while Rowsley posted a net loss of $4.2 million.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: SPH launches Singapore's first car-selling concierge service
summary: SPH launches Wheel Deal, a car-selling concierge service in Singapore, allowing car owners to receive quotes from authorized dealers and potentially close deals the same day. The service, which has seen S$540,000 worth of used cars sold since its soft launch, aims to provide convenience, trust, and transparency in the car trade. At least six dealers, including 99 Motors Trading and CarTimes Automobile, are part of the network. A mobile app is not currently planned, with the service instead focusing on the "human touch" provided by its service representatives.

site_title: Bonds tumble around the globe as Fed rate odds climb past 50 per cent
summary: Bonds worldwide are falling as traders increase odds the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates above 50% this year. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields reached a seven-week high of 2.24% after Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments. Global bond yields are rising in sympathy with Treasuries, driven by the Fed's influence on global debt markets. The yield on the Bloomberg Global Developed Sovereign Bond Index also reached a seven-week high, with traders seeing a 58% chance the Fed will raise its benchmark by its Dec. 15-16 meeting.

site_title: Australian banks say they will support low-carbon lending
summary: Australian banks National Australia Bank and Commonwealth Bank of Australia have announced initiatives to support low-carbon lending, potentially hindering the country's coal industry. National Australia Bank will finance A$18 billion in renewable energy projects through 2022, while Commonwealth Bank will consider environment risks in loan approvals. This move follows similar efforts by ANZ Banking Group to lend A$10 billion to projects cutting greenhouse gases. Australia's largest banks have lent over A$36 billion to fossil fuel projects since 2008, prompting green groups to call for banks to stop providing loans citing climate damage.

site_title: Philippine Oct inflation steady at record low 0.4%
summary: The Philippine annual inflation rate remained steady at 0.4% in October, matching the previous month's record low, according to the statistics agency. Lower food prices were offset by increases in transport, alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and clothing costs. This brought the 10-month average inflation rate to 1.4%, below the central bank's 2-4% target for the year. The rate slightly beat the 0.5% forecast in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Australia's new vehicle sales up 3.4% year on year in Oct
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales rose 3.4% in October, driven by strong demand for sports utilities, with 94,321 vehicles sold. Sports utility vehicles (SUVs) saw a 20.5% increase, while passenger vehicles dipped 5.3%. Toyota retained the top spot with 18.0% market share, followed by Hyundai and Mazda. The local Holden unit and Ford trailed behind. This marks the second consecutive month of strong sales growth, with SUVs and small SUVs leading the way.

images.alt_text: Sales of new vehicles in Australia rose 3.4 per cent in October compared with the same period a year ago, a second month of strong gains led by demand for sports utilities.

site_title: Rio Tinto sees strong growth in iron ore demand outside China
summary: Rio Tinto expects strong growth in iron ore demand outside China, driven by a 2% average annual increase to 3 billion tonnes by 2030. Non-Chinese demand for steel is expected to increase by 65% in the same period, with Asean economies and India playing key roles. Australia and Brazil are expected to supply half of the expansion in global iron ore demand through the seaborne market.

site_title: Standard Chartered said to seek sale of billionaire Ruia loans
summary: Standard Chartered and other creditors to India's billionaire Ruia brothers are seeking to sell off US$3.5 billion in loans to the Essar Group, citing concerns over the conglomerate's debt and declining earnings. The loans were used to fund new projects and investments, but the company's earnings have been hurt by commodity price falls and weak demand. Negotiations are ongoing, but creditors are reluctant to offload the loans at a significant discount. The situation remains fluid, with Essar Global stating it will consider selling assets to pay down debt.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wall St and Yellen's hint at Dec rate hike
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.58% on Thursday, as US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible December interest-rate hike, pricing in a 58% chance of a rate increase. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,022.76, with DBS, Singtel, and UOB leading the decline. Traders now expect a 58% chance of a rate hike, up from 50% the previous day. The market remains cautious despite a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.54% higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.54% higher on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 102.53 points to 19,029.44. This follows a positive lead from Asia's other major markets, including Singapore, where stocks have rallied for a fifth consecutive day. Meanwhile, US stocks also reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: GIC to invest US$85m in Bloomage BioTechnology
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is investing HK$659 million (S$119.34 million) in Hong Kong-listed Bloomage BioTechnology Corp, betting on the firm's leading medical cosmetic products and services. The investment includes convertible bonds and new shares. This move aligns with GIC's strategy of investing in technology companies in China and India.

site_title: US dollar strengthens to three-month high after Fed chief says Dec rate rise a "live possibility"
summary: The US dollar strengthened to its highest level in three months after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that an interest-rate increase in December is a "live possibility" if economic data holds up. The dollar rose 0.9% to US$1.0866 per euro, with a 58% chance of a rate hike in December, according to traders. The Fed is closely watching the US jobs market, which added 182,000 jobs in the latest report, as they consider raising rates for the first time since 2006.

site_title: China woes hurt chipmaker Qualcomm's profit forecast
summary: Qualcomm Inc forecasted a profit of 80-90 cents per share for the first quarter, significantly below analysts' expectations. The company struggles with fierce competition from Chinese and Taiwanese rivals, and delays in closing new licensing agreements in China. Revenue declined 18.5% to $5.46 billion, but topped Street expectations. Qualcomm shares fell nearly 6% in extended trading. The company faces ongoing challenges in China, including improper royalty withholding by some customers, and is in the middle of a strategic review.

site_title: "Brexit" could cut Irish/UK trade by 20 per cent: think tank
summary: A report by the Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) in Ireland estimates that trade between Ireland and the UK could fall by at least 20% if Britain leaves the European Union, with significant implications for the Irish economy. The report highlights the importance of the UK as Ireland's second-largest market for merchandise exports and largest market for the fast-growing service sector. Ireland's government has also expressed concerns over the potential impact on peace in Northern Ireland.

site_title: French FN founder Le Pen's home searched in tax fraud probe: legal sources
summary: French police searched the home of National Front founder Jean-Marie Le Pen in a tax fraud probe, according to judicial sources. The investigation, opened in June, suspects Le Pen of stashing money abroad and failing to declare his assets. A formal complaint was filed on September 24, naming Le Pen and his wife Jany. The probe is ongoing, with Le Pen and his wife facing possible charges.

site_title: UK unveils powers to spy on Web use, raising privacy fears
summary: The UK has unveiled new surveillance powers, including the ability to track website visits, sparking concerns over privacy. The Home Secretary, Theresa May, says the measures are necessary to keep the country safe, but critics argue they represent an assault on freedoms. The new bill will limit access to web use to "Internet connection records" and not full browsing history, and will also require communication service providers to hold customers' web browsing data for a year. Critics, including tech companies and civil liberties groups, say the bill is a setback for privacy rights and could lead to a surveillance state.

site_title: Expedia unveils US$3.9b deal for HomeAway
summary: Expedia has agreed to acquire vacation marketplace HomeAway for $3.9 billion, bolstering its efforts to compete with online travel aggregators like Kayak and Airbnb. The deal, announced on November 4, 2015, comes weeks after Expedia's takeover of online rival Orbitz. HomeAway has over 1 million vacation listings and operates under its own brand and VRBO. The acquisition aims to expand Expedia's presence in the alternative accommodations space and strengthen its portfolio of trusted travel brands.

site_title: US government approves Italy's request to arm its drones
summary: The US State Department has approved Italy's request to arm its MQ-9 Reaper drones with Hellfire missiles and other munitions, marking the first effective sale of armed drones since the US policy change in February. This approval follows Britain's use of armed drones since 2007, and Italy is set to be the second country to receive this capability.

site_title: China's Xi heads to Vietnam as anger brews over visit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is visiting Vietnam, a move that has drawn ire from Vietnamese nationalists amid a decades-old feud over disputed territory in the South China Sea. Anti-China activists have staged rare protests in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, while the Chinese leader aims to improve relations and calm tensions. Xi will meet with Vietnamese leaders to discuss the territorial dispute and cooperation on trade, education, and infrastructure. Vietnam has been strengthening ties with other nations to counter China's growing regional influence, and the visit is seen as an attempt by Xi to improve relations after a low point in 2014.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras buys gasoline from Braskem in November
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrobras agreed to buy 82,000 cu m of gasoline from Braskem SA in November, bolstering fuel supplies amid a strike that cuts crude oil output. The contract, signed on Oct 26, reflects the lower retail price for gasoline in Brazil. The purchase eases Petrobras' fuel-import needs, reducing the impact of a 30% decline in Brazil's real against the US dollar. The deal comes amid concerns over Petrobras' naphtha contracts with Braskem, controlled by the Odebrecht Group, amidst a price-fixing scandal.

site_title: Malaysian Air chief putting last touches to Southeast Asia hub
summary: Malaysian Air chief Christoph Mueller says the network restructuring aimed at establishing Kuala Lumpur as a Southeast Asia hub is 90% complete. The airline is shifting to smaller jets, slashing capacity by 30%, and has cut 6,000 jobs. The restructuring plan, valued at 6 billion ringgit, aims to target markets including China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar. Mueller aims to fine-tune frequency patterns but has fixed capacity-per-destination. The airline has amassed 4.9 billion ringgit in losses since 2011 and was taken private by Khazanah Nasional Bhd in a 1.38 billion ringgit buyout.

site_title: Europe: Shares end off highs as Yellen points to Dec hike
summary: European shares ended the day off their highs after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible rate hike in December, while Germany's blue-chip index fell due to a scandal at Volkswagen. The FTSEurofirst 300 rose 0.46% despite strong US services sector data, and basic resources stocks gained 1.6% on firmer copper prices. Yellen stated the Fed would take a gradual approach to raising rates, and the European Central Bank's stimulus review in December may help European equities make gains by year-end.

site_title: Obama plans to visit Laos, a first for a US president
summary: President Barack Obama plans to visit Laos in 2016 to attend a regional economic summit, making him the first US president to visit the country. This visit comes after a National Security aide's recent trip to Laos, which helped lay groundwork for Vientiane's 2016 chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. The visit highlights a shift in US relations with Laos, a country that was heavily bombed by the US during the Vietnam War.

site_title: Planning for a green future
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is leading efforts to develop a sustainable maritime industry in the country. To achieve this, MPA has implemented measures such as the Maritime Singapore Green Initiative, which offers financial incentives for environmentally friendly shipping practices. The agency is also planning the Tuas Next Generation Port, set to open in 2030, with a focus on efficiency, intelligence, sustainability, and community orientation. MPA aims to raise awareness and encourage companies to adopt sustainable practices, recognizing the alignment between environmental sustainability, profits, and people.

site_title: Making the space count
summary: Singapore's economic success is attributed to innovative infrastructure development, particularly in the 1980s with the introduction of the Singapore Science Park. The park integrated high-quality business and research infrastructure with lifestyle amenities, setting a model for future projects. The government's clustering concept has also been successful, with the creation of industries such as biomedicine and chemicals. To meet evolving needs, Singapore is exploring new ways to develop its infrastructure, including reclaiming land and using underground space. The country's success has been recognized globally, with the World Bank Group announcing plans to expand its Singapore office.

site_title: Pakistan factory collapse kills 18, dozens trapped
summary: At least 18 people were killed and 51 injured when a factory collapsed in Lahore, Pakistan, with around 100 more still trapped. The incident occurred near the eastern Pakistani city, less than two weeks after a 7.5-magnitude earthquake in Afghanistan and Pakistan, killing nearly 390 people.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends down after energy slide, Yellen comments
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, retracing recent gains, as energy shares fell 1.0% and US crude oil dropped 3.3%. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments suggested a possible interest rate hike in December, adding to investor caution. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, but the market was weighed down by energy shares.

site_title: Lloyd's CEO urges insurers to focus on risk knowledge rather than pricing
summary: Lloyd's CEO Inga Beale emphasized the need for insurers to focus on risk knowledge rather than pricing, citing declining underwriting profits and competitive pressure. She urged insurers to prioritize understanding exposures and pricing accordingly to ensure sustainability. New and emerging risks, such as cyber attacks and reputation damage, present opportunities for insurers, but require a deeper understanding of non-physical risks. Beale also highlighted the growth potential of the Asia-Pacific market, with Lloyd's writing $4.7 billion in premiums last year, and expects further expansion into China, Malaysia, and Latin America.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$258m for violating US sanctions
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay US$258 million in fines for violating US sanctions by doing business with countries like Iran and Syria. The bank disguised over 27,000 transactions valued at over US$10.86 billion between 1999 and 2006, and will install an independent monitor and fire six employees involved in the scheme. The bank will also bar three employees from work involving US operations. The penalties are dwarfed by those paid by French banks BNP Paribas and Credit Agricole, and follow a record US$2.5 billion fine for interest rate rigging in May.

site_title: Social media use was high, but not as decisive for voters
summary: In Singapore's 2015 general election, social media use was high among voters, with 79% of citizens aged 18-65 using social media to some extent. However, social media did not play a decisive role in the election, with 47.3% of voters already making up their minds before Nomination Day. Mainstream media sources were more trusted than social media, with TV and print newspapers being the top three most-trusted sources. Social media users were more interested in election issues and more optimistic about government responsiveness, but also more divided on the role of a powerful leader.

site_title: How to tally your return on environment
summary: Buckman Laboratories, a chemistry firm, prioritizes its customers' return on environment by measuring the environmental savings from its solutions. The company aims to minimize its impact on the environment, reporting regularly to stakeholders on its progress. Buckman has set specific goals, such as zero accidents and zero negative environmental impact, and invests in research and development for greener technologies. The firm's commitment to sustainability is anchored in its people, assets, and technology, driving sales and improving cash flow. Buckman has received awards for its eco-friendly alternatives and green initiatives, solidifying its culture of sustainability.

site_title: Chinese still 'jumping' firewall to use Twitter: study
summary: A study by Harvard University's Berkman Center for Internet and Society found that despite China's "Great Firewall" blocking Twitter, many Chinese activists, journalists, and others continue to use the platform to connect with the world. Researchers identified 36 clusters of users, including those focused on politics, technology, and entertainment, who use various tools to bypass the firewall. While the study notes that Chinese Internet repression is succeeding, determined users continue to find ways to access Twitter, highlighting the challenges of the government's internet filtering system.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cache Logistics Trust is placing out S$100 million new units at a 4-6% discount to its VWAP, with S$37 million reserved for acquisitions and S$60 million to repay debt. This may lead to a 5% drop in unit price to S$0.95. Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 5% dip in Q3 net property income due to softer macro conditions and haze. F&N is reportedly interested in increasing its stake in Vinamilk, with a potential US$4 billion offer for SCIC's 45.1% stake.

site_title: Rickmers suspends distributions as charter revenue falls
summary: Rickmers Maritime, a Singapore-based shipping business trust, has suspended distributions to unitholders amid declining charter revenue. The trust reported a 17% fall in revenue to US$27.4 million in the third quarter, citing lower market charter rates for seven vessels. Despite a net profit of US$9 million, the trust cited a 24% decline in cash from operating activities to conserve cash flow. The decision is expected to last until charter conditions improve, with the trust aiming to resume distributions when the market improves.

site_title: Bomb on Russian plane is 'highly possible scenario': US official
summary: A US official has stated that a bomb is a "highly possible scenario" behind the downing of a Russian airliner in Egypt, killing all 224 people on board. The official attributed the potential attack to the Islamic State group, citing intelligence gathered before and after the crash. If confirmed, it would be the first IS bomb attack on a passenger plane. The Egypt branch of IS claimed responsibility but provided no details, prompting skepticism. The US had no prior evidence of a specific threat.

images.alt_text: It is "highly possible" that the Russian airliner that crashed in Egypt was brought down by a bomb, a US official said Wednesday.

site_title: A clean source of energy
summary: Gashub Technology, a Singapore-based company, has developed fuel cell generators with zero carbon emissions, producing only water as a by-product. The technology uses hydrogen gas as fuel to generate electricity, making it a cleaner alternative to traditional power sources like diesel generators. With no moving parts and no combustion, fuel cells are more reliable and environmentally friendly. Gashub has received an Achievement of Excellence award for its efforts in developing fuel cell technology, and the company is now working on recycling biomass into high-value products like green diesel and electricity.

site_title: Honda parts ways with long-time airbag supplier Takata
summary: Honda has ended its partnership with airbag supplier Takata, citing the company's "misrepresentation and manipulation of test data" in its airbag designs. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has also imposed a $70 million penalty on Takata for failing to disclose defects in its airbags, which have led to eight deaths and over 100 injuries. The penalty could increase to $200 million if Takata fails to meet the terms of the consent order.

site_title: SATS Q2 bottom line rises 27% on lower expenditure
summary: SATS, a ground-handler, reported a 27% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$59.7 million for Q2 FY2016, driven by lower expenditure. Revenue fell 4.4% to S$422.7 million due to a decline in its food solutions business. The company transferred its food distribution business to SATS BRF Food.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Moody's cuts Volkwagen's credit rating amid emissions scandal
summary: Moody's has cut Volkswagen's credit rating to A3 due to the growing emissions cheating scandal. The downgrade cites the company's reputation and earnings as being at risk. Volkswagen admitted to falsifying fuel consumption levels on some cars, expanding allegations on emissions cheating. Moody's believes the developments pose additional risk to Volkswagen's reputation, future sales, and cash.

images.alt_text: Moody's hit embattled German automaker Volkswagen with a credit downgrade on Wednesday, saying the company's reputation and earnings were at risk from the growing emissions cheating scandal.

site_title: StanChart's bad loans show cracks in Asian economies
summary: Standard Chartered, a major bank in Asia, is facing significant financial troubles due to its high exposure to bad loans in emerging markets. The bank is cutting 15,000 jobs and seeking $5.1 billion in funding. Asian companies have taken on excessive debt, with 11% of India's loans classified as "stressed assets" and China's Sinosteel Co missing an interest payment. This trend is expected to worsen, with loan growth in the region slowing and defaults rising. Fitch Ratings warns that Asian credit cycles are more advanced than those in Europe, exposing deeper credit market issues.

site_title: Green champions
summary: The Singapore Sustainability Awards (SSA) is currently in its sixth year, recognizing the most commendable sustainable practices and green solutions among organizations in Singapore. The SSA has two categories: "Adopter" for organizations demonstrating sustainable practices, and "Enabler" for those providing green technology solutions. The awards aim to promote sustainable practices and benchmark against top companies.

site_title: US regulator's bid to keep watch on audits of China firms falls through
summary: US regulators' bid to inspect audits of Chinese firms listed on American stock exchanges has fallen through, dealing a setback to the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. The PCAOB had sought access to Chinese audits as dozens of Chinese companies raised billions of dollars from US investors. Negotiations collapsed in October due to China's narrowed terms, leaving US investors uncertain about the quality and reliability of Chinese audits. The PCAOB continues to work towards a resolution, but the outcome may trigger collateral damage for US companies in China.

site_title: Facebook grows user base to 1.55b, profits up
summary: Facebook reported a 11% profit increase to $891 million in the third quarter, with advertising revenues soaring 41% to $4.5 billion. The social network's monthly active users reached 1.55 billion, up 14% from last year. Mobile accounted for 78% of ad revenues, and shares rose 2.3% in after-hours trade. Analysts attribute Facebook's success to its massive user base, which is expected to drive growth in online advertising, surpassing Google's 30.4% share.

site_title: Haw Par rides on Tiger Balm to 31% profit growth in Q3
summary: Haw Par Corp reported a 31.1% profit growth in Q3 2015, reaching S$34.9 million, driven by increased sales of Tiger Balm health products and investment profits. Revenue grew 23.6% to S$48.1 million, while operating profit from healthcare rose 68% to S$13.1 million. However, the leisure business experienced a 99.5% drop in operating profit to S$2,000 due to weak tourism outlook and intense competition. The company expects the leisure business to remain negatively affected.

site_title: STI sails past 3,000 points on China cue
summary: The Singapore blue-chip index surpassed 3,000 points on Wednesday, driven by a rebound from a dose of China cheer that also lifted other regional markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 40.92 points to 3,040.48, its second consecutive day of gains, as blue chips accounted for about two-thirds of the S$1.03 billion traded. The rally was also boosted by gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Taiwan, while Tokyo rose after Japan Post's market debut.

site_title: Credit Suisse case shows how banks always win in pre-crisis structured notes
summary: Credit Suisse is seeking a London court to recoup interest on soured commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) worth over 14 billion euros. The Swiss bank's asset management unit is requesting a determination on unpaid interest on Class X notes, which were designed to favor arrangers and pay out even after underlying loans defaulted. These notes were part of deals originated before the financial crisis, and their high interest rates are being questioned by investors and experts, who argue that they were skewed in favor of the originating bank.

site_title: Huge underground sector a boon to India: Jaitley
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has rejected economists' calls to widen the tax net and rein in the country's massive underground economy, citing its job-generating potential. The informal sector, estimated at $780 billion, employs over 90% of India's workforce, with 400 million people involved. Jaitley instead proposes financing small entrepreneurs and increasing consumer spending, citing the need to strengthen the neo-middle class. This approach goes against the International Monetary Fund's advice to widen the tax net to alleviate the country's fiscal revenue shortfalls.

site_title: ECB president calls for single scheme to protect deposits
summary: The European Central Bank's president, Mario Draghi, has called for a single deposit protection scheme to safeguard savers across the euro zone, warning that failure to implement such a reform undermines the currency union. The call comes amid a years-long deadlock on the issue, with Germany opposing liability for losses elsewhere. The ECB aims to protect deposits, which are the most widespread form of money, and ensure similar protection wherever they are located, amid concerns about bank stability in the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Draghi signalled that failure to introduce a safety net risked repeating mistakes in the "institutional design" when the euro currency was established.

site_title: Nurturing a greener environment
summary: Singapore hosts GreenUrbanScape Asia, the region's leading event for urban design, landscape, and greenery, from Nov 5-7. The biennial event aims to promote sustainable urban environments and connects business, government, and organizations. Singapore's City in a Garden is characterized by pervasive greenery, and the event aims to share successful approaches and technology globally and regionally. The event is jointly organized by SingEx Exhibitions, National Parks Board, and others to foster environmental awareness and planning in urban development.

site_title: Royal Bank of Canada scraps limit on size of immigrant mortgages
summary: Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) has removed its internal limit on mortgage loan size for immigrants in Vancouver, allowing wealthy buyers from mainland China to finance multi-million-dollar homes. The move taps into surging demand for financing by newcomers, with over 80% of luxury market buyers having ties to China. A case study found that two-thirds of buyers had Chinese names, and 88% of those had mortgages, with some individuals having ambiguous job titles suggesting foreign income. Critics call for government intervention to address affordability and concerns over bank lending practices.

site_title: Glencore to sell part of silver output to repay debt
summary: Glencore, a Swiss mining and commodities giant, is selling a share of its future silver output to repay debt. The company's copper production has slumped 2% over the past nine months due to declining production at its Alumbrera mine in Argentina and suspension of activities at the Katanga mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Glencore aims to reduce its $30 billion debt by a third and has reached a deal to deliver silver to Silver Wheaton of Canada for $900 million upfront.

site_title: Momentum builds behind dollar as eyes move to jobs data
summary: The dollar reached 21/2 month highs against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, driven by rising US interest rates and global growth expectations. The euro fell 0.3% to $1.0926 after ECB chief Mario Draghi's speech, while the dollar rose 0.3% against a basket of six major rivals. Economists expect a 180,000 job gain in the US, which could lead to a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, further boosting the dollar.

site_title: Thailand's Singha Estate plans to buy more UK hotels
summary: Thailand's Singha Estate plans to acquire more UK hotels after purchasing Jupiter Hotels for £155 million. The company aims to double its revenue to 6 billion baht by 2016 and expand through acquisitions at home and overseas. Singha Estate plans to use the Mercure brand to manage other hotels if the acquisition is concluded. The company received a two-year bridge loan of £120 million to finance the acquisition, and is considering refinancing the debt for longer terms.

site_title: Amazon's debut brick & mortar store draws Seattle residents
summary: Amazon has opened its first brick-and-mortar bookstore in Seattle's University Village outdoor mall, offering customers the ability to browse and purchase books, as well as try gadgets like the Fire TV streaming device and Kindle e-reader. The move aims to provide a physical space for customers to experience Amazon's products, following its online-only model. The store has received positive feedback, with customers praising the layout and selection of books, and Amazon plans to expand to other cities if the concept is successful.

site_title: Buyers snap up Vornado's US$50m condos
summary: Vornado Realty Trust has sold 14 luxury condominiums at 220 Central Park South in Midtown Manhattan for over $50 million each. About 53% of the project's 118 units have sold, with buyers from the US and New York. The project, designed by Robert AM Stern, features unobstructed views of Central Park and has raised asking prices five times since sales began. The most expensive unit is a $100 million penthouse, and the company expects the project to continue as the premier super-luxury development in the area.

site_title: Swing in support towards PAP from mid, high income earners: poll
summary: A survey by the Institute of Policy Studies found that middle and higher-income earners in Singapore shifted their support towards the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in the 2015 general election, increasing the party's share of the popular vote to 69.9%. The survey also showed that respondents increasingly agreed on the need for checks and balances in Parliament. However, factors such as the government's performance on issues like housing prices and healthcare may have outweighed the desire for political diversity, contributing to the PAP's improved performance.

site_title: Sony faces spectre of losing Bond franchise
summary: Sony faces the possibility of losing the James Bond franchise after its pact with MGM and the Broccolis expires with the release of Spectre. The film is expected to deliver the largest US opening weekend in the 53-year history of the series, generating $90-100 million. Sony, Warner Bros, and 20th Century Fox are vying for the franchise, which is valued at $1.9 billion in ticket sales in the US. A new co-producer and distributor could earn $300 million in profit per film, with the success of Spectre likely to influence negotiations.

site_title: Live, work and play under one roof
summary: Singapore's Changi City, a 4.7-hectare integrated community, was completed in 2013 and embodies the "live-work-play" concept. The project, developed by Ascendas and Frasers Centrepoint, features business spaces, retail, entertainment, and a hotel residence. It has received international recognition, including the Asia Pacific Property Awards and the Singapore Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark GoldPLUS award. Changi City aims to cater to the new generation workforce's expectations while keeping costs affordable for corporations.

site_title: Striving for harmony in work and life
