summary: Canon prioritizes environmentally friendly practices in its business operations, aiming to "live and work together for the common good" through sustainable products and solutions. The company uses green technology, such as plant-derived biomass plastic, and life-cycle assessment to reduce CO2 emissions. Canon also helps clients implement green technology, conducts site audits, and discloses life-cycle CO2 emissions on its website. The company was honored with an Achievement of Excellence award at the Green Technology Awards, recognizing its efforts to promote sustainability.

images.alt_text: At the Singapore Sustainability Awards are (from left): Ho Meng Kit, CEO of SBF; Melvyn Ho, senior vice-president, Canon Singapore; and Masagos Zulkifli, Minister for the Environment and Water Resources.

site_title: Small, big car COE premiums down; all eyes on car expo
summary: COE premiums for small and big cars have softened in Singapore's first bidding exercise under the new quota, with Category A and B premiums decreasing by S$1,300 and S$2,388 respectively. Category E and C premiums rose, while Category D motorcycle premiums fell. The November 2015-to-January 2016 quota has 21,653 COEs, 0.9% fewer than the previous quarter. TheCOE event at TheCars@Expo this weekend may see increased sales and premium increases.

site_title: Activision gets Candy Crush in tax-saving US$5.9 billion deal
summary: Activision Blizzard Inc. has agreed to a $5.9 billion deal to acquire King Digital Entertainment plc, the maker of Candy Crush Saga. The acquisition will give Activision access to the growing mobile gaming industry and help the company save $1 billion in taxes by repatriating $3.6 billion in cash stored outside the US. The deal, which is expected to be completed by spring 2016, will boost Activision's estimated non-GAAP revenue and earnings per share by 30% in 2016. King's CEO, Riccardo Zacconi, will continue to run the company as an independent unit of Activision.

site_title: Uber sticks to China expansion as regulatory curbs loom
summary: Uber is expanding into new Chinese cities despite proposed regulations on the ride-hailing industry, which require cars to be registered for commercial use and GPS-enabled, and drivers to pass qualification tests. The company plans to be in about 100 new cities by the end of next year and double its employee count to 400. Uber's China unit has raised $1.2 billion and has a strong presence in at least five of the top 10 busiest cities, representing 30-35% of the ride-hailing market in China.

site_title: Oct business conditions stagnate; weak outlook across economy
summary: The Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.2 in October, its slowest pace in six months, indicating stagnation in business conditions. New business orders and employment declined, with a marginal drop in employment being the sixth contraction in eight months. The manufacturing sector has been contracting, and experts warn of downside risk for the broader economy. However, some analysts believe that external factors and the upcoming year-end holiday season may help improve business conditions before the year ends.

site_title: Cache raises S$100m in placement
summary: CACHE Logistics Trust has raised S$100 million through a private placement, issuing 106.27 million new units at S$0.941 each. The funds will be used for potential acquisitions, loan repayment, and corporate purposes. The placement price represents a 5% discount to the trust's adjusted volume weighted average price. The new units will not be entitled to an advanced distribution, while existing unitholders can expect an estimated 0.86 Singapore cent per unit for the period from Oct 1, 2015 to Nov 12, 2015. The trust's logistics warehouse portfolio has a total gross floor area of 6.7 million square feet valued at S$1.3 billion.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hot-button issues still of concern but pragmatic voters see the bigger picture
summary: In Singapore's 2015 General Election, policy changes reduced the temperature of hot-button issues like the cost of living, which dominated the 2011 election. The Institute of Policy Studies survey found that the areas of government performance people were least satisfied with included cost of living, rich-poor gap, housing affordability, and immigration policy. However, the PAP secured a 10-percentage-point swing, indicating a greater sense of risk and uncertainty in the world. Voters prioritized security and bread-and-butter issues, with the PAP's reputation and track record being key factors in voting decisions.

site_title: Hugo Boss expects better Q4 despite weak China
summary: Hugo Boss expects a fourth-quarter sales and earnings recovery in Europe, driven by stable sales at its own stores, despite weak China and the US. The company predicts a 3-5% increase in sales and core profit on a currency-adjusted basis. Hugo Boss has been investing in expanding its retail network and shifting away from wholesale sales. Despite this, the company expects "tough trading" to continue in the US and China into 2016, with recent weakness in these markets persisting.

site_title: China's development plan has Xi's fingerprints all over it
summary: China's new development blueprint, unveiled by President Xi Jinping, reflects his assertive nationalist vision, prioritizing the "Chinese dream" and a "more balanced, inclusive and sustainable growth model". The plan aims to achieve 6.5% annual economic growth and promotes services, hi-tech innovation, and environmental sustainability. Xi Jinping's signature is evident in the document's emphasis on purifying the Internet, tightening controls on the arts, and solidifying consensus through socialist core values. The plan represents Xi's best chance to enact reforms and establish a legacy before his successor takes over in 2022.

site_title: Thailand keeps key rate unchanged as fiscal spending takes lead
summary: Thailand's central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged at 1.5% for the fourth consecutive meeting, as it waits to assess the impact of government stimulus spending on local demand. The decision was unanimous among monetary policy committee members. Economists had predicted the decision, with 22 out of 22 surveyed by Bloomberg News forecasting the unchanged rate.

site_title: Vital for Europe and Asia to get the most out of this ASEM
summary: Europe and Asia face common global challenges, including terrorism, human mobility, and economic imbalances. Improved connectivity between the two continents is crucial for Asia's continued growth, and dialogue and cooperation are essential for addressing these issues. The Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM) provides a platform for this cooperation, with the European Commission working to strengthen trade agreements and build new ones. The EU has also shown its commitment to peace and security, supporting ceasefires in Myanmar and the Philippines, and plans to co-host an international conference on Afghanistan. A strong partnership between Europe and Asia is vital for global peace and prosperity.

site_title: A track record of innovation
summary: Elmich founder Alan Lee spotted an opportunity to develop sustainable products after noticing buildings in Singapore used gravel for rainwater drainage. In the early 1990s, a lighter plastic drainage cell became available, making it a more efficient choice. Lee invested in developing green technology products, reducing costs and environmental impact. His business focused on sustainable solutions, leveraging this innovation to improve building design.

site_title: Eurozone business growth still lukewarm in October
summary: Eurozone business growth remained steady at 0.4% in October, in line with forecasts, despite the European Central Bank's stimulus program. The news comes as a lukewarm result, indicating the program's impact on economic activity and price pressures remains limited.

site_title: Firms can embrace zero-based budgeting to fuel growth
summary: Companies can fuel growth by embracing zero-based budgeting, a method that removes unnecessary costs and creates detailed forecasts. By building a budget from a zero base, companies can identify areas to increase or decrease focus, drive growth, and unlock new value. Zero-based budgeting can achieve cost savings ranging from 5% to 40%, with 80% of non-people cost savings realized within the first year. By implementing ZBB, companies can create a cost-efficient culture, re-invest savings into growth initiatives, and drive competitiveness.

site_title: Will the budget deal be a game changer for the Fed?
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's successor may face increased pressure to raise interest rates in December after a bipartisan budget deal reached in Washington, which provides a boost to the economy and could make a rate hike more likely. The deal, which increases federal spending by $80 billion over two years, may accelerate economic growth and change the atmosphere for the Fed's interest rate policy. However, it remains to be seen whether the Fed will raise rates, as economists predict the deal's fiscal boost will accelerate economic growth but not necessarily lead to higher inflation.

site_title: Williams' widow points to dementia as a cause of his suicide last year
summary: Robin Williams' widow, Susan Schneider Williams, has spoken publicly about the circumstances surrounding his 2014 death, attributing his suicide to diffuse Lewy body dementia rather than depression. Williams had been experiencing symptoms since 2013, which were misdiagnosed as depression and Parkinson's disease. The disease, which affects 1.3 million Americans, often goes undiagnosed due to its overlapping symptoms with Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Schneider Williams hopes her husband's case will shed light on the disease and raise awareness for those suffering from it.

images.alt_text: Mrs Williams said her husband Robin had had "this endless parade of symptoms" since autumn 2013.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux agreed to buy a 30% stake in Kaqun Europe for $8 million, with plans to develop a product line under the "ELO" brand for Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa. Halcyon Agri Corp posted a $47,000 net profit in the third quarter, reversing a year-ago loss, while Hock Lian Seng's nine-month net profit more than tripled to $25.2 million due to revenue from property development projects.

site_title: Japan Post Bank eyes US$16b shift into stocks
summary: Japan Post Bank, a state-owned financial institution, is shifting a portion of its $2.39 trillion asset portfolio into stocks, with an estimated $16 billion flowing into equities. The bank's president, Masatsugu Nagato, plans to boost its allocation of shares to about 2 trillion yen, a small increase from its current 900 million yen. This move is seen as a cautious approach, as the bank's liabilities are mostly made up of deposits rather than long-term pension money, limiting its investment horizon.

site_title: China's slowdown could be a plus for US, Europe
summary: China's slowdown, the world's second-largest economy's 25-year low growth rate, is expected to boost Western European and US consumers and companies. Lower commodity prices, driven by China's factory-gate deflation, are increasing spending power and corporate earnings growth. However, emerging markets in Asia and commodity exporters like Brazil and South Africa are at risk, and financial markets may be affected. The US and Europe's share of exports to China is small, making the negative impact manageable, according to Credit Suisse's Neville Hill.

site_title: Al Ahli seals deal to build Fox mega theme park in Dubai
summary: Al Ahli Holding Group has signed an agreement to build a Fox-branded theme park and resort in Dubai, set to open by mid-2020. The 4 million sq ft park will feature Fox-themed attractions, including a hotel, and rival Dubai Parks and Resorts. The project aims to increase Dubai's pull as a family tourism destination, solidifying its position as a major player in the industry.

site_title: JD.com calls on watchdog to probe Alibaba
summary: JD.com has sent a complaint to China's antitrust regulator, the State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC), alleging that Alibaba is "forcing merchants" to choose exclusively with its platforms during promotions. JD.com claims this limits competition and harms consumers. Alibaba denies the allegations, stating that its rival is "panicking" due to its superior user experience. If the SAIC launches an investigation, it could result in punishment for Alibaba under China's antitrust laws. This comes as tensions rise in the lead-up to China's Singles' Day online shopping event.

site_title: China Oct services activity climbs to 3-month high
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at its fastest pace in three months in October, with a reading of 52.0, according to a private survey. This marks a reversal of the 14-month low in September. The improvement is attributed to stronger new business and employment, easing concerns over the economy's weakness. However, business expectations moderated to a record low in October. The growth is seen as a sign that previous stimulus policies have started to take effect, reducing the need for further support.

site_title: Singles' Day spat shows Alibaba's jealous side
summary: Alibaba's e-commerce giant JD.com has accused its US$210 billion rival Alibaba of bullying merchants into using only its platform during the annual "Singles' Day" event. The online shopping promotion has become a national festival in China, with Chinese shoppers spending $9.3 billion on Alibaba's platforms last year. This has raised concerns about market power and potential regulator intervention. Alibaba's dominance in the e-commerce market has sparked a possessive side, prompting JD.com to speak out against the practice.

site_title: Developer Country Garden backs out of Beijing land deal
summary: Chinese developer Country Garden Holdings Co has withdrawn from a Beijing land deal after the final prices exceeded its budget. The company won two plots of land in Beijing's Fengtai district but decided not to buy due to the high prices. Land prices in Beijing have soared 45% in the third quarter, and Chinese developers are becoming more cautious in buying land in first-tier cities. This trend is expected to continue, with average land prices for residential use in Beijing accounting for 70-80% of estimated housing prices.

site_title: Groupon COO succeeds co-founder as CEO
summary: Groupon's co-founder Eric Lefkofsky stepped down as CEO, effective immediately, and will return to the role of chairman. Rich Williams, COO, will succeed him. The company forecast current-quarter and 2016 revenue below analysts' expectations, leading to a 27% drop in shares. Groupon plans to spend more on marketing and shift focus from consumer electronics, which generate lower margins. This change is expected to lower revenue by $50-$100 million in the current quarter. The company's active customer base growth slowed to 4% in the third quarter.

site_title: San Francisco voters reject ballot measure to curb Airbnb
summary: San Francisco voters rejected a ballot measure aimed at curbing Airbnb rentals, which sought to limit short-stay rentals to 75 days per year and require hosts to register with the city. The measure, intended to preserve scarce housing for residents, lost 55-45. The decision comes as housing costs in the city have been driven up by the influx of tech industry workers. Airbnb's presence in San Francisco remains unchanged.

site_title: 2 Indonesian governors reject minimum wage policy
summary: Indonesian governors Basuki Tjahaja Purnama and Ganjar Pranowo have rejected the central government's directive to calculate annual minimum wage increases based on the economy's growth rate and inflation. Instead, they plan to set minimum wages based on local living costs, at least for 2016. The governors argue that the new method could lead to wage rises that do not account for regional costs, and they claim they cannot be forced to comply. The central government has not imposed sanctions on non-compliant local leaders, leaving it unclear how they will address the issue.

site_title: China to start Shenzhen-Hong Kong bourse link before year is out
summary: China plans to link its Shenzhen stock exchange with the Hong Kong market by the end of this year, according to People's Bank of China chief Zhou Xiaochuan. The move, part of China's efforts to open up its capital market, would allow foreign investors to trade on Shenzhen's exchange, which mainly trades small companies and technology stocks. The proposal is subject to regulatory approval, but investors are optimistic about the potential boost to the Chinese stock market, with the Shenzhen index surging 5.12% and the Shanghai market jumping 4.31%.

site_title: Japan Post's red-letter day delivers a value gap
summary: Japan Post's 1.4 trillion yen (S$16.2 billion) initial public offering (IPO) has delivered a value gap, with shares in the postal operator and its finance arms soaring. The IPO is a milestone for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government, marking Japan's biggest privatisation in decades. While the shares of Japan Post Bank rose 15%, those of Japan Post Holdings and Japan Post Insurance jumped 26% and 56% respectively, sparking debate over the IPO prices. The IPO also highlights a gulf in value between the parent and its subsidiaries, with analysts suggesting the parent could be worth 2,003 yen per share.

site_title: Shift to value-creating economy is the way to go: Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of shifting to a value-creating economy in Singapore, which would create good jobs and maintain the country's competitive edge. To achieve this, companies must build capabilities and innovate to produce unique products and deliver better solutions. A network of innovative and entrepreneurial companies is crucial, led by outstanding leaders who make strategic choices and create opportunities for their employees. The five critical areas for Singapore's future economy are companies, jobs, markets, technology, and resources.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Trade gap in Sept narrows to 7-month low as fuel imports fall
summary: The US trade gap narrowed to a 7-month low in September, decreasing 15% to $40.8 billion, driven by a decline in foreign fuel imports and an increase in exports. The decline eased concerns about the impact of slower global growth and a stronger dollar on the US economy. Exports rose 1.6% to $187.9 billion, led by sales of soybeans, while imports fell 1.8% to $228.7 billion. The trade deficit excluding petroleum narrowed to $35.2 billion, indicating the trade gap had little impact on the economy in the third quarter.

site_title: 50 firms honoured at Golden Jubilee Business Awards ceremony
summary: The Singapore Business Federation honored 50 major local companies at the Golden Jubilee Business Awards for their achievements and contributions over the decades. The recipients included household names such as Cathay Organisation and OCBC Bank, and were recognized for their perseverance and growth in tandem with Singapore. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat presented the awards, highlighting the importance of businesses remaining competitive as the country moves into the next 50 years and beyond. The event also celebrated the 59-year-old youngest company and the 187-year-old oldest company among the recipients.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Chinese home buying in Australia is easing, says Credit Suisse
summary: Chinese demand for Australian property is easing due to an economic slowdown at home, according to Credit Suisse. Falling auction clearance rates in Sydney and Melbourne indicate fewer cashed-up foreign buyers, with Chinese buyers accounting for a significant portion of the market in the past. A slowdown in Chinese consumer confidence is expected to dim their appetite for global property by 30% in 2015, with prices potentially decreasing as a result.

site_title: Data shows China's emissions from coal greatly underestimated
summary: China's coal emissions have been significantly underestimated, with new government data showing a 17% increase in coal consumption annually since 2000, resulting in approximately 900 million metric tonnes more carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere each year. This correction complicates efforts to limit global warming, particularly for a country already leading the world in greenhouse gas emissions. The revised data pose a challenge for international climate negotiations in Paris and may lead to a higher peak in emissions, potentially sooner than expected.

site_title: Britain to unveil plan for new Internet spying laws
summary: Britain's government is set to unveil new Internet spying laws to combat terror threats, with proposals granting intelligence agencies new powers to request Internet communications data. The Investigatory Powers Bill would allow for intercepting Internet communication records, but not the content of messages or browsing history. Critics have branded the plans a "snooper's charter," citing concerns over insufficient oversight and potential misuse. The bill aims to modernize the government's duty to keep the public safe, but civil liberties groups warn of the risks of blanket surveillance.

site_title: Oil giants turn to scrip dividends in bid to retain cash
summary: Europe's three biggest oil companies, Royal Dutch Shell, Total SA, and BP Plc, are using scrip dividends to retain cash amid the oil industry's record downturn. By issuing new shares to investors instead of payouts, the companies save $8 billion annually, equivalent to 8.5% of their total cash and equivalents. However, this means future earnings will be diluted, and investors may start looking at earnings per share rather than cash payouts when oil prices rise. The scrip dividend is seen as a temporary solution to preserve cash until oil prices recover.

site_title: Some users upset as Twitter trades stars for hearts, favourites for likes
summary: Twitter has replaced its star button for "favouriting" posts with a heart, sparking criticism from some users who find the change confusing. The new system is intended to be more universal and expressive, allowing users to convey a range of emotions. Twitter's product manager, Akarshan Kumar, stated that the heart symbol resonates across languages, cultures, and time zones. The change comes as Twitter aims to boost user engagement and follows a similar shift made by Facebook.

site_title: A yardstick for sustainable business
summary: The Singapore Sustainability Awards (SSA) recognized 10 organizations for their commitment to sustainable business practices, including Elmich, Marina Bay Sands, and Wilmar International, which won top honors under the Green Technology Awards (GTA) and Sustainable Business Awards (SBA) categories. The awards aim to inspire other businesses to adopt green practices and create a sustainable future. A new accreditation scheme, the Singapore Sustainability Label, was also unveiled to recognize and encourage green businesses that may not meet the full requirements for the awards.

images.alt_text: "I hope that more firms will start thinking about incorporating green technologies into their business practices, and create a more sustainable future for us." - Masagos Zulkifli, Minister for the Environment and Water Resources

site_title: High-priced drugs stretching rich nations' health budgets: OECD
summary: The OECD reports that specialty medicines are straining wealthy nations' health budgets, accounting for 20% of total health spending. Pharmaceutical spending in OECD countries reached $800 billion in 2013, with new drugs and rising demand expected to increase this level further.

site_title: All powers welcome to operate in international waterways to maintain region's security: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen said all powers are welcome to operate in international waterways to maintain regional security, amid concerns over US patrols in the South China Sea. Singapore recognizes the responsibility of users and stakeholders to contribute to waterway security.

site_title: IMF says no firm date for yuan SDR review
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has not set a firm date for reviewing whether to include the Chinese yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, contrary to a report suggesting a delay. The review, which occurs every five years, aims to maintain global financial stability. The Chinese government is pushing for yuan inclusion to raise its international profile. A negative outcome could add depreciation pressure on the yuan, complicating Beijing's efforts to stabilize the currency. The IMF has not confirmed a specific date for the review, citing that a meeting will be convened in November.

site_title: Malaysia raises excise on cigarettes by more than 40%
summary: Malaysia has increased excise tax on cigarettes by more than 40%, effective immediately. This move is part of the government's efforts to reduce the country's fiscal deficit. Brewers and gaming companies are expected to face similar tax rises. The tax hike aims to curb smoking and generate additional revenue. The move is part of a broader strategy to tackle the country's economic challenges, but the impact on the industry and consumers remains to be seen.

site_title: Rowsley swings to net loss of S$4.2m in Q3
summary: Rowsley Ltd, a Singapore-based investment company controlled by billionaire Peter Lim, reported a net attributable loss of S$4.2 million for the third quarter ended September, due to a slump in the property market and a fair value adjustment loss. The company's group revenue declined 16% to S$17.6 million, mainly due to a decline in architectural services revenue. Despite the challenges, Rowsley's CEO Lock Wai Han stated that the company will focus on executing its acquisitions and business plans to diversify its earnings base and grow its portfolio globally.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Rowsley chief executive officer Lock Wai Han noted that the continued slowdown of the Singapore property market made it a "challenging quarter". He added that looking ahead, the group will focus on executing its acquisitions and business plans.

site_title: CapitaLand Q3 earnings up 48% to S$192.7m
summary: CapitaLand reported a 48% increase in net profit to S$192.7 million for the third quarter, driven by stronger operational performance and higher portfolio and revaluation gains. Revenue rose 17.1% to S$1.08 billion, fueled by development projects in China and higher rental revenue from shopping malls. The group's EBIT grew 31% year-on-year to S$459.1 million, with the serviced residence arm Ascott reporting a 93% jump in Ebit. CapitaLand expects residential sales to perform well in China, with 2,000 completed units to be handed over in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Teens spend nearly nine hours every day consuming media: study
summary: A new study by Common Sense Media found that teens spend nearly 9 hours a day consuming media, with tweens aged 8-12 averaging 6 hours daily. This excessive media use poses concerns for the government, who have yet to explore its implications. The study's findings are staggering, even for its executive director, Jim Steyer, who acknowledges the significant impact on young people's lives.

site_title: New SGX CEO targets digital, consumer IPOs; boosting liquidity also a major focus
summary: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye aims to boost listings from digital and consumer sectors, and improve liquidity to attract companies for IPOs. Despite challenges from macroeconomic obstacles and a slump in traditional sectors, Loh is focusing on new industry sectors and outreach programs to support the tech and start-up ecosystem. He also seeks to redefine SGX's regulatory role to ensure it remains relevant and value-adding, acknowledging potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Stiff competition hits Yangzijiang Q3 gain
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 16% year-on-year decline in net profit to 680.7 million yuan in Q3, despite a 10% increase in revenue to 4.1 billion yuan. The company's gross profit margin fell 3 percentage points to 18% due to increased competition and slower newbuild demand growth. YZJ delivered nine vessels in the quarter, with new shipbuilding orders worldwide decreasing 45% year-on-year. Despite the challenges, the company's executive chairman remains optimistic about the consolidation of Chinese shipbuilding capacity and potential opportunities for private-owned yards.

site_title: UK services rebound to lead growth pick-up in Q4
summary: The UK services sector rebounded in October, with the Markit/CIPS UK services purchasing managers' index rising to 54.9 from a 2 1/2-year low of 53.3 in September. This suggests economic growth picked up speed at the start of Q4, despite business confidence slipping to a 2 1/2-year low. The rebound was stronger than expected, above the forecast of 54.5 by economists.

site_title: Dent from Astra cuts Jardine C&C Q3 profit
summary: Jardine C&C reported a 15% decline in Q3 net profit to US$182.2 million, primarily due to weaker performance from Indonesia-based Astra International. Revenue dropped 20% to US$3.7 billion, and earnings per share fell 16%. The group's automotive company Astra saw a 17% decline in net profit under Indonesian accounting standards. The board has not declared a dividend for the quarter. The company's trading performance is expected to remain little changed for the remainder of the year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore to host historic China-Taiwan meeting (Amended)
summary: Singapore will host a historic meeting on November 7 between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou, marking the first direct dialogue between the leaders from both sides since the 1949 civil war. The meeting, facilitated by Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, aims to promote development in cross-strait relations and will be attended by the leaders, their wives, and a closed-door session at the Shangri-La hotel, followed by a press conference and dinner. The event comes amid concerns about the Taiwanese general election and Beijing's intentions towards Taiwan.

site_title: Made-in- China Lexus could take decades on quality concern
summary: Lexus, a luxury car brand owned by Toyota, may not start producing vehicles in China for decades due to concerns over quality. Despite improvements in China's manufacturing credentials, Lexus has stuck to shipping finished models from Japan, incurring higher import taxes. The company's executive vice-president, Takashi Yamamoto, believes that "made-in-Japan guarantees quality," and that China's quality risk is too high for local production. This has led to pricing disadvantages for Lexus in the Chinese market, where locally produced German luxury cars are more affordable.

site_title: New Canadian PM Trudeau to name Morneau as finance minister: source
summary: Incoming Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will name Bill Morneau, a 53-year-old former corporate executive, as his finance minister in his Cabinet announcement on Wednesday. Morneau, elected to Parliament in the October 2015 election, previously headed a major public policy think tank. This move marks a significant appointment for Trudeau's government, as Morneau brings extensive experience in corporate and public policy to the role.

site_title: Bali airport closure extended due to volcanic ash
summary: Bali's Ngurah Rai International Airport has been extended until Thursday due to volcanic ash from Mount Rinjani, grounding hundreds of flights. Authorities initially closed the airport on Tuesday and two smaller airports on Lombok island and East Java. 692 flights, including 320 international ones, were canceled between Tuesday and Thursday, with 106 flights scrapped on Wednesday. Thousands of tourists were stranded at the airport, but officials reported "everything's going smoothly." Seismic activity and eruptions of Mount Rinjani continue at a higher intensity.

site_title: Saudi women's fitness boom defies norms, treading softly
summary: Saudi women's fitness centers are booming, defying societal norms, with over 4,000 members and expansion plans in the works. Founded by Princess Sara bint Mohammed Al Saud, NuYu has spread to three locations, while international chains and local gyms cater to the growing demand. Despite challenges from licensing and conservative attitudes, women's fitness is gaining traction, with a 2013 survey revealing a third of Saudi women were obese and a 2012 Olympic debut for Saudi female athletes.

site_title: HDB terminates job by troubled Punj Lloyd unit
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has terminated its contract with Sembawang Engineers and Constructors (SEC) for the McNair Towers public housing project in Singapore, citing the contractor's financial woes. The project, valued at S$106 million, is about 79% complete. The termination is part of HDB's efforts to ensure the project's completion, with a new contractor expected to take over. The decision comes after SEC's financial struggles, including S$80 million in estimated losses on the McNair Towers project.

site_title: US$1.2b project seen boosting LA office market
summary: The US$1.2 billion Wilshire Grand Center project in downtown Los Angeles is set to provide the city's first new tower-based office space in about 25 years. The 1,100-foot-tall building will offer technology features and is expected to boost the office market, despite high vacancy rates of 18.4% in the third quarter. Experts attribute the market's strength to urban renaissance, improved transportation links, demographic shifts, and foreign investment. The project's completion is seen as a catalyst for more growth in the office market, with rents potentially stable or decreasing due to abundant office space under construction.

site_title: Marks & Spencer raises clothing, homewares profit margin forecast
summary: Marks & Spencer raised its annual profit margin forecast for clothing and homewares, despite a 1.9% decline in sales in its second quarter. The company reported a 6.1% rise in first-half underlying pre-tax profit and increased its dividend by 6.3%. CEO Marc Bolland's focus on improving gross margins has paid off, with the non-food division increasing its margin by 2.85 percentage points. The company now forecasts a 2-2.5% increase in full-year margins, beating previous expectations of 1.5%.

images.alt_text: M&S shares have risen 29 per cent on hopes that the billions of pounds spent by Mr Bolland will pay off.

site_title: Asian guru reveals value-investment secrets
summary: Asian value investor Dr. Tan Chong Koay has revealed his investment secrets in the book "Rising Above Financial Storms". A pioneer in the Asian investment scene, Dr. Tan has weathered financial crises and emerged unscathed, with his Pheim Asset Management fund achieving record performance. He emphasizes the importance of market timing, diversification, and understanding investor psychology, rather than relying solely on empirical data. Dr. Tan's contrarian approach to investing has yielded multiple "baggers" and earned him numerous accolades, making the book a must-read for those seeking insights into the Asian market.

site_title: ECB sees modest impact from China slowdown if spillovers limited
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) believes China's slowdown will have a modest impact on the euro-area economy unless it triggers a global economic downturn. China accounts for 6% of euro-area exports, but a significant portion of these exports are re-exported. The ECB estimates a 1% loss in Chinese GDP would lead to a 0.1-0.15% decline in euro-area economic activity over two to three years. Despite this, the ECB has left the door open to expanding its quantitative-easing program due to inflation remaining at zero.

site_title: US crude stocks rose even as imports plunged: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose by 2.8 million barrels last week, while gasoline and distillate inventories fell. Gasoline stocks dropped 3.3 million barrels, and distillate stockpiles fell 1.3 million barrels. Crude imports fell to the lowest level in nearly a quarter century, at 89,000 barrels per day. Refinery crude runs rose by 21,000 barrels per day, and refinery utilization rates increased by 1.1 percentage points.

site_title: Turkey outlook hinges on ability to spur growth, fight inflation: Moody's
summary: Turkey's credit outlook will depend on the new government's ability to tackle slowing growth and high inflation, according to Moody's. The AK Party's election victory removed political uncertainty but will be determined by policy implementation and the capital environment. Moody's has a "Baa3" rating on Turkey with a "negative" outlook, and a review is scheduled for December. Economists expect growth to fall short of official targets, and investor confidence is tied to economic policy execution rather than individual leaders. The government must address structural problems to improve the country's credit outlook.

site_title: Chairman of China Southern Airlines probed for suspected graft: watchdog
summary: China's chairman of China Southern Airlines, Si Xianmin, is being investigated by the Communist Party's graft watchdog for "serious discipline violations," a euphemism for corruption. This move raises concerns about the airline's management.

site_title: US September trade deficit smallest in seven months
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to its lowest level in seven months in September, falling 15% to $40.8 billion, as exports rebounded. Lower crude oil prices also contributed to the decline. Exports rose 1.6% to $187.9 billion, with increases in capital goods and automobiles, while imports fell 1.8% to $228.7 billion, the lowest level since February. The decline reverses the widening deficit seen in August, and economists expect the trade gap to continue shrinking.

site_title: KL bourse to stay in the doldrums until domestic woes are resolved
summary: Malaysia's stock market is expected to remain in a doldrums until domestic issues are resolved. Despite a brief reprieve in October with a foreign net buy of RM620 million, the market has returned to a net sell mode, with foreign investors selling nearly RM18 billion worth of shares this year. The concerns include a commodity slump, looming US rate hike, and China's slowing economy, as well as domestic woes such as the 1MDB scandal and political uncertainty. Analysts expect volatility to persist and the market to focus on domestic issues after a potential US rate hike in December.

site_title: Long-lost Disney film Sleigh Bells found in British archive
summary: A long-lost Disney film, Sleigh Bells, has been discovered in a British archive, 87 years after its original release in 1928. The six-minute animated film features Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, an early precursor to Mickey Mouse, and will be screened for the first time since its release. The film has been restored with the help of Walt Disney Animation Studios and will have its world premiere in London on December 12. The discovery could lead to more "lost" Disney films being uncovered, with the studio indicating a desire to research and recover missing titles from their history.

site_title: US private sector adds 182,000 jobs in October: ADP
summary: US private employers added 182,000 jobs in October, surpassing economists' expectations of 180,000. This follows a September revision of 190,000 jobs. The ADP National Employment Report, released on Wednesday, is ahead of the US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report on Friday. Economists forecast a 180,000 job growth and a 5.1% unemployment rate.

site_title: Philippines probes airport bullet-planting extortion
summary: The Philippine government is investigating claims of a major extortion racket at Manila's airport, where security personnel allegedly plant bullets in passengers' luggage to extort money. Transport Secretary Joseph Emilio Abaya confirmed cases had been filed against security officers and said President Benigno Aquino intended to fire anyone involved. The scam has targeted poor Filipinos, who are often forced to pay small sums of money to avoid being charged. The United Nations has also warned its staff of the potential dangers, prompting extra security measures to be installed at the airport.

site_title: CapitaLand-Norges joint venture out of Asia Square deal - for now
summary: Negotiations between BlackRock and a consortium led by CapitaLand and Norges Bank Investment Management (NBIM) on the sale of Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore are currently "on hold". The deal could be Singapore's largest office transaction, with the consortium reportedly seeking to buy the tower for a significant sum. The consortium includes the world's largest asset manager, BlackRock, and Norway's sovereign wealth fund manager, NBIM. The negotiations are ongoing, but for now, no deal has been reached.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Eurozone business growth remained tepid in October: PMI
summary: Eurozone business growth remained tepid in October, with the European Central Bank's stimulus program having little impact on economic activity or price pressures. The Markit PMI index came in at 53.9, above the 50 mark, indicating expansion since July 2013, but below expectations. Quarterly economic growth is estimated at around 0.4 percent, in line with previous forecasts.

site_title: Halcyon's Q3 back in black with US$47,000 profit
summary: Halcyon Agri reported a net profit of US$47,000 in the third quarter, reversing a year-ago loss of US$12.2 million. The rubber producer attributed the turnaround to its newly acquired trading business. For the first nine months of the year, net profit was US$4.5 million, or 1.07 US cents per share, marking a significant reversal from the year-ago net loss.

site_title: Rotary Engineering Q3 net profit down 42% to S$6.3m
summary: Rotary Engineering reported a net profit of S$6.3 million for Q3 2015, down 42% from S$10.9 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue fell 65% to S$60.3 million due to the completion of major projects. The company's Q3 results were impacted by a decline in revenue, primarily caused by project completions.

site_title: Groupon plunges as revenue, profit forecasts miss estimates
summary: Groupon Inc fell 24% in premarket trading after missing revenue and profit forecasts for the current quarter, with adjusted per-share results predicted to range from a loss of 1 US cent to earnings of 1 US cent. Co-founder Eric Lefkofsky will step down as CEO and be replaced by Rich Williams, who will focus on streamlining international operations and possibly cutting jobs. Groupon reported adjusted third-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share, compared to estimates of 2 US cents.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion airport upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGS Investment downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: Bumi Armada bullish on smaller FSUs for liquefied gas
summary: Bumi Armada's head of gas business sees the company's success in securing a gas floater in Malta as a sign of growing demand for smaller liquefied gas storage and regasification units worldwide. This is attributed to the increasing need for LNG imports globally. The company's US$300 million worth of contracts with ElectroGas Malta in April marked its first foray into the gas business, showcasing the expanding market for such units.

site_title: Hong Kong: Key index posts best day in a month
summary: Hong Kong's main share index, the Hang Seng, posted its best daily gain in a month, rising 2.2% to 23,053.57, driven by optimism over a potential trading link with Shenzhen stock markets before the year-end. The China Enterprises Index also gained 2.7% to 10,560.74 points, while Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing rose 4.4%. The strong performance was largely attributed to the anticipated launch of a trading link between Hong Kong and Shenzhen.

site_title: US economy doing well; December rate hike possible: Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the US economy remains solid, with a possible interest rate hike at the December meeting. The last rate increase occurred in 2006, and Yellen suggested it could happen for the first time in nine years.

site_title: Noble Group said to appoint metals traders after departures last month
summary: Noble Group, Asia's largest trading house, appointed Alex Nizan and Johannes Polatinsky to trade industrial metals, including copper and zinc, following the departure of at least five traders last month. Nizan, former Noble's warehousing head, will trade copper, while Polatinsky, a former Glencore trader, will handle copper trading. Jarryd Rubinstein will market refined zinc. These appointments aim to maintain Noble's metals trading presence despite the personnel changes.

site_title: Global air freight demand up 1% in Sept: Iata
summary: Global air freight demand rose 1% in September, a slight improvement from the previous month, according to IATA. Load factor fell to 43.2%, the lowest level since 2009, due to carriers adding capacity. IATA director-general Tony Tyler stated that the global trend is fragile and the improvement is narrow. Despite the slight increase, air freight volumes remain below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after surge in Chinese shares
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following a surge in Chinese shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 26.69 points, or 0.15%, to 17,944.84. The S&P 500 climbed 2.96 points, or 0.14%, to 2,112.75, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 12.91 points, or 0.25%, to 5,158.04. The market's gains come despite concerns over a potential Fed rate hike and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Higher Q2 net profit for SATS boosted by lower expenditure
summary: SATS reported a 26.8% increase in Q2 net profit to S$59.7 million, driven by lower expenditure. Revenue dropped 4.4% to S$422.7 million. The company attributed the results to a challenging operating environment, but remains confident in long-term growth prospects for Asia. An interim dividend of 5 Singapore cents per share was declared.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Musk's SpaceX finds crowd for US$3.5b NASA cargo flights
summary: Elon Musk's SpaceX is competing for a US$3.5 billion contract to haul supplies and experiments to the International Space Station, with Boeing, Orbital ATK, and Sierra Nevada Corp also vying for the seven-year agreement. SpaceX is the only US-made entry in the competition, giving it an advantage over its rivals, which rely on Russian engines. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will award the contract as soon as Thursday, amid concerns over US dependence on imported Russian motors.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng net profit triples to S$25m on recognition of project revenue
summary: Hock Lian Seng's nine-month net profit more than tripled to S$25.2 million, driven by recognized revenue from property development projects, including S$89 million from Ark@KB and S$21.4 million from property development. Revenue grew 43.9% to S$149.8 million, while gross profit shrank 33% to S$5 million due to lower margins. The company's core civil engineering segment also saw revenue growth of 43.9%.

site_title: Singapore shares up 1.4% as China worries ease
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.4% on Wednesday, driven by easing concerns over China's slowdown. The Chinese government unveiled a five-year plan to bolster the economy, boosting investor sentiment. The blue-chip index closed at 3,040.48 points, with 1.83 billion shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 255 to 138, and Stratech Group led the gains. The rally follows a five-day streak, ahead of GDP data releases.

site_title: AirAsia says major shareholders looking at 'strategic options' on investments
summary: AirAsia Bhd, Asia's largest budget carrier, says major shareholders are evaluating "strategic options" after co-founder Tony Fernandes sounded out investors to take the company private. No decision has been reached on the shareholder's stakes in the airline. AirAsia received approaches from investors to co-invest in its leasing subsidiary, Asia Aviation Capital Ltd, allowing them to indirectly own the aircraft. The stock is still down nearly 46% this year after a research firm reported the airline needed to be recapitalized. No formal offer has been made to take the company private.

site_title: Haw Par Q3 profit grows 31% on bounding healthcare segment
summary: Haw Par Corp's third-quarter net profit rose 31.1% to S$34.9 million, driven by its robust healthcare segment. Revenue grew 23.6% to S$48.1 million, with operating profit from healthcare increasing 68% to S$13.1 million. The company's leisure business reported a 99.5% drop in operating profit to S$2,000, citing weak tourism outlook and intense competition. No dividends were declared, and shares closed 0.5% higher.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's COE premiums softened in the first bidding exercise, with dealers reporting slower sales. The new CEO of SGX aims to restore confidence in the stock market, which has yet to recover from a 2013 penny-stock crash. CapitaLand abandoned talks to buy Asia Square Tower 1. Taiwan and China will meet in Singapore on Saturday to discuss cross-strait issues. Citic Group agreed to buy Biosensors for $1.1 billion. The Singapore stock market rose 1.4% as concerns over China's slowdown eased.

site_title: Maersk Line to slash 4,000 jobs by end-2017
summary: Maersk Line, the world's number one container shipping firm, plans to cut 4,000 jobs by the end of 2017 to boost its dominant position in a falling market. The company will also defer vessel investments and slash administrative costs by $250 million over two years. This move comes after the maritime division of Danish conglomerate AP Moeller-Maersk warned that a fall in activity would hit annual results. The cuts are part of a transformation plan to make the organization simpler and leaner, with the goal of improving the online client experience.

site_title: IMF postpones decision on yuan's inclusion in SDR basket: report
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has postponed its decision on including the yuan in the Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket until November 30, according to a report. The IMF was initially set to make a decision on November 4. This decision delay may impact China's economic growth and global financial markets.

site_title: China cabinet says to deepen interest rate reform: state radio
summary: China's State Council has announced plans to deepen interest rate reform, including the use of short-term repo and medium-term lending facilities. The cabinet will also establish a financing guarantee fund to lower borrowing costs for small firms and accelerate the reconstruction of "zombie" firms. Additionally, the approval process for highway projects will be streamlined.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reports lower Q3 profit
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported a 15% year-over-year decline in Q3 net profit to US$182.2 million, with revenue dropping 20% to US$3.7 billion. The decline was attributed to weaker domestic demand and stiff competition in Indonesia, where the company's automotive arm, Astra, saw a significant drop in performance. However, the group's direct motor interests and other interests contributed to the decline. For the nine-month period, net profit fell 16% to US$544 million, with revenue dropping 15% to US$11.94 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: S&P cuts rating of Japan's Sharp further into junk territory
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded Japanese electronics maker Sharp Corp's debt to 'CCC+' from 'B-', further pushing it into junk territory, citing its deteriorating fortunes after a $1.7 billion bailout. Sharp is struggling to turn around its LCD business due to tough competition, and S&P believes it may have difficulty meeting financial commitments in the next six to 12 months. The company has warned of a potential loss of 26 billion yen and is under pressure from its banks to restructure or find a buyer for its LCD business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 8.06 points to 1,685.62. A total of 2.7 billion lots, valued at RM2.5 billion, were traded, with 558 gainers outnumbering losers 333.

site_title: Volkswagen shares plummet again on new emission 'irregularities'
summary: Volkswagen shares plummeted 10.7% to an intraday low of 99.12 euros after the company revealed "irregularities" on carbon emissions in its cars, with 800,000 more vehicles showing inconsistencies. The latest scandal, related to petrol engines, could cost the company 2 billion euros. The company admitted to using defeat devices in 11 million diesel vehicles, sparking outrage and investigations globally. The revelation adds to the company's ongoing pollution cheating scandal, which has already led to significant financial losses and damage to its reputation.

site_title: Hyflux to buy 30% stake in European beauty and therapy company for US$8m
summary: Hyflux has agreed to purchase a 30% stake in European consumer water technology company Kaqun Europe for US$8 million. The deal will also see the development of a line of products under the brand "ELO" for sale in the Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa. Hyflux will own a 70% stake in Elo Water, while Kaqun Europe will retain a 30% stake. The acquisition is expected to capitalize on growing consumer interest in health and wellness products.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise; DAX down as Volkswagen slumps
summary: European shares rose, with the FTSEurofirst 300 up 0.4% to 1,500.57, despite Germany's DAX index falling 0.2% due to a Volkswagen scandal. Volkswagen fell 10% after underestimating fuel consumption in 800,000 cars, while Porsche dropped 9.5% due to concerns over VW's results. Glencore rose 5.6% after announcing strong trading and debt reduction plans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise 1.3% as Japan Post soars on market debut
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.3% on Wednesday, driven by Japan Post's market debut, with the Nikkei 225 index advancing 243.67 points to 18,926.91. The company's US$11.5 billion initial public offering was the largest so far this year.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares end higher on China's services PMI
summary: South Korean stocks and the won ended higher on Wednesday, driven by positive signs for China's services sector activity. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.2% to 2,052.77 points, while the won was quoted at 1,132.0 to the dollar. Gaming company NC Soft Corp jumped 11.7% for its biggest one-day percentage gain since January 28.

site_title: M&S raises non-food margin forecast despite another sales dip
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) raised its annual forecast for non-food profit margins despite a 1.9% dip in quarterly sales in its general merchandise division. The retailer beat forecasts for first-half profit and increased its dividend. M&S attributed the sales dip to unseasonal conditions and a focus on full-price sales. The company's non-food division increased its gross margin by 2.85 percentage points in the first half, and its full-year guidance was raised to 2-2.5 percentage points from 1-1.5 percentage points previously.

site_title: China underreporting coal consumption for years: experts
summary: China has been underreporting its coal consumption for years, with revised statistics showing an increase of up to 17% in previous years. The National Bureau of Statistics raised coal consumption figures by 600 million tonnes for 2012, equivalent to over 70% of the US's annual coal consumption. The revised figures suggest Chinese emissions have been a larger driver of global warming than previously thought, which could impact climate change negotiations at the upcoming UN summit in Paris.

site_title: UK services rebound, economy to pick up in Q4: PMI
summary: UK services sector growth rebounded more strongly than expected, rising to 54.9 in October, up from a 28-month low of 53.3 in September, suggesting economic growth picked up speed at the start of the fourth quarter. This data, combined with strong readings from manufacturing and construction sectors, may encourage the Bank of England to consider raising interest rates before the end of the year. However, business confidence slipped to a 2-1/2-year low, and cost pressures remained low, raising questions about the durability of the recovery.

site_title: Glencore cuts debt on asset sales, says trading is strong
summary: Glencore, a Swiss-based mining and trading giant, is on track to reduce its debt to $20 billion by the end of 2016 through asset sales and cost-cutting measures. The company plans to cut copper output by 455,000 tonnes by 2017, aiming to lift prices. Glencore has sold assets, suspended dividend payments, and raised $2.5 billion in new equity capital to achieve its debt-reduction goals and regain investor trust. The company's trading division performed well, maintaining its adjusted earnings target of $2.5-$2.6 billion for the year.

site_title: Shift from value-adding to value-creation: Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to shift from a value-adding economy to a value-creating one, focusing on innovation, differentiation, and building deep capabilities to compete globally. He stated that producing unique products or solutions is crucial to commanding a premium and sustaining a competitive edge, rather than simply improving existing ones.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks up in early trading
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trading on November 4, 2015, despite comments from Chinese President Xi Jinping signaling lower growth. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.9%, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.47%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.81%. The gains were a surprise to the mainland market.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow US higher as energy producers advance
summary: Asian stocks rose for the third day in a row, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 1.2% to 135.11, driven by energy producers and financial companies. China's stocks rose the most in seven weeks, led by financial and technology companies, after the government unveiled its five-year plan to bolster the economy. Nissan Motor Co. advanced 2.6% and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd jumped 4.7% after China's central bank sparked a surge in the nation's stock market.

site_title: HKEx, China stocks retreat after clarifications over stock connect plan
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) shares retreated after clarifying that no agreement has been reached with Chinese counterparts on the proposed Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme. The shares had risen 8% earlier on speculation of the scheme's impact on turnover. The programme is still subject to regulatory approval and no agreement has been entered into. The clarification led to a decline in HKEx shares, while Hong Kong's main index fell 1% and the H-share index rose 3.84% before trading down.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

The share price of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) retreated from its earlier highs after the bourse clarified that no agreement has been entered into with its Chinese counterparts on the proposed Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme.

site_title: South Korea's Hyundai launches luxury car brand Genesis
summary: South Korea's Hyundai Motor launched its luxury car brand Genesis, expanding its presence in the growing luxury auto market. The Genesis brand, named after Hyundai's Genesis sedan, will introduce four new models by 2020, including a large sedan. Hyundai aims to shed its image as a cheaper alternative with its high-end lineups, including Genesis and Equus.

site_title: AIIB to start offering loans to foreign countries in Jan: Indonesia finmin
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), backed by China, is set to start offering loans to foreign countries in January, according to Indonesia's finance minister. Indonesia will contribute US$672.1 million in capital, making it the eighth largest shareholder. The AIIB aims to finance Indonesian infrastructure developments, including energy and power plants.

site_title: Honda lifts full-year revenue forecast on weak yen, strong North America sales
summary: Honda Motor Co raised its full-year revenue forecast to 14.6 trillion yen due to strong vehicle sales in North America and a weaker yen. The company's quarterly net profit rose 6.9% to 127.7 billion yen, beating analyst estimates. Operating profit for the second quarter fell 2.5% to 164.84 billion yen. This marks Honda's first reporting under international accounting standards. The stronger yen and North America sales are expected to have a positive impact on Honda's revenue.

site_title: China: Stocks surge 4%, post best day in seven weeks
summary: China's stocks surged 4% on Wednesday, their best daily gain in seven weeks, driven by optimism over a potential trading link between Hong Kong and Shenzhen stock markets. China President Xi Jinping's comments on the economy and Beijing's proposal of its 13th five-year plan also contributed to the market's upward momentum. The stock connect scheme remains subject to regulatory approval, but investors remain hopeful it will be launched before the year-end.

site_title: DBS hires banks for sterling covered bond debut
summary: DBS Bank has mandated four banks to arrange meetings for a sterling covered bond debut. The proposed transaction will be the bank's second offshore covered deal, following a US$1 billion three-year bond priced at 37bp over mid-swaps in July. DBS's dollar debut was rated Aaa/AAA/AAA and issued from a US$10 billion multicurrency programme. The covered bond is expected to be the second offshore deal from the bank.

site_title: Thai junta turns to populist subsidies to ease farmer tensions
summary: Thailand's junta has approved $1.3 billion in rural subsidies to ease farmer tensions amid record low commodity prices and weak exports. The move aims to appease politically powerful farmers and is seen as a reversal of the military government's initial pledge to wean farmers off expensive subsidies. The subsidies, worth around $1 billion, will support rice and rubber farmers, who have threatened protests over the ban on political gatherings. The move is part of a broader effort by the junta to boost the economy and appease rural discontent.

site_title: Tokyo's famed Hotel Okura auctions furniture, memorabilia
summary: Tokyo's iconic Hotel Okura is auctioning off memorabilia, including furniture and items from the Imperial and Royal suites, due to its demolition. The 53-year-old hotel, which hosted world leaders and celebrities, will be replaced by a 510-room twin-tower hotel. Proceeds from the auction will go to a charity promoting music and art in northeastern Japan. Iconic items like the hotel's "Okura lanterns" will be kept for the new building, set to open in 2019. The online auction, running until December 20, features over 300 items, including pieces from the hotel's restaurants and bars.

images.alt_text: Fans of Tokyo's soon-to-be demolished Hotel Okura are getting a chance to purchase memorabilia from the sixties-era modernist masterpiece, which has hosted world leaders, British royalty and even fictional superspy James Bond.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains, NZ scales new peak
summary: Australian shares rose 0.92% to 5,287.60, extending gains for a second session, driven by firm demand for bank stocks and upbeat results from CSR Ltd. The "Big Four" banks rose, led by Commonwealth Bank of Australia, while retail sales data showed little reaction. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index hit a fresh high, scaling a second successive peak, as investors await a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

site_title: Australia: Shares trim gains, NZ stocks scale fresh peak
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 5,242.3 points, despite early gains, after banks took a breather. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index set a fresh record peak at 6,071.21, driven by soft jobs data and falling global dairy prices, which fueled speculation of a Reserve Bank of New Zealand interest rate cut in December.

site_title: Taiwan official says nothing rushed, opaque about Xi-Ma meeting
summary: A Taiwan government official stated that the push for a historic meeting between Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou and Chinese President Xi Jinping was not rushed or opaque. The idea of the meeting was broached by the chief of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, and both sides' dedication to maintaining peace was emphasized. This will be the first meeting between the leaders of the two sides since the Chinese civil war ended in 1949.

site_title: Desire for political diversity in Singapore has dropped: IPS post-GE2015 survey
summary: The Institute of Policy Studies (IPS) conducted a survey after the 2015 general election in Singapore, finding that the desire for political diversity among voters decreased. The top issues influencing voting decisions were cost of living, housing affordability, healthcare affordability, meeting retirement needs, and government transparency and accountability. Notably, the use of the Internet and social media did not significantly impact the role of television and print newspapers in shaping voter attitudes, with TV being seen as the most important communication channel.

site_title: HKEx says no agreement yet on planned Shenzhen-HK Stock Connect
summary: HKEx says no agreement has been reached with Chinese counterparts regarding the proposed Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme, despite a surge in the Shenzhen Composite Index and Hang Seng Index. The clarification was issued after China's central bank inadvertently sparked the market's rally with comments on the 2015 start date of the link. The programme remains subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Gold near 4-wk low on US rate hike fears, fund outflows
summary: Gold prices steadied after a five-day decline, staying near a four-week low due to investor concerns over a potential US rate hike this year. Spot gold rose 0.4% to $1,121.80 an ounce, but remains under pressure from weak technicals and outflows from exchange-traded funds. A US jobs report this week could determine the timing of a rate hike, potentially sending gold prices lower.

site_title: COE premiums mixed
summary: COE premiums in Singapore experienced mixed results from the first bidding exercise, with Category A and B premiums decreasing, while Category E and C premiums increased. Category A premiums fell to S$56,001, and Category B premiums dropped to S$57,501. Category E premiums rose to S$60,689, and Category C premiums increased to S$43,809. The results are attributed to slower sales over the past week, but dealers expect changes after this weekend's TheCars@Expo event.

site_title: China sacks Tianjin port chief after blasts: People's Daily
summary: China has fired the president of Tianjin Port Group, Zheng Qingyue, and plans to prosecute him for dereliction of duty over the deaths of over 160 people in a chemical blast at the port. Zheng will also be removed from his positions at other city centers. The People's Daily newspaper said government investigations found the port operator's management neglected safety oversight duties, and blamed poor regulation of the involved company, Tianjin Ruihai International Logistics Co Ltd. Officials face criminal prosecution for dereliction of duty, amid growing anger over safety standards in China.

site_title: ASEAN's lack of consensus shows concern over South China Sea: US
summary: US Defence Secretary Ash Carter stated that ASEAN's inability to agree on a joint statement at a defence ministers' forum reflects concern over China's activity in the South China Sea. The issue was a point of discussion among countries at the meeting, which included the US, China, Japan, and Australia. ASEAN's lack of consensus highlights the growing tensions in the region.

site_title: Lloyd's launches expanded underwriting platform in Singapore as business grows
summary: Lloyd's, a specialist insurance and reinsurance market, has launched an expanded underwriting platform in Singapore, aiming to grow its business in the Asia-Pacific. The platform now has 20 service companies, 24 syndicates, and 380 staff, making it Lloyd's largest hub outside London. Since 2009, premium income from Asia has grown 170%, with 90% coming from regional markets outside Singapore. The move allows Lloyd's to further develop its distribution network and strengthen its ability to offer clients specialist insurance coverage in the region.

site_title: Standard Chartered's bad loans show cracks in Asia economies
summary: Standard Chartered's financial struggles, driven by delinquent loans in emerging markets such as India, signal cracks in the Asian economy. The bank is cutting 15,000 jobs and seeking $5.1 billion in funding. Rising leverage in India to Indonesia increases the risk of corporate debt defaults. Fitch Ratings warns of "stressed assets" in India and China's Sinosteel Co misses an interest payment, raising concerns about the region's credit cycles. Defaults in Asia are still rare, but the bank's troubles and others, like Kaisa Group Holdings, highlight the need for caution.

site_title: CapitaLand pulls out of talks to buy Asia Square Tower 1
summary: CapitaLand has ceased negotiations to acquire Asia Square Tower 1, a Singapore office building, citing the need for returns that align with the group's strategy. The decision follows a confirmed plan to negotiate with the vendor, which included a consortium of Norway's sovereign wealth fund. The potential transaction, seen as the largest office deal in Singapore, was previously reported as the preferred bidder. CapitaLand will continue to explore opportunities that meet its requirements.

site_title: Dollar retreats against emerging currencies as concerns fade
summary: The US dollar retreated against emerging currencies in Asia as concerns over China's economy faded, with the Malaysian ringgit and Indonesian rupiah gaining solid ground. The dollar strengthened against the yen, while the euro edged up against it. Investors now await fresh input from the Federal Reserve on its interest rate hike timeline, with expectations of a delayed rate hike. This boost the case for emerging currencies, with the dollar down against the ringgit, rupiah, won, and other currencies.

images.alt_text: The US dollar fell against emerging market currencies in Asia on Wednesday as worries over China's economy faded and investors awaited fresh input from the Federal Reserve on its timeline for an interest rate hike.

site_title: Update: Two years on, SGX's new CEO seeks to fix stock-rout fallout
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Loh Boon Chye is working to restore confidence in Southeast Asia's largest stock market, two years after a mystery penny-stock crash wiped out $6.9 billion in market value. Loh aims to revive interest in equities by introducing a bond-trading platform, adding currency products, and diversifying revenue streams. The exchange has seen a 25% decline in daily trading value since the crash, and companies have looked elsewhere to list. Analysts are bullish on SGX shares, and Loh is focused on overcoming the lingering fallout from the 2013 crash.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd chief executive officer Loh Boon Chye says his top priority is to restore confidence in Southeast Asia's biggest stock market, where turnover is yet to recover from a mystery penny-stock crash more than two years ago.

site_title: Nikkei Singapore PMI falls to 50.2 in Oct as business conditions stagnate
summary: Singapore's Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.2 in October, down from 51.4 in September, indicating stagnating business conditions. New business orders and employment declined, with only a fractional improvement in overall operating conditions. The manufacturing sector's PMI showed a reading of 48.9, contracting for the fourth month in a row. The weaker growth signals a slowdown in the Singaporean private sector economy.

site_title: Hot stock: Biosensors surges more than 20% on Citic's offer to buy rest of company
summary: Biosensors International Group surged over 20% on Wednesday after Citic Group Corp's private-equity arm agreed to buy the remaining shares for about S$1.1 billion. The share price hit S$0.82 before trading around S$0.81, up 13 cents or 19%, following the offer. Citic is paying S$0.84 per share, 24% higher than the last closing price.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: New Canada PM Trudeau to be sworn in, promising 'sunny ways'
summary: Justin Trudeau, Canada's 23rd prime minister, will be sworn in, promising a more open and friendly government. The new cabinet, expected to be around 30 members or fewer, will have an equal number of male and female ministers, a first for Canada. Trudeau won a surprise majority with a more positive outlook and a willingness to stimulate the economy. The swearing-in ceremony marks the end of a decade of Conservative rule under Stephen Harper. Trudeau, 43, is the first son of a prime minister to take office and the second-youngest in Canadian history.

site_title: Seoul: South Korea won up on China's services activity; shares up
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.3% to 1,129.3 per dollar on Wednesday, following a private survey showing China's services sector activity increased to its fastest pace in three months. The Caixin/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 52.0 in October. Local shares held steady, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 0.3% at 2,053.52 points. Investors await Friday's non-farm payrolls report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: China Oct services activity climbs to 3-month high: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at its fastest pace in three months in October, according to a private survey, with the Caixin/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 52.0. This growth, though, was largely driven by new business, and business expectations moderated to a record low. The data suggests that previous stimulus policies are starting to take effect, but the economy remains uncertain, with the official services survey showing a cooling in growth. The PMI reading is a sign of stabilization, but further support measures are expected from policymakers.

site_title: Chinese home buying in Australia is easing, Credit Suisse says
summary: Chinese demand for Australian property is easing due to an economic slowdown at home, according to Credit Suisse. Auction clearance rates in Sydney and Melbourne have fallen, suggesting fewer foreign buyers, particularly from China. The economic slowdown in China has dimmed consumer confidence and appetite for overseas property, with Chinese buyers accounting for 44% of Sydney's new homes in the past three years. The slowdown may dim Chinese appetite for global property by 30% in 2015.

site_title: China consumers to spend more in Nov 11 'Singles Day' shopping spree: Nielsen
summary: Most online consumers in China plan to spend more during this year's "Singles Day" shopping promotion, with 56% saying they will spend more than last year, according to a Nielsen survey. The average expected spend is 1,761 yuan, a 22% increase from 2014. This year's trend will be closely watched for clues about private consumption as China's economy faces its slowest growth in over 20 years.

site_title: Takata plunges as Honda dumps it as airbag supplier after record US fine
summary: Takata shares plummeted nearly 20% to 1,100 yen after Honda dumped it as an airbag parts supplier, citing the need to stop using Takata airbag inflators linked to at least eight deaths and scores of injuries globally. US regulators imposed a record fine of up to $200 million. The crisis-hit firm faces further challenges, with its stock continuing to decline.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets, news of historic meeting with China
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.6% on Wednesday, following strong gains in overseas markets. The TAIEX index reached 8,847.72, hours after Taiwan and China announced their leaders would meet for the first time since 1949.

site_title: US fines Takata record US$200 million over faulty airbags
summary: US auto safety regulators fined Japanese auto parts maker Takata $200 million for providing inadequate information about its faulty airbags, which have caused eight deaths worldwide. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) also ordered 12 automakers to accelerate recalls and replace the equipment by 2019. The agency is investigating the use of ammonium nitrate in the airbags and has ordered Takata to stop using it in replacement inflators.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q3 net profit falls 16% to 680.67m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Q3 net profit fell 16% to 680.67m yuan, primarily due to a 42% decrease in other income and a 133% increase in finance expenses. Revenue rose 10% year-on-year to 4.14 billion yuan, driven by a higher number of vessels delivered according to schedule. Earnings per share decreased to 17.76 RMB cents, down from 21.17 RMB cents in Q3 2014. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Oil prices slide on profit-taking, but supply risks support
summary: Oil prices slid in thin trading on Wednesday, with Brent futures falling 4 US cents to US$50.50 a barrel and US crude dropping 2 US cents to US$47.88 a barrel. Investors took profits from the previous session's rally, but potential supply disruptions in the US, Brazil, and Libya supported prices. The decline came after oil prices reached their highest levels since October 13 earlier in the week.

site_title: Citic to buy rest of Singapore's Biosensors in S$1.1 billion deal
summary: Citic Private Equity Funds Management Co. agreed to buy the remaining 80.4% stake in Singapore-based Biosensors International Group Ltd. for approximately S$1.1 billion. The deal price is S$0.84 per share, a 24% premium over the stock's last closing price. Biosensors, which makes medical devices used in heart surgery and intensive care treatment, will continue to operate independently under Citic's ownership. The deal marks Citic's entry into the medical device sector.

site_title: South Korea Q4 exports seen down around 9 per cent on year: state bank
