summary: South Korea's exports are forecast to decline by around 9% in the October-December period, extending a year-long decline and dragging on growth in Asia's fourth-largest economy. This follows a 9.5% decline in the third quarter, mainly due to China's cooling economy and Europe's struggles. Shipments have posted their worst annual loss in six years, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of year-on-year deterioration. The decline is attributed to a leading exports indicator that fell 6.2% this quarter from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports are likely to fall sharply in the current quarter, a government-run bank specialising in trade financing said on Wednesday, extending a year-long decline that has dragged on growth in Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: UK shop prices drop again in Oct, more falls expected in X'mas run-up: BRC
summary: UK shop prices dropped 1.8% in October compared to the same period last year, a slightly less marked decline than in September. Food and non-food prices fell at a slower rate, with clothing, books, and DIY items experiencing the deepest levels of deflation. Retailers are expected to continue lowering prices in the run-up to Christmas to attract shoppers.

site_title: Indonesia chief econ minister says there is room for interest rate cut
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister, Darmin Nasution, stated that the central bank has room to cut interest rates due to easing inflation and a shrinking current account deficit. Inflation decreased to 6.25% in October, and the central bank will consider monetary policy easing in its next meeting on November 17. Nasution cited cooling inflation and a shrinking current account deficit as reasons for the potential interest rate cut, which could alleviate economic pressure.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's chief economic minister said on Wednesday the central bank has room to cut interest rates after inflation eased to 6.25 per cent in October.

site_title: Japan Post shares soar 16.5% above IPO price in trading debut
summary: Japan Post shares rose 16.5% above their IPO price of 1,400 yen, reaching 1,631 yen, in their Tokyo trading debut. The company's US$11.5 billion share sale is the largest so far this year. The banking unit's stock also jumped 16% to 1,680 yen. This successful debut is a significant milestone for Japan's largest postal service provider.

site_title: Cache issues 106.27m new units at S$0.941 each, plans advanced distribution
summary: CACHE Logistics Trust has raised S$100 million through a private placement by issuing 106.27 million new units at S$0.941 each. The new units will be used for potential acquisitions, loan repayment, and general corporate purposes. The trust plans to declare an advanced distribution of 0.86 Singapore cents per unit to existing unitholders. The placement price represents a 5% discount to the trust's adjusted volume weighted average price. The trust's logistics warehouse portfolio totals 6.7 million square feet valued at S$1.3 billion.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: South China Sea tensions scuttle Asia defence chiefs statement: US
summary: US defence officials say a joint declaration by Asia-Pacific defence ministers has been scrapped due to China's opposition to mentioning its island-building activities in the disputed South China Sea. China's reclamation and militarisation in the area has caused a divide in the region, according to US officials. The US insists it has freedom of navigation in the area, but China considers any criticism of its claims as a challenge to its sovereignty. The USS Lassen's recent visit to the Spratly Islands has further strained relations between the two countries.

site_title: Temasek seeks cloud startups in India as e-commerce 'overheated'
summary: Temasek's venture capital arm, Vertex Venture Holdings, is shifting its focus in India to software startups that cater to small and medium businesses, as the e-commerce sector becomes "overheated" with unprofitable investments. Vertex plans to invest $5-6 million in 3-4 Indian companies over the next 12 months, with a focus on enterprise software makers. The company sees an opportunity to capture market share in the estimated $300 million software-as-a-service market in India, which is dominated by small and medium businesses.

site_title: Pioneer firms honoured at Singapore Golden Jubilee Business Awards ceremony
summary: The Singapore Golden Jubilee Business Awards honored 50 major local companies for their achievements and contributions over the decades. The recipients, including Cathay Organisation and OCBC Bank, were recognized for staying relevant to changing domestic and global needs. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat praised their pioneering spirit, emphasizing the importance of remaining competitive as Singapore continues to progress. The awards ceremony highlighted the success of Singaporean businesses in creating value and reinventing themselves over the past 50 years.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.91 points to 1681.66 on Wednesday, with a 202-47 gain/loss ratio. The market opened higher, with volume reaching 116.6 million lots worth RM37.2 million.

site_title: Ringgit extends gains as rally in oil brightens revenue outlook
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.6% to 4.2597 a dollar, its largest gain in over a week, as Brent crude rallied to above US$50 a barrel, improving the country's revenue outlook. The positive sentiment from US stocks and Brent's climb helped drive the currency's gains, with policy makers expected to keep the benchmark rate at 3.25%. Malaysian government bonds also rose, with the yield declining three basis points to 3.61%.

site_title: Impasse at defence meeting over South China Sea: US official
summary: US defence officials say a meeting of Asia-Pacific defence chiefs is at an impasse due to China's lobbying to exclude mention of the South China Sea dispute from a joint communique. China claims the sea as its sovereign territory and rejects outside interference, while the US insists on freedom of navigation. The US and China held a bilateral meeting, with China describing a "bottom line" below which it would defend the islands, but the US says this is not an ultimatum. The signing ceremony for the joint communique is now in doubt, highlighting the growing divide over the issue.

site_title: Indonesia closes Bali airport due to volcanic eruption
summary: Indonesia closed Bali's Ngurah Rai airport until Thursday due to volcanic eruptions on Mount Rinjani, with tremors and potential for further eruptions recorded. The airport closure affects tens of thousands of travelers. This marks the second time Bali's airport has been closed due to volcanic activity, following a July closure due to Mount Raung eruptions in East Java.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q3 net profit up 48.3% to S$192.72m
summary: CapitaLand's Q3 net profit rose 48.3% to S$192.72 million, driven by higher profit after tax, better business unit performance, and portfolio gains. Revenue increased 17.1% to S$1.08 billion, with contributions from China development projects and higher rental revenue. Earnings per share rose to 4.5 Singapore cents, but no dividend was declared.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Fortune Reit, China Minzhong, F&N
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include CapitaLand's 48.3% surge in third-quarter net profit to S$192.72 million, Fortune Reit's 12% rise in distribution per unit, and China Minzhong Food Corp's net profit of S$3.41 million. Fraser & Neave debunked reports of a US$4 billion bid for Vinamilk. The Singapore Exchange saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Australia shoppers, exporters bode well for GDP growth
summary: Australian retail sales posted a 0.4% increase in September, with spending for the third quarter making moderate gains. Export volumes rebounded, likely contributing 1 percentage point to GDP growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia cited "green shoots" in economic data, leading to a decrease in the chance of interest rate cuts. GDP growth is expected to rebound after a worrying slowdown in the second quarter, with the trade deficit narrowing to $2.3 billion in September. This positive economic news could boost policymakers' optimism.

site_title: No women, no bonus: British financial firms urged to come clean on lack of diversity
summary: The UK government is urging British financial firms to link bonuses to the number of women in senior roles and to report their gender diversity figures publicly. A report by Virgin Money's Jayne-Anne Gadhia recommends measures to address the lack of women in the financial services industry, which contributes 127 billion pounds to the British economy. The goal is to increase female workforce representation and boost economic productivity. The report also aims to increase female representation on FTSE 350 boards to a third by 2020.

site_title: Data hogs force Microsoft to cut cloud storage
summary: Microsoft has ended its unlimited cloud storage offering for Office 365 subscribers due to a small number of users abusing the system, storing over 75 terabytes of data. The company will instead provide 1 terabyte of storage for $1.99/month, reducing free storage from 15GB to 5GB and discontinuing 100GB and 200GB paid plans. The changes will begin in early 2016, allowing Microsoft to focus on delivering high-value productivity and collaboration experiences.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.62% as Japan Post starts trading
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.62% higher on November 4, 2015, as Japan Post Holdings and its units made their market debut after the largest share sale of the year. The Nikkei 225 index rose 300.41 points to 18,983.65. This move marked a significant milestone for Japan Post, which had raised $20.5 billion through its initial public offering. The debut came after a year-long process and was seen as a major step forward for the postal service's expansion into the financial sector.

site_title: Internet firms must store usage data for one year: UK surveillance bill
summary: The UK government will present a bill requiring internet firms to store customer usage data for up to a year to aid security agencies in tracking online communications. The Investigatory Powers Bill aims to address a capability gap and maintain public safety, while including judicial authorisation for accessing internet connection records. Rights campaigners criticize the move, citing concerns over privacy, but the government assures that intrusive actions will be subject to strong oversight arrangements.

site_title: Twitter trades stars for hearts, favourites for likes
summary: Twitter has retired its star button, replacing it with a heart to express user preferences. The change, similar to Facebook's "likes," aims to provide a better way for users to express their views. However, the move has sparked criticism from some users, who prefer the star system. The change was made in an effort to simplify user interactions and align with other social media platforms.

site_title: Two years on, SGX's new CEO seeks to overcome stock-rout fallout
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd's new CEO Loh Boon Chye aims to restore confidence in the stock market, which suffered a mystery penny-stock crash two years ago, wiping out $6.9 billion in market value. Loh, a veteran banker, acknowledges the impact of the crash and is discussing with investors, brokers, and listed companies to revive interest in equities. He emphasizes overcoming the lingering doubts as his top priority, using the acronym ABL to describe the affected companies.

site_title: Australian central bank holds rates, but hints at policy easing if needed
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept its cash rate steady at 2% on Tuesday, but hinted at potential policy easing if needed to support the economy. Governor Glenn Stevens stated that business conditions had improved and employment was stronger than expected, while inflation remained subdued. The RBA left the door open for a rate cut, but investors are not expecting it by year-end. Interbank futures imply a 36% chance of an easing, with some experts warning of a debt-driven bubble in home prices.

site_title: Taiwan, China leaders to hold historic meeting in Singapore on Saturday
summary: Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Singapore on Saturday, marking the first time leaders from both sides have met since the Chinese civil war ended in 1949. The meeting aims to discuss cross-strait issues and maintain the status quo, with Ma not signing any agreements or issuing joint statements. The move comes at a sensitive time in Taiwan, with elections scheduled for January 16, and follows previous attempts by China to influence Taiwan's elections, which have backfired.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.42% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 12.70 points or 0.42% to 3,012.26 on Wednesday, following regional gains and a US stocks rally. Top gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, DBS, UOB, and Biosensors International Group. The market saw 54.1 million shares worth S$43.7 million traded, with 92 gainers and 44 losers.

site_title: Walt Disney to invest US$200m in Vice Media
summary: Walt Disney Co is investing US$200 million in Vice Media, a global multimedia brand known for its coverage of current affairs for the Millennial generation. This investment comes as Vice is set to take over H2, a spinoff from the History channel, which is owned by Disney, Hearst Corp, and NBC Universal. Vice will launch a new channel, "Viceland," featuring prime-time shows, and will expand its content offerings. The investment is part of Vice's efforts to bring news to young consumers who access it through digital and social media channels.

images.alt_text: Founder, CEO VICE Shane Smith.

site_title: Groupon appoints new CEO, forecasts weak 2016
summary: Groupon appoints new CEO Rich Williams, replacing Eric Lefkofsky, effective immediately. The company forecasts weak 2016 revenue, predicting $2.75-$3.05 billion, below analyst estimates. Groupon will spend $150-$200 million more on marketing and shift focus from consumer electronics to online marketplace. This change is expected to lower current-quarter revenue by $50-$100 million. The company also reported a net loss of $27.6 million in the third quarter, with revenue flat at $713.6 million.

site_title: Moscovici confident of 'compromise' with Greece on remaining reforms
summary: EU's economic affairs commissioner Pierre Moscovici expressed confidence that Greece will reach a "compromise" with its creditors by the end of the week on remaining reforms demanded under its third bailout. The talks centered on four key issues, including home loan foreclosures, bad loans, VAT on private education, and debt restructuring. Moscovici assured Greece that the European Commission is "on your side" and progress has been made. A successful compromise would pave the way for the Eurogroup's November 9 meeting, where Greece will receive outstanding bailout funds.

site_title: Expat demand drives condo boom in Phnom Penh
summary: A condo boom is underway in Phnom Penh, driven by expat demand, with developers like Oxley Holdings and Teho International building high-rise apartments. The market is expected to grow, but supply may outstrip demand in a few years unless the middle class shifts away from traditional house ownership. Foreigners account for 60-70% of condominium sales, and local buyers are purchasing for investment purposes. The construction and real estate industries are contributing significantly to Cambodia's GDP, with prime residential land prices rising 14.1% in the first half of this year.

site_title: Japan Post to make Tokyo debut after US$11.5b IPO
summary: Japan Post Holdings and its banking and insurance units are set to make their market debut in Tokyo after a record-breaking $11.5 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company, which has about 24,000 offices nationwide, plans to use the proceeds to fund reconstruction efforts after the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. The IPO is the largest globally since Alibaba's $25 billion IPO last year, and analysts expect it to boost investment in Japanese firms and shake up the country's rigid corporate culture.

site_title: US: Energy, retail shares lead stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose for the second straight session, led by energy and retail sectors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 90.93 points (0.51%) to 17,919.69, while the S&P 500 rose 5.82 (0.28%) to 2,109.87. Energy stocks, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, gained 1.8% and 3.4%, respectively, as large oil companies could benefit from oil price recovery and industry consolidation. Retail stocks jumped after Victoria's Secret and American Eagle Outfitters lifted their earnings forecasts.

site_title: Soros pulls US$490m from Gross fund
summary: George Soros has pulled $490 million from a Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund managed by Bill Gross, dealing a significant blow to Gross's efforts to prove himself post-Pimco. The fund lost 2% since Gross took over, worse than 63% of similar funds. Gross struggled to attract outside money and faced redemptions, despite having the backing of Soros, one of the most successful hedge fund managers. The move is a setback for Gross, who is trying to rebuild his reputation as a top bond manager.

site_title: Tesla sets new model unveiling for next March
summary: Tesla has set a new model unveiling date for March 2016, aiming to introduce the Model 3, a more affordable electric car priced at around $35,000. The company reported a loss of $230 million in the third quarter, despite producing a record 13,091 vehicles and delivering 11,603. Tesla's Model X has seen a surge in global orders, with China being a key driver of growth. The company also expects to begin production at its "gigafactory" in Nevada by the end of 2016.

site_title: A welcome return to 'good economic news is good for stocks'
summary: The US Federal Reserve is signaling a potential interest rate hike in December, which could be good news for investors. This marks a shift away from prolonged reliance on central bank stimulus, which has fueled asset bubbles and complacency in markets. The Fed's clear signal is a response to growing US economic strength and inflation concerns. As a result, the Dow Jones Industrial Average may experience a return to "good economic news is good for stocks," benefiting investors despite initial market volatility. The federal funds futures market now prices in a 50% probability of a rate hike in December.

site_title: Oil prices rally on talk of firmer market
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 4% on Tuesday as traders expect a firmer market ahead of the US petroleum report. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate contract jumped $1.76 to $47.90 a barrel, its highest level in over three weeks. Refinery utilization rates are forecast to rise for a third consecutive week, and crude oil stockpiles are expected to rise by the smallest amount in six weeks. The market is also optimistic about Libya's potential to increase crude exports and Brazil's oil production.

site_title: VW emissions-cheating scandal widens with new CO2 revelations
summary: Volkswagen's emissions-cheating scandal widened with the revelation of 800,000 additional vehicles showing "inconsistencies" in carbon emissions, including petrol engines. The company estimates the latest findings could cost 2 billion euros. A separate impact assessment on Porsche SE, which owns 32.4% of VW's capital, suggests potential negative effects on its results. The exact scale of irregularities remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Germany's Volkswagen said Tuesday an internal probe had found that 800,000 more vehicles showed "inconsistencies" on carbon emissions, including the first petrol engines, as the auto giant sank deeper into a massive pollution cheating scandal.

site_title: Police raid German soccer HQ over 2006 World Cup payment
summary: German police raided the headquarters of the German Football Federation and the homes of top officials over tax evasion allegations linked to the 2006 World Cup. Prosecutors launched a tax probe into a 6.7-million-euro payment to FIFA, which was allegedly used to buy votes to secure the hosting of the tournament. The investigation is focused on tax evasion allegations, but the statute of limitations has expired, preventing direct corruption accusations. The DFB president, former president, and former general secretary are under investigation.

site_title: Fitbit beats market expectations but is winded by fresh share sale
summary: Fitbit Inc. reported strong Q3 earnings, beating analysts' forecast of 10 US cents per share, with revenue nearly tripling to US$409.3 million. However, the company's share price fell 10% after announcing a fresh share sale, lifting lock-up restrictions on over 2 million shares a month early. Fitbit forecasts a profit of 20-25 US cents per share and revenue of US$620-650 million for the fourth quarter, despite net income falling 33.5% due to increased research and development and marketing costs.

site_title: US dollar firms against euro
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro on Tuesday, reaching US$1.0959 per euro, as traders awaited public comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen on possible interest rate hikes. The decision to leave interest rates near zero at the October policy meeting and signal a December hike was still on the table has fueled speculation about a potential rate increase. Yellen will testify on Wednesday about the Fed's supervision and regulation of the US financial system, with market analysts hoping for signals on the economy's readiness for a rate hike.

site_title: Factory orders fall for second straight month
summary: US factory orders fell 1.0% in September for a second consecutive month, as the manufacturing sector struggles due to a strong dollar and deep spending cuts by energy companies. However, motor vehicle production remains a bright spot, with orders surging in September and expected to continue in October. Factory activity is being constrained by inventory overhang and tepid global demand, but a report showing new orders rose in October for the first time since July suggests the worst may be over.

site_title: Europe: Stocks weather Standard Chartered, Volkswagen storm
summary: European stocks weathered a turbulent day on Tuesday, with Standard Chartered and Volkswagen dominating trading. Standard Chartered reported a surprise third-quarter loss and announced plans to raise $5.1 billion in fresh capital, while Volkswagen faced new accusations of emissions cheating. Despite the negative news, European markets recovered, with London's FTSE gaining 0.34% and the eurozone's CAC 40 index closing 0.41% higher. Volkswagen's share price pared its losses to close 1.51% down, while Standard Chartered's shares fell 6.67% to finish the day at 666.00 pence.

site_title: Corn drought turning China's hope for record crop into shrunken harvest
summary: China's corn crop is expected to decline by 5.8% this season, the largest drop since 2000, due to a summer drought and late-season rains that stunted plant growth and delayed harvests. A record crop was anticipated to sustain China's huge pork habit, but the smaller harvest may boost domestic prices already inflated by subsidized government purchases and restrictions on cheaper imports. Global stockpiles are also expected to drop for the first time in five years.

site_title: Plan to build Singapore in India sends land prices soaring
summary: India's Andhra Pradesh state government plans to build a new capital city, Amaravati, to rival Singapore, with a master plan developed in cooperation with Singaporean firm Surbana Jurong. The city will cover 212 square kilometers and feature canals, water taxis, manufacturing hubs, universities, and skyscrapers. The project aims to create a high-tech metropolis by 2027, with a cost estimated at 250 billion rupees. The government has secured land from farmers through a promise to return a third of the property and offer annual payments. The project's success relies on securing massive funds, with critics questioning the feasibility of the plan.

images.alt_text: In India, where it can take a decade to acquire enough land to build a factory, Mr Naidu's plan is daring.

site_title: Fresh studies shine new light on global income inequality
summary: Studies led by Nora Lustig have shed new light on global income inequality, finding that it is not rising globally, but rather declining in some regions, including Latin America and South Asia. Contrary to the common assertion that rising inequality is the central economic fact of our times, the data suggests that rich-country pundits and news outlets have a disproportionate impact on international debates. The studies also show that tax-and-transfer schemes can significantly reduce inequality, with emerging countries doing better than advanced economies. However, the quality of government programs plays a crucial role, and some public expenditure may serve little purpose other than keeping certain political constituencies quiet.

site_title: Offshore accommodation bolsters POSH topline in Q3
summary: POSH, a Singapore-based offshore services company, reported a 20% year-on-year increase in revenue to US$80.4 million in Q3, driven by higher contributions from its offshore accommodation division. However, net profit fell 14% to US$12.6 million, excluding a one-time gain from vessel disposal. The company attributed the decline to lower vessel charter rates and fleet utilisation, as well as higher operating and repair costs. Despite the challenges, POSH initiated cost control measures and maintained a strong balance sheet with untapped bank lines of US$374.5 million.

site_title: Star Trek lives long with new TV series
summary: The new Star Trek TV series, set to debut in January 2017, will be primarily shown on CBS's streaming service, CBS Access, with only a preview episode broadcast on the network. The series will introduce new characters and alien civilizations while exploring contemporary themes. However, fans expressed concern over the exclusive streaming model and the involvement of executive producer Alex Kurtzman, who directed two previous Star Trek movies. Despite this, many fans are excited for the return of the franchise, with one fan calling it a "nerdgasm."

site_title: Financial crime: Leaders can instil spirit of compliance
summary: Singapore's strong economy and financial hub reputation are threatened by financial crimes, such as the Sunshine Empire and Profitable Plots cases. The country's enforcement regime aims to hold individuals and corporate entities accountable for misconduct, with a focus on swift and firm action. A spirit of compliance is also crucial, with leaders playing a key role in shaping individual and organizational behavior. Effective enforcement and compliance can deter similar behavior, while the threat of personal criminal sanctions and imprisonment can serve as a deterrent.

site_title: Thailand ups tax benefits to boost investment projects
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Apisak Tantivorawong, announced tax incentives to boost investment projects, aiming to accelerate the country's sluggish economy. The new incentives include tax exemptions and deductions for projects approved by the Board of Investment (BOI) and private sector investments. The government also streamlined the public-private partnership process to speed up infrastructure projects. These measures aim to stimulate investment and drive economic growth, with forecasts predicting 2.7% growth for this year and 1.9% for the next.

site_title: Putting old ways to rest
summary: Jenny Tay, managing director of Direct Funeral Services, advocates for advance preparation and professionalising the funeral industry. This comes as the company aims to educate people about the importance of planning ahead.

site_title: Statins do more than lower cholesterol
summary: Statins, commonly used to lower cholesterol, have been shown to have benefits beyond just reducing cholesterol levels. They also reduce artery-damaging inflammation, stabilize plaque, and cleanse arteries of plaque. According to new guidelines, statins may be prescribed to 46% of people aged 40-75, which could cut in half the number of people developing cardiovascular disease. However, some individuals may not respond well to statins, and doctors are encouraged to try at least three statins before moving on to another option.

site_title: North Sea drillers out in the cold as Statoil cuts rig contracts
summary: Statoil ASA, Norway's largest oil company, has cut its investment in North Sea drilling by cancelling or suspending rig contracts, affecting companies like Transocean Ltd, Seadrill Ltd, and Fred Olsen Energy ASA. This move is in response to the 60% slump in North Sea Brent crude prices, which has led to a sharp decline in charter rates and a need for oil companies to slash costs and renegotiate contracts. Analysts predict that up to 20 rigs in Norway and the UK may be scrapped, leading to a "graveyard" of idle rigs in the North Sea.

site_title: Constant construction
summary: Companies in early stages should align their mission statement with branding strategy, while established companies should conduct an annual internal exercise. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz will open a Royal Healthcare specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. Researchers have developed a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its campus up for sale. Chinatown Business Association seeks S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of an outdoor area.

site_title: The wonder of it all
summary: Watches & Wonders, a luxury watch show in Hong Kong, unveiled key timepieces, marking its independence from the SME Magazine. Meanwhile, a specialist healthcare centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz took control. Researchers at NUS are working on sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve the price. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard expressed concerns over poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets $5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its campus up for sale.

site_title: UOB's PE unit leads US$23m Series B in Taiwan startup
summary: UOB Venture Management has led a US$23 million Series B investment in Taiwan-based AI startup Appier, accounting for about a third of the amount. Appier uses AI to predict consumer behavior across multiple screens, helping brands reach consumers where and when they matter most. The investment will help Appier develop its products, identify new business opportunities, and recruit talent across Asia. This round of funding is expected to aid in the mass adoption of cross-screen technology, particularly in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: The United Overseas Bank (UOB) Plaza building is pictured in the central business district in Singapore in this Jul 24, 2015.

site_title: New, emerging risks present opportunities for insurers: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has identified emerging risks such as cyber, liability, supply chain, and reputation as opportunities for the insurance industry. Cyber risk alone costs the global economy between $300 billion to $1 trillion annually, and businesses must prepare with cyber insurance as part of a comprehensive risk management strategy. The MAS also supports a Natural Catastrophe Data Analytics Exchange (NAT CAT DAX) to pool insurable claims data and unlock new economic exposure and loss datasets.

site_title: BlackBerry bets its hardware future on new Android phone
summary: BlackBerry is releasing a new Android phone, the "Priv", which could be the company's last attempt at making its devices profitable before ending production. CEO John Chen has stated that he will exit the device business if he can't make it profitable. The Priv features BlackBerry's security and productivity features, including a physical keyboard, and runs a full version of Google's Android operating system. If the Priv sells well, it may keep the phone business going, but if not, BlackBerry could stop producing phones within the next year.

site_title: Better margin, currency gains lift YHS Q3 profit
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a Singaporean drinks maker, reported a tripled net profit of S$9.4 million in its third-quarter earnings, driven by currency gains and improved gross margin. Despite a 4.6% drop in revenue to S$109.5 million, the company's gross profit rose 2.5% to S$43.8 million. The company attributed the decline in revenue to competitive selling prices in its markets and higher initial operating costs. Despite this, the company expects its performance to remain satisfactory, with food and beverage margins expected to come under pressure in the next 12 months.

site_title: Global banks can't be wound down with certainty, says FSB
summary: Global banks can't be wound down with certainty due to cross-border resolution issues, according to the Financial Stability Board. Nations need comprehensive legislation to recognize and support other countries' decisions in winding down a bank. Temporary stays on termination rights and "bail-in" rules remain impediments to cross-border resolution. The FSB aims to address these challenges to achieve orderly bank resolutions, a key goal set by world leaders.

site_title: STI rebounds after five straight losses
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 25.15 points to 2,999.56 on Tuesday, following an overnight rally in Wall Street and gains in Hong Kong and China. The main drivers of the index were the three banks, with DBS leading the way with a 2% jump to S$17.60. However, Maybank Kim Eng downgraded DBS to a "sell" citing downcast regional consumer sentiment and business prospects. Despite low turnover of S$880.3 million, the index has now staged a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Mystery deepens over Russian airliner crash in Egypt
summary: A Russian charter plane crashed on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt on Saturday, killing all 224 people on board. The Airbus jetliner's cause remains unknown, with company executives ruling out technical or human error. Representatives from at least five countries are investigating the crash, raising questions about the aircraft's repair history and possible terrorist involvement. The investigation has sparked debate, with aviation officials criticizing the company's assertion that the crash was not caused by technical or human error.

site_title: UK exports growth hits six-year low in Q3
summary: UK exports experienced the weakest growth in orders since the 2009 financial crisis, with firms reporting limited growth in overseas sales and orders, according to a British Chambers of Commerce survey. The UK's export drive is at risk of going into reverse gear, with too few British companies making the jump to export. A separate survey suggests domestic demand may be the main driver of the slowdown in UK economic growth, which dropped to 0.5% in the three months to September.

site_title: What a year
summary: It's been an intense year, marked by significant events such as the passing of Singapore's first prime minister and the SG50 celebrations. Businesses have struggled under an unforgiving economic landscape. New developments include the opening of Royal Healthcare's specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, and NUS researchers' startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Other notable news includes OCBC's target of S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, Shatec's campus closure and staff cuts, and the rebranding of heritage businesses for the younger generation.

site_title: Mobile technology and targeted marketing barge in on holidays
summary: Mobile travel technology is changing the way people plan and book holidays. According to Euromonitor International, US$96 billion of global online travel sales were made via mobile devices in 2014. Travel providers like Booking.com and Expedia are using data from mobile purchases to offer personalized recommendations for hotels and restaurants. This trend is expected to continue, with mobile travel sales forecast to rise at a compound annual growth rate of 22% from 2014-2019. Beacon technology will enable more tailored marketing, allowing companies to see where customers are at any time.

site_title: M1 in tie-up to create next-gen SDN data centre
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, is partnering with VMware, Palo Alto Networks, and Huawei to develop a next-generation software-defined networking (SDN) data centre. The collaboration aims to enhance M1's corporate offerings and launch new services more swiftly and flexibly. SDN technology provides a unified view of the network, enabling central management and control over individual elements. This move is expected to improve M1's connectivity solutions and cloud-based data centre services for corporate customers, driven by the growth potential in this segment.

site_title: Nice work
summary: A specialist centre for Royal Healthcare is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Meanwhile, researchers from NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In the retail sector, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard is struggling with poor footfall and vacant units, with tenants expressing concerns about survival. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and selling the building.

site_title: China's Huami keeps pace as it goes head to head with Fitbit
summary: Huami Inc, a Chinese wearable technology company, is launching a series of new fitness trackers that will rival Fitbit's global dominance. The devices, priced at one-tenth the cost of Fitbit's gadgets, will track vital signs like heart rate and blood pressure. Huami's CEO, Huang Wang, plans to expand the company's product line to Europe and the US, with a goal of challenging Fitbit's market share. Despite mounting competition, Huami is profitable, with over $10 million in net profit each quarter, and is considering a third round of fundraising.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks CIMB Research reported that the Q3 2015 results season featured slowing loan growth and rising credit costs. UOB delivered the steepest earnings outperformance, mainly due to one-off investment gains. DBS and OCBC met expectations.

site_title: Let remisiers buy-in for clients who short sell by mistake
summary: A proposal by R Sivanithy suggests allowing remisiers to buy-in accidentally shorted securities on T+1, similar to the current error-in-trade (EIT) accounts. This would reduce the need for a separate cash market. If remisiers cannot buy-in on T+1, they could do so on T+2 with a small penalty. Only when this fails would SGX step in to buy-in on T+3, maintaining the current settlement process's integrity. This change would address the issue of most shorts being accidental and done by retail investors or remisiers themselves.

images.alt_text: In "Time to rethink the need for buying-in" (BT, Oct 30), R Sivanithy advocates the revival of the cash market to complement the current buying-in process of the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Nazir: Political uncertainty top worry of Malaysia's foreign investors
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's government is facing significant concerns from foreign investors due to ongoing 1MDB scandal, which has led to a slump in global oil prices and a 18.5% decline in the ringgit against the dollar. Chairman of CIMB, Nazir Razak, states that restoring political stability is crucial for Malaysia's reputation and growth, calling for swift investigations into 1MDB to be concluded and findings made public.

site_title: Google aims to begin drone parcel deliveries in 2017
summary: Google's Project Wing plans to begin drone parcel deliveries in 2017, with the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) expected to publish final rules for commercial drone operations early next year. The company is in talks with the FAA and other stakeholders about setting up an air traffic control system. Project Wing has conducted testing in the US and Australia, and aims to develop new vehicle types and shapes. The system for identifying drone operators and keeping UAVs away from other aircraft could be set up within 12 months.

site_title: Adele's Hello breaks record with 1.1 million digital sales
summary: Adele's comeback single "Hello" broke records, selling over 1.1 million digital songs in its debut week, becoming the first song to reach the one million download mark on the Billboard charts. It surpassed Justin Bieber's single "Sorry," which sold 276,800 downloads. The song was streamed 47.5 million times globally on Spotify, making it the most streamed song in a week. Adele's album "25" is set to be released this month.

images.alt_text: Hello was the first single from Adele's upcoming new album 25, to be released this month, and follows a four-year break from music.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GIC is in talks with India-based app 'Little' for a potential US$50 million financing round. Little previously raised US$50 million in July from investors including Paytm, Tiger Global, and SAIF Partners. China Minzhong Food Corp reported a 73% decline in net profit to S$3.41 million for the three months ended Sept 30. Neo Group agreed to buy a 90% stake in CT Vegetables & Fruits for S$4.8 million.

site_title: China set to be hotbed for US$100b green bond market
summary: China is poised to become a major hub for the $100 billion green bond market, driven by the country's vast investments in solar and wind capacity. Authorities and developers are seeking alternatives to loans for funding clean energy projects, with policymakers promoting healthy development during economic slowdowns. China has already issued several green bonds, with some selling out quickly, and is expected to play a prominent role in the regional green bond market. The country's ambitious targets for renewable energy and its need for low-carbon financing make it an attractive destination for green bond issuers.

site_title: Bitcoin is back - and ready for business
summary: Bitcoin has embarked on a seven-week winning streak, the longest since November 2013, with industry experts citing enhanced interest and acceptance from established financial companies. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and others have taken an interest in Bitcoin's blockchain technology for overhauling trading of securities, derivatives, and loans. Investors are speculating that the economic situation in China, with its capital controls and recent outflow of cash, is fueling the rise. A recent EU court ruling exempting virtual currencies from value-added tax is also contributing to the positive sentiment, potentially propelling Bitcoin to "store of value" status.

site_title: Making it simple
summary: Snehal Patel, co-founder of MyDoc, discusses improving healthcare accessibility by connecting patients, professionals, partners, and payers. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz plans to open a Royal Healthcare specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. Researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, while Hao Mart's Taste Orchard faces poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec cuts staff and puts its Orchard campus up for sale.

site_title: Still more net sells than buys in Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more stocks than they bought in the three months to Oct 28, with net sells of S$1.44 billion compared to net buys of S$551.5 million. However, in the consumer goods segment, there were net buys of S$109.7 million, outweighing net sells of S$63 million.

site_title: What lies ahead
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges such as talent shortages, rising costs, and the need to leverage technology for expansion. Meanwhile, a specialist healthcare center is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, following Sojitz's takeover. Researchers have developed a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In the retail sector, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard struggles with low footfall and vacant units. Financial institutions, such as OCBC, are targeting serial entrepreneurs for loans by 2028. Other businesses, like Shatec, are adapting to changing market conditions.

site_title: As Modi triples spending, stocks of India's road builders rally
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has tripled spending on roads and highways, boosting stocks of road builders, particularly smaller contractors. The custom index of eight stocks has gained 8.3% this year, outperforming the benchmark S&P BSE Sensex. In contrast, the nation's power producers are grappling with losses due to erratic fuel supplies and selling below cost to state-owned distributors. The government aims to roll out $45 billion of road projects over the next three years, with plans to increase daily construction to 30 kilometers by the end of 2016.

site_title: SGX setting up Chicago Hub to allow direct access
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is setting up a direct-access hub in Chicago, allowing North American customers to trade SGX's equity, foreign exchange, and commodities future contracts. The hub, located at CME Group's facility in Aurora, Illinois, is part of SGX's effort to remain accessible to global traders following the Global Financial Crisis. The move is expected to bring investors closer to Asia's markets and reinforce SGX's role as the world's largest offshore market for Asian equity index futures.

site_title: S'pore and China to ink a slew of bilateral deals during Xi's visit
summary: Singapore and China are set to announce several bilateral agreements during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit from November 6-7. The agreements include a third government-to-government project focusing on modern connectivity and the service-sector economy, as well as upgrades to the bilateral free trade agreement. The third project, expected to be located in Chongqing, will be a key nodal point for China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. The visit comes as China's economy develops and moves up the manufacturing value chain, with Singapore's services sector expected to benefit from the agreements.

site_title: AIIB chief pledges 'world-class charter'
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is set to become operational by the end of 2015, with a "world-class charter" governing its activities. The bank's designated president, Jin Liqun, has pledged a non-resident board structure, which he believes will ensure efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The AIIB's main areas of activity will be energy, transport, and water/urban sectors, with a focus on co-financing projects with existing multilateral development banks. The bank's unit of account will be the US dollar, and it will begin recruiting staff in the fourth quarter of 2015.

site_title: Rail issue: do what MOH did, bring foreign expertise to bear
summary: A series of MRT breakdowns occurred on October 28, causing inconvenience to commuters. Two separate incidents, including a train malfunctioning and a truck overturning against a pillar, highlighted the need for a thorough investigation. Experts from less accident-prone overseas railway systems are recommended to review the system's hardware and software before a packed train operates. This approach was successful in identifying the cause of a problem at the Singapore General Hospital, and it is suggested that similar assistance may be required to resolve the recurring MRT issues.

site_title: UK to return ex-Macau official's corrupt assets worth US$43m
summary: The UK has agreed to repatriate approximately $43 million of ill-gotten assets belonging to former Macau official Ao Man-long, who was jailed for bribery and money laundering in 2008. The assets, worth around $100 million, were acquired through corruption while Ao was in charge of land sales in Macau. The repatriation comes as China seeks to stamp out corruption, and follows a series of investment deals between China and the UK worth over $60 billion. The assets will be returned to Macau as part of a larger effort to recover corruption proceeds.

site_title: Cleaner and leaner HSBC struggles to grow
summary: HSBC reported a 16% decline in adjusted pretax profit in Hong Kong due to a turbulent summer in emerging markets. The bank's quarterly expenses fell as it cut costs, with bad debt provisions down 30% despite regional economic concerns. Despite this, HSBC's growth prospects remain uncertain, with shares down 17% this year. The bank is focusing on expanding its retail and commercial customer base in China's Pearl River Delta and setting up a new securities joint venture in China, which could tap into the country's booming bond market.

site_title: Shipping industry leaders focus on value creation
summary: Shipping industry leaders attended a Seoul meeting, focusing on value creation amidst complex regulations and market challenges. They emphasized the need for quality over quantity, enhancing shipbuilding and classification standards, and ship operating procedures. The industry expressed concerns over the Ballast Water Management Convention's potential entry into force, citing technical risks and lack of type-approved equipment. They also supported cross-industry cooperation on cyber safety and security, as well as improving casualty investigation reporting and environmental regulations.

site_title: Slight rise in Oct PMI, but it's too early to cheer
summary: Singapore's October PMI rose 0.3 point to 48.9, still in contraction mode, but economists caution against optimism. The slight improvement is attributed to the year-end festive season demand, but the sluggish outlook is expected to persist until the middle of next year. The manufacturing sector's sub-index for new orders and new export orders also rose, but the overall reading remains below the 50-point mark. Economists warn that the recent uptick could be seasonal and may not last into Q1 2016.

site_title: Lack of trade finance slowing global growth: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) reports that a lack of trade finance is slowing global growth, with the global trade finance gap estimated at $1.4 trillion in 2014. Increasing costs and complexity in complying with regulatory requirements are major impediments to trade finance, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The ADB's Trade Finance Programme aims to close market gaps for trade finance, supporting over $20 billion in trade since 2009. The programme's guarantees and loans to banks will play a vital role in enabling businesses to realize their maximum potential from new trade opportunities.

site_title: China shouldn't behave like a sore loser on Spratlys issue
summary: China's reaction to the US Navy's freedom-of-navigation operation in the South China Sea has been low-key, with Chinese naval commander Wu Shengli holding a teleconference with US Admiral John Richardson. The US decision not to cancel scheduled military-to-military exchanges reflects a growing maturity in the bilateral relationship. The arbitral tribunal's decision to proceed with the case against China has significant implications, with China's pledge to uphold international law being called into question. China's refusal to participate in the tribunal's proceedings and its assertion that the decision is "null and void" raises concerns about its commitment to international law.

site_title: Dell seen selling US$10b of assets ahead of EMC merger
summary: Dell is selling around $10 billion in non-core assets, including software and services, to reduce debt ahead of its $49.5 billion acquisition of EMC Corp. The assets to be sold include Quest Software, SonicWall, and IT services provider Perot Systems, but not Dell's hardware assets. The deal, valued at $67 billion, is expected to close between May and October 2016. Dell and its shareholders are contributing $4.25 billion in equity to the deal, which aims to achieve an investment-grade credit rating within 18-24 months after the merger.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Newly registered companies in Singapore include those with issued capital between S$200,000 and S$5 million. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is planning to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being taken over by Sojitz. Researchers at NUS have developed a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff, and putting the building up for sale. Chinatown Business Association is seeking compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: US to keep operating in South China Sea: US defence chief
summary: US Defence Secretary Ashton Carter reaffirmed that the US will continue to operate in the South China Sea, citing international law as the basis for its actions. Carter made the statement during a meeting with his Chinese counterpart Chang Wanquan in Kuala Lumpur. The US will continue to fly, sail, and operate in the region, contradicting China's claims of sovereignty over the area.

site_title: Property data
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Property data shows vacant units and poor footfall at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard, prompting tenant concerns. OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts down its Orchard campus, cutting 42 staff and selling the building. Meanwhile, a Royal Healthcare specialist centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS are working to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. A Chinatown Business Association is seeking $77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of an outdoor area. Munchi Pancakes modernizes traditional snacks.

site_title: Far East H-Trust's Q3 DPS hit by revenue dip, higher finance costs
summary: Far East H-Trust reported a 9.1% year-on-year fall in Q3 distribution per stapled security to 1.2 Singapore cents due to softer hotel and serviced residence revenues, despite stable occupancies. Gross revenue dropped 4.8% to S$29.7 million, and net property income declined 4.6% to S$26.9 million. The trust's finance costs increased 20.6% to S$5.18 million due to higher short-term interest rates. Despite this, the trust's financial position remains stable, and its CEO believes that government initiatives to strengthen Singapore as a travel destination will benefit the tourism sector.

site_title: Developing win-win situations
summary: Spring has supported 94 Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) projects, benefiting 632 SMEs and startups in capability development since its inception. The SME magazine reports on various business and startup news, including a specialist healthcare centre opening in Tokyo or Osaka, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: China won't risk sudden fall in yuan: JP Morgan
summary: China's central bank will maintain the yuan's stability despite potential IMF inclusion, according to JP Morgan Chase & Co. Chief China Economist Zhu Haibin stated that a sudden drop in the yuan could harm the economy, which is forecast to grow at 6.9% this year. The IMF is expected to decide on the yuan's inclusion in its reserve currencies later this month, with a 11% probability of a drop to 6.50 USD by year-end.

site_title: StanChart plans rights issue to raise US$5.1b; 15,000 jobs to be axed
summary: Standard Chartered plans a US$5.1 billion rights issue to counter a third-quarter loss and declining revenue. The bank will also cut costs, dump underperforming loans and businesses, and axe 15,000 jobs. The announcement sent its shares down 10% to 645 pence.

site_title: Asian currencies gain against US dollar
summary: Asian currencies strengthened against the US dollar on Tuesday as investors awaited US economic data that could influence a Federal Reserve interest rate decision. The Australian dollar gained 0.67% after the Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at 2.0%, while the US dollar retreated against Singapore, Taiwan, and other Asian currencies. Investors are paring back their long US dollar positions, helping Asian currencies rise, as the Fed considers a potential rate hike in December.

site_title: US factory orders fall for second straight month
summary: US factory orders declined 1.0% in September, the second consecutive month, due to a strong dollar and deep spending cuts by energy companies. The manufacturing sector, accounting for 12% of the economy, is constrained by inventory overhang and global demand. However, a report on October orders showed a rise for the first time since July, suggesting the sector may be improving. Orders for transportation equipment fell 3.1% and motor vehicle production rose 1.5%, while inventories and shipments indicate a possible end to the slump.

site_title: EU failing to tackle tax dodging one year after 'LuxLeaks'
summary: The European Union has failed to effectively tackle tax avoidance practices despite vowing to address loopholes after the LuxLeaks scandal one year ago. A report by 19 organizations found that most member states still provide opportunities for multinationals to dodge taxes, with Luxembourg and Germany being the worst offenders. Although some measures have been taken, new loopholes have emerged, and EU governments are pushing for confidentiality to conceal company ownership. The EU has launched probes into tax deals and agreed to automatically exchange information on tax deals with multinationals, but progress has been slow.

site_title: SembMarine's new steel fab facility boosts productivity
summary: SembMarine's new steel fabrication facility in Singapore has opened, boasting a streamlined process that halves production time and man-hours required for every tonne of steel fabricated. The 120,000 sqm facility features computerized systems, mechanized equipment, and high-capacity cranes, increasing its tonnage capacity by three times that of its existing yard. The facility aims to enhance automation and productivity, positioning SembMarine as a one-stop shop for offshore and marine engineering solutions, and supporting the company's transformation into a high-tech production hub.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns of potentially lower-than-expected H2 revenue and similar operating losses to the first half, citing market headwinds. London's Heathrow is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continue a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Is Jumbo Group's IPO worth a bite?
summary: Jumbo Group's initial public offering (IPO) has sparked interest in the market, despite its relatively low dividend yield and valuation multiple. The company's strong operating margins and solid free cash flow over three financial years make it an attractive option. However, sustaining this performance while expanding overseas is crucial for its success. Analysts are cautiously optimistic about the IPO, viewing it as a potentially appetizing addition to the dry listing market this year.

site_title: An off-site revolution
summary: Construction SMEs adopt new technologies to save costs and boost productivity. A specialist centre, Royal Healthcare, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz's control. Researchers at NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its Orchard campus up for sale. An otah business rebrands heritage for the younger generation, while Munchi Pancakes modernizes traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'. Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: The Peak names 10 women in annual Power List
summary: The Peak magazine has named 10 Singapore women as game-changers in their respective professions, including Chew Gek Khim, Chong Ee Rong, and Noeleen Heyzer. The list recognizes their achievements in leadership, philanthropy, and social enterprise. This comes as Singapore's listed companies have seen a slight increase in the percentage of women on their boards, from 9.1% in the first half of 2015. The list was compiled in collaboration with the Singapore Institute of International Affairs and Patrick Daniel, editor-in-chief of SPH English/Malay/Tamil Media.

site_title: Capital idea
summary: Corporate venture capital investments by corporate entities into external startups aim to advance strategic objectives and leverage synergies. A specialist centre for Royal Healthcare is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz's acquisition. Researchers at NUS are working on sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve its price. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and selling the building. Chinatown Business Association is seeking S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of outdoor space.

site_title: China's 'hedge fund brother No 1' targeted in insider trading probe
summary: China's "hedge fund brother No 1" XU XIANG, who led Zexi Investment to success, is facing an insider trading probe. Xu, known for his impressive stock market returns, has been detained by police and his office was searched. This comes as China intensifies probes into strategies that may have exacerbated the summer stock market rout. Xu's detention is the latest in a growing list of executives swept up in a crackdown, including those from major brokerages and regulatory officials.

site_title: Amazon opens first physical bookstore
summary: Amazon has opened its first physical bookstore, Amazon Books, in Seattle's University Village. The store integrates online and offline book shopping, offering thousands of books in-store and millions more online. Prices will be identical, and customers can use the mobile application to read reviews and purchase items. The store also sells Amazon-branded devices, such as the Kindle and Echo. This marks a significant shift for Amazon, which has led the bookselling industry's shift to the internet.

site_title: Shipping braces for green tax after Paris talks
summary: The shipping industry expects a carbon levy due to growing momentum from climate talks in Paris, which may lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. The industry, responsible for 90% of world trade, would face increased costs due to the tax. A market-based mechanism or fuel-use levy is likely to be implemented, adding to the industry's rising expenses.

site_title: Xi sees annual growth of no less than 6.5% in next 5 years
summary: China's President Xi Jinping announced a 5-year economic plan, aiming for annual growth of no less than 6.5% to achieve a "moderately prosperous" society by 2020. The plan includes increasing the yuan's convertibility, promoting overseas investment, and boosting consumption. Authorities will also accelerate financial system reform, reduce income gaps, and step up poverty reduction efforts. The goal is to double 2010 GDP and per capita income by 2020, with a focus on sustainable growth and structural changes.

site_title: A concert hall recital - without a player
summary: The Steinway Spirio is a technologically advanced "player piano" that can replay the music of great pianists, down to each key stroke and pedal motion, in the comfort and privacy of a home. The piano uses proprietary software that translates audio recordings into data, capturing nuances and complexity. It features a large and expanding catalogue, with over 1,000 titles, and can be controlled via a complimentary iPad. The Spirio is available in two models, priced at S$218,000 and S$183,000, and offers a unique way for music lovers to enjoy piano music without needing a live pianist.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Toyota, Chrysler report robust October US auto sales
summary: Toyota and Chrysler reported robust October US auto sales, with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles predicting annualized sales of over 18 million vehicles, exceeding analyst expectations. Fiat Chrysler sold 195,545 vehicles, a 14.7% increase from last year, marking its 67th straight month of year-over-year gains.

site_title: Forbes family sues Chinese majority stakeholder investors
summary: The Forbes family is suing Chinese investors, Hong Kong-based Integrated Whale Media Investments, for allegedly failing to pay a majority stake in Forbes Media, valued at $475 million in 2014. The family claims the investors refused to make full payments, prompting a lawsuit filed in a Maryland court. Integrated Whale has rejected the charges as baseless and without merit. The lawsuit follows a deal in which the Forbes family lent money to the investors to finance the acquisition.

site_title: Volkswagen denies fresh US allegations of emissions fraud
summary: Volkswagen denies US allegations of emissions fraud, stating that no software has been installed to cheat on emissions tests for new models, including the Porsche Cayenne. The US Environmental Protection Agency claims that some 2014-2016 VW, Audi, and Porsche models with 3.0-litre engines have equipment to turn off emissions systems when driven on actual roads. Volkswagen faces potential fines of up to $18 billion and further costs from lawsuits. The company will cooperate with the EPA to clarify the matter, but the conflict could prolong the emissions scandal.

site_title: US: Stocks dip at open
summary: US stocks opened lower, with the Dow Jones falling 29.80 points to 17,798.96. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the S&P 500 down 6.52 points to 2,097.53 and the Nasdaq down 15.73 points to 5,111.42. AIG fell 4.1% after reporting a third-quarter loss, and investors are anticipating a period of consolidation in the broader market, according to Briefing.com analyst Patrick O'Hare.

site_title: F&N denies reports of its bid for Vinamilk stake
summary: Frasers & Neave (F&N) has denied reports that it submitted a $4 billion bid to buy the State Capital Investment Corporation's (SCIC's) 45.1% stake in Vietnam Dairy Product Joint Stock Company (Vinamilk). The SCIC stake, valued at around $2.8 billion, is part of Vietnam's government divestment plans. Despite F&N's denial, Vinamilk's shares hit an all-time high before easing, following reports that analysts see the firm as an attractive buy due to its "good business results" and "promising prospects".

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hafary profit falls 27% in quarter ended Sept on higher expenses
summary: Hafary Holdings reported a 27% decline in net profit to S$2.4 million for the quarter ended September, due to higher expenses eating into margins. Revenue rose 14.4% to S$30.9 million, but profit before tax fell 21.8% to S$3.1 million. The company attributed the decline to increased purchase and related expenses. Despite this, Hafary remains optimistic about market opportunities and expects average construction demand to be between S$27 billion and S$36 billion in 2016.

site_title: Thailand offers more tax benefits to speed up investment projects
summary: Thailand's finance minister has approved more tax incentives to accelerate private investment projects, aiming to boost the sluggish economy. The incentives include tax exemptions and deductions for projects approved by the Board of Investment, with the goal of spurring investments and faster growth. The new measures also reduce the time for public-private partnership projects to nine months from nearly two years. The private sector welcomes the step, expecting it to benefit the country's economy, which is expected to grow 2.7% this year.

site_title: Bhutan's happiness index edges up but PM not too pleased
summary: Bhutan's Gross National Happiness (GNH) index has increased, with people reporting higher levels of happiness and better sleep quality compared to five years ago. The index, launched in 2010, measures social wellbeing indicators beyond conventional GDP, including leisure time and forest cover. The positive trend is attributed to the country's focus on quality-of-life factors. However, the Prime Minister's reaction to the news was not available, suggesting a possible disconnect between the government's policy goals and the reported increase in happiness. The exact details of the Prime Minister's reaction are not specified in the article.

site_title: Goldman Sachs cut exposure to oil and gas companies last quarter
summary: Goldman Sachs reduced its exposure to oil and gas companies in the last quarter, bringing its total exposure below $12 billion for the first time since 2014. The firm's market exposure was negative $243 million at the end of September, down from $482 million three months earlier. This move comes amid a decline in oil prices, which have fallen 41% in the past year, and significant writedowns reported by oil and gas producers. Goldman Sachs' lending risk to non-investment-grade companies was $4.4 billion, with $1.6 billion in funded loans.

site_title: China to gradually scrap quota limit for inbound and outbound investment
summary: China plans to gradually scrap quota limits for inbound and outbound investment over the next five years, according to a ruling Communist Party communique. The move aims to increase investment flexibility and promote economic growth. This reform follows a high-level policy meeting to set the country's 13th Five-Year Plan. The decision is expected to raise pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is set to slow.

site_title: Standard Chartered being investigated in Britain: CEO
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is investigating Standard Chartered, the bank's CEO said, amid ongoing sanctions compliance and anti-money laundering oversight. The investigations, ongoing since 2015, are related to past sanctions violations and a $300 million US fine in 2014. The bank has cooperated fully and is raising $5.1 billion in capital to cut 15,000 jobs and return to growth.

site_title: Strong rental reversion, acquisition jack up Fortune Reit Q3 DPU
summary: Fortune Reit reported a 12% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 11.54 Hong Kong cents for the third quarter, driven by a 12.9% increase in revenue to HK$470.45 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate stood at 98% and a 21.8% rental reversion was achieved from renewed leases. Despite economic uncertainties, the Reit's portfolio of private housing estate retail properties is expected to maintain a resilient performance.

site_title: 'Iron Lady' Thatcher's personal effects to go on sale
summary: Margaret Thatcher's personal effects, including 350 items accumulated during her 11 years in Downing Street, are to be sold in London next month by Christie's auction house. The items include famous handbags and jewelry, with an emerald and diamond necklace expected to fetch £120,000-£180,000. Proceeds will be split between Thatcher's children and grandchildren. The sales take place 25 years after Thatcher left office, offering collectors a chance to acquire items from the longest-serving UK prime minister in the 20th century.

site_title: Singapore's PMI contracts again, at 48.9 in Oct
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 48.9 in October, marking a contraction in the manufacturing sector for the second consecutive month. This was in line with expectations. The PMI rose 0.3 point from the previous month, but remains below the 50-point mark. Contractions in new orders, new export orders, and production output contributed to the decline, with inventory recording its first-time contraction. The electronics PMI also fell to 48.6, lower than forecast.

site_title: China says annual growth no less than 6.5% over next five years
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country's annual economic growth will be no less than 6.5% over the next five years to reach its goal of doubling its 2010 GDP and per capita income by 2020.

site_title: S&P may cut credit grades of biggest US banks
summary: Standard & Poor's may cut credit grades of eight top US banks, including JP Morgan Chase & Co, Bank of America Corp, and Citigroup Inc, due to reduced government support in a crisis. The firms are under review for senior unsecured and nondeferrable subordinated debt ratings and may face increased borrowing costs and collateral requirements. The move follows the Federal Reserve's approval of a rule requiring banks to hold debt convertible into equity, reducing the government's role in supporting systemically important institutions.

site_title: Swiss start enforcement actions against banks over Petrobras scandal
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma has initiated enforcement actions against three banks over their failure to prevent money laundering following an investigation into the Petrobras graft scandal. The probe, which began in September, found shortcomings in the implementation of money-laundering regulations at the banks. Finma will investigate these shortcomings and impose penalties, but details will be announced after the cases are resolved. The enforcement actions follow Swiss authorities' collaboration with Brazil on the investigation, which has also led to the freezing of $400 million and the return of $120 million to Brazil.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 13.49 points to 1,677.56, driven by a 521-357 gainers-to-losers ratio. The market saw significant trading volume of 2.8 billion lots valued at RM2.3 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong, Singapore rise in global finance secrecy rankings
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore have improved their ranking for financial secrecy, with Hong Kong rising to number two and Singapore to fourth in a 2015 index compiled by the Tax Justice Network. Both cities have failed to implement sufficient reforms to their corporate secrecy regimes, lacking country-by-country reporting and public registries of beneficial ownership. The Tax Justice Network criticizes their lack of progress in addressing financial secrecy issues.

site_title: StanChart CEO says no plan to review HQ location
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters stated that the bank has no plans to review its London headquarters, prioritizing its restructuring efforts instead. The bank is raising $5.1 billion in new capital and cutting 15,000 jobs as part of its turnaround plan. Winters cited the UK's predictability and pragmatic business environment as reasons for staying put, contrasting with rival HSBC's consideration of relocating.

site_title: Tech boom eases world stocks to 2-1/2 month high
summary: World stocks reached a 2-1/2 month high on Tuesday, driven by a 15-year high for tech stocks on the Nasdaq. The Nasdaq's milestone helped Europe's FTSEurofirst dip 0.1%, despite a 1% gain in Asia. The MSCI's 45-country All World index remained in positive territory. Tech firms' earnings were deemed "ok" this quarter, and China's President Xi Jinping's statement on growth helped bolster the mood.

site_title: Indonesian consumers optimistic about the next six months: central bank survey
summary: Indonesian consumers showed optimism in the next six months, with a consumer confidence index of 99.3 in October, up from 97.5 in September, the lowest since February 2009. A reading above 100 indicates optimism. This improvement follows previous pessimistic months, suggesting a slight recovery in consumer sentiment.

site_title: SGX sets up Chicago hub to improve access for North American customers
summary: SGX sets up a new hub in Chicago to improve access for North American customers, offering direct connectivity to its equity, foreign exchange, and commodities future contracts. The SGX Chicago Hub will be located at the CME Group's co-location facility in Aurora, Illinois. This move aims to bring investors in North America closer to Asia's markets, solidifying SGX's role as the world's largest offshore market for Asian equity index futures.

site_title: GSK aims to file up to 20 new drugs for approval by 2020
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) aims to file up to 20 new drugs for approval by 2020 as part of efforts to revitalize its portfolio. The company highlighted projects in respiratory medicine, immunology, and rare diseases. This move follows falling sales of its best-selling inhaled lung treatment Advair. GSK's first research and development day in over a decade aims to boost investor expectations for its product pipeline.

site_title: Thailand extends tax incentives for long-term equity investment: finmin
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved extending tax incentives for long-term-equity funds (LTFs) for three more years, from 2016, to revive the flagging stock market and boost domestic savings. The incentives allow taxpayers to deduct up to 15% of their income or 500,000 baht for investment in LTFs, with a holding period of seven calendar years instead of five. The move aims to attract investors and stimulate the economy.

site_title: Multi-faceted solution needed to tackle transboundary haze: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan emphasizes the need for a multi-faceted solution to tackle transboundary haze in Southeast Asia. The haze, caused by widespread forest fires, has impaired millions of people's health and damaged the regional economy. Balakrishnan calls for intensified regional and international cooperation to hold accountable companies responsible for the destruction, and for a price to be paid for environmental damage. He cites the loss of over 2 million hectares of forest and 1.6 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere as a result of these actions.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
A multi-faceted solution is needed to tackle transboundary haze, Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Vivian Balakrishnan, said on Tuesday.

site_title: Update: China's Xi says 6.5% annual growth enough to meet goals: Xinhua
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that a 6.5% annual growth rate for 2016-2020 will meet the country's wealth goals, aiming to double GDP per capita by the end of the decade. This target is part of achieving a "moderately prosperous society" by the 100th anniversary of the Communist Party's foundation. The growth rate is a reduction from the current "around 7%" target, and some economists consider it unattainable. The comments come as China's economy transitions to a more modest pace, dubbed the "new normal," amid economic turbulence and market reforms.

site_title: Malaysia's image needs restoring, says PM's brother
