summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing a crisis over the 1MDB scandal, which has led to widespread protests and concerns over foreign investment. His brother, Nazir Razak, chairman of CIMB bank, says the government's reputation for political stability is at risk and that restoring confidence is crucial. The scandal has damaged Malaysia's image and led to a 18.5% decline in the ringgit currency this year, with Nazir calling for swift investigations and transparency to clear up the mess.

site_title: S.Korea's economy, inflation moving as forecast: Bank of Korea minutes
summary: South Korea's economy and inflation are moving as forecast, according to the Bank of Korea's monetary policy board minutes. A member stated that the economy and inflation are "currently moving not far from the path that was previously forecast" and that the dangers of changing interest rates are increasing. The link between financial conditions and the real economy is weakening.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on bank relief rally, RBA hints room for easing
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Tuesday, driven by a bank relief rally and a Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) hint at a possible rate cut. The RBA maintained its cash rate at 2.0% amid subdued inflation, indicating room for further easing to support the economy. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index reached a new record high.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets remained flat at the open, with the FTSE 100 index rising 0.03% to 6,363.60 points, while the Paris CAC 40 increased 0.08% to 4,920.02 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.05% to 10,945.35 points. The flat opening comes as investors await updates on US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Europe's major stock markets flattened in opening deals on Tuesday, with London's benchmark FTSE 100 index adding a marginal 0.03 per cent to 6,363.60 points.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng Q3 net profit almost triples on currency gains
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q3 net profit nearly tripled to S$9.4 million, driven by a S$4.7 million gain from currency translation, offsetting a 4.6% decline in revenue to S$109.5 million. The company expects food and beverage margins to come under pressure due to competitive selling prices and higher initial operating costs. Despite this, overall performance is expected to remain satisfactory.

site_title: UBS says it has 'received inquiries' over Fifa banking links
summary: Swiss banking giant UBS has received inquiries from authorities over its links to FIFA, amid the corruption scandal rocking football's world body. The bank is cooperating with these inquiries, similar to Credit Suisse, which acknowledged last week it was being probed. UBS stated that it has received inquiries about accounts related to FIFA and other soccer associations, and is cooperating with authorities.

site_title: UBS names new CFO in raft of top management changes
summary: UBS announced a series of top management changes, effective January 1, 2016. Tom Naratil will shift roles as president of UBS's wealth management business in the Americas and president of UBS Americas, while Kirt Gardner will take over as group CFO. These changes come after UBS reported a bigger-than-expected year-on-year rise in third-quarter net profit.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Standard Chartered axes 15,000 jobs, raising $5.1 billion in capital, amid a "disappointing" third-quarter loss. Singapore and China are set to sign high-level agreements during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit. Consumer confidence in Singapore rose in Q3, while Olam International Ltd secured a $1 billion loan from 19 global banks. The Straits Times Index rebounded 25.15 points on Tuesday after five straight days of losses.

site_title: China: Stocks close down, trading volume 1-mth low
summary: China's stocks closed down 0.3% on Tuesday in thin trading, with the CSI300 index falling to 3,465.49 points. Trading volume hit a one-month low, with 19.2 billion shares traded in Shanghai and 22.4 billion shares traded in Shenzhen. Investors are cautious ahead of the Chinese Communist Party's 13th-five year plan, which is expected to outline policy priorities. Key stocks fell, including Meiyan Jixiang, Agricultural Bank Of China, and Jiangnan Fiber.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher after five straight days of losses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rebounded 25.15 points to 2,999.56 on Tuesday, ending five straight days of losses. The index rose in line with an overnight Wall Street rally and gains in Hong Kong and China. Banks DBS and Macquarie Warrants led the gains, while Maybank Kim Eng called a "sell" on DBS. Turnover was low, with 1.3 billion units worth S$880.3 million traded, and 265 rises versus 140 falls were recorded.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won close higher, helped by autos
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.7% to 2,048.40 points, driven by stronger-than-expected October sales from automakers Hyundai and Kia, which jumped 2.5% and 4.7%, respectively. The South Korean won also gained 0.3% against the dollar. The gains came amid hopes for another wave of stimulus after weak global manufacturing data.

site_title: China's biggest challenge is negotiating middle income gap: state planner
summary: China's top economic planner, Xu Shaoshi, stated that the country's biggest challenge in the next five years is negotiating the middle income gap. China aims to achieve its targets set out in the 12th five-year plan, which runs from 2011 to 2015. The 13th five-year plan, finalized by the Communist Party, aims to address the middle income gap and promote economic and social development between 2016 and 2020. Xu expressed confidence in China's ability to meet its targets, but the issue of the middle income gap remains a significant challenge for policymakers.

site_title: UOB Venture Management invests in Taiwan startup Appier's Series B round
summary: UOB Venture Management invested in Appier's US$23 million Series B round, joining Sequoia India, JAFCO Asia, TransLink Capital, and MediaTek Ventures. Appier, a Taiwan-based AI startup, uses AI to predict consumer behavior across screens, enabling enterprises to reach consumers effectively. CEO Chih-Han Yu stated that AI is crucial for resolving cross-screen complexity and solving analytical problems, with advertising being just the beginning.

site_title: Fortune Reit posts 12% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: Fortune Reit reported a 12% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the third quarter, reaching 11.54 Hong Kong cents, driven by a 12.9% increase in revenue to HK$470.45 million and 14.7% increase in net property income to HK$328.9 million, largely due to strong rental reversion and additional income from acquired Laguna Plaza.

site_title: BMW has surprise Q3 profit gain on Europe recovery
summary: BMW posted a surprise 4.3% increase in third-quarter operating profit to €2.354 billion, driven by strong sales in European core markets. The company reaffirmed its goal of beating last year's record 2.12 million sales, citing a 6.9% sales increase in Europe. However, BMW cited headwinds including heightened competition, upfront spending, and rising personnel costs, leading some analysts to express a lack of optimism for 2016. The company still expects a profit margin of 8-10% in the automotive division this year.

site_title: Flights to and from Bali, including 2 with Singapore, cancelled over volcanic ash cloud
summary: Flights to and from Bali, including two with Singapore, have been cancelled due to a volcanic ash cloud from Mount Rinjani in Lombok. Airlines such as Jetstar and Virgin have labelled conditions at Denpasar Airport as "unsafe for flying." The cancellations follow assessments from the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up, buoyed by global markets
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.9% to 22,568.43 on Tuesday, tracking global market gains. The benchmark for US tech stocks reached its highest in 15 years, contributing to the increase. The Hang Seng index and China Enterprises Index also rose 0.4% and 0.9% respectively. Total trading volume was 1.5 billion shares. The gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and come ahead of US GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Former senior Chinese official jailed for 12 years for graft
summary: A Chinese court has sentenced former senior official Li Chongxi to 12 years in prison for corruption charges. Li, a former top aide to disgraced security chief Zhou Yongkang, admitted to his crimes and expressed regret. He used his positions to secure rights for local companies to develop state-owned land and accepted bribes valued at 11.1 million yuan. The conviction is part of China's sweeping anti-corruption campaign launched by President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Activision to buy Candy Crush's maker King in US$5.9b deal
summary: Activision Blizzard agreed to buy King Digital Entertainment for $5.9 billion, unifying console and PC games with mobile game Candy Crush Saga. The deal, valued at 16% premium to King's closing price, is expected to be completed by spring 2016 and boost Activision's estimated non-GAAP revenue and earnings-per-share by 30% in 2016. King will remain an independent unit under Activision, with CEO Riccardo Zacconi continuing to run the company.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine opens SEA's largest steel structure fabrication workshop
summary: Sembcorp Marine has opened the largest steel structure fabrication workshop in South-east Asia, located in Tuas Boulevard, Singapore. The 35-hectare facility utilizes computerized systems and equipment to optimize production efficiency, reducing man-hours and production time by half. The new workshop aims to increase production capacity and improve overall efficiency.

site_title: Australian dollar climbs, falls back, after RBA decison
summary: The Australian dollar initially rose above 72 US cents after the Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates at a record low of 2.00% on Tuesday, but later fell back. The decision was as expected, with no changes to the rate. The Aussie touched a three-week low last week and was steady at US$0.7170.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence on the rise in Q3: Nielsen
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence rose in Q3, reaching 101 points, the highest in South-east Asia, according to Nielsen's Global Survey of Consumer Confidence and Spending. This places Singapore as the 12th most optimistic country globally. The survey measures perceptions of job prospects, finances, and spending intentions, with a score above 100 indicating optimism.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: In rare appearance, Larry Page discusses new Alphabet structure
summary: Larry Page, Google co-founder and Alphabet CEO, discussed the company's new structure in a rare public appearance. He compared it to a venture capital firm and Berkshire Hathaway, citing its ability to innovate with large resources. The new structure will operate like a venture capital firm, with aspects similar to Berkshire Hathaway. Page also addressed Google's efforts in China and delegated questions to Sundar Pichai, the new Google CEO. He showcased projects such as Project Loon, a plan to deliver Internet service from connected air balloons.

site_title: US to operate 'wherever' law allows in South China Sea
summary: US Admiral Harry Harris reaffirmed the country's commitment to operate in the South China Sea "wherever international law allows," amid China's construction of artificial islands. Harris stated that international seas and airspace belong to everyone, and the US will not be deterred by China's claims. The US has been conducting "routine freedom of navigation operations" in the region, which has sparked tensions between the two nations. Despite warnings from China, the US has maintained a strong stance, with the chief of US naval operations speaking with his Chinese counterpart via video, and countries in the region seeking to intensify security cooperation with the US.

site_title: GIC in talks with India-based app Little on possible funding: report
summary: GIC is in talks with India-based app Little for a potential US$50-million financing round. This comes after Little raised US$50 million in July from Paytm, Alibaba-backed Tiger Global, and SAIF Partners. The discussions are ongoing, with GIC looking to invest a significant amount in the company, which has also received backing from Flipkart. Little's chief Manish Chopra declined to comment, while a GIC spokesperson did not respond to an email.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Saudi non-oil business growth slows to record low in October
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector experienced its lowest growth rate since 2009, with a seasonally adjusted Emirates NBD Purchasing Managers' Index of 55.7 in October, down from 56.5 in September. The country's low oil prices are contributing to a huge state budget deficit, estimated at over $100 billion this year. The government has implemented spending cuts, while borrowing to finance the deficit is increasing money market interest rates. Despite this, the non-oil sector's growth rate is still relatively robust, with overall GDP growth expected to be supported by higher oil production.

site_title: South Korea central bank to keep easy stance but wary of household debt, Fed hike
summary: South Korea's central bank plans to maintain an easy monetary policy stance, keeping interest rates at a record low 1.50% due to steady economic recovery and low inflation. However, the bank remains wary of household debt levels and external risks, such as the US Federal Reserve's policy changes. The Bank of Korea will closely monitor these risks and act to rein in debt should it pose financial stability concerns. The bank's accommodative policy is expected to support economic growth, but may lead to limited increases in market interest rates.

site_title: Japan's lofty 'hydrogen society' vision hampered by cost
summary: Japan aims to become a "hydrogen society" with homes and fuel-cell cars powered by emissions-free energy, but high costs and convenience concerns are hindering the plan. The government has set a goal of a hydrogen market worth 1 trillion yen annually by 2030, with plans to equip 1.4 million residences with hydrogen-producing technology by 2020. However, production has lagged behind demand, and the technology remains out of reach for many due to high costs, with only 100,000 houses currently powered. Environmental concerns and the need for renewable energy sources to produce green hydrogen also pose challenges to the ambitious plan.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.16% on Tuesday, reaching 3,008.82 points, following a higher close in US and European markets. The top traded stocks included DBS, Noble, Singtel, UOB, and OCBC Bank.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by positive business surveys, Commerzbank
summary: European shares rose 0.3-0.5% on Monday, boosted by positive business surveys and Commerzbank's better-than-expected results, reversing early losses. The ECB expressed readiness to maintain inflation targets, lifting investor confidence. Greek shares surged, with the ATG index up 3.1%, following the release of ECB stress test results showing Greek banks had a lower capital shortfall than expected. Commerzbank rose 6.6% after announcing its first dividend payment in 8 years, while HSBC fell 0.8% despite a 32% increase in pretax profit.

site_title: Asian currencies gain against US dollar
summary: Asian currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars, gained against the US dollar in cautious trading ahead of key economic data from the US. Investors are paring back their long US dollar positions, helping Asian currencies rise. The US dollar retreated in Singapore trade, with the Singapore dollar trading at 1.3524. The Australian dollar rose 0.01% to US$0.7148, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.21% to US$0.6758. The Fed's next move on interest rates will be influenced by the US data, which could set the tone for speculation on future rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore, China to sign high-level agreements during Xi's visit
summary: Singapore and China are set to sign high-level agreements during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit on Nov 6-7, including a third government-to-government project and an upgraded bilateral free trade agreement. Details on education, customs, and finance industry agreements are also expected to be released. These agreements aim to strengthen bilateral ties and promote cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: China: Stocks up in early trading
summary: China stocks rose on Tuesday morning, tracking global market gains despite weak domestic manufacturing data. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.16% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.27%, while the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rose 1.01%. The gains came despite China's manufacturing data showing a decline.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up following gains in US tech share markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.0% to 8,700.98, driven by gains in US tech shares, including TSMC and Hon Hai Precision. The Nasdaq 100 closed at its highest level in over 15 years, boosting Taiwanese technology shares. The electronics subindex rose 1.1% and the financials subindex gained 1.1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.400 per US dollar.

site_title: Update: Standard Chartered axes 15,000 jobs, announces US$5.1b capital raise
summary: Standard Chartered is cutting 15,000 jobs as part of a restructuring plan that will cost around $3 billion. The bank posted a "disappointing" third-quarter loss and is raising $5.1 billion in capital to return to growth. The job losses are part of a major restructuring effort to address the bank's struggles. The bank's spokeswoman declined to provide further details on the job cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Chinese stocks halt losing streak on global outlook
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1% on Tuesday, halting a five-day losing streak, led by commodity producers. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index advanced to 10,344.39, driven by gains from Jiangxi Copper Co and China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. The rebound follows US equities recouping losses from China's yuan devaluation and signs of resilience in manufacturing. This marks a 14% rebound from a September low, as the government introduces measures to boost growth amid the slowest economic expansion in a quarter of a century.

site_title: Australia extends rate pause as economy rebalances from mining
summary: Australia's central bank extended its interest-rate pause for a sixth month, keeping the cash rate at 2% as the economy rebalances away from mining. The decision was made as the Australian dollar declined 30% in three years, boosting competitiveness of local industries. Reserve Bank Governor Glenn Stevens cited encouraging signs in the economy, including a weaker currency and potential US interest rate hikes in December, as justification for the rate decision.

site_title: Standard Chartered set to raise £3.3 billion in rights issue
summary: Standard Chartered is set to raise £3.3 billion in a rights issue to boost its capital ratio, following an unexpected quarterly loss of $139 million. The London-based bank reported a pretax loss, lower than analyst estimates of $903 million. The two-for-seven issue priced at 465 pence per share will increase the lender's common-equity Tier-1 capital ratio to 13.1%. Largest shareholder Temasek Holdings Pte will take up 15.8% of existing share capital. The bank will pay no final dividend for this year.

site_title: Asia: Shares aim to break losing streak
summary: Asian share markets rose on Tuesday, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific index gaining 1.1% after a five-session losing streak. Australian stocks bounced 1.2% and China's CSI300 index remained flat. The US stock market, led by a 1.45% gain in the Nasdaq, ended at its highest close since 2000. Meanwhile, European bonds were pressured by improved economic data and ECB comments on stimulus. The dollar index remained steady, while the Australian dollar held at US$0.7167 ahead of a central bank policy meeting.

site_title: F&N says it has not submitted any offer for SICC's stake in Vinamilk
summary: F&N, a Singapore-listed conglomerate, has denied media reports that it submitted a US$4 billion offer to buy the State Capital Investment Corporation's 45.1% stake in Vietnam Dairy Product Joint Stock Company (Vinamilk). F&N, which holds an 11% stake in Vinamilk, stated that it has not submitted any offer to Vinamilk or SICC regarding a potential purchase of SICC's stake. This comes after reports sparked concerns about a potential takeover of the dairy company.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on bank relief rally, rate hold hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% on Tuesday, driven by a bank stocks rally, as investors awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy meeting. Most economists expect the RBA to keep interest rates on hold, boosting the local dollar. Energy stocks also firmed, while Telstra rebounded after a 20% decline since early August. The S&P/ASX 200 index is up 3.3% for the year, outperforming New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won gain on hopes global economy can shake off chill
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by a rise in US orders and stronger-than-expected factory activity in Germany. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 2,044.74 points, with companies sensitive to cyclical economic trends leading the market. The South Korean won also gained 0.2% against the US dollar, following strength in regional currencies. The rally is attributed to hopes that the global economy can shake off the chill, with analysts citing the euro zone's sturdy growth as a potential benefit for South Korea's exports.

site_title: New Zealand commodity prices rise in October
summary: New Zealand's main commodities prices rose 6.9% in October, according to ANZ Bank's commodity price index, driven by rebounding dairy prices. This marks the second consecutive monthly increase. On an annual basis, the index fell 11.8%, a decline from a 18.2% drop in the previous month.

site_title: One man's plan to build Singapore in India sends land soaring
summary: India's Andhra Pradesh state is building a new capital city, Amaravati, to replace Hyderabad, which is being divided. The city will be a high-tech metropolis, rivaling Singapore, with a planned area of 212 square kilometers. Chief Minister N. Chandrababu Naidu secured land from farmers through a promise of annual payments and infrastructure guarantees. The project aims to be completed by 2019, but faces funding challenges, with estimates suggesting a cost of 250 billion rupees. The project's success is seen as crucial for India's economic growth, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi backing the initiative.

site_title: Dell eyes US$10 billion asset sales ahead of EMC merger: sources
summary: Dell plans to sell around $10 billion in non-core assets, including Quest Software, SonicWall, and AppAssure, to reduce its debt load ahead of the $67 billion merger with EMC Corp. The divestitures will not include Dell's hardware assets. The combined company aims to achieve an investment-grade credit rating within 18-24 months by reducing debt. Dell is contributing $4.25 billion in equity to the deal, and the transaction is expected to close between May and October 2016.

site_title: Over 40 per cent of China's online sales counterfeit, shoddy: Xinhua
summary: More than 40% of goods sold online in China last year were either counterfeit or of poor quality, according to an official report by Xinhua news agency. This highlights the ongoing issue of counterfeiting and shoddy products in the country's fast-growing online sector. The report calls for accelerated legislation, improved supervision, and clearer consumer rights to address the problem, which has grown 40% to 2.8 trillion yuan in online sales last year.

site_title: 'Super-agers' study may reveal secrets to staying young
summary: A US$3.2 million study is underway to uncover the secrets of "super-agers" - individuals who remain sharp and healthy into old age. Mary Helen Abbott, 77, is part of the study and defies traditional retirement home stereotypes with her active lifestyle. Abbott, who still smokes and wears revealing clothing, attributes her longevity to a combination of factors, including her social connections, physical activity, and attitude. The study aims to identify the common traits and habits of super-agers, potentially revealing the key to a longer, healthier life.

images.alt_text: Mary Helen Abbott, 77, paints her lips bright pink, still smokes the occasional cigarette, keeps up on all the gossip at the retirement home and wears a short skirt to fitness class.

site_title: Exchange losses hit Q1 bottom line for China Minzhong
summary: China Minzhong Food Corp reported a net profit of 15.5 million yuan (S$1.2 million) for Q1 FY16, down 73% due to higher exchange losses. Revenue dipped 4% year-over-year to 467.7 million yuan, primarily affected by its beverage business segment. Gross profit declined 7.6% to 118.1 million yuan, with overall gross profit margins falling to 25.3%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia ahead of US crude inventories report
summary: Oil prices in Asia rose ahead of US crude inventories data, with West Texas Intermediate up 16 US cents at $46.30 and Brent crude up 11 US cents at $48.90. Analysts expect the data to show rising commercial crude stockpiles, indicating weaker demand in the US. The global crude supply glut continues to depress prices, with oil prices more than 50% lower from their peak in June 2014. A global economic slowdown, led by China, and high oil production from Russia also contribute to the glut.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rebounded in Asia on Tuesday, buoyed by bargain hunting ahead of the release of US government data that will gauge crude demand in the world's biggest economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1 point to 1665.07 on Tuesday, with 138 gainers outpacing 40 losers. The index opened higher, with 41.4 million lots traded worth RM14.6 million.

site_title: Google aims to begin drone package deliveries in 2017
summary: Google's Project Wing plans to begin drone package deliveries in 2017, with the goal of having commercial business up and running by then. The company is in talks with the Federal Aviation Administration to set up an air traffic control system for drones. Alphabet's Project Wing is working with NASA and other stakeholders to develop a drone registry and system for identifying drone operators. The company aims to carve out low-altitude "Class G" airspace for drones, keeping them away from manned aircraft.

site_title: South Korea Oct inflation hits 11-mth high as consumption recovers
summary: South Korea's annual inflation rose 0.9% in October, the highest in 11 months, as consumption recovered. This beat expectations and suggests inflation is starting to leave its low point. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel, also accelerated to 2.3%. The Bank of Korea is unlikely to cut interest rates soon, according to economists, despite recent data showing a firm rebound in private consumption. This supports the central bank's stance, with interest rates likely to remain at 1.50% for the rest of the year.

site_title: SHA encourages hotel industry partners to commit to sustainable sources
summary: The Singapore Hotel Association (SHA) is encouraging its hotel members to commit to sustainable sources for paper and pulp materials, a move welcomed by the Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) and the Singapore Environment Council (SEC). Letters and declaration forms will be sent to hotels to source materials from environmentally friendly suppliers, aiming to combat the haze in the region. This initiative is seen as a step towards reducing the industry's environmental impact.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: M1 to create next-generation data centre with partners
summary: TELCO M1 is partnering with VMware, Palo Alto Networks, and Huawei to implement a next-generation software-defined networking (SDN) technology proof of concept in its cloud-based data centre. This will enable M1 to develop and launch new services more swiftly and with greater flexibility for corporate customers. The SDN technology provides a unified view of the network with central management control, streamlining network planning and service introduction. The goal is to enhance M1's capabilities and agility to serve large enterprises and government agencies.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
TELCO M1 is tying up with VMware, Palo Alto Networks and Huawei to implement a next-generation software-defined networking (SDN) technology proof of concept in its cloud-based data centre.

site_title: News Corp unit REA to acquire iProperty
summary: REA Group, a News Corp unit, has made a takeover offer for iProperty Group, valuing the Australian-listed property site at A$751 million. REA, which already owns 22.7% of iProperty, is offering shareholders either A$4 or a mix of cash and shares. The proposed deal, a scheme of arrangement, has been backed by iProperty's independent directors. The acquisition validates Southeast Asia as a hub for internet companies, with Patrick Grove, iProperty chairman, citing the region's 250 million smartphone users as a major draw.

site_title: Chinese yuan drops after shift by central bank
summary: China's central bank sharply raised the daily yuan reference rate, but the currency dropped instead, falling to 6.3374 yuan per dollar. This move, the largest since 2005, signals the government's commitment to reforms aimed at freeing up yuan trade. Analysts attribute the drop to market expectations of the International Monetary Fund's decision to include the yuan in its Special Drawing Rights basket, set to be made this month. The yuan remains stronger than its pre-August devaluation range.

site_title: EU failing to tackle tax dodging one year after 'LuxLeaks': campaigners
summary: The European Union is failing to tackle tax dodging, one year after the 'LuxLeaks' scandal revealed sweetheart deals between top companies and Luxembourg, allowing them to pay as little as 1% in taxes. Despite EU measures, 28 member states still provide opportunities for multinationals to dodge taxes, with Luxembourg and Germany being the worst offenders. Campaigners say the EU system remains complex and dysfunctional, with new loopholes emerging, and citizens have yet to see significant action.

site_title: Ecuador ordered to pay US$1b to US oil firm Oxy
summary: Ecuador has been ordered to pay US$1 billion to US oil firm Occidental Petroleum (Oxy) by a World Bank arbitration panel for cancelling a contract. The ruling comes after Oxy sued Ecuador for US$3.37 billion in 2006. Ecuador's President Rafael Correa condemned the lawsuit, but welcomed the reduced damages. The ICSID, a World Bank branch, has yet to publish the full ruling, which also claims Ecuador violated a bilateral investment treaty with the US. The decision adds to Ecuador's budget woes amid falling crude prices and a depreciating currency.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East H-Trust, SingPost, SIAEC, China Minzhong, Penguin Int'l
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported lower distribution per stapled security (DPSS) of 1.2 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Sept 30, down from 1.32 cents a year ago. Gross revenue slipped 4.8% year on year due to lower revenue from hotels and serviced residences, impacted by corporate travel softness and a strong Singapore dollar.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Lower DPSS for Far East H-Trust in Q3
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) reported a 4.8% year-over-year decline in gross revenue to S$29.66 million for the third quarter, mainly due to lower revenue from hotels and serviced residences. Net property income also fell 4.6% to S$26.89 million. The company's distribution per stapled security (DPSS) decreased to 1.2 Singapore cents, down from 1.32 cents a year ago. Despite this, the trust remains optimistic about Singapore's tourism prospects.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Project seeks to develop more effective marine coatings
summary: Assistant Professor Ali Miserez from Nanyang Technological University is leading a project to develop more effective marine coatings. The project, funded by the Singapore Maritime Institute, aims to understand how marine organisms stick to solid structures at the molecular scale and replicate this adhesion using bio-inspired materials. The goal is to create coatings that prevent fouling, reducing the weight and friction of boats, and subsequently decreasing fuel consumption and greenhouse emissions, estimated to cost the global shipping industry S$40 billion annually.

site_title: Fitbit announces early lockup expiration, stock offering
summary: Fitbit Inc announced an early lockup expiration and a 21 million-share stock offering, sending its shares down 10% in extended trading. The company lifted lockup restrictions on over 2 million shares, ahead of the original schedule, as it tries to attract more corporate customers. Fitbit forecast a profit of 20-25 cents per share and revenue of $620-650 million for the fourth quarter, beating analyst expectations. Despite strong results, the company's shares declined due to the stock offering.

site_title: Oil prices dip on Chinese, Russian data
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday due to China's manufacturing output continuing to contract and Russian oil production hitting a new record high. The weakening demand outlook and increased supply led to a global oil oversupply, pushing prices lower by more than 50% since mid-2014. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for December closed at $46.14 a barrel, down 45 cents from Friday's settlement, and Brent North Sea crude fell 77 cents to $48.79. Experts attribute the decline to a bearish market sentiment and a lack of urgency to sell despite news from China, Russia, and Iran.

site_title: China forex regulator tells staff to take graft fight seriously
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator has urged its officials to take seriously the Communist Party's fight against corruption and follow rules closely. The State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) has emphasized the importance of fighting corruption, advising officials to be aware of their limitations and adhere to standards of behavior. This comes as President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption crackdown continues, with dozens of senior officials investigated or jailed since 2012. The regulator's internal discipline team has issued guidelines for officials to follow, emphasizing the need to "keep a clear head" and resist temptations.

site_title: Coming: An app that serves as eyes for the blind
summary: IBM Research and Carnegie Mellon University are developing an app called NavCog to help the visually impaired navigate their surroundings. The app uses Bluetooth beacons, phone sensors, and computer vision to provide turn-by-turn directions, identifying users' location, direction, and surrounding environment. The platform is open-source, allowing developers to build enhancements and speed its rollout to other environments. The goal is to make the system accessible to any environment, including those without Bluetooth beacons, and eventually expand its capabilities to include facial recognition, emotion recognition, and ultrasonic technology.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Tuesday
summary: Japan's financial markets closed on Tuesday due to a national holiday. Meanwhile, global markets continued their rally, with Singapore stocks rising for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. In Asia, traders brushed off new US President Trump threats to extend their stocks rally. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, while Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Adele breaks record with million song downloads
summary: Adele broke a record with her song "Hello" becoming the first track to download over 1 million times in a week in the US. The song, from her upcoming album 25, opened at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and was streamed 20.4 million times. This surpasses previous records held by Flo Rida and Justin Bieber. Adele's album 25 is expected to be a major release, potentially rivaling Taylor Swift's 1989 album.

images.alt_text: Adele on Monday shattered a record with her long-awaited song Hello, which became the first track downloaded more than one million times in a week in the United States.

site_title: Hyundai Heavy expects earnings to improve soon
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries Co, the world's largest shipbuilder, expects to improve fourth-quarter earnings due to the completion of ship construction projects and a reduction in potential losses from order cancellations. The company's shipbuilding backlog now consists of completed ships, and most projects are expected to be finished by next year. Despite a decline in oil prices and resulting payment delays, Hyundai Heavy aims to meet its target of $14.3 billion in shipbuilding contracts this year. The company's shares have declined 19% since the start of the year.

site_title: Ex-chief of Pheim Singapore back to lead company
summary: Veteran fund manager Tan Chong Koay has been re-appointed as CEO and executive director of Pheim Asset Management (Asia) by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) after serving a three-year ban for his involvement in a 2004 case of window dressing shares of United Envirotech. The MAS approved his re-appointment after he completed his probation period. Pheim has consistently outperformed in its respective categories, with a cumulative return of 497.3% over a 20-year period.

images.alt_text: Ven Sreenivasan

site_title: China economic imperatives: social stability, urbanisation, internationalisation of yuan
summary: China's 13th five-year plan has set a lower GDP growth rate, potentially between 6.5% and 7%, sparking concerns about job creation. However, the true economic imperatives for China are social stability, internationalisation of the yuan, and urbanisation. Achieving social stability requires addressing widening income disparity and ethnic tensions, while internationalising the yuan is crucial for global confidence. Urbanisation efforts, such as the One Belt One Road initiative, can close the income gap and create a middle-income class, driving the economy towards domestic growth.

site_title: US dollar adrift in calm seas; Australian dollar eyes RBA squall
summary: The US dollar remained stable, trading between 96.635 and 96.965, while the euro hovered between US$1.1000 and US$1.1053. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7145 ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate review on Tuesday, where a decision to hold or cut is uncertain, with a 50-50 chance of a rate cut implied by debt markets.

images.alt_text: The dollar, euro and yen started trade on Tuesday in familiar territory, having shuffled sideways as uninspired traders waited for bigger fish to fry after the latest readings on global manufacturing activity failed to provide fresh impetus.

site_title: DBS upbeat on topline growth as it posts 6% rise in Q3 profit
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 6% rise in Q3 profit, exceeding expectations. The bank expects topline growth of up to 8% next year, driven by loans linked to Singapore mortgages and trade. Chief executive Piyush Gupta attributed the growth to the core business. The bank showed no clear deterioration in loans linked to China and the oil-and-gas sector. DBS's growth prospects are seen as a positive sign for the Singapore banking sector.

site_title: Temasek drags Olam from Muddy Waters to winning US$1b loan
summary: Singapore commodities trader Olam International Ltd has secured a US$1 billion loan from 19 global banks, following a successful defense against a short-selling attack from Muddy Waters LLC in 2012. The company, controlled by Singapore state investment fund Temasek Holdings, has seen its dollar bonds return 6.7% in the past year, outperforming rival commodities traders. With the influx of funds, Olam plans to pursue acquisitions worth US$100-200 million, a shift from its previous strategy, and is taking advantage of a commodities rout to expand its business.

images.alt_text: Olam International Ltd, the Singapore commodities trader that fended off an attack from US-based short seller Muddy Waters LLC in 2012, is discovering it's good to have friends with deep pockets.

site_title: Steelmaking's demise at place of birth signals wider crisis
summary: Tata Steel has shut its Redcar plant in northern England, marking the end of steelmaking in the region, and is shedding another 1,200 jobs. This move signals a wider crisis in the steel industry, as production in Britain becomes increasingly economically unviable. The closure is a blow to the UK, but also affects the entire European steel market, which is already facing challenges. The shutdown highlights the decline of steel production in Britain, a country once at the heart of the steelmaking world.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Penguin International reported a 49.6% growth in third-quarter net profit to S$11.98 million, while its nine-month profit declined 4.2% to S$23.9 million. SHC Capital faces delisting after calling off a reverse takeover deal and reported S$38.9 million in net assets as of October 31. China Environment may need to raise additional capital due to slow customer payments amid tight credit access.

site_title: US: Dow back in black for 2015 as oil shares bounce
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed the year in positive territory for the first time since July, rising 165.22 points to 17,828.76. This comes after a seven-year peak in US construction spending, which reached $1.09 trillion in September. Oil shares, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, surged due to a technical bounce, while pharmaceutical stocks and tech companies also saw gains. Despite a decline in bond prices, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index reached fresh records.

site_title: DNV GL grooming local manpower in maritime research
summary: DNV GL has established an ECO Research Centre in Singapore to invest over S$3 million in research and development to enhance its energy efficiency advisory solutions for the maritime industry. The centre, launched almost three years ago, aims to strengthen DNV GL's services for a greener and more sustainable maritime sector. As a global operating company with over 16,000 professionals, DNV GL is committed to making the world safer, smarter, and greener through its research and advisory services.

site_title: On anniversary of Rabin's death, peace still elusive
summary: Israelis mark the 20th anniversary of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's assassination, a pivotal moment in the country's pursuit of peace with Palestinians. The assassination by a Jewish extremist in 1995 halted a potential path to reconciliation, leaving the question of whether a peaceful coexistence is achievable. As Israel grapples with the legacy of Rabin's vision, the nation remains divided, highlighting the stark contrast between hope and reality in the pursuit of lasting peace.

site_title: Britain to unveil new online spying laws
summary: Britain is set to unveil new online spying laws, aiming to keep pace with the digital age and tackle terrorist activity online. The proposed Investigatory Powers Bill will allow authorities to access internet and social media activity with a special warrant, and technology companies will be required to keep records of emails and social media use for 12 months. The measures, announced by Home Secretary Theresa May, will not ban encryption and will not give police powers to access browsing history. The bill will be scrutinised by lawmakers before being debated in parliament.

site_title: US says Volkswagen also violated emission rules in larger engines
summary: US regulators say Volkswagen also installed "defeat devices" in its 3.0-litre diesel engines, cheating US emissions tests, affecting around 10,000 luxury cars sold in the US. The company denies the allegations, but faces a potential $18 billion in fines and further damage to its reputation. The scandal has already led to the loss of one CEO and nearly a third of the company's shares. Investigations are ongoing, and Volkswagen has promised full cooperation with authorities.

site_title: HSBC's Q3 profit exceeds estimates as legal costs fall
summary: HSBC's Q3 profit exceeded estimates, rising to $6.1 billion from $4.6 billion a year earlier, driven by a decline in fines and legal settlements. Operating costs fell 19% to $9 billion, beating analysts' forecasts. The bank reiterated that a decision on its domicile may not come until next year. CEO Stuart Gulliver said cost-reduction measures are having an impact, with the bank aiming to eliminate 25,000 jobs. HSBC's shares fell 0.6% in Hong Kong, despite a 2% increase in pretax profit in Asia.

site_title: Deutsche unit eyes emerging Asia infrastructure plays
summary: Deutsche Bank's asset management unit is considering investing in emerging Asian infrastructure markets, particularly in China and India, due to attractive valuations. However, the unit remains cautious due to regulatory risks and difficult environments in these countries. The unit prioritizes stable cash flow distributions and stable regulatory environments, focusing on mature assets in developed markets. This approach has yielded defensive and low-volatility returns, making it an attractive option for investors seeking real assets. Despite the potential for growth, regulatory risks and volatility remain a concern for investors.

site_title: Hackers hit Vodafone UK customers in second telco attack in one week
summary: Hackers accessed customer account details, including phone numbers and bank details, of approximately 1,800 Vodafone UK customers in the second telco attack in one week. The breach occurred through a third party and Vodafone's own systems were not breached. The hackers accessed e-mail addresses and passwords, with a handful of customers experiencing fraudulent attempts on their accounts. The incident is being investigated, and the company has notified the National Crime Agency and Information Commissioners' Office.

images.alt_text: Hackers accessed some 1,800 subscribers' e-mail addresses and passwords through a third party and Newbury, England-based Vodafone's own systems weren't breached, the company said.

site_title: Disappointing growth in manufacturing as stimulus fails to spur
summary: China's manufacturing industry contracted for a third straight month in October, while euro zone factories showed only modest growth, contradicting expectations of a stimulus boost from central banks. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program has failed to lift inflation near its target, prompting policymakers to consider further easing. Italy's manufacturing sector, however, saw its ninth consecutive month of growth, and Germany's growth was only modest. The news raises doubts over whether US interest rates will rise this year, and China's policymakers are expected to ease monetary policy further in December.

site_title: What oil slump? Saudis spend without feeling pinch
summary: Saudi Arabia continues to maintain its luxury lifestyle despite an oil slump, as the government prioritizes sharing revenue with the public to maintain the Al Saud family's power. By running large budget deficits, the kingdom avoids disrupting the social contract that has kept the ruling family in power for decades. This approach allows the government to maintain its spending habits, including shopping malls and luxury restaurants, without feeling the pinch of reduced oil revenues. The strategy has helped the kingdom weather the economic downturn, ensuring the continued stability of the monarchy.

images.alt_text: Sharing oil wealth with the public has helped keep the Al Saud family in power, and the kingdom's rulers would rather run huge budget deficits than risk tampering with the bedrock social contract.

site_title: GE ships prefab pharma factories to China to help drugmakers cut costs
summary: General Electric (GE) has shipped its first pre-made biopharmaceutical factory, called KUBio, from Germany to China, aiming to help pharmaceutical companies cut costs and gain a head start in the approval process for new drugs. The factory, which was assembled in 11 days, can reduce costs by up to 45% compared to traditional facilities. GE plans to replicate this concept globally, with interest from countries such as Turkey and Brazil. The move is driven by China's growing demand for cheaper access to complex biologics and biosimilars, and GE hopes to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: Australian banks report record profit but outlook dim
summary: Australian major banks Westpac, National Australia Bank, ANZ Banking Corp, and Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported record profits, with combined annual cash earnings of A$30 billion. However, rising bad debt charges and margin pressure cloud the outlook for the sector, with regulators demanding more cash be set aside against loan books. The "Big Four" banks' return on equity has dropped to 15% from 15.5%, and they have raised over A$20 billion to comply with new capital rules. The sector faces a "lower-for-longer environment" with intense competition and regulatory uncertainty.

site_title: IPOs of Japan Post, units more than five times subscribed
summary: Japan Post Holdings and its two financial subsidiaries, Japan Post Insurance and Japan Post Bank, successfully completed the country's largest IPO in three decades, raising over 1.4 trillion yen (S$11.6 billion). The IPO received bids over five times the planned share offerings, with some investors attracted by high dividend yields and relatively cheap share values. The government allocated 80% of shares to domestic investors, aiming to encourage small savers to invest in shares. The success is seen as vital for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to secure cash and showcase the shift to investments from savings.

site_title: ClassNK boosts R&D in Singapore
summary: ClassNK has opened its Global Research and Innovation Centre (GRIC) in Singapore, marking its first research centre outside Japan. The centre will focus on maritime industry projects with industry, academia, and government agencies in Singapore and globally. ClassNK has secured S$7 million in funding from the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) to support the Maritime Clean Energy Research Programme. The centre will concentrate on projects related to structural integrity, fatigue, rugged robotics monitoring systems, and materials/composite for the marine environment, with a goal to develop in-house research capabilities and recruit researchers in Singapore within the next five years.

site_title: China tells eager parents to hold off baby-making for now
summary: China has reaffirmed its one-child policy until March 2026, despite a recent decision to allow couples to have two children. The policy change, announced by President Xi Jinping, aims to manage the country's slowing economy and raise the population to 1.45 billion by 2030. The National Health and Family Planning Commission has instructed local authorities not to implement their own two-child limits until the policy is amended. The move is seen as a compromise between population growth and rising costs of raising children.

images.alt_text: Children celebrating Halloween in Beijing, China, on Friday. The Communist Party's Central Committee has decided to allow all couples to have more children after the country's labour force shrank for the first time and previous efforts to encourage births fell short of its goal.

site_title: Fine wines languish in China warehouses as consumers cool
summary: China's wine market is experiencing a slowdown due to a faltering economy and a crackdown on graft, leading to a surplus of wine in bonded warehouses. Consumers are opting for cheaper wines, causing prices to drop and margins to shrink. The market, which was expected to continue growing, is now expected to grow at only 1% annually until 2020. Luxury wine imports, particularly from Bordeaux, are suffering, while more affordable New World wines from countries like Chile and South Africa are gaining market share.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

DBS Group Research upgraded UOL Group to "BUY" with a target price of S$8.47, citing its deep value play due to a portfolio of quality commercial properties and hotels. In contrast, NOL Ltd was downgraded to "HOLD" after reporting a core net loss of US$87 million in Q3 2015. Riverstone Holdings was also upgraded to "BUY" with a target price of S$2.25, driven by expected strong 3Q results and a niche cleanroom business. Meanwhile, CIMB Research maintained its "HOLD" stance on NOL, awaiting a potential buyer.

site_title: Rodyk & Davidson to join world's biggest law firm
summary: Rodyk & Davidson, Singapore's oldest law firm, has merged with Dentons, the world's largest law firm, and Gadens, an Australian law firm, to form Dentons Rodyk. The combined outfit will have over 7,000 lawyers and offices in over 50 countries. The deal, valued at over $2 billion, is the largest of its kind in Singapore's legal history and creates a polycentric law firm with no single headquarters. The partnership aims to serve clients globally while maintaining autonomy for Rodyk & Davidson.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US refiners enjoy windfall from low oil prices
summary: US refiners are experiencing a windfall from low oil prices, with Tesoro Corp reporting a record profit in the third quarter and Valero Energy Corp, Phillips 66, and Marathon Petroleum Corp posting their best quarter in at least three years. Crude prices have fallen by more than half from their 2014 peak, allowing refiners to capitalize on high demand for their products and resulting in record refining margins. Refiners are using the windfall to diversify by buying pipelines and other assets, with Marathon attempting to buy a natural gas gathering and transporting company.

site_title: Weakness persists at US factories as global sales stall
summary: US manufacturing remained stagnant in October with the Institute for Supply Management's index at 50.1, the weakest since May 2013. Global sales and a strong dollar hindered producers, while a record first-half inventory growth and energy sector woes persisted. Despite a slight improvement in auto output, a quick turnaround is unlikely, according to Moody's Analytics. The index of employment decreased to 47.6, and export orders contracted for the fifth straight month, leading to fewer job opportunities on factory floors.

site_title: KL mulls over Dibs for first-time home buyers
summary: Malaysia is considering revising the Developer Bearing Interest Scheme (Dibs) for first-time home buyers, which could allow its return to the market in a limited form. The government aims to balance the needs of buyers and developers amid a real estate slump. The House Buyers' Association opposes Dibs, instead proposing a build-then-sell 10:90 plan. The proposed relaxation comes after the recent Budget failed to stimulate the property sector, with some analysts expecting a soft outlook for the next few quarters.

site_title: For S-East Asia, Africa spells opportunity
summary: Singapore's Africa-South East Asia Chamber of Commerce (Aseacc) is positioning the country as a business hub in the continent, with 14 members including large shipping and commodity companies. Aseacc's co-founder, Paulo Gomes, believes Singapore's "Singapore model" of blending private and public sectors can be applied to Africa's urban development and planning. Despite China's significant investment in Africa, South-east Asian companies, including Singapore, are increasingly playing a bigger role in the continent. Opportunities for Singapore lie in urban development, value-added manufacturing, and planning cities to address Africa's growing urban challenges.

site_title: 2 Telok Ayer shophouses fetch S$18.2m
summary: A pair of adjoining shophouses in Singapore's Telok Ayer Street sold for S$18.2 million, with a price of around S$2,600 per square foot. The buyer, Spanish tycoon Ricardo Portabella Peralta, is believed to be the owner of a corporate service and consultancy group. This sale is one of the highest on Telok Ayer Street and follows recent shophouse deals in the area. Market analysts note that shophouse prices are holding steady due to limited supply and strong demand from investors and end-users, with predictions of a 5-10% appreciation in prices over the next six months.

site_title: SAP chief embarks on health-care mission after losing eye in an accident
summary: SAP CEO Bill McDermott, who lost his vision in an accident, is now focusing on improving healthcare through technology. He believes SAP's software can help doctors and medical professionals work more efficiently by sharing and analyzing digital information. McDermott's experience has spurred SAP to develop cloud-based systems for health care, including patient billing and research tools. He aims to create better care coordination and processes through data analysis, inspired by his own experience with siloed care.

site_title: SIA Engineering's Q2 profit rises 5.7% on cost cuts
summary: SIA Engineering's Q2 net profit rose 5.7% to S$44.5 million, driven by cost cuts. The company maintained its interim dividend per share at six Singapore cents, unchanged from last year. This works out to earnings per share of 3.96 cents, up from 3.75 cents previously. Despite a decline in topline earnings, the firm's profit growth was attributed to lower expenses.

site_title: First made-in-China big passenger plane unveiled
summary: China unveiled its first big passenger plane, the C919, a narrow-body jet seating 168 passengers, on November 2, 2015. Developed by Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (COMAC), the plane targets the lucrative segment dominated by Boeing's 737 and Airbus' A320. Production has been underway for over a year, but its maiden voyage is now planned for 2017, with foreign firms supplying systems and engines. COMAC has received orders for 517 C919 planes, mostly from domestic buyers, and plans a wide-body plane, the C929, in cooperation with Russia's United Aircraft Corp.

site_title: Labour of love
summary: Yvon Bock, a mother of four, founded Hegen after experiencing the challenges of breastfeeding. The company, born after five years of research and development, offers innovative baby bottles with patented features such as a no-screw-thread closure and interchangeable lids. After an initial setback, Hegen successfully launched its product, which is now available in Singapore and globally. The company's growth is attributed to government support, a strong online presence, and partnerships with brick-and-mortar stores. Hegen plans to expand its product range and distribution channels, aiming to become a quantum leap in baby-feeding products.

site_title: India's Coffee Day falls in trading debut
summary: Coffee Day Enterprises Ltd, an Indian cafe operator and coffee exporter, fell in its trading debut after raising 11.5 billion rupees in its largest share sale in three years. The stock dropped 11% to 291.80 rupees, lower than the initial offering price of 328 rupees. The company plans to use the proceeds to trim debt and expand its network, with a goal of opening 135 outlets and installing 5,000 vending machines annually. Coffee Day is the market leader with a 64% market share in India's coffee houses.

site_title: China intensifies financial crackdown, targets funds, banks
summary: China's financial crackdown intensifies as authorities investigate strategies blamed for a US$5 trillion stock-market rout. Shanghai police raided hedge funds Zexi Investment and Yishidun International Trading, detaining executives and seizing materials. The Agricultural Bank of China president has been taken away to assist in the investigation. The crackdown targets funds and banks, raising concerns about the country's financial stability.

site_title: VW may have under-reported safety incidents
summary: Volkswagen may have under-reported safety incidents, including at least one death and three injuries, to the US National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA) database. Lawsuits concerning these incidents, filed over the past eight years, were not found in the records. The company has set aside 6.5 billion euros for the potential costs of the scandal, which comes as Volkswagen faces regulatory investigations and a criminal probe in the US related to emissions controls. Volkswagen will commission an outside audit of its compliance with US safety-reporting laws.

site_title: CME online trading platform unavailable until further notice
summary: CME Group's online trading platform CME Direct is unavailable until further notice due to a technical issue. The platform experienced connectivity issues, affecting users' ability to log in. The exchange issued a member notice on Monday following earlier messages about the issue. The cause of the technical issue has not been specified.

site_title: Two-thirds of Asian business families want professional managers
summary: Asian business families, particularly in Singapore, are seeking to attract and develop professional managers to ensure long-term business sustainability. Two-thirds of respondents want to hire external talent, with autonomy and trust being key factors in attracting and retaining professionals. However, 86% of Singapore business families still prefer family ownership and management. The survey also highlighted the need for Asian business families to improve their wealth management knowledge and adopt a long-term management approach to drive future growth, with sustainability and continuity being a top priority.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Visa to buy Visa Europe for as much as 21.2b euros
summary: Visa Inc agreed to acquire Visa Europe Ltd for up to 21.2 billion euros, unifying the brand globally after eight years as separate companies. The deal includes an upfront payment of 16.5 billion euros and up to 4.7 billion euros more after the fourth anniversary. This marks the end of years of speculation about the companies reuniting, following their split in 2007 ahead of Visa Inc's initial public offering.

site_title: Gender gap: Add grassroots effort to bold rules
summary: Singapore's gender gap in boardrooms remains stagnant, with women making up only 9.1% of directors of Singapore-listed companies, despite efforts by the Diversity Action Committee to address the issue. While quotas are being considered, experts prefer targets as a more effective approach. A survey by the Singapore Institute of Directors found that most boards cite a lack of suitable candidates as a barrier, highlighting a cultural problem that requires grassroots engagement. The government and market operators are urged to support and supply diversity advocates to address the structural issues perpetuating the gender gap.

site_title: China slowdown is now top concern of Asian treasurers
summary: China's economic slowdown has replaced foreign exchange volatility as the top concern for company treasurers in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a JP Morgan survey. 48% of respondents cited China as the most significant macro issue, up from 13% in April. Interest-rate concerns have fallen sharply, with less than 2% of treasurers highlighting such worries. Many companies plan to use excess cash for strategic purposes, such as share buybacks and mergers and acquisitions, with M&A activity expected to continue rising in the low interest rate environment.

site_title: Lufthansa cabin staff plan one-week strike from Nov 6: union
summary: Lufthansa cabin staff are planning a one-week strike starting from November 6 if management does not meet their demands for improved pay and early retirement provisions. The UFO union gave management until Thursday to present a revised offer, threatening walkouts from November 6-12.

site_title: The pain in Spain
summary: Spain's economy is experiencing a recovery, with eight consecutive quarters of growth, but this progress is not solely due to austerity and structural reforms. The country's easing of austerity measures and low inflation have contributed to its growth, but it remains fragile. Spain's GDP growth is expected to be 3% in 2015 and 2.5% in 2016, but it will not return to its pre-crisis size before 2017. The country faces significant challenges, including high debt, low productivity, and demographic issues, which may hinder its long-term growth prospects.

site_title: China funds buying dollar property bonds risks exporting bubble
summary: China's bond investors have fueled a 5.5% surge in dollar-denominated property bonds in October, the largest monthly gain since 2012. The yield premium on Evergrande Real Estate Group's 2018 bond over US Treasuries dropped to 708 basis points, near its lowest since 2014. This rally may be exporting a leverage-driven bubble, as China's cash-strapped developers take on excessive debt. The question remains whether China's bond investors have insight into the situation or are simply participating in a global market trend.

site_title: China's investors still putting money in small-cap stocks
summary: Chinese investors continue to invest in small-cap stocks, despite the US$4 trillion selloff in China's stock market earlier this year. Wu Xin, a 28-year-old investor, has been buying shares in the ChiNext Index, which has seen a significant rebound. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: More than just a real-estate agency
summary: OrangeTee, a Singaporean real estate agency, has established itself as a key player in the industry over the past 15 years by differentiating itself through a broader range of services and a focus on Asian cultural elements. The company's growth formula, "PIN," emphasizes the importance of "People," "Innovation," and "Network." OrangeTee prioritizes investing in human capital, providing opportunities for employees to expand their knowledge and skills, and building a strong network with overseas partners. The company's focus on its people and innovative approach has enabled it to maintain a strong brand and provide high-quality services to its clients.

site_title: Greenback slips after weak US and China data
summary: The US dollar declined against the yen and euro following weak US and Chinese data, fueling concerns about the global economy. The US consumer spending rose only 0.1% in September, and China's manufacturing sector activity declined for the third straight month. This has bolstered the case against a December rate rise, pushing back the move into 2016. The euro gained ground against the US dollar, rising to $1.1035, while the yen rose to 132.80 yen.

site_title: Hedge funds cease betting the wrong way on gold
summary: Hedge funds have cut their net-long position in gold for the first time in six weeks, after the Federal Reserve's policy statement drove the biggest weekly price drop in two months. The funds had been positioning for a rally, boosting their holdings by 17-fold since mid-September. The drop in prices, which saw over $1.05 billion wiped from the value of exchange-traded gold products, reflects the view of Goldman Sachs Group Inc that tighter monetary policy makes gold less competitive against assets with interest payments or dividends.

site_title: IMF likely to add yuan to list of SDR currencies soon: Washington body
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is likely to approve the inclusion of the yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, marking a significant step towards the internationalization of the Chinese currency. The yuan has become the fourth most heavily used currency in global payment transactions and the second-most used currency in global trade finance. However, the IMF's decision may be influenced by China's further depreciation of the currency and slowdown in economic growth, which could slow the pace of internationalization.

site_title: Saizen Reit soars 19% on news of Japan assets' sale
summary: Saizen Reit, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (Reit), has announced the sale of its entire Japanese portfolio to Lone Star Funds for 44.66 billion yen (S$517.3 million). The deal, valued at 3.4% premium to the appraised value of its 136 residential properties, sent Saizen Reit's units soaring 19% on Monday. The sale is expected to result in a cash payout to unitholders, potentially leading to a delisting or liquidation of the Reit.

site_title: ExxonMobil's 'leaner ship' floats higher than rivals in oil downturn
summary: ExxonMobil Corp has successfully navigated the worst oil market slump since the 1980s by maintaining its 75,300-strong workforce, avoiding significant layoffs. The company's decades of financial discipline has enabled it to remain lean and efficient, outperforming rivals such as Chevron Corp. In contrast, industry job cuts have exceeded 200,000 worldwide. ExxonMobil's strategy has allowed it to maintain its competitive edge, positioning the company as the most-efficient oil company in the world.

site_title: Opec growing optimistic of a pathway to higher prices
summary: Opec is optimistic about a pathway to higher oil prices, expecting prices to reach $80 per barrel by 2020. However, the group faces internal challenges, including Iran's efforts to regain its position as the second-largest producer, and potential oversupply from Libya. Opec's success relies on cooperation from non-Opec producers, particularly Russia, but intense sectarian rivalry and geopolitics may hinder cohesion. The group's ability to implement effective quotas and control production is uncertain, and the world economy's slowdown, including China's reduced oil purchases, may further reduce demand.

site_title: Jeep sales keep soaring as shoppers dismiss poor quality ratings
summary: Jeep sales continue to soar, despite poor quality ratings from Consumer Reports, ranking the brand as the second-least-reliable in the US market. Jeep sales rose 23% this year through September, outpacing Subaru's 14% growth, and are on track to meet or exceed Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' sales projections. Jeep's global sales rose 39% last year, topping one million for the first time, and the brand's go-anywhere image remains a major draw for consumers.

site_title: Revenue surge boosts Sing Hldgs' Q3 profit
summary: Sing Holdings reported a net profit of S$2.75 million for Q3, more than doubling from S$307,000 a year ago, driven by a revenue surge of 158.5% to S$35.51 million. The group recognized an additional 18% of contracted sales from condo units in Robin Residences, bringing cumulative recognition to 76%. Net profit for the nine months ended September jumped to S$4.05 million, with revenue and nine-month other income also rising significantly. The group expects weak buying sentiment in the Singapore property market, but continues to monitor opportunities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Bank of England posits 35% house price decline in stress test
summary: The Bank of England has set a stress test scenario that predicts a 35% decline in UK house prices between 2015 and 2018, a recession lasting until 2017, and unemployment reaching 11% by 2018. This test aims to assess the UK banking system's resilience, with interest rates expected to jump to 4.2% and inflation reaching 5.6% in 2017. The test, known as the "anchor scenario," excludes international factors affecting the seven largest banks.

site_title: UK index names S'pore economy as world's most successful
summary: Singapore has surpassed Switzerland as the world's most successful economy, according to the Legatum Institute's Prosperity Index. The city-state ranks 17th globally, driven by high productivity and export prowess, particularly in high-tech manufactured exports. Singapore's strong performance in the Economy sub-index, where it tops the rankings, is attributed to its high capital per worker and low unemployment rate. Despite ranking 38th in Personal Freedom, the country excels in other sub-indices, indicating a well-rounded prosperity.

site_title: US manufacturing sector growth slows in October: ISM
summary: The US manufacturing sector experienced its lowest growth level since May 2013 in October, with the Institute for Supply Management's index falling to 50.1, down from 50.2 the previous month. This marks the fourth consecutive monthly decline, indicating a slowdown in the sector.

site_title: Petronas seen delaying LNG final investment decision
summary: Petronas is likely to delay its final investment decision (FID) on the Kasawari gas field development in Block SK 316 off Sarawak, amid uncertainty over oil-linked LNG prices. The development's start-up is now expected to occur in 2021, rather than 2017, and may result in a delay in the target contract package, valued at over $1 billion. This could impact Petronas' plans to source alternative feed gas to support its ninth LNG train at the Malaysia LNG complex, which is currently under construction.

site_title: US and UK to test financial cyber-security later this month
summary: The US and UK will conduct a joint cyber-security test later this month to assess how regulators respond to a major cyber-attack or IT problems in their financial sectors. The test will focus on communication and coordination between US and UK regulators, with no testing of physical bank systems. This exercise was agreed upon by US President Barack Obama and British Prime Minister David Cameron in January, with the aim of improving their response to online attacks on their financial sectors.

site_title: Fog grounds planes across UK with delays extending to Tuesday
summary: A fog covering much of Britain has caused significant disruptions to flights at UK airports, with restrictions in place for a second day. London's Heathrow and Gatwick airports, as well as Manchester, have limited aircraft movements due to poor visibility. Delays are expected to continue through Tuesday, with some airlines reporting 50% capacity at Heathrow and 59 grounded flights by EasyJet. European regulations require airlines to provide food and accommodation for stranded passengers, and carriers are advising customers to check flight status online.

site_title: New York hotels go on offensive against Airbnb rentals
summary: New York's hotel industry is launching a counterattack against Airbnb, citing estimated losses of $88.9 million in hotel food spending and $1 billion in construction activity. The Hotel Association of New York City claims Airbnb generated $451.4 million in gross revenue in the city in 2015, which will jump to $805.3 million in 2018. The organization says Airbnb's business model is hurting the industry and that the startup is essentially a "de facto hotel company" without regulation.

site_title: Greece sets terms for banks to raise cash in 14.4b euro recap
summary: Greece's government has set terms for banks to raise cash in a 14.4 billion euro hole, with the state-owned Hellenic Financial Stability Fund offering 25% common shares and 75% contingent convertible securities. The European Central Bank expects banks to raise at least 4.4 billion euros from shareholders and bondholders. Bank stocks rallied on the news, with Alpha Bank AE and Eurobank rising 24.4% and 25.8% respectively. The government's participation in the capital injection will determine the ownership structure of battered lenders, with US billionaire Wilbur Ross warning that diluting existing shareholders' stakes could lead to investor reluctance.

site_title: Greek bank stress tests results "pleasing": German fin ministry
summary: Germany's Finance Ministry is pleased with the results of Greek bank stress tests, as the capital hole is smaller than the 25 billion euros (S$39 billion) allocated for the country's bailout program. The ministry will examine Greek banks' plans and the European Central Bank's response. This development may ease concerns about the stability of Greece's financial system.

site_title: Has the American Budget War truly ended or is it just an armistice?
summary: US President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans have reached a budget deal, increasing spending on domestic and defense programs over two years while suspending the debt limit into 2017. This marks an end to the "budget wars" that dominated Washington for nearly eight years. The deal comes as the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill changes and may pave the way for a grand deal on budget and tax reform. However, some experts view the agreement as an interim solution that kicks the budgetary can to the next president.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama speaks at the Center for Law and Justice at Rutgers University in Newark, New Jersey, on Nov 2, 2015.

site_title: Dubai's DP World becomes sole owner of Southampton container terminal: statement
summary: DP World, a Dubai-listed ports operator, has become the sole owner of Southampton container terminal after purchasing the remaining 49% stake from Associated British Ports (ABP). The company extended the license agreement for DP World Southampton for another 25 years until 2047. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. This acquisition marks DP World's expansion in the UK port market.

site_title: AKP's Turkey election win reduces near-term uncertainty: Moody's
summary: Moody's says the AK Party's Turkish election win reduced near-term political uncertainty, but its impact on sovereign credit quality will depend on the party's strategy to address low growth, high inflation, and volatile capital flows. Banks in Turkey still face elevated risk aversion towards emerging markets and geopolitical risks.

site_title: Talent recruitment, development seen as key for sustainability of local businesses: study
summary: A report by United Overseas Bank and the Singapore Management University's Business Families Institute found that two-thirds of Asian business families see talent recruitment and development as a major challenge to ensuring long-term sustainability. To address this, they are hiring external professional managers and prioritizing trust, fairness, and remuneration in attracting and retaining them.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: STI falls for fifth day on China worries
summary: The Straits Times Index fell for the fifth consecutive session, losing 23.94 points or 0.8% at 2,974.41, amid China's sluggish manufacturing and weak Dow futures.
