Key players in the market, including OCBC, UOB, and Neptune Orient Lines, also experienced losses. Analysts point to China's October PMI of 49.8, below expectations, as a major contributor to the market's weakness.

site_title: Areva says China's CNNC may buy minority stake
summary: Areva has signed a memorandum of understanding with China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC) for a possible partnership that could see CNNC take a minority stake in the French nuclear company. The partnership covers various aspects of the nuclear industry, excluding the reactor business. Areva Chairman Philippe Varin stated that the cooperation with Chinese partners is integral to the company's future success, offering numerous opportunities for both parties.

site_title: Japan Post IPO more than 5 times oversubscribed: sources
summary: Japan Post Holdings and Japan Post Bank's initial public offering (IPO) was more than five times oversubscribed, with the combined offering of the three companies expected to be Japan's largest in nearly three decades. The IPO is set to list on Wednesday.

site_title: DBS glides ahead of peers on sounder oil-and-gas exposure
summary: Singapore's DBS Group outperformed its peers in the third quarter, posting a 6% increase in net profit despite a dour outlook for the banking sector. The bank's asset quality remained stable, with non-performing loans (NPL) at 0.9% and no change in bad loans over six quarters. In contrast, OCBC Bank posted a 27% drop in net profit due to restructuring efforts in the oil-and-gas sector and a lower net interest margin. UOB's NPL ratio rose to 1.3% from 1.2% a year ago, while its net interest margin increased. The banks' loan growth expectations were revised downward, with OCBC lowering its forecast to a low single digit.

site_title: Feathers fly over Thailand's lucrative cockfighting pits
summary: In Thailand, cockfighting is a centuries-old tradition and a lucrative industry, with bets often reaching high amounts. The practice, where roosters compete with their spurs wrapped in fabric, is technically illegal but tolerated under the guise of preserving ancient Thai culture. Despite concerns over animal welfare, the industry is estimated to generate significant revenue, with champion birds selling for over $85,000. Animal rights groups are pushing for an end to the practice, citing exploitation and cruelty, but the official view supports cockfighting as a vital part of Thai heritage.

site_title: Partisan growth gaps
summary: The US economy has historically performed better under Democratic presidents, with an average annual growth rate of 4.35% compared to 2.54% under Republican presidents since 1947. Despite this, Republicans often boast about their ability to deliver growth, despite having a historically poor track record. The Democratic record is attributed to factors such as better luck on oil prices and technological progress, but the exact reason remains unknown. Republicans, on the other hand, tend to promise economic miracles to sell policies that favor the donor class, often relying on epistemic closure and media bias to maintain their claims of economic superiority.

site_title: India's IndiGo raises US$459m in IPO, at upper end of range
summary: India's IndiGo, owner of Indian budget airline, raised 30.1 billion rupees (S$643 million) in an initial public offering at 765 rupees per share, at the upper end of its price range. This is India's largest IPO since 2012, surpassing Bharti Infratel's $750 million listing. The airline's market debut is expected later this month, following a book-building process that attracted orders six times the available shares.

site_title: China Environment may have to raise cash if customers cannot pay on time
summary: China Environment may need to raise additional capital if its customers fail to pay on time, citing a tight credit environment and slow work progression. The company, which supplies industrial gas cleaning equipment, has a proposed S$3.2 million share placement that will be sufficient to meet present requirements. China Environment shares closed unchanged at 9.5 Singapore cents on Monday. The company may seek fresh funds from existing shareholders, new private placements, or debt financing methods if collection of trade receivables is slow or non-existent.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd IPO expected to price at 20 euros a share: source
summary: Hapag-Lloyd is expected to price its initial public offering (IPO) at the low end of a revised range of 20-22 euros per share, according to a source. The IPO is expected to go through despite a profit warning from peer Maersk due to industry overcapacity. The IPO books are set to close on Tuesday, and trading will start on Friday. The move comes after Hapag-Lloyd trimmed the planned IPO volume and lowered the price range.

site_title: Singapore shares lower for fifth straight session on China worries
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 0.8% on Monday, marking its fifth consecutive drop, due to concerns over China's October PMI and weak Dow futures. The index closed at 2,974.41 points. All three major banks, OCBC, UOB, and DBS, ended lower, with OCBC falling for the fourth consecutive day. In the shipping sector, Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) shares fell 0.035 to S$0.96.

site_title: Penguin Q3 profit grows 50% on gains from vessel sales
summary: Penguin International reported a 49.6% increase in third-quarter net profit to S$12.0 million, driven by gains from vessel sales. Revenue declined 7.2% to S$48.3 million, while nine-month profit slipped 4.2%. The company attributed the boost to gains from vessel sales and cost-cutting measures. Demand for crewboats and supply intervention vessels has decreased due to the offshore oil and gas industry's worsening sentiments.

site_title: SHC calls off RTO, faces delisting if new business not found
summary: SHC Capital, a Singaporean company, has terminated its reverse takeover deal with Chinese equipment maker Tong Da Medical Device due to lack of progress in due diligence. SHC has until January 31, 2016, to find a new business or face delisting from the Catalist board. The company has spent S$1.4 million on the deal and has S$38.9 million in net assets, including S$39.3 million in cash. SHC is exploring options, including a voluntary liquidation, to avoid delisting.

site_title: One-off gains lift Q2 earnings of SingPost
summary: SingPost reported a 38.5% rise in net profit to S$53.44 million for its second quarter, driven by one-off gains. Revenue rose 19.4% to S$263.17 million. The company's underlying net profit decreased 4.8%. Revenue from its logistics business grew 43.3% to S$156.06 million, while retail and e-commerce revenue increased 7.1% to S$23.94 million. SingPost expects capital expenditure to remain high due to redevelopment projects and investments in e-commerce logistics solutions.

site_title: US: Stocks up ahead of Disney results, jobs report
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday ahead of Disney's earnings report and the October jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 46.31 points (0.26%) to 17,709.84, while the S&P 500 gained 5.15 points (0.25%) to 2,084.51. The Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, reaching a fresh record. The gains came despite tariff uncertainty and split views among Fed officials, with investors focusing on the upcoming economic reports.

site_title: UBS names Chee, Beniwal as investment-banking heads for Asia
summary: UBS has appointed Joseph Chee and Saurabh Beniwal as co-heads of corporate-client solutions for Asia, filling a role vacated by David Chin. Chee, former head of global capital markets for Asia, and Beniwal, former leader of Southeast Asia corporate client solutions, will report to Matthew Hanning, Asia Pacific head of corporate-client solutions. The appointments come after UBS split its investment bank into two groups in 2012. The corporate-client solutions group is responsible for mergers advisory, capital markets, and financing for companies, financial institutions, and private-equity firms.

site_title: US small-business borrowing rose in September: PayNet
summary: US small businesses increased borrowing in September, with the Thomson Reuters/PayNet Small Business Lending Index rising to 140.4, a 11% increase from last year. The growth trend suggests consumer spending will drive GDP growth in the fourth quarter, potentially leading to a 2% annual GDP pace. The delinquency rate on loans over 30 days past due rose to 1.45% in September. This uptick in borrowing, combined with a cooling US GDP growth, may prompt the Federal Reserve to consider raising interest rates in December.

site_title: Volkswagen's Audi keeps margin target despite Q3 profit drop
summary: Audi, Volkswagen's luxury division, maintains its profitability target despite a Q3 profit drop, citing strong demand in Europe and the US. The company reported a 4.4% decline in Chinese sales and costs associated with new models and plants. Audi expects a return on sales of 8-10% this year, despite its benchmark margin slipping to the bottom end of the range. The company plans to continue hiring and reduce costs as part of its 2015-19 budget plan.

site_title: Visa agrees to buy Visa Europe for as much as 21.2 billion euros
summary: Visa agrees to acquire Visa Europe in a deal valued at up to 21.2 billion euros, uniting the brand globally after eight years as separate companies. The 16.5 billion-euro upfront consideration aims to boost earnings by 5-12% and increase market share, potentially disrupting Visa's operations and benefiting smaller competitor MasterCard. The acquisition, finalized after years of speculation, will bring together Visa Europe's 500 million accounts and 16 billion transactions processed annually.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q2 earnings rise 5.7% despite revenue drop
summary: SIA Engineering's Q2 net profit rose 5.7% to S$44.5 million despite a 6.7% drop in revenue to S$266 million. Lower expenses, mainly from cutting subcontract, staff, and material costs, contributed to the increase. The company warned of a challenging operating environment due to lower work content and longer check intervals on newer aircraft. Earnings per share grew to 3.96 cents, and net asset value inched up to S$1.194.

site_title: ECB's Nowotny urges caution on bond buying: newspaper
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Ewald Nowotny urged caution on expanding bond buying to boost inflation, despite the bank's 2% inflation target being missed. Nowotny advised a steady-hand policy, suggesting that quantitative easing has helped prevent deflation and an economic crisis in the euro zone. He emphasized the need for fiscal policies and structural reforms from Euro zone countries to support the effort, rather than solely relying on monetary easing.

site_title: Mubadala, Temasek sale of Abu Dhabi finance firm said to stall
summary: Mubadala Development Co and Singapore's Temasek Holdings' sale of Abu Dhabi consumer finance firm Dunia Finance LLC has stalled after bids failed to meet shareholder expectations. The company may consider an initial public offering next year, valuing it at up to US$1 billion. Shareholders sought four to five times book value, with Dubai's Majid Al Futtaim Holding LLC among those interested in the company. Dunia Finance reported a 61% profit increase in 2014, with assets of 1.6 billion dirhams.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group reported a 6% increase in net profit to S$1.07 billion for Q3 2015. Singapore ranked as the world's top-ranked economy in the Legatum Institute's Prosperity Index. The sale of Abu Dhabi finance firm Dunia Finance LLC has stalled after failing to meet shareholder expectations. Demand for life sciences professionals is rising, with talent recruitment seen as a key challenge to local business sustainability. China raised its yuan currency by the largest amount in a decade, causing Singapore shares to fall for the fifth consecutive session.

site_title: Tan Chong Koay gets MAS approval as fund management CEO
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has approved Tan Chong Koay, 65, as CEO and executive director of Pheim Asset Management (Asia). This follows his application for a fund management licence last month. No further details on his tenure or plans are mentioned.

site_title: UK factory PMI surges to 16-month high, exports recover
summary: The UK factory PMI surged to a 16-month high of 55.5 in October, indicating a rapid economic growth pick-up in the last three months of the year. Export orders recovered, with new orders increasing to their highest level since August 2014. This contrasts with other measures of the economy, which showed a contraction in factory orders. The survey suggests a quarterly growth rate of around 1%, dispelling fears of a global economic slowdown and potentially influencing interest rate expectations.

site_title: Australia: Shares drops to one-month lows, RBA eyed
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.4% to a one-month low on Monday, with banks leading losses ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,165.8, its largest daily drop since late September. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also declined, ending a 12-day rally. The RBA's decision is expected to impact the market on Tuesday.

site_title: China approves US$6.7b high-speed railway project
summary: China has approved a US$6.7 billion high-speed railway project worth 42.7 billion yuan, set to run through central Henan and eastern Anhui provinces. This approval is part of Beijing's efforts to boost economic growth in less-developed western regions. The project aims to promote development in these areas, following recent infrastructure investments.

site_title: Greek factory activity downturn eases in October: PMI
summary: Greek manufacturing activity contracted at a slower pace in October, with the PMI index rising to 47.3 points from 43.3 in September, but still below the 50 mark. Production, new business orders, and employment all declined, but at a slower pace than in previous months. The economic decline appears to be slowing to a more stable pace, according to Markit economist Samuel Agass. This marks the 14th month of contraction, but the slowest in five months.

site_title: SingPost Q2 net profit down 4.8% to S$37.5m
summary: SingPost reported a 4.8% drop in Q2 net profit to S$37.54 million, despite a 19.4% increase in revenue to S$263.17 million. The company's earnings per share rose 41.5% to 2.31 cents. For the half-year period, net profit rose 1.4% to S$77.83 million, with revenue increasing 20.1% to S$517.78 million. The company attributed the decline to one-off gains from divestment of subsidiaries.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets fell in opening deals on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.65% to 6,319.70 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 0.92% to 10,749.98 points. The Paris CAC 40 dropped 1.0% to 4,848.86. The declines followed a mixed session in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: China says one-child policy stays in effect for now
summary: China's one-child policy remains in effect until new rules allowing all couples to have two children are approved by the parliament in March. The National Health and Family Planning Commission stated that localities must enforce existing population and family planning laws, despite a loosening of the policy announced last week. The policy change aims to raise China's population to 1.45 billion by 2030, benefiting approximately 90 million families. China had previously relaxed the policy in 2013, but only a fraction of eligible couples have applied to expand their families.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end slightly lower
summary: Malaysia's shares closed slightly lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 1.64 points to 1,664.07. The Bursa Malaysia saw 2.61 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.97 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 455 to 412.

site_title: US Fund Third Point buys stake in Japan's Seven & I Holdings
summary: US hedge fund Third Point, led by billionaire Daniel Loeb, has acquired a stake in Japan's Seven & I Holdings, the operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores. Third Point stated that Seven & I Holdings is undervalued compared to global competitors and urged the CEO to spin off its Ito Yokado supermarkets chain, aiming to rebuild it as an independent firm.

site_title: Indonesia foreign tourist arrivals up 9.84% on year in Sept
summary: Indonesia saw a 9.84% increase in foreign tourist arrivals in September, reaching 869,200 visitors, surpassing August's 2.87% growth. The country aims to attract 20 million tourists by 2019. The removal of visa requirements for 45 countries is expected to boost tourism.

site_title: ST Aero wins cabin reconfiguration contract from Air Canada for 8 A330s
summary: ST Aerospace wins a contract from Air Canada to reconfigure the cabins of 8 Airbus A330 aircraft. The work will start in 2016 and be completed by 2017, with upgrades including premium economy seats, enlarged economy class sections, and an audio and video on-demand system. This follows a previous contract for 12 Boeing 767-300 aircraft, now redelivered to Air Canada. The project is valued and reflects the company's continued trust and confidence from the airline operator.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ryanair profit soars almost 40%
summary: Ryanair reported a 37% increase in earnings after taxation to €1.09 billion (S$1.7 billion) for the first half of 2015, driven by strong demand, a strong pound, fuel savings, and poor weather conditions in northern Europe. The airline is on track to meet its annual earnings forecast, with ongoing improvements to customer services contributing to its success. Ryanair's profits soared nearly 40% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise as China surveys spur stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.3% on Monday, snapping a four-day slide, following soft Chinese economic surveys that sparked hopes of stimulus measures. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,035.24 points. The South Korean won also gained 3 cents against the dollar, ending at 1,137.0 to the dollar. Investors took the Chinese economic surveys as a positive sign, increasing expectations of further stimulus from China, which boosted the shares.

site_title: China: Stocks close down, small-cap rally fizzles
summary: China's stocks closed down 1.6% on Monday, with the CSI300 index falling to 3,475.96, amid concerns about the weak economy and Beijing's crackdown on illegal futures trading. Small-cap shares, which had initially rallied, fizzled out. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.7% to 3,325.08 points, with Meiyan Jixiang, China Shipbuilding, and Agricultural Bank Of China among the most active stocks. Total A-share trading volume in Shanghai reached 22.9 billion shares, while Shenzhen saw 27.4 billion shares.

images.alt_text: Investors chat in front of an electronic board showing stock information at a brokerage house in Beijing, China, Oct 30, 2015.

site_title: Dollar struggles after weak US, China data
summary: The US dollar extended losses against the yen and euro due to weak US and Chinese data, fueling concerns about the global economy. US consumer spending rose only 0.1% in September, the slowest rate since January, and China's manufacturing sector activity declined for the third straight month. This weakened the case against a December interest rate hike, bolstering the dollar's value. The dollar slipped to 120.34 yen and 132.73 yen against the euro, but gained modestly against emerging currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down on China economy concerns
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 1.2% on Monday due to concerns over China's weak economy and a crackdown on illegal futures trading. China arrested two executives from a Hong Kong-owned fund for irregular trades involving hundreds of millions of dollars. This is the first public arrest linked to a non-mainland fund caught in the crackdown. The Hang Seng index fell to 22,370.04, while the China Enterprises Index lost 1.5% to 10,240.33 points.

site_title: Philippines' Megaworld, Travellers invest more in Manila casino, township project
summary: Philippine property firm Megaworld Corp will invest around $300 million in the residential portion of a 31-hectare casino and township project in Manila's Entertainment City complex. The project, Westside City, will be completed by 2020 and includes upscale apartments, a luxury mall, and 1,500 hotel rooms. The total budget for the project is $1.4 billion, with Travellers International Hotel Group Inc, a joint venture between Alliance Global Group Inc and Genting Hong Kong Ltd, also investing in the project. The move aims to tap into non-gaming revenue sources amid China's corruption crackdown.

site_title: Hersing Centre at Toa Payoh on sale, indicative price about S$78 million
summary: The Hersing Centre in Toa Payoh, Singapore, is being sold for S$78 million, equivalent to about S$1,750 psf. The 44,411 sq ft commercial building is strategically located in the heart of Toa Payoh Central, opposite HDB Hub and Toa Payoh MRT Interchange. The sale price is indicative, and the property features a 3-storey structure with a mezzanine level.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Gold dips to 4-week low on US rate hike fears
summary: Gold prices dropped to a 4-week low, falling 0.2% to $1,139.93 an ounce, as investors feared a US interest rate hike this year. This is the fourth consecutive session of selling pressure, with physical demand and investor flows failing to support the metal. Traders warn of further price drops, citing a deteriorating technical picture. The US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike has led to a sell-off in gold, leaving it at its lowest level since October 5.

site_title: Hyundai's China sales increase for first time in 7 months
summary: Hyundai Motor Co. reported its first sales increase in China in 7 months, with deliveries rising 8.5% in October, driven by sales of its new Tucson SUV and a tax cut on vehicle purchases. The Seoul-based automaker accelerated the introduction of the new SUV and cut its price to boost demand. The tax cut, implemented by China's government, helped Hyundai achieve its biggest monthly global sales gain since December 2014.

site_title: Japan eyes greater corporate bond market transparency with new price data
summary: Japan's securities regulators have launched a new system to increase transparency in corporate bond markets by requiring real-time trade data on high-liquidity bonds. The system, launched by the Japan Securities Dealers Association, will disclose trades exceeding 100 million yen (S$1.16m) on bonds rated AA or above. However, critics argue the new regulations only cover a portion of the market and have a significant time lag, potentially leading to distorted market pricing. The JSDA will review the regulations annually, but its effectiveness remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Japanese authorities are trying to bring greater transparency to corporate bonds with new price data, but with new rules extending to only a part of the market few see the changes having an immediate impact.

site_title: Demand heats up for candidates in Singapore's life sciences sector: report
summary: Demand for regulatory affairs, sales and marketing professionals in Singapore's life sciences sector has increased due to consolidation activity in the global life sciences industry. A shortage of local candidates has led to rising senior vacancies, with regulatory, medical, and compliance functions being the most in-demand. The recent hold on foreign employment pass applications has fueled competition for local candidates. Key roles in high demand include regulatory affairs professionals with leadership skills, manufacturing professionals with biologics expertise, and marketing professionals with strong scientific communication experience. This trend is expected to continue as international pharmaceutical companies base their regional head offices in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sprint says aims to slash costs up to US$2.5b, including layoffs
summary: Sprint Corp plans to slash fiscal 2016 expenses by up to US$2.5 billion through layoffs and cost controls. The company aims to bolster its wireless network quality, speed, and capacity. Sprint reported a US$20 million loss in the first quarter, with revenue falling 8.7% to US$8.03 billion, missing analyst estimates. Majority owner Softbank Corp has no plans to sell its stake in Sprint, easing investor concerns. The company will provide more details on job cuts and network plans in its fiscal second-quarter results on Tuesday.

site_title: Australian banks in record profit but outlook downbeat
summary: Australia's major banks, Westpac, National Australia Bank, ANZ Banking Corp, and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, reported record cash earnings of A$30 billion, driven by mortgage growth. However, rising bad debt charges and margin pressure are expected to cloud the outlook, with the sector preparing for its slowest earnings growth since the global financial crisis. Return on equity has dropped to 15% from 15.5%, and regulators are demanding more cash be set aside against loan books amid fears of a housing bubble.

site_title: Asia: Markets down as soft China surveys fuel growth fears
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan losing 0.6% due to soft Chinese factory surveys that fueled global growth concerns. Chinese stocks dropped 0.7% and 1% in Shanghai and Hong Kong, respectively. The dollar edged back against the yen as risk appetite waned. The US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates is expected to be influenced by this week's US data, including non-farm payrolls on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares tread water on poor China outlook; won eases
summary: South Korean shares were nearly flat at midday on Monday, erasing earlier losses on optimism China will resume stimulus measures following poor manufacturing sector activity. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.1% to 2,030.15 points. The won dipped against the dollar, trading at 1,142.5 to the dollar. Investors remain cautious on anticipation of a US Federal Reserve rate hike in December. China's factory activity fell for an eighth straight month, fueling fears of sluggish momentum.

site_title: Nissan raises full-year profit forecast on stronger Q2 North America sales
summary: Nissan Motor Co raised its full-year operating profit forecast by 8% to 730 billion yen ($8.5 billion) due to stronger vehicle sales in North America, surpassing expectations. The company also increased its revenue forecasts for the full year. This improvement is attributed to the company's success in the North American market, which has driven higher-than-expected second-quarter operating profit. The revised forecast is higher than the previous year's operating profit of 590 billion yen.

site_title: China gives currency largest boost in a decade
summary: China raised the central rate for its yuan currency by 0.54% against the US dollar, the largest amount in a decade, in a move aimed at promoting the yuan as a global reserve currency. The increase follows a surprise devaluation in August and aims to maintain a stable foreign exchange market. China has pledged not to engage in competitive devaluations and seeks to convince the International Monetary Fund to include the yuan in its special drawing rights reserve currency basket. The move is seen as a step towards stabilizing the economy and supporting the yuan's inclusion in the IMF's basket.

site_title: Australia: Shares stung by banks, NZ stocks off record highs
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% on Monday, marking the sixth consecutive decline, amid concerns over slowing growth in the Asian economy and a possible interest rate decision by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,168.50. The financial sector was particularly hit, with Westpac Banking Corp down 2.2% after reporting modest credit growth and ongoing regulatory uncertainty. Investors await the RBA's interest rate decision on Tuesday, with most analysts expecting rates to remain at a record low of 2.0%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.34% lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened 1.34% lower on Monday, following a decline on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 255.99 points to 18,827.11. This week's focus will be on Japan Post's trading debut and fresh US data. The US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, Polaris, mm2Asia
summary: DBS Group reported a net profit of S$1.07 billion for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, up 6% from a year ago. Total income rose 8% to S$2.71 billion, with net interest income reaching a record at S$1.81 billion. Net interest margin reached a four-year high of 1.78%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: NZ stock exchange rethinks corporate governance rules
summary: New Zealand's stock exchange, NZX, is reviewing its corporate governance rules, last updated over a decade ago, to address clarity issues and fragmentation in reporting regimes. The review aims to improve corporate governance standards. Submissions are open until January 29, with proposed rule changes to be released in the second quarter of 2026.

site_title: Singapore is world's top-ranked economy: Legatum Institute
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's top-ranked economy by the Legatum Institute, surpassing Switzerland, China, Norway, and Germany. The country's high productivity rate and strong export market contributed to its ranking. However, it ranks 38th globally in personal freedom and 25th in social capital. The Prosperity Index, which assesses 142 countries across eight categories, highlights Singapore's prosperity, entrepreneurship, and quality education and healthcare systems, but also notes areas for improvement.

site_title: China completes production of own passenger plane
summary: China has completed the production of its first domestic passenger plane, the C919, a narrow-body jet capable of seating 168 passengers. The plane, which has a range of up to 5,555km, is expected to make its maiden flight in 2016 or 2017 after being delayed from its original 2015 schedule. The C919 is part of China's efforts to reduce dependence on European consortium Airbus and Boeing, with orders for 517 planes from domestic and foreign buyers. Foreign firms supply systems and engines, with a financing deal worth $7.9 billion secured by the Chinese government.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.61% on Monday, following Wall Street's lower close on Friday. By 9:02 am, 59.9 million shares worth S$54.5 million changed hands. The top traded stocks included Singtel, DBS, and CapitaLand. This decline marks a reversal from the previous 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which saw the STI rise 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil prices decline in Asia on weak China manufacturing
summary: Oil prices declined in Asia on Monday following data showing China's manufacturing sector shrank for the third straight month. US crude production fell 45,000 barrels per day in August, boosting hopes of easing global oversupply. Oil prices dropped 0.19 cents to $46.40 and 3 cents to $49.53 per barrel. This comes as China's economy, the world's second-largest, appears to be slowing down, with growth at 6.9% between July and September, and a manufacturing sector contraction. This may negatively impact oil market sentiments and restrict gains in the coming weeks.

site_title: Polaris flags loss for FY ending Dec 31
summary: Polaris expects to record a net loss for the FY ending Dec 31 due to its associate company PT Trikomsel Oke Tbk in Indonesia. The company attributed the loss to market challenges in Indonesia, including a depreciating rupiah and economic slowdown. Trikomsel will implement cost-reduction initiatives to improve its liquidity and profitability. Despite the expected loss, Polaris remains "favourable" in its Asian operations, particularly in Singapore, and remains open to growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: News Corp property website to buy out rival for US$414m to gain Asia presence
summary: News Corp's REA Group Ltd plans to acquire iProperty Group Ltd in Southeast Asia for A$580 million, gaining a foothold in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Hong Kong. The deal would give REA exposure to growing Asian property markets, benefiting from mobile and internet adoption. REA shares rose 1.3% and iProperty shares jumped 11% following the announcement. The acquisition is expected to be put to a shareholder vote in January, with Citigroup advising REA on the deal.

site_title: HSBC profit rises 32% in third quarter, exceeding estimates
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc, Europe's largest bank, reported a 32% increase in third-quarter profit to $6.1 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The jump was driven by a decline in fines and settlements, which fell $1.4 billion from last year. HSBC also cut operating expenses by 19% to $9 billion. The bank is assessing its global network and considering a potential move of its headquarters away from London, with a decision possibly not made this year.

site_title: The Ascott signs four new management contracts in China
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence arm, The Ascott, has signed four new management contracts in China for 583 units, expanding its presence in the country. The contracts are for properties in Shanghai and Beijing, with Ascott's total units in China reaching over 14,300. The move strengthens Ascott's position as the largest international serviced residence owner-operator in China, with Chinese domestic travellers accounting for 30% of its business. The contracts are part of Ascott's strategy to capitalize on China's growing tourism and business sectors.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil prices drop on China demand worries
summary: Oil prices dropped in early Asian trading on Monday due to concerns over weaker demand from China. Benchmark US crude futures fell 41 cents to $46.18 per barrel, while Brent futures declined 23 cents to $49.33 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to China's slowing economic growth and reduced oil demand growth for September, which fell 2.1% from the same period last year. This suggests moderate demand ahead, according to Barclays.

site_title: Singtel's Optus wins exclusive broadcast and digital rights to Barclays Premier League
summary: Singtel's Optus has secured the exclusive Australian rights to the Barclays Premier League for three seasons, starting in August 2016. The deal includes live broadcast coverage and digital rights for all 380 Premier League games. Optus CEO Allen Lew stated that this is a significant step in the company's strategy to become a mobile-led multimedia company, ensuring Aussie football fans can watch the world's most popular football league.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China arrests HK-owned fund executives for futures manipulation: Xinhua
summary: China has arrested two executives from a Hong Kong-owned fund, Yishidun, and a technical supervisor at China Fortune Futures, for allegedly manipulating futures markets. The executives, Gao Yan and Liang Ze, and Jin Wenxian, were arrested for making over 2 billion yuan (S$442 million) in irregular trades using software that could execute up to 32 contracts in one second. The case is part of China's intensified probes into market manipulation since its stock market plunged in mid-June, with several journalists, executives, and regulators already under investigation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.64 points to 1665.30. The market saw 64.4 million lots traded worth RM17.7 million, with 117 gainers and 63 losers.

site_title: IMF pushes Europe for formal restructuring accord on Greek debt
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is pushing European countries to agree on a formal restructuring of Greece's debt before lending new money to the country. IMF Deputy Managing Director David Lipton stated that a debt operation agreed between Greece and its creditors is necessary for the IMF to proceed. The restructuring must include specific terms for reducing the borrowing burden, such as lower interest rates and longer loan maturities. The IMF has set four priorities for a new program: implementing policy pledges, fiscal structural policies, fixing the banking sector, and addressing the debt.

site_title: Australia's Westpac cash profit rise 3% to a record
summary: Westpac Banking Corp reported a 3% rise in annual cash profit to a record A$7.8 billion, driven by growth in mortgages. The bank's pre-earnings move to raise A$3.5 billion to meet stricter capital rules and push home loan rates higher to protect profits. This is part of a broader trend of Australia's four major banks preparing for their slowest earnings growth since the global financial crisis due to record low interest rates and a cooling economy.

site_title: Russian jet broke up in mid air, too early for conclusions, official says
summary: A Russian airliner, Metrojet, crashed in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula on Saturday, killing all 224 people on board. The Airbus A321 broke apart in mid-air, with fragments scattered over 20 square kilometers. Russian authorities have ordered the jet to be grounded until the cause of the crash is known. Egyptian analysts are examining the plane's black boxes, while Russian experts are helping identify and transport the bodies. The crash is linked to Russia's airstrikes in Syria, with Islamic State claiming responsibility. An investigation is ongoing, and it may take months to determine the cause of the crash.

site_title: South Korea, Japan hold long-awaited summit
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe held their first summit in nearly four years, marking a significant step towards a more pragmatic partnership. The meeting comes after a series of diplomatic efforts by both countries, prompted by their shared ally the US. While the summit may not fully mend the deep-seated mistrust, it aims to create a normal channel for dialogue and pave the way for more working-level discussions on trade and security issues, particularly in regards to North Korea. Expectations are tempered, with analysts focusing on incremental progress rather than major breakthroughs.

site_title: Honda recalls 2016 CR-Vs over new Takata airbag defect
summary: Honda is recalling 515 2016 CR-V models due to a new Takata airbag defect, where the inflator could rupture and cause metal fragments to hit occupants, resulting in serious injury or death. The recall, related to a manufacturing defect, was discovered after a test at Takata's Mexico factory. This is the latest in a larger recall involving over 19 million vehicles made by 12 carmakers, with 23 million defective inflators needing replacement.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks mostly flat, Powertech off after early surge
summary: Taiwan's stocks were mostly flat on Monday, with the TAIEX index unchanged at 8,552.97, following downbeat sentiment in overseas markets. The electronics subindex rose 0.1%, while the financials subindex lost 0.3%. Shares in Powertech Technology fell 0.4% after a surge in early trading due to a potential stake acquisition by China's Tsinghua Unigroup. Meanwhile, Inotera Memories' shares dropped 0.8% after replacing its Chairman Charles Kau, who joined a Chinese group trying to purchase a stake in Micron Technology.

site_title: The numbers behind Japan Post's IPO, the biggest since Alibaba's
summary: Japan Post's initial public offering (IPO) on November 4 will be the largest this year and the biggest since Alibaba's 2014 IPO, raising 1.44 trillion yen (approximately $12 billion). The IPO is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal to encourage individual investment, but the three Japan Post companies face challenges, including universal service obligations and declining mail volumes. The IPO's success is seen as crucial for future offerings, and the company's banking unit has a low book value of 0.47 times, making it cheaper than Japan's three largest banks.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge stays tame in Oct: TDMI
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge showed prices remained unchanged in October, with the annual pace at 1.8%, below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. This soft inflation data fueled speculation the central bank might cut interest rates at its November 3 meeting, but most analysts doubt a rate cut is imminent. The data showed price rises in tobacco, newspaper, and utilities, offset by falls in fruit and vegetables. Core inflation measures were also subdued, with the trimmed mean measure of the CPI flat in the month.

site_title: mm2 Asia acquires two cinemas in Malaysia from Cathay Cineplexes
summary: SINGAPORE-BASED mm2 Asia acquired two cinemas in Malaysia from Cathay Cineplexes for RM40 million (S$13.1 million) on Nov 1. The cinemas, Cathay Cineplex Damansara and Cathay Cineplex City Square, have 30 screens and 5,298 seats. mm2 Asia expects a "substantial contribution" from its cinema business with upcoming Hollywood blockbusters, including year-end and Chinese New Year holidays. This acquisition is part of the group's expansion plans in the regional market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 'Smart beta' ETFs popular in US, little known in S'pore
summary: Smart beta ETFs, which use alternative weighting methods beyond market capitalization, have gained popularity in the US but remain relatively unknown in Singapore. Industry insiders express reservations about their construction and sustainability, citing potential risks and the need for further testing. Despite this, proponents argue that smart beta can deliver better performance and diversification, with some firms, such as Tobam and BlackRock, investing heavily in these products. However, critics question the long-term viability and cost-effectiveness of smart beta ETFs, which often come with higher fees.

site_title: No treat for soldier in suicide bomber costume at US Army base
summary: A US soldier attempted to enter Fort Bragg Army base in North Carolina dressed as a suicide bomber for Halloween, prompting a security alert and search for explosives. The incident resulted in a brief closure of the gate as explosive technicians cleared the site. The base removed a Facebook post about the incident due to profane comments. It is unclear if the soldier will face charges. This incident highlights the ongoing security concerns at Fort Bragg, which has experienced violence in the past.

site_title: Joy and anguish greet AKP win in Turkey vote
summary: Turkey's Justice and Development Party (AKP) won a surprise parliamentary majority with around 50% of the vote, enough to take around 315 seats in the 550-member parliament, returning to single-party rule. The victory was met with both joy and anguish, with many fearing an escalation of the country's military campaign against Kurdish rebels and authoritarian policies. Violence erupted in the main Kurdish city of Diyarbakir, with clashes between police and Kurdish youths. Analysts say the result gives President Recep Tayyip Erdogan a clear mandate to pursue his agenda, which critics describe as increasingly authoritarian.

site_title: China Oct Caixin factory PMI shrinks again but at slower pace
summary: China's factory activity fell for an eighth straight month in October, but at a slower pace, according to the Caixin/Markit China Manufacturing Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI). The PMI edged up to 48.3 in October from 47.2 in September, indicating a contraction in activity. The reading is the highest since June 2015, sparking hopes that the industry's slump may be bottoming out, but it remains below the 50 mark, fueling doubts about a modest pick-up in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Corked? Fine wines languish in China warehouses as consumers cool
summary: China's wine market has experienced a slowdown, with wine consumption expected to grow only 1% annually until 2020. This has led to an oversupply of wine, causing many importers to cut prices and struggle to sell their inventory. The Chinese government's crackdown on corruption and a decrease in consumer spending have also contributed to the decline. As a result, many wine importers are facing financial losses, with some even selling their wine at below-cost prices. This trend may benefit more affordable New World wines, which are gaining market share in China.

site_title: A huge El Nino is spreading mayhem worldwide
summary: A powerful El Nino event is affecting global weather patterns, causing droughts, floods, and commodity price fluctuations worldwide. Dominating weather patterns through the end of 2015 and into 2016, El Nino has triggered Pacific typhoons, reduced water levels in Vietnamese reservoirs, and led to lower milk production in Argentina. The phenomenon is expected to cause "major disruptions, widespread droughts and floods" and could lead to significant economic losses. With advance warning, El Nino can be managed, but without it, widespread mayhem is likely.

site_title: India's choked capital starts 'pollution toll' for trucks
summary: India's capital, New Delhi, has introduced a toll for all trucks and commercial vehicles to improve air quality ahead of Diwali celebrations. The toll, approved by the Supreme Court, aims to reduce pollution by nearly a third, attributed to lorries. The move, which charges light commercial vehicles 700 rupees and large trucks 1,300 rupees to enter the city, aims to curb pollution but faces concerns over enforcement and potential diversion of traffic.

site_title: Australia home price growth cools in Oct: RP Data
summary: Australian home prices experienced a slowdown in October, with a 0.2% increase in capital cities, according to CoreLogic RP Data. Annual growth in home values decreased to 10.1%, with Sydney's median price reaching $800,000, a 15.6% increase from the same period last year. Regulators have tightened lending standards and mortgage rates, contributing to the market cooling. Cities like Brisbane and Perth saw price declines, while Adelaide experienced a 1.5% gain. The slowdown aims to curb price growth and maintain a more stable market.

site_title: DBS reports Q3 net profit of S$1.07 billion, up 6% after a S$50 million charge
summary: DBS Group reported a net profit of S$1.07 billion for the third quarter of 2015, up 6% from the same period last year. Total income rose 8% and net interest income reached a record S$1.81 billion, with a four-year high net interest margin of 1.78%. A one-time charge of S$50 million was taken for the adoption of funding valuation adjustment to the fair value of derivatives. Adjusting for the charge, net profit would have risen 10% from last year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Target revives free holiday delivery to edge past Walmart
summary: Target Corp is reviving its free holiday delivery policy, offering free shipping and returns on all items starting November 1, in an effort to edge past Walmart, which is discouraging online shoppers to pick up items at brick-and-mortar stores. This move comes as more consumers shift to online shopping, and retailers face a dilemma between free shipping and in-store impulse buys. The strategy is expected to attract holiday shoppers, with Target's shares up 1.7% for the year, while Walmart's shares have lost a third of their value.

site_title: US tech giants' China deals raise security risks
summary: US tech giants, including IBM, Cisco Systems, and Microsoft, are partnering with Chinese companies that have ties to the Chinese military, raising security concerns. These partnerships, which share commercial technologies, have become critical to defense and could help China's military research and operations. A report by Defense Group Inc, a security firm, found that IBM's partnerships in China are damaging US national security. Experts say the issue is tricky, as cooperation is a natural outgrowth of globalization, and limiting US companies' work could damage their competitiveness. The US government operates on the principle that companies should not sell advanced technology that can be put to military use.

site_title: China likely to export more aluminium despite low prices
summary: China, the world's top aluminium producer, is likely to export more aluminium despite low prices, adding to global trade tensions. China exported a record 3.1 million tonnes of aluminium in the first nine months of the year, with prices hitting six-year lows. Analysts attribute the surge in exports to cheaper power prices offered by the Chinese government, which is making it easier for smelters to operate. This move is expected to heat up competition with global producers and increase tensions with countries like the US and Russia.

site_title: Most Gulf carriers re-route flights over Sinai after Russian crash
summary: Most Gulf carriers re-routed flights over Egypt's Sinai Peninsula after a Russian aircraft carrying 224 passengers crashed on Saturday. The carriers, including UAE, Qatar, Bahrain, and Kuwait, took the precautionary measure due to a militant group's claim of bringing down the plane in response to Russian air strikes. German carriers Lufthansa and Air France-KLM also avoided flying over the peninsula, while Etihad Airways will continue to fly over Sinai but avoid certain areas. Re-routing will add to fuel costs and may impact flight schedules.

site_title: Combined monetary, fiscal big bang likely by BOJ in Nov
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to implement a combined fiscal and monetary stimulus package in November to boost Japan's economy, which is struggling to achieve its inflation target. The move would mark a shift in the BOJ's strategy from focusing on inflation to promoting broader economic growth. This decision comes as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seeks to increase Japan's GDP by 20% to 600 trillion yen, a goal he announced earlier. The BOJ's actions are seen as a response to Abe's bid to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Zero rate policy comes with a cost
summary: The Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee stated that global financial conditions have stabilized since late summer, but acknowledged weaker US data, including slowing labor markets and soft export activity. This has raised concerns about the prospects for rate normalization, with a rough probability of over 50% for an initial rate hike at the December meeting. The Fed's employment mandate has been met, with a low unemployment rate, but inflation remains below the target 2% level, hurting low-end households. A zero-interest rate policy comes with a cost, subsidizing borrowers and hurting savers.

site_title: Bacon lovers take WHO report with pinch of salt; futures swallow wholesale
summary: The World Health Organization's report linking processed meat to colorectal cancer has sparked public backlash, with many consumers expressing support for bacon and sausage on social media. Despite this, industry analysts note that the impact on the US meat industry and retail market is unclear, with prices for pork bellies falling to their lowest level since July due to seasonal factors and oversupply. The WHO report's suggestion that cutting consumption can reduce the risk of colorectal cancer has not yet been reflected in consumer or retail market data, and the meat industry's response remains uncertain.

site_title: NY Halloween show sees revellers dress as Trump and bacon
summary: Thousands attended New York City's giant Halloween Parade, celebrating creativity and style. The 42nd edition featured a range of costumes, including Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, Mets hats, and bacon-themed attire. Despite warnings about the health risks of bacon, it remained a popular choice. The event was described as a "bonanza of pure creativity" and "the ultimate creative expression." Participants included a pediatrician dressed as Trump, a couple dressed as New York cops, and a couple celebrating their first parade as newlyweds.

site_title: 1MDB says offers for unit close to asking price
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) said offers for its energy unit, Edra Global Energy, are close to its asking price of RM16 billion to RM18 billion. The unit's debt is included in the offers, with Tenaga Nasional Bhd and at least two other bidders interested in acquiring the assets. Despite allegations of financial irregularities, 1MDB has consistently met its debt obligations. The Malaysian government will decide on any foreign ownership restrictions, with 100% overseas ownership seen as acceptable by 1MDB president Arul Kanda.

site_title: Holograms are going mainstream, with the future full of possibility
summary: Holograms, three-dimensional light projections, are becoming mainstream in the entertainment industry. Concert promoters have used holograms to revive deceased artists like Tupac Shakur, Michael Jackson, and Whitney Houston. The technology records light fields, allowing for a 3D presentation. Companies like Hologram USA and Pulse Evolution are planning tours and productions featuring holograms of these artists. However, some experts question the long-term appeal of holograms, citing concerns about the "uncanny valley" effect and the potential for novelty to wear off.

site_title: Second 'gin craze' sweeping London
summary: London is experiencing a revival of the gin industry, with sales of premium gin rising 49% over the past two years. The city is home to numerous distilleries and dedicated bars, such as Ladies and Gentlemen, which produces 12 bottles of gin a day. The industry's growth has been driven by a trend for "craft" products, and the market is now worth £345 million. Experts predict a second "Gin Craze" after the drink's first boom in the 18th century, with the government considering tax breaks to encourage further growth.

site_title: India on track to rival China's economic growth
summary: India's GDP growth in Q1 and Q2 reached 7.5% and 7% respectively, surpassing China's growth pace. The growth is attributed to new Prime Minister Narendra Modi's pro-business policies, including increased foreign investment caps and a proposed 25% corporate tax rate. Falling oil prices have also stabilized India's current account deficit, which is now less than 2% of its GDP. Modi's administration is also pushing for a common goods and services tax, which could further boost trade and foreign investments.

site_title: Jury still out on Juncker's 'last chance' EU Commission as crises continue
summary: European Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker's efforts to revitalize the EU have been hindered by ongoing crises, including the migrant and Greek debt crises. Despite his efforts to be more "political" and proactive, his plans have failed to gain widespread support from EU member states. The Juncker Commission's actions have also created friction with other EU leaders, particularly Donald Tusk, and have led to concerns about centralization and the marginalization of his commissioners. The EU's economic growth and unity plans have stalled, and Juncker's vow to restore confidence in Europe remains unfulfilled.

site_title: Emerging markets attractive with valuations down: Oaktree's Marks
summary: Debt investor Howard Marks, co-founder of Oaktree Capital Management, says emerging markets are attractive due to corrected valuations and a bright long-term outlook, despite uncertainty over China's commodity demand. Marks believes the US economy is "through the period of easy bounceback" but faces a grind-out period of growth. He also notes a bond bubble, but high-yield bonds are relatively inexpensive compared to other bonds. Marks warns of the potential for a geopolitical scare to tighten markets, but expects no imminent debt crisis.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of below-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen green and transition finance cooperation. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while CGS-CIM downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth.

site_title: Parental wisdom for success
summary: Successful business leaders share that their parents' indirect advice, often based on their strengths and passions, led them to their current careers. Examples include Philip Jeyaretnam's father advising him to pursue law, Eric Sin's parents encouraging him to "run it like it's your own business," and Rohit Gandhi's parents advising him to be entrepreneurial. Many leaders emphasize the importance of integrity, humility, hard work, and determination in their success. They also highlight the value of learning from others, embracing challenges, and staying adaptable in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: Japan Post's market debut this week seen as test of Tokyo's reforms
summary: Japan Post, the country's largest postal service provider, made its market debut this week with a record-breaking initial public offering (IPO) of over $11.5 billion. The move is seen as a test of Tokyo's reforms aimed at shaking up the country's rigid corporate culture and attracting foreign investors. The IPO is part of the government's privatization efforts, with proceeds earmarked for reconstruction efforts and social welfare costs. Analysts expect the listing to boost interest in investing in Japan, but also warn of potential risks, including slowing global growth and market volatility.

site_title: China's PMI stabilises in October
summary: China's official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) remained at 49.8 in October, unchanged from September but below economists' expectations of a slight rebound. This marks the third straight month of negative territory, indicating a contraction in manufacturing activity. The services sector, which has been supporting GDP growth, expanded at its slowest pace in seven years. Despite the government's efforts to stimulate the economy with interest rate cuts and increased liquidity, factories continue to struggle due to low commodity prices and oversupply.

site_title: Deezer's IPO deferment shows investors' doubts
summary: Deezer, a French music streaming company, postponed its initial public offering (IPO) citing "market conditions", sending a signal of investors' doubts about its economic model. Despite a 53% revenue jump to €142 million last year, Deezer is still not profitable. The company's reliance on music recording companies for content and tie-ups with mobile operators also raised concerns. The postponement follows a crowded market with competitors like Spotify and Apple Music, and analysts question whether streaming services can turn profitable.

site_title: Airbnb rings up US$451.4m revenue in NY in a year
summary: Airbnb generated US$451.4 million in revenue in New York City in 2015, accounting for 7.8% of overnight stays, according to a report by the Hotel Association of New York City. The industry expects this number to jump to US$805.3 million in 2018. Hotels brought in a larger portion of sales, 95% of gross revenue, but the report estimates a loss of US$88.9 million in hotel food spending and US$1 billion in construction activity.

site_title: Lights out in Britain for underground coal mining
summary: The last deep coal mine in Britain, Kellingley Colliery, is set to close in December, marking the end of an enterprise spanning over two centuries that helped make Britain an industrial power. The mine's closure is due to pressure from cheaper imported coal, despite efforts by the miners to resist. The closure of Kellingley is a blow to Yorkshire, where coal mining engendered a strong sense of identity and camaraderie among miners. The National Union of Mineworkers, which once had significant influence in British politics, has seen its clout diminish over the decades.

site_title: Seventh heaven for gutsy Radwanska at WTA Finals
summary: Agnieszka Radwanska won the BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals presented by SC Global, defeating Petra Kvitova 6-2, 4-6, 6-3 in a three-set thriller. The 26-year-old Pole, ranked sixth, broke down in tears after the match, which was her first WTA Finals title and the biggest of her 10-year career. Radwanska's victory marked a first in the tournament's 43-year history, as she won the title after losing two matches in the round robin stage.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Keeping the bad directors at bay
summary: Companies and their shareholders should ensure they renew their boards and continually scrutinize them to prevent corporate failures and scandals. Weak boards and non-performing directors have been linked to major corporate failures, including Lehman Brothers' 2008 collapse, the Satyam scandal in India, and accounting scandals at Olympus and Toshiba in Japan. A culture of complacency and lack of moral courage among directors can lead to poor governance and ultimately, financial disaster. Renewing and scrutinizing boards can help prevent such failures and ensure that directors exercise sufficient diligence and responsibility in their stewardship of the company.

site_title: SGX eyes bigger slice of the booming ETF market pie
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) aims to tap into the growing exchange-traded fund (ETF) market, which is booming globally. To attract investors, SGX has launched educational campaigns, waived clearing fees, and allowed unqualified investors to trade more ETFs on its platform. Industry players suggest introducing an S-Reit ETF and addressing the perception of illiquidity to increase its market share.

site_title: Starbucks lags market calls on Q1 profit
summary: Starbucks reported a Q1 profit forecast that missed analysts' estimates, with earnings expected to be 44-45 US cents a share, down from 47 US cents. The company is investing in technology and employee benefits, including mobile ordering and college-tuition benefits, which are expected to continue next year with increased spending. Despite the miss, Starbucks shares have gained 53% this year, and analysts praise the company's focus on technology, calling it a "great investment."

site_title: Analysts warn of pitfalls as easy money sparks big M&A boom
summary: A massive M&A boom is underway, with US$1.2 trillion in mergers and acquisitions in the first nine months of the year, a 89% increase from the same period last year. Easy money and low interest rates are fueling the trend, with companies seeking to grow through acquisitions rather than organic growth. Analysts warn that hastily arranged mergers can end in tears, citing examples such as the failed AOL-Time Warner merger. Despite the risks, big mergers appear to be back for a while, with major deals including Pfizer's acquisition of Allergan and Anheuser-Busch InBev's bid for SABMiller.

site_title: The end of the bounce?
summary: Morgan Stanley has revised its stance on emerging markets, stating that the bounce has run its course due to reached targets and a poor earnings season. The US investment bank now expects a range-bound market until the Federal Reserve meeting on December 16, with no new bull market. This contradicts its previous recommendation to "believe in the bounce" three weeks ago.

site_title: China market hit trough in Q3, says UBS hedge fund
summary: China's market hit its trough in Q3, according to Dawn Fitzpatrick, global head and chief investment officer of UBS's hedge fund unit. This marks a significant recovery from the recent volatility, setting hedge funds apart from those solely riding beta trends. Fitzpatrick attributes the turnaround to the market's ability to absorb and respond to shocks, distinguishing it from idiosyncratic risk.

site_title: Search for yield to hold EM debt steady
summary: A moderately hawkish Federal Reserve may stall a recovery in emerging market currencies, but the global search for yield will likely keep dollar-denominated emerging market debt from retreating in price substantially. Emerging market currencies have fallen 40% since 2013, but dollar-denominated debt has risen 3% year-to-date, with spreads to US Treasuries still wider than historical averages. Global liquidity, supported by a dovish European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, is expected to remain high, reducing the odds for a relapse into systemic EM concerns.

site_title: Oxley's Phnom Penh project more than 50% taken up
summary: Oxley Holdings has sold over 50% of its 507 residential units in Tower 1 of The Peak, a 55-storey mixed-use development in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The project, launched in September 2015, offers a range of units and guarantees a 12% net rental return for two years. Construction is expected to begin in 2016 and be completed in 2020. The Peak shares an address with a Shangri-La Hotel and is located in the heart of Phnom Penh, near the Mekong River.

site_title: A digital platform to move capital efficiently
summary: LinkedIn's mission is to make professionals more productive and create an economic graph showcasing global economic opportunities. The platform's business streams are divided into three segments: talent solutions, marketing solutions, and premium subscriptions. With 8 out of 10 Singaporean professionals having a profile, LinkedIn curates individual data, in addition to company data. The company aims to achieve this through its vision, while its business segments cater to various needs of professionals and companies.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: S Korea, Japan and China to improve economic ties
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang agreed to improve economic ties, aiming to conclude a 16-nation free trade area and a three-way free trade deal. The leaders also pledged to strengthen cooperation and create new growth momentum, despite historical tensions between Japan and South Korea. The agreement is seen as a diplomatic breakthrough, with China playing a key role in promoting the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. The meeting comes amid efforts to ease tensions in the region, including North Korea's nuclear program.

site_title: Expect gradual weakness in EM currencies
summary: A surprise from the Fed has put December lift-off expectations back on the table, potentially triggering a sustained bid for the US dollar against emerging market currencies. However, investors may be selective in taking bearish exposure in low-yielding currencies, and yields in Asia may grind higher but remain within recent ranges. Developed market equities are expected to outperform emerging market equities, with European equities potentially benefiting from dovish policy and the US easing concerns over negative spillovers. The US dollar's strength against EM currencies is likely to be gradual and orderly, cushioned by expectations of a dovish Fed lift-off and stable China markets.

site_title: Two firms report changes in overseas portfolios
summary: Two Singapore-listed companies, Saizen Reit and Oxley Holdings, have reported changes in their overseas portfolios. Saizen Reit will sell its Japanese assets to Triangle TMK for 44.7 billion yen (S$518.3 million), while Oxley Holdings has sold over 50% of units in Phase 1 of its Phnom Penh project, The Peak. The deals are expected to be completed in 2016 and 2020, respectively.

site_title: Indirect ownership of ETFs on the cards
summary: BlackRock is creating dividend-oriented exchange-traded funds (ETFs) for Asian clients, which can be offered through investment-linked insurance policies. These funds may include a mix of equities and bonds, with management fees under 0.3-0.4% per year. The company plans to distribute these products to banks in Singapore within 12 months, marking a potential shift towards indirect ownership of ETFs. Existing private banks already use ETFs as underlying vehicles for more sophisticated products, such as leveraged participation notes.

site_title: Two condos launched over weekend notch 60% sales
summary: Two new condominiums, Principal Garden and Thomson Impressions, have seen 60% of their units sold over the first weekend of their launch. Principal Garden, a 663-unit development, sold 60% of its units at an average price of above S$1,600 psf. Thomson Impressions, a 288-unit project, saw 58% of its units sold, with the two-bedroom units being the most popular. Developers UOL Group and Kheng Leong expect to release more units to meet strong demand.

site_title: All Black 'zombies' party after big win
summary: Thousands of All Black fans in Wellington celebrated New Zealand's historic 34-17 World Cup final win over Australia, with the victory prompting jubilant parties and cheers. The game, which was played at 5am due to time zone issues, saw thousands of supporters pour out of pubs, despite some struggling with exhaustion. Prime Minister John Key praised the team's achievement, and fans expressed pride in the All Blacks' record third World Cup victory, which is seen as a testament to the country's rugby culture.

site_title: New York's autumn art sales tipped at bumper US$2b
summary: New York's autumn art sales are expected to reach US$2 billion, with Christie's and Sotheby's auctioning hundreds of modern, impressionist, post-war, and contemporary art pieces. The sales, set to take place from Nov 4-12, include works by artists such as Picasso, Modigliani, Lichtenstein, and Van Gogh. The auction is fueled by demand from Asia and the Gulf, with some pieces expected to fetch record-breaking prices, including Modigliani's Reclining Nude valued at US$100 million and Lichtenstein's Nurse estimated at US$80 million.

site_title: Radwanska beats Kvitova to win WTA Finals
summary: Agnieszka Radwanska won the WTA Finals in Singapore, defeating Petra Kvitova 6-2, 4-6, 6-3 in a two-hour and five-minute match. Radwanska, a 26-year-old Pole, was a last-minute qualifier and won her first major title. She dominated the first set but lost the second before coming back to win the deciding set. Radwanska was overcome with emotion after the victory, calling it "the best" moment of her career.

site_title: US technology exports used in spying face scrutiny
summary: US technology exports, particularly those with dual-use capabilities, face scrutiny for potential use in spying and human rights abuses. The Obama administration has pursued a few cases to limit authoritarian governments' access to surveillance technology, but the issue remains contentious due to its dual-use nature. The tech industry opposes stricter regulations, arguing they would hinder the sale of technology to protect and secure networks. The administration plans to issue a new regulation after consultation with the industry, but critics argue lax restrictions allow repressive countries to exploit the technology.

site_title: Russia grounds carrier's A321s following Egypt crash: report
summary: Russia grounds all Airbus A321 jets operated by Kogalymavia, a Russian airline, following the crash of its Metrojet flight in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, which killed 224 people. The Russian transport regulator has ordered the grounding, but Kogalymavia claims it received no such order. Egyptian and Russian investigators will examine the "black box" recorders recovered from the crash site, which was likely brought down by a militant group affiliated with Islamic State. The cause of the crash remains unknown, but Russia's Transport Minister denies the group's claim that it was in response to Russian airstrikes in Syria.

site_title: UK's scandal-hit Lords enjoy rare day in sun
summary: The UK's House of Lords, a scandal-hit chamber, held a series of votes that forced Prime Minister David Cameron's government to rethink its austerity drive, including a £4.4 billion cut to tax credits. The government claims the Lords exceeded its powers, but Labour dismisses it as a "smokescreen" to hide the government's embarrassment. A review of the Lords' powers, chaired by Conservative Lord Tom Strathclyde, will focus on limiting the ability to vote down finance-related legislation, with the aim of improving stability in Parliament.

site_title: Palette of gutsy Italian fare
summary: Beppe De Vito's new restaurant, Aura, has opened at the National Gallery in Singapore, offering luxurious Italian cuisine in a stunning setting. The two-level restaurant features opulent decor and a rooftop view, with prices that cater to both high-end and average diners. The menu boasts generous portions, including pastas, appetizers, and mains, with some standout dishes like the spicy pasta taglioni and braised oxtail ragu. While the food may not be sublime, Aura's value-for-money and accessible Italian cuisine make it a worthwhile experience, earning a rating of 7.

site_title: Market recovery gets a boost from the Fed
summary: US stocks rallied last week, with the S&P 500 rising 8.3% in October, its largest monthly return in four years. The Fed's statement suggested a lasting market recovery, boosting confidence. However, third-quarter profits shrank 3.6% due to the oil crash, affecting energy and commodity companies. Despite this, deal activity has picked up, with Pfizer reportedly considering a $120 billion bid for Allergan. The Fed's decision not to raise interest rates and the dollar's strength are seen as contributing factors to the market's resilience, with many experts predicting the bull market will continue.

site_title: Denka to invest more in S-E Asia to boost foreign sales
summary: Japanese specialty chemical firm Denka plans to invest more in Southeast Asia, with Singapore being a key location due to its efficient infrastructure and logistics. The company aims to boost foreign sales to at least half of its overall revenue by 2017. Denka has already established a strong presence in Singapore, with four plants generating $600 million in sales last year, and plans to expand its operations there. The company's focus on research and development, particularly in life sciences, is expected to drive future growth.

images.alt_text: Mr Yoshitaka said "each time we pick an investment location, we study the value add and choose the most competitive location".

site_title: NY condo builders target less-wealthy amid market turmoil
summary: Hong Kong developer Neo Que Yau's Euro Properties is building a $160 million condo tower in Manhattan, targeting less-wealthy Chinese buyers with prices starting at $5 million. The 500-foot tower, designed by Soo K Chan, will feature large, luxurious units priced between $3 million and $7 million, which are seen as a "sweet spot" for the market. The project aims to capitalize on the growing demand from Chinese investors seeking affordable US real estate, with properties priced at $1,800 to $2,500 per square foot in high demand.

site_title: S. Korea, China, Japan put hostility aside at rare summit
summary: South Korea, China, and Japan held a rare summit, marking the first in over three years, with the leaders agreeing to put aside historical animosities and work together on regional trade and security. The 90-minute meeting focused on free trade, North Korea's nuclear program, and the threat of ballistic missile technology. The leaders expressed their "firm opposition" to nuclear development and vowed to denuclearize the Korean peninsula. A trilateral free-trade agreement was also discussed, and the summit was seen as a symbolic statement of intent to mend strained ties between the three nations.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open lower after profits report
summary: Shanghai stocks fell 0.52% on Friday, following a profits report that added to concerns about China's economy. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 3,616.54, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.62% to 2,311.22. In contrast, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rose 0.30% to 22,555.42. The decline in Shanghai stocks was likely due to the mixed economic data, which may have raised concerns about the country's economic growth.

site_title: Fiat's unique woes: Airbags may deploy without crash
summary: Fiat Chrysler has recalled 1.8 million vehicles in the US due to a chronic airbag problem where the airbags may deploy without an accident. The issue has been ongoing since 2012, and the latest recall affects 2003 Jeep Liberty and 2004 Jeep Grand Cherokee models, including 284,000 in the US. The company has issued several recalls since 2012, highlighting the unique woes of its airbag system.

site_title: IHH Healthcare posts 19% fall in Q3 net profit on unrealised forex losses
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad reported a 19% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to RM118.5 million, primarily due to unrealised foreign exchange losses of RM217.1 million. Revenue rose 16% to RM2.06 billion, driven by growth at existing hospitals and new hospital openings. Operational profit after tax and minority interests grew 30% to RM210.9 million. The group expects to expand its footprint in India and China, but faces currency volatility and higher costs.

site_title: Independent advisory firms see opportunity despite tough M-E market
summary: Independent advisory firms in the Middle East, such as CH Stirling and Trussbridge Advisory, see opportunities in the challenging banking market, driven by the slump in oil prices and global bank layoffs. Despite concerns about a potential "shake out" of smaller boutiques, these firms plan to raise capital and expand staff, citing the need for quality independent advice in a more difficult market. With a focus on diversions and a relaxed work environment, CH Stirling aims to attract clients and recruits, while Trussbridge Advisory is backed by an Abu Dhabi sheikh.

site_title: Introduction to ETFs
summary: The article delves into the world of Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) in Singapore, highlighting their benefits as a cheap and transparent way to access the market. Despite efforts by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to encourage their trading, many Singapore investors remain unfamiliar with ETFs. The article aims to educate investors about the potential of ETFs and their growth in Asia and Europe, driven by retail investors.

site_title: Wheat hits biggest weekly gain in nearly four months
summary: US wheat futures prices rose 1.5% last week, their largest weekly gain in nearly four months, ahead of a highly anticipated USDA supply and demand report. Chicago Board of Trade December soft red wheat closed at $5.22 a bushel, its biggest daily price increase since October 7.
