The USDA report, scheduled for November 10, is expected to impact prices, with traders focusing on yield and production numbers. Better-than-expected demand for US supplies and forecasted rainfall also supported prices.

site_title: Egypt rescuers widen search for Russian plane crash victims
summary: Egyptian rescue teams are widening their search for victims of a Russian passenger plane crash in Sinai, finding 163 bodies out of 224 people on board the Airbus 321. The plane, carrying 214 Russian and 3 Ukrainian passengers, crashed after taking off from a Red Sea beach resort. Russian investigators have arrived in Cairo and will access the wreckage site to analyze the black box. Egypt and Russia have expressed skepticism about an Islamic State group claim of responsibility for the crash. The search area has been expanded to 15 square kilometers.

site_title: Thousands take to the streets in Taiwan in Asia's biggest gay parade
summary: Thousands of people in Taiwan took part in the 13th Taiwan LGBT Pride event, with approximately 78,000 marching through downtown Taipei to advocate for same-sex marriage. The event aimed to bring about a pro-gay government that would legalize same-sex marriage, with hopes that the upcoming presidential elections would bring about change. The parade featured rainbow flags, handmade placards, and costumes, including a group dressed as Sailor Moon characters, as well as a choir group singing in support of the cause.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices fall 0.1% in October
summary: Japan's consumer prices fell 0.1% in October, marking the third straight monthly decline, as core inflation declined. The decline was attributed to falling gasoline prices. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate improved to 3.1%, while household spending fell 2.4% year-on-year. The data was in line with analyst expectations.

site_title: Market may stay flat for the remaining year
summary: US stocks rose slightly last week ahead of the Federal Reserve's mid-December meeting. Analysts predict the market will remain flat for the remaining year if jobs and holiday sales reports meet the Fed's expectations. Consumer spending growth is expected to lag, but wages are rising due to a tightening labor market. Goldman Sachs predicts a bearish year in 2016, citing interest rate hikes, while Federated Investors' chief strategist Phil Orlando expects the market to finish the year at record highs as investors reconcile with rate hikes.

site_title: Hingis, Mirza seize ninth title at WTA Finals
summary: Martina Hingis and Sania Mirza won their ninth title at the WTA Finals in Singapore, defeating Garbine Muguruza and Carla Suarez Navarro 6-0, 6-3. The top seeds, who partnered in March, have won multiple titles including Wimbledon, the US Open, and Indian Wells. Hingis, 35, and Mirza, 28, ended the year as the world number one women's doubles team, with Hingis also securing her 50th doubles title and Mirza defending her title from last year.

site_title: Saizen Reit to sell all Japan assets to Triangle TMK for 44.7b yen
summary: Saizen Reit, a Japanese real estate investment trust, has accepted a 44.66 billion yen (S$518.3 million) offer from Triangle TMK to acquire all of its Japanese assets. The deal is at a 3.4% premium to the appraised value of the properties. The transaction is expected to be completed once HSBC Institutional Trust Services, the trustee of Saizen Reit, completes the necessary formalities. The sale marks a significant development in the Japanese real estate market, with Triangle TMK acquiring Saizen Reit's entire portfolio of properties in the country.

site_title: Macau gambling revenue falls 28.45% in October, 17th straight month of decline
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 28.45% in October, marking the 17th consecutive month of decline, as VIP gamblers stayed away due to China's anti-conspicuous spending campaign. Revenue fell to US$2.51 billion, down from US$3.44 billion in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's investigation into unauthorised money outflows.

site_title: China securities body finds 1t yuan error in Citic reports
summary: China's Securities Association of China (SAC) found that Citic Securities Co, the country's largest brokerage, overstated its financial derivatives by over 1 trillion yuan (S$220.1 billion) in monthly reports from April to September. The error was caused by a system upgrade and did not impact Citic's reported earnings. The SAC is investigating the matter but has not accused Citic of wrongdoing. Citic shares were largely unaffected by the announcement. The error emerged amid broader investigations into brokerage misdemeanors following China's stock market crash in the summer.

site_title: VW's Audi suspends two engineers in emissions probe
summary: Audi has suspended two engineers in an emissions probe related to its 3.0 litre V6 diesel engines, which were found to evade emissions limits in the US. The investigation, part of a broader scandal at parent company Volkswagen, has led to the ouster of its CEO and a 20 billion euro market value loss. Audi is investigating potential manipulation of emission-control devices by employees in technical development and other departments. This is the eighth official to be put on leave, including at least six senior individuals, amid a growing emissions scandal.

site_title: Why financial incentives fall short in driving employees
summary: Financial incentives often fail to drive employee motivation and performance, despite being widely used in companies. This is due to a misunderstanding of human behavior, rooted in psychology rather than economics. Research has shown that rewards and punishments can undermine intrinsic motivation, and that financial incentives can be counter-productive. To solve problems effectively, leaders must first define and understand them properly, rather than relying on oversimplified solutions. This highlights the need for a more nuanced approach to motivation and performance, one that takes into account the complexities of human behavior.

images.alt_text: A job seeker at a career fair in San Francisco. A Gallup poll showed only 31.5% of US workers were "engaged" in their jobs in 2014, 51% were "not engaged", and 17.5% were "actively disengaged".

site_title: China regulator orders brokerages to halt OTC swap lending: sources
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has ordered domestic brokerages to halt OTC swap lending, following a scandal involving CITIC Securities' $166 billion swap trading error blamed on an IT upgrade. The move comes after a discovery of the error, which CITIC Securities attributed to a technical issue. The CSRC did not comment on the matter.

site_title: China economy not responding to monetary, fiscal easing
summary: China's economy shows muted response to monetary and fiscal easing, with privately compiled PMI and sentiment indicators deteriorating in November. The manufacturing PMI fell to 42.4 and the non-manufacturing reading to 42.9, both below 50, indicating deteriorating conditions. The Baidu SME Index also slipped, signaling weaker momentum in small and medium-sized enterprises, which contribute 60% of China's economy. The government's growth goal may be missed for a second year if official data confirms the sluggishness.

site_title: German business morale unexpectedly rises in November
summary: German business morale unexpectedly rose to 109.0 in November, the strongest reading since June 2014, according to a survey by the Munich-based Ifo economic institute. This improvement comes despite weaker export prospects in emerging markets. The survey was conducted before the Paris attacks on November 13, and most responses were received before the incident. The reading surpassed the Reuters forecast of 108.2.

site_title: Orders for business equipment in US rise more than forecast
summary: US business equipment orders rose 1.3% in October, exceeding forecasts, driven by a strong domestic job market and consumer spending. This indicates steady corporate investment despite global sales waning. Shipments of non-military capital goods decreased 0.4% in October, but bookings for non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft jumped 3.2%. The data suggests businesses are investing in new equipment, with factories reducing inventory and average hourly earnings rising 2.5% in October, potentially making capital investment more attractive.

site_title: Leading with head, heart and guts
summary: Deutsche Post DHL's CEO Frank Appel, 54, has made a career of taking risks and switching between jobs, including from a PhD in neurobiology to management consultancy and eventually becoming the world's largest employer's CEO. He took over the reins in 2008, when the firm was facing operational headaches and a global financial crisis, and managed to turn the company around through a "realistic and pragmatic approach." Appel is optimistic about the future, focusing on the rising middle class in Asia and the potential of drones in disaster situations, but acknowledges the volatile economic backdrop and the need for flexibility.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher as yen eases after US data
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, following a broad Asian rally, as the US released upbeat data. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.49%, while the Topix index rose 0.48%. A weaker yen supported Japanese exporters. The gains came as investors looked past US trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Twelve Chinese hedge fund houses unreachable by phone, text, email
summary: China's Asset Management Association has failed to contact 12 domestic hedge fund companies, including Guotai Junan International Holdings Ltd, after trying to reach them through phone, email, and SMS. The association urged the 12 companies to contact them within five working days, or they will be classified as "missing". This comes as Chinese financial executives face increased regulatory pressure due to insider trading and other irregularities. The hedge fund industry has grown rapidly in recent years, but many lost heavily during the market crash in mid-June.

site_title: Rare, 25-carat pink diamond found in Imelda Marcos collection
summary: A 25-carat, rare, barrel-shaped pink diamond has been discovered among the jewelry collection of former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos, which is now being appraised by Christie's. The diamond, valued at $5 million, is one of only three pure, vivid pink diamonds of more than 10 carats to appear for sale in nearly 250 years. The Philippine government had previously tried to auction the collection in 2005, but Imelda Marcos contested the move, claiming ownership of only two sets. The collection, featuring Burmese rubies, Indian and South African diamonds, and Colombian emeralds, is estimated to be worth $6-$8 million.

site_title: 3 foreign banks buy up bulk of Indian state govt debt
summary: Three foreign banks - Nomura, Standard Chartered, and Bank of America Merrill Lynch - bought around 90% of Indian state bonds sold to foreigners in October, converting them into derivatives. This raises concerns about volatility in India's debt market. Foreigners have bought about $9.7 billion of debt so far this year, driving up domestic debt returns to 7.8%, the highest in Asia. India's central bank seeks to discourage "bond tourists" and maintain long-term investors, but a sharp sell-off could still impact the market.

site_title: Slow growth expected to continue next year: Schroders
summary: Schroders' chief economist Keith Wade forecasts 2.5% global GDP growth in 2016, down from 2.9%, citing slower US growth due to a stronger dollar. Economies are cautious after the 2008-9 financial crisis, with people hesitant to borrow again. Fund managers at Schroders, including Richard Sennitt, are buying relatively cheap Asian companies in sectors like materials and consumer discretionary, but are cautious about market volatility. The group also expects interest rate hikes in the US and a slowdown in China, but sees opportunities in energy and telcos.

site_title: China seeks to deepen ties with global accounting rules
summary: China has established a working group to deepen ties with global accounting rules, specifically the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). This move aims to meet the G20 goal of a single set of high-quality, global accounting rules. China's cooperation could reassure investors about the quality of accounts published by Chinese companies, addressing concerns that led to the US Securities and Exchange Commission de-registering dozens of Chinese companies. China will be fully involved in the development of IFRS standards.

site_title: Singapore averts technical recession: Q3 GDP up 1.9%, 2015 growth seen at close to 2%
summary: Singapore's economy averted a technical recession in Q3 2015 with a 1.9% quarterly growth rate, reversing a 2.6% contraction in Q2. The services sector, particularly wholesale & retail trade, drove the growth, while the manufacturing sector contracted 6.2% year-on-year. The government adjusted its 2015 growth forecast to "close to 2%," down from an earlier projection of 2-2.5%. The economy is expected to grow 1-3% in 2016, with a strengthening of global growth in advanced economies and emerging markets.

site_title: India said to mull tax incentives to spur investment in housing
summary: India may offer tax incentives to encourage investment in the housing sector, with Finance Minister Arun Jaitley asking the National Housing Bank to design a program. This move comes amid a slowdown in the economy, with India's growth target of 8% at risk. Home sales in India's top eight property markets fell 4% in the quarter through June, while unsold inventory rose 18%. The government aims to build 20 million houses by 2022 to meet demand from an urban population projected to swell to 600 million by 2031.

site_title: Hot stock: New Silkroutes opens trading at 0.1 Singapore cent
summary: New Silkroutes Group, formerly Digiland, opened trading at 0.1 Singapore cent after announcing Malta's Ministry of Energy and Health as a new shareholder in its joint venture IEG Malta, aiming to transform Malta into an oil and gas trading hub. The company also announced a change in ownership and stated it will fund its investment through internal resources.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: 1MDB sells off energy assets to China firm for RM9.83b
summary: 1MDB has sold its energy assets under Edra Global Energy Bhd to China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN) for RM9.83 billion, aiming to pare its estimated RM42-billion debt. The transaction is the largest announced merger-and-acquisition deal in Malaysia and the biggest in the Asian power sector. 1MDB will assume all relevant gross debt and cash, while CGN will take over the operating companies' assets. The deal is expected to be completed in February and is part of 1MDB's debt-rationalisation scheme, which also includes seeking development-equity partners and a debt-for-asset swap.

site_title: Companies with most to lose from damaged Russia-Turkey relations
summary: Russia and Turkey's relations have deteriorated significantly following Turkey's downing of a Russian jet along the Syrian border. Russia is a major source of Turkey's imports, with $25 billion in 2014, and Russian tourists account for 12% of Turkey's visitors. The incident has led to a sharp drop in stocks, the lira, and the rouble in emerging markets, with President Vladimir Putin calling it "a stab in the back." The worsening relations pose significant risks for companies with ties to both nations, including gas exporters and airlines.

site_title: ADIB mulls S'pore as hub for expansion
summary: Islamic banking giant Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank (ADIB) is considering expanding into Singapore as its potential hub for retail banking and trade finance, with the decision dependent on the viability of the market. ADIB, the world's fourth-largest Islamic bank by assets, aims to boost its trade finance business by offering investors greater access to the Middle East and North Africa region. The bank's CEO, Tirad Al-Mahmoud, noted that the Silk Road's trade potential in Asia is ancient and will continue, and ADIB plans to have a physical presence in Singapore, potentially through an acquisition, to tap into the vast opportunity of Islamic financing in Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Facebook 'safety check' at the ready after Paris attacks
summary: Facebook to activate "Safety Check" feature for more human disasters, following criticism over not using it for Paris and Beirut attacks. The social network will use the feature to help people signal they are safe after deadly attacks. Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged criticism, stating the company will work to help people suffering in other situations. The feature will be used for more human disasters, including natural disasters and humanitarian crises.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Singapore International Film Festival is set to kick off its 26th edition with the opening film "Panay," a Taiwanese coming-of-age drama that explores the indigenous family's efforts to save their ancestral land. The film, written and directed by Cheng Yu-chieh and Lekal Sumi, has received the Audience Choice award at the 2015 Taipei Film Festival. The festival will also feature the international premiere of Arcade Fire: The Reflektor Tapes, a documentary about the band's 2013 album and world tour.

site_title: Australia cuts potential GDP growth to 2.75% as population slows
summary: Australia's Treasury lowered its estimate of the economy's potential growth rate to 2.75% due to weaker population growth and fewer hours worked. This is down from the initial estimate of 3% and projected to fall further to 2.5% by 2050 as the population ages. The country's working-age population growth slowed to 1.5% over the year to June 2015, lower than expected. The cut in growth rate reflects the impact of a weakening economy and a commodity-price boom ending.

site_title: AIA, Konica Minolta launch digital health accelerator
summary: AIA Group Limited and Konica Minolta Inc have launched a 12-week digital health accelerator program in Singapore to develop an integrated healthcare system. The program, called the "AIA-Konica Minolta Digital Health Accelerator," will provide resources, expertise, and mentor networks to startups with innovative digital healthcare ideas. Up to 10 companies will participate in the program, which will culminate in a showcase in June 2016 to seek investor support. The program aims to address Singapore's estimated US$305 billion protection gap in healthcare and capitalize on the government's push towards a Smart Nation.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q3 profit more than doubles despite halving of revenue
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a net profit of US$17.7 million in the third quarter, more than doubling from US$7.3 million a year ago. Despite a 49.8% decline in revenue to US$2.4 billion due to lower jet fuel prices, CAO's cost of sales decreased, resulting in a gross profit of US$12.9 million. The company attributed its profitability to increased gains from jet fuel trading and lower losses from other oil products. CAO's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, expressed confidence in the company's growing strengths in the jet fuel market.

site_title: Singapore banks must innovate: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizes the need for banks to innovate in a competitive and rapidly evolving environment. Despite strong balance sheets, Singapore's banks can be surpassed in specific areas, and Lee cites China's success in mobile payments and emerging technologies like blockchain as examples. The liberalization of the financial sector in 1997 led to foreign banks entering the market, prompting local banks to consolidate and upgrade. Lee concludes that Singapore's strategy has led to strong and safest financial institutions, with a vibrant sector to be proud of.

site_title: SocGen will cut 2,000 jobs by 2020 as part of branch closures
summary: Societe Generale SA plans to cut 2,000 jobs, or 7% of its workforce, at its main French retail unit through 2020 as clients increasingly switch to online services. The lender aims to reduce its domestic network by 20% to 1,800 outlets and invest 1.5 billion euros in digital services. The job cuts will be achieved through staff retirements and other measures, with a focus on refocusing its branch setup to service 8 million clients, prioritizing mobile access and online services.

site_title: HDB extends application period for mega sales exercise to 10 days
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) is extending the application period for its mega sales exercise from 7 to 10 calendar days. The mega launch, combining September and November sales, will offer about 12,000 flats, including 7,000 Build-To-Order and 5,000 balance flats. All flat details will be available online, and buyers are advised to view the information online rather than rush to the HDB Hub to apply. The mega launch will be held in the second half of this month, allowing more buyers to benefit from recent new policies and expanded options.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Zeti says ringgit is 'significantly undervalued' amid growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz says the ringgit is "significantly undervalued" and risks to economic expansion are low due to strong exports and a surplus in the current account. Despite a 20% decline in the currency this year, Zeti believes the ringgit will recover when the US Federal Reserve normalizes interest rates and domestic issues are resolved. She notes that investors have already anticipated the Fed rate increase and have largely priced it in.

site_title: Governments must deal with ideology behind terrorism too: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to address the ideology behind terrorism, not just those who carry out acts, at the G20 Summit. He advocated for governments to engage with community leaders to build trust and confidence, and for international cooperation to raise the security bar for terrorists. Lee acknowledged that this is not a long-term solution to the problem, but rather a means to bolster vigilance against terrorism.

site_title: Paris attacks shake up US elections
summary: The Paris attacks have shifted the focus of the US presidential election from domestic economic issues to foreign policy and national security. The Democratic candidates, Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders, and Martin O'Malley, initially planned to focus on economic issues but were forced to adjust their debate agenda in response to the attacks. The Republican candidates, including Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, are capitalizing on the shift in attention to emphasize their tough stance on national security and terrorism. The attacks have also led to criticism of President Barack Obama's handling of the Middle East and the rise of the Islamic State.

site_title: Asia: Stocks wobble after Wall Street hit by crude slump
summary: Asian stocks wavered on Thursday after a sharp drop in US crude prices and weaker commodity prices. The US crude futures rose 0.4% to $43.09 a barrel, stabilizing after tumbling 3% overnight. Japan's core machinery orders rose 7.5% in September, but the Nikkei stock index fell 0.2%. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was slightly down, and the dollar index remained steady at 98.829.

site_title: Paris attacks reveal Belgium as the heart of European terror
summary: Belgium has emerged as a hub for European terrorism, with the recent Paris attacks highlighting the country's connection to radicalized individuals. Seven people in Brussels have been detained in connection with the Paris attacks, including two Frenchmen who lived in Belgium. Authorities suspect that militants consider Belgium a more permissive environment, allowing them to move undetected. The country's proximity to France and its porous borders have made it a haven for terrorists, with many returning from Syria to carry out attacks. Belgian authorities are stepping up security and intelligence-gathering efforts to combat radicalization.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia's Q1 profit bolstered by partial disposal of former subsidiary
summary: Parkson Retail Asia reported a net profit of S$49.5 million for Q1FY16, up from S$6.86 million, driven by a S$46 million gain from the partial disposal of Parkson Hanoi Co. Revenue fell 15.7% year-over-year to S$92.69 million. Earnings per share increased to 7.3 Singapore cents. The company's Q1 results were in line with lower gross sales proceeds.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Diesel - still delightful
summary: The BMW 116d is a fun-to-drive hatchback that marks the German luxury brand's return to COE Category A, a segment it exited due to engine output limit changes. The 116d features a 1.5-litre turbodiesel engine producing 116 hp, low-end torque, and an 8-speed automatic transmission. It boasts excellent driving position, balance, and stability, making it a great entry-level BMW model. With a price tag of S$138,800 (with COE), the 116d offers a premium driving experience despite its lower price point.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.84 points to 1663.48. Losers outnumbered gainers 83 to 73, and volume reached 31.3 million lots worth RM9.8 million.

site_title: Julius Baer's maiden Singdollar perpetual bonds snapped up
summary: Julius Baer's maiden S$450 million Basel III-compliant perpetual Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds were oversubscribed, with orders reaching S$1.8 billion. The bonds were priced at 5.9%, down from the initial 6.375% due to strong demand from private bank investors. This marks the highest-yielding AT1s in the SGD bond universe, with Moody's giving Julius Baer a rating of A3 and the expected issue rating of Baa2.

site_title: Strong 6.9-magnitude quake hits Chile: USGS
summary: A 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of central Chile late Tuesday, with the epicenter near Coquimbo. The USGS reported the quake initially had a magnitude of 6.6, but corrected it to 6.9. There was no immediate tsunami alert. Chile has experienced frequent earthquakes, including a 2010 quake that killed over 500 people and a September 2015 quake that left 15 dead and over 16,000 homeless. The country lies on the "Ring of Fire," prone to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

site_title: Apple announces 1,000 new jobs in Ireland as EU tax ruling nears
summary: Apple announces 1,000 new jobs in Ireland as the European Union nears a decision on whether the company's tax deal with the country is unfair state aid. The deal, which allows Apple to shelter profits worth tens of billions of dollars, is due to be reviewed after Christmas. This move comes after the EU accused Ireland of breaching international tax rules. The additional jobs are part of Apple's efforts to boost its presence in Ireland, where it declares much of its overseas profit for tax purposes.

site_title: Future gazing
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group CEO Nobuyuki Hirano is optimistic about Japan's economic future, citing Abenomics' success in boosting business earnings, stock prices, and employment. However, he acknowledges the challenges of an ageing society, shifting consumer trends, and the need for demographic reform. Hirano supports immigration as a solution to Japan's low birth rate, suggesting a focus on highly-skilled talent in various fields. He also emphasizes the importance of increasing women's and seniors' participation in the workforce. Despite Abenomics' achievements, Hirano notes that consumption remains sluggish, and the demographic issue must be addressed to ensure sustainable growth.

site_title: Air Berlin CEO aims to double share of business travel
summary: Air Berlin's new CEO, Stefan Pichler, aims to double its share of business travel within the next three years. The airline plans to achieve this by adding more long-haul routes and increasing its market presence in the business sector. Air Berlin will reduce frequencies on less profitable routes and refurbish its A330 planes with new business class seats to attract more business customers. The airline expects to boost operating profits by 310 million euros by the end of 2018. Pichler is working to bring costs down and restore profitability after years of losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down on afternoon selling pressure
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.6% on Monday, closing at 22,726.77, due to afternoon profit-taking and declines in technology stocks, including Tencent ahead of its earnings release. The China Enterprises Index also dropped 0.5%. The losses outweighed an initial boost from the successful listing of China International Capital Corp. Total trading volume was 1.6 billion shares.

site_title: McDonald's will not put properties into Reit, CEO says
summary: McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook announced that the company will not spin off its properties into a real estate investment trust (Reit), citing that the potential upside was not compelling and the risks were too great. This decision comes as part of the company's plans to lure back diners, cut costs, and shift restaurant ownership to franchisees, while also returning more cash to investors. Easterbrook stated that this decision was made after significant deliberation and is in the best interest of shareholders.

site_title: Eurozone decides not to release new money for Greece
summary: Eurozone finance ministers will not release a 2 billion euro tranche of loans to Greece due to disagreements on reforms, particularly protection for poorer families facing home repossessions. A deal could be struck by the end of this week. Disagreements also persist on tax measures, including late repayment of overdue taxes and a tax on private education. Greek officials stress the need for a political decision to protect primary residences and prevent evictions.

site_title: High chance of Dec hike in US interest rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve has increased the likelihood of a December interest rate hike, with a 85% chance of a rate hike according to Federal funds futures market. The strong October US employment report and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments on rate hikes have driven up bond yields, leading to a shift in investment thinking from bad economic news being good for stocks to good economic news being good for stocks. This may lead to volatility in markets as players adjust to a world of higher US interest rates.

site_title: Eurozone ministers give Greece one more week for reforms
summary: Eurozone finance ministers have urged Greece to deliver on overdue reforms within a week to secure crucial funds from its bailout. The deadline comes after Athens narrowly avoided a euro exit months ago. The reforms, including modernizing the economy and raising taxes, are crucial for unlocking the disbursement of 2 billion euros to recapitalize the Greek banking sector. Greek officials say talks confirmed a positive climate, but disagreements remain over home foreclosure rules.

site_title: Saizen Reit's Q1 attributable income down 53.1% on fair-value loss
summary: Saizen Reit posted a 53.1% drop in attributable income to 204.1 million yen in Q1 2016, primarily due to a net fair-value loss on financial derivatives and investment properties. A 69 million yen loss on investment properties and a 112.2 million yen loss on forward contracts contributed to the decline. Gross revenue edged up 0.3% to 976.6 million yen, while net property income fell 1.1% to 667.7 million yen. The Reit has proposed the divestment of all its residential properties for 44.66 billion yen.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.95% lower on profit taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.95% lower on Tuesday following a weak session on Wall Street and amid profit taking after a surge the previous day. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 185.69 points to 19,457.05.

site_title: Fed faces challenge of how to justify possible slowdown in jobs growth: Bullard
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard faces a challenge in convincing investors of a potential interest rate hike in December, as a slowdown in job growth may be misinterpreted as a sign of a broader economic downturn. Bullard argues that monthly job growth averaging over 200,000 is unsustainable and that a slowdown to 100,000-125,000 per month is natural and would not indicate poor macroeconomic performance. The Fed is struggling to balance its communication with market expectations, and Bullard suggests a new campaign may be needed to convey this message.

site_title: Asia: Markets eye US jobs report, Nikkei riding high
summary: Asia's markets closed on a mixed note, with Tokyo's Nikkei index reaching its highest level in over two months due to Japan Post's successful initial public offering. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong remained down, tracking a lower finish on US Wall Street, which was awaiting the US jobs report that could indicate a Fed interest rate hike. Chinese firms rallied on hopes for economic reforms, while Standard Chartered shares slumped after a Fitch downgrade.

site_title: S'pore is China's largest investor
summary: Singapore has become China's largest investor country, with investments totaling US$5.8 billion in over 700 projects in 2015. This marks the second consecutive year that Singapore has surpassed China as the largest foreign investor. Singapore is also China's largest investment destination in Asia, with bilateral trade in goods increasing by 5.4% to S$121.5 billion in 2014. The strong business sector interaction between Singapore and China is expected to continue, driven by China's focus on expanding urbanization and boosting domestic consumption, presenting new opportunities for Singapore companies in sectors such as healthcare, education, and environmental services.

site_title: BNP Paribas to shut Hong Kong 'dark pool' business: sources
summary: BNP Paribas is shutting down its Hong Kong 'dark pool' business, BNP Internal Exchange (BIX), due to new regulations set to increase costs and risks for such platforms. The move comes as the bank prepares for the new rules, which will take effect next month. BNP's decision was made in response to the increased costs and regulatory hurdles associated with operating a 'dark pool' in Hong Kong. The bank declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: China's vulnerability in the South China Sea
summary: China's actions in the South China Sea are driven by a desire for security, stemming from its perceived vulnerability in nuclear defense and dependence on open sea routes for energy supply. The area is crucial for China's energy needs, with 85% of its oil imports passing through the Malacca Straits, a potential choke point. China's construction of artificial islands and assertive behavior in the region are attempts to create "facts on the ground" and secure its energy supply. To de-escalate tensions, the US and other claimant states should appeal to China's willingness to negotiate, provide assurances on energy security, and support smaller claimant states.

site_title: Fed rate hike 'makes sense': US reserve bank president
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams suggests a December rate hike is "the next step" due to nearing full employment and rising inflation. Williams believes inflation will return to the 2% target and supports gradual rate increases to normalize policy, citing factors like weak oil prices and a strong dollar will soon ebb. This stance aligns with Fed Chair Janet Yellen's desire for gradual rate hikes. The comments boost traders' bets on a rate increase and follow a strong October jobs report that pushed the jobless rate to 5%, close to full employment.

site_title: Online firms fail on privacy, data protection: survey
summary: Major online firms, including Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft, received poor ratings for protecting users' privacy and freedom of expression in a study by the Ranking Digital Rights project. Only six of the 16 companies scored above 50%, while seven scored below 25%. The report found that most companies failed to disclose information about data collection and sharing, and that some laws and regulations hinder their ability to respect users' rights. The study aims to promote corporate transparency, empowering users to make informed decisions about their online activities.

site_title: Stable, sustainable property market in interest of all: Heng
summary: Singapore's property market is stable and sustainable, according to Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat, but developers still face challenges from government cooling measures. The measures, which include a 10% Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty on land cost, have led to oversupply, price reductions, and rising construction costs. Developers must sell 100% of unsold units by 2017 to qualify for remission of the duty. The government has taken a medium-term approach to managing land supply, using prudential measures to promote market sustainability.

site_title: Home once owned by mobster put on market for at least US$5.5m
summary: The 75 Bluff Road estate in Fort Lee, NJ, once owned by infamous mobster Albert Anastasia, is up for auction with a minimum price of $5.5 million. The 25-room, 1947 Mission-style mansion, built on a hill overlooking Manhattan, features a sprawling basement, vintage kitchens, and marble fireplaces. The property has a complex history, having been owned by various notable figures, including comedian Buddy Hackett and trucking tycoon Arthur Imperatore Sr. Despite some signs of wear, the estate's intact architecture and stunning views make it a unique and potentially valuable offering.

site_title: China aims to launch Hong Kong-Shenzhen stock connect before year-end: PBoC
summary: China aims to launch a trading link between Hong Kong and Shenzhen stock markets before the end of the year, according to People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan. The link, which allows foreign investors to access mainland-listed stocks, was technically prepared in August. The launch follows Hong Kong and Shanghai's landmark trading scheme launched late last year, which enabled direct access to mainland stocks. The scheme is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: Indonesia offers incentives to investors in special economic zones
summary: Indonesia's chief economy minister, Darmin Nasution, announced incentives for investors in special economic zones, including tax holidays of up to 25 years and exemptions from the negative investment list. Foreigners can also own property and import raw materials without paying value-added tax. This move aims to stimulate economic activity in the country's periphery. Indonesia's economy grew 4.73% in the third quarter, slightly faster than the previous quarter but below expectations. The country currently hosts eight special economic zones, including those for palm oil, petrochemicals, and tourism.

site_title: High cost hampers Japan's lofty 'hydrogen society' vision
summary: Japan's ambitious "hydrogen society" vision, aimed at powering homes and fuel-cell cars with emissions-free energy, is hindered by high costs and convenience issues. Despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's hopes to meet modest emissions targets, production of hydrogen cars has lagged behind demand, with Toyota's Mirai model costing nearly double a comparable electric car. Heavy regulations on building fuelling stations and high production costs are major barriers, with only 100,000 houses currently powered by hydrogen technology. The government aims to equip 5.3 million residences by 2030, but progress is slow.

site_title: Guarded hopefulness
summary: Bloomberg News' editor-in-chief John Micklethwait has adapted to the challenges of the digital age with a sense of "paranoid optimism," recognizing the importance of staying ahead in a rapidly changing media landscape. After 27 years at The Economist, Micklethwait has seen media giants falter in the face of online migration. He is now navigating the shift to digital platforms and expanding coverage in Asia's growth story, with a focus on staying agile and relevant in the face of emerging trends and technologies.

site_title: Expansion plans
summary: BT to expand product line, tapping market opportunities and meeting changing customer needs. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz takes control of Royal Healthcare, planning to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. NUS researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus, cutting staff and putting the building up for sale.

site_title: Inflation target still eludes Draghi halfway through his ECB term
summary: Mario Draghi, European Central Bank president, is halfway through his eight-year term, but has yet to meet his inflation target of 2%. Despite implementing record-low interest rates and asset purchases, inflation has averaged 1.2% over the past four years. Draghi's activist approach has been met with skepticism and hostility, particularly in Germany, where he faces criticism for his monetary policies. He is now considering another round of easing in December, but faces challenges from a fragile recovery, a strong euro, and energy price risks.

site_title: Policy U-turns needed for many issues in Singapore
summary: Singapore's public transport system may need policy U-turns to address reported inefficiencies and profit-making orientation. Kishore Mahbubani suggested re-nationalizing public transport services as an alternative. Additionally, Mahbubani emphasized the need for "political courage" to make policy changes. The article also highlights various critical issues in Singapore, including companies' struggles with layoffs, the evolving climate investing approach by Temasek, and the global implications of Donald Trump's foreign policy.

site_title: Director activity remains low, buyback value jumps
summary: Director activity in Singapore remained low, with 25 purchases worth S$1.06 million and 5 disposals worth S$1.15 million recorded between Oct 26 to 30. Buyback activity was also low, with nine companies making 24 repurchases worth S$10.5 million. Key director purchases included Sunningdale Tech's executive chairman Koh Boon Hwee, who bought 53,000 shares at 84.5 cents each, and iX Biopharma's independent director Ko Kheng Hwa, who purchased 176,000 shares at 30.4 cents each. Acquisitions were also made by Super Group and Venture Corporation, with Super Group purchasing 488,000 shares at 92 cents each.

site_title: Profit and sustainability go hand in hand
summary: Ardentec, a Taiwanese semiconductor testing firm, has successfully raised revenue while maintaining low carbon emissions. The company implemented environmental initiatives, such as a smart water treatment system and LED lighting, which saved 56,000 kWh of electricity and 113,000 kWh of electricity annually. Ardentec's revenue increased 11% to S$29 million, and the company received a Sustainable Business Award for its efforts. CEO David Hsiao believes that profit, people, and planet can co-exist, and that sustainable business is a profitable business.

site_title: Stocks around the world drop on China factory data
summary: Stocks worldwide dropped on Monday, November 2, 2015, due to a contraction in China's manufacturing sector, which fell to 48.3 in October, below the expansion threshold of 50. Turkish assets surged after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's AK Party won a majority, while Asian shares and US futures declined. The yen and euro advanced on concerns over China's economy, which is expected to slow further, with investors watching US employment reports for potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Fragrance's Q3 profit up 14.3%, revenue falls
summary: Fragrance Group's Q3 net profit rose 14.3% to S$27.8 million, despite a 52.0% drop in revenue to S$64.0 million. The decline was mainly due to a fall in property development revenue. The company has sold almost all its residential units in Singapore and is working on redevelopment plans for its Australian portfolio. Earnings per share remained steady, and the net asset value increased to 14.9 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

The new seven-storey industrial building in Geylang,owned by property developer Fragrance Group.Fragrance Group's net profit for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2015, rose 14.3 per cent to S$27.8 million even as its revenue dropped 52.0 per cent, from S$133.3 million to S$64.0 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down 2.10% on weak China data
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index dropped 2.10% on Monday, ending a three-day winning run, due to weak Chinese manufacturing data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 399.86 points to 18,683.24. This move fueled fears about China's economy, the world's second-largest. The broader Topix index also declined 2.00%. The market's decline followed a three-day winning streak, which was halted by the disappointing Chinese data.

site_title: World food prices up 3.9% in October: UN food agency
summary: World food prices rose 3.9% in October, driven by concerns over sugar and palm oil supplies, but remained 16% cheaper than last year, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization. This is the sharpest increase since July 2012. The FAO adjusted its 2015 cereal output forecast to 2.530 billion tonnes and raised its wheat output forecast for 2015/16 to 736.2 million tonnes.

site_title: MSCI to include China stocks listed abroad in EM indexes
summary: MSCI will include overseas-listed Chinese shares in its emerging market indexes, starting this month. Analysts estimate up to $70 billion will flow into these stocks over the next six months, increasing China's weight in the index to over 26%. The move aims to encourage foreign capital into China's financial markets, despite concerns over market distortion. Investors welcome the inclusion of US-listed tech giants like Alibaba and Baidu, which are more geared to China's domestic consumption. The decision could lead to mainland-listed companies being included in global equity portfolios in the future.

site_title: Silicon Valley granddaddy HP officially splits into two
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) splits into two entities, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc, after 77 years. HPE will focus on software and business services, while HP Inc will handle personal computer and printer operations. The move aims to revitalize the company, which has been in a defensive mode for several years, and adapt to the tech landscape's need for flexibility and nimbleness. The new entities begin trading independently on Monday.

site_title: Connecting the dots
summary: Star architect Soo K Chan is set to launch a real estate fund, potentially combining his career's series of dots. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, a low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, and Jack Ma's Ant is adding a stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe, while productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, and markets are rising despite concerns about the trade war and de-dollarisation.

site_title: Principal Garden sells 60% of units in initial launch
summary: UOL Group and Kheng Leong Company sold 60% of the 200 units at Principal Garden condominium, a 663-unit development in Singapore, following its initial launch on the first weekend. Units were priced above S$1,600 psf. The 70-30 joint venture is located near the Alexandra Park Connector and the Central Business District.

site_title: Oil slump continues to hit Rotary
summary: Rotary Engineering reported lower revenue and profit for the third quarter, with net profit of S$6.3 million and revenue of S$60.3 million, down 65% and 42% from the same period last year. Despite better margins, the company expects continued pressure on profits due to low oil prices. Gross margins improved due to better productivity and the completion of projects. The company's order book is currently at S$144 million, and it is actively pursuing business opportunities and strategic investments to add to its services.
